headline: Correction Officer Is Stabbed in Head by Rikers Detainee
abstract: The officer was seriously injured in the attack, which took place in the protective custody unit at Rikers, a union official said.
lead_paragraph: A city correction officer at the Rikers Island prison complex was seriously injured on Monday when a detainee stabbed him more than a dozen times in the back of the head, the correction officers’ union said in a statement.

headline: Game 3 of the World Series Is Postponed Because of Rain
abstract: The Houston Astros and the Philadelphia Phillies are tied at one game apiece. The series is scheduled to resume Tuesday, and each remaining game will be pushed back one day.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Game 3 of the World Series was postponed Monday because of rain, with the Houston Astros and the Philadelphia Phillies tied at one game apiece. The series is scheduled to resume Tuesday, and in place of eliminating the built-in travel day, each game will be pushed back one day.

headline: Rumor Has It …
abstract: Make some connections with Bruce Haight’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Rumor has it that this is the 61st puzzle constructed by Bruce Haight for The Times. That’s a lot of puzzles!

headline: Idaho Man Convicted in 1984 Murder of 12-Year-Old Colorado Girl
abstract: The long-unsolved kidnapping and killing of Jonelle Matthews haunted the community of Greeley, about 50 miles north of Denver.
lead_paragraph: A Colorado jury on Monday convicted an Idaho man of murder and kidnapping in the 1984 disappearance and death of a 12-year-old girl who was killed days before Christmas, a case that went unsolved for decades and haunted the tight-knit community of Greeley, Colo., where she lived.

headline: Prosecutor Announces Charges Against Suspect in Pelosi Attack
abstract: David DePape, who is accused of breaking into the San Francisco home of Speaker Nancy Pelosi, was charged with attempting to kidnap Ms. Pelosi and with assaulting a relative of a federal official.
lead_paragraph: David DePape, who is accused of breaking into the San Francisco home of Speaker Nancy Pelosi, was charged with attempting to kidnap Ms. Pelosi and with assaulting a relative of a federal official.

headline: Suit by Meadows Seeking to Block Jan. 6 Panel’s Subpoenas Is Dismissed
abstract: The decision does not necessarily mean the committee will get the information it is seeking.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Monday dismissed a lawsuit by Mark Meadows, the final chief of staff for President Donald J. Trump, that sought to block two subpoenas from the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack, including one to Verizon for Mr. Meadows’s phone and text data.

headline: 2-Minute Showers and a Flotilla of Gas Shipments: Europe Braces for Winter
abstract: Countries across the continent have taken extraordinary steps to decrease energy use and ramp up supply, moving swiftly away from their longtime primary provider, Russia.
lead_paragraph: A flotilla of tankers carrying liquefied natural gas have been parked in a maritime traffic jam off the coast of Spain in recent days, waiting to unload their precious cargo for Europe’s power grid. In Finland, where sweltering sauna baths are a national pastime, the government is urging friends and families to take saunas together to save energy.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 1, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 1, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about Giorgia Meloni, Italy’s new prime minister, and what her ascent has meant to her far-right followers misstated when the Italian Social Movement was first formed. It was 1946, not 1948.

headline: In Israel’s Election, the Judiciary Is on Trial
abstract: Everyone’s eyes are on Benjamin Netanyahu as Israelis head back to the polls. It’s the Supreme Court they should be most worried about.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Israel’s election this week is being touted as a new referendum on an old leader — former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is standing trial on corruption charges and is attempting yet another political comeback. But the country faces a much deeper, more worrisome concern: Israel’s judicial branch is on trial and with it Israel’s best hope for democracy.

headline: Putin Says Ukraine Doesn’t Exist. That’s Why He’s Trying to Destroy It.
abstract: The country has a profound story to tell.
lead_paragraph: How did people imagine Ukraine before Feb. 24, 2022? If pressed, some might have conjured mail-order brides and shaven-head gangsters roaming one big post-Soviet Chernobyl. But most probably didn’t think even that; instead, they didn’t imagine Ukraine at all. The country popped up on most people’s radar only in connection to Western political scandals and Russian war making. Few Westerners visited it, and those who did might have concluded — as one Western journalist confessed to me recently — that “Ukraine was just like Russia but without all the crap.”

headline: Three more grain ships set sail from Ukraine amid questions about their safety.
abstract: Three more ships carrying grain departed from Ukraine’s Black Sea ports on Tuesday, a day after President Vladimir V. Putin signaled that Russia would no longer ensure the safety of the cargo vessels, a message that underscored the perils facing a watershed agreement meant to help alleviate the global food crisis.
lead_paragraph: Three more ships carrying grain departed from Ukraine’s Black Sea ports on Tuesday, a day after President Vladimir V. Putin signaled that Russia would no longer ensure the safety of the cargo vessels, a message that underscored the perils facing a watershed agreement meant to help alleviate the global food crisis.

headline: Fourteen People, Including Three Children, Are Wounded in Chicago Shooting
abstract: The victims were attending a vigil near the city’s West Side when the shooting occurred, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen people, including a 3-year-old boy and two other children, were wounded in a drive-by shooting in Chicago on Monday night, the police said.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Skyrocketing inflation in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Consumer prices in the 19 countries that use the euro as their currency rose at a record annual rate of 10.7 percent in October, the European Commission reported yesterday.

headline: Word of the Day: omniscient
abstract: This word has appeared in 49 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word omniscient has appeared in 49 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 21 in “Who’s Playing Dungeons & Dragons These Days? The Usual Fans, and Then Some” by Amelia Diamond:

headline: When Picasso Created an Image of Notre-Dame, All in Glass
abstract: The “gemmail” — a glass mosaic — will go on the auction block with an estimate of at least $1 million.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at an unusual Picasso — it’s an all-glass image of the Notre-Dame cathedral. And with Election Day a week away, we’ll look at two races, including one for a House seat the Democrats have long dreamed of flipping.

headline: Red Poster
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: In Close, Crucial Governor’s Races, Poll Finds Sharp Split on Elections
abstract: In Arizona, voters are narrowly divided on whether to elect a prominent Trump-backed election denier. In Pennsylvania, they appear likely to reject a similarly minded Republican.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2022 midterm elections for the latest news and updates.

headline: The Fading Art of Preserving the Dead
abstract: A dwindling group of professionals is tasked with navigating the often fraught passage from life to death.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Here’s what’s at stake as Israelis cast their ballots.
abstract: As Israelis vote on Tuesday in their fifth parliamentary election in less than four years, former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is hoping to return to power, but polls are predicting another deadlock.
lead_paragraph: As Israelis vote on Tuesday in their fifth parliamentary election in less than four years, former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is hoping to return to power, but polls are predicting another deadlock.

headline: Why Does Israel Keep Having Elections?
abstract: A divided electorate and shifting alliances make for a delicate balance in the country’s voting outcomes and lawmakers’ ability to hold diverse blocs together.
lead_paragraph: Israel keeps returning to the polls primarily because voters remain evenly split on the question of whether Benjamin Netanyahu, the longest-serving Israeli prime minister, is fit to run the country while standing trial on corruption charges.

headline: Trevor Noah Brings ‘The Daily Show’ to Georgia
abstract: Noah kicked off a week of taping in Atlanta on Monday ahead of next week’s big elections.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: American Money Has Discovered Indian Cricket
abstract: Billion-dollar investment funds and N.F.L. ownership groups are among those angling for a foothold in the Indian Premier League. The returns, not the sport, are the draw.
lead_paragraph: In the decade since he founded the private investment firm RedBird Capital Partners, Gerry Cardinale has acquired stakes in sports properties as varied as Fenway Sports Group, the Yankees’ YES Network and the Italian soccer team A.C. Milan. One of his partners at RedBird, Alec Scheiner, previously worked as a vice president of the N.F.L.’s Dallas Cowboys, and later ran the Cleveland Browns.

headline: Long Line of Ladies
abstract: In Northern California, the Karuk people celebrate a girl’s first period in a coming-of-age ceremony.
lead_paragraph: In Northern California, the Karuk people celebrate a girl’s first period in a coming-of-age ceremony.

headline: Denmark Heads for Period of Uncertainty After Snap Election
abstract: With no clear coalition as of Tuesday night, the stage is set for a negotiation to form what analysts say will likely be a centrist government.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — Denmark on Tuesday voted in a snap general election, precipitated by anger over a government-mandated mink cull during the pandemic that led to accusations that top officials, including the prime minister, misled the public.

headline: What Are the Little Rituals That Keep You Going?
abstract: What routines, habits or practices do you do to stay grounded, happy and healthy?
lead_paragraph: What are the little things you do regularly that make you feel good, whether physically or mentally or both?

headline: In This Novel, You’ll Hear a Dead Person. Listen Carefully.
abstract: Jacqueline Bublitz’s debut, “Before You Knew My Name,” follows the parallel tracks of two women in New York City — one vital and vibrant, the other not so much.
lead_paragraph: Should men have a curfew? A British politician, Baroness Jenny Jones, proposed one for men after the London police advised women not to go out alone at night, in the wake of a high-profile killing. Baroness Jones intended the curfew as a provocative thought experiment: Imagine if cities belonged only to women after dark. After reading “Before You Knew My Name,” though, a curfew for men might seem downright reasonable.

headline: Can’t Sleep? Try Sticking Your Head in the Freezer.
abstract: In a new book, a sleep scientist offers tips for better rest — without reaching for a pill.
lead_paragraph: A good night’s sleep can make us more empathetic, more creative, better parents and better partners, according to Aric Prather, a psychologist at the University of California, San Francisco who treats insomnia and is the author of the new book “The Sleep Prescription.” Sleep can help us manage stress; it can make us competent and capable and better able to take on the day. But Dr. Prather says we too often view sleep as an afterthought — until we find ourselves frozen in the middle of the night, our thoughts racing, fumbling for rest or relief.

headline: My Greek Father’s Simple, Comforting Bowl of Chickpeas and Spinach
abstract: Revithia me spanaki is a connection to his legacy that I’m passing on to my son.
lead_paragraph: Not long before he died, my father, a doctor, announced that he would write a cookbook of Greek food. The news came as a shock. In England, where he’d spent most of his life, he had shown very little interest in cooking. In Greece, where he was born and where he returned to live much later, he was now fanatical about it. Research began. Tavernas were scouted and recipes recorded. One summer when I visited him, we went together to a restaurant on the island of Paros. There he had discovered fava, a pea or bean purée, yellow and buttery, that he thought was the best he’d ever had. He felt it deserving of a page in his book. I watched him photograph the dish from above, his shirt damp with midafternoon sweat, the cotton pulled tight against his belly, the fava set against a plain white tablecloth.

headline: In Northern Ireland During the Troubles, a Secret Romance
abstract: Louise Kennedy’s debut novel, “Trespasses,” considers the relationship of a Catholic woman and a Protestant man.
lead_paragraph: Recently, The New York Times published a photograph of children in Ukraine playing on a playground, surrounded by bombed-out buildings. I happened to see it the same week I was reading “Trespasses,” the brilliant, beautiful, heartbreaking debut novel by Louise Kennedy. I think the two will be forever linked in my mind.

headline: A Worrisome Pattern Re-emerges in Seeking Response From Republicans
abstract: A big challenge for some pollsters, nonresponse bias, appears to be back.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the 2020 election, most pollsters concluded that the polls probably underestimated Donald J. Trump because of something called nonresponse bias. In short, Mr. Trump’s supporters were less likely to respond to surveys than Joe Biden’s supporters, even among people who had the same demographic characteristics.

headline: Did your company just add salary information to job posts?
abstract: Tell us how a new law in New York City that requires employers to include salaries on job posts is affecting you.
lead_paragraph: Starting Tuesday, nearly all employers in New York City are required to include a salary range in their job posts, whether they advertise jobs on an online job board, in a job fair flier or on an internal bulletin board.

headline: The Gloriously Earthy Stink of Katherine Dunn’s Fiction
abstract: The posthumous publication of a new novel, six years after Dunn’s death, is a chance to celebrate the bawdy originality of the author of the cult hit “Geek Love.”
lead_paragraph: Katherine Dunn lived the hard-core life of a character in a Katherine Dunn novel. She was born in 1945 in Garden City, Kan., one of five siblings. Her father abandoned the family when she was a toddler. Her mother, an artist, remarried a mechanic, and the couple worked as migratory fruit pickers, drifting west until they eventually settled near Portland, Ore. As a teenager, too broke to buy drugs, Dunn later joked, she would sometimes try to catch bugs in order to get high. Dunn’s mother beat her; once, she threw a screwdriver that punctured Dunn’s calf, leaving a lifelong scar. When Dunn was 17, she left home for good. After a brief stint in jail for attempting to pass a bad check, she enrolled in Reed College. She fell in love, dropped out of Reed and traveled around the world before returning to Portland to raise her son, Eli. She cobbled together jobs, wrapping candy on assembly lines and posing nude for life-drawing classes. She also waited tables and bartended at dive bars where she dodged biker-gang fights. A patron once tried to slit her throat.

headline: Asian American Students Face Bias, but It’s Not What You Might Think
abstract: How “stereotype promise” shapes Asian Americans’ educations.
lead_paragraph: Affirmative action is on trial again. This time, opponents of race-conscious college admission practices are claiming that Asian Americans are hurt by it. The plaintiffs in Students for Fair Admissions Inc. v. President & Fellows of Harvard College, which presented oral arguments before the Supreme Court on Monday, allege that Harvard holds Asian American applicants to higher academic standards and rates them lower than other students on personal characteristics, such as fit, courage and likability. The proposed solution is to abandon race as a factor in admissions decisions.

headline: When a Girl’s First Period Calls for Celebration, Not Stigma
abstract: In “Long Line of Ladies,” the Karuk people celebrate a girl’s first period in a coming-of-age ceremony.
lead_paragraph: When I first got my period, I shied away from having my Kinaaldá, the Navajo coming-of-age ceremony for girls. While my community encouraged me to have my ceremony, I felt conflicted. On the one hand, my family was working to help young people learn and embrace traditional knowledge; on the other, I struggled to feel proud after years of seeing my culture misrepresented or dismissed by the Western world. If I could go back and talk to my 14-year-old self, I would tell her that the choice wasn’t hers alone — generations of people had been fighting to bring back Native traditions — and participating in this ceremony could help create healing for our people.

headline: Is It Better to Brush Your Teeth Before Breakfast or After?
abstract: It’s a hotly debated question in dentistry.
lead_paragraph: Q: Is it better to brush my teeth before or after breakfast? Some dentists say it’s better to brush before, some say after — which one is it?

headline: In the Political Talk Show Race, Outrage Is Winning
abstract: Americans don’t want to share a living room with one another. We prefer to live and be entertained in ideological encampments.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Noah recently surprised fans (and, according to some accounts, also Comedy Central management) when he announced plans to leave “The Daily Show.” His departure is one of many notable personnel changes in late-night television: James Corden will leave “The Late Late Show” next year, TBS canceled “Full Frontal With Samantha Bee,” and Desus and Mero broke up with each other and their hugely successful Showtime late-night show beloved by a diverse viewership of millennials.

headline: Jerry Saltz Plays It Uncharacteristically Safe
abstract: “Art Is Life” collects the art critic’s essays, reviews, interviews and more from the past two decades.
lead_paragraph: Outsiders might bash the art world for being a glitzy form of grift, a multibillion-dollar shell game or giant inside joke designed to make the uninitiated feel like rubes; but Jerry Saltz, the senior art critic for New York magazine, maintains a rosier view of the ecosystem to which he belongs. Bad actors notwithstanding, the real art world is “a great broken beautiful family of misfits,” according to one of the essays that earned him a Pulitzer Prize in 2018. “I refuse to believe that this spirit has left the art world, even though I recognize that this exquisite internal essence can be buried under loads of external bull——.” This devotional verve suffuses the articles, reviews, obits and interviews collected in “Art Is Life: Icons & Iconoclasts, Visionaries & Vigilantes, & Flashes of Hope in the Night.” Published between 1999 and 2021, they collectively form a love letter to the art that, for Saltz, makes all the wheeling and dealing worth putting up with.

headline: A Dystopian Fable About the Unshakable Borders of Class
abstract: In her new novel, “Saha,” Cho Nam-Joo follows a group of outcasts to examine the strict enforcement of social hierarchies.
lead_paragraph: In a world powered by hierarchies, what does it mean to not be “anyone or anything deserving of a category”? This is the question explored in “Saha,” the newest book by the Korean novelist Cho Nam-Joo.

headline: If You Raised Money After a Fire, Can You Spend It on a Vacation?
abstract: The Times’s Ethicist columnist on whether people have a say in how their donations are used after a crisis.
lead_paragraph: A young couple I know from our church were displaced from their apartment by a fire. All their furnishings and effects had to be replaced, and it was expensive for them to move pending the payment of their insurance benefit.

headline: Imprisoned on an Island, They Formed an Unlikely Arts Colony
abstract: In Simon Parkin’s riveting account, a shameful chapter in British history is also a testament to creativity and hope.
lead_paragraph: A German invasion of mainland Britain never felt closer than during that period between 1940 and 1945, when thousands of Nazi soldiers occupied the Channel Islands, holding captive the British citizens of Guernsey, Jersey and Sark in isolating and punitive conditions. But hundreds of miles farther north in the cold, gray waters of the Irish Sea, halfway between Cumbria and the coast of Northern Ireland, lies an island on which these authoritarian circumstances occurred in reverse.

headline: Tell Me Something Bad About Tulsa
abstract: RJ Young’s “Requiem for the Massacre” is more coming-of-age story than reckoning.
lead_paragraph: It’s not news that the United States has a long history of enslaving, torturing and killing Black people. A particular method, for lack of a better word, thrived in the late 19th and early 20th centuries — targeted efforts by white mobs to violently destroy Black communities. In 1919, there were so many attacks between May and August alone that the writer James Weldon Johnson termed it “The Red Summer.” In 1923, the community of Rosewood, Fla., was razed; and the list goes on, with far too many such tragedies to cite here. But since 2019’s HBO hit “Watchmen,” only one of these massacres has become a cultural shorthand: the Tulsa massacre of 1921, in which thousands of white people stormed the city’s Greenwood district and burned it to the ground, killing an estimated 300 African Americans and leaving thousands homeless. Say “Tulsa” now and people listen. But what happens when a massacre becomes a meme?

headline: Schumer Can Take the Insults, if It Helps Keep Democrats in Power
abstract: Senator Chuck Schumer, heavily favored to defeat his Republican challenger, Joseph Pinion, argued in a debate as much for his party as for his re-election.
lead_paragraph: For an hour on Sunday night, Senator Chuck Schumer endured insult after insult. He was called a liar and a failure. He was blamed for inflation, the decline of the shipbuilding industry, and death threats to Supreme Court justices. He was referred to as a modern-day Goliath, a “blind biblical giant,” a surprising description of a senator famed for both his spectacles and his slouch.

headline: Did an Unorthodox Therapist Drive a Woman to Suicide?
abstract: “Case Study,” by Graeme Macrae Burnet, is a novel of found documents detailing troubled lives and shifting identities.
lead_paragraph: To get to Primrose Hill from central London, you take the Tube to Chalk Farm Station, exit to your right toward a cafe and an off-license, and climb a path to an overpass above train tracks. The path is called, rather unassumingly, Bridge Approach, and a five-minute walk leads to Primrose Hill. I happened to live in these parts for three years, and I crossed the overpass twice a day most days. Just to the south is the Pembroke Castle pub, where Liam Gallagher of Oasis was once arrested, in 1998. Another neighborhood tippler, Kingsley Amis, favored the Queen’s at the corner of St. George’s Terrace, according to his biographer Zachary Leader, who printed his monthly tab. From my balcony I could see the phone box where Sylvia Plath would desperately call Ted Hughes at his lover’s flat in her last days. It is a quiet neighborhood, but one dense with intrigue and peopled by famous, messy and tortured artistic personages.

headline: I Wish the Jury Had Not Sentenced My Family’s Killer to Death
abstract: How a killer’s death sentence can bring new pain to families of victims.
lead_paragraph: This week, Nikolas Cruz, who killed 17 people in the 2018 shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., will be formally sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole, and the families of those who were killed or injured will again have a chance to speak about the irreparable harm done to them.

headline: Inflammatory Radio Ads From 2 Trump-Aligned Groups Are Airing in Battleground States
abstract: The ad campaigns, totaling over $6.5 million, talk about “anti-white bigotry” and transgender care for children.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest radio ad blitzes in the final stretch of the midterm elections is a provocative package of advertisements aimed at deepening cultural divides over transgender care for children and racial tensions.

headline: A Powerful Theory of Why the Far Right Is Thriving Across the Globe
abstract: The political scientist Pippa Norris explains how a ‘silent revolution in values’ is fueling the global rise of the right.
lead_paragraph: As we approach the 2022 midterms, the outlook for American democracy doesn’t appear promising. An increasingly Trumpist, anti-democratic Republican Party is poised to take over at least one chamber of Congress. And the Democratic Party, facing an inflationary economy and with an unpopular president in office, looks helpless to stop them.

headline: Food Prices Soar, and So Do Companies’ Profits
abstract: Some companies and restaurants have continued to raise prices on consumers even after their own inflation-related costs have been covered.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: A Carbone on Every Continent: Major Food Group Is Going Global
abstract: The restaurant hotshots have New York in their DNA and several opulent new places in Florida. But their sights are set on cities around the world.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Here’s something you don’t often see at a New York restaurant opening: showgirls. The old-school kind, in fishnets and stilettos, corsets and feathered headpieces. At the Oct. 18 opening party for Contessa, in the Design District, four of them squeezed through the crowd while another hung by her ankles from a high perch, pouring Prosecco from 10 feet up as guests lifted glasses to her.

headline: Truth Social’s Influence Grows Despite Its Business Problems
abstract: The right-wing social network faces two federal investigations and an uncertain financial future. But it has still managed to outpace its rivals.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Pandemic Generation Goes to College. It Has Not Been Easy.
abstract: Students missed a lot of high school instruction. Now many are behind, especially in math, and getting that degree could be harder.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: What Does the End of Yeezy Mean for the Sneakerverse?
abstract: Rampant speculation has entered the market.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: In a New Novel, Percival Everett Riffs Gleefully on 007
abstract: “Dr. No,” which borrows its name from an early James Bond story, features a math professor who’s recruited by a supervillain.
lead_paragraph: Was there superior technology in the 1960s for removing the smell of cigarettes from clothing or did James Bond’s tuxedo permanently reek? In rewatching “Dr. No,” the first Bond film, I couldn’t reconcile all that photogenic smoke with my strong intuition that Sean Connery always smelled fantastic.

headline: A 16th-Century French Chateau That Honors a Family’s Histories of Exile
abstract: For centuries, the owners of an ancestral estate have sought to secure within its walls the worlds they lost.
lead_paragraph: THE ACHE OF exile has animated many great works of art. Pablo Neruda published “Canto General,” his lacerating book of poems about living underground, in the wake of his 1948 expulsion from the Chilean Senate; Oscar Wilde produced the crystalline prose of “De Profundis” while banished to England’s Reading Gaol prison for sodomy. Being forced to flee from Germany to Paris to New York as the Nazis rose to power was the catalyst for the painter George Grosz’s 1944 masterpiece, “Cain, or Hitler in Hell.”

headline: From Nashville to Tupelo on the Natchez Trace Parkway
abstract: With no billboards or gas stations, a fall drive along this winding, verdant All-American Road, is a head-clearing journey, offering encounters with history, nature, music and more.
lead_paragraph: As I pulled away from the Loveless Cafe, near the northern end of the Natchez Trace Parkway, the rain clouds that had been brewing southwest of Nashville unleashed a shower over what, in the distance, looked to be tiny Bon Aqua, Tenn., where I once lived. There was a welcome touch of fall in the air, so I was willing to gamble on a little rain.

headline: Inquiry Scrutinizes Trump Allies’ False Claims About Election Worker
abstract: Prosecutors are seeking testimony from three people who took part in the pressure campaign against the worker, Ruby Freeman, after the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — One is a 69-year-old Lutheran pastor from Illinois. Another is a celebrity stylist who once described herself as a publicist for Kanye West. A third is a former mixed martial-arts fighter and self-described “polo addict” who once led a group called “Black Voices for Trump.”

headline: In Hunt to Solve ‘Fairy Circle’ Mystery, One Suspect Is Dismissed
abstract: Water competition, termites and poisons have all been credited with causing the formations in an African desert’s vegetation, but researchers say a new study discounts one of them.
lead_paragraph: The strange, barren spots pepper the vast Namib Desert, which stretches from southern Angola to northern South Africa. They are known as “fairy circles,” and for a natural phenomenon with such a whimsical name, scientific debates over their origins have been heated.

headline: The Democrats’ Last Stand in Wisconsin
abstract: With the G.O.P. in control of a majority of statehouses, Democrats are fighting for seats in battleground states. Is it too late?
lead_paragraph: Wisconsin’s 51st Assembly District lies in the southwest part of the state — part of the larger Driftless Area, so named because it was mysteriously spared the drift of the glaciers that flattened much of the Midwest during the last ice age. The resulting landscape is forested and hilly, arable but not easy to farm on an industrial scale. As a result, many of the farms in this region are still small and independently owned, which explains in part why the area is less reliably Republican than many of the state’s other rural regions. Presidential races in the 51st tend to move back and forth between the two parties.

headline: Southern California Minimalism with Old World Charm
abstract: An interior designer wanted to create a home where “everything gets put away at night” — and she succeeded. Sort of.
lead_paragraph: An interior designer wanted to create a home where “everything gets put away at night” — and she succeeded. Sort of.

headline: A Minimalist House for Clutter-Free Living (Despite the Kids)
abstract: A Southern California designer wanted to create a home where “everything gets put away at night” — and she succeeded. Sort of.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Heininger had long dreamed of designing a house in Manhattan Beach, Calif., where she could raise a family. So in 2017, when she and her husband, Taylor Heininger, began having children, they started hunting for a teardown close to the ocean.

headline: Film Club: ‘Svonni v. the Swedish Tax Agency’
abstract: What can we learn from the fight between an Indigenous Sami woman and a government bureaucracy?
lead_paragraph: “Svonni v. the Swedish Tax Agency” is a five-minute Op-Doc film that touches on themes of tradition, respect, bureaucracy and discrimination. It profiles Ida-Maria Svonni, a Sami woman fighting for her right to claim a tax deduction for the purchase of a dog. Why doesn’t the Swedish Tax Agency understand that her dog, Rikke, is an essential tool for reindeer herding and not simply a pet? To answer this question, the humorous short film reveals a larger cultural clash and the struggle to practice Sami culture in today’s Sweden.

headline: Twitter in the Time of Elon Musk
abstract: What comes next for the social media giant now that it’s under the stewardship of the wealthiest person in the world?
lead_paragraph: It was long awaited, and some doubted that it would ever come to pass, but last week, the tech billionaire Elon Musk officially took over Twitter.

headline: Libertarian Candidate Drops Out of Arizona Senate Race and Endorses Masters
abstract: “This is another major boost of momentum as we consolidate our support,” Blake Masters said.
lead_paragraph: The Libertarian candidate running for Senate in Arizona — who had threatened to play spoiler in the closely watched race — is dropping out and endorsing Blake Masters, the Republican nominee.

headline: Many States Omit Climate Education. These Teachers Are Trying to Slip It In.
abstract: Around the United States, middle school science standards have minimal references to climate change and teachers on average spend just a few hours a year teaching it.
lead_paragraph: In mid-October, just two weeks after Hurricane Ian struck her state, Bertha Vazquez asked her class of seventh graders to go online and search for information about climate change. Specifically, she tasked them to find sites that cast doubt on its human causes and who paid for them.

headline: Saudi Aramco Reports $42 Billion in Profit as Cash Rolls In for Oil Giants
abstract: Bumper earnings from Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, and BP were, nonetheless, a slight decline from the previous quarter.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, said on Tuesday that it had earned $42.4 billion in net income in the third quarter. The figure was more than double the nearly $20 billion that Exxon Mobil earned for the period.

headline: Uber’s Revenue Is Up 72 Percent From Last Year, but It Posts a Loss
abstract: The company had strong revenue growth but lost money in part because of its investments in other ride-hailing businesses.
lead_paragraph: Uber on Tuesday reported revenue growth exceeding expectations from Wall Street, suggesting that the company has continued to recover from a pandemic slump as drivers return to the platform. But it posted a net loss, in part because of its investments in other ride-hailing companies.

headline: Affirmative Action’s Future
abstract: The Supreme Court seems poised to end the policy.
lead_paragraph: Laws need support from the public or the courts to survive. Affirmative action seems to have neither.

headline: New Faces Celebrate Día de Los Muertos
abstract: We visited a job center for day laborers on Staten Island that was planning for two big events: graduation for a construction safety course, and a ceremony marking the Mexican Day of the Dead.
lead_paragraph: We visited a job center for day laborers on Staten Island that was planning for two big events: graduation for a construction safety course, and a ceremony marking the Mexican Day of the Dead.

headline: Elon Musk May Yet Meet Twitter Executives in Court
abstract: Disputes over compensation and firings, and potentially over layoffs, could push both sides into fresh legal battles.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk’s deal to buy Twitter may have closed, but his battle with the company’s board and executives seems to be barreling forward. After what DealBook hears was a bitter closing on Thursday, Musk is taunting Twitter and the law firm it worked with in its lawsuit against him, Wachtell Lipton, with the prospect of litigation, while trying to avoid paying top executives the golden parachutes they’re owed. It appears that fraught legal battles lie ahead, and it’s unclear whether Musk’s aim is to win or simply punish.

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Final Journey
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 2, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “It’s quite profound. Even after death claims the body, we’re going to beautify it in some way — like, death cannot win.”

headline: Scientists Are Gaining on R.S.V., a Persistent Threat to Children
abstract: Vaccines and treatments are in trials, but the virus remains a leading killer of infants worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Of the three respiratory viruses Americans are grappling with this winter, two — the coronavirus and the flu — are well-known threats. The third, respiratory syncytial virus, which already has sent thousands of children to hospitals, is a mystery to many.

headline: Bursting Into Dance: Gentlemen, Assume the Superhero Stance!
abstract: “Spirited,” a revisionist “Christmas Carol,” leads with tap, thanks to the choreographer Chloé Arnold and her team, Ava Bernstine-Mitchell and Martha Nichols.
lead_paragraph: The trailer for “Spirited” arrives feet first. Two silhouetted bodies trade syncopated riffs in a lively tap showdown. “It’s beginning to sound a lot like Christmas,” the title cards announce, before the dancers are revealed to be the film’s stars: Will Ferrell and Ryan Reynolds.

headline: Inside the Harvey Weinstein Rape Trial in Los Angeles
abstract: The trial, which began last month, is expected to last several more weeks.
lead_paragraph: Every day last week during the beginning of Harvey Weinstein’s rape trial, jurors, lawyers and spectators spilled out of elevators and onto the ninth floor of the hulking Clara Shortridge Foltz courthouse in downtown Los Angeles.

headline: Disney Tries Mixing Streaming With Shopping
abstract: The Walt Disney Company announced that it would experiment with offering Disney+ subscribers exclusive access to themed merchandise.
lead_paragraph: Can shopping make Disney+ even more of a must-have streaming service?

headline: Second Anonymous Woman Defends Claim That Walker Pressured Her for Abortion
abstract: An anonymous woman reiterated her claim that Mr. Walker, a nominee for Senate in Georgia, pressured her to have an abortion decades ago. The Times could not confirm the account.
lead_paragraph: An anonymous woman on Tuesday defended her claim that Herschel Walker, the Republican nominee for U.S. Senate in Georgia, pressured her to have an abortion nearly three decades ago after a yearslong extramarital relationship.

headline: A Bridge Offered Relief From Migrants’ Toil, Before Taking Their Lives
abstract: Cash compensation for victims’ families will do little to make up for the life, and economic hope, of migrants among the 134 killed in India.
lead_paragraph: At 18, Habibul Sheikh quit school and left his home in eastern India for the promise of a better life, beckoned to a bustling industrial town on the other side of the country.

headline: Christina Applegate Pours One Out for ‘Dead to Me’
abstract: Diagnosed with multiple sclerosis during filming of the show’s final season, Applegate was determined to finish the story. She said it was the hardest thing she’s ever done.
lead_paragraph: When Christina Applegate looks back, she can recognize the signs. Filming a dance sequence during the first season of the Netflix wine-mom dramedy “Dead to Me,” she found herself off balance. Later, her tennis game began to falter. At the time, Applegate, an actress with an aversion to special pleading, didn’t make excuses. She had to work harder, she told herself. She had to try again.

headline: Behind 3 Champions’ Smithsonian Portraits
abstract: Serena and Venus Williams and Ava DuVernay, and the artists who portrayed them, talk about their choices, which will be on view at the National Portrait Gallery.
lead_paragraph: Three strikingly personal and introspective new portraits of three famous women — the tennis champions Serena and Venus Williams and the filmmaker Ava DuVernay — go on view at the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery in Washington on Nov. 10 as part of the institution’s Portrait of a Nation Award.

headline: Takeoff, of Atlanta Rap Trio Migos, Shot Dead at 28
abstract: The rapper was killed in a shooting at a bowling alley in Houston overnight.
lead_paragraph: The rapper known as Takeoff, a subtle vocal technician and one-third of the chart-topping group Migos, whose singsong flow helped define Atlanta’s ever-evolving, influential rap sound, was shot and killed overnight outside a Houston bowling alley, the authorities said. He was 28.

headline: Where Russian Fire Pours Down, His Men Sneak Forward
abstract: The commander of a Ukrainian reconnaissance unit spearheading the counterattack in the southern region of Kherson explained how his team helped breach defenses he described as frighteningly dense.
lead_paragraph: KHERSON REGION, Ukraine — The explosions flashed bright red against the dimming landscape. Half a dozen mortar strikes in quick succession raised cones of lethal shrapnel and dirt. Black smoke curled above the trees.

headline: Bolsonaro Agrees to Transition, Two Days After Losing Brazil Election
abstract: Breaking his silence, President Jair Bolsonaro did not admit defeat or repeat his baseless claims about election fraud, but his administration signaled that the transfer of power would proceed.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — Two days after losing Brazil’s presidential election, President Jair Bolsonaro agreed to a transition of power on Tuesday, easing fears that the far-right leader would contest the results after warning for months that the only way he would lose would be if the vote were stolen.

headline: Lucian Freud, Stripped of Fame and Scandal
abstract: A major London exhibition asks viewers to put aside the details of the artist’s tumultuous life and concentrate on his paintings.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When the National Gallery staged a show of Gauguin portraits in 2019, it took pains to highlight aspects of the artist’s personal life: The writing on the entrance wall stated that he had “repeatedly entered into sexual relations with young girls, ‘marrying’ two of them and fathering children.” These aspects had barely been mentioned in previous Gauguin shows, and the museum was making amends.

headline: Martin Intensifies as Post-Tropical Storm but Poses No Threat to Land
abstract: The storm, which was moving over the central North Atlantic on Thursday, was expected to weaken over the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Martin became a post-tropical cyclone as it moved over the central North Atlantic Thursday, a day after strengthening into a hurricane. Forecasters said that while it was causing strong winds and hazardous seas it posed no immediate threat to land.

headline: How Brains Send a Signal That It’s Time to Vomit
abstract: In a study of mice, researchers worked out a neural pathway that could help researchers alleviate nausea symptoms from chemotherapy drugs.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who’s had a shady oyster or a mushroom soup that didn’t sit well remembers the ominous queasiness heralding impending bad times. Bacteria release toxins that start the body’s process of speedily evacuating the contents of the stomach. It’s a protective mechanism of sorts — getting rid of the invaders en masse is probably helpful in the long term, even if it’s unpleasant in the short. But it has remained something of a mystery how the brain gets the alarm signal, then sends another one to tell the stomach to initiate a technicolor yawn.

headline: Roberts Extends Freeze on House’s Attempt to Obtain Trump’s Tax Returns
abstract: The move further delays an oversight request by the House Ways and Means Committee from 2019 as the midterm election looms.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. issued an order on Tuesday to temporarily bar the Treasury Department from giving former President Donald J. Trump’s tax returns to a House committee, the latest move in a long-running dispute over whether Congress can gain access to them.

headline: Job Openings Rose in September Despite Higher Interest Rates
abstract: The labor market has remained stronger than expected even as the Federal Reserve has tried to get inflation under control.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s extreme shortage of job seekers worsened in September, the Labor Department reported Tuesday, after easing the previous month.

headline: On the Scene of a Russian Rocket Attack
abstract: The attack knocked pumps that drive running water to homes across Kyiv offline, leaving 80 percent of the city without water.
lead_paragraph: The attack knocked pumps that drive running water to homes across Kyiv offline, leaving 80 percent of the city without water.

headline: Alcohol Deaths Claim Lives of Working-Age Americans
abstract: A C.D.C. study estimates that, over five years, one in eight deaths of people ages 20 to 64 occurred because of alcohol-related injuries or illness.
lead_paragraph: An estimated one in eight deaths of Americans ages 20 to 64 in the years 2015-19 was the result of injuries or illness caused by excessive alcohol use, according to a new study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: A Surge of Overseas Abortion Pills Blunted the Effects of State Abortion Bans
abstract: New data suggests that abortion has declined about 2 percent in the U.S. since the end of Roe, accounting for people who traveled across state lines or ordered pills online.
lead_paragraph: As states banned or restricted abortion this summer, the number of American women ordering abortion pills from overseas jumped significantly — enough to offset most of the drop in legal abortions.

headline: What’s next for the Amazon?
abstract: The election is over. We talked to people on both sides of Brazil’s political divide about their expectations.
lead_paragraph: Environmentalists in Brazil are breathing a bit more easily after Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, who made climate a cornerstone of his campaign, won the country’s presidential election on Sunday.

headline: Barry Keoghan Doesn’t Mean to Be a Scene-Stealer
abstract: The Irish character actor has earned praise as a supporting player in movies like “The Banshees of Inisherin,” but he’s ready to be a star.
lead_paragraph: “The Banshees of Inisherin,” Martin McDonagh’s black comedy about longtime friends, Padraic (Colin Farrell) and Colm (Brendan Gleeson), who have a contentious falling out, has the shape of a classic two-hander. What’s strange is that its M.V.P. is neither of the leads but rather Barry Keoghan, as the slow-witted neighborhood boy Dominic, who steals every scene he’s in. Sprightly and erratic, with a hint of pathos behind an air of foolishness, he feels fully realized, and despite the limited screen time, Keoghan is vivid and moving.

headline: New York’s Hottest Club Is … the Bar at Moynihan Hall?
abstract: With weekly D.J.s and decent cocktails, the train station watering hole is attracting drinkers with no intentions of traveling.
lead_paragraph: Liane Emerson picked the place for her third date with Austin Bailey. She knew the Midtown bar was cool, but her date wasn’t so sure. “He thought it was weird,” she said.

headline: Day of the Dead in High Style
abstract: Vogue Mexico on Thursday hosted its third gala celebrating the holiday. “We want this event to be shared globally,” its top editor said.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The formula was familiar. It included invitations from Vogue, a carpet filled with celebrities, fashion designers and models dressed to the nines, and even a theme.

headline: A Hamptons Property Fight Over a Black Whaler’s Homestead
abstract: Property tussles in the moneyed enclaves of Long Island are nothing new, but the battle to preserve the homestead of Pyrrhus Concer raises questions of whose history gets to be honored.
lead_paragraph: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. — Though summer crowds have retreated from this exclusive enclave, one fixture of its landscape has lately become a year-round constant: a large white container truck parked on an overgrown lot by Agawam Lake.

headline: ‘This Is Our March 2020’: Children’s Hospitals Are Overwhelmed by R.S.V.
abstract: A drastic and unusually early spike in the respiratory infection is swamping pediatric units across the United States, causing long waits for treatment and worries about winter.
lead_paragraph: A pediatrician in Mount Zion, Ill., sent a video of a 6-month-old named Natalie to a colleague for advice: The infant’s belly was puffing and retracting with every pant as she struggled to breathe, her nostrils flaring and bubbles forming on her lips.

headline: When Everything Is Heavy, a Touch of Humor Can Help
abstract: Beyond making tough moments a little easier, cultivating levity is good for your health.
lead_paragraph: Wendi Aarons was writing at her local library when the sound of an angry voice made everyone look up. A patron, outraged over a book policy, vowed to take her child to another library and stormed off after berating the staff. The entire room was “so upset,” recalled Ms. Aarons, a humorist in Austin, Texas. “It was just this awful, uncomfortable silence.”

headline: Gael Greene, Who Shook Up Restaurant Reviewing, Dies at 88
abstract: She brought sass and sensuality to the job as a critic for New York magazine for four decades. She also helped create the charity Citymeals on Wheels.
lead_paragraph: Gael Greene, who reinvented the art of the restaurant review with sass and sensuality in four decades as New York magazine’s restaurant critic, died on Tuesday at her home in an assisted living facility in Manhattan. She was 88.

headline: On the scene of a Russian rocket attack.
Security Training Group Asks Musk to Rid Twitter of Antisemitism
abstract: An organization that helps secure Jewish facilities across North America said Twitter had an “antisemitism problem,” and asked its new owner to fix it.
lead_paragraph: The nonprofit organization Secure Community Network, which provides safety consulting and training for Jewish facilities across North America, wrote a letter on Monday to Elon Musk, Twitter’s new owner, imploring him to clamp down on antisemitic content that could endanger lives.

headline: Molyvos, Greek in Midtown West, Reopens in a New Location
abstract: Kwame Onwuachi’s restaurant debuts in David Geffen Hall; the Atoboy team unveils its Rockefeller Center spot; and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: After nearly 25 years on Seventh Avenue and 55th Street, this Greek restaurant has found a new, less sprawling home at the southern edge of the theater district, in the former Esca space. “We wanted something smaller,” said Nick Livanos, who owns the restaurant with family members, “and this gave us the opportunity.” Capacity is down to 65 seats from 220, in a spacious and airy room graced with stonework and a terrace for when the weather warms again. There’s still a wall of family photos — the Livanos family is from the village of Molyvos on the island of Lesbos — and another of painted plates from the island of Rhodes. The restaurant will continue to offer home-style fare, like stuffed peppers and meatballs along with a fairly typical Greek lineup, but what will not be available for the reopening are the grilled fish and lamb specialties. Gas has yet to be connected. “We are able to provide about 75 percent of our menu as it is,” Mr. Livanos said. Added to the menu and not derailed by the lack of fuel is a new section of raw, chilled and marinated dishes like Ionian hamachi crudo with anise carrot purée, ouzo-cured salmon, marinated sardines en croute and smoked Ioanian eel with a ouzo-blood orange glaze. The various spreads, salads, spanakopita, dolmades and moussaka remain on the menu.

headline: Julie Powell, Food Writer Known for ‘Julie & Julia,’ Dies at 49
abstract: She attempted to cook every recipe in a classic Julia Child cookbook and documented the effort in a popular blog that became a best-selling book and a hit movie.
lead_paragraph: Julie Powell, the writer whose decision to spend a year cooking every recipe in Julia Child’s “Mastering the Art of French Cooking” led to the popular food blog  the Julie/Julia Project, a movie starring Meryl Streep and a new following for Mrs. Child in the final years of her life, died on Oct. 26 at her home in Olivebridge, in upstate New York. She was 49.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Pippa Norris
abstract: The Nov. 1, 2022 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Pippa Norris. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Taylor Swift to Bring Eras Tour to Stadiums Next Year
abstract: The singer-songwriter described her planned concerts as “a journey through all of my musical eras of my career.”
lead_paragraph: For the first time in five years, Taylor Swift is going on tour.

headline: Corporate America Has a Message for the Fed About Inflation
abstract: If the Federal Reserve’s chair, Jerome H. Powell, and his colleagues look at company earnings reports, these themes might catch their eye.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials are battling the fastest inflation in four decades, and as they do they are parsing a wide variety of data sources to see what might happen next. If they check in on how executives are describing their companies’ latest financial results, they might have reasons to worry.

headline: ‘William Still’ Isn’t a Household Name. It Should Be.
abstract: Andrew Diemer’s “Vigilance” gives a freedom fighter his due.
lead_paragraph: When he died in 1902, The New York Times called him “the Father of the Underground Railroad,” a figure as celebrated for his dramatic rags-to-riches life story as his towering role in the abolitionist movement. Yet, a century after his death and 201 years after his birth, William Still’s is not a household name. With this compelling new biography, Andrew Diemer, an associate professor of history at Towson University, seeks to elevate the freedom fighter to the contemporary prominence he deserves.

headline: Nets Fire Coach Steve Nash
abstract: The Nets have struggled to a 2-5 start, and their star guard Kyrie Irving is under fire for promoting an antisemitic documentary.
lead_paragraph: The Nets fired Coach Steve Nash on Tuesday as the team struggled on the court and faced criticism for the off-court actions of the star guard Kyrie Irving.

headline: Once a G.O.P. Stalwart, Liz Cheney Hits the Trail for Democrats
abstract: Stumping for Elissa Slotkin in Michigan, Ms. Cheney had an urgent message for voters: “We all must stand and defend the republic.”
lead_paragraph: EAST LANSING, Mich. — As political speeches go, Representative Liz Cheney’s address to a packed gym here on Tuesday evening was hardly a barn burner. But her message was deeply serious, and the aim of her visit was extraordinary, for a Wyoming Republican: to re-elect a Michigan Democrat, Representative Elissa Slotkin.

headline: Former U.K. Health Secretary Gets a TV Gig, Then a Suspension
abstract: Matt Hancock, who was filmed in a steamy embrace with an aide, breaking strict Covid distancing rules, will appear on “I’m a Celebrity … Get Me Out of Here!”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Best known as the former British health secretary who quit after breaking Covid distancing rules when he was caught in a steamy embrace with an aide, Matt Hancock now has another claim to fame. He is joining the cast of a TV show whose previous contestants have been filmed eating insects and animal testicles.

headline: Prosecutors Look at Florida Election Protest as a Model for Jan. 6
abstract: The Justice Department is examining ties among the far-right Proud Boys, Roger Stone and others over their roles in 2018 “Stop the Steal” demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: President Donald J. Trump and other top Republicans were stoking claims that the election had been stolen, and their supporters were protesting in the streets. Members of the far-right group the Proud Boys and people close to Roger J. Stone Jr., including Representative Matt Gaetz, took part in the action as the crowd was chanting “Stop the Steal.”

headline: ‘God Forbid’ Review: An Affair With Political Implications
abstract: The Hulu documentary covers a high-profile affair involving a pool attendant and the prominent evangelical couple Becki Falwell and Jerry Falwell Jr.
lead_paragraph: “God Forbid: The Sex Scandal That Brought Down a Dynasty,” a Hulu documentary from the director Billy Corben, concerns a sensational, high-profile affair between Giancarlo Granda, a pool attendant at a luxury hotel in Miami Beach, Fla., and Becki Falwell, the wife of the prominent Republican evangelist Jerry Falwell Jr. — whom Granda claims participated in these relations as a silent voyeur. At the time, Falwell Jr. was the president and chancellor of one of the nation’s largest Christian colleges, Liberty University, and one of the best known evangelical supporters of former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Opinion Round Table: Is Diversity in the Modern Era on Trial?
abstract: Three panelists join Lulu Garcia-Navarro to discuss what happens if the Supreme Court ends affirmative action.
lead_paragraph: Three panelists join Lulu Garcia-Navarro to discuss what happens if the Supreme Court ends affirmative action.

headline: N.Y.C. Buildings Commissioner’s Phone Seized in Criminal Gambling Probe
abstract: Eric Ulrich, 37, a former councilman from Queens, was questioned Tuesday by investigators from the Manhattan district attorney’s office.
lead_paragraph: Investigators for the Manhattan district attorney questioned the New York City buildings commissioner as part of an illegal gambling investigation and seized his phone on Tuesday morning, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: The 2022 Holiday Gift Guide
abstract: What should you get for all the beloved but quirky, picky, fancy, practical or eccentric people in your life? Let our experts help.
lead_paragraph: What should you get for all the beloved but quirky, picky, fancy, practical or eccentric people in your life? Let our experts help.

headline: For Netanyahu’s corruption trial, a Jerusalem court is still surveying over 300 witnesses.
abstract: The Israeli electorate remains divided over the former prime minister, even as his continuing trial on corruption charges has mostly dropped out of the headlines.
lead_paragraph: Much like Israel’s political morass, which is largely a byproduct of Benjamin Netanyahu’s legal troubles, the corruption trial of the former prime minister has no clear end in sight.

headline: Elon Musk’s Twitter Faces Exodus of Advertisers and Executives
abstract: At least five Twitter executives have left in recent days, as one of the world’s largest ad companies said clients should pause spending on the social media platform.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter is facing an exodus of executives and skittish advertisers as Elon Musk and his advisers take control of the social media company, prepare to lay off employees and make changes to the product.

headline: Do You Have to Sign and Date Mail-In Ballots in Pennsylvania?
abstract: The state’s top election official has said ballots that are signed but not dated should still be counted if they’re returned by Nov. 8. But it’s probably a good idea to make sure to date it, anyway.
lead_paragraph: As the Republican National Committee awaits a ruling by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court over its challenge of undated mail-in ballots in the state, the partisan back-and-forth over whether ballots need to have handwritten signatures on them is creating uncertainty.

headline: A Clash Over Race and College Admissions
abstract: Readers discuss the affirmative action cases before the Supreme Court. Also: U.S.-Saudi relations; climate protests; a new cabinet position.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pleas for Help Went Unheeded for Hours in Deadly South Korea Crush
abstract: Transcripts of desperate emergency calls exposed the failure of the government response, and contradicted official claims about when the disaster was first reported.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — The first, desperate call for help, warning of people at risk of being “squashed to death,” came at 6:34 p.m. on Saturday — nearly four hours before the South Korean authorities have said they received the initial report of a crowd crush that would kill more than 150 people.

headline: Supreme Court Rules That Lindsey Graham Must Testify in Georgia Inquiry
abstract: The court’s order said the questioning allowed by lower courts was limited and subject to appropriate safeguards.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday refused to block a Georgia grand jury subpoena seeking testimony from Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, about his activities in the aftermath of the 2020 presidential election.

headline: Why Do People Who Don’t Like Politics Hold the Fate of the Country in Their Hands?
abstract: In our flawed system, those who pay very little attention to our politics hold decisive power.
lead_paragraph: It’s almost Election Day, and once again, the party that wins the midterms will likely be determined by swing voters — a small but critical slice of the electorate that, despite the polarization of U.S. politics, is still open to voting for Democrats or Republicans.

headline: Elon Musk’s Biggest Problem on Twitter May Be Its Advertisers
abstract: His provocative behavior online could spell trouble for Twitter’s biggest revenue source.
lead_paragraph: Twitter is free for users (for now, at least) because of advertising.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Love Drama’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: After I fell down the stairs as a toddler, I became very timid. Hoping to expand my comfort zone, my parents signed me up for a baby gymnastics class, enlisting my grandfather to take me. Week after week, he sat with me on the sidelines. I never got the courage to join the group, and he never pushed me. As good as it feels to grow, sometimes it feels better to know someone accepts you just as you are. I’m still fairly timid as an adult. My grandpa passed last year, but I carry the feeling of his unconditional love. — Sam Aboody

headline: Key Witness Has Covid, Disrupting Trump Organization Trial After One Day
abstract: Jeffrey S. McConney, the company’s controller, had coughing fits on the stand. The judge said the trial would likely resume Monday, but that many in the courtroom were at risk.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey S. McConney, the controller of Donald J. Trump’s family business and the first witness in the trial of the company, tested positive for Covid-19 on Tuesday, delaying the long-awaited proceeding and driving home the difficulties of holding trials at a time when the disease remains prevalent.

headline: Top Democrats Question Their Party’s Strategy as Midterm Worries Grow
abstract: Leading lawmakers and strategists are openly doubting the party’s kitchen-sink approach, saying Democrats have failed to unite around one central message.
lead_paragraph: Top Democratic officials, lawmakers and strategists are openly second-guessing their party’s campaign pitch and tactics, reflecting a growing sense that Democrats have failed to coalesce around one effective message with enough time to stave off major losses in the House and possibly decisive defeats in the tightly contested Senate.

headline: A Nation of Quitters
abstract: What not-so-quiet quitting means for the economy.
lead_paragraph: You know you’re a serious economics nerd when you’re waiting on pins and needles for the latest JOLTS — Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey — results. Well, I am and I was. As it turned out, there wasn’t much news in the report released on Tuesday. But there has been a lot of news over the past few months, most of it good.

headline: Suspect in Pelosi Attack Had Other Targets, Authorities Say
abstract: The man accused of breaking into the home of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and assaulting her husband told the police that he also planned to confront other state and federal politicians.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After an intruder broke into the San Francisco home of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and bludgeoned her husband with a hammer, leaving him unconscious for three minutes as he lay in a pool of blood, the attacker told the police that he had other targets: a local professor and several prominent state and federal politicians.

headline: Restaurant Review: Claud, a Basement Dining Room With Much Higher Aims
abstract: This small, French-influenced restaurant is one of the most impressive places to hit the East Village in several years.
lead_paragraph: For some people, a bad table is one where nobody can see them. For others, it’s one where everybody can. In my book, a table is bad when it distracts you from settling down and paying attention to the meal.

headline: 2 Newark Police Officers Shot While Responding to 911 Call, Officials Say
abstract: Their injuries were not life threatening. The suspected shooter remained at large on Tuesday evening.
lead_paragraph: Two uniformed police officers were shot on Tuesday afternoon in Newark, the largest city in New Jersey, as they responded to a 911 call about a man wanted for a separate shooting there last week, law enforcement and state officials said.

headline: ‘The Unbelieving’ Review: Life After Faith
abstract: In a probing new play from the Civilians, based on interviews from the book “Caught in the Pulpit: Leaving Belief Behind,” current and former members of the clergy grapple with the reality of losing their religion.
lead_paragraph: For Adam, not his real name, change started with curiosity and critical thinking. A Church of Christ minister and a creationist, he came to realize that his worldview was sheltered, so he set out to educate himself.

headline: A Diverse Supreme Court Questions the Value of Diversity
abstract: Since 1978, the sole justification for race-conscious admissions has been educational diversity. The rationale’s days may be numbered.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over five hours of Supreme Court arguments on Monday on the fate of affirmative action in higher education, the justices and the lawyers arguing before them mentioned diversity more than 200 times.

headline: A Short Guide to Restaurant Thanksgiving
abstract: Don’t feel like cooking? Not a problem, if you plan ahead.
lead_paragraph: The countdown to Thanksgiving has officially begun. And while most people gather at a loved one’s house for dinner (4 p.m. or bust!), a brave, avant-garde few forgo the headaches and the dishwashing and their worst relatives, choosing instead to leave the work to the professionals.

headline: Alien Superstar
abstract: Wesley Morris and J Wortham kick off a new season of “Still Processing” by grappling with the complicated questions of Jordan Peele’s “Nope.”
lead_paragraph: J Wortham and Wesley Morris are back, just in time for Scorpio season. Ever since they watched Jordan Peele’s latest film, “Nope,” together over the summer, they haven’t been able to stop talking about it. The film stars Daniel Kaluuya and Keke Palmer as siblings whose family horse ranch is threatened by an otherworldly creature. But instead of escaping or destroying the monster, they are determined to take a picture of it. Why is proof so important? And why do they assume no one will believe their lived experience?

headline: ‘Rip It Up!’ A Simple Exercise to Connect Classroom Learning to the Outside World
abstract: With this hands-on, interactive activity, a professor challenges his students to find a New York Times article that relates to their leadership class — by tearing apart the paper.
lead_paragraph: This idea was submitted by Todd Cherches, who is an adjunct assistant professor of leadership at New York University and a lecturer on leadership at Columbia University.

headline: Canada Aims to Add 1.45 Million Immigrants by 2025
abstract: The policy would increase immigration one week after the country’s census agency announced that Canada had set a new milestone in immigration.
lead_paragraph: With nearly one million job vacancies across the country, Canada is turning more squarely toward foreigners to address its labor shortage and has set record-breaking immigration targets for the coming three years.

headline: Trump and DeSantis Plan Dueling Florida Rallies as Rivalry Builds
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump and Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, who is viewed as his most likely political challenger, planned competing campaign events.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s final run of midterm campaign rallies includes stops in Ohio and Pennsylvania, both key Senate battlegrounds. But a third event in Florida, where Republicans are heavily favored, will instead highlight the party’s political tensions as it looks to the 2024 presidential election.

headline: Engaging or Enabling an Autocrat? Colombian Leader Visits Venezuela.
abstract: Colombia’s new president met with his Venezuelan counterpart, a milestone in the move by leftist leaders in Latin America to ease the isolation of Nicolás Maduro’s government in Caracas.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — It was a meeting that just a year ago would have been nearly unthinkable.

headline: The Facts About the Attack on Paul Pelosi, According to Prosecutors
abstract: The attack has caused alarm about the threat of violence to elected officials, and has also become the focus of baseless conspiracy theories.
lead_paragraph: The attack on Paul Pelosi, the husband of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, has not only raised alarm about the threat of violence to elected officials and their families, but also become the focus of baseless conspiracy theories propagated by a litany of Republicans and conservatives.

headline: The Visual Artist Who Thinks of Herself as a Dancer or an Aviator
abstract: At 93, June Leaf is still fascinated by bodies and machines in motion, and still working every day.
lead_paragraph: Over a career spanning more than seven decades, the 93-year-old artist June Leaf has stubbornly resisted art-world trends and easy categorization. In her paintings, drawings and sculptures, she describes a dreamlike world of bodies and machines in motion: people dragging themselves up staircases, a winged woman whose torso is the frame of an antique sewing machine, figures painted on a fabric scroll that can be turned with a hand-built crank. “I think of myself as a dancer making art,” Leaf said in a recent interview at her home in New York. “Or an aviator making art.” She recalled, as a teenager in Tucson, Ariz., seeing a performance by the mime artist Angna Enters, in which “she danced and painted on the stage. I remember thinking, ‘That’s what I’m going to do.’”

headline: Bernard Rosen, Budget Brain for Four New York City Mayors, Dies at 91
abstract: He knew how to find hidden pots of money. “There wasn’t a budget director in the last 50 years who didn’t rely on Bernie,” one of his acolytes said.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Rosen, the dependable first deputy budget director who advised four New York City mayors on how to close looming deficits by scraping together tens of millions of dollars here and tens more there, died on Oct. 22 in Queens. He was 91.

headline: U. of Florida Trustees Approve Ben Sasse as School’s Next President
abstract: Mr. Sasse, Republican of Nebraska, is expected to resign from the Senate by the end of the year to lead Florida’s flagship public university.
lead_paragraph: The University of Florida said Tuesday that its board of trustees had voted unanimously to select Senator Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska, as the university’s next president.

headline: How Takeoff and the Migos Flow Changed Atlanta Rap
abstract: Quick-jabbing triplets had been a staple of rap, but the trio made the style sound fresh, thanks in large part to Takeoff, its master of syncopation. The rapper was shot and killed at 28 on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The Atlanta trio Migos’ 2013 breakout hit “Versace” represented a clear demarcation line between the city’s older generation of rappers and its new vanguard. The rapping — much of it delivered in triplets — was a glittery stomp. Tightly clustered syllables that landed like quick jabs.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: Israel Votes, Again
abstract: Plus Bolsonaro will step aside in Brazil and investigations mount in India’s bridge collapse.
lead_paragraph: Early exit polls from Israel’s fifth parliamentary election in four years suggest that Benjamin Netanyahu may reclaim power. He would preside over one of the most right-wing governments in the country’s history even as he is on trial on corruption charges.

headline: The Heir: In Nevada, a G.O.P. Candidate Sheds His Political Inheritance
abstract: His grandfather was among the first Reagan Republicans. Adam Laxalt, the party’s Senate candidate in Nevada, wants to lead a Trumpian future.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — With his Georgetown law degree, connections to Republican luminaries in Washington and a grandfather once known as Ronald Reagan’s “first friend,” Adam Laxalt could easily be mistaken as a legacy candidate.

headline: Racism and Theater, Then and Now
abstract: I dealt with racism onstage in the 1980s. Times have since changed, and recent charges of racism can be peculiar.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1980s, I was in the chorus of a college musical theater production of “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.” Most of the male chorus members were in one of two big set pieces, either a big dance number (the office party “Pirate Dance”) or a niftily staged song (“I Believe in You”). Only three of the 10 or so chorus guys were not placed in either number, and I was one of them.

headline: Parkland Gunman Gets 34 Life Sentences
abstract: The gunman who killed 17 people at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School was addressed directly by the families of his victims for the first time.
lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Brimming with rage, disappointment and grief, relatives of the 17 people fatally shot at a Florida high school four years ago confronted the gunman at a charged two-day sentencing hearing in which they repeatedly denounced the criminal justice system for sparing his life.

headline: Here’s What Diversity Means for One Group of Harvard Students
abstract: As the Supreme Court considers the role of race in college admissions, a diverse group of Harvard undergraduates shared their views.
lead_paragraph: In the early months of the coronavirus pandemic, Ava Salzman, now a senior at Harvard, took a class on oral storytelling in times of crisis. Despite the awkwardness of an online setting, Ms. Salzman said she felt that she and her 19 classmates found refuge in their shared stories.

headline: What Any Parent Would Do
abstract: Britt Reid, son of Kansas City Coach Andy Reid, was sentenced to prison for severely injuring a 5-year-old girl in a crash after he drank alcohol on the job. Her family has railed against the plea deal reached in a football-mad city.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The distance from the Kansas City Chiefs’ training complex to Interstate 435 is short. It would have taken Britt Reid only moments on Feb. 4, 2021, to drive from the facility, where he had been drinking, to the highway’s on-ramp, where his pickup truck reached 83.9 miles per hour before it rammed into two stopped cars and seriously injured a 5-year-old girl.

headline: From Yale to Newsmax, Usha Vance Has Helped J.D. Vance Chart His Path
abstract: The Ohio Senate candidate’s wife, an accomplished lawyer, remains ensconced in the milieu he now rails against.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, two students at Yale Law School decided to organize a discussion group on the subject of “social decline in white America.”

headline: Daniel Smith, 90, Dies; Thought to Be the Last Child of an Enslaved Person
abstract: He led a life marked by encounters with touchstone moments in Black history, from the March on Washington to Barack Obama’s first inauguration.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Smith, who was believed to be the last surviving child of an enslaved person, and who over a long and eventful life witnessed firsthand many of the central moments of the African American experience, died on Oct. 19 in Washington. He was 90.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Big Publishing Merger Was Blocked, but Brought the Industry Little Clarity
abstract: The uncertainty comes at a time when publishing is facing slumping sales after a pandemic boom, and fears of recession.
lead_paragraph: A judge blocked the largest publisher in the country from absorbing a rival, thwarting further consolidation in an industry that has been deeply reshaped by mergers in recent years. But the decision brought little clarity about what lies ahead for the companies involved, or for the publishing world.

headline: Christine Farnon, ‘Guiding Light’ of the Grammys, Dies at 97
abstract: Present at the creation, she guarded the awards’ independence and integrity but, the Grammys’ longtime producer said, “never received the recognition she deserves.”
lead_paragraph: Christine Farnon, a quiet force behind the Grammy Awards who was credited with shepherding the event from a private black-tie affair to a telecast seen by tens of millions, died on Oct. 24 in Los Angeles. She was 97.

headline: With Falsehoods and Ridicule About Pelosi Attack, Republicans Mimic Trump
abstract: The former president has shown Republicans that there is no penalty — and possibly a reward — from voters for spreading false claims and insulting political opponents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaking on a conservative radio talk show on Tuesday, former President Donald J. Trump amplified a conspiracy theory about the grisly attack on Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s husband, Paul Pelosi, that falsely suggested that Mr. Pelosi may not have been the victim of a genuine attack.

headline: Even After Jan. 6 Riot Was Quelled, Oath Keepers Were Urged to Fight On
