abstract: Testimony at the seditious conspiracy trial of members of the far-right group demonstrated that they were not deterred by their failure to stop certification of the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Past dark on Jan. 6, 2021, even after the pro-Trump mob had been chased away and the police had restored some order at the Capitol, members of the Oath Keepers militia kept discussing plans to disrupt the certification of the 2020 election.

headline: Why Election Experts Are So Confused About the 2022 Turnout Mystery
abstract: It’s a unique midterm year, with a Republican-friendly environment, an abortion ruling energizing Democrats, and increased partisanship in how people cast ballots.
lead_paragraph: WILLOW GROVE, Pa. — It’s the biggest mystery of the midterms: Which groups of voters will turn out in the largest numbers?

headline: Putin Is Starting to Do What Won Him a War 7 Years Ago
abstract: We can’t let Russia’s president turn Ukraine into Aleppo.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, as Bashar al-Assad was losing his war to remain in power in Syria, he pleaded for, and got, Russian military intervention. President Barack Obama reacted with airy disdain.

headline: Russia Pushes Ukrainians to Relocate as Possible Battle for Kherson Looms
abstract: Ukrainian officials said that Moscow was trying to clear out civilians to provide places for newly mobilized Russian troops to occupy.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Russia moved on Tuesday to expel Ukrainian civilians from their homes in a broader swath of occupied Kherson, as signs grew that a major battle for control of the region was nearing.

headline: Shattered by Nazi Bombs, a Fossil’s Lost Copies Are Just Being Found
abstract: The first full ichthyosaur fossil was thought lost to the ravages of World War II. But researchers recently identified a copy, then more started to emerge.
lead_paragraph: In May 1941, the Royal College of Surgeons in London was bombed during a Nazi air raid. Among the specimens lost from its museum collection was a skeleton of an ichthyosaur — an extinct marine reptile that appeared millions of years before dinosaurs laid their first footprints on prehistoric soil.

headline: A Coach Who Has ‘Seen It All’ Keeps Making the World Series
abstract: Kevin Long’s knowledge and experience as a hitting coach helped the Phillies win a pennant. Just like it did with the Yankees, the Mets and the Nationals.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Forty-two players have appeared on a World Series roster for three different franchises. The list stretches from Don Baylor to Ben Zobrist, with big names (Roger Clemens), funny names (Stuffy McInnis) and forgotten names (Franklin Morales) in between.

headline: Mike Pence Visits Georgia as Gov. Brian Kemp Plays Up Early Turnout
abstract: The former vice president was the first of several prominent Republicans who will visit before Election Day in support of Mr. Kemp.
lead_paragraph: CUMMING, Ga. — Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia, flanked by former Vice President Mike Pence and several fellow state Republican candidates, stressed the importance of voter turnout Tuesday in a campaign swing through Atlanta’s northern suburbs.

headline: How China Lost America
abstract: Four trends have led to the end of the steady integration of the Chinese economy with the West.
lead_paragraph: When future historians look back on 2022, they will have a lot to choose from when they ask the question: What was the most important thing that happened that year? Was it Brexit, Chexit, Ruxit or Trumpit?

headline: Biden Verbally Fumbles, Twice, During Campaign Trip in Florida
abstract: The president confused the American war in Iraq with the Russian war in Ukraine and then misstated how his son Beau died.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — President Biden verbally fumbled during a campaign swing in Florida on Tuesday, confusing the American war in Iraq with the Russian war in Ukraine, and then he fumbled again while he tried to correct himself, misstating how his son Beau died in 2015.

headline: Biden, in Midterm Campaign Pitch, Focuses on Social Security and Medicare
abstract: In a whirlwind tour of Florida, the president sought to paint Republicans as a threat to the two retirement programs. But his campaign swing did not go without bumps.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — President Biden pressed his argument on Tuesday that a Republican victory in next week’s midterm congressional elections would endanger Social Security and Medicare, bringing his case to the retirement haven of Florida, where the politics of the two programs resonate historically.

headline: Police Cameras at Pelosi’s House Were Unmonitored as They Caught Break-In
abstract: Minutes went by before any Capitol Police officer reviewed the footage. Law enforcement leaders said they planned to beef up protections for members of Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — U.S. Capitol Police security cameras captured the break-in at Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s San Francisco home last week in which her husband, Paul, was viciously assaulted, but costly minutes went by before any officer reviewed the footage, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: John McVay, Key Figure in the Making of a 49ers Dynasty, Dies at 91
abstract: He rebounded from the humiliation of “the fumble” as coach of the ’78 New York Giants to help San Francisco win five Super Bowls over 14 seasons as a top team executive.
lead_paragraph: John McVay, who was fired as the New York Giants’ head coach in the wake of the infamous November 1978 play known as “the fumble,” but who went on to help build the San Francisco 49ers into five-time Super Bowl champions in 14 seasons, died on Monday at his home in Granite Bay, Calif., northeast of Sacramento. He was 91.

headline: Pennsylvania Supreme Court Says Mail-In Ballots Without Dates Should Not Be Counted
abstract: Republicans had sued to stop election officials from counting noncompliant ballots, which could again become a crucial point of contention in the battleground state.
lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court on Tuesday ordered election officials in the battleground state to refrain from counting mail-in ballots that lack a written date on their outer envelope, siding with Republicans in a matter that could have national implications on Nov. 8.

headline: Louisiana Governor Calls for Inquiry Into Abuses at Juvenile Detention Center
abstract: The move comes in response to a New York Times investigation documenting years of torment and lenient oversight, and a surge in suicide attempts.
lead_paragraph: Gov. John Bel Edwards of Louisiana said this week that he was calling for an investigation into one of the state’s largest juvenile detention centers, after The New York Times documented a long record of repeated abuse, lenient oversight and, in recent years, a surge in suicide attempts. Three children have died by suicide there since 2017.

headline: Netanyahu Holds Slight Lead in Israeli Election, Exit Polls Show
abstract: If the right-wing bloc does eke out a narrow victory, it will allow Mr. Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister, to return to office even as he stands trial on corruption charges.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-wing alliance may have won a narrow lead in Israel’s fifth election in less than four years, exit polls suggested on Tuesday night, giving him a chance of returning to power at the helm of one of the most right-wing governments in Israeli history.

headline: Read the document that reveals new details about the Pelosi attack
abstract: A filing by prosecutors in San Francisco revealed new details about the break-in at Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s home and the attack on her husband.
lead_paragraph: A filing by prosecutors in San Francisco revealed new details about the break-in at Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s home and the attack on her husband.

headline: Vance Says He Will Accept Election Results, While Still Questioning 2020’s
abstract: The Republican Senate candidate in Ohio fielded questions in a Fox News town hall event that also included his Democratic rival, Representative Tim Ryan.
lead_paragraph: J.D. Vance, the Republican nominee for Senate in Ohio, said Tuesday evening that he would accept the results of his election — while also saying he stood by his false claims that the 2020 election had been “stolen.”

headline: Many Lawyer Puns
abstract: Enjoy this punchy puzzle by Ethan Zou and Tomas Spiers.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Hello, solvers, and happy Wednesday! Today we have a puzzle from Ethan Zou, who is making his New York Times Crossword debut, and Tomas Spiers, who is making his second appearance in The Times. Congratulations to both on this punny, punchy puzzle.

headline: North Korea Launches 23 Missiles, Triggering Air-Raid Alarm in South
abstract: People on an island took cover as one missile landed near South Korean territorial waters. The South responded by firing three missiles of its own.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — North Korea fired nearly two dozen missiles Wednesday in its largest deployment on a single day, an escalation in recent tensions that triggered an air-raid alert on a populated island in the South and provoked a military warning from Seoul.

headline: Barrage of Homers Puts Phillies in Control of World Series
abstract: In the first World Series game in Philadelphia since 2009, the Phillies took Houston’s Lance McCullers Jr. deep five times and cruised to victory.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — It had been more than a week since fans in Philadelphia had seen their team in person, plenty of time to savor the lasting image from that day: A dramatic eighth-inning, go-ahead home run by Bryce Harper. It was a defining two-run blast that all but clinched the National League pennant for the surprising, streaking Phillies.

headline: Judge Curbs Actions of Election-Monitoring Group in Arizona
abstract: The group may not take photos or videos of voters, openly carry firearms near ballot boxes, or post information about voters online, a federal judge ruled.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Arizona has sharply curtailed the activities of an election-monitoring group in the vicinity of ballot boxes, including taking photos or videos of voters, openly carrying firearms, posting information about voters online, or spreading falsehoods about election laws.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 2, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Nov. 2, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about a correction officer who was stabbed while working at Rikers Island prison complex misstated the number of people who died either in or shortly after being released from New York City’s jails in 2013. It was 23, not 21.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Musk Is Asked to Remove Antisemitic Posts on Website
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, November 2, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “You can’t have a digital town square if a significant part of the population feels they’re going to get lynched in it.”

headline: Geno Smith Isn’t the Only Reason the Seahawks Are Riding a Mile High
abstract: A new offensive system, a resurgent quarterback, and a stellar draft class have the Seahawks soaring in the N.F.C. West.
lead_paragraph: The Seattle Seahawks are practically a textbook example of a rebuilding team. They were constructed to sink to the bottom of the standings like a lobster trap so they could snare a quarterback in the 2023 N.F.L. draft and start over.

headline: A Capital Draped in Darkness
abstract: The streets of Ukraine’s capital, illuminated with nightlife only weeks ago, are shrouded in darkness and shadows now because of restrictions on the use of electricity. The lack of light creates moments of apprehension, but also of beauty.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Phillies Hit 1,950 Feet of Homers in Game 3
abstract: A look at Philadelphia's five home runs in a dominant Game 3 win that gave the team a 2-1 lead over the Houston Astros in the World Series.
lead_paragraph: A look at Philadelphia's five home runs in a dominant Game 3 win that gave the team a 2-1 lead over the Houston Astros in the World Series.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: The latest developments from elections in Brazil, Denmark and Israel.
lead_paragraph: Two days after losing Brazil’s presidential election, Jair Bolsonaro, the incumbent, agreed to a transition of power yesterday, while not acknowledging that he had lost the vote or that the election had been free and fair. “President Bolsonaro has authorized me — when requested, based on the law — to start the transition process,” his chief of staff, Ciro Nogueira, said.

headline: Russia rejoins the grain deal after saying it received safety assurances.
abstract: Russia said on Wednesday that it was rejoining a deal that allows the shipment of grain from Ukrainian ports through the Black Sea, easing days of uncertainty over an agreement that had offered hope to countries facing severe food shortages.
lead_paragraph: Russia said on Wednesday that it was rejoining a deal that allows the shipment of grain from Ukrainian ports through the Black Sea, easing days of uncertainty over an agreement that had offered hope to countries facing severe food shortages.

headline: Stephen Colbert Isn’t Amused by Elon Musk’s Plan to Monetize Twitter
abstract: Colbert said that Musk’s idea to charge users for verification would lead to “chaos” on Twitter. “I rely on that blue check mark to know which of my butters I can’t not believe!”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: impugn
abstract: This word has appeared in 21 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word impugn has appeared in 21 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 22 in “An Activist Short Seller Gets His Day in Court” by Bernhard Warner:

headline: Astros Starter Insists Awful Game Had ‘Nothing to Do With Tipping’
abstract: Houston’s Lance McCullers Jr. set a World Series record by allowing five home runs. The Phillies hinted they were onto something but McCullers said he just pitched poorly.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Lance McCullers Jr. had just set a World Series record by surrendering five home runs in a game, and he wasn’t having any of it. Not the pitch-tipping theories that were wildly circulating on social media, not the possibility that he was rusty after having pitched just twice since Oct. 3, none of it.

headline: ‘Goodnight Moon’
abstract: What is your favorite book from childhood?
lead_paragraph: “Goodnight Moon,” the first book many babies receive as a gift, celebrated its 75th birthday this year. Did your parents read this book to you when you were younger?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Widespread Racial Bias Found in Home Appraisals
abstract: Researchers found evidence of a persistent practice that gives higher values to homes when the occupants are white, and devalue them if the owners are people of color.
lead_paragraph: White homeowners can expect their homes’ values to increase at twice the rate of homeowners of color, a stark confirmation of systemic racial bias in home appraisals, according to a new report.

headline: As Housing Costs Soar, Co-Living Makes a Comeback
abstract: The living arrangements, known as “dorms for adults,” are on the upswing after declining in the pandemic, and developers are adapting to the renewed interest.
lead_paragraph: At first, Lindsey Tindage, a 27-year-old corporate recruiter, was leery of co-living, a housing model that brings strangers together in a dormitory-like arrangement.

headline: For Daughter of American Militant, Scars of ISIS’ Reign Run Deep
abstract: Allison Fluke-Ekren, a teacher from Kansas, dragged her family to Syria and forced her daughter, Leyla, to train for war on behalf of the Islamic State. Now her daughter wields final words against her.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — Leyla Ekren, a quiet but scrappy girl from rural Kansas, lost her childhood in Syria, where her mother dragged her after war broke out more than a decade ago.

headline: As Netanyahu Nears Victory, Israel’s Extremist Parties Celebrate
abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu’s near-certain victory in this week’s election in Israel won’t be confirmed until Thursday, but his far right allies are already savoring their rise to power.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s once and likely future prime minister, was forced to wait on Wednesday after taking an almost insurmountable lead in Israel’s election, as officials delayed calling the election until all votes were counted.

headline: After Covid Lockdown, Fear and Unrest Sweep iPhone Factory in China
abstract: Hundreds of workers are said to have fled, afraid of being forced into quarantine with inadequate food and supplies.
lead_paragraph: Covid lockdown measures have generated a wave of fear and unrest inside the world’s largest iPhone manufacturing complex, in north-central China, with stories of food shortages among quarantined employees filling social media, and large numbers of workers fleeing the facility.

headline: What Issues Are Most Important for You Leading Up to the Midterm Elections?
abstract: Inflation, abortion, crime, climate change, immigration, jobs, college loans or something else? What’s on your mind?
lead_paragraph: The United States midterm elections are coming up on Nov. 8. In this year’s midterms, Americans will vote on members of the House of Representatives and the Senate. Many states and local governments will also hold their own elections. There is a lot at stake.

headline: Newly Published, From Egotistical Artists to Corporate Control
abstract: A selection of recently published books.
lead_paragraph: ARTIST, by Yeong-shin Ma. Translated by Janet Hong. (Drawn & Quarterly, paperback, $39.95.) This wry story, drawn with pen on paper, follows three friends — a novelist, a painter and a musician — as they struggle with creative obstacles, daily tedium and the pretensions of their wounded egos.

headline: The Man Beat Cancer Years Ago. Why Was There a Mass in His Lung?
abstract: Could the disease be back?
lead_paragraph: The doctor’s voice over the phone was warm and reassuring. The patient, a 62-year-old man, had a chest CT earlier that day, and Dr. David Smith, his longtime P.C.P., was telling him that the radiologist saw a mass. It sounded bad, but it probably wasn’t cancer, Smith told him. “I didn’t want you to see the report and worry,” he added. The report said that the mass in his lungs looked like a neoplasm — the fancy word for tumor. But it went on to acknowledge that it could also just be left over from the really bad pneumonia the man had three months earlier.

headline: The $24 Trillion Market That Predicts and Influences Interest Rates
abstract: The market for U.S. government bonds, called the Treasury market, offers predictions on the path for interest rates and the economy.
lead_paragraph: How much higher will interest rates go?

headline: Pecan Tarts: A Love Story
abstract: Pastry has always been synonymous with pleasure — a way that we can treat our lovers and friends or strangers, even if for only a moment.
lead_paragraph: My first pecan tart came from a crush. A guy who lived next door. In the way of queer latchkey teenagers globally, we baked at his place in the afternoons. I crushed pecans. He sifted sugar. Sometimes we brushed hands, folding butter into flour. Once the tarts had been baked, we split them down the middle, until my crush became my friend, and we both grew up, and came out. We moved on to other relationships and other pleasures in other places — but I never entirely forgot about the tarts.

headline: The Meaning of Stanford’s Apology to Jews
abstract: For decades, elite institutions sidelined Jewish students. What does that history tell us about affirmative action today?
lead_paragraph: To anyone who understands the history of Jewish exclusion on elite campuses, the central findings of a recently released, long-awaited report from Stanford University were no shock. The report confirmed that Stanford admissions officers purposefully limited the enrollment of Jewish students in the 1950s, in part by greatly reducing the number of applicants admitted from heavily Jewish public high schools.

headline: In ‘Cheap Land Colorado,’ Surrounded by Beauty but Barely Getting By
abstract: For his new book, the journalist Ted Conover joined a community of off-gridders in a desolate corner of the West, capturing lives full of anguish and contradiction.
lead_paragraph: When I first heard that the title for Ted Conover’s new book was “Cheap Land Colorado,” I assumed it had to be a play on the Lynyrd Skynyrd song “Sweet Home Alabama.” Even the syllables track.

headline: Will One Small Shift Fix the Polls in 2022? (Wonkiness: 8/10)
abstract: The potential improvement is based on the idea that voters are less likely to recall voting for a losing candidate.
lead_paragraph: The great polling misfire of the 2020 election wasn’t just about how Trump supporters were less likely to respond to political surveys.

headline: People Love to Hate-Watch Tech Villains. That Won’t Hurt Spotify.
abstract: “The Playlist” resembles other TV dramas that follow founders to their eventual comeuppance — except Spotify isn’t facing any messy implosion.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Ek, a founder of Spotify and its current chief executive, sits in front of a U.S. Senate committee hearing. Or rather: A Swedish actor playing Ek sits in front of a Senate hearing, as imagined by a Swedish production designer. A fictitious senator named Landy is grilling him, hard. “Your business model just doesn’t work for musicians, does it?” she asks. Her tone makes it obvious that she already knows the answer Ek would give if he were willing to tell the truth. As she peppers him with facts and figures about Spotify’s market share and artists’ measly cut of its revenue, Ek tries to fight back, insisting that his streaming service, whatever its shortcomings, is still the best path forward for musicians hoping to make a living from their art. But the more Landy presses, the more shaken Ek looks, as though he didn’t expect the questioning to be so tough. There is a moment in which it seems he might be considering the possibility that her criticisms have merit: Maybe, despite all of his company’s rhetoric about freedom for artists, he really is just a new breed of music-industry monopolist.

headline: The Price of $5 Donations: Is Small-Dollar Fund-Raising Doing More Harm Than Good?
abstract: Tim Miller and Micah Sifry on how grass-roots funding has changed American politics.
lead_paragraph: As midterm frenzy reaches its peak, your inbox might be full of imploring fund-raising emails with increasingly desperate headlines: “Just $3 can make all the difference.” “Can you chip in today?” “Ultimately, it’s up to you.” In theory, the small-dollar donation model is a good thing: It enables voters to have a say in who their candidates are and counterbalances the influence of superdonors and industry lobbyists. But as extremist candidates increasingly adopt grass-roots approaches and self-fund-raise their way into Congress, could small-dollar donations be doing more harm to our democracy than good?

headline: How to Salvage a Workout After a Bad Night of Sleep
abstract: The key to enjoying exercise after a fitful slumber is to start early and keep it simple.
lead_paragraph: After a bad night’s sleep, nothing feels right. The mind is fuzzy and the muscles are sapped. Often the last thing you want to do is work up a sweat. You might find yourself wondering what kind of workout you should do, and if it’s better to put it off until you’re not quite so groggy.

headline: Hayao Miyazaki’s ‘Shuna’s Journey,’ Finally Translated Into English
abstract: First published in Japan in 1983, this picture book from the fabled animator is eerie, enchanting and surpassingly strange.
lead_paragraph: “Shuna’s Journey” is an eerie and enchanting book, a voyage into a delicately mythic realm of beauty and heartbreak. Here a traditional Tibetan folk tale about a search for fruitful seeds is interwoven with scenes of surpassing strangeness, ranging from an encounter with a vast ship made of rock — its floors formed by human bones that crunch underfoot — to a giant silvery moon that hurtles across the sky guiding a youth toward a “land of the god-folk.” It is a place in which resilient and resolute young people, both male and female, lead their elders into a better future. This visionary space has been created by the legendary Japanese artist, animator and director Hayao Miyazaki.

headline: Pack Your Bags, We’re Moving to ‘Roku City’
abstract: Instead of streaming a new TV show or movie, some Roku users are in it for the screen saver.
lead_paragraph: If you let a Roku idle long enough, you will eventually be transported to a magenta cityscape beyond time and space. The screen slowly pans across cozy diners, gothic mansions and a sumptuous, moonlit lagoon, all sheathed in a groovy, “Blade Runner”-esque color palette.

headline: Big ‘Pippin’: The Harmony and Dissonance of an American Classic
abstract: Elysa Gardner’s “Magic to Do” goes backstage at Bob Fosse and Stephen Schwartz’s 1972 musical about a lost prince.
lead_paragraph: In theater circles, it’s not always easy to come out as an ardent fan of “Pippin.”

headline: Bruno Walter, a Conductor Who Found Truth Through Beauty
abstract: A survey of Walter’s recorded output is fascinating for the ways in which it reveals him reinventing the traditions he was seen to represent.
lead_paragraph: “Truth can be repulsive,” Bruno Walter, a conductor whose life had taught him that fact all too well, once said. “But Mozart has the power to speak truth with beauty.”

headline: Prisoners Like Me Are Being Held Hostage to Price Hikes
abstract: Shampoo. Sausages. Prisoners are struggling to afford staples whose prices have swelled beyond their ability to pay.
lead_paragraph: The hole in the sole of my shoe is a problem. The plastic bag I sandwich between my two best pairs of socks can do only so much during the days we’re let outside. It protects well against the rain that soaks in through my shoe, but Idaho snow is a formidable foe.

headline: The Untold Story of ‘Russiagate’ and the Road to War in Ukraine
abstract: Russia’s meddling in Trump-era politics was more directly connected to the current war than previously understood.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Fed Faces Tough Decisions as Inflation Lingers and Economic Risks Loom
abstract: The central bank is expected to raise rates three-quarters of a point today, but what it says about its next steps will be even more important.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is expected to continue its fight against the fastest inflation in 40 years on Wednesday by raising rates three-quarters of a percentage point for the fourth time in a row. What officials signal about the central bank’s future plans is likely to be even more important.

headline: Planning to Fly? You’ll Need This ID.
abstract: For years, the government has warned travelers they will need a security-enhanced Real ID to board domestic flights, and for years the requirement has been delayed. Now they mean it.
lead_paragraph: It’s a change nearly 20 years in the making: a post-Sept. 11 law requiring that U.S. travelers carry more than a standard driver’s license to board a domestic flight. Now, after years of delays, it is finally kicking into gear.

headline: Security Cameras Make Us Feel Safe, but Are They Worth the Invasion?
abstract: Internet cameras like Amazon’s Ring come at a high cost to our privacy.
lead_paragraph: I have always been fascinated by webcams that watch for anything that moves. When I lived in a no-frills neighborhood in San Francisco a few years ago, my camera witnessed all flavors of urban crime, from amateur fireworks shows to street fights. After I moved to the suburbs, my camera became a nature documentarian of the local fauna, like the deer that devour my rosebushes the instant they bloom.

headline: Did the Nets Get Rid of the Wrong Person?
abstract: The star-loaded Nets have an awful record and parted ways with Coach Steve Nash. But a bigger problem with Kyrie Irving and his antisemitic social media post remains.
lead_paragraph: Be careful what you wish for. That adage comes to mind when I think of Kyrie Irving and his misguided, misinformed and downright dangerous support of antisemitism.

headline: ‘Elites Are Making Choices That Are Not Good News’
abstract: White working-class support for right-wing populism is hardening.
lead_paragraph: Even as the economic pressures that drove millions of white working-class voters to the right are moderating, the hostility this key segment of the electorate feels toward the Democratic Party has deepened and is less and less amenable to change.

headline: Bill Outlawing Online Suicide Assistance Would Open Sites to Liability
abstract: Bipartisan legislation in the House targets not only the online activity of individual users but also the website operators hosting it.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers are seeking to make online assistance of suicide a federal crime, pushing to hold accountable both individual users and the tech companies and websites that allow such content on their platforms.

headline: It’s Time to Bring Russia and Ukraine to the Negotiating Table
abstract: The risk of a wider war between NATO and Moscow is rising by the day, as is the risk that a prolonged war could undermine Western democracy.
lead_paragraph: This essay has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: Russian Military Leaders Discussed Use of Nuclear Weapons, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: The conversations alarmed the Biden administration because they showed how frustrated Moscow had become over its battlefield setbacks in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior Russian military leaders recently had conversations to discuss when and how Moscow might use a tactical nuclear weapon in Ukraine, contributing to heightened concern in Washington and allied capitals, according to multiple senior American officials.

headline: At HBO, an Early Mandate to Air ‘Things for Men’
abstract: A new history of the entertainment company traces its origins in a culture of male license, misogyny — and violence.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s, Michael Fuchs, HBO’s pugnacious, Bronx-born future chief executive, made a big bet on male appetites. In his view, broadcast networks like NBC tailored their programming to avoid offending women viewers, whom advertisers relied on to buy household products. Ad-free HBO had no such obligations. “I figured out that the man in the household decided whether or not to have HBO,” Fuchs said. “I made sure there were things for men.”

headline: Republicans, Eyeing Majority, Float Changes to Social Security and Medicare
abstract: Democrats have seized on Republican proposals to limit retirement benefits to galvanize voters ahead of the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans, eyeing a midterm election victory that could hand them control of the House and the Senate, have embraced plans to reduce federal spending on Social Security and Medicare, including cutting benefits for some retirees and raising the retirement age for both safety net programs.

headline: As Stakes Rise, State Supreme Courts Become Crucial Election Battlegrounds
abstract: Pivotal issues like abortion, gerrymandering and voting have been tossed into state justices’ laps. Politicians, ideological PACs and big money are following.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — State supreme court races, traditionally Election Day afterthoughts, have emerged this year as crucial battlefields in the struggle over the course of American democracy, attracting a torrent of last-minute money and partisan advertising.

headline: Here’s Where the U.S. Is Testing a New Response to Rising Seas
abstract: Native American tribes are competing for the first federal grants designed to help move communities away from high water and other dangers posed by climate change.
lead_paragraph: SHOALWATER BAY INDIAN RESERVATION, Wash. — The van carrying tribal officials veered off the coastal highway, away from the Pacific and onto a dirt path hidden by cedar and spruce trees. After climbing an old logging road, it emerged into a clearing high above the Shoalwater Bay Indian Reservation, half a square mile of oceanfront that’s disappearing fast.

headline: How the Right Became the Left and the Left Became the Right
abstract: A pair of prominent headlines highlights the reversals.
lead_paragraph: One of the master keys to understanding our era is seeing all the ways in which conservatives and progressives have traded attitudes and impulses. The populist right’s attitude toward American institutions has the flavor of the 1970s — skeptical, pessimistic, paranoid — while the mainstream, MSNBC-watching left has a strange new respect for the F.B.I. and C.I.A. The online right likes transgression for its own sake, while cultural progressivism dabbles in censorship and worries that the First Amendment goes too far. Trumpian conservatism flirts with postmodernism and channels Michel Foucault; its progressive rivals are institutionalist, moralistic, confident in official narratives and establishment credentials.

headline: It Can Happen Here: 8 Great Books to Read About the Decline of Democracy
abstract: It’s among the world’s oldest forms of government, but it’s increasingly under threat. These books consider the sources and effects of an alarming global trend.
lead_paragraph: Autocratic demagogues. The erosion of the rule of law. Growing inequality. The upending of elections. Normalization of violence. These are all symptoms of what the scholar Larry Diamond has called “democratic recession” — and we are seeing them not just in America, but around the world. Over the last 16 years, according to Freedom House, a nonprofit that researches and promotes global democracy, more nations have moved away from democratic principles than strengthened their embrace of them. The list includes the United States. What’s new is that this trend is happening in modern, prosperous, liberal democracies.

headline: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Ornette Coleman
abstract: We asked writers, critics and musicians including Kamasi Washington, Nubya Garcia and Shabaka Hutchings to tell us how they connect with Coleman’s fearless artistry.
lead_paragraph: Over the past three months, The New York Times has asked musicians, writers and scholars to share the favorites that would make a friend fall in love with jazz — starting with Duke Ellington, then moving on to Alice Coltrane and bebop.

headline: These Cakes Have Thorns
abstract: A group of bakers are taking nonconformist cake decorating trends to new heights, creating otherworldly confections bristling with surreal protrusions.
lead_paragraph: CAKE IS COMFORT: a product of care and precision, the taste of childhood birthdays. But the versions that captivated scrollers on Instagram during the pandemic’s early lockdowns were often perversely discomforting — gloopy and off kilter, their layers sagging beneath shimmering accents and swaths of overexuberant piping, they were gleeful but also a little unhinged, their gaudy neon frosting laced with the anxiety of the time. Since then, bakers’ interest in unconventional aesthetics has only increased, resulting in even stranger forms. Though still maximalist in spirit, the latest cake designs are characterized not by mess but by jagged outgrowths, their surfaces blanketed with sharp peaks of meringue and jutting sprigs of herbs and flowers.

headline: Patty Murray Faces Stiff Challenge in Senate Re-election Race
abstract: The five-term Washington senator is concerned about complacency among Democratic voters, who have come to regard her as a fixture who will always be there. She faces a Republican newcomer, Tiffany Smiley.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Ahead of their first election in Washington State, Carys Hagen and her partner, Shaw Lenox, stumbled upon a rally held for Senator Patty Murray, a Democrat, on a stage in the corner of the Seattle Center.

headline: Who Wears Crop Tops to the Office?
abstract: Young employees, many of them new to office jobs, are bringing a wardrobe staple usually reserved for the weekends into the workplace.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Santina Rizzi graduated from Florida State University in spring 2021 with a degree in political science, she started working as a paralegal at a Miami law firm where the office dress code was business casual: button-up shirts, long skirts (or short skirts with tights) and closed-toe shoes.

headline: Detroit Reclaims Halloween, a Holiday Once Marred by Fire
abstract: After decades of Devil’s Night fear and arson, Halloween in Detroit is again a celebration, and a sign of a changing city.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — As a teenager in the 1980s, Jamal Lawson rode his bike from fire to fire on the nights around Halloween, watching what others had set ablaze in Detroit.

headline: Can Lee Zeldin Reinvent His Way to the N.Y. Governor’s Mansion?
abstract: Representative Lee Zeldin’s political career reflects decades of preparation, alliances with more powerful Republicans and a hard-right embrace of former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: SHIRLEY, N.Y. — As a young U.S. Army lawyer of unmistakable ambition, Lee Zeldin could almost see his future unfurling before him. It was his first stint in Iraq, and he was already imagining the kind of distinguished career in uniform that would have laid the groundwork for one in politics.

headline: What You Get for $3 Million
abstract: A midcentury-modern retreat in Dallas; a three-bedroom home near the Battery in Charleston, S.C.; and a Shingle-style house in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: A midcentury-modern retreat in Dallas; a three-bedroom home near the Battery in Charleston, S.C.; and a Shingle-style house in Seattle.

headline: $3 Million Homes in Texas, South Carolina and Washington
abstract: A midcentury-modern retreat in Dallas, a three-bedroom home near the Battery in Charleston and a Shingle-style house in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: This house, designed by David Braden, a former president of the Dallas chapter of the American Institute of Architects and the Texas Society of Architects, has walls of glass that offer views of the wooded property and the city skyline in the distance. It is across the street from Kessler Parkway Park, where walking trails wind along Coombs Creek, and is within easy driving distance of downtown: The historic district is 10 minutes away, as are the Bishop Arts District and Deep Ellum neighborhoods, popular dining and nightlife destinations.

headline: Rikers: A Bright Green Future for a Dark Place?
abstract: One day, Rikers could be a source of light, in the form of solar power. Plus, Lee Zeldin’s efforts to avoid positions some New Yorkers consider unenlightened.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at a plan for Rikers Island, assuming the jails there are shut down in five years on the timetable set by the City Council. We’ll also look at Representative Lee Zeldin, the Republican candidate for governor, who tapped into discontent about inflation and crime in his campaign against Gov. Kathy Hochul.

headline: From Sebring to Bohm, a History of 1,000 World Series Homers
abstract: Jimmy Sebring hit the first World Series homer back in 1903 and in the third game of the 118th Fall Classic, Alec Bohm of the Phillies hit the 1,000th.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Alec Bohm hit the 1,000th home run in World Series history in Game 3 on Tuesday at Citizens Bank Park. For a while, it seemed as if his Philadelphia Phillies teammates might slam a thousand more.

headline: Hurricane or Typhoon? How Tropical Cyclones Get Their Names.
abstract: There are variations around the world, particularly in the Western Pacific, in how countries name and measure tropical cyclones. We can explain.
lead_paragraph: Whenever a tropical cyclone barrels toward the Southeastern United States, forecasters assign it a name and a category based on a grading system that is widely used for storms in the Atlantic Ocean.

headline: The Man Who Tried to Kidnap Nancy Pelosi
abstract: Investigators have released details that paint a frightening story of what happened in the attack at the speaker’s home.
lead_paragraph: Early on Friday, an intruder broke into the San Francisco home of Nancy Pelosi and bludgeoned Ms. Pelosi’s husband, Paul, with a hammer.

headline: Denmark’s Center-Left Coalition Wins Election Majority
abstract: An unpredictable race ultimately gave the governing Social Democratic Party its best showing in two decades, though analysts said it looked set to form a more centrist government.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — Denmark’s center-left coalition emerged with a majority of parliamentary seats early Wednesday, after a tight overnight count in an unpredictable general election gave the governing Social Democratic Party its best showing in two decades.

headline: The New Abortion Landscape
abstract: Women in states with abortion bans are turning to telemedicine.
lead_paragraph: Just two years ago, about 250,000 people had abortions in the U.S. states where the procedure is now banned or severely restricted, or probably soon will be. Since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade on June 24, allowing those prohibitions to take effect, where have women in these states turned?

headline: Your Guide to the 2022 New York City Marathon
abstract: Everything you need to know about the five-borough race.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates from the 2022 New York City Marathon.

headline: The New York Times Company Adds 180,000 Digital Subscribers
abstract: The Times recorded an adjusted operating profit of $69 million for the third quarter, up from $65 million in the same period last year.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company said on Wednesday that it had gained 180,000 online subscribers in the most recent quarter, and that it was improving its profit forecast for the full year.

headline: Overtime Elite Gets Media Deal With Amazon Prime Video
abstract: The deal to stream Overtime Elite’s games to Prime Video comes as top male players consider the league an option instead of traditional high schools and colleges.
lead_paragraph: ROSELLE, N.J. — On a recent Friday evening, Naasir Cunningham was back home in New Jersey doing what he does best: flying up and down a basketball court, deftly floating in baskets and hitting an array of jump shots from various angles.

headline: The Nets’ Problems Are Bigger Than Steve Nash
abstract: The Nets dumped their coach, but the team has never lived up to expectations. And there’s no clear path forward now.
lead_paragraph: For the past three seasons, success for the Nets had been rooted in hypotheticals.

headline: Between the Mountains and the Sea in Eastern Spain
abstract: This six-bedroom, L-shaped house on 4.9 acres in Jávea, a resort town in Spain’s eastern Costa Blanca region, is for sale for $1.97 million.
lead_paragraph: This six-bedroom, L-shaped house on 4.9 acres in Jávea, a resort town in Spain’s eastern Costa Blanca region, is for sale for $1.97 million.

headline: An ‘Oasis of Calm’ in Costa Blanca for $2 Million: House Hunting in Spain
abstract: Prices in Jávea, the former fishing village and now resort town on the Mediterranean coast, offer comparative value in Spain’s luxury market.
lead_paragraph: With Montgó mountain as its backdrop, this six-bedroom, five-bath house sits on 4.9 landscaped acres in the Montgó-Ermita section of Jávea, a former fishing village and now resort town in Spain’s popular Costa Blanca region.

headline: Kyiv says it is preparing 425 shelters in case of a Russian nuclear attack.
abstract: Worries that the Kremlin might turn to its nuclear arsenal have deepened since President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia raised the specter of using such weapons to hold on to territorial gains.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — A top Kyiv official said that more than 400 fallout shelters were being readied in the capital and that similar measures were being taken elsewhere around the country to prepare for a possible nuclear attack from Russia.

headline: Investors Await the Fed’s Next Move
abstract: Markets expect another big interest rate increase on Wednesday. But investors are also anxious about the central bank’s coming moves.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday is the final meeting of the Fed’s Open Market Committee before next week’s midterm elections, and the central bank’s move on interest rates looks like a foregone conclusion.

headline: How Hollywood Got Behind California’s Prop. 28
abstract: The ballot initiative would dedicate a percentage of the state general fund for arts and music education in public schools.
lead_paragraph: Show business in California is stalwart in supporting political causes, but rarely does the industry turn on the wattage for, say, a school-finance ballot initiative.

headline: Our Son Committed Us to Wedding Costs We Can’t Afford. Help!
abstract: Without consulting them, a reader’s son agreed to a plan to have his parents split the costs of a lavish wedding with his future in-laws.
lead_paragraph: Our son and his fiancée, both 24, are getting married next summer. The bride’s mother has commandeered the planning. When the kids express an opinion, she gets huffy and overrules them. Early on, she asked my son, “Are your parents splitting the cost of the wedding with us?” Flustered, he said yes. But no one told us! Now, the mother of the bride has planned an extravagant affair and sent us a spreadsheet with “our share” of the costs. We can’t afford it. I think she is way off base. My wife wants us to take out a loan. Your thoughts?

headline: How ‘Babylon’ Roars Through the 1920s
abstract: The writer-director Damien Chazelle and the production designer Florencia Martin discuss how they captured the excess of a period when Hollywood was heading for a reckoning.
lead_paragraph: After he turned the streets of Los Angeles into a playground and a dance floor for the musical “La La Land,” you might think the writer and director Damien Chazelle would have little left to mine from the location.

headline: 5 Unfounded Claims About Voting in the Midterm Elections
abstract: Here are some of the main falsehoods and rumors that have spread on social media in the lead-up to Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Voting-related falsehoods and rumors are flourishing across social media in the final stretch before Election Day on Tuesday.

headline: Who Is Jennifer Lawrence Now?
abstract: The Oscar-winning “Hunger Games” actress is free from her franchise commitments. But after a brief hiatus from acting, what will she do next?
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Sandwich Generation Is Getting Squished
abstract: Caring for kids and parents simultaneously can carry an emotional and financial toll.
lead_paragraph: In early 2020, I wrote about the struggles of the “sandwich generation,” demographers’ label for those who are caring for children and aging relatives at the same time. The sandwich generation parents I spoke to in that prepandemic moment talked about the emotional and financial toll of that level of caregiving responsibility. Some had to leave full-time employment or change jobs because caring for a parent with failing health and children with their own abundant needs took too much time and required too much flexibility.

headline: Personal Tech Has Changed. So Must Our Coverage of It.
abstract: Our tech problems have become more complex, so we are rebooting the Tech Fix column to focus on the societal implications of the tech we use.
lead_paragraph: Turn off your iCloud backups! This piece of advice echoed all over the web last year after Apple announced a new tool that would scan iPhone photos for child sexual abuse imagery, prompting widespread concern about digital privacy.

headline: CVS and Walgreens Near $10 Billion Deal to Settle Opioid Cases
abstract: The dual agreements would resolve thousands of lawsuits over the retailers’ role in the addiction crisis. But a large majority of state, local and tribal governments must sign on.
lead_paragraph: CVS and Walgreens, two of the nation’s largest retail pharmacy chains, said on Wednesday that they had reached tentative agreements to pay about $5 billion each to settle thousands of lawsuits over their role in the opioid crisis, a development that could signal the beginning of the end of years of opioid litigation.

headline: Living In ... Accord, N.Y.
abstract: With its central location, stunning scenery and culturally diverse community, the Ulster County hamlet has seen an influx of residents recently.
lead_paragraph: With its central location, stunning scenery and culturally diverse community, the Ulster County hamlet has seen an influx of residents recently.

headline: Accord, N.Y.: A ‘Laid-Back Agricultural Hub’ With a ‘Chill Vibe’
abstract: With its central location, stunning scenery and culturally diverse community, the Ulster County hamlet has seen an influx of residents in recent years.
lead_paragraph: When Craig Mersky and Stephanie Miller bought a house in Accord, N.Y., eight years ago, they envisioned it as a weekend place to escape from Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. But nearly two years ago, the pandemic pushed the couple to make a permanent break. In December 2020, they bought a bigger house and an adjoining lot with plenty of space where their son, Max, 3, and rescue dog, Lemonade, could run and play.

headline: A Beginner’s Guide to the Rowing Machine
abstract: Fitness companies have caught on to the fact that these devices deliver an intense full-body workout.
lead_paragraph: Rowing machines are having a moment. Long the ugly ducklings of the gym, tucked away in forgotten corners, the workout devices are getting a makeover — just like indoor cycling machines did a decade ago.

headline: It’s Time to Order the Turkey
abstract: The countdown to Thanksgiving has begun. Take a few minutes to make a plan and decide which recipes you’ll be making this year.
lead_paragraph: Egad, it’s November — let the countdown to Thanksgiving begin!

headline: Fed Makes Fourth Jumbo Rate Increase and Signals More to Come
abstract: The Federal Reserve has now raised interest rates six times this year as it tries to quash the fastest inflation in four decades.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials made their fourth supersize interest rate increase in a row on Wednesday and signaled that they planned to lift rates higher than they had previously anticipated as inflation proves surprisingly rapid and stubborn.

headline: What Fed Rate Increases Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
abstract: Savers will benefit and borrowers can expect to pay more on credit cards, student loans and other forms of debt.
lead_paragraph: As the Federal Reserve has lifted its key interest rate several times this year, Americans have seen the effects on both sides of the household ledger: Savers benefit from higher yields, but borrowers pay more.

headline: 3 Lively Vegetarian Sides That Add Color to the Thanksgiving Table
abstract: A vibrant kale salad, a creamy chard casserole and carrots glazed in miso bring hearty flavor to the holiday in this menu from David Tanis.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving isn’t exactly a colorful vegetable-forward occasion. The holiday’ palette is rather somber: There’s a lot of brown, beige, camel and dull green, and a few nice autumnal colors thanks to cranberry sauce and candied yams.

headline: Harry Bates, Modernist Architect of Long Island Homes, Dies at 95
abstract: Withstanding “a tsunami of shingles” on houses going up on the East End, he stuck to an aesthetic of clean, elegant lines and simple materials.
lead_paragraph: Harry Bates, an architect who designed scores of modernist houses on Fire Island in the 1960s and ’70s and in the Hamptons in the 1980s and ’90s, and then, with a design partner 45 years his junior, had a surge of output and influence around the turn of the century, died on Tuesday in Fernandina Beach, Fla. He was 95.

headline: These 6 Thanksgiving Dishes Are Best When They’re Made Ahead
abstract: Prepare mashed potatoes, gravy, cranberry sauce and more holiday favorites in advance for dishes with the best texture and flavor.
lead_paragraph: Peter Kelsch, a third-generation farmer in southeastern Idaho, kills Kelsch Farms’ russet Burbank potato plants three weeks before harvest. Once the plants are dead, the potatoes’ skins harden and cure over time, leading to less starchy potatoes and, ultimately, better mashed potatoes.

headline: Washington Commanders’ Owners Hire Bank to Explore Sale of Team
abstract: Daniel and Tanya Snyder, the embattled owners of the N.F.L. team, announced they would seek “potential transactions” related to the sale of the team.
lead_paragraph: Daniel and Tanya Snyder, the embattled owners of the Washington Commanders, said they had hired bankers to explore potentially selling the team they have owned since 1999.

headline: Biden to Give Speech Wednesday Night About Threats to Democracy
abstract: President Biden will talk about democracy and the threats election deniers pose to the voting process, one of several recent speeches about extreme far-right ideology.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden will give a speech on Wednesday night about protecting democracy and the threats that election deniers pose to the voting process.

headline: How Do You Tell the Story of Roe v. Wade?
abstract: A new exhibition at Harvard’s Schlesinger Library looks at how the 1973 Supreme Court decision reshaped American culture and politics.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — In the corner of a ground-floor gallery at Harvard’s Schlesinger Library on the History of Women in America sits a small plexiglass case, holding two cowboy hats.

headline: ‘Enola Holmes 2’ Review: A Clever Force of Nature
abstract: Millie Bobby Brown delivers an understated, playful performance in this young-adult mystery sequel.
lead_paragraph: Enola Holmes is back, and she’s ready for both her first official case as a detective and, work schedule permitting, some romance. Millie Bobby Brown delivers an understated, playful performance in the follow up to the Netflix young-adult mystery “Enola Holmes.” This time around, the director Harry Bradbeer and the screenwriter Jack Thorne forgo prolonged dialogue when Enola breaks the fourth wall, making more room for Brown’s intense looks and physical gestures to resonate.

headline: How Her Ancestors Reignited Her Return to Theater
abstract: Quiara Alegría Hudes is back with a new work, an Off Broadway production of “My Broken Language,” adapted from her 2021 memoir.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, the playwright Quiara Alegría Hudes announced that she would be taking a pause from the theater. The art form she loved so much had become a source of heartbreak: She was tired of the industry’s lack of cultural diversity, the disinterest those in power had in changing the status quo and the anxiety she felt leading up to opening night (the unexpected hiccups, the uncertainty of how a work would be received by critics and audience members).

headline: North Korea secretly shipped munitions to Russia through the Middle East and North Africa, the U.S. says.
abstract: The national security spokesman, John Kirby, said that it was unclear if the munitions had reached Russia, but that in any case, they would not “change the course of the war.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States on Wednesday accused North Korea of covertly shipping a “significant number” of artillery shells to Russia to aid its war effort in Ukraine, a sign that Moscow is increasingly turning to pariah states for military supplies as the grinding conflict persists.

headline: Thank You, Julie Powell. I Owe You.
abstract: The “Julie & Julia” author was the patron saint of amateur epicures.
lead_paragraph: Did Julie Powell catch a wave or set it in motion? Seize a moment or create it? That’s often the question about people who define their times as vividly as she did. All I know is that there was a line of demarcation, a Before Powell and an After Powell, and that following The Julie/Julia Project, which debuted in 2002, I noticed a new breed of dreamer, who came to the Big City not with a glossy headshot and dancing shoes but with a whisk and a flourless chocolate cake recipe.

headline: Ethiopia and Tigray Forces Agree to Truce in Calamitous Civil War
abstract: After two years of fighting that left hundreds of thousands dead and millions displaced and facing starvation, the surprise deal came out of peace talks convened by the African Union in South Africa.
lead_paragraph: After two years of brutal civil war, the Ethiopian government and the leadership of the northern Tigray region agreed to stop fighting on Wednesday as part of a deal that offered a path out of a conflict that has killed hundreds of thousands and displaced millions in Africa’s second-most-populous country.

headline: Doctors Warn F.D.A. of Health Risks Posed by Flawed Oxygen Devices
abstract: Especially for Black patients, inaccurate readings have imperiled care and may have contributed to deaths during the pandemic, experts told an advisory panel.
lead_paragraph: Researchers warned an expert panel of the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday that flawed readings on devices measuring oxygen levels in the blood — especially among Black and dark-skinned patients — might have contributed to deaths during the coronavirus pandemic. Panelists, in turn, urged the federal agency to raise accuracy standards and to alert doctors and consumers of the potential risks.

headline: A Chilling Crackdown at a Tehran Apartment Complex
abstract: Iran’s security forces shot at windows and threw stun grenades in a raid at the Shahrak Ekbatan complex, where a member of the feared Basij militia was killed last week, residents said.
lead_paragraph: The family of four was watching television at home in central Tehran on Sunday night when a series of big explosions outside rattled their windows. The mother grabbed her two children and ducked under the dining table.

headline: Israel’s Election: 5 Takeaways
abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu seems poised to take power again. But regardless of his fate, the election already highlights several trends that could have a lasting effect on Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The results of Israel’s fifth election since 2019 may not be confirmed until Friday, but the vote already demonstrates profound political and social shifts in Israel.

headline: Phillies Fans Are Raucous, but They Didn’t Move a Seismograph
abstract: A viral tweet shared by thousands made it look like home runs by Bryce Harper and Alec Bohm had registered as seismic events.
lead_paragraph: The love affair between Philadelphia and the Phillies has been on display throughout the postseason. With every Bryce Harper home run, Nick Castellanos sliding catch and Seranthony Domínguez strikeout, the capacity crowds at Citizens Bank Park seemed to explode with enthusiasm.

headline: George Booth, New Yorker Cartoonist of Sublime Zaniness, Dies at 96
abstract: He depicted a quirky cast of people and pets — notably his mad-as-a-hatter bull terrier, which became a reader favorite and the magazine’s unofficial mascot.
lead_paragraph: George Booth, the New Yorker cartoonist who created a world of oddballs sharing life’s chaos with a pointy-eared bull terrier that once barked a flower to death, and sometimes with a herd of cats that shredded couches and window shades between sweet naps, died on Tuesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 96.

headline: Dobby’s Grave Can Stay on a Beach in Wales, but Please Stop Giving Him Socks
abstract: After a grave site for the “Harry Potter” elf became a tourist attraction, tributes to the character prompted environmental concerns.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In one of the more tragic moments from the “Harry Potter” series — spoilers ahead if you’ve been meaning to get around to it for a decade or two — Dobby, an elf, dies in Harry Potter’s arms on an expansive beach that the creature describes, in one of his final breaths, as “such a beautiful place to be with friends.”

headline: Police Capture Suspect in Shooting of Two Rookie Officers
abstract: The New Jersey man, who was also wanted in connection with a shooting in Newark several days earlier, was charged with two counts of attempted murder.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — A day after two New Jersey police officers were shot while responding to a 911 call, a man identified as the prime suspect, who had eluded the authorities during a chaotic, daylong search, was arrested on Wednesday, according to the Essex County Prosecutor’s Office.

headline: Ways to Reverse the Decline in Math Skills
abstract: Readers address the national drop in math skills among students. Also: Jokes about the Pelosi attack; crime victims; the purpose of polling.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Steve Reich, Busy as Ever, Enters His Late Period
abstract: At 86, this eminent composer takes a surprising but still searching direction in his music, while recent projects look back on six decades of work.
lead_paragraph: Steve Reich — one of our greatest living composers, with a recognizably pulsing sound and a place in the pantheon of Minimalist pioneers — recently turned 86. It’s not the clean kind of age, usually in multiples of five, that you often see observed with a concert like Carnegie Hall’s celebration in his name on Tuesday night. But that’s the pandemic-disjointed world we live in.

headline: Trump Lawyer Expressed Worry Over False Claims of Election Fraud
abstract: John Eastman also suggested in a newly disclosed batch of emails that getting the case in front of Justice Clarence Thomas would be the most likely route to delaying certification of the 2020 results in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A conservative lawyer who was an architect of a plan to keep former President Donald J. Trump in office warned in late December 2020 that if Mr. Trump falsely swore to the courts that he had specific evidence of voter fraud in Georgia, both the president and his lawyers could face prosecution.

headline: Former Heavyweight Boxer Charged With Trafficking $1 Billion of Cocaine
abstract: Goran Gogic helped move vast amounts of cocaine from Colombia to Europe using U.S. ports, prosecutors said. One haul was among the largest cocaine seizures in U.S. history, they said.
lead_paragraph: Goran Gogic, a former professional boxer, was charged in a Brooklyn federal court last week with trafficking over 20 tons of cocaine, estimated to be worth more than $1 billion, prosecutors said.

headline: In Texas, a Battle for Hispanic Voters Moves to the Cities
abstract: Republicans are vying for Latino voters not just along the border but also in the state’s growing cities, historically a bulwark for Democrats.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — In the two years since Donald Trump drew far more votes than most Republicans ever had in South Texas, attention around the country has focused on Hispanic voters in the unique region along the border, where large-scale immigration has challenged many lower-income and often culturally conservative communities.

headline: Mike Birbiglia Can’t Get ‘Hadestown’ Out of His Head
abstract: The comedian, 44, discussed his one-man Broadway show that opens this month, his love for Taylor Swift and why he doesn’t actually hate the Y.M.C.A.
lead_paragraph: Mike Birbiglia has found that he can make a living off a personal crisis.

headline: For Elon Musk, Lessons From Friendster
abstract: This is how social networks die.
lead_paragraph: For Elon Musk, the new owner of Twitter, the demise of Friendster is a cautionary tale. Friendster, a social network founded in 2002, gained millions of users soon after it started but lost them almost as quickly, later metamorphosing into an online gaming site based in Malaysia before closing down entirely in 2018. Already by 2009, The Onion satirical news site ran a story headlined “Internet Archaeologists Find Ruins of ‘Friendster’ Civilization.”

headline: The New Covid Subvariants Don’t Really Change Anything
abstract: Infections are common, and deaths are high, but we haven’t had a truly new variant for about a year.
lead_paragraph: The Covid pandemic still isn’t over, but it has gone remarkably flat.

headline: ‘Parade’ Review: The Trial and Tragedy of Leo Frank
abstract: City Center’s gala production delves further into America’s history of violence and delivers the best-sung musical in many a New York season.
lead_paragraph: Just six months after its universally beloved Encores! revival of “Into the Woods,” New York City Center returns with another timely, excellent production about collective responsibility and loss. Smartly directed by Michael Arden, City Center’s gala presentation of “Parade,” which opened on Tuesday night and runs through Sunday, delves further into America’s history of violence and delivers the best-sung musical in many a New York season.

headline: Top Democrat Grills Capitol Police About Lawmaker Protection After Pelosi Attack
abstract: Representative Zoe Lofgren, Democrat of California and the chairwoman of the Administration Committee, raised questions in a lengthy letter to J. Thomas Manger, the Capitol Police chief.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the most senior Democrats in the House of Representatives on Wednesday demanded to know why the Capitol Police did not do more to prevent the attack on Paul Pelosi, the husband of Speaker Nancy Pelosi, at their San Francisco home last week, and questioned what the agency was doing to improve security for members of Congress and their families.

headline: Why Does Twitter Verify Some Accounts?
abstract: Elon Musk, who recently closed a deal to acquire the social media company, could soon charge a monthly fee for the blue verification badge that indicates a Twitter account is authentic.
lead_paragraph: Now that Elon Musk has completed a $44 billion buyout of Twitter, its blue profile badges, which indicate users are who they say they are, could come with a monthly fee, likely somewhere between $8 and $20 per month.

headline: It Was ‘Win Now’ vs. ‘Win Later’ at the N.F.L.’s Trade Deadline
abstract: The Vikings pulled off an in-division trade, the Ravens got some help for the middle of their defense, and the Jaguars made a bet on the future.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. trade deadline is a simple divider for some. As the only team at 7-0, the Eagles are in great shape. As the only teams with just one win, the Texans and Lions should think about next year.

headline: The Internet Still Thinks I’m Pregnant
abstract: When Amy Pittman had a miscarriage, she grieved her loss — and tried to move on. But the internet wouldn’t let her.
lead_paragraph: Amy Pittman was thrilled about her first pregnancy. She immediately downloaded a pregnancy app, and she was charmed when it showed her baby had grown from the size of a lavender bud to the size of a chocolate chip. When she miscarried, she deleted the app and the chocolate chip avatar, but the internet never caught on. Seven months later, Amy received a sample of baby formula. Although she had deleted the pregnancy app, the baby formula company didn’t know — and thought she was a new mom. She laughed — what else could she do — and loved the idea that her chocolate chip was out there, trolling the internet.

headline: Trump Settles With Protesters Who Said His Bodyguards Attacked Them
abstract: One of the demonstrators said a bodyguard struck him on the head outside Trump Tower in 2015. Terms of the deal were not released.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump on Wednesday reached a settlement in a civil case brought by protesters who said they were attacked by his bodyguards in 2015, a deal that will spare the former president and his family business the prospect of two simultaneous trials in New York State court.

headline: Campaigns Pay Influencers to Carry Their Messages, Skirting Political Ad Rules
abstract: Campaigns are using social media influencers as a way to reach young and diverse voters, a novel and mostly unregulated strategy. Some are even spreading the message through dating apps.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In between posts showing himself running ladder drills and lifting weights, Ky’Wuan Dukes, a 20-year-old wide receiver at Johnson C. Smith University, tells his 21,000 Instagram followers to vote. He has also discussed gun control and abortion rights, as part of a campaign he is paid to participate in by NextGen America, a Democratic political action committee and advocacy group.

headline: Stocks Slide as Fed Leaves Investors Unsure About Path Ahead
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said the central bank “still has a ways to go” before it will be done raising interest rates, and that rates may go higher than previously anticipated.
lead_paragraph: Stocks seesawed on Wednesday, but eventually ended the day lower, after Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, dashed investors’ hopes that an end to the central bank’s rate increases may soon be over.

headline: Taylor Swift’s ‘Midnights’: Listener Mailbag
abstract: The New York Times pop music team had its say; now a new panel answers questions about the blockbuster album.
lead_paragraph: The commercial success of Taylor Swift’s “Midnights” has verged on the comical. In its first week of release, it moved the equivalent of almost 1.6 million units, the most for any album since Adele’s “25” in 2015 (which didn’t start out available on streaming services). More than half a million of those sales were vinyl albums, a new record that shows her power in physical media. She is the first artist to occupy the whole Top 10 of the Billboard Hot 100, a new record that highlights the album’s first-week streaming strength.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Abbott Elementary’ and More
abstract: I am a reporting fellow on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I am a reporting fellow on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching and listening to.

headline: The R.S.V. Surge
abstract: A lot of Americans are still in the dark about the virus and what to do about it.
lead_paragraph: A drastic and unusually early spike in infections caused by the respiratory syncytial virus, known as R.S.V., is overwhelming pediatric units across the U.S. Patients are experiencing long waits for treatment and hospital systems are rearranging staffing and resources to meet the sudden demand.

headline: Black Faith Leaders in Georgia Speak Out Against Herschel Walker
abstract: The group has long been a highly influential voice on politics in their communities and played a key role in mobilizing Black voters.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — While Georgia’s Black faith leaders walk the line between their religious and political convictions in the last few days before the midterms, some have turned sharply to amplifying their criticisms of the state’s Republican Senate candidate, Herschel Walker.

headline: U.S. Says Russians Discussed Tactical Nukes
abstract: Plus, a look at Kyiv plunged in darkness from rolling blackouts.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: A Group Raised Money to Push Adams’s Agenda. Much of It Went to One Man.
abstract: A political action committee has given more money to its founder and his charter school than to candidates aligned with Mayor Eric Adams.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, with Eric Adams’s election as mayor of New York City all but assured, a key ally set up a political action committee as a way for the mayor-in-waiting’s supporters to advance his agenda on public safety and education.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: A Truce in Tigray
abstract: Plus North Korea fired a record number of missiles, and Russia rejoined the grail deal.
lead_paragraph: Ethiopia’s government and rebel forces in the northern Tigray region will end their brutal civil war. A team of mediators said the two parties had agreed to “a permanent cessation of hostilities.”

headline: 28 Cheap Thanksgiving Recipes for an Easy, Impressive Feast
abstract: You don’t have to spend a lot to create a spectacular, inflation-friendly holiday menu.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving, for a lot of us, means a glistening table practically buckling under the weight of the food: a burnished bird, overflowing side dishes, every kind of pie and several bottles of wine. But with food costs soaring and continued supply chain issues, this year’s feast might look a little different. How do you create a feeling of plenty when the dollars in your bank account are anything but?

headline: Tumblr Says Clothing Is Optional Again
abstract: Reversing a 2018 ban, the company said that nudity and “mature subject matter” would be allowed. But “visual depictions of sexually explicit acts” remain off limits.
lead_paragraph: Tumblr, the once-popular social media platform, is again allowing nudity, four years after announcing a ban on explicit content.

headline: ‘That’s How You Create a Dynasty. Guys Like That.’
abstract: Jose Altuve, Yuli Gurriel and Alex Bregman have been the constants for an Astros team that never stops evolving. With one more win they can secure a second World Series title.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — It was at an All-Star Game several years ago that Justin Verlander was talking to CC Sabathia about life with the Yankees. Players often are curious about the inner workings of other teams, and this was when the vaunted “Core Four” — Derek Jeter, Jorge Posada, Andy Pettitte and Mariano Rivera — were still the heart and soul of the Yankees.

headline: Kansas, Looking to Fend Off N.C.A.A., Suspends Bill Self
abstract: The University of Kansas said Self, its men’s basketball coach, would miss four games. An N.C.A.A. panel is still reviewing allegations stemming from a federal probe into corruption in the sport.
lead_paragraph: Bill Self, the coach of the reigning Division I champion Kansas men’s basketball team, will begin the season with a four-game suspension as part of the university’s self-imposed punishments in response to its ongoing case with the N.C.A.A. that emerged from a sport-wide corruption and bribery scandal.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Has America Outgrown Affirmative Action?
abstract: If the conservative Supreme Court majority’s reaction to oral arguments on Monday was any indication, race-conscious admissions could soon be a thing of the past.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.

headline: Russia Rejoins Grain Deal, but Warns It Could Pull Out Again
abstract: The agreement allows Ukraine, a major food producer, to export grain by sea, easing the threat of famine in other countries.
lead_paragraph: Russia on Wednesday rejoined an agreement allowing the shipment of Ukrainian grain through the Black Sea, one of the few areas of cooperation amid the war in Ukraine, easing uncertainty over the fate of a deal seen as crucial to preventing famine in other parts of the world.

headline: Lawyers Who Advanced Trump’s Election Challenges Return for Midterms
abstract: Donald Trump’s push to overturn his 2020 loss was roundly rejected by courts. Now dozens of lawyers who argued the cases are working for Republican campaigns and groups.
lead_paragraph: At least three dozen lawyers and law firms that advanced Donald J. Trump’s failed attempt to overturn the 2020 election are now working for Republican candidates, parties and other groups, filing lawsuits and other complaints that could lay the groundwork for challenging the results of midterm elections, according to a New York Times analysis of campaign finance records and legal filings.

headline: Biden Warns That ‘Big Lie’ Republicans Imperil American Democracy
abstract: In a prime-time address, President Biden condemned election violence and voter intimidation just days before Tuesday’s midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden issued an impassioned condemnation of his predecessor and other Republicans on Wednesday night for encouraging political violence, voter intimidation and “the Big Lie,” framing next week’s elections as a pivotal test of American democracy.

headline: Attorneys General Sue to Stop Dividend Tied to Kroger-Albertsons Deal
abstract: The suit could portend other regulatory battles to come as the supermarket chains look to close their nearly $25 billion merger.
lead_paragraph: Three attorneys general filed a federal lawsuit on Wednesday against the supermarket chains Kroger and Albertsons, seeking to prevent Albertsons from going forward with a dividend payment to its shareholders associated with its proposed $24.6 billion sale to Kroger.

headline: Rijksmuseum’s Vermeer Show to Include Recently Disputed Work
abstract: The museum will present “Girl With a Flute” as a Vermeer work in an exhibition next year despite a contrary finding by the National Gallery of Art, which owns the painting.
lead_paragraph: The Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam announced on Tuesday that among the treasured works to be featured in its expansive exhibition on Johannes Vermeer next year would be a painting, “Girl With a Flute,” that has for years been embraced as one of the rare surviving works by a painter considered one of history’s finest.

headline: Oath Keepers Leader Sought to Get Message to Trump After Jan. 6
abstract: One of the government’s final witnesses in the seditious conspiracy trial of members of the far-right group described attempts by Stewart Rhodes to urge Donald J. Trump to keep his grip on power.
lead_paragraph: Four days after the storming of the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, Stewart Rhodes, the leader of the Oath Keepers militia, held a secret meeting in the parking lot of a Texas electronics store.

headline: Scenes from the final campaign sprint.
Judge Rules Against Harvard in Case on Fumbled Insurance Filing
abstract: The university’s blunder means it cannot use a $15 million policy to pay for its legal expenses in defending a challenge to its affirmative action program.
