lead_paragraph: It was a week of beginnings. The new David Geffen Hall at Lincoln Center held an opening night gala on Oct. 26 with a lively concert that featured Alicia Keys, Renée Fleming, Vanessa Williams and the New York Philharmonic. Mayor Eric Adams gave opening remarks at the cocktail reception, which was followed by a dinner that took over two tiers.

headline: Houston’s ‘Veteran’ Rookie Wins World Series M.V.P.
abstract: Jeremy Peña had big shoes to fill when Carlos Correa left the Houston Astros. Peña responded by being named the most valuable player of the A.L.C.S. and the World Series.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Where would the Houston Astros be without Jeremy Peña?

headline: Fact-Checking the Misleading Claim About 87,000 Tax Agents
abstract: The claim, which has been debunked numerous times, has resurged ahead of the midterm elections. Here’s why it’s still wrong.
lead_paragraph: As the midterm campaigns come to a close, Republican lawmakers are seizing on misleading claims warning that Democrats are recruiting an army of tax auditors, finding new resonance in an assertion debunked months ago.

headline: Yuval Noah Harari Unspools the Story of Human History — for Kids
abstract: In “Unstoppable Us,” he presents the provocative ideas that drove his 2015 best seller, “Sapiens,” without dumbing them down.
lead_paragraph: Where are you from?

headline: A Key Polling Warning Sign Has Dimmed Since September
abstract: The emergence of Republican-leaning pollsters has reduced the risk that polling averages will overestimate Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Way back in September, we noticed a warning sign in the polls: Democrats were showing strength in exactly the places where the polls overestimated their chances in 2020.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Who Are All Those Celebrities at the Weird Al Pool Party? A Guide
abstract: We break down that star-studded scene from “Weird: The Al Yankovic Story,” the sorta kinda true portrait of the pop star’s life, now on the Roku Channel.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how Weird Al Yankovic, the accordion-playing king of parody, would like you to think “Another One Rides the Bus” was written: At a pool party, the radio personality Wolfman Jack challenged him to devise a sendup of Queen’s “Another One Bites the Dust” on the spot.

headline: Macy’s Plans to Invest Millions to Fund Minority-Owned Businesses
abstract: The department store chain is investing $30 million over five years to support entrepreneurs from underrepresented groups in the retail industry.
lead_paragraph: Robin Wilson has experienced plenty of success since starting her home textile business, Clean Design Home, in 2000. Her hypoallergenic products have been sold at Bed Bath & Beyond, and she has fulfilled large orders for a hotel chain. Her wares are also available at 50 Macy’s locations across the United States, which has resulted in millions of dollars worth of sales.

headline: Developing Nations Have a Message at Global Climate Talks: Polluters, Pay Up
abstract: Poor countries facing climate hazards want the United States and other industrialized nations to compensate them for the harm caused by greenhouse gases.
lead_paragraph: In Pakistan, flooding this summer killed 1,700 people and left one-third of the country underwater. In Fiji, entire villages are retreating inland to escape rising seas.  In Kenya, persistent drought has killed livestock and devastated livelihoods.

headline: His Roman Holiday Lasted a Lifetime
abstract: “Just Passing Through” collects the diaries and photographs of Milton Gendel, who lived large, bought plenty and schmoozed with the glamorous.
lead_paragraph: If Paris is a moveable feast, as Hemingway would tell every college junior on a gap year, then Rome is a stately banquet at which guests linger perhaps longer than they intended. The photographer, critic and salonist Milton Gendel was one. He arrived there on a Fulbright scholarship at 30, and more or less stayed for almost 70 more years.

headline: Russia Reactivates Its Trolls and Bots Ahead of Tuesday’s Midterms
abstract: Researchers have identified a series of Russian information operations to influence American elections and, perhaps, erode support for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2022 midterm elections for the latest news and updates.

headline: Could India Help Broker Peace in Ukraine?
abstract: India has good relations with both Russia and the West, and seeks a more muscular role in geopolitics. The biggest obstacle is that Ukrainians and Russians don’t want to talk.
lead_paragraph: In July, when a critical deal was brokered by the United Nations and Turkey to free up millions of pounds of desperately needed Ukrainian grain, India played an important behind-the-scenes role in helping sell the plan to Russia, which had been blockading the grain ships.

headline: How Molly Jong-Fast Tweeted Her Way to Liberal Media Stardom
abstract: She wasn’t a political expert. But her Trump-era angst found a following among Democrats — and even the White House is interested.
lead_paragraph: Molly Jong-Fast had just finished interviewing Vice President Kamala Harris for her podcast when she hopped in an Uber S.U.V. headed to the Century, the Manhattan literary club where she was throwing a book party for the media critic Margaret Sullivan, a friend. The editors of Rolling Stone and Vanity Fair greeted her with hugs. The owner of The New Republic, Win McCormack, stopped to say hello.

headline: Big Tobacco Heralds a Healthier World While Fighting Its Arrival
abstract: The industry continues to fight efforts to restrict certain products, like spending heavily to urge California voters to overturn a law banning tobacco flavors.
lead_paragraph: For decades, public health advocates chipped away at the influence of Big Tobacco with measures aimed at discouraging cigarette use. But the bitter legal and political battles were just a prelude to the unfolding climactic clash that could determine the fate of smoking and whether these companies adapt or falter.

headline: Somalis Are Going Hungry. Their Government Isn’t Calling It a Famine.
abstract: Humanitarian groups say Somalia’s leaders are resisting a formal declaration of famine that could unlock aid and save lives.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — A severely malnourished child is admitted to a clinic in Somalia on average every minute of every day. With crops and animals decimated in the worst drought to blanket the nation in four decades, millions of Somalis stand on the brink of starvation in an unprecedented humanitarian catastrophe.

headline: Winding Down With LaKeith Stanfield
abstract: The “Atlanta” actor is juggling several projects, but he still tries to have a little fun.
lead_paragraph: LaKeith Stanfield was settling into his hotel in Atlanta at around 10 p.m. He’d just wrapped a full day of filming for his upcoming movie “Haunted Mansion,” set to release next summer.

headline: What Happens When Crypto Meets Ted Lasso
abstract: A group of American cryptocurrency investors is trying to turn an obscure English soccer club into “the internet’s team,” with a global following of crypto enthusiasts.
lead_paragraph: Preston Johnson, a soft-spoken cryptocurrency millionaire with a long, bushy, brown beard, leaned forward in his seat, fists clenched, surveying his empire. He wasn’t perched on a mega yacht or enjoying any of the other ostentatious perks of crypto wealth. The setting was humbler: a small soccer stadium in a town about 30 miles south of London, where the lowest-ranked team in England’s professional leagues was battling for survival.

headline: Can Republicans and Democrats Find a Way Forward on Immigration?
abstract: Any hope for immigration reform on undocumented Dreamers, border security or legal immigration will likely hinge on compromise, something that has eluded lawmakers for decades.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A drug needle goes into a person’s arm; an adult and child walk through a graveyard; and footage of migrants walking along a sandy stretch of a border wall, in Yuma, Arizona, streams while ominous music plays in the background of this video.

headline: In Affluent Greenwich, It’s Republicans vs. ‘Trumplicans’
abstract: The Connecticut suburb was once home to George Bush and has historically been a moderate conservative stronghold. But new hard-liners are on the attack, galvanized by the culture wars.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: A ‘Legend’ Finally Gets His Moment
abstract: Dusty Baker’s first World Series title as a manager is a crowning achievement for a beloved player, manager and person.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — For all of Darren Baker’s life, his father had chased a championship. That was Dusty Baker’s job, from San Francisco to Chicago to Cincinnati to Washington to Houston, and he always did it quite well. He just never got the ending right.

headline: Republicans Are Doubling Down on Trumpism. It’s Going to Work.
abstract: In 2016 the Republican Party made a bet on a controversial political novice. Now a party made in his image is about to win again.
lead_paragraph: If Republicans have many things going for them in next week’s elections — an economy that’s like a millstone around Democrats’ necks, fear in the electorate about crime and a chaotic immigration system, President Biden’s low approval ratings — they are also taking what appear to be some enormous risks: having candidates on the ballot seen by many as too inexperienced, extreme or scandal burdened to win their races.

headline: ‘White Lotus’ and the Plight of the American Man
abstract: HBO’s “The White Lotus” questions modern masculinity.
lead_paragraph: What the hell happened to the great American man? How did he go from swashbuckling hero of his own story to tragicomic villain in everyone else’s? One minute, he’s Superman, Steve McQueen, Sylvester Stallone. The next, he is everything wrong with America.

headline: Republicans Have Made It Very Clear What They Want to Do if They Win Congress
abstract: Here comes the G.O.P.’s calamity caucus
lead_paragraph: What Republicans are offering, if they win the 2022 elections, is not conservatism. It is crisis. More accurately, it is crises. A debt-ceiling crisis. An election crisis. And a body blow to the government’s efforts to prepare for a slew of other crises we know are coming.

headline: Why the F.B.I. Is So Far Behind on Cybercrime
abstract: The bureau’s outmoded approach is one of the most important factors behind the stunning rise of cybercrime.
lead_paragraph: There are many factors behind the stunning rise of ransomware. Our reporting found that one of the most important is the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s outmoded approach to computer crime targeting people and institutions in the United States.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Taken Under Fascism, Spain’s “Stolen Babies” Are Learning the Truth’
abstract: Thousands of Spanish children were taken from hospitals and sold to wealthy Catholic families. This is Ana Belén Pintado’s story.
lead_paragraph: The phenomenon of babies stolen from hospitals in Spain, once shrouded in secrecy, is now being spoken about.

headline: Democrats, Don’t Despair. There Are Bright Spots for Our Party.
abstract: Victory may all depend on “candidate quality.”
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party and Senator Mitch McConnell rarely see eye to eye on anything. But if Democrats hold the line in the elections on Tuesday and keep control of the Senate — and we still have a shot — it will come down to candidate quality.

headline: The Week in Business: The Fed Stays Its Course
abstract: Job growth slowed last month, but remained strong. Elon Musk cleaned house. And the economy will be a big issue in the midterms.
lead_paragraph: When the Federal Reserve raised interest rates another three-quarters of a point on Wednesday, the fourth-consecutive increase of that size, the central bank sent mixed messages about its path. The policy statement accompanying the rate decision emphasized that officials would soon slow down the increases. But Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, seemed to communicate the opposite, saying at a news conference that it was “premature to think about pausing” the Fed’s aggressive campaign to tame inflation. Investors liked one of these messages more than the other: The policy memo briefly pushed up stocks on Wall Street; Mr. Powell’s comments sent them falling. Fed officials have expressed concern about doing too little to fight inflation, but they are also acutely aware of the risks of doing too much. On Wednesday, Mr. Powell acknowledged that the window for a so-called soft landing that would avoid tipping the economy into a recession had “narrowed.”

headline: What’s at Stake
abstract: Tuesday’s elections will determine the next two years of President Biden’s agenda — and shape the future of democracy.
lead_paragraph: To understand the importance and consequences of Tuesday’s midterm elections, I spoke to Astead Herndon, a political reporter who has been covering this election cycle for the Times podcast “The Run-Up.”

headline: Why Ashton Kutcher is running his first, and maybe last, marathon.
abstract: He has raised more than $1 million for his nonprofit, Thorn, and he also wants to beat Sean Combs’s time.
lead_paragraph: For Ashton Kutcher’s first marathon — and perhaps his last — there was only one choice: New York City.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 7, 2022
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Taiwan’s Bomb Shelters: ‘A Space for Life. And a Space for Death.’
abstract: Preparing for war over hundreds of years has left a mark on the island, with its hundreds of bomb shelters. Some are being turned into cultural oases.
lead_paragraph: KEELUNG, Taiwan — Visitors to Keelung, a mountainous port city on Taiwan’s northern coast, might reasonably think that the white wall at the back of Shi Hui-hua’s breakfast shop is, well, a wall. Only a few air vents suggest that there might be something on the other side.

headline: Myra Melford Builds Anew With an All-Star, All-Woman Quintet
abstract: The pianist’s latest group fills its recent album “For the Love of Fire and Water” with idiosyncratic life.
lead_paragraph: Draft up a list of today’s most inventive and respected players in the realm of what tends to be called improvised music (or creative music or free jazz) and you’ll inevitably name the players in the pianist Myra Melford’s Fire and Water Quintet: the saxophonist Ingrid Laubrock, the guitarist Mary Halvorson, the cellist Tomeka Reid and the percussionist Lesley Mok.

headline: The Case for ‘Hibernating’ During Winter
abstract: Sleep is good for our bodies and our souls.
lead_paragraph: As the days shorten and the dark hours stretch, every impulse in me is to slow down, get under a blanket and stay there till spring. In a 2020 piece for The Atlantic exploring the possibility of human hibernation, James Hamblin wrote that as the winter months come upon us, “Maybe our minds and bodies are telling us we’re not supposed to be fighting so hard.” As the New York winter hardened, he resolved: “It is absolutely ridiculous that we don’t hibernate.” Hamblin makes clear that we can’t actually hibernate all winter long, though short periods of human hibernation are theoretically possible and could be useful for certain medical treatments. Still, his basic point is spot on.

headline: Marcel Hug and Susannah Scaroni win the wheelchair races in record fashion.
abstract: Both Hug and Scaroni set course records in their races.
lead_paragraph: Marcel Hug of Switzerland won his fifth New York City Marathon men’s wheelchair title by shattering the course record convincingly, while Susannah Scaroni of the United States grabbed her first title in the women’s division and also set a course record.

headline: Here are the celebrities running this year’s marathon.
abstract: Ashton Kutcher, Ellie Kemper and Lauren Ridloff join a group of former athletes and “Bachelor” stars running in the New York City Marathon.
lead_paragraph: Among the delights of the New York City Marathon is its democratizing effect, as New Yorkers and far-flung visitors run alongside professional athletes and celebrities.

headline: In Final Push for Votes, Both Parties Court Black Men
abstract: Democrats and Republicans see Black male voters as key in tight races. Most support Democrats, but some see Republicans as offering a better shot at upward mobility.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Williamson comes from a long line of Georgia Democrats. Growing up, his parents voted Democrat, his grandmother voted Democrat. So did most of his friends and neighbors. And for a while, Mr. Williamson did, too.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Dooymaaj salad, cheesy kimchi noodles and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I love Kay Chun’s tofu and cabbage stir-fry with basil (above), a subtle recipe with a nice mustardy kick. But what I want for dinner is a punchy, freestyled variation on that dish with bacon in place of the basil, and a sauce of oyster and soy sauces, water, cornstarch and a sprinkle of sugar.

headline: Police Remove Bicyclist From the Marathon Course
abstract: As the elite runner Daniel do Nascimento crossed the Queensboro Bridge, New York City Police pulled a man with a backpack on a bicycle off the course.
lead_paragraph: As the elite runner Daniel do Nascimento crossed the Queensboro Bridge, New York City Police pulled a man with a backpack on a bicycle off the course.

headline: Ela Bhatt, Advocate for Women Workers in India, Dies at 89
abstract: The cooperative she founded has helped millions of women who had never before had a safety net. “They were,” she said, “the poorest among the poor.”
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Ela Bhatt, a champion of gender justice and equality who secured protections for millions of Indian women in the work force and helped them become self-reliant, died on Nov. 2 in Ahmedabad, India. She was 89.

headline: Climate Conference to Debate Whether Rich Nations Will Pay for Damage
abstract: For the first time, the conference agenda will officially include the divisive issue of compensation by large nations responsible for the bulk of emissions.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the COP27 Climate Summit in Egypt.

headline: A Climate Change Skeptic’s Change of Heart
abstract: Responses to Bret Stephens’s column about his new views after a visit to Greenland. Also: Homelessness in L.A.; political extremists; divorce and politics.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Confidence, Anxiety and a Scramble for Votes Two Days Before the Midterms
abstract: As candidates made their closing arguments on Sunday, Democrats braced for potential losses even in traditionally blue corners of the country while Republicans predicted a red wave.
lead_paragraph: The turbulent midterm campaign rolled through its final weekend on Sunday as voters — buffeted by record inflation, worries about their personal safety and fears about the fundamental stability of American democracy — showed clear signs of preparing to reject Democratic control of Washington and embrace divided government.

headline: What is the prize money for the New York City Marathon?
abstract: The men’s and women’s winners will receive $100,000. The wheelchair winners got less — but made up for some of it with bonuses.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot of prize money to be doled out to this year’s New York City Marathon winners.

headline: Russian state media confirms that a top general is no longer in his post.
abstract: Col. Gen. Alexander Lapin had been publicly bashed by a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin over his performance in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The senior Russian military commander who was publicly bashed by a close ally of President Vladimir V. Putin over his performance in Ukraine is no longer in his post, according to Russian state media, in what appeared to be the latest in a string of personnel shake-ups as Moscow grapples with open criticism of its setbacks on the battlefield.

headline: Indigenous Voters, Gaining Influence, Look to Mobilize
abstract: Having swayed a presidential election and increased their representation in Congress, Indigenous voters are poised to help decide the outcome of the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — Tesla Cox’s eyes filled with tears as she thought about watching her state elect its first Alaska Native to Congress this year, and what it could mean for the future.

headline: N.Y.C. Marathon Runners Helped Off the Course After Collapsing
abstract: Runners in the New York City Marathon endured unseasonably warm weather, with temperatures in the mid-70s.
lead_paragraph: Runners in the New York City Marathon endured unseasonably warm weather, with temperatures in the mid-70s.

headline: How to Run the New York City Marathon
abstract: There are several ways to get one of the 50,000 spots in the New York City Marathon. Here’s a list of the possible options.
lead_paragraph: You’ve watched the New York City Marathon runners. Maybe you know some. Maybe you want to join the party and run the marathon yourself next year. So how do you get to be one of the 50,000 runners lining up on the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge in 2023?

headline: Michael Basman, Chess Master Known for ‘Bad’ Openings, Dies at 76
abstract: He was known for playing some of the least respected openings, including the Grob, the Creepy Crawly or the St. George Defense. But he was often successful.
lead_paragraph: Michael Basman, an English international chess master who was known for playing some of the most irregular and least respected openings — often with success — died on Oct. 26 in Carshalton, a suburb of London. He was 76.

headline: Runners and Spectators Celebrate the New York City Marathon
abstract: Crowds cheered on more than 50,000 runners racing through all five boroughs of New York.
lead_paragraph: Crowds cheered on more than 50,000 runners racing through all five boroughs of New York.

headline: As Midterms Near, Biden Faces a Nation as Polarized as Ever
abstract: President Biden had hoped to preside over a moment of reconciliation after the turmoil of the Trump years. But the fever of polarizing politics has not broken ahead of Tuesday’s midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. — Before heading into a community center for a campaign rally the other day, President Biden stopped to speak to the overflow crowd that could not squeeze into the small facility.

headline: Twitter Is Said to Delay Changes to Check Mark Badges Until After Midterms
abstract: Users and employees had raised concerns that Elon Musk’s plan to give check marks to those who paid a monthly fee could be misused to sow discord.
lead_paragraph: Twitter is delaying the rollout of verification check marks to subscribers of its new $7.99 a month subscription service until after Tuesday’s midterm elections, according to an internal post viewed by The New York Times and two people with knowledge of the decision.

headline: How Fast Celebrities Ran the 2022 New York City Marathon
abstract: Now you can compare yourself against Ashton Kutcher.
lead_paragraph: Once again, the New York City Marathon offered ordinary runners a rare opportunity: a chance to measure up to (and perhaps beat) celebrity runners like the actor Ashton Kutcher or former New York Giants running back Tiki Barber.

headline: Brooklyn Couple Throws 35th Annual Marathon Block Party
abstract: The couple served breakfast and hired a D.J. to work the crowd and cheer on the runners.
lead_paragraph: The couple served breakfast and hired a D.J. to work the crowd and cheer on the runners.

headline: Dancing Near the Edge of a Lost Democracy
abstract: Republicans have turned doubt about the 2020 election — and about the legitimacy of any elections they lose — into a test of faith.
lead_paragraph: One of the most sobering statements from President Biden’s speech last week on protecting democracy was one that might well have gone unnoticed by many who heard it or read about it.

headline: At 11th-Hour Rally, Biden Pushes for Hochul in Crucial N.Y. Election
abstract: The campaign visits by President Biden and Bill Clinton show that the governor’s race, once a worry-free contest for Democrats, may be up for grabs.
lead_paragraph: Leaning on presidents past and present, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York barnstormed around the New York City area this weekend, furiously trying to stave off a major upset by focusing on areas where high Democratic voter turnout will be crucial for her chances.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: COP27 Begins
abstract: Plus India could be key to peace in Ukraine and a child’s death in China sparks new outrage over the zero Covid policy.
lead_paragraph: The 27th annual U.N. climate talks, known as COP27, began yesterday. At the top of the agenda for developing countries is financing for loss and damage: Who will pay for the costs of a warming world?

headline: Trump May Pose a Test No Special Counsel Can Pass
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump’s apparent plan to soon announce his candidacy is challenging Attorney General Merrick B. Garland’s desire to show that the Justice Dept. can operate above partisanship.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Merrick B. Garland has long said that the Justice Department is up to the task of investigating former President Donald J. Trump, whose final weeks in office included his supporters attacking the Capitol as he refused to acknowledge his election loss.

headline: Two Weeks From World Cup, U.S. Star Counts the Minutes
abstract: Christian Pulisic’s role as a late-game substitute for Chelsea has not been the perfect preparation for Qatar. But his form is not the only question facing the United States.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of Mexico vs. Argentina and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: Reality of Irving’s Import to Nike: ‘They Can Drop Him’
abstract: Kyrie Irving’s relationship with the athletic apparel giant has been lucrative, but his recent post about an antisemitic movie has led the company to suspend its dealings with him.
lead_paragraph: Nike is facing plenty of challenges this year.

headline: The New York City Marathon: A 26.2-Mile Fashion Show
abstract: It’s New York City. No one is here to be subtle. Here’s what some runners wore for the city’s largest block party.
lead_paragraph: Before 50,000 runners are unleashed onto the streets of New York, they congregate in Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island and face an hourslong wait. In those early hours, marathon runners linger, grapple with pre-race jitters and admire what others are wearing.

headline: Russia Looks to Private Militia to Secure a Victory in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: Wagner Group forces launched attacks from several directions on the city of Bakhmut, though analysts said seizing it would yield little strategic value.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of unexpected battlefield setbacks for Russia, the war in Ukraine on Sunday delivered another surprise: the emergence of a former Russian convict and onetime hot-dog seller as perhaps the Kremlin’s best hope for a small, face-saving military victory.

headline: Meta Is Said to Plan Significant Job Cuts This Week
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, said last month that many “teams will stay flat or shrink over the next year” as his company faces economic challenges.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Meta plans to lay off employees this week, three people with knowledge of the situation said, adding that the job cuts were set to be the most significant at the company since it was founded in 2004.

headline: What We Learned From Week 9 in the N.F.L.
abstract: The Jets’ defense had a counter for the Bills’ top-rated offense, Tom Brady stirred up some old magic, and Joe Burrow got a lift from Bengals not named Ja’Marr Chase.
lead_paragraph: The power atop the A.F.C. has constantly shifted among 10 or so playoff-quality teams fighting for just seven spots, but each week the Buffalo Bills have made the most consistent case of being worthy of a top seed. That changed on Sunday with an eyebrow-raising 20-17 loss to the Jets in which Josh Allen’s options were decidedly earthbound.

headline: Now It Makes Sense!
abstract: Jill Singer makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Monday, solvers, and welcome to a new week of New York Times Crossword puzzles! Today’s offering comes from Jill Singer, a debut constructor whose theme is sure to make you smile at the weird ways humans use metaphors to express emotions.

headline: Amazon Considers Disclaimer to Antisemitic Film Irving Shared Online
abstract: The company said it was working with the Anti-Defamation League to potentially add language to the page that viewers see before buying or renting the film.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Nets and the Anti-Defamation League sent a letter to Amazon asking the company to address the “deeply and unequivocally antisemitic” documentary and related book at the heart of the Brooklyn Nets guard Kyrie Irving’s suspension. The company said it was working with the A.D.L. to explore adding a disclaimer to the film.

headline: For Fetterman, Campaign Trail Doubles as Road to Recovery
abstract: After a stroke and an uneven debate against his rival, Mehmet Oz, John Fetterman is leaning into his health challenges, to cheering crowds, as he campaigns for Senate in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: COLLEGEVILLE, Pa. — John Fetterman was getting fired up at a campaign rally on Thursday evening, vigorously bashing his Republican opponent, Mehmet Oz, as a “fraud,” when the lingering effects of the stroke he had in May abruptly surfaced.

headline: Jets Turn Up the Pressure on the Bills in the A.F.C. East With a Win
abstract: Josh Allen was sacked five times and threw two interceptions against the Jets, who climbed to within a half-game of their division rivals.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — This season, the Buffalo Bills had gone on the road and defeated the Los Angeles Rams, the defending Super Bowl champions; the Baltimore Ravens, led by a former league most valuable player; and Kansas City, the team responsible for ending the Bills’ 2021 season in heartbreaking fashion in the divisional round of the playoffs.

headline: Review: ‘You Will Get Sick’ Tells the Untellable, for a Price
abstract: In a new Off Broadway play, Linda Lavin shines as a woman paid to say what an ailing young man cannot.
lead_paragraph: Disease, dying and death are usually depicted as wretched or bloody onstage. We’re meant to cry or recoil.

headline: Trump-DeSantis Rift Grows, With Dueling Rallies in Florida
abstract: The Republican Party’s top two stars are campaigning, separately, in the midterms’ last days.
lead_paragraph: SUN CITY CENTER, Fla. — Former President Donald J. Trump hasn’t endorsed Gov. Ron DeSantis this year because, as he has explained, his fellow Floridian never asked. Mr. DeSantis didn’t attend the Trump rally on Sunday in Miami, his allies said, because he wasn’t personally invited.

headline: Apple Could Be Short of iPhones Because of Factory Disruptions in China
abstract: The company said Covid-19 restrictions were slowing production of the company’s new phones ahead of the holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Weeks after expressing optimism about the global economy and its business, Apple on Sunday warned that its sales would fall short of expectations because a key iPhone factory in China had been shut down by a coronavirus outbreak.

headline: Your Pies Have Arrived
abstract: Apple, pecan, pumpkin, lemon meringue: They’re all here, as you’ve never seen them before.
lead_paragraph: Apple, pecan, pumpkin, lemon meringue: They’re all here, as you’ve never seen them before.

headline: What to Know About Irving’s Antisemitic Movie Post and the Fallout
abstract: Irving, the Nets guard, has faced backlash since he promoted an antisemitic film on social media last month.
lead_paragraph: Nets guard Kyrie Irving continues to face backlash for posting a link on Twitter to an antisemitic film last month.

headline: Can North Carolina Finish the Job? Or Will the Big Ten Break Through?
abstract: The Tar Heels are ranked No. 1 after losing last season’s final to Kansas. And Gonzaga figures to be a contender again with Drew Timme among the star big men who’ve returned to college.
lead_paragraph: More than seven months after Kansas stormed back from a 15-point halftime deficit to beat North Carolina in the Division I men’s basketball championship game, a new season will begin Monday night.

headline: South Carolina and Stanford Headline Talent at the Top
abstract: High expectations, a missing star and some upstart teams with chances to make a deep run.
lead_paragraph: A new women’s college basketball season will tip off on Monday, and the same teams that dominated the last two campaigns will be favored to do so again.

headline: No Corrections: Nov. 7, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 7, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Indigenous Voters, Gaining Influence, Aim to Mobilize
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, Nov. 7, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Our next steps are not just getting our people to go and vote, but getting our people to be the people that people vote for.”

headline: Next to Lambeau Field, a Place Where Cheeseheads Come Together
abstract: In Green Bay, the field at the mixed-use development next to the Packers’ home stadium was designed as a place for football-obsessed fans to celebrate, win or lose.
lead_paragraph: In Titletown, games of catch have an open invite.

headline: Even as Challenges Mount, Europeans Stick by Ukraine
abstract: Inflation and anxiety over nuclear weapons may be eating into some popular support for the war, but key governments remain insulated from the pressures for now.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The high cost of living is provoking strikes, protests and widespread grumbling. Talk about nuclear weapons has heightened anxieties and encouraged some to demand rapid negotiations. And President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is wooing politicians, including many from populist parties on the right and the left who have flirted with him in the past.

headline: It Took Two Weeks to Call Every State in 2020. This Is When to Expect Results This Year.
abstract: We surveyed every state about their plans for counting votes in the 2022 election.
lead_paragraph: We surveyed every state about their plans for counting votes in the 2022 election.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: The 27th annual U.N. climate talks opened yesterday in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: Developing countries face irreversible damage from climate change but have done little to cause the crisis. And they are demanding compensation from the parties they see as responsible: wealthier nations that have emitted half of all heat-trapping gases since 1850 and created pollution that is dangerously heating the planet.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Atlanta’ and ‘Black Panther’
abstract: The series staring Donald Glover concludes its fourth and final season. And the Marvel blockbuster airs on FX as the sequel premieres in theaters.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 7-13. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Israel’s New Kingmaker Is a Dangerous Extremist, and He’s Here to Stay
abstract: Itamar Ben-Gvir used to be seen as a dangerous radical. Now he is mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Late Tuesday night in Jerusalem, Itamar Ben-Gvir, the leader of the far-right Jewish Power Party, stood onstage triumphant before a raucous, ecstatic crowd. His supporters chanted, “Look who it is, the next prime minister!” as trance beats blared in the background. Mr. Ben-Gvir, in fact, had not been elected prime minister, but he will have played an instrumental role in returning Benjamin Netanyahu to power.

headline: What’s at Stake in These Elections
abstract: The winners of races at every level of government will play crucial roles in overseeing and certifying the 2024 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Midterm elections in the United States are often presented as a referendum on the party in power, and that message appears to be resonating this fall. But voters need to consider the intentions of the party that hopes to regain power, too, and what each vote they cast will mean for the future of this country.

headline: A History of Doo-Wop Emerges From Sandy Wreckage
abstract: Kenny Vance’s home in the Rockaways was damaged by the hurricane 10 years ago. But he was able to save some precious footage.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Hurricane Sandy did billions of dollars’ worth of damage, but it didn’t destroy everything in its path. We’ll find out about a documentary that exists because Sandy didn’t ruin the raw footage. And we’ll take a last look at the campaigns and the candidates.

headline: Word of the Day: poignant
abstract: This word has appeared in 411 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word poignant has appeared in 411 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 23 in “What We Will Miss Most About Roger Federer” by Michael Steinberger:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Race Question in Supreme Court Adoption Case Unnerves Tribes
abstract: The issue is whether a federal law that seeks to place Native American foster children in Native American homes is constitutional. The case could turn on whether the justices see tribes as racial groups or sovereign nations.
lead_paragraph: The little girl who will soon be known by the nine justices of the United States Supreme Court as Y.R.J. is now 4 years old. For much of her short life she has been living with Dr. Jennifer Brackeen and Chad Brackeen, a suburban Texas couple fighting with the Navajo Nation to adopt her. Y.R.J.’s birth mother is Navajo. The Brackeens are white.

headline: A Messy Marital Split Tarnishes a Roman Soccer Legend
abstract: Francesco Totti and Ilary Blasi once shared a storybook love. Now she’s hiding his Rolexes, and he’s holding hostage her Jimmy Choos.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Once upon a time, Francesco Totti, the crowned prince of Italian soccer, celebrated a goal by ripping off his jersey and revealing a T-shirt reading, “You’re the One,” a proclamation of eternal love for Ilary Blasi, a showgirl who stole his heart. The two got married on live television, had three children and moved into a villa befitting Rome’s born-and-bred royal family.

headline: Michael Bloomberg announces a new initiative to phase out coal in 25 countries.
abstract: The goal is to see coal plants retired in many developing countries by 2040, with some wealthier countries ending coal use by 2030.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — Michael Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City and now a special envoy on climate change for the United Nations, announced a new international plan on Monday to help 25 countries in Africa, Asia and Latin America phase out coal by 2040.

headline: 40 Chickens in 40 Days: How a Philadelphia Man Cheered His City
abstract: Alexander Tominsky was on an epic quest to give Philadelphia something to celebrate, but he said he felt relieved to be done with the challenge. “My body is ready to repair,” he said.
lead_paragraph: There was no confetti strewn across the streets of Philadelphia on Sunday morning, no chants of “We are the champions,” or whiffs of smoke from celebratory fireworks. The city had lost both the World Series and the Major League Soccer Cup final on Saturday in a span of about five hours.

headline: What Are Your Stories of Rebuilding After Disaster? Tell Us.
abstract: Headway wants to learn more about the people affected by this issue and the stories we should tell.
lead_paragraph: The era we are now in the midst of might be defined, most notably, by the omnipresence of disaster. Plagues, droughts, floods, toxic air and water, wars, massacres, famines, earthquakes, heat waves, wildfires, recessions, dust storms, despotism — slow-motion nightmares are crashing into fast-moving catastrophes, each one amplifying the next.

headline: Who’s attending COP27, and who isn’t.
abstract: The leaders of some of history’s largest polluters are slated to speak, as are those from countries that are bearing the brunt of the effects of climate change.
lead_paragraph: Who will be present at the COP27 climate conference in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, is as revealing as who won’t be.

headline: Who Will Win in These Eight Races?
abstract: Political experts place their bets on the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: Political experts place their bets on the midterm elections.

headline: A Core Question at COP27: Who Will Pay for Climate Change?
abstract: At this year’s annual climate summit, a debate over who bears the financial responsibility for climate change, and what they owe, will be center stage.
lead_paragraph: At this year’s annual climate summit, a debate over who bears the financial responsibility for climate change, and what they owe, will be center stage.

headline: What Are the Best Forever Boots?
abstract: A reader wants a pair of boots that will stay in style.
lead_paragraph: Why settle for five years? I’d go for 10. That is, after all, when the sustainable apparel coalition writes the environmental impact of a garment down to zero. And, like sneakers, flats and a pair of heels, boots — the everyday kind, not the rain or snow kind — are one of the basic building blocks of a footwear wardrobe. Finding the right pair can solve a myriad of dressing problems, not to mention provide some welcome ankle support. But where to begin?

headline: How Do You Make Hard Decisions?
abstract: Some decisions are more difficult than others. What path do you choose when there isn’t a clear best choice?
lead_paragraph: Should you cut your hair — or perhaps dye it? Should you finally ask that special someone out on a date? Should you join a sports team, get an after school job or perhaps run for class president? Where should you go to college, or what should you do after high school?

headline: What Has Happened to My Country?
abstract: The vertigo of our democratic crisis is impossible to escape.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — There I was, snug in my own bed in the middle of the night, turning to sleep on my side, when wham! the room slid sideways. Then it took off, spinning and spinning as though a sadistic carnival barker had flipped a switch and pushed the speed to max.

headline: How Bad Are Things? I Asked Some Election Workers.
abstract: Elections are staffed by real people, with real lives, who opt into this system. That could make you nervous — or deeply reassure you.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — One of the challenges of being alive right now is making sense of the threat to the American election system: It’s hard to determine, conclusively, how widespread that threat is, how much chaos and danger we’re living through and what to do next.

headline: Who Will Win the Battle for Congress? Four Scenarios.
abstract: A wide range of outcomes is still possible. Here are signs to look for on election night.
lead_paragraph: Just about anything is still possible in this year’s midterm elections.

headline: Home for the Holidays, With Long-Festering Issues
abstract: In Lynn Steger Strong’s third novel, “Flight,” a trio of siblings converge for their first Christmas without their mother. It’s complicated.
lead_paragraph: Lynn Steger Strong’s first two novels, “Want” and “Hold Still,” derived their considerable power from the sense you had, reading them, of being enclosed in the mind and the fraught circumstances of her isolated protagonists.

headline: Supreme Court Case on State Legislatures Could Open Litigation Floodgates
abstract: The justices will hear arguments next month on a legal theory that could transform federal elections — and, experts said, lead to countless lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: As the Supreme Court prepares to hear a case next month that could radically reshape how federal elections are conducted, it has received scores of friend-of-the-court briefs featuring enough strange bedfellows to fill a hotel.

headline: Countries Made Bold Climate Promises Last Year. How Are They Doing?
abstract: At last year’s U.N. climate summit in Glasgow, world leaders pledged to halt deforestation, phase out fossil fuel subsidies and offer up more climate aid. Following through has been tough.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the COP27 Climate Summit in Egypt.

headline: After Years in Limbo, Finding a Place of Her Own
abstract: There was subletting, apartment-sharing, couch-surfing, roommates, cockroaches and a guest bedroom. The story also includes a sunny one-bedroom in Brooklyn.

headline: The Woman T.S. Eliot Loved at Arm’s Length and Enshrined in Verse
abstract: Drawing on newly released letters from the poet to Emily Hale, with whom he maintained a decades-long, mostly epistolary affair, “The Hyacinth Girl,” by Lyndall Gordon, reconsiders his life and work.
lead_paragraph: T.S. Eliot was so famously reserved, so conspicuously buttoned up, that Virginia Woolf joked about him coming to lunch in a “four-piece suit.” And yet, a vibrant new book by Lyndall Gordon, “The Hyacinth Girl,” reveals the hidden ardors running beneath the surface of both his life and work.

headline: More Predictions! And Some Very Mixed Feelings.
abstract: The midterms are finally upon us.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: OK, Bret — it’s elections week! Tell me the one outcome you’re most hoping to see and the one you’re most dreading.

headline: Putting Writers’ Lives on the Reading List
abstract: It’s never too young to be inspired by Maya Angelou, Virginia Woolf and the “daring original” Ruth Krauss.
lead_paragraph: Writing is not quite the glamour profession it used to be, the poet Amanda Gorman on the cover of Time last year notwithstanding. (Over a decade had passed since a writer was on that magazine’s cover, and what does being on the cover of Time mean now, anyway?) So nostalgia wafts thickly over three new picture books about authors, all of which serve as parables about creativity. That your little creator might end up making “content” for TikTok is a problem for another day.

headline: ‘Espionage Lite’ or Deal Making? Prosecutors Struggle to Draw a Line.
abstract: The acquittal of Thomas J. Barrack Jr., a former Trump adviser, showed the difficulty of proving wrongdoing amid a brew of political, personal and commercial interests.
lead_paragraph: The federal trial of Thomas J. Barrack Jr., a businessman and adviser to former President Donald J. Trump, hinged on a single, deceptively simple question: What makes someone an agent of a foreign government?

headline: Love Comes and Goes, but a Screenshot Is Forever
abstract: Want to fight fair? Some couples advocate taking it to the texts.
lead_paragraph: On a Tuesday in early October, at around 5 p.m., Robb Loeb was with his wife, Jenn, in their Atlanta home, hanging a bookshelf. Or rather, attempting to hang a bookshelf.

headline: An Engine of Upward Mobility Struggles to Capture Opportunities in Tech
abstract: Students at the City University of New York are increasingly graduating with degrees in technology. A new report details the obstacles they face in landing jobs.
lead_paragraph: The technology industry has been a leading engine of growth for good-paying jobs in New York City over the past decade. That trend continued through the pandemic, but a new report casts doubt on how widely the tech-fueled prosperity is being shared.

headline: Can the Most Hated Meal Be Redeemed? ‘The Big Brunch’ Says Yes.
abstract: Contempt for brunch is persistent, but a new show on HBO Max approaches the meal with ambition and optimism.
lead_paragraph: I’d watched enough “Sex and the City” in my 20s to see how brunch could give a group of friends, and the episodic structure they lived in, a leisurely rhythm. But I was a cook — my rhythm was determined by a schedule pinned to a corkboard outside my chef’s office. If it put me on brunch service, it felt like I’d done something wrong: There was nothing more frivolous, tedious or hellish than brunch.

headline: Bob Dylan Breaks Down 66 Classic Tunes in His New Book
abstract: “The Philosophy of Modern Song” offers commentaries on a range of music, written in the singer’s unmistakable lyrical style.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: China’s Business Elite See the Country That Let Them Thrive Slipping Away
abstract: The business class, which shunned politics, is now questioning if there is still a place for it in a system dominated by one ruler, Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: For decades, China’s business class had an unspoken contract with the Communist Party: Let us make money and we’ll turn a blind eye to how you use your power.

headline: Architects Plan a City for the Future in Ukraine, While Bombs Still Fall
abstract: Irpin was one of the first Ukrainian cities to be destroyed and liberated. Now it’s becoming a laboratory for rebuilding.
lead_paragraph: In the final few days of February, as the Russian Army advanced toward Kyiv, Ukrainian forces blew up the Irpin bridge, ripping open its latticed metal insides so that their edges buckled and curled. A suburb of Kyiv, Irpin was the last city that the Russian Army would have had to conquer to reach the capital; the bridge provided the fastest route from the city center to the Kyiv ring road. “It was the main bridge that stopped the invasion of Kyiv,” says Slava Balbek, a Ukrainian architect who is volunteering as a drone operator with territorial defense forces. “It’s like if you cut your arm off so the rest of your body will be saved.”

headline: Fears and Suspicion Hang Over Voting on Cusp of Election Day
abstract: Even as voting goes smoothly, the 2022 midterm elections have exposed the toll Donald J. Trump’s falsehoods have taken on American democracy.
lead_paragraph: Voters go to the polls on Tuesday after a campaign season so filled with conspiracy theories and lies that officials worry they will undermine confidence in the election no matter how the balloting goes.

headline: The World’s Most-Visited Glaciers Could Soon Be Gone
abstract: The U.N.’s cultural agency warns that ice sheets on Kilimanjaro, in the Dolomites and in Yosemite may disappear by 2050, highlighting travel’s impact on climate change.
lead_paragraph: Making the World Heritage List from UNESCO, the United Nations’ educational, scientific and cultural organization, is a kind of gold seal of approval in the tourism world. The list, which began in 1978, has more than 1,150 sites nominated by their host nations and includes tourist destinations like the Great Wall of China, the Great Barrier Reef in Australia and the Central Amazon Conservation Complex in Brazil.

headline: What You Get for $1.4 Million in California
abstract: A 1920 bungalow in Los Angeles, a 1909 Craftsman-style house in Oakland and a two-bedroom cottage in Redondo Beach.
lead_paragraph: A 1920 bungalow in Los Angeles, a 1909 Craftsman-style house in Oakland and a two-bedroom cottage in Redondo Beach.

headline: $1.4 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1920 bungalow in Los Angeles, a 1909 Craftsman-style house in Oakland and a two-bedroom cottage in Redondo Beach.
lead_paragraph: In 1932, the Summer Olympic Games were held in Los Angeles, and athletes were housed in small homes constructed especially for that purpose in the View Park neighborhood. Later, the unfurnished structures were sold for $140 dollars each. This one was moved to Eagle Rock, where it served as a clubhouse for scouting troops. The sellers, who bought it in 2021, did a full renovation, installing a new kitchen and bathrooms, copper plumbing, a Nest thermostat and a tankless water heater.

headline: Are Trees Talking Underground? For Scientists, It’s in Dispute.
abstract: From Ted Lasso to TED Talks, the theory of the “wood-wide web” is everywhere, and some scientists argue that it is overblown and unproven.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: How Much Do You Know About Malaysia?
abstract: Can you find Malaysia on a map? What else do you know about this Southeast Asian nation with about 31 million people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find Malaysia on a map? What else do you know about this Southeast Asian nation with about 31 million people?

headline: Egypt’s most prominent political prisoner escalates a hunger strike as the summit begins.
abstract: Alaa Abd El Fattah, an activist and software developer, has been imprisoned for most of the last nine years over his condemnations of Egypt’s authoritarian government.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — The world leaders, government negotiators, climate scientists and other dignitaries are unlikely to see his name anywhere in Sharm el Sheikh, the beach resort city hosting the COP27 summit. But Alaa Abd El Fattah, Egypt’s most prominent revolutionary voice and its most famous political prisoner, is making his absence felt.

headline: John Fetterman and the Fight for White Working-Class Voters
abstract: How the Democrats’ Senate candidate in Pennsylvania fits into a plan to win back the constituency that was once the core of their base.
lead_paragraph: For the Democrats to hold on to power in Washington, they have to do what President Biden did in Pennsylvania two years ago: Break the Republican Party’s grip on the white working-class vote, once the core of the Democratic base.

headline: Does America Vote Too Much?
abstract: Elections have consequences that go beyond the results.
lead_paragraph: Americans casting their ballots in tomorrow’s midterm elections might be voting in their 30th or 40th contest in four years. In the same amount of time, a German citizen might vote in six to eight races.

headline: A Cubed, Colorful Retreat in the California Desert
abstract: Plus: an iced coffee season that never ends and more from T’s cultural compendium.
lead_paragraph: A mile from the entrance to California’s Joshua Tree National Park, a neo-primitive structure composed of three cubes stands out from the barren desert landscape like a Modernist mirage. Constructed in the early ’90s as a private family retreat, Monument House was designed by the Southern California-based architect Josh Schweitzer, best known for renovating historic homes like the Frank Lloyd Wright-designed Samuel-Novarro House in Los Angeles. Now, through the hospitality brand Homestead Modern, the five-acre estate is open for private bookings for the first time.

headline: COP27 offers the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheikh another moment in the spotlight.
abstract: The Red Sea resort hosting the U.N. climate summit has played a role in international diplomacy, but also suffered tragedy.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — Most of the time, Sharm el Sheikh is best-known outside Egypt as a beach haven for tourists from northern countries in search of the sun: Germans, British and, until this year, planeloads of Ukrainians and Russians getting sunburned together along the calm waters and rich coral reefs of the Red Sea.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Will Return as Oscars Host
abstract: It will be the late-night star’s third turn in the job, after stints in 2017 and 2018, the last time the show went with just one host.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the Academy Awards have gone with three hosts new to the job. They’ve gone with zero hosts. But in 2023, just one will be on hand, and it’s a veteran: Jimmy Kimmel. The late-night star, who has emceed the ceremony twice before, will be the sole host of the 95th Oscars when they air March 12 on ABC, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced Monday.

headline: In the Marseille Clubs, Leather, Lamé and Fur Reign Supreme
abstract: This season, get inspired by the high-gloss style of the French city’s nightlife.

headline: 26.2 Miles Is Easy. Getting Around New York City Is Not.
abstract: Daniel Romanchuk, 24, placed second in the New York City Marathon on Sunday. But getting around the city in a wheelchair can be more challenging than the race itself.
lead_paragraph: One of Daniel Romanchuk’s most frequent challenges, it turns out, is at the finish line.

headline: A New Push for Business to Help Pay for Climate-Change Solutions
abstract: As global leaders gather at COP27, efforts are reportedly underway to have companies help shoulder the financial burden.
lead_paragraph: As world leaders gather in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, for the COP27 climate conference, questions about how to deal with the potentially catastrophic effects of global warming have reached a new level of urgency. No less contentious: how to pay for solving the problem, and just how much will businesses be asked to pitch in.

headline: Is California’s Fire Season Over?
abstract: The wet weather that is arriving this week is expected to substantially reduce, if not eliminate, fire danger for the rest of the year.
lead_paragraph: California’s recent fire seasons have stretched unsettlingly late into the year, with devastating blazes breaking out in November and December. Tomorrow is the anniversary of the start of the Camp fire, the deadliest fire in state history.

headline: Wordle Wrap-Up: Oct. 31 to Nov. 6
abstract: A recap of the Wordle answers for the past week.
lead_paragraph: Hi Wordlers! Welcome to Wordle Wrap-Up, a reminder of which words were answers this week. For stories, stats and brain teasers, sign up for the Gameplay newsletter. For a daily reminder to play Wordle, sign up for reminders.

headline: Wordle Finally Has an Editor
abstract: Tracy Bennett will be programming Wordle every day.
lead_paragraph: After nearly a year of speculation, it will finally be our fault if Wordle is harder. Starting Nov. 7, Wordle will have a dedicated editor, just as the Crossword, Mini and Spelling Bee do.

headline: Will Rain Affect Turnout Tomorrow? The Answer Is Cloudy.
abstract: Where the Election Day forecast is wetter than normal.
lead_paragraph: Where the Election Day forecast is wetter than normal.

headline: Tom Brady Has Passed for 100,000 Yards. Sort Of.
abstract: The Buccaneers quarterback reached a career milestone only by adding in his postseason totals to his regular-season mark. But no rival can match him on either list.
lead_paragraph: The number that was everywhere on Sunday was large and pleasingly round. Tom Brady had surpassed 100,000 yards passing, the latest milestone in his long and storied career.

headline: A Total Lunar Eclipse in Early Tuesday Skies
abstract: Those who woke up early to head to the polls on Tuesday, got a shot at seeing the moon darken as it fell into Earth’s shadow.
lead_paragraph: During the early hours on Tuesday, darkness will slip across the face of the moon before it turns a deep blood red. No, it isn’t an Election Day omen — it’s one of the most eye-catching sights in the night sky.

headline: Coke Is a Sponsor of the Climate Summit in Egypt. Some Activists Aren’t Happy.
abstract: They cite recent report that says the company’s production of plastics is increasing.
lead_paragraph: The decision to include Coca-Cola as a major sponsor of this year’s United Nations climate summit in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, has angered many climate activists, who cite a recent report that says the company’s production of plastics is increasing.

headline: Democrats Fight to Hold Oregon House Seat After Defeat of Centrist Incumbent
abstract: Representative Kurt Schrader, a seven-term Democrat, lost his primary to a more liberal opponent. Now the competitive seat is up for grabs, with a Republican favored to win.
lead_paragraph: Peter Watts, a registered Democrat and lawyer in Clackamas County, would have gladly voted this year to re-elect his longtime Democratic congressman, Representative Kurt Schrader of Oregon.

headline: Make Room for Pie
abstract: Stunning but not hard to pull off, these nine new pies from Genevieve Ko will be the highlight of your holiday.
lead_paragraph: A burnished turkey may be the eminent Thanksgiving centerpiece, but everyone knows that the real star of the meal is pie. Be it pumpkin, apple, mango or whatever your folks used to make, a golden-crusted pie on the dessert table is a happy sight — even at the end of the most prodigious meal of the year. As my friend Karen says, “There’s always room for pie.”

headline: Why Control of Kherson City Is Important to Russia and Ukraine
abstract: The forced withdrawal of troops is a significant setback to Moscow’s campaign to control southern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The retreat of Russian forces from the key city of Kherson is a watershed moment in Ukraine’s campaign to reclaim territory in the south of the country that Moscow captured near the start of its invasion.

headline: The Gender Gap in the Abortion Debate
abstract: Men are less likely than women to feel driven by the issue, which could have profound implications for upcoming elections.
lead_paragraph: Two canvassers walked a cul de sac in a Northeastern Pennsylvania town looking for “persuadables” — independent voters who might be convinced to vote for Democrats — and Erik Brandt, out resurfacing his driveway, offered himself as one.

headline: In This Novel, Teenage Artists Spawn a Deadly Moral Panic
abstract: The friends at the center of Kevin Wilson’s “Now Is Not the Time to Panic” hang photocopied posters around their small Tennessee town. Chaos ensues.
lead_paragraph: These days, teenagers of the 1990s find themselves in the bizarre position of having to conjure their childhoods as if they had taken place in the 1890s. Is life before smartphones really so alien? American teens still drive around with their nascent licenses, listening to questionable music, eating Pop-Tarts from gas stations (possibly, chillingly, the same Pop-Tarts). More important, they still develop intense and thrilling friendships. In his fourth novel, “Now Is Not the Time To Panic,” Kevin Wilson (best known for “Nothing to See Here” and “The Family Fang”) addresses the contours of this liminal time, capturing the still-relevant feeling of trying “to remember what was in the cassette player, if it was cool.” His is a buoyant tribute to small-town life, a book about creativity and creation in a world before “send” buttons.

headline: National Park Service Asks Visitors to Please Stop Licking Toads
abstract: The Sonoran desert toad’s toxins create an intense psychedelic experience, but that’s not an excuse to put one in your mouth.
lead_paragraph: Tempting as it may be, please don’t lick the toads.

headline: A Low Point for the Monarchy, in a New Season of ‘The Crown’
abstract: Queen Elizabeth II wasn’t always the wildly popular figure that Britain mourned this year, as the latest episodes of the Netflix hit recall.
lead_paragraph: It is 1991 in Britain. At Buckingham Palace, Queen Elizabeth II, now a venerable 65, is settling in to her 39th year on the throne. At No. 10 Downing Street, Margaret Thatcher is gone, savagely defenestrated a year earlier by treacherous members of her own party. Her replacement as prime minister, the dully ineffectual John Major, has failed to repair the sclerotic economy, which has slid into recession. It is an uncertain, unexciting time.

headline: Italy Blocks Male Migrants From Leaving Rescue Ships
abstract: The new right-wing government appears to be taking a harder line with people who are picked up in the Mediterranean as they try to cross from Libya.
lead_paragraph: About 250 migrants coming from Libya were stuck in an Italian port on Monday onboard charity-run rescue ships after the new right-wing Italian government refused to allow them to set foot on shore.

headline: Switzerland Is Paying Poorer Nations to Cut Emissions on Its Behalf
abstract: The agreements raise concerns that other countries will follow suit, delaying more difficult cuts of greenhouse gas emissions in wealthier nations.
lead_paragraph: Switzerland, one of the world’s richest nations, has an ambitious climate goal: It promises to cut its greenhouse gas emissions in half by 2030.

headline: Le Bernardin Celebrates Its 50th Anniversary
abstract: The seafood restaurant marks the occasion with a special dinner, an exhibit on the history of the Jewish deli comes to New York and more.
lead_paragraph: In a business known for its short shelf life, a restaurant like Le Bernardin turning 50 is significant. The owners, Maguy Le Coze and the chef, Eric Ripert, have planned a dinner to mark the occasion. Ms. Le Coze and her brother, Gilbert, first opened their seafood restaurant in 1972 on the Left Bank in Paris, with a view of Notre Dame, then relocated the restaurant near the Arc de Triomphe. They made the trans-Atlantic move to the present location in New York in 1986, as an anchor in a collection of restaurants in a new office tower on Seventh Avenue. The restaurant received four stars in its first New York Times review, three months after opening, a top ranking it has maintained over decades. In Paris it received two stars from Michelin, but was never awarded the ultimate three. (Mr. Le Coze contended that it was because they only served fish.) When Michelin introduced its New York guide in 2005, the restaurant finally achieved the third star. It was a pinnacle that Mr. Le Coze was unable to enjoy: He died unexpectedly of a heart attack in 1994. Ms. Le Coze kept the restaurant going with Mr. Ripert, who became her partner in the restaurant. To mark the anniversary they have organized a $1,000 per person six-course dinner on Wednesday with 10 percent going to the charity City Harvest, which Mr. Ripert supports. The menu combines echoes of Le Bernardin classics, like the pounded tuna first course; and monkfish with a sunchoke purée replacing melted leeks. (Mr. Le Coze is often credited with popularizing monkfish for the American audience.) In recent years, Le Bernardin has always been at or near the top of global restaurant awards.

headline: DeSantis Campaign Video Hints at National Aims and Draws Trump’s Ire
abstract: It has not been aired on television and there are no plans to use it as a paid advertisement for Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, but that may not be the point, so long as it spreads on social media.
lead_paragraph: Back in April, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, a Republican, released “Sweet Florida,” a catchy campaign anthem by two current members of the Southern rock band Lynyrd Skynyrd.

headline: How Belize Cut Its Debt by Fighting Global Warming
abstract: Developing nations are reducing their debt by pledging to protect their resources in financial deals that could give them a bigger role in the fight against climate change.
lead_paragraph: TURNEFFE ATOLL, Belize — Belize faced an economic meltdown. The pandemic had sent it into its worst ever recession, putting the government on the brink of bankruptcy.

headline: ‘Channeling the Mama Bear’: How Covid Closures Became Today’s Curriculum Wars
abstract: According to a new survey, one issue is especially divisive: teaching about L.G.B.T.Q. rights and gender identity.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: C.E.O.s Are Talking More About Recession
abstract: The possibility of an economic slowdown has been a hot topic during the latest batch of quarterly earnings conference calls.
lead_paragraph: Despite a surprisingly resilient labor market, talk of an economic downturn is on the lips of corporate leaders.

headline: Across the Country, Voting Issues Are on the Ballot. Abortion and Guns Are, Too.
abstract: Ballot initiatives on an array of issues offer an opportunity to take the nation’s temperature, particularly when it comes to voting access.
lead_paragraph: In Connecticut, voters will decide on Tuesday whether to allow early voting. In Michigan, residents are weighing measures that supporters say will make it easier to cast ballots.

headline: How Can Standup Succeed in a Fragmented Culture? Nurse Blake Has One Answer
abstract: He may be the least known star at the New York Comedy Festival but his fans are fellow R.N.s and others who appreciate his medical-industry jokes.
lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON, N.Y. — At the first of two rowdy shows here at the Paramount Theater on a weeknight last month, the standup comic Nurse Blake walked onstage and asked if any of the more than 1,000 people there were drinking. After a cheer, he quipped: “Probably E.R. nurses.”

headline: A Putin Ally Says Russia is Interfering in the Midterms
abstract: Yevgeny Prigozhin, a prominent businessman who founded a private mercenary force closely linked to the Kremlin, posted a sardonic statement about election meddling.
lead_paragraph: With alarm over foreign manipulation of the U.S. midterm elections swirling ahead of Tuesday’s vote, an influential Russian businessman and close associate of President Vladimir V. Putin sardonically boasted on Monday that Russia was interfering in the election.

headline: To Understand New Extremism, Look to History
abstract: Some of the forces protecting European nations even as far-right candidates thrive are not in play in the United States, and particularly not within a Republican establishment vulnerable to a takeover.
lead_paragraph: The central question in American politics today is, I think, “what the *expletive my editor won’t let me use* is going on?!?”

headline: Even as Egypt Hosts Climate Summit, Selling Fossil Fuels Is a Priority
abstract: Desperate for cash as the fallout from the Ukraine war batters its economy, Egypt has been conserving natural gas at home to sell to Europe.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the COP27 Climate Summit in Egypt.

headline: What Is Mastodon and Why Are People Leaving Twitter for It?
abstract: Since Elon Musk took ownership of Twitter, some of its users have migrated to Mastodon, an alternative social platform.
lead_paragraph: Since Elon Musk completed a $44 billion deal to purchase Twitter on Oct. 27, he has struggled to assuage concerns about a potential proliferation of misinformation and hate speech on the platform. Amid the brouhaha, some Twitter users have sought out alternative social media platforms. A popular one is Mastodon, which has an estimated 4.5 million accounts.

headline: How the Two Parties and Their Voters View the Election
abstract: Readers discuss polarization and whether democracy is at stake. Also: Politics and religion; voter integrity; rising antisemitism; putting Russia on notice.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Republicans are using lawsuits and rhetoric to push Election Day voting.
abstract: The efforts, which are strong in battleground states, could create a false impression that Republicans are faring better on election night.
lead_paragraph: Since the 2020 election, Republican voters have been encouraged by some of their most vocal leaders, including former President Donald J. Trump, to eschew mail voting and instead cast a ballot in person, preferably on Election Day.

headline: Paxlovid May Reduce Risk of Long Covid in Eligible Patients, Study Finds
abstract: The research looked at patients who qualified for the antiviral through age or health conditions. Those who took it shortly after infection were 26 percent less likely to have symptoms 90 days later.
lead_paragraph: People who took the antiviral drug Paxlovid within a few days after being infected with the coronavirus were less likely to be experiencing long Covid several months later, a large new study found.

headline: Hochul and Zeldin Make Last-Minute Appeals in Unpredictable Race
abstract: In a last spurt of campaigning, the two candidates for governor of New York focus on encouraging their supporters to turn out on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of Election Day, Gov. Kathy Hochul and her Republican challenger, Representative Lee M. Zeldin, sprinted around New York City and its suburbs, making last-minute appeals to voters in what has become a surprisingly competitive campaign.

headline: Liverpool F.C., One of Soccer’s Biggest Brands, Is for Sale
abstract: Months after its Premier League rival Chelsea traded hands in a deal worth $3 billion, Liverpool’s owners hired bankers and said they would entertain offers for the club.
lead_paragraph: The American owners of Liverpool F.C., one of soccer’s most storied teams, have hired Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley to explore a sale of the club, a six-time European champion, according to two people with direct knowledge of the team’s plans.

headline: How unusual would a November hurricane be in Florida?
abstract: The official Atlantic hurricane season runs through Nov. 30. But hurricanes this late in the season are rare, and only a few have made U.S. landfall.
lead_paragraph: The latest forecasts from the National Hurricane Center make it clear that this week a storm with hurricane-force winds could be menacing the east coast of Florida.

headline: The Fed Won’t Say It, but It Doesn’t Want a Strong Stock Market
abstract: When you’re fighting inflation, it’s a problem if people feel richer.
lead_paragraph: What a great country, right? Six days before a crucial midterm election, the head of the central bank was talking down the stock market.

headline: Covid Patients Coming Off Ventilators Can Take Weeks to Regain Consciousness
abstract: A new paper suggests that the combination of the virus and anesthesia plunges the brain into a prolonged state of quiet — like a freshwater turtle in winter.
lead_paragraph: In March 2020, New York City’s hospitals filled up with patients desperately ill with Covid-19. In many cases, when their fluid-filled lungs could no longer give them oxygen, doctors sedated them and put them on ventilators.

headline: One of Nature’s Most Impressive Jumpers: The Springtail.
abstract: Springtails are about the size of a pinhead, but they can control their jumps like seasoned acrobats.
lead_paragraph: Among the wonders of the natural world that few people have ever noticed: a semiaquatic springtail in motion.

headline: ‘My Broken Language’ Review: Piecing Together a Life of Many Dialects
abstract: In Quiara Alegría Hudes’s new play at the Signature Theater, five performers try to summon generations of willful women.
lead_paragraph: English was the playwright Quiara Alegría Hudes’s first language. But her mother’s house, in North Philadelphia, sheltered other tongues — Spanish, Spanglish, the brash gold-hoops-and-spandex sass of her older cousins.

headline: Los Angeles Voters Are in a Foul Mood. Will a New Mayor Change Anything?
abstract: Residents are frustrated over homelessness, crime and rising costs. Two candidates for mayor, Karen Bass and Rick Caruso, say they can turn the tide.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was Saturday and sunny in the nation’s second most populous city, but the Rev. James McKnight’s mood was grim.

headline: When Does Collaboration Become Collusion?
abstract: Adhering to antitrust regulation while negotiating collective sustainability targets is proving tougher to navigate for some in the fashion industry.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2020, during the earliest and darkest months of the coronavirus pandemic, a group of clothing executives and designers began talking — tentatively — about upending some of the global fashion industry’s hidebound practices.

headline: The Secret to Great Thanksgiving Turkey Is Already in Your Fridge
abstract: A mayonnaise-based marinade gives this bird from J. Kenji López-Alt its gorgeous finish. Spatchcocking and a simple brining technique get it evenly cooked and juicy.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving has long been my favorite holiday, but, as someone who creates recipes for a living, it has one drawback: having to come up with new ways to tackle the same bird, year after year.

headline: Biggest Surge of Misinformation May Arrive After Election Day, Researchers Say
abstract: People who study disinformation are warning that far-right influencers will seize on ballot-counting delays and other routine issues as evidence of fraud.
lead_paragraph: While misinformation has played a consistent role in the midterm election season, researchers are warning that the biggest surge could come after Election Day, as far-right candidates and their supporters seize on ballot-counting delays and misleading narratives to sow doubt about the results.

headline: Tracking Tropical Depression Nicole
abstract: Maps show the storm’s forecast track and rainfall as it crossed Florida and headed up the Appalachians.
lead_paragraph: Maps show the storm’s forecast track and rainfall as it crossed Florida and headed up the Appalachians.

headline: How does The Times get live election results?
abstract: We combine the work of our team of journalists and software engineers with the reporting of more than 4,000 Associated Press correspondents to power our results pages.
lead_paragraph: We report vote totals provided by The Associated Press, which collects results from states, counties and townships through a network of websites and more than 4,000 on-the-ground correspondents. To estimate how many votes remain to be counted, our team of data journalists and software engineers gathers vote tallies directly from the websites of election officials and compares these with our turnout expectations.

headline: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Streamline Challenges to Agency Power
abstract: The justices appeared ready to rule that people and companies need not wait for administrative rulings to press constitutional claims in federal court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, which has in recent years become increasingly skeptical of the power of administrative agencies, seemed ready on Monday to make it easier to challenge their structure and authority.

headline: A $102 Million Closer? It Could Pay Off in October.
abstract: Steven A. Cohen and the Mets are on the verge of completing an eye-popping deal with the right-hander Edwin Díaz that will be the largest contract for a reliever in baseball history.
