lead_paragraph: There are very few things more polarizing in baseball than the value of relief pitchers. Some will swear that relievers are interchangeable parts and are far too volatile on an annual basis to take them seriously. Others will insist that a team can’t possibly win without an officially sanctioned Capital-C Closer (bonus points if he wears glasses or has interesting facial hair).

headline: Trump, eyeing another run, keeps G.O.P. focus where he wants it.
abstract: A rumored announcement at a Monday rally has some Republicans nervous about the election eve fallout.
lead_paragraph: For all the rallies, emailed fund-raising pitches and exhortations on his social media website to support Republican candidates, former President Donald J. Trump was always destined to make the 2022 election about one thing: himself.

headline: American Aid Worker Is Shot Dead in Baghdad
abstract: Security officials said that gunmen opened fire on the aid worker’s vehicle in a drive-by shooting in the central Baghdad neighborhood where he lived.
lead_paragraph: An American aid worker was shot dead on Monday while driving a car in Baghdad, Iraqi officials said, in a rare attack on a foreigner in the Iraqi capital.

headline: Resistance to misinformation is weakening on Twitter, a report found.
abstract: Researchers at Tufts expressed concern in a report about conspiracy theories on Twitter ahead of the midterms.
lead_paragraph: Concerns about misinformation on Twitter have flared in the days since Elon Musk’s takeover on Oct. 27, pushing away advertisers, rattling researchers and increasing fears that conspiracy theories and false narratives could pollute the political discourse on the platform ahead of the midterm elections.

headline: ‘A Reason to Act Faster’: World Leaders Meet on Climate Amid Other Crises
abstract: On the first day of COP27, the U.N. climate talks, world leaders urged each other to move faster to cut the pollution that is warming the planet while recognizing the war in Ukraine’s global energy effects and the unequal effects of climate change to date.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the COP27 Climate Summit in Egypt.

headline: Ernie Lazar, Who Trawled for Secret Government Documents, Dies at 77
abstract: By pursuing his “unusual hobby” of filing as many as 10,000 Freedom of Information requests about extremist groups, he proved invaluable to historians and journalists.
lead_paragraph: Ernie Lazar, an unheralded hero of researchers who mined his vast digital and documentary archive of government records on political extremists to invigorate their books, articles and arguments and to warn against “it can’t happen here” complacency, died on Nov. 1 at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 77.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: The U.S. Midterms Loom
abstract: Plus a warning at COP27 and Kherson in distress.
lead_paragraph: Americans will finish voting in midterm elections today, which could change the balance of power in state and federal legislative bodies, influence foreign policy and foreshadow the 2024 presidential race.

headline: WTA Chief Talks Money, China and Why Tennis Needs More Female Coaches
abstract: Even without China’s “zero-Covid” policy, Steve Simon said that unresolved concerns about Peng Shuai would keep women’s tennis away from Shenzhen and a lucrative 10-year-deal to stage the Finals.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — The WTA Finals, the elite season-ending women’s tennis tournament, was supposed to take place in Shenzhen, China, for 10 years and fill the WTA’s coffers.

headline: A MAGA America Would Be Ugly
abstract: Forget Orban’s Hungary. We’d be worse.
lead_paragraph: If you aren’t feeling a sense of dread on the eve of the midterm elections, you haven’t been paying attention.

headline: A Window for Diplomacy?
abstract: The U.S. is quietly trying to shore up prospects for peace talks, even if the sides aren’t ready.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: How Are You Approaching the Holidays?
abstract: We’d like to know how you’re preparing for possible surges of Covid, flu and R.S.V.
lead_paragraph: Last year, many of us woke up the day after Thanksgiving to news of the emergence of Omicron, a highly contagious new coronavirus variant that was driving up cases in Southern Africa. We spent the next few weeks scrambling to learn about the new threat and what it meant for our lives — and holiday plans.

headline: Facing a Tide of Criticism, Elon Musk Is Tweeting Through It
abstract: The new owner of Twitter has embarked on a tweeting spree to push back, spar and justify his actions.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure and facing a wave of criticism, Elon Musk has increasingly turned to his favorite release valve: Twitter.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Greece to Ban Sale of Spyware After Government Is Accused of Surveillance
abstract: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis announced the ban after a news report claimed that he had directed the use of spyware against prominent politicians and journalists, which he denied.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis announced on Monday that Greece would ban the sale of spyware, after his government was accused in a news report of targeting dozens of prominent politicians, journalists and businessmen for surveillance, and the judicial authorities began an investigation.

headline: Oath Keepers Leader Points Finger at Colleagues in Sedition Trial
abstract: Stewart Rhodes, the founder of the far-right militia, testified that he did not order anyone to go into the Capitol on Jan. 6 and that he had nothing to do with an armed force waiting nearby.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the height of the chaos at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, two dozen members of the Oath Keepers militia met outside the building with their leader, Stewart Rhodes.

headline: Why Kherson, Bracing for Battle, Matters So Much to Russia and Ukraine
abstract: Both sides have given great weight to what happens in Kherson, a city of symbolic and strategic value, where conditions are increasingly dire for the thousands of people who remain.
lead_paragraph: In the face of a Ukrainian advance, Russian forces are making the occupied city of Kherson increasingly unlivable, in apparent preparation for a major battle there that has been looming for months.

headline: Airbnb Will Now Warn Travelers About Hidden Cleaning Fees
abstract: Cleaning fees and checkout requirements, often hidden until checkout, have been a source of frustration for users. The company said it was changing its policy to include them earlier in a search.
lead_paragraph: Alea Simone was checking out of an Airbnb in Shreveport, La., where the property’s host asked her to put used towels and sheets in the laundry. But the laundry room was not on the property. And Ms. Simone was already paying a cleaning fee on top of that.

headline: Here’s how we call winners on election night.
abstract: We rely on The Associated Press, but in some tightly contested races, we will evaluate the A.P. race calls before declaring a winner.
lead_paragraph: In virtually every race, we rely on calls by The Associated Press, which employs a team of analysts, researchers and race callers who have a deep understanding of the states where they declare winners.

headline: Apple Built Its Empire With China. Now Its Foundation Is Showing Cracks.
abstract: Lawmakers’ objections to an obscure Chinese semiconductor company and tough Covid-19 restrictions are hurting Apple’s ability to make new iPhones in China.
lead_paragraph: Every September, Apple unveils its latest phones at its futuristic Silicon Valley campus. A few weeks later, tens of millions of its newest handsets, assembled by legions of seasonal workers hired by its suppliers, are shipped from Chinese factories to customers around the world.

headline: Cornell Halts Fraternity Parties After Alleged Sex Assault and Druggings
abstract: The campus police issued alerts over the weekend that one student was sexually assaulted and at least four others were drugged at off-campus residences affiliated with fraternities.
lead_paragraph: Cornell University announced the temporary suspension of all fraternity parties and social events in a statement on Monday, following alerts from the school’s Police Department over the weekend that one student was sexually assaulted and at least four others were drugged at off-campus residences affiliated with fraternities registered with the school.

headline: How to Watch Election Night Like a Pro
abstract: Strategists are watching a few East Coast races that could be called early, offering a rough road map to the entire country.
lead_paragraph: Want to know how the story of the 2022 midterms is going to end as soon as possible on election night? Strategists in both parties are zeroing in on a handful of East Coast races that could be called early in the evening, giving us a rough road map to the entire country. (Here’s when to expect the results in every state.)

headline: Review: In ‘Only Gold,’ Each Move Is Worth 1,000 Words
abstract: The new Kate Nash dance musical, choreographed by Andy Blankenbuehler, is spectacular as long as you pay no attention to what it’s saying.
lead_paragraph: The cutesy Frenchness of “Only Gold,” a dance-musical hybrid directed and choreographed by Andy Blankenbuehler, begins even before the lights go up. (The preshow announcement is winkingly bilingual.) But it really moves into overdrive when Kate Nash, the English singer-songwriter who provided the music and lyrics, arrives onstage and says: “Paris. 1928. A time when rules were ready to be broken.” A show that starts that way should come with a content warning: These clichés may hurt your teeth.

headline: Election Day in New York: Who’s Running and How to Vote
abstract: Democrats are aiming to keep control of the governor’s mansion, the State Legislature and a majority of New York’s House seats, but Republicans seem to have momentum.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2022 midterm elections for the latest news and updates.

headline: Don’t Believe Lee Zeldin When He Says He Can’t Touch Abortion Access in New York
abstract: Governors can do many things to mess with reproductive rights.
lead_paragraph: I called Mark Levine, the Manhattan borough president, on Monday morning to see how worried he was about New York’s governor’s race. Levine, a Democrat who’d just come from campaigning with Gov. Kathy Hochul, was pretty worried. Yes, polls have shown Hochul consistently ahead of the Trumpist Republican congressman Lee Zeldin, but Levine thought the race could go either way.

headline: Senator Raphael Warnock of Georgia Criticizes Calls for His Deportation
abstract: Nikki Haley, a former South Carolina governor, made the comments during a rally with Mr. Warnock’s opponent, Herschel Walker.
lead_paragraph: During a campaign event in Macon, Ga., on Monday, Senator Raphael Warnock responded to comments from a former South Carolina governor, Nikki Haley, who, during a rally with Herschel Walker on Sunday, said that Mr. Warnock should be deported.

headline: Fueled by Falsehoods, a Michigan Group Is Ready to Challenge the Vote
abstract: In private meetings, activists, lawyers and G.O.P. officials laid out their strategy. “If there is a close election, it’s going to be up to us to fix it,” one said.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The invitation went out in early July.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 8, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 8, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about Russians engaged in a grass-roots effort to find missing sons, husbands, brothers and other loved ones who fought for Russia misstated the location of Rostov-on-Don. It is in southwestern Russia, not southeastern Russia.

headline: Are You Sure About That?
abstract: Enrique Henestroza Anguiano’s puzzle may enlighten you.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Enrique Henestroza Anguiano, who is making his fourth appearance in the New York Times Crossword with today’s puzzle.

headline: Nancy Pelosi Says Attack on Husband Will Affect Her Political Future
abstract: In her first televised interview since the attack, Ms. Pelosi also spoke about the first frightening moments after she learned what happened to her husband, Paul Pelosi.
lead_paragraph: In her first televised interview since her husband, Paul Pelosi, was violently attacked, Speaker Nancy Pelosi described the first terrifying moments after she learned from the Capitol Police what had happened inside their San Francisco home on Oct. 28, and said that the traumatic episode would affect her decision about her political future.

headline: At his last midterm rally of 2022, Trump offers a save-the-date for his 2024 plans.
abstract: The former president, after days of promotional teases, talks up “a very big announcement on Nov. 15 at Mar-a-Lago” during a rally for J.D. Vance in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: VANDALIA, Ohio — On the climactic, final night of the 2022 midterm campaigns, Donald J. Trump hosted a rally to help lift a Senate hopeful in Ohio — and instead grabbed the spotlight entirely for himself.

headline: New Endorsements for College Athletes Resurface an Old Concern: Sex Sells
abstract: Female college athletes are making millions thanks to their large social media followings. But some who have fought for equity in women’s sports worry that their brand building is regressive.
lead_paragraph: Olivia Dunne is a gymnast on Louisiana State’s women’s team.

headline: Quotation of the Day: As Los Angeles Selects Mayor, City Is Losing Faith in Its Path
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Nov. 8, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Pessimism at the national level has dribbled to the local level.”

headline: In Governors’ Races, Voting Access and Abortion Rights Are Put to Test
abstract: Some of the closest races feature contests involving Republicans who question or deny the results of the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Voters will elect governors in 36 states on Tuesday, including in a handful of races that will determine the fate of voting access and abortion rights.

headline: The Battle for the Senate Hinges on These Key Races
abstract: Republicans are hopeful they can capture control of the Senate, but Democrats are taking aim at some wobbly G.O.P. candidates who are very loyal to Trump.
lead_paragraph: With control of the evenly divided Senate still anybody’s guess, the 2022 midterms have featured unusual uncertainty — from the primaries all the way to Election Day. While the national environment has favored Republicans, the questionable appeal of some of their candidates has kept Democrats in the fight.

headline: Republicans Aim to Retake the House, With Many Democratic Seats Imperiled
abstract: Few prognostications give Democrats a chance to hold onto their narrow margin in the House, and Republicans hope to make gains in traditionally bedrock blue states.
lead_paragraph: Republicans need a net gain of just five seats to take control of the House of Representatives, putting them on enviable terrain given that in the 22 midterm elections from 1934 to 2018, the president’s party has averaged a loss of 28 House seats.

headline: As Ukraine Bears Down, Life Worsens in Occupied Areas
abstract: Those fleeing speak of the growing dangers of bombardment and of Russian forces commandeering homes and sheltering among civilians.
lead_paragraph: SOUTHERN UKRAINE — Some fled on foot, clambering across a destroyed bridge as fighting engulfed their village. Others traveled out in convoys of cars through Russian military checkpoints. What these families left behind, they said in interviews on their journey in search of safety, was escalating danger and hardship in the Russian-occupied region of Kherson and surrounding areas, where a pivotal confrontation of the war is looming.

headline: What I’m Voting For
abstract: From inflation to crime to abortion, there is no shortage of issues battling for the attention of midterm voters. New York Times photographers talked to men and women across the country about the issues that mattered to them.
lead_paragraph: From inflation to crime to abortion, there is no shortage of issues battling for the attention of midterm voters. New York Times photographers talked to men and women across the country about the issues that mattered to them.

headline: Why the 92nd Street Y Hired a Rabbi
abstract: With antisemitism on the rise, the cultural institution decided to more fully embrace its Jewish identity.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll meet the rabbi that the 92nd Street Y is hiring in an effort, its chief executive says, to “more publicly assert our Jewish identity.” We’ll also find out about the crop that is being harvested legally in New York State for the first time in decades.

headline: The War in Ukraine Will End, and That’s When We’ll See the True Tensions in Europe
abstract: A cold winter won’t break the E.U.’s resolve. Peace negotiations might.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Europe these days reminds me of the early weeks of the pandemic: We are living with a sense that the end of the world is just around the corner. But this time, anxiety over Russia’s nuclear weapons has replaced talk of the virus.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: European countries are backing Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: More than eight months into Russia’s war on Ukraine, Europe is holding firm on maintaining support for Ukraine and tough sanctions on Russia — even amid an escalating cost-of-living crisis that has precipitated strikes, protests and gloom. Most of those pushing for immediate peace or a re-embrace of Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, are for now sequestered in the political opposition.

headline: Word of the Day: stupendous
abstract: This word has appeared in 38 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word stupendous has appeared in 38 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 10 in “Black Holes May Hide a Mind-Bending Secret About Our Universe” by Dennis Overbye:

headline: The World Is Falling Short of Its Climate Goals. Four Big Emitters Show Why.
abstract: New data reveals progress toward climate goals but also major challenges ahead.
lead_paragraph: New data reveals progress toward climate goals but also major challenges ahead.

headline: Late Night Rates Trump’s New Nickname for Ron DeSantis
abstract: “Trump doesn’t even know what that means,” Jimmy Fallon said after Donald Trump referred to the Florida governor as “Ron DeSanctimonious.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Here’s what to expect on Tuesday at the climate talks in Egypt.
abstract: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — Climate activists are expected to increase pressure on companies and world leaders on Tuesday at the United Nations climate summit, demanding that they move faster on pledges to reduce emissions.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — Climate activists are expected to increase pressure on companies and world leaders on Tuesday at the United Nations climate summit, demanding that they move faster on pledges to reduce emissions.

headline: Cities
abstract: Are you a city person? Or do you prefer a more quiet life?
lead_paragraph: A recent Times article profiled the downtowns of 10 cities across America, including Chicago, pictured above.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: To Cover the Midterms, It’s All Hands on Deck
abstract: David Halbfinger, the Politics editor for The New York Times, shares what goes into overseeing a sprawling operation.
lead_paragraph: Election Day for the 2022 midterms is finally here — but for the New York Times journalists who write about the campaigns, the divisions within the country and the national mood, the work began well before November. The coverage effort is newsroom-wide: Journalists from desks such as Culture and Business have a hand in the report, but “the Politics desk is ground zero for all of this,” said David Halbfinger, The Times’s Politics editor.

headline: A Soccer Team Once United Iran. Now It Reflects Its Divisions.
abstract: Team Melli was long seen as a unifying force in a fractious nation. As it heads to the World Cup, it has become ensnared in its country’s internal politics.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of Argentina vs. Mexico and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: Rotted Vegetables and Rancid Milk No More, as a Bridge Replaces Ferries
abstract: Truck drivers used to wait for days before crossing the Gambia River by ferry, but a towering bridge has cut the transit time down to minutes, and brought Senegal and Gambia closer.
lead_paragraph: MADINA WANDIFA, Senegal — Although still sweaty and tired after his long journey, the long-distance truck driver was upbeat as he watched workers unload hundreds of boxes of butter from his truck onto the pavement of a busy city street in southern Senegal.

headline: Kenya Discloses Part of Secret Railway Contract With China
abstract: The publication of details of a 2014 loan agreement for a cross-country train fulfilled a campaign vow by President William Ruto and revealed Beijing’s tough terms.
lead_paragraph: Kenya’s government has disclosed some details of the loan agreement the country signed in 2014 with China to build a railway, a major step toward political accountability but one that could strain relations with Beijing, the country’s top financier of infrastructure projects.

headline: What Time Do the Polls Close? A State-by-State Guide
abstract: A mapped guide to the races at stake in the midterm elections across the country.
lead_paragraph: A mapped guide to the races at stake in the midterm elections across the country.

headline: How to Talk to Kids About Drugs in the Age of Fentanyl
abstract: Fentanyl has exponentially increased the risk of youthful experiments.
lead_paragraph: In September, two 15-year-old Los Angeles girls overdosed on fentanyl, one of them fatally, after they purchased what they thought were prescription opioid‌‌ pills. Although most overdose deaths occur among adults, teen opioid fatalities have doubled in recent years, even as opioid use among adolescents has plummeted.

headline: What Foods Are Closely Linked to Someone You Love?
abstract: Share your favorite food memory, and the person who inspired it.
lead_paragraph: When you have family get-togethers, are there certain dishes you can always count on being part of the meal? Do you have any beloved recipes or food traditions in your family? Does anyone prepare a favorite dish or dessert for you on birthdays or holidays? Do any foods remind you of people you love?

headline: How We’ve Come to Genuflect to the ‘Free Market’
abstract: Jacob Soll’s ambitious history takes us from Cicero to Milton Friedman, but is hobbled by questionable assertions.
lead_paragraph: Late in the process of writing what was going to be a positive, if not quite head-over-heels, review of “Free Market,” I tried looking up a quote that the author Jacob Soll appeared to attribute to Milton Friedman. The famed economist, Soll writes, “came up with the nihilistic and even possibly anti-democratic libertarian concept that ‘all bad things come from governments.’”

headline: Fire Dept.’s First Female Boss Takes Over an Agency Resistant to Change
abstract: Laura Kavanagh has never been a firefighter, but has deep experience with the department and the city. She oversees 17,370 people, and is the youngest leader in a century.
lead_paragraph: Laura Kavanagh had been out celebrating: The next day she would become the New York Fire Department’s acting commissioner, and she had gathered with friends on a Thursday night to toast her success.

headline: Haruki Murakami Has Never Found Writing Painful
abstract: In a new memoir, “Novelist as a Vocation,” the Japanese writer reflects on his craft and his career.
lead_paragraph: Since 2007, success as a novelist settled comfortably upon him, the Japanese writer Haruki Murakami has, in his eccentric way, been writing an autobiography. Without advertising itself as such, it nevertheless keeps arriving, piecemeal: first a short, brilliant book about his habits as a daily runner, later a long essay about his father, most recently an illustrated compendium of his T-shirt collection.

headline: Compare and Contrast. But Never Confess.
abstract: “Like” and “I Can Explain” delightfully get inside kids’ heads as they puzzle out what it means to be human — and how to keep one step ahead of Mom.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t like “Like.” I loved “Like.”

headline: Are the Polls Still Missing ‘Hidden’ Republicans? Here’s What We’re Doing to Find Out.
abstract: There’s no breakthrough in our experiment yet, but the differences are intriguing.
lead_paragraph: It won’t be long until we learn the results of the 2022 midterm elections — and how the polls fared.

headline: Gabrielle Blair Embraces ‘the Least Sexy Way to Talk About Sex’
abstract: In her book “Ejaculate Responsibly,” the home renovation guru encourages readers to revisit their thinking about unwanted pregnancies.
lead_paragraph: Rarely does an author pull off a pivot as head-spinning as the one Gabrielle Blair made between her first book and her second. “Design Mom” (2015) is a room-by-room guide to living with children, featuring aspirational photography, tips for decluttering a mudroom and gentle reminders not to skew too highbrow in the Lego phase of life.

headline: Hillary Clinton Accepted Her Loss, but a Lot Has Changed Since 2016
abstract: How the defeated behave matters as much as who wins.
lead_paragraph: America is holding its first coast-to-coast elections since the insurrection at the U.S. Capitol in 2021. That revolt, an attempt to stop the certification of the last presidential election, cost several lives. A lot is at stake.

headline: War, Sex, Statecraft and Lots of Bling
abstract: Christopher de Bellaigue’s “The Lion House” is a history of the 16th-century Ottoman sultanate that reads like a novel, overflowing with naval battles, high-stakes diplomacy, opulence, avarice and brutality.
lead_paragraph: When it was discovered in 2014, in the habitable zone of a red dwarf star, the planet Kepler 186f was suggested as a possible future home for our human descendants. Of course, like all the most desirable real estate, it’s probably already occupied. Five hundred light-years away, its alien natives might actually be watching the events of our 16th century right now, as if on a box set.

headline: Daniel Barenboim, a Towering Maestro Held Back by Illness
abstract: The pianist and conductor turns 80 soon, but deteriorating health has kept him from the celebrations he had long planned.
lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be a time of celebration for Daniel Barenboim.

headline: A Planned Restart of a Crab Harvest Pits Conservation Against Industry
abstract: After a decade-long ban, the potential revival of crab harvesting in the Delaware Bay poses a threat to shorebirds, naturalists say.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in 10 years, a fisheries regulator is poised to restart the harvest of female horseshoe crabs in the Delaware Bay, a policy change that conservationists say will threaten the survival of the Atlantic species of the red knot, an imperiled shorebird.

headline: Jovan Adepo and Thundercat on Jazz, Superheroes and Ego Death
abstract: Two creative people in two different fields in one wide-ranging conversation. This time: the “Watchmen” actor and the musician.
lead_paragraph: The anime-loving singer and jazz-trained bassist known as Thundercat occupies such a specific place in popular music, it’s easy to forget how ubiquitous he is: Apart from his own funk- and jazz-inflected R&B releases, the 38-year-old artist (born Stephen Bruner in Los Angeles) has collaborated over the years with everyone from Erykah Badu to Kendrick Lamar to the California crossover thrash band Suicidal Tendencies.

headline: You’ve Planned the Holiday Menu. Now Where Will You Put All the Guests?
abstract: If you’re expecting a big crowd for Thanksgiving, you’ll need a flexible space that can accommodate everyone. Here’s how to design it.
lead_paragraph: With the holidays approaching, have you thought about how you’ll accommodate all of your guests when they come for dinner?

headline: George Saunders on the ‘Braindead Megaphone’ That Makes Our Politics So Awful
abstract: The writer shares his observations on how social media has shaped the American psyche — and how more compassion and affection could help.
lead_paragraph: George Saunders is regarded as one of our greatest living fiction writers. He won the Booker Prize in 2017 for his novel “Lincoln in the Bardo” and has published numerous short-story collections to wide acclaim, including his most recent book, “Liberation Day.” He also happens to be one of my favorite people to read and to talk to.

headline: No One Forced Republicans to Do Any of These Things
abstract: Why do we act as though the lunacy of election denial is an organic phenomenon?
lead_paragraph: In “The Eighteenth Brumaire of Louis Bonaparte,” Karl Marx famously observed, “Men make their own history, but they do not make it as they please; they do not make it under self-selected circumstances, but under circumstances existing already, given and transmitted from the past.”

headline: New Voting Laws Add Difficulties for People With Disabilities
abstract: Restrictions in several states on mail-in voting are sending more people with disabilities to the polls. What they find isn’t always easy to navigate.
lead_paragraph: Laura Halvorson was ready to vote. On Thursday afternoon, she sat in front of a ballot screen at the Igo Library in San Antonio, after spending a month preparing for this moment. It was the first time in years that she had been in a public place, other than a doctor’s office.

headline: What Dreams Are Made On
abstract: Five luminous bedtime books to help little ones wind down at night.
lead_paragraph: Falling asleep, drifting off — you’d think that bedtime would be the most effortless part of our days. Yet the passage from waking life to the world of dreams is anything but straightforward. It requires ritual, strategy; it invites delay and procrastination. With darkness comes a host of dangers: anxious thoughts, potential nightmares, a menacing presence beneath the bed. But darkness also ushers in magic, the magic of the familiar made wonderful and strange. In the moonlight, everything appears changed; on the cusp of sleep, reality dissolves into dream. Five new picture books smooth the tricky path to bedtime by celebrating both the quiet pleasures and the wild transformations that happen at night.

headline: The Return of the Jaguar
abstract: Thanks to Mexican conservation efforts, the jaguar is making a comeback in the Yucatán Peninsula. A traveler ventures into its habitat in the tropical jungles surrounding an ancient Maya city.
lead_paragraph: From the top of the great pyramid of the ancient Maya city of Calakmul in the southern Yucatán Peninsula in Mexico, you can see all the way to Guatemala. The jungle stretches out infinitely in every direction, an ocean of green punctuated only by the stepped pyramid peaks of two other Maya temples.

headline: Can an Island Feed Itself?
abstract: After years of destructive weather that have disrupted Puerto Rico’s food supplies, new visions of local agriculture are taking root.
lead_paragraph: When Hurricane Maria hit Puerto Rico in September 2017, Alfredo Aponte Zayas took shelter in his grandmother’s house, which had been built to withstand strong storms. He spent two days inside consoling his eldest daughter as they watched water pouring in through the electrical sockets. When he finally ventured out, once the hurricane passed, he found a ruined landscape. What trees remained standing had been stripped to their trunks. Hundreds of cows lay dead in the fields; half-collapsed houses were everywhere.

headline: Ocean-Eaten Islands, Fire-Scarred Forests: Our Changing World in Pictures
abstract: No single image tells the story of a climate in crisis, but our photographers have come back from their global travels with an encyclopedia’s worth of pictures that hint at the scope and devastation.
lead_paragraph: Climate change does not lend itself to easy documentation.

headline: Here are the states that allow same-day voter registration.
abstract: Nearly half of U.S. states allow voters to register and cast ballots on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half of U.S. states allow voters to register and cast ballots on Election Day. Vote.gov provides state-specific information, including where to register and what documents are required.

headline: This is how ranked-choice voting works.
abstract: The system, in which voters list candidates in order of preference, is gaining popularity around the nation. Nevada will vote whether to adopt it.
lead_paragraph: Ranked-choice voting, when voters list candidates in order of preference instead of casting a single ballot, has the potential this election season to shake up the two party system in the United States.

headline: Film Club: ‘New Climate Promises, Same Old Global Warming’
abstract: What responsibility do corporations have right now to take action on climate change?
lead_paragraph: “New Climate Promises, Same Old Global Warming” is a five-minute film that addresses the issue of corporate responsibility with regard to climate change. Many of the world’s biggest and most polluting corporations have recently promised to stop adding carbon to the atmosphere, saying that they’ll reach net-zero emissions in the next few decades. What is the value of these promises?

headline: How Democracy Itself Ended Up on the Ballot in Wisconsin
abstract: A 50-50 battleground state has become an experiment in single-party rule — and today’s election may push it a stage further.
lead_paragraph: Over the last decade, Wisconsin has become an extreme experiment in single-party rule. Republican officials have redrawn the state’s election districts and rewritten laws to ensure their domination of the state’s legislature.

headline: Your Election Day Guide
abstract: How to make sense of the results.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the only certainty about today’s midterm elections — which will determine control of American government at all levels and shape democracy’s future — is that the polls will close tonight.

headline: Texas High Schoolers Must Retake SATs After Tests Fly Off UPS Truck
abstract: Seniors who sat for the SATs last month at El Paso High School will have to retake the test after many of the sheets with their answers were scattered on the street.
lead_paragraph: The rumors had been circulating through the hallways of El Paso High School for days: Students had seen test papers strewn across busy Mesa Street on Oct. 28, and the pencil-filled Scantron bubbles were a dead giveaway — these were SAT tests, just like the ones that 315 students had taken at the school in Texas the day before.

headline: Maduro faults capitalism for causing climate change, but doesn’t mention Venezuela’s historic role in oil.
abstract: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela denounced capitalism and the extraction of natural resources as the causes of climate change during a scorching critique at COP27 on Tuesday that made no mention of his own country’s history as an oil producer.
lead_paragraph: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela denounced capitalism and the extraction of natural resources as the causes of climate change during a scorching critique at COP27 on Tuesday that made no mention of his own country’s history as an oil producer.

headline: The World’s Democracies Ask: Why Can’t America Fix Itself?
abstract: Conversations across continents reveal alarm over the United States’ direction, as it slides away from ideals it once pressed other nations to adopt.
lead_paragraph: Lin Wei-hsuan was just a child when he observed his first Taiwanese election almost two decades ago. His parents took him to watch the vote-counting, where volunteers held up each paper ballot, shouting out the choice and marking it on a board for all to see — the huge crowd of citizens inside, and many more watching live on television.

headline: The Song of the Fall? It’s a Symphony, Actually.
abstract: A 120-year-old piece by Gustav Mahler is finding new life with unlikely listeners after a star turn in “Tár.”
lead_paragraph: For a 70-minute Austrian symphony first performed more than a century ago, Mahler’s Fifth makes a surprisingly strong case for itself as the song of the season.

headline: A lawmaker shouted at the sister of a jailed Egyptian activist at a U.N. event.
abstract: A prison hunger strike by the dissident, Alaa Abd El Fattah, has overshadowed the climate summit in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — The Egyptian lawmaker stood in a dark suit under the bright lights of a United Nations-sponsored news conference at COP27 on Tuesday, confronting the sister of Egypt’s most famous political prisoner before dozens of international journalists and other participants in the climate summit.

headline: Five States Have Abortion Referendums on the Ballot.
abstract: After voters in Kansas rejected an amendment to the state’s Constitution in August, five other states will vote on proposals about abortion.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s overturning of Roe v. Wade in June at first appeared like it might change Democratic fortunes in this year’s midterm elections, giving the party an energizing issue even as inflation remained high and President Biden’s approval ratings remained low.

headline: Why Wall Street Loves Gridlock in Washington
abstract: Stocks tend to rally after midterm elections, historical data shows. They perform even better when voters deliver divided government.
lead_paragraph: It’s become a favorite data point among sell-side Wall Street historians: In the year after every midterm election since 1950, the S&P 500 has gone up, regardless of the party in power.

headline: Churchill’s Aura, and Bright Colors, Draw New Fans to His Art
abstract: A statesman for whom painting became a refuge, Winston Churchill created hundreds of works, some of which have sold at elevated prices in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Winston Churchill, whose fiery resolve and puckish impudence led many to embrace him as an inspiring, authentic, if imperfect, leader, never set out to become an accomplished artist. He only began painting as a respite from depression when, at age 40 in 1915, he resigned as the civilian head of Britain’s Royal Navy during World War I.

headline: A Closer Look at Churchill as Painter
abstract: Though an amateur, Churchill developed accomplished senses of space and color in his landscapes and still lifes.
lead_paragraph: Though an amateur, Churchill developed accomplished senses of space and color in his landscapes and still lifes.

headline: A Last-Minute Guide for California Voters
abstract: What to know about voting in today’s election and following the results.
lead_paragraph: Today is Election Day.

headline: For Fitness Buffs and Landlords, Gyms Are Hot Again
abstract: Hoping to capitalize on a renewed interest in communal experiences, fitness chains are reconfiguring their spaces, offering more room to exercise and better amenities.
lead_paragraph: Jenny Radke, a Broadway and television actress, was never big on joining health clubs or taking fitness classes. With a background in dance, she has long known how to keep herself fit.

headline: Jimmy DeSana, Downtown Pioneer and Provocateur, Goes Mainstream
abstract: The photographer moved effortlessly between scenes: No Wave music, performance, queer subcultures, downtown nightlife, the Pictures Generation and mail art.
lead_paragraph: A list of things Jimmy DeSana photographed — shoes, sofas, legs and butts — misses his true subject, which was a sensibility. He regarded the body as a playground, gender as an ongoing invention, and domestic interiors as surreal constructions. He had a queer take on life.

headline: Colts Owner Defends Hiring Coach With No N.F.L. Experience
abstract: Jeff Saturday, most recently an ESPN analyst, was tabbed as the team’s interim head coach, having coached only high school football.
lead_paragraph: The Indianapolis Colts hired Jeff Saturday, who has never coached above the high school level, as their interim head coach on Monday. The move stunned fans, the news media and executives of other N.F.L. teams.

headline: Can You Get a Full-Body Workout in 20 Minutes?
abstract: Yes, but you have to pick the right routine.
lead_paragraph: Q: Sometimes I only have 20 minutes for a workout. What are the most efficient exercises to make the best use of my time?

headline: To Play the Queen, ‘The Crown’ Chooses Another Stalwart Briton
abstract: Peter Morgan, the show’s creator, said that Imelda Staunton had the “vulnerability and strength” to play Queen Elizabeth II for the final two seasons.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Almost midway through the new season of “The Crown,” which arrives on Netflix on Wednesday, Queen Elizabeth II, played by Imelda Staunton, is aggressively confronted, one after another, by almost every member of her immediate family. Her three older children want to get divorced; her sister, Princess Margaret, is still angry with her for forbidding her marriage, 40 years earlier, to the divorced Peter Townsend. Even her mother upbraids her for being insufficiently stoic.

headline: Kohl’s Chief Executive, Michelle Gass, Will Depart to Join Levi’s
abstract: Ms. Gass, who will be become president at the denim maker, is expected to take over the top post at the company within 18 months.
lead_paragraph: Kohl’s chief executive, Michelle Gass, is leaving the department store chain next month to become president of Levi Strauss & Company and eventually succeed its longtime leader, Chip Bergh.

headline: These Farmers Tried to Stop Yet Another Coal Mine. What Happened Next?
abstract: In South Africa, a township’s battle over a new mine shows the challenge of a nation dependent on coal, but also desperate to leave it behind.
lead_paragraph: PHOLA, South Africa — Dozens of cattle farmers swarmed the excavator clawing into a green pasture in South Africa’s coal belt, shouting a threat to the man behind the controls: Stop digging, or they would topple the machine.

headline: Philadelphia says it will delay counting thousands of paper ballots.
abstract: The decision will slow down the count in a hotly contested battleground state, where John Fetterman, a Democrat, and Mehmet Oz, a Republican, are in a close Senate race.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia agency that oversees elections said it will delay counting thousands of paper ballots after the polls close Tuesday night because of a lawsuit that accused it of being open to double counting.

headline: Fear and suspicion hang over the midterm elections.
abstract: For the vast majority of the 40 million Americans who have already voted in the midterm elections, the process was smooth and unremarkable.
lead_paragraph: For the vast majority of the 40 million Americans who have already voted in the midterm elections, the process was smooth and unremarkable.

headline: Video Shows Total Lunar Eclipse
abstract: Video from Philadelphia showed the sun, the Earth and the moon in a line, which caused the moon to pass through Earth’s shadow in the last total lunar eclipse until 2025.
lead_paragraph: Video from Philadelphia showed the sun, the Earth and the moon in a line, which caused the moon to pass through Earth’s shadow in the last total lunar eclipse until 2025.

headline: Draft Report Offers Starkest View Yet of U.S. Climate Threats
abstract: “The things Americans value most are at risk,” says a draft of the National Climate Assessment, a major federal scientific report slated for release next year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The effects of climate change are already “far-reaching and worsening” throughout all regions in the United States, posing profound risks to virtually every aspect of society, whether it’s drinking water supplies in the Midwest or small businesses in the Southeast, according to a draft scientific report being circulated by the federal government.

headline: Antidepressants Don’t Work the Way Many People Think
abstract: The most commonly prescribed medications for depression are somewhat effective — but not because they correct a “chemical imbalance.”
lead_paragraph: Over the course of the Covid-19 pandemic, rates of depression and anxiety soared, and many Americans turned to antidepressant medication to help them cope. Even before the emergence of Covid, 1 in 8 American adults was taking an antidepressant drug. According to one estimate, that number rose by 18.6 percent during 2020. Zoloft is now the 12th most commonly prescribed medication in the United States.

headline: While candidates made their final appeals, Trump tried to steal the spotlight.
abstract: President Biden and other major figures hit the campaign trail Monday, but former President Trump’s tease of a 2024 White House run also drew attention.
lead_paragraph: In the last full day of campaigning, Republican and Democratic candidates made their final appeals to voters before one of the most consequential and unpredictable midterm campaigns drew to a close.

headline: Setting a Kahlo Drawing Aflame in Search of an NFT Spark
abstract: It’s tough to profit in the struggling market of blockchain assets right now. Burning a purported drawing from Frida Kahlo’s personal diary didn’t help a businessman’s cause.
lead_paragraph: First came the mariachi band, a flame-juggling dancer and the models in bathing suits and ball gowns sauntering beside the pool of a Miami mansion.

headline: French Cardinal’s Admission Renews Scrutiny of Church Sexual Abuse
abstract: A former archbishop of Bordeaux acknowledged that he had behaved “reprehensibly” with a 14-year-old girl over three decades ago, in the latest revelation to jolt Roman Catholics in France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A cardinal’s admission that he had behaved “reprehensibly” with a 14-year-old girl over three decades ago was one of several revelations that threw a gathering of French bishops into turmoil this week, renewing scrutiny of sexual abuse in the Roman Catholic Church in France a little over a year after a landmark report on the pervasiveness of the issue.

headline: ‘Incredible but True’ Review: Track to the Future
abstract: A suburban couple makes a life-altering discovery in the basement of their new home in this delightfully odd comedy.
lead_paragraph: However you respond to the wacky oeuvre of the French filmmaker Quentin Dupieux, its loopy originality is cheering. Through a string of out-there movies featuring killer tires, monstrous insects and cursed outerwear, he has remained committed to exposing the sadness behind much of human silliness. Whatever his subject, it’s never solely about the goof.

headline: Taylor Swift’s Second-Week Sales Are Still Among the Year’s Biggest
abstract: The singer’s blockbuster new album, “Midnights,” holds strong atop the Billboard 200 chart, and her single “Anti-Hero” is No. 1 on the Hot 100.
lead_paragraph: Following the expectation-shattering blockbuster debut of her new album, “Midnights,” Taylor Swift has coasted to a second week atop the charts, earning the equivalent of another 342,000 album sales, according to the tracking service Luminate.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews George Saunders
abstract: The Nov. 8, 2022 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with George Saunders. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Cybersecurity agency sees no threats to voting but warns of glitches.
abstract: The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency in Washington detected “no specific or credible threat to disrupt” voting ahead of Tuesday’s election, but officials warned that glitches typically occur at polling stations.
lead_paragraph: The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency in Washington detected “no specific or credible threat to disrupt” voting ahead of Tuesday’s election, but officials warned that glitches typically occur at polling stations.

headline: Crypto World Is Rocked as World’s Largest Exchange Rescues Rival
abstract: Binance, the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange, said it had reached a deal to buy FTX, amid fears the industry could enter another meltdown.
lead_paragraph: The cryptocurrency world was rocked on Tuesday as one of the largest exchanges for digital currencies, seemingly on the verge of collapse, was bailed out by a major rival in a deal that underlined the perils of the industry’s volatility.

headline: Evelyn de Rothschild, Scion of Banking Dynasty, Dies at 91
abstract: Initially showing little promise, he eventually joined the family firm and rose to chairman, wielding vast influence in Britain’s financial and political affairs.
lead_paragraph: Evelyn de Rothschild, who as a London scion of the European banking dynasty helped Britain privatize its railroads, steel and coal in the tradition of his ancestors, who had helped finance the acquisition of the Suez Canal and the defeat of Napoleon, died on Monday evening at his home in London. He was 91.

headline: Hello From COP27
abstract: Frustration and distrust among leaders are high. But, for the first time, countries have agreed to discuss funding for climate reparations.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — Hello from the United Nations-led international climate talks at a sprawling convention center here on the shores of the Red Sea.

headline: Elon Musk Puts His Own Politics on Display on Election Day
abstract: The new owner of Twitter has urged his followers to vote Republican.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk put himself and his politics center stage on Twitter on Election Day.

headline: Marc Swanson Draws Comfort From Rural Cemeteries and ’80s Club Music
abstract: For his eerie installation, “A Memorial to Ice at the Dead Deer Disco,” the artist looked to Maggie Nelson, Hollywood glamour and upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: Exiled, like many an artist, from Brooklyn to upstate New York, Marc Swanson came to discover that the celebrated 19th-century painter Thomas Cole had captured many scenes on the Catskill Village land where his house now stood.

headline: The U.S. has a plan to raise cash for developing nations. Some are skeptical.
abstract: John Kerry, the country’s climate envoy, was expected to announce the carbon offset plan on Wednesday. Payments from companies would go to countries struggling to adopt renewable energy.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration wants corporations to fund renewable energy projects in developing countries in a way that allows the companies to count resulting cuts in greenhouse gases against their own climate goals.

headline: Inflation Plagues Democrats in Polling. Will It Crush Them at the Ballot Box?
abstract: Americans are extremely attuned to the cost of living, and as midterm election voters head to the polls, they are divided over whom to blame.
lead_paragraph: Inflation has roared back onto the scene as a key issue ahead of the 2022 midterm elections, after five decades during which slow and steady price increases were a political nonissue.

headline: Katherine Dunn’s Misfit Ballad Resurrects a Voice Like No Other
abstract: The beloved author of “Geek Love,” who died in 2016, left behind an unpublished novel, “Toad,” about a self-loathing hermit. It’s finally available.
lead_paragraph: “Toad” is a curious specimen: a novel written in the 1970s that remained dormant until this year not because it was lost or unfinished or dreadful but because it was spurned. In 1989 Katherine Dunn published “Geek Love,” a tender and hallucinatory yarn about a family of circus freaks. It landed with a cannonball splash where her two earlier novels, “Attic” and “Truck,” had produced ripples. Between Dunn’s early fiction and her runaway hit, she wrote “Toad” and submitted it to her publisher. The book was rejected.

headline: Live Election Results: Top Races to Watch
abstract: Follow the latest results and vote analysis on The Times’s election night dashboard of the most important races in the 2022 midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest results and vote analysis on The Times’s election night dashboard of the most important races in the 2022 midterm elections.

abstract: See live estimates for the control of Congress in tonight’s midterm election results.
lead_paragraph: See live estimates for the control of Congress in tonight’s midterm election results.

headline: At the Oscars of American Fashion, a New Generation Rises
abstract: The CFDA awards recognize a diverse slate of designers amid further calls for change.
lead_paragraph: The night before the midterm elections the winds of change were blowing through the halls of Casa Cipriani on South Street at the tip of Manhattan, whooshing over the step-and-repeat of celebrity entrances at the 67th annual Council of Fashion Designers of America Awards, more colloquially known as “the fashion Oscars.”

headline: A Parisian Brasserie With a Global Footprint Sets Up Shop in TriBeCa
abstract: A Ukrainian restaurant in the former Pegu Club space, a new look for the restaurant in Scandinavia House and more news.
lead_paragraph: Desbrosses Street in TriBeCa is not exactly the Champs-Élysées, but it’s a fairly broad boulevard. So it’s still an appropriate home base for this venerable Paris brasserie, now with a global presence. It’s managed by Groupe Barrière, whose hotels often house a Fouquet’s. Built into the Hotel Barrière Fouquet’s New York, the ground-floor brasserie is brightly elegant, done with Art Deco details, glittering chandeliers, red leather upholstery, brass trim and white tablecloths. Pierre Gagnaire, whose work at Saint-Étienne in Paris has earned him three Michelin stars, is supervising the menu. The executive chef, Bradley Stellings, who worked with Alain Ducasse and his second-in-command, Didier Elena, said that Mr. Gagnaire’s signature, typically a refreshing touch of citrus, could be found in a number of traditional dishes, even the French onion soup. Count on oysters, escargots, caviar service, lobster fricassee, chicken paillard, a salmon casserole with Champagne, and, for dessert, the signature mille-feuille and profiteroles. Sharing the hotel lobby is Par Ici Cafe, for more casual Mediterranean fare in an indoor-outdoor setting with a garden. There are also several bars throughout.

headline: A Surprising WTA Finals Victory Mirrors the Year in Women’s Tennis
abstract: Caroline Garcia, ranked just 79th in May, won the season-ending championship and will finish at No. 4 in a year that saw Serena Williams and Ashleigh Barty retire.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — A sometimes shocking women’s tennis season neared an end here on Monday night with Caroline Garcia’s unexpected victory at the WTA Finals — one more surprise in a year full of them.

headline: Tracking the Climate Toll as Leaders Meet
abstract: Readers discuss climate change as the summit in Egypt continues. Also: Ties to Israel; diarists of Ukraine; hope for the homeless; father and daughter.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: After a grueling election, officials brace for the aftermath.
abstract: This is the first election in which a substantial number of candidates for major offices are election deniers or conspiracy theorists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pulling off a successful election amid partisan rancor, rampant misinformation and widespread doubts about the electoral system has been hard.

headline: With Russia Stalling, Agency Refers Valieva Case to Sports’ Highest Court
abstract: The move by the World Anti-Doping Agency to supersede Russian officials comes amid delays and distrust in how the figure skater’s case is being handled.
lead_paragraph: In a stunning show of mistrust for the way that Russian officials are handling the doping case of Kamila Valieva, the figure skating star from the Beijing Games, the World Anti-Doping Agency has wrested the case from them and filed an appeal directly to the highest court in sports.

headline: Florida’s secretary of state is blocking federal monitors from entering polling sites.
abstract: The secretary, Cord Byrd, joined Republican officials in Missouri in rejecting a Justice Department request to safeguard federal voting laws.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Florida’s Republican secretary of state has rejected a request from the Justice Department to place federal monitors inside polling sites in three of the state’s most populous counties, a move federal officials say could erode protections for minority and disabled voters.

headline: Candy on the Table, an Eye on the Exit: Poll Workers Run a Tense Election Day
abstract: Uncertainty rippled beneath the bustling energy as volunteers readied to face voters, monitors and America’s anxious mood. “I hope they don’t punch me out,” one worker said.
lead_paragraph: Hours before voting began in this Northern Arizona college town, Nina Swidler went over some final notes for her team working an election in the shadow of conspiracy theories and threats.

headline: Elizabeth Holmes Denied New Trial and Is Set to Be Sentenced
abstract: The founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos faces a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A judge on Monday denied Elizabeth Holmes’s requests for a new trial, paving the way for the entrepreneur to be sentenced next week for defrauding investors and potentially sent to prison later this month.

headline: The needle is back. Here’s how it works.
abstract: Our forecasting tool can help you understand which candidate or party is on track for victory.
lead_paragraph: The needle is an innovative forecasting tool that was created by The Times and debuted in 2016. It is intended to help you understand what the votes tallied so far suggest about possible winners in key contests, before the election is called.

headline: How The Times covers elections.
abstract: Explaining the policies and processes that define our journalism.
lead_paragraph: Our mission to bring you the truth through our journalism also includes warning you about the falsehoods. Misinformation flourished across social media in the final stretch before Election Day. We have several reporters tracking the trends and the shifting tactics employed by those spreading untruths. Here are five unfounded claims about voting in the midterm elections.

headline: Israel Has Serious Problems, but Impending Fascism Isn’t One of Them
abstract: Israel’s Arabs deserve to be treated as full fellow citizens rather than as a potential fifth column.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Anshel Pfeffer, a columnist for the left-wing newspaper Haaretz, was appalled last week after the Israeli electorate gave a far-right alliance nearly 11 percent of the vote, making it the third-largest parliamentary bloc in the Knesset. He called the bloc leader, Itamar Ben-Gvir, a “fascist,” a description that fits a man who once kept a portrait of the Israeli terrorist Baruch Goldstein in his living room.

headline: Pelosi, Recounting How She Learned of Attack, Teases Decision About Her Future
abstract: The House speaker would not say how the assault on her husband had affected her thinking about whether to stay in Congress. But she said it underscored how Republicans are determined to “put a stop to me.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi was asleep in her apartment in Washington early one morning last month when her doorbell and loud knocking alerted her to Capitol Police officials at her door. They were there to inform her that her husband, Paul Pelosi, had been attacked inside the couple’s home in San Francisco.

headline: Review: Making an Epic Visual Impact With Minimal Means
abstract: The most intriguing aspects of Dimitris Papaioannou’s “Transverse Orientation” arise from a tension between grandeur and simplicity.
lead_paragraph: A naked man mounts a bull. A bull gives birth to a naked woman. A woman, ensconced in a sort of translucent vulva costume, gives birth to a silicone baby. These are just a few of the surreal and primal images that populate Dimitris Papaioannou’s “Transverse Orientation,” a nearly two-hour wordless spectacle — somewhere between dance, theater, circus arts and visual installation — that had its New York premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Monday.

headline: ‘Her Loss’ Is Playtime for Drake and 21 Savage
abstract: The rappers’ collaborative album is loose and untethered, a frisky experiment that’s intermittently successful.
lead_paragraph: One of the grim inevitabilities of new pop star albums is how they are parsed, chewed through and cracked into gossipy bites the moment they arrive. Within minutes of the release of “Her Loss,” the new collaborative album by Drake and 21 Savage, Twitter and hip-hop news and gossip sites were aflame: a stray reference to Serena Williams’s husband, nods to old rap industry quarrels, an ambiguous multiple entendre referencing Megan Thee Stallion.

headline: D.I.Y. Sci-Fi: A Talk With Justin Benson and Aaron Moorhead
abstract: The filmmaking and acting team discuss their latest low-budget science fiction movie, “Something in the Dirt,” and their work on the Marvel Disney+ series “Moon Knight.”
lead_paragraph: The writing-directing-acting duo Justin Benson and Aaron Moorhead’s latest film, the science fiction satire “Something in the Dirt,” follows John (Moorhead) and Levi (Benson), neighboring tenants in a ramshackle Los Angeles apartment complex. After observing inexplicable supernatural phenomena in Levi’s flat, they attempt to capture the event on camera for personal gain, but meet disaster instead.

headline: After Decades of Resistance, Rich Countries Offer Direct Climate Aid
abstract: Several European leaders at COP27 announced funds to help poor nations recover from loss and damage caused by climate change. The United States was silent.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the COP27 Climate Summit in Egypt.

headline: Epstein Victim Says She May Have ‘Made a Mistake’ in Accusing Dershowitz
abstract: Virginia Giuffre, who was trafficked as a girl by Jeffrey E. Epstein, had accused Alan Dershowitz of abusing her. Now she says she is no longer certain.
lead_paragraph: Virginia Giuffre, a victim of Jeffrey E. Epstein who for years maintained that the law professor Alan Dershowitz had sexually assaulted her when she was a teenager, settled a defamation lawsuit against Mr. Dershowitz on Tuesday and said that she might have “made a mistake” in accusing him.

headline: Wolf Blitzer passes a torch to Jake Tapper for CNN election coverage.
abstract: For the first time since 2004, the veteran broadcaster won’t be the network’s lead anchor announcing general election projections.
lead_paragraph: Wolf Blitzer is synonymous with election night on CNN, the bearded M.C. whose booming pronouncements (“CNN is ready to project…”) have guided Americans through some of the most momentous political events of their lives.

headline: Is Divided Government Good? Don’t Take Elon’s Word for It.
abstract: A widespread view, with questionable justification.
lead_paragraph: I have to admit: It has been fascinating to see Elon Musk tweeting his way ever deeper into a hole. It’s like watching a car crash — an electric, self-driving-car crash.

headline: Review: Tipping the Scales in ‘A Delicate Balance’
abstract: This Off Broadway production of Edward Albee’s drama is the first to feature a full cast of Asian American actors.
lead_paragraph: In the everyday drama of her family life, Agnes knows the importance of maintaining a sense of balance; she’s the fulcrum, she says. It’s a vital role, whatever the circumstance.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘The Men I’ve Begged to Stay’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Laura and I spent the fall of 1960 bantering about the upcoming presidential election. Both freshmen at Texas Lutheran College, we discovered that we shared an interest in politics, though from opposite sides. As we poked and jostled one another, I saw that Laura was bright, beautiful and determined. Our mutual friends said we were a mismatch. But I knew we were possible for each other, and was sure of it on the morning of Nov. 9 when, on my way to breakfast, I heard her voice from a group of women say: “Oh no, here he comes.” — John Canuteson

headline: The French Foreign Legion Advances Into Fashion
abstract: The result? A fresh take on old combat boots.
lead_paragraph: Since its formation in 1831, the French Foreign Legion has had boots on the ground in five continents, on terrain ranging from sun-baked deserts, to snowy wastelands, to festering jungle swamps, to densely crowded metropolises.

headline: Zelensky warns the U.N. climate gathering that Russia’s war is undercutting any possible collective action.
abstract: Reports from the ground and research on previous armed conflicts suggest that the ecological impact of the conflict could be enormous.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Tuesday warned that the “insane” and “illegal” war provoked by Russia was distracting international attention from the threat of climate change and contributing to the “catastrophic” effects of global warming.

headline: Restaurant Review: Why Does This Tibetan Kitchen Also Cook Sichuan Food?
abstract: Nha Sang, in Queens, reflects the recent history of its owners’ homeland.
lead_paragraph: If, like many New Yorkers with a taste for Tibetan food, you are used to finding your momos and shapaley at the top of rickety staircases, or behind cellphone stores, or in the backs of gift shops, your first trip to Nha Sang in Elmhurst, Queens, may come as something of a shock.

headline: Justices Debate State Law Opening Courts to Suits Against Corporations
abstract: A novel Pennsylvania law requires corporations that do business in the state to consent to being sued there, even if the suits have nothing to do with the state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court struggled on Tuesday to decide whether Pennsylvania can require corporations to consent to being sued in its courts — by anyone, for conduct anywhere — as a condition of doing business in the state.

headline: How’s the Jewish Deli Doing?
abstract: As the exhibit “‘I’ll Have What She’s Having’: The Jewish Deli” arrives in New York, Nikita Richardson dives into the evolving scene.
lead_paragraph: The Jewish deli is such a defining part of New York City that it might as well be the very air we breathe (along with pizza, dim sum, Trinidadian doubles and curbside halal).

headline: Summer Renaissance
abstract: Disco is back. And so is Donna Summer. But the singer’s transcendence doesn’t stop at disco.
lead_paragraph: Donna Summer’s 1977 hit “I Feel Love” is the inspiration for the final track on Beyoncé’s new album, “Renaissance.” Summer became the queen of disco in the ’70s, but her catalog goes much further than that. You can hear her legacy in decades of electronic and R&B. “She is an architect of the pop culture we experience today,” J says.

headline: ‘The Music Man,’ Race and Broadway
abstract: Even a famously “white” musical can benefit from a more diverse cast.
lead_paragraph: I want to revisit the issue of modern theater and whiteness these days. Space didn’t allow me to specify in last week’s newsletter that my thoughts on it have been influenced by the shows I have taken in of late.

headline: Disney+ Adds 12 Million Subscribers, but Cites ‘Peak Losses’
abstract: The confidence generated by the subscriber growth was offset by widening financial losses for the company’s direct-to-consumer division over all.
lead_paragraph: Disney emphasized on Tuesday that profitability for its flagship streaming service was on the horizon. But the company’s quarterly results did little to instill confidence, with better-than-expected Disney+ subscriber growth, particularly in North America, offset by widening financial losses for Disney’s direct-to-consumer division as a whole.

headline: Pulses to Their Brains and 2 Women’s Binge Eating Went Away
abstract: A small study demonstrated that deep brain stimulation, used for people with Parkinson’s disease, can limit an urge to overeat.
lead_paragraph: What if an uncontrollable urge to rapidly eat large amounts of food is rooted in an impaired brain circuit? If that were the case, people who live with binge eating disorder — a psychiatric diagnosis — might be no more at fault for overeating than a patient with Parkinson’s disease is for their tremors.

headline: Broadcast networks will give wall-to-wall political coverage, only a recent move for a midterm election.
abstract: Before 2018, TV reporting focused on major Senate and governor races, but now House races are getting detailed coverage.
lead_paragraph: For the second consecutive midterm election cycle, the broadcast networks are preparing to hand over their entire prime-time blocks to election coverage.

headline: Europeans stick by Ukraine, despite mounting challenges.
abstract: Inflation and anxiety over nuclear weapons may be eating into some popular support for the war, but key governments remain insulated from the pressures for now.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The high cost of living is provoking strikes, protests and widespread grumbling. Talk about nuclear weapons has heightened anxieties and encouraged some to demand rapid negotiations. And President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is wooing politicians, including many from populist parties on the right and the left who have flirted with him in the past.

headline: Trump Says He Would Support Representative Kevin McCarthy for Speaker
abstract: The former president said that, if he runs for president and wins in 2024, Senator Mitch McConnell will “be out in two minutes.”
lead_paragraph: In an interview with Fox News, former President Donald J. Trump said he would support Representative Kevin McCarthy, the minority leader, in his bid for speaker if Republicans win back control of the House of Representatives with Tuesday’s election.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: The U.S. Votes
abstract: Plus Europe makes climate pledges and Kenya discloses details of a Chinese railroad contract.
lead_paragraph: After one of the most consequential, unpredictable and expensive midterm campaigns, Americans finally began voting in person yesterday. The polls haven’t closed yet, and I’ll bring you the latest updates on the most consequential results tomorrow. (Follow our live coverage.)

headline: Florida’s Election Police Have a Million-Dollar Budget and Just a Few Cases
abstract: Republican officials established one of the first state agencies in the country solely dedicated to election crimes and voter fraud, but the violations — 20 out of 11 million voters in 2020 — appeared inadvertent.
lead_paragraph: Voter fraud is exceedingly rare in the United States, but that did not stop the Republican-controlled Florida Legislature and Gov. Ron DeSantis, also a Republican, from establishing one of the first state agencies in the country solely dedicated to election crimes and voter fraud.

headline: Trump Threatens to Reveal Unflattering Information About DeSantis if He Runs
abstract: “I know more about him than anybody other than perhaps his wife,” the former president reportedly said.
lead_paragraph: Several hours before polls opened on Tuesday for Election Day in Florida, former President Donald J. Trump warned the state’s governor, Ron DeSantis, against mounting a challenge to Mr. Trump’s own anticipated presidential candidacy in the 2024 election cycle.

headline: Herman Daly, 84, Who Challenged the Economic Gospel of Growth, Dies
abstract: Perhaps the best-known ecological economist, he faulted his mainstream peers for failing to account for the environmental harm growth can bring.
lead_paragraph: Herman Daly, who for more than 50 years argued that the economic gospel of growth as synonymous with prosperity and progress was fundamentally, and dangerously, flawed because it ignored its associated costs, especially the depletion of natural resources and the pollution it engenders, died on Oct. 28 in Richmond, Va. He was 84.

headline: Aerial War Over Ukraine Heats Up as Russia Pounds Cities
abstract: Ukraine, beefing up its air defenses, says Russia has bought ballistic missiles from Iran to replace the precision weapons it is firing at services vital to civilians.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — As Ukrainian officials celebrate the arrival of more advanced Western air-defense systems and claim growing success at shooting down Russian rockets and drones, they are warning that Moscow is buying new long-range weapons against which Kyiv’s forces have little defense — specifically, ballistic missiles from Iran.

headline: Leslie Phillips, 98, Dies; Comic Actor Voiced ‘Harry Potter’ Hat
abstract: He made a name for himself in British satires, then late in his career reached a different audience as the voice of the Sorting Hat in the Harry Potter movies.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Phillips, a British actor who in a career that began before World War II played numerous comic roles, then reached new generations of filmgoers when he provided the voice of the Sorting Hat in the Harry Potter films, died on Monday at his home in London. He was 98.

headline: Informant Likely to Testify as Defense Witness in Oath Keepers Sedition Trial
abstract: A man who served as No. 2 to Stewart Rhodes, the group’s leader, is said to have secretly reported to the F.B.I. in the months leading up to the Jan. 6 attack.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An F.B.I. informant who was embedded for months in the inner circle of Stewart Rhodes, the leader of the Oath Keepers militia, is likely to testify as a defense witness at the seditious conspiracy trial of Mr. Rhodes in connection with the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Lucid Said It Will Raise Up to $1.5 Billion in Capital
abstract: The electric carmaker made the announcement on the same day it reported losing $670 million in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: Lucid Group, an electric car company that has struggled to ramp up manufacturing, said on Tuesday that it had reached agreements to raise up to $1.5 billion, shoring up its financial position as it works to streamline and expand its production operations.

headline: Poll workers in suburban Atlanta were removed after being linked to the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
abstract: A Fulton County official said the woman “seemed to imply” in a social media post that she was going to videotape elements of her work at the polling place, which is forbidden.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Two elections workers, a woman and her son, were removed from their posts at a polling place in suburban Johns Creek, Ga., on Tuesday morning after officials discovered that the woman was linked to the storming of the U.S. Capitol building on Jan. 6, 2021, according to officials from Fulton County and the Georgia secretary of state’s office.

headline: Scientists Say Concussions Can Cause a Brain Disease. These Doctors Disagree.
abstract: As another major medical institution acknowledged the link between concussions and the brain disease C.T.E., a group of scientists who guide many of sports’ top governing organizations dismissed the research at its conference.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — For the first time since 2016, one of the most influential groups guiding doctors, trainers and sports leagues on concussions met last month to decide, among other things, if it was time to recognize the causal relationship between repeated head hits and the degenerative brain disease known as C.T.E.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Ukraine’s New Air Defense System Comes With a Deep Supply of Ammunition
abstract: The two NASAMS launchers delivered to Kyiv fire common air-to-air missiles used by its allies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After eight continuous months of combat, Ukraine is running low on the missiles that its Soviet-era air defense systems use to shoot down Russian drones and warplanes. But on Monday, according to U.S. and Ukrainian officials, the country received its first shipment of an advanced weapon whose design helps solve the supply problem.

headline: Anne Bogart Is Not Entirely Retiring
abstract: “I think that the legacy is more how we offer a model for future young companies,” Bogart said of the theater company she leads, which is ending its producing activities.
lead_paragraph: The theater director Anne Bogart first made a splash with the radical student productions she put on while teaching at New York University in the early 1980s. Her “South Pacific” (1984), for example, was conceived as the show that veterans in a mental institution performed as part of their therapy. Legend has it that the Rodgers and Hammerstein estate snuffed out the production, but Bogart clarified that it simply denied an extension. “It’s more dramatic to say they shut us down,” she said, chuckling.

headline: Voting Machine Problems in Arizona Fuel Right-Wing Fraud Claims
abstract: Maricopa County said it had isolated the problem: printers were not making dark enough markings on the ballots, and that it was not a software problem.
lead_paragraph: A series of technical glitches disrupted ballot counting on Tuesday at about one in four voting centers in Republican-led Maricopa County, Ariz., rekindling embers of baseless voter fraud claims in the right-wing media and politicians.

headline: Yes, There Are Great Thanksgiving Desserts That Aren’t Pie
abstract: Melissa Clark has three of them: pumpkin butterscotch custard, mini oatmeal-cranberry whoopie pies and a simple cardamom cake studded with red-wine pears.
lead_paragraph: Of all the possible Thanksgiving desserts, pies are the most classic.

headline: In a Nation Divided, One Area of Agreement: Voting Matters
abstract: “I want to do everything I can to use my voice to create the kind of democracy that deserves to exist,” one voter said.
lead_paragraph: They had been assured that they were wasting their time. That the fix was in. That a fair outcome was impossible, what with all that Democratic ballot-rigging — or was it Republican voter suppression?

headline: Vermont Election Results
abstract: See full results and maps from the 2022 Vermont elections.
lead_paragraph: See full results and maps from the 2022 Vermont elections.
