headline: Anger and regret as votes are rejected because of missing data in Pennsylvania.
abstract: The ballots were undated, unsigned, incorrectly dated or were not placed in the required outer envelope, causing them to be disqualified.
lead_paragraph: Howard Schwartz filled out his mail-in ballot more than two weeks before Election Day, dropped it in a drop-box near his home in northeast Philadelphia, and found out just the day before the polls opened that his vote had been rejected.

headline: Moore, a Democrat, Will Become Maryland’s First Black Governor
abstract: Wes Moore, the celebrity author and former nonprofit executive, defeated a far-right Republican backed by former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Wes Moore, a Democrat, celebrity author and former nonprofit executive, won Maryland’s election for governor, according to The Associated Press, defeating a far-right Republican and becoming the first Black governor of the state.

headline: Gov. DeSantis Wins Florida Re-election in a Rout
abstract: Ron DeSantis, the Republican governor, demonstrated his viability as a potential presidential contender by beating Charlie Crist, a Democrat with wide recognition in the state.
lead_paragraph: Ron DeSantis won a second term as Florida’s governor in a rout on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, cementing Republicans’ grip on power in a state that was once a premier battleground as well as his own reputation as a top contender for the presidency.

headline: 25-Year-Old Florida Democrat Secures Generation Z’s First House Seat
abstract: Maxwell Alejandro Frost focused on issues important to many young voters: gun violence, climate change, abortion rights and Medicare for all.
lead_paragraph: Generation Z officially has a seat in Congress.

headline: Rubio is re-elected to Senate, defeating Demings in Florida.
abstract: The two-term Republican defeated Representative Val Demings, a Democrat who would have been the state’s first Black senator.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, defeated his Democratic challenger, Representative Val Demings, on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press. The win secures his third term in Congress and further cements the G.O.P.’s grip on the state.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 9, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Nov. 9, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about the construction of a bridge across the Gambia River, which has eliminated one of the region’s biggest traffic bottlenecks, misstated when the project began.  It was in 2015, at a time when then-President Yaya Jammeh was facing intense pressure for change, not 2017, the year he lost power.

headline: Marjorie Taylor Greene Is Re-Elected and Poised for More Power in G.O.P.
abstract: The Georgia Republican’s racist and antisemitic conspiracy theories put her on the party’s fringes, but she is likely to play a more central role in the next Congress.
lead_paragraph: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, whose racist and antisemitic conspiracy theories put her on the fringes of the Republican Party when she was first elected two years ago, was re-elected on Tuesday and is poised to play a more central role in the next Congress. The race was called by The Associated Press.

headline: Judge Dismisses Alexander Vindman’s Lawsuit Against Trump Allies
abstract: Mr. Vindman, a witness in the first Trump impeachment trial, failed to prove that Donald Trump Jr., Rudolph W. Giuliani and others had engaged in more than “political hackery,” the judge wrote.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Tuesday dismissed a lawsuit by Alexander S. Vindman, a chief witness in President Donald J. Trump’s first impeachment trial, against Donald Trump Jr., Rudolph W. Giuliani and two other top Trump allies, saying that Mr. Vindman had failed to prove that they had conspired to intimidate and retaliate against him.

headline: Malliotakis Defends N.Y.C. House Seat, Toppling Familiar Democratic Foe
abstract: Max Rose loses a comeback bid in a district that is based mainly in Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: Representative Nicole Malliotakis defended her seat on Tuesday against Max Rose, the Democrat whom she unseated two years ago, preserving her status as the lone Republican in New York City’s House delegation, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Lee Bontecou, Acclaimed Creator of Unusual Sculptures, Dies at 91
abstract: Her use of what one critic called “a three-dimensional form that was neither painting nor sculpture” earned the kind of praise typically reserved in the 1960s for male art stars.
lead_paragraph: Lee Bontecou, whose enormous, enigmatic wall-mounted sculptures garnered the kind of public acclaim and institutional backing in the 1960s typically reserved for male art stars at the time, died on Tuesday at her home in Florida. She was 91.

headline: Well, What Do We Have Here?!
abstract: David Tuffs reimagines some classic films.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Well, what do we have here?! It appears to be David Tuffs’s fifth New York Times Crossword puzzle, and it’s a fun one.

headline: Bennet Wins Third Senate Term in Colorado in Tougher-Than-Expected Fight
abstract: Senator Michael Bennet, a Colorado Democrat, held off an unexpectedly strong challenge from Joe O’Dea, a Republican making his first run for public office.
lead_paragraph: Senator Michael Bennet, Democrat of Colorado, was elected to a third full term on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, easily holding off a surprisingly strong challenge from Joe O’Dea, a Republican political newcomer.

headline: Chuck Schumer Wins 5th Term as Democrats in N.Y. Hold Hope for Hochul
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul held an early lead in a surprisingly tight race against Rep. Lee Zeldin, a conservative Republican.
lead_paragraph: New York voters elected Senator Chuck Schumer, the Senate majority leader, to a historic fifth term on Tuesday, as Democrats warily watched whether his fellow Democrat, Kathy Hochul, would remain in the governor’s mansion.

headline: Rep. Tom Malinowski’s Rematch With Tom Kean Jr. in N.J. Remains Undecided
abstract: In another critical race, incumbent Rep. Andy Kim, a Democrat, defeated Bob Healey Jr., a Republican.
lead_paragraph: A key congressional race in a New Jersey swing district remained undecided late Tuesday night.

headline: Texas Re-elects Abbott as Its Governor, Rejecting O’Rourke
abstract: Gov. Greg Abbott, a two-term Republican, fended off a strong challenge from Beto O’Rourke, his Democratic opponent.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas brushed off a concerted and well-funded challenge from Beto O’Rourke, the former congressman from El Paso, winning a third term by a comfortable margin on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, and dashing Democrats’ hopes of retaking the governor’s mansion for the first time in decades.

headline: Governor Election Results
abstract: Follow the latest results in the most competitive gubernatorial elections from 11 states.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest results in the most competitive gubernatorial elections from 11 states.

headline: Patience, Please! Networks Urge Caution on a Chaotic Midterm Night.
abstract: “Wait for more votes,” warned CNN’s John King, as wary anchors tried to avoid any predictions that might go awry.
lead_paragraph: After a bitterly contested and partisan midterm election campaign, television’s top news anchors delivered a uniform message on Tuesday to Americans eager for a resolution: Check back tomorrow.

headline: N.Y.C. House Incumbents Coast to Victory, as Other Races Hang in Balance
abstract: Several races, including one involving Representative Sean Patrick Maloney, the powerful Democratic leader, were still awaiting further vote counts.
lead_paragraph: As Democrats and Republicans anxiously watched results in the state’s most competitive congressional races hours after the polls closed on Tuesday night, a handful of New York City races featuring some of the delegation’s biggest names were declared.

headline: Gov. Brian Kemp Wins Re-election in Georgia, Topping Stacey Abrams
abstract: Ms. Abrams, a Democrat, bowed to Mr. Kemp, the Republican incumbent, in a rematch of their 2018 race. He had campaigned on his conservative policy wins.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Stacey Abrams has conceded to Brian Kemp, the Republican governor of Georgia, Mr. Kemp’s campaign said late Tuesday, ending a bitter, high-profile rematch of their 2018 contest.

headline: Rep. Andy Kim Is Re-elected in a New Jersey Swing District
abstract: Mr. Kim, a Democrat, will return to Washington for a third term after a race that appeared to narrow in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: Representative Andy Kim, a New Jersey Democrat whose race appeared to narrow in the final weeks of the campaign, was re-elected on Tuesday to a third term over Republican challenger Bob Healey Jr.

headline: Vance Elected Senator in Ohio; Once Anti-Trump, He Benefited From His Support
abstract: J.D. Vance, the Republican author of “Hillbilly Elegy,” defeated Representative Tim Ryan. Mr. Vance was once a sharp critic of Donald J. Trump but refashioned himself.
lead_paragraph: J.D. Vance, the Republican author of the book “Hillbilly Elegy,” won his Senate race in Ohio, according to The Associated Press, defeating Representative Tim Ryan, a Democrat who ran an attention-grabbing campaign as he tried to win back some of the white working-class voters who had fled his party in the Trump era.

headline: Republicans Gain Ground in Push to Take House as Democrats Hold Off Red Wave
abstract: Republicans picked up momentum in their drive for the House majority, but Democrats held crucial seats, dashing projections of a blood bath, and claimed a key Senate seat in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Republicans on Tuesday gained ground in their push to take control of the House, although Democrats appeared to be holding their own against hard-right G.O.P. candidates in crucial districts as they grasped to defend their narrow majority.

headline: Hassan Holds On in New Hampshire Senate Race
abstract: Maggie Hassan beat Don Bolduc, a retired Army general with far-right views, in a campaign that tightened sharply in the final days.
lead_paragraph: Senator Maggie Hassan of New Hampshire, a Democrat, was re-elected, according to The Associated Press, holding one of her party’s most vulnerable seats in the battle for Senate control.

headline: Bolstered by Attack Ads, Conservative Republican Wins North Carolina Senate Seat
abstract: Ted Budd defeated the Democrat, Cheri Beasley, to capture the seat of the retiring Republican, Senator Richard Burr.
lead_paragraph: Representative Ted Budd, a North Carolina conservative endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump, defeated his Democratic rival, Cheri Beasley, according to The Associated Press, ensuring that Republicans will hold the seat of retiring Senator Richard Burr.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Overcoming Legal Barriers to Find Physical Ones
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Nov. 9, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “I’m just so angry. They constantly are changing things, it feels like, to the disability community.”

headline: A Midseason Look at Who Could Win M.V.P. and Other N.F.L. Awards
abstract: It seems almost certain that Aaron Rodgers won’t win his fifth Most Valuable Player Award, a race in which Patrick Mahomes is fast making up ground on Josh Allen.
lead_paragraph: Josh Allen’s worrisome Sunday against the Jets has thrown the N.F.L.’s Most Valuable Player Award race into chaos.

headline: Phantom Retreats and Stolen Bones: The War of Deceit in Ukraine
abstract: Both Russia and Ukraine are using confusion as well as artillery on the battlefield. The latest question: Is Russia really retreating from the strategic city of Kherson, as its defense minister says, or is it laying a trap?
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — In a jerky cellphone video filmed last week through the window of a bus, the Russian checkpoint in Ukraine’s embattled Kherson region looked abandoned. “Empty,” somebody says in the background, as passengers begin to cheer.

headline: Who’s Driving Climate Change? New Data Catalogs 72,000 Polluters and Counting
abstract: A nonprofit backed by Al Gore and other big environmental donors says it can track emissions down to individual power plants, oil fields and cargo ships.
lead_paragraph: Upstream from Shanghai along the Yangtze River, a sprawling factory complex in eastern China is churning out tens of millions of tons of steel a year — and immense quantities of planet-warming gases.

headline: Murray Wins Sixth Term in Washington, Overcoming a Tough Challenge
abstract: Patty Murray, one of the most senior Democrats, beat back a surprisingly stiff challenge from Tiffany Smiley, a Republican and political newcomer.
lead_paragraph: Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, was elected on Tuesday to a sixth term, according to The Associated Press, overcoming a surprisingly stiff challenge from Tiffany Smiley, a Republican and political newcomer.

headline: Shapiro Defeats Mastriano, an Election Denier, for Pennsylvania Governor
abstract: Josh Shapiro, a Democrat and the state attorney general, defeated Doug Mastriano, who was central to trying to overturn Pennsylvania’s 2020 election results.
lead_paragraph: Josh Shapiro, a Democrat and Pennsylvania’s attorney general, won the governor’s race in the state early Wednesday, according to The Associated Press. He defeated Doug Mastriano, a Republican who was central to efforts to overturn Pennsylvania’s 2020 election results.

headline: Despite scandals, Ken Paxton is re-elected as the Texas attorney general.
abstract: A perennial Republican political survivor and a Trump loyalist, he won a third term, defeating a progressive civil rights lawyer.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Despite a lingering criminal indictment and accusations of corruption by former top aides, Ken Paxton, the perennial Republican political survivor and Trump loyalist, won re-election on Tuesday to a third term as the attorney general of Texas, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Texas 34th Congressional District Election Results
abstract: See full results and maps from the 2022 Texas elections.
lead_paragraph: See full results and maps from the 2022 Texas elections.

headline: Hochul Holds N.Y. Governor’s Mansion for Democrats
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul became the state’s first woman to be elected governor, in a victory that was more decisive than some Democrats had expected.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York, a once-obscure Democrat from Buffalo, won her first full term as governor on Tuesday, prevailing against a Trump-aligned Republican, Representative Lee Zeldin, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Stacey Abrams Delivers Concession Speech to Supporters
abstract: Stacey Abrams, a Democrat, congratulated her Republican opponent, Gov. Brian Kemp, on his re-election and said she would never “stop running for a better Georgia.”
lead_paragraph: Stacey Abrams, a Democrat, congratulated her Republican opponent, Gov. Brian Kemp, on his re-election and said she would never “stop running for a better Georgia.”

headline: Election skeptics are winning races across the country.
abstract: Nearly 200 Republicans so far who questioned or denied the results from 2020 have been elected.
lead_paragraph: While votes are still being counted across the country, nearly 200 Republicans who have questioned the results of the 2020 election — or denied President Biden’s victory outright — have won races so far in the midterms.

headline: Gov. Whitmer Wins Tough Re-election Race Over Dixon in Michigan
abstract: The contest between Gretchen Whitmer, a Democrat who stood up to Donald Trump, and Tudor Dixon, a Trump-backed former steel executive, hinged on abortion, the economy and democracy.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, a Democrat who stood up to former President Donald J. Trump and was once considered one of the most endangered governors in this year’s elections, won a tough race for re-election in Michigan, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Results from the U.S. midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: After a bitterly contested and partisan midterm election campaign, full results from yesterday’s vote in the U.S. are yet to be delivered. Early this morning, as Democrats were bracing to defend their slim majorities in the House of Representatives and the Senate, there was little sign of the so-called red wave that Republicans had expected or hoped for. Follow the latest updates.

headline: Fetterman Wins Pennsylvania Senate Race as Democrats Notch Key Win
abstract: Lt. Gov. John Fetterman, who said he was fighting for everyone “that ever got knocked down,” defeated Mehmet Oz, the celebrity TV host, after a tumultuous campaign.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. John Fetterman, the unconventional, tattooed figure into whom Democrats poured their hopes of preserving their tenuous hold on the Senate, defeated Mehmet Oz to capture Pennsylvania’s Senate race on Tuesday, according to New York Times projections, flipping a seat that had been in Republican hands.

headline: Angie Craig Fends Off G.O.P. Challenger in Minnesota, a Key Win for Democrats
abstract: The congresswoman had focused her campaign on reproductive rights after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June.
lead_paragraph: Representative Angie Craig, the Minnesota congresswoman whose victory helped Democrats create a House majority in 2018, defeated Tyler Kistner, a Republican and former Marine, according to The Associated Press.

headline: G.O.P. Retains House Seat on Long Island, a Swing-District Battleground
abstract: Representative Andrew Garbarino defended his seat for the Republicans, who also held late leads in three other Long Island House races.
lead_paragraph: Representative Andrew Garbarino, a Republican, won his race in the Second Congressional District on Long Island, a key battleground in the battle for the House. The race was called early Wednesday morning by The Associated Press.

headline: Word of the Day: corroborate
abstract: This word has appeared in 175 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word corroborate has appeared in 175 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 2 in “The Unexpected Power of Random Acts of Kindness” by Catherine Pearson:

headline: Late Night Goes Live on Election Night
abstract: Stephen Colbert said that the midterms looked less like a red wave of Republican victories and more like “a pink trickle.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Hochul Wins Full Term in New York Amid a Wave of Discontent
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul became the state’s first woman to be elected governor, prevailing in a contest that was the closest New York has seen in decades.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul, a once-obscure Democrat from Buffalo, won a full term as governor of New York on Tuesday, surviving a potent swell of pandemic-era discontent with her party to become the first woman ever elected to the state’s highest office.

headline: Trump Hoped for a Celebration but Did Not Have Much to Cheer
abstract: The former president endorsed roughly 300 candidates in the midterm elections. With votes still being counted, those in competitive races appeared to have mixed results.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump wasn’t on the ballot Tuesday, but he’d spent the past two years behaving otherwise, aiming to deliver key victories to a Republican Party from which he’s likely to seek, once again, a presidential nomination.

headline: Across Texas, there was neither a red wave nor a blue one.
abstract: The surge of enthusiasm that lifted up Texas Democrats in 2018 did not resurface. At the same time, the party avoided a complete wipeout in South Texas.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The familiar contours of Texas politics held firm for another election despite a concerted effort and many millions in campaign spending aimed at proving otherwise.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Pie
abstract: What kind is the best kind, in your opinion? Why?
lead_paragraph: “Pies are happiness,” writes The Times in a piece that offers recipes for nine types that, the food writers claim, are “easier than you’d think” to make yourself.

headline: Despite the Fears, Election Day Mostly Goes as Planned
abstract: There were the usual glitches, some ginned up into misinformation. But voting was largely free of major incidents of intimidation or disruption.
lead_paragraph: While there were reports of delays, glitches and disinformation in some key swing states — Arizona in particular — that could loom larger as vote counting plays out, few of the major disruptions that had been feared came to pass on Election Day.

headline: Hochul Wins, but It’s No Cakewalk
abstract: The Democrat’s campaign will be analyzed and criticized, but she emerged as the first woman to be elected to the governorship in New York State.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at how Gov. Kathy Hochul fared in her race and how other races around the state were playing out after an unpredictable Election Day.

headline: Votes on Ballot Measures Reflect the Nation’s Divisions
abstract: Mixed results on referendums involving marijuana and voting rights were among the outcomes on state ballots.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Maryland and Missouri approved ballot measures on Tuesday to legalize recreational marijuana, according to The Associated Press, adding those states to a list that has swelled in recent years. But similar efforts were also shot down in Arkansas, North Dakota and South Dakota — a mixed result that underscored the varying public attitudes over marijuana use.

headline: The DBQ Project: Forming Arguments With History, Literature and Current Events
abstract: A history teacher and an English teacher paired New York Times articles with novels and memoirs to prepare students to tackle the document-based question, or DBQ.
lead_paragraph: If you teach high school social studies, you're probably familiar with the document-based question, or DBQ, in which students are asked to analyze a historical issue using primary and secondary sources as evidence.

headline: Michigan, California and Vermont Affirm Abortion Rights in Ballot Proposals
abstract: Voters in all three states amended their constitutions to include reproductive rights, while Kentucky voters rejected an amendment that would have said there was no right to abortion.
lead_paragraph: Voters in all five states where abortion-related questions were on the ballot this week chose to secure access to the procedure or reject further limits. The results, which came just months after the U.S. Supreme Court removed the constitutional right to abortion, showed that when asked directly, a broad cross section of Americans want to protect abortion rights.

headline: Welcome to Manzanar, a Camp of a Horrifying Sort
abstract: Two books for young readers shine a light on the experiences of Japanese Americans during World War II.
lead_paragraph: When “Farewell to Manzanar,” a memoir about a Japanese American family’s incarceration during World War II, was published in 1973, it helped blow open a subject that had been guarded, for different reasons, by both its victims and its perpetrators. Jeanne Wakatsuki Houston’s story was so compelling, so unsentimental yet full of poignant details, that it became assigned reading in many schools and was made into a TV movie.

headline: Did Ron DeSantis Just Become the 2024 Republican Front-Runner?
abstract: The script has been written, the stage prepared. Will the Florida governor play the part that’s waiting for him?
lead_paragraph: A red wave swept Florida, but elsewhere, it barely lapped the shore. Endangered House Democrats are surviving all over, the battle for the Senate may be tilting toward the Democrats, and at best Republicans have won themselves a return to stalemate, not the victory that the circumstances seemed to promise.

headline: How to Make a Cheese Board
abstract: A few cheeses, some fruits and nuts, and bread or crackers are all you need to build an artfully arranged platter.
lead_paragraph: The gates are flung open, guests start to arrive and Thanksgiving dinner? Soon. In the meantime, something to nibble with a glass of wine is required. The simplest, most appealing choice is a cheese plate. A few cheeses artfully arranged with a smattering of fruits and nuts is enough to whet the appetite for the big feast (and not ruin it either, since it’s up to the guests to monitor what they consume).

headline: The Immensity of Seoul’s Sadness
abstract: The deaths at the Halloween celebration were the second mass tragedy to befall that generation.
lead_paragraph: In April 2014, South Koreans watched in horror as TV news showed live footage of a huge ferry tilting 50 to 60 degrees, sinking into the sea. Aboard were over 300 high school students on a school trip to Jeju Island, the country’s most popular resort. Initial reports said the students were all rescued, but it soon emerged that they were, in fact, still on the ship. The nation watched in real time — for two and a half hours — as the ship sank completely and disappeared from view. It would turn out that rescue efforts had been botched, and the captain and crew had escaped in lifeboats after telling the students and other passengers to stay put. The trapped teenagers sent final video messages to their parents, some of which were broadcast on the news. No statement came from the Blue House or President Park Geun-hye, whose whereabouts was not clear. Seven hours later, President Park finally appeared, visiting the Central Disaster Safety and Countermeasures Headquarters and asking, “Why is it so hard to find the students if they are wearing life jackets?”

headline: How to Navigate Gifting Season While Keeping Your Cool
abstract: Etiquette and shopping experts offer advice on some of the most common holiday issues, including wish list taboos, the politics of regifting and climate-conscious gift wrapping.
lead_paragraph: Holiday gift-giving can be a daunting task no matter how long you’ve been at it. Luckily, help is here. We polled a number of gift and shopping gurus to tackle a host of frequently asked questions and to solve those gift-giving dilemmas.

headline: Read Your Way Through Dublin
abstract: Virtuosity and creativity with language are “everyone’s birthright” in the Irish capital, says Tana French, an award-winning mystery writer who has made it her home.
lead_paragraph: One of my favorite things about Dublin is its relationship with words. History is embedded deep in language here. A lot of Dublin communities are tight-knit, with roots that go back centuries, so the dialect is sprinkled with words and phrases that have been passed down over the generations, even after they’ve vanished everywhere else. In Dublin, “my girlfriend” is still “me mot,” from the Victorian English “mort” for “woman” — long gone out of use in England, but still alive here. And back in the 16th century, “child” meant specifically a girl child; it’s been gender-neutral almost everywhere for hundreds of years, but within the last decade, when I had my second baby, older Dublin people still asked me “Is it a boy or a child?”

headline: Noah Beck Doesn’t Know Why He’s Famous
abstract: The TikTok star got lucky during the pandemic. But can he use social media fame to court Hollywood?
lead_paragraph: Noah Beck’s first TikTok post was a flop.

headline: Russia’s Retreat From Kherson Brings Ukraine One Step Closer to Victory
abstract: Ukraine’s defiance of Russian aggression paves the way for a free world that might prevail over Vladimir Putin’s autocratic regime.
lead_paragraph: News Update: Russia’s defense minister, Sergei K. Shoigu, on Wednesday ordered Russian forces to retreat from the city of Kherson in Ukraine.

headline: Books to Kindle Children’s Curiosity About Classical Music
abstract: A young Glenn Gould’s passion for the piano and a sensitive boy’s view of “Carmen.”
lead_paragraph: Formal education in classical music has largely vanished from many American schools. Yet young people still develop a passion for it — at home, from films and television programs and, occasionally, from books such as these two. If these attractive stories do not provide any specific instruction about how music is made, they are likely nevertheless to kindle curiosity.

headline: For Republicans, Crime Pays, No Matter What Else Happens
abstract: The struggles of the contemporary Democratic Party over crime are part of an intraparty ideological struggle that goes back at least to the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: In the months leading up to Election Day, the Republican Party conducted an advertising campaign focused on crime and social disorder, on looting and shoplifting in big cities across the country. They tried to associate Democrats with “defund the police” messages that are, in fact, voiced by a very small minority of party members, but that appear to have undercut mainstream Democrats running in key races, including many who nonetheless hung on to their seats. The issue isn’t going away anytime soon and may well play a major role in 2024.

headline: A History of Humanity in Cubits, Fathoms and Feet
abstract: “Beyond Measure,” by James Vincent, tells the story of human civilization through its systems of measurement, showing how they have promoted knowledge, social control and ongoing conflict.
lead_paragraph: Reading James Vincent’s quietly thrilling new book, “Beyond Measure: The Hidden History of Measurement From Cubits to Quantum Constants,” I began to think that one measure (so to speak) of the human experience might be the number of things we take for granted. Rulers and scales and clocks: These are mundane appliances of daily life, obvious and uncontroversial to the point of banality.

headline: Smartphones Are Like Cars. So Why Don’t We Maintain Them?
abstract: Regularly replacing our phones takes a toll on our wallets and the environment. We should instead take care of them as we do our cars.
lead_paragraph: A smartphone is not all that different from a car. When parents deem their children old and responsible enough, they may let them get one. There are several ways to pay for it: buying outright, financing or leasing. And like cars, phone models have become nearly indistinguishable from one year to the next.

headline: Giorgia Meloni and the Politics of Power Dressing
abstract: The first female prime minister of Italy can’t avoid people caring about what she wears, but she can use it.
lead_paragraph: The first female prime minister of Italy wears Armani.

headline: After Historic Win, Hochul Confronts Challenges and Some Second-Guessing
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul managed to repel late momentum by her Republican opponent, Lee Zeldin. Now she must govern over a fractured New York electorate.
lead_paragraph: For Gov. Kathy Hochul, a second historical milestone was clearly in her grasp: Nearly 15 months after she unexpectedly became New York’s first female governor, she was about to be the first woman in the state to be elected to the position.

headline: Steven Spielberg Gets Personal
abstract: In making his autobiographical film “The Fabelmans,” he confronted some painful family secrets, as well as what it means to be Jewish in America today.
lead_paragraph: Over more than 50 years, Steven Spielberg has directed movies about every subject under the sun. Sharks, dinosaurs, extraterrestrials both friendly and not, pirates, spies, soldiers and heroes both historical and imaginary. Not many filmmakers can match his range. But one subject Spielberg has avoided is himself.

headline: Can a National Museum Rebuild Its Collection Without Colonialism?
abstract: After a fire destroyed thousands of Indigenous artifacts, the curators of this Brazilian museum are adopting a radical new approach.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of Sunday, Sept. 2, 2018, the National Museum of Brazil in Rio de Janeiro was closed, and its hallways were empty. Silent activity, however, coursed within its walls. Electricity hummed through wires connected to computers; climate-controlled storage and three air-conditioning units connected, improperly, to a single circuit breaker in the ground-floor auditorium. When one unit most likely received a surge of electricity it couldn’t handle, the overburdened system sparked. The museum’s smoke-detector system was not set. There were no sprinklers or fire doors, and a flame bloomed. Seeing the news, staff members rushed to the building and pleaded with firefighters to let them enter and rescue something — anything. Within hours, the entire neoclassical colossus built in the early 1800s was ablaze.

headline: Living In ... New Hope, Pa.
abstract: The Bucks County borough may be small, but it has a lot to offer — and much lower taxes than towns on the other side of the Delaware River.
lead_paragraph: The Bucks County borough may be small, but it has a lot to offer — and much lower taxes than towns on the other side of the Delaware River.

headline: Imagining a Memorial to an Unimaginable Number of Covid Deaths
abstract: In cities, especially, monuments have become not just an artistic genre unto themselves but evanescent, ever-evolving tributes to those we lost — and continue to lose.
lead_paragraph: ONE DAY, PROBABLY in the not-too-distant future, somebody will propose, and somebody else will design and somebody else will build, an official memorial to Americans lost to Covid-19 — 1,055,000 as I write this in early October, more than perished in any war in U.S. history. And it is easy to imagine that that memorial will be built in New York City, where so many of the country’s most shattering losses occurred in the pandemic’s initial months in 2020.

headline: Five Takeaways From a Red Wave That Didn’t Reach the Shore
abstract: Democrats showed up, Trump-backed candidates underperformed and inflation wasn’t the whole story: Here are last night’s lessons.
lead_paragraph: Democrats tried to outrun history — and the lead weight of a wounded president who made his final political appearance of the campaign in deep-blue Maryland, in a county he won two years ago by an overwhelming margin.

headline: New Hope, Pa.: A Walkable River Town With Plenty of Attractions
abstract: The Bucks County borough may be small, but it has a lot to offer — and much lower taxes than towns on the other side of the Delaware River.
lead_paragraph: When Kim and Mark Breiland lived in Chesterfield, N.J., near the Pennsylvania border, they loved crossing the Delaware River into New Hope, Pa. With fewer than 3,000 residents, the 1.4-square-mile Bucks County borough is small, but has plenty of attractions: historic architecture, galleries, restaurants, shops, a promenade along the river, a steam railroad, and a playhouse in an old mill.

headline: What You Get for $1.1 Million
abstract: An International-style home in Riverwoods, Ill.; a two-bedroom townhouse in Savannah, Ga.; and an 1845 farmhouse in Manchester, Vt.
lead_paragraph: An International-style home in Riverwoods, Ill.; a two-bedroom townhouse in Savannah, Ga.; and an 1845 farmhouse in Manchester, Vt.

headline: A Girl Loses Her Mother in the Jungle, and a Migrant Dream Dies
abstract: The pandemic, climate change and growing conflict are forcing a seismic shift in global migration. In few places is that more clear than a perilous crossing called the Darién Gap.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: $1.1 Million Homes in Illinois, Georgia and Vermont
abstract: An International-style home in Riverwoods, a two-bedroom townhouse in Savannah and an 1845 farmhouse in Manchester.
lead_paragraph: This home was designed by Philip Thrane, a student of Mies van der Rohe, whose much-admired Farnsworth House is a little over an hour away. Like that house, this one was meant to blur the lines between indoors and outdoors, with sheets of glass that offer views of the surrounding woods, giving the main spaces a front-row seat to the changing of seasons. While it feels remarkably private, this property is just 10 minutes from shopping centers with grocery stores and other amenities.

headline: Sea Turtle Sanctuary Has Survived 40 Years. Climate Change May Kill It.
abstract: Against long odds and initially strong opposition, a pristine marine preserve in the Philippines has thrived for decades under the care of local fishermen. Warming waters threaten the achievement.
lead_paragraph: APO ISLAND, the Philippines — The large green sea turtles used to be terrified of humans, scuttling away as fast as they could.

headline: How a G.O.P. Wave Became a Ripple
abstract: The conditions seemed ripe for Republicans to make big midterm pickups. Voters had other ideas.
lead_paragraph: All the conditions were there for a wave, but in the end Republicans appeared to have generated no more than a red ripple.

headline: Picking the Thanksgiving Wine Is the Easy Part
abstract: For this meal, selecting bottles is so simple that wine’s ceremonial importance is sometimes forgotten in the blizzard of preparations.
lead_paragraph: With all the tricky elements that go into creating the Thanksgiving feast, wine’s role can fade into the background trimmings with the pumpkins and ornamental corn.

headline: See Which 2020 Election Deniers and Skeptics Won and Lost in the Midterm Elections
abstract: More than 220 Republicans who questioned or denied the 2020 election results have won in the midterms so far.
lead_paragraph: More than 220 Republicans who questioned or denied the 2020 election results have won in the midterms so far.

headline: The House Hangs in the Balance, as Fetterman’s Win Boosts Senate Democrats
abstract: Republican hopes of an emphatic repudiation of President Biden had morphed into a district-by-district slog by Wednesday. But the party still had multiple paths to a House majority.
lead_paragraph: Democrats displayed unexpected resilience in the 2022 midterms, flipping a Republican-held Senate seat in Pennsylvania and rebuffing G.O.P. candidates in a wide array of House seats. But the party’s excruciatingly narrow margins in both chambers meant the battle for power on Capitol Hill remained undecided early Wednesday morning.

headline: Here’s a look at Nicole’s path.
China’s Great ‘Zero-Covid’ Guessing Game
abstract: Companies, investors and global policymakers are trying to divine when the Chinese government will drop its strict restrictions. It comes down to one man: the country’s top leader, Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: It is the great economic guessing game about China: When will the Chinese government ditch its zero-tolerance approach to Covid-19?

headline: Counting all of the votes in Nevada could take days, election officials say.
abstract: Overwhelmed state election officials say that they have been flooded by thousands of mail-in ballots, many of which will not be counted until Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Overwhelmed election officials in Nevada say that they have been flooded by thousands of mail-in ballots, and that it may take several days to count the votes and upload results.

headline: The Republican Wave That Wasn’t
abstract: Making sense of the unexpected midterm results.
lead_paragraph: In the early hours of Wednesday, control of both the House and Senate remained uncertain.

headline: Meta Lays Off More Than 11,000 Employees
abstract: The parent of Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp reduced its work force by 13 percent and extended a hiring freeze through the first quarter of next year.
lead_paragraph: Since Mark Zuckerberg founded Facebook in 2004, the Silicon Valley company has steadily hired more employees. At the end of September, it had amassed its largest-ever number of workers, totaling 87,314 people.

headline: The Midterms
abstract: It’s not yet clear which party will control the House or Senate, but the long-trailed “red wave” has not materialized.
lead_paragraph: The votes are still being tallied across the country — but we’re starting to get a picture of what these midterms were all about, and where American politics might be headed. Astead Herndon joins Michael Barbaro, host of “The Daily,” to sift through early midterm election results.

headline: Still Undecided
abstract: The majorities in the House and the Senate remain uncalled. Here’s what we know.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2022 midterm elections for the latest news and updates.

headline: Stocks Fall Amid Unclear Midterm Outcome and Crypto Meltdown
abstract: New data about inflation in the United States due on Thursday will steer expectations over how aggressively the Federal Reserve could be in raising interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Stocks dropped on Wednesday, after expectations of a “red wave,” in which Republicans would comprehensively win control the House and potentially also gain a majority in the Senate, failed to materialize in the midterm elections.

headline: Schools Are Closing Across Florida Ahead of Nicole
abstract: Some districts were closed as early as Wednesday, while others have canceled classes for the rest of the week.
lead_paragraph: Schools and universities across Florida are closing their doors as Nicole, expected to arrive in Florida on late Wednesday or Thursday as a hurricane, closes in on the state.

headline: Running Officials Did Not Test Long-Shot New York City Marathon Winner Before Race
abstract: Sharon Lokedi won Sunday’s marathon in her debut at the distance. Because she was little known, she was not subjected to the prerace drug testing program.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Lokedi, a largely unknown figure in elite distance running, came out of nowhere to win the New York City Marathon on Sunday, toppling some of the fastest marathoners in the world.

headline: Accessories That Are Worth the Fuzz
abstract: Hats, bags and shoes in cheerful colors to combat the cold.

headline: When We’ll Know: The Remaining Key Factors in Georgia, Nevada, Arizona
abstract: Who will control the Senate and the House? Settle in for a long wait.
lead_paragraph: For the second Election Day in a row, election night ends without a clear winner.

headline: Working Without a Contract, Yankees G.M. Has a Long Shopping List
abstract: Aaron Judge’s free agency looms over everything at the general managers’ meetings, but Brian Cashman says he has other holes to fill. Cashman’s own deal will have to wait.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — As the Yankees’ general manager since 1998, Brian Cashman is supposed to lead. He is not used to following. But in terms of keeping the superstar right fielder Aaron Judge, who is free to sign with whichever team he desires for the first time in his career, Cashman suggested he would be doing more following.

headline: Crypto Investors Grapple With the Collapse of a Giant
abstract: Prices of digital currencies have tumbled even after the exchange FTX announced a provisional lifeline by a top rival, Binance.
lead_paragraph: Devastation in the crypto market continued on Wednesday, after the giant crypto exchange Binance announced a bombshell deal to buy its embattled rival, FTX. (The deal excludes FTX’s American operations.) The entire market’s capitalization now stands at $900 billion, down from $3 trillion just one year ago, while major cryptocurrencies were down by double-digit percentages. The damage is largely contained within crypto; both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq closed up yesterday.

headline: A Historic Villa on Tenerife for $1.59 Million
abstract: This 19th-century Mudéjar-style home in the center of Icod de los Vinos, a town on Tenerife in the Canary Islands, is for sale for $1.59 million.
lead_paragraph: This 19th-century Mudéjar-style home in the center of Icod de los Vinos, a town on Tenerife in the Canary Islands, is for sale for $1.59 million.

headline: A Former Social Club on Tenerife: House Hunting in the Canary Islands
abstract: The Canary Island capitals of Las Palmas de Gran Canaria and Santa Cruz de Tenerife are seeing more demand than most of Spain’s other capitals.
lead_paragraph: This eight-bedroom, four-bath house was built in the early 19th century in the historic center of Icod de los Vinos, a town on the northwestern coast of Tenerife, the largest and most populous island among Spain’s Canary Islands.

headline: What Are Your Reactions to the Results of the Midterm Elections?
abstract: As the votes are counted, we invite teenagers to post reactions and have conversations here. What do the results mean for you, your community and our nation?
lead_paragraph: How much attention have you paid to the midterm elections? How do you feel about the results that have been announced so far? What do you think they mean for you, your community, your state and our nation as a whole?

headline: Is My Online Fling Holding Me Back From Dating in Real Life?
abstract: A reader wonders if his online-only relationship with a woman who lives abroad is complicating his search for a partner in morning-breath range.
lead_paragraph: I met a woman online a few months ago. We exchanged numbers and have texted nearly every day since. (She lives in Spain; I live here. We are both in our 20s.) What started as an online sexual fling has evolved into something more: We use pet names, watch TV shows together and confide in each other. We also have sex online. We know this isn’t a real relationship, but if we lived in the same place, it would be amazing! I have been honest about trying to date women where I live, which she dislikes hearing, but I haven’t had much luck. Do you think this online relationship is stifling my ability to find someone in real life?

headline: What We Know So Far About California Election Results
abstract: The statewide races played out largely as predicted.
lead_paragraph: For many election-watchers, the most important contests in the Golden State on Tuesday were in congressional swing districts in Orange County and the Central Valley. A number of House races there were viewed as among the most competitive in the nation.

headline: Migrant Ship, Turned Away by Italy, Heads Toward France
abstract: The new right-wing government allowed passengers on three vessels to disembark, but it stood firm on a fourth, a move that France denounced as “unacceptable.”
lead_paragraph: A charity-run rescue vessel carrying hundreds of migrants was heading to France on Wednesday after Italy declined to allow its passengers to disembark, prompting a claim of victory from the new right-wing, anti-migration government in Rome but sharp criticism from rights groups and from Paris.

headline: Keurig Dr Pepper Invests $50 Million in Nonalcoholic Brewer
abstract: The deal is a sign of continued interest in the fast-growing category, which jumped to about $670 million in sales in 2021.
lead_paragraph: Keurig Dr Pepper has invested $50 million in Athletic Brewing, the nonalcoholic beer maker, as part of a $75 million fund-raising round by Athletic, the companies announced on Wednesday.

headline: The Republican provocateur Lauren Boebert is in an unexpectedly tight race in Colorado.
abstract: A freshman House member, Ms. Boebert, 35, was facing a stiff challenge from Adam Frisch, a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: The race as of Wednesday morning was too close to call in Colorado’s Third Congressional District, where Representative Lauren Boebert, a far-right Republican who heckled President Biden during his State of the Union speech, was locked in a surprisingly tight contest with Adam Frisch, a Democrat.

headline: Adidas Cuts Forecast Again as It Contemplates Future for Yeezy Brand
abstract: The German sportswear company slashed its yearly forecast after dropping the popular Yeezy line over hate speech by its creator, Kanye West.
lead_paragraph: Adidas, just weeks after severing its very profitable relationship with the rapper and designer Kanye West, said on Wednesday that it would need to cut revenue and earnings forecasts for a fourth time this year.

headline: Sarah Ruhl and Rebecca Taichman on Conjuring ‘Becky Nurse of Salem’
abstract: Their new Off Broadway play, a dark comedy about power, inheritance and, of course, witchcraft, is now in previews at Lincoln Center Theater.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Tuesday morning, the playwright Sarah Ruhl and the director Rebecca Taichman were gazing at a window, diamond-paned and much-repaired, on the second floor of the New-York Historical Society. A showpiece of the Society’s exhibition “The Salem Witch Trials: Reckoning and Reclaiming,” the window had once stood in the home of Rebecca Nurse, a Salem woman who was hanged for witchcraft in 1692. At 71, she was the eldest woman among the trials’ two dozen victims.

headline: A diverse field of candidates make history in the midterms.
abstract: The first Black governor of Maryland, the first woman elected to the Senate from Alabama and the first openly transgender state legislator in Montana were among the victors.
lead_paragraph: The first Generation Z member of Congress. The nation’s first openly lesbian governors. The first Black governor of Maryland.

headline: Sean Patrick Maloney Concedes to Mike Lawler in Major Loss for Democrats
abstract: Mr. Maloney, who leads the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, was seeking to represent a different district after New York’s messy redistricting process.
lead_paragraph: Representative Sean Patrick Maloney, the chair of the powerful Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, conceded defeat on Wednesday in his bid for a House seat in New York City’s northern suburbs to a Republican state assemblyman, Mike Lawler, a stinging and symbolic loss for Democrats.

headline: These Thanksgiving Salads Are Bright, Bold and Easy
abstract: Grapefruit and herbs, apples and greens, beets and yogurt: These three pairings are designed to balance out all that holiday richness, Yewande Komolafe writes.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to Thanksgiving, I love using the ingredients of the season to create warmth, comfort and balance. I also love dishes that manage to bring together familiar flavors and unique combinations. Each one of these recipes sets out to do all of that, while being luxurious but still a little lighter than the other items on the table. They may not revolutionize your traditional Thanksgiving feast, but they’ll certainly refresh it.

headline: 50 Years of Stevie Wonder’s ‘Talking Book’
abstract: A conversation about the singer, songwriter and multi-instrumentalist’s studio innovations, and melding of social consciousness and musical creativity.
lead_paragraph: “Talking Book,” from 1972, was Stevie Wonder’s 15th album — yes, you read that correctly. He had been a child star for Motown Records, and after that, a beneficiary of the power of the label’s hit factory. But when he renegotiated his contract in the early 1970s, he secured complete creative control over his music, and that’s when he became a superstar.

headline: The Secret to Thanksgiving Turkey
abstract: J. Kenji López-Alt shares the best way to cook your centerpiece bird.
lead_paragraph: Here at New York Times Cooking we start brainstorming turkeys in July. It’s our job to come up with thrilling new recipes for your Thanksgiving table, and it can take months of testing and tweaking to create something at least as tasty and reliable as the many, many, many turkey recipes that have come before.

headline: A Walk Through the ‘Barbarian’ Basement With Zach Cregger
abstract: The writer and director of the twisty horror film “Barbarian” discusses its secrets while addressing some of the online chatter.
lead_paragraph: Zach Cregger was recently on a hike in the woods when he saw a woman walking toward him on the path. He smiled, took his hands out of his pockets and didn’t linger as she walked by.

headline: 36 Hours in Barcelona
abstract: Leafy pedestrian "superblocks," restored architectural gems and new outstanding restaurants only add to the allure of the Catalan capital.
lead_paragraph: Leafy pedestrian "superblocks," restored architectural gems and new outstanding restaurants only add to the allure of the Catalan capital.

headline: On Twitter, Elon Musk Details His Plans for Twitter’s Business
abstract: Mr. Musk, the social media service’s new owner, has been looking for ways to generate more revenue at the company.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — With little warning, in front of hordes of listeners, Elon Musk on Wednesday laid out his most comprehensive overview for Twitter’s business since he took control of the company less than two weeks ago.

headline: Once Again, a Runoff Election in Georgia May Decide Senate Control
abstract: Senator Raphael Warnock and his Republican challenger, Herschel Walker, are still neck and neck with less than half the vote. They will go to a runoff if neither gains 50 percent.
lead_paragraph: The closely watched Senate race in Georgia might culminate in a runoff election on Dec. 6 if no candidate receives 50 percent of the vote, setting the stage for several more weeks of campaigning in a race that could determine control of the upper chamber.

headline: How Peter Asher, a Jack-of-all-Trades in Music, Mastered Them All
abstract: The British musician, manager, producer, executive and author known for his work with Linda Ronstadt and James Taylor, is the subject of a new book exploring his unique run in the industry.
lead_paragraph: MALIBU, Calif. — In December 1977, in an exceptionally rare move, Rolling Stone put a producer and a manager on its cover: Peter Asher, a bespectacled, copper-haired Brit, photographed sandwiched between his artists James Taylor and Linda Ronstadt.

headline: J.D. Vance Gets What He Came For in Ohio, No Elegy Necessary
abstract: Many Republicans woke up on Wednesday to disappointment. But in Ohio, at least, was the picture of a gambit rewarded as the best-selling author won a Senate seat.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — It was nearly Wednesday morning, long after the beef tenderloin crostini started looking a little pale, when a young man in a red bow tie gave himself permission to dance a little. “Takin’ Care of Business” had, by then, played a half-dozen times, without the business taken care of.

headline: Florida airports close down or warn of possible flight cancellations.
abstract: Orlando and Palm Beach airports said they would halt all commercial arrivals and departures, while others stayed in operation for now.
lead_paragraph: Some of Florida’s busiest airports said they would shut down on Wednesday, and others issued travel advisories about possible cancellations, as Tropical Storm Nicole approached from the east at near hurricane strength.

headline: After Near Wipeout in Election, Israeli Left Wonders: What Now?
abstract: Support for Israel’s left collapsed against Benjamin Netanyahu and his far-right alliance in last week’s election. To regain relevance, the left’s leaders say they need to change — but disagree on how.
lead_paragraph: KIBBUTZ HULDA, Israel — On the night religious ultranationalists triumphed in last week’s Israeli national elections, a funereal hush descended over Kibbutz Hulda, a village in central Israel that had long been a bastion of left-leaning secular parties.

headline: Republican Tom Kean Jr. Defeats Rep. Tom Malinowski, a Democrat, in New Jersey
abstract: The race, a rematch from 2020, had been considered the state’s most competitive congressional contest.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tom Malinowski, a second-term New Jersey Democrat, was defeated on Wednesday by his Republican opponent, Tom Kean Jr., the namesake of a popular former governor making his fourth run for Congress.

headline: Dispute Over Java Man Raises a Question: Who Owns Prehistory?
abstract: An Indonesian claim against a Dutch museum has pushed the debate about restitution into the realm of the natural history museum — where it hasn’t been much of an issue until now.
lead_paragraph: LEIDEN, the Netherlands — Ancient crocodile jaws, the cranium of a primeval water buffalo and a million-year-old turtle shell are just a few of the fossils that fill long metal shelves in a depot of Naturalis Biodiversity Center, a popular natural history museum in the Netherlands.

headline: The Secret Dinners Where Marijuana Is in Every Dish
abstract: Adventurous chefs are hosting semi-clandestine dinners that incorporate cannabis. Does it impart a unique flavor? Or is it there for the buzz?
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.The first dish arrived with panache — a delicate scallop crudo with candied ginger and mushrooms sprinkled on top, served in a giant scallop shell. But where, some surely wanted to know, was the weed?

headline: Tough N.Y. Election Holds Lessons for Republicans and Democrats Alike
abstract: Democrats faced a resurgent Republican Party. But running on crime and inflation was no panacea in a deep blue state.
lead_paragraph: With a few races still up in the air on Wednesday, New Yorkers were parsing returns and finding signs of both Democratic resilience and some surprising Republican gains.

headline: Why Correspondence Chess Is Still Popular Among Elite Players
abstract: Players can take days or even weeks to take a turn, and they have embraced the use of software to find the best moves.
lead_paragraph: After more than two years of play, Jon Edwards, a retired administrator at Princeton University, won the 32nd World Correspondence Chess Championship on tie-breaks last month, beating correspondence chess grandmasters from around the world. Mr. Edwards, who earned his own correspondence chess grandmaster title in the process of winning the championship, is the first American to triumph in the event in nearly 40 years, and only the third American ever to do so.

headline: How News About Maricopa County’s Ballot-Counting Machines Went Viral
abstract: Claims spread from fringe accounts to the mainstream, with help from prominent influencers on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Claims spread from fringe accounts to the mainstream, with help from prominent influencers on Twitter.

headline: Redfin, the Online Real Estate Broker, Lays Off 13% of Its Staff
abstract: The company also said it was shuttering RedfinNow, its home-flipping service, as concerns grow about a slowdown in the housing market.
lead_paragraph: The real estate brokerage firm Redfin said on Wednesday that it was laying off 13 percent of its work force, the company’s latest move to cut costs amid a slowing housing market.

headline: Senate Control Comes Down to a Few Races, and Nevada Is One of Them.
abstract: The duel between Catherine Cortez Masto, the Democratic incumbent, and Adam Laxalt, her Republican challenger, serves as a referendum on voters’ concerns nationwide over inflation and the economy.
lead_paragraph: The duel in Nevada between Senator Catherine Cortez Masto, one of the Democratic Party’s more vulnerable incumbents, and Adam Laxalt, a Republican who helped to spearhead former President Donald J. Trump’s effort to overturn the state’s 2020 election results, is the most expensive political contest in state history — with good reason.

headline: Nicole is an ‘unusual’ storm system, forecasters say.
abstract: Experts say Tropical Storm Nicole has a hurricane-style warm core, but it is wrapped in a vast, lopsided wind shield that more resembles a cold-core storm.
lead_paragraph: Forecasters said Tropical Storm Nicole was a system with abnormal characteristics, including the broad area where it was expected to have an impact.

headline: Medication Treatment for Addiction Is Shorter for Black and Hispanic Patients, Study Finds
abstract: The analysis of 15 years of prescription data showed that the racial disparities are widening.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have long known that racial and ethnic minorities are less likely to be prescribed lifesaving addiction treatment options than white people.

headline: Jordan Is Running Out of Water, a Grim Glimpse of the Future
abstract: The small Middle Eastern nation is already one of the driest countries in the world and rising heat, coupled with a growing population, is making things much worse.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the COP27 Climate Summit in Egypt.

headline: Pat Ryan, a Democrat, Won an Open N.Y. House Seat in August. He Just Did It Again.
abstract: Representative Pat Ryan’s win over a conservative Republican in New York’s 18th Congressional District came just a few months after he won a special election in the 19th District.
lead_paragraph: Three months after preserving an open Democratic House seat in New York’s Hudson Valley, Representative Pat Ryan has done so again, defeating his Republican opponent in a neighboring congressional seat, according to The Associated Press on Friday.

headline: Elizabeth Stewart, Champion of Scotland’s Folk Music, Dies at 83
abstract: She was part of a musical family of Scottish Travellers that furthered the nation’s folk revival and influenced its American counterpart.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Stewart, a folk singer, pianist and composer who furthered the legacy of her musical family and the culture of the ethnic grouping known as Scottish Travellers through her recordings, performances and musicology, died on Oct. 13 in the village of Kemnay, near Aberdeen, Scotland. She was 83.

headline: How ‘Atlanta’ and ‘The Good Fight’ Chose Chaos
abstract: Two great but very different series, ending Thursday, decided that the most realistic portrait of America today is a surrealist one.
lead_paragraph: There’s more separating “Atlanta” and “The Good Fight” than simply the distance between Georgia and Illinois. The first series is a kaleidoscopic comedy (except when it’s a drama) about young Black people in and around the hip-hop industry. The second is a cutting legal drama (except when it’s a comedy), centered on an older, well-to-do white woman at a historically Black law firm in Chicago.

headline: Nets Name Jacque Vaughn as Head Coach
abstract: Vaughn, an assistant coach, was filling in since the team fired Steve Nash last week. Guard Kyrie Irving, who promoted an antisemitic movie on Twitter, remains suspended.
lead_paragraph: No stranger to drama lately, the Nets eschewed a protracted coaching search and made a quick decision to hire someone familiar.

headline: After Months of Silence, Chinese and U.S. Climate Envoys Briefly Speak
abstract: John Kerry, the top U.S. climate negotiator, has met at least three times with his Chinese counterpart at COP27. Their countries are the planet’s biggest polluters.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the COP27 Climate Summit in Egypt.

headline: Wisconsin Voters Re-elect Johnson, an Election Denier, in a Key Senate Race
abstract: Senator Ron Johnson, a Republican and one of the foremost spreaders of misinformation, won a third term, turning back a challenge from Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ron Johnson, a Wisconsin Republican and one of the nation’s foremost spreaders of misinformation, won a third term, according to The Associated Press, turning back a challenge from his Democratic rival, Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes.

headline: Elon Musk’s Twitter Did Not Perform at Its Best on Election Day
abstract: False narratives about voting in the midterm elections proliferated on the platform, which has shed half its employees since Mr. Musk bought the company last month.
lead_paragraph: Before the sky had fully lightened in Arizona on Tuesday morning, one of the most pervasive false narratives of the midterm elections was already spreading on Twitter.

headline: Paul Morantz, Lawyer Who Campaigned Against Cults, Dies at 77
abstract: He took on sects and other fringe groups in California, as well as abusive psychotherapists and a self-help guru. At one point assassins tried to kill him with a rattlesnake.
lead_paragraph: Paul Morantz, a lawyer and investigative journalist who in the 1970s was so successful at taking on cults, abusive psychotherapists and self-proclaimed gurus around California that one of his targets tried to assassinate him with a rattlesnake, died on Oct. 23 in Los Angeles. He was 77.

headline: Molinaro Seizes an Open House Seat in New York From Democrats
abstract: Marc Molinaro, who ran unsuccessfully for governor in 2018, defeated Josh Riley, a Democrat, in New York’s Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: Marc Molinaro, a Republican county executive in New York’s Hudson Valley, has won the race for New York’s 19th Congressional District, flipping a Democratic seat, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Putin’s top security official visits Iran as Russia seeks precision weapons.
abstract: The visit comes as Western and Ukrainian officials warn that Russia is trying to secure high-tech Iranian missiles and drones to deploy on the battlefield.
lead_paragraph: The Kremlin’s top security adviser arrived in Tehran late Tuesday amid growing signs that advanced Iranian weapons are being used on Ukrainian battlefields.

headline: ‘We May Have Reached the Limit of Crazy That Will Be Tolerated’
abstract: Frank Bruni digs into the midterm results with Mallory McMorrow and Jonathan Last.
lead_paragraph: Frank Bruni, a contributing Opinion writer, hosted a written online conversation with Jonathan Last, the editor of The Bulwark, and Mallory McMorrow, a Democratic state senator from Michigan, to discuss midterm results and the future of Americans politics.

headline: Tony Evers and Ron Johnson Keep Their Seats in Wisconsin
abstract: A split result for Democrats and Republicans in a closely divided swing state.
lead_paragraph: KENOSHA, Wis. — Gov. Tony Evers, a Democrat, won a second term in Wisconsin while Senator Ron Johnson, a Republican, narrowly held onto his seat, a split result in one of the most closely divided states in the nation.

headline: The Best Vegetarian Thanksgiving Looks as Good as It Tastes
abstract: With a showstopping centerpiece and four vibrant side dishes, this menu makes the most of fall vegetables.
lead_paragraph: Vegetables star in these five new dishes that were made for vegetarians and created to appeal to everyone. Maybe you’re adopting a meatless holiday meal for the first time or maybe you have never felt tethered to turkey and are finally skipping the bird this year because of its increasingly high cost. These recipes provide the richness, comfort and abundance you expect from Thanksgiving: deep, roasted caramelized flavor embellished with bursts of acidity from citrus, hints of heat and some welcome levity from fresh herbs.

headline: Germany Blocks 2 Foreign Investment Deals, Taking a Firmer Line on China
abstract: The decision to bar a Chinese-owned firm from acquiring a domestic semiconductor maker comes as Germany reappraises ties to its giant trading partner.
lead_paragraph: The government of Chancellor Olaf Scholz blocked the sale of a semiconductor company to a Chinese-owned firm on Wednesday, as Germany seeks to toughen protection of its domestic technology and ease its dependence on China.

headline: Biden Celebrates Beating the Odds, but He Faces a New Challenge
abstract: President Biden appeared to have the best midterms of any president in 20 years, avoiding the “shellacking” his predecessors endured. But even a narrow Republican majority could transform his presidency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Wednesday celebrated avoiding the “giant red wave” that many had anticipated in this week’s midterm elections and reaffirmed that he intends to run again in 2024, even as he vowed to work across the aisle with ascendant congressional Republicans.

headline: Republicans Did Not Read the Room
abstract: It turns out that voters care about abortion and democracy after all.
lead_paragraph: I’ll admit it: I let the right, and political analysts who were listening to the right, psych me out.

headline: Democrats Cling to Supermajorities in N.Y. Legislature Amid G.O.P. Gains
abstract: Republicans unseated some longtime Democratic lawmakers in areas where the party’s candidate for governor, Lee Zeldin, performed well.
lead_paragraph: Democrats in New York were clinging to their supermajorities in the State Legislature as of Wednesday morning, with a handful of competitive races still too close to call, stalling Republican hopes of curbing Albany’s leftward tilt.

headline: Election Denial Didn’t Play as Well as Republicans Hoped
abstract: Democrats won races for top election posts in several political battlegrounds where their Republican rivals had cast doubt on the 2020 contest and signaled their desire to overhaul voting systems.
lead_paragraph: Voters in a series of critical battleground states rejected Republican candidates for governor, attorney general and secretary of state who have spread doubts about the 2020 election, blocking an effort to install allies of former President Donald J. Trump in positions with sweeping authority over voting.

headline: Sometimes This Octopus Is So Mad It Just Wants to Throw Something
abstract: A study finds that the gloomy octopus — its real name — is in the small club of animals that toss things at other members of their own species.
lead_paragraph: It turns out that the urge to hurl something at an irritating neighbor is not confined to land animals. A study published on Wednesday in the journal PLOS ONE shows that octopuses of at least one species throw silt and shells, sometimes at one another. It’s a rare behavior in the animal kingdom, and the study is the first time it has been documented in octopuses.

headline: Not Trump’s Night: The Red Wave That Wasn’t
abstract: Readers assess the midterm elections. Also: A first-time voter; Social Security; abuse of children at a detention center; Elon Musk and Twitter.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘The Crown’ Review: The Worst of Times
abstract: The fifth season of the Netflix hit, with a new cast including Imelda Staunton as the queen, depicts the royal family at its lowest point.
lead_paragraph: Has “The Crown” fatigue set in for you yet? Peter Morgan’s popular vivisection of the British royal family, back for its fifth season on Netflix after a two-year wait, has consumed more than its share of pixels, including three feature articles in this newspaper. So we’ll try to keep it short.

headline: Credibility Questions Dog World Bank President at Climate Summit
abstract: David Malpass has faced continuing criticism from those who question his commitment to climate action as well as the bank’s track record.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the COP27 Climate Summit in Egypt.

headline: In Search of Enheduanna, the Woman Who Was History’s First Named Author
abstract: “She Who Wrote,” an exhibition at the Morgan Library, explores the world of an ancient Mesopotamian priestess who wrote with a strikingly personal voice.
lead_paragraph: It was a random morning in November, and Enheduanna was trending.

headline: Warnock and Walker Head to Runoff in Pivotal Georgia Senate Race
abstract: The contest between Senator Raphael Warnock, the Democrat, and Herschel Walker, the Republican, is seen as key to which party controls the Senate.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The race between Senator Raphael Warnock of Georgia, the Democratic incumbent, and his Republican opponent, Herschel Walker, will continue into a December runoff election, The Associated Press said on Wednesday, with neither candidate clearing the 50 percent threshold to win outright.

headline: Binance Pulls Out of Deal to Acquire Rival Crypto Exchange FTX
abstract: The rapid collapse of FTX, built by the billionaire Sam Bankman-Fried, suggests that no company in the freewheeling, loosely regulated crypto industry is safe.
lead_paragraph: It was a stunning fall for a celebrated executive who was leading the crypto industry’s charge into the mainstream of finance.

headline: Some Russian war bloggers express anguish over the Kherson order, while others see its pragmatism.
abstract: “This betrayal is now carved up on my heart for centuries,” one military blogger wrote online. Another blogger lauded the move as a way to preserve the army.
lead_paragraph: They feared it might come for weeks, but still, when a Russian commander announced on Wednesday that Russian troops would be pulled from the strategically important city of Kherson, Ukraine, Russian hawkish military bloggers and commentators responded with despair, anguish and denial.

headline: Ron DeSantis’s God Complex
abstract: The Florida governor’s resounding re-election will only feed his divine delusions.
lead_paragraph: After decades of closely observing and writing about American politics, I’m accustomed to the runaway religiosity of many political campaigns and to a whiff of theocracy in our democracy. But an ad that Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida released in the final days of his successful re-election bid nonetheless took my breath away.

headline: ‘Black Panther: Wakanda Forever’ Review: Women on the Home Front
abstract: Shadowed by Chadwick Boseman’s death, this sequel focuses on King T’Challa’s mother and the women helping her to contend with a slippery new villain.
lead_paragraph: The first “Black Panther” movie opened in February 2018. A lot has changed since then, both in the Marvel Cinematic Universe and in the one that most of us non-superheroes are compelled to inhabit.

headline: Our 8th Annual Student Review Contest
abstract: We invite students to play critic and submit an original review about any kind of creative expression covered in The New York Times. Contest open from Nov. 16 to Dec. 14.
lead_paragraph: Do you like sharing your opinion with others? Do you have strong critiques and reactions to books, movies, restaurants or fashion? Are you a foodie or a gamer? A music buff or a theater aficionado?

headline: Joe Tarsia, an Architect of the Sound of Philadelphia, Dies at 88
abstract: His work as an engineer at Sigma Sound Studios left a sonic stamp on R&B hits by the O’Jays, the Delfonics, the Stylistics and many others.
lead_paragraph: Joe Tarsia, the recording engineer and studio operator who was among the architects of the lush, fervent blend of soul, disco and funk known as the Sound of Philadelphia, died on Nov. 1 in Lancaster, Pa. He was 88.

headline: Is This Crypto’s Lehman Moment?
abstract: Here’s how to make sense of the industry-shaking collapse of FTX.
lead_paragraph: The crypto industry is known for dramatic twists, roller-coaster prices and fortunes that appear and disappear overnight.

headline: This Trick Is Helping Young People Get Their Finances in Order
abstract: It’s called cash-stuffing, and it’s extremely nondigital.
lead_paragraph: When Jasmine Taylor turned 30 a year and a half ago, her personal finances were a mess. “I told myself, this is my last year of living like this,” she said to me. She hunted for a system that would help her discipline her spending and came upon a budgeting strategy called cash-stuffing that she’s been using ever since.

headline: Putin stays silent on the Kherson withdrawal order, as others parse his motive.
abstract: Some analysts saw the order as a reminder of President Vladimir Putin’s willingness to make tactical concessions.
lead_paragraph: Many of the Russian cheerleaders of the invasion of Ukraine on Wednesday cast the defense minister’s order to withdraw from Kherson City as a monumental defeat — Moscow’s most devastating, according to one of them, since the fall of the Soviet Union.

headline: For Britain’s New Leader, Politics at Home Overshadow a Smooth Global Debut
abstract: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s pragmatic diplomacy did not grab attention the way the resignation of a cabinet minister did.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Prime Minister Rishi Sunak moved into 10 Downing Street two weeks ago, he promised a government of “integrity, professionalism and accountability” after the serial scandals of his former boss, Boris Johnson, and the chaotic policies of his immediate predecessor, Liz Truss.

headline: In Wake of U.S. Election, Ukrainian Lawmakers Will Reach Out to Washington
abstract: Officials are optimistic that Washington will continue to support the war effort. But a delegation is planning a trip to meet lawmakers of both parties.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Throughout the war with Russia, Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, has complained about the reluctance of the United States to provide the powerful and accurate weapons his country needed. Until recently, he had not had to worry that the flow might be reduced or even cut off.

headline: Donald Trump Was the Midterm’s Biggest Loser
abstract: Times Opinion writers on why we didn’t get a red wave.
lead_paragraph: As midterm election results continue to trickle in, one thing is clear: There’s no predicting American voters. After an unexpected showing for Democrats in tight races across the country, Jane Coaston speaks with the Times editorial board member Michelle Cottle and Times Opinion columnist Ross Douthat to recap what happened at the polls. Together they discuss how the Democrats won “the expectations game,” who had the worst night (Donald Trump) and what the clouded results reveal about the bigger story of American democracy. “What we are looking at is an electorate that is feeling unsettled, and neither party made the case that they were going to provide the strength, stability, normalcy to create a wave election,” Cottle says.

headline: Van Orden, Republican Who Attended Jan. 6 Rally, Wins Wisconsin House Seat
abstract: Derrick Van Orden, a Navy SEAL who rallied at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, beat Brad Pfaff, a Democratic state senator, flipping a House seat in rural Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: Derrick Van Orden, a retired Navy SEAL who rallied at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, beat Brad Pfaff, a Democratic state senator, according to The Associated Press. His win flips a House seat in rural Wisconsin and hands Republicans a crucial pickup in their push to claim a majority.

headline: Republican Defeats 2-Term Democrat to Win Iowa House Seat
abstract: Cindy Axne was one of seven House Democrats to carry a Trump district in 2020, but could not hold off Zach Nunn, a state senator and Air Force veteran.
lead_paragraph: Zach Nunn, a Republican state senator, unseated Representative Cindy Axne in Iowa’s Third Congressional District, according to The Associated Press on Wednesday, a painful loss for Democrats in a closely watched contest.

headline: McCarthy Announces Run for Speaker as Scalise Lines Up for No. 2
abstract: Even with control of the House undecided, Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, announced his bid in a letter to his colleagues.
