lead_paragraph: Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California and the minority leader, on Wednesday announced his bid to be speaker even before it was clear his party would control the House, as G.O.P. leaders began jockeying for power after a disappointing midterm showing.

headline: U.S. Announces a World Cup Roster Shaped by a Wholesale Turnover
abstract: Coach Gregg Berhalter named the 26-player roster for the U.S. men’s national soccer team’s long-anticipated return to the World Cup after missing out in 2018.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of Argentina vs. Mexico and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: Here are the uncalled races that could determine control of Congress.
abstract: Both chambers of Congress remained up for grabs, with crucial contests that could determine control yet to be called.
lead_paragraph: As Republicans moved closer to winning a slim House majority and Democratic victories squelched what had been projected to be a red wave, crucial races in the fight for control of Congress remained unresolved on Wednesday afternoon, making it impossible to be certain which party would prevail.

headline: What to Do With the Time We Get
abstract: A man with a chronic illness savors the time he has with the ones he loves.
lead_paragraph: Ari Diaconis knew a bright future lay ahead of him. He was a gifted athlete with a well-paying job at a Wall Street law firm, and a partner, Dunia, with whom he shared a deep connection. But a neurological illness shifted his vision for the path ahead and shined a spotlight on the present — snuggles in bed and time spent in their apartment — a life raft from the city downstairs.

headline: Elected to House in 2018, Most Democratic Women Are Hanging On
abstract: Many were centrists with strong national security credentials and were elected in the anti-Trump midterm wave four years ago. But most survived this year, even in tough G.O.P.-leaning districts.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, 36 new women, all but one of them Democrats, were elected as the largest freshman class of women the House had ever seen.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: No ‘Red Wave’ in U.S. Midterms
abstract: Plus Russia says it is retreating from Kherson City and markets try to parse China’s “zero Covid.”
lead_paragraph: In the critical midterm elections, Democrats defied the historical odds as well as an anticipated “red wave” that could have given the Republican Party a substantial majority in the House and a narrower one in the Senate.

headline: How Republicans Flipped 4 Congressional Seats in New York
abstract: A chaotic redistricting process was intended to help Democrats. But Republicans made significant gains.
lead_paragraph: The grueling midterm battles that arose from New York’s redistricting chaos continued on Wednesday, with tight races in a couple of consequential districts still up in the air — elections that could help decide the balance of power in Congress.

headline: Where the Midterms Mattered Most for Abortion Access
abstract: Voters supported abortion rights in several states and elected governors friendly to access in some of the most competitive races. Other states may see more restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Voters supported abortion rights in several states and elected governors friendly to access in some of the most competitive races. Other states may see more restrictions.

headline: How to Approach the Holidays
abstract: Advice for gathering this winter.
lead_paragraph: There was a brief moment this fall, when Covid-19 cases were low and we hadn’t yet heard the word “tripledemic,” that I thought we might have something close to a normal holiday season, for the first time in years. But the last few weeks have changed the picture.

headline: The Disease Took Zara, Then Sara. Could Ayla Be Saved?
abstract: Two sisters in one family died from a genetic disorder. Before a third child with the disease was born, doctors hatched a plan to spare her of its effects.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, doctors have successfully treated a fetus by infusing a crucial enzyme into its minuscule umbilical cord, halting an otherwise fatal inherited disorder known as severe infantile Pompe disease.

headline: Supreme Court Closely Divided in Case on Native American Adoptions
abstract: In considering the constitutionality of the Indian Child Welfare Act, the justices explored congressional power and equal protection principles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court heard more than three hours of arguments on Wednesday in a sprawling challenge to the constitutionality of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978, which makes it hard to remove Native American children from their tribes and heritage.

headline: Russia Orders a Retreat From Kherson
abstract: A withdrawal from the southern city would be a blow to Putin.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘The Watcher’ and More
abstract: I am a senior photo editor on The Times's Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I am a senior photo editor on The Times's Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching and listening to.

headline: An Ancient People’s Oldest Message: Get Rid of Beard Lice
abstract: Archaeologists in Israel unearthed a tiny ivory comb inscribed with the oldest known sentence written in an alphabet that evolved into one we use today.
lead_paragraph: The tiny ivory comb came from ancient ruins in central Israel and was about the size of a child’s thumb. A number of its teeth had snapped. It was so encrusted in dirt that the archaeologist who found it initially added it to a bag of assorted bones.

headline: Rivian Lost $1.7 Billion in the Third Quarter
abstract: The electric truck maker said it had enough cash to fund its operations through 2025.
lead_paragraph: Rivian, an electric vehicle start-up that aims to compete with Tesla, on Wednesday reported another substantial quarterly loss as it worked to increase production.

headline: Forbes Nears Deal With Investor Group for Under $800 Million
abstract: The group of bidders includes investors from the United States and overseas, a company spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: Forbes is in advanced talks to sell itself to a group of investors, a company spokesman said, approaching a deal that would bring the chronicler of the wealthy and powerful under new ownership.

headline: Officials order evacuations of oceanfront condos in Daytona Beach Shores over erosion fears.
abstract: The town along Florida’s east coast suffered severe erosion from Hurricane Ian in September. Now it’s bracing for more.
lead_paragraph: Emergency officials in Daytona Beach Shores are evacuating six ocean-facing residential buildings as Tropical Storm Nicole continues to bite away at the coastline.

headline: Poor Countries Need Climate Funding. These Plans Could Unlock Trillions.
abstract: As global warming delivers cascading weather disasters, leaders at U.N. climate talks say it’s time to radically overhaul the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the COP27 Climate Summit in Egypt.

headline: Judge Gives Long Sentence to Couple Who Tried to Sell Submarine Secrets
abstract: Prosecutors had recommended three years in prison for Diana Toebbe, but a federal judge sentenced her to almost 22 years, a longer term than her husband.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge sentenced a Navy engineer to 19 years in prison on Wednesday and — in an unusual twist — handed his wife nearly 22 years for the couple’s botched attempt to sell sensitive nuclear propulsion secrets to a foreign country.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Russia Orders Retreat From Kherson, a Serious Reversal in the Ukraine War
abstract: Russia’s position had grown perilous in Kherson, a strategic city and one of the biggest prizes seized in its Ukraine invasion, but Russian hawks reacted angrily to the withdrawal.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — The Kremlin on Wednesday announced a retreat of Russian forces from the strategically important city of Kherson in southern Ukraine, a concession to military reality eight months after capturing the area, and one of the most significant reversals of President Vladimir V. Putin’s war effort.

headline: Brittney Griner Heads for a Russian Penal Colony
abstract: The U.S. basketball star, detained for more than eight months so far, is being transferred to an undisclosed prison in Russia, her lawyers said. The United States denounced the move.
lead_paragraph: Wherever Brittney Griner was on Wednesday, one thing was clear: The American basketball star imprisoned by Russia was not heading back home, despite a concerted U.S. campaign to win her freedom.

headline: McCarthy Announces Speaker Bid, as Republicans Grasp for House Majority
abstract: With many races unresolved, the top House Republican rushed to declare victory and alert his colleagues that he still meant to seek the top post, even as he toiled to shore up his right flank.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California and the minority leader, on Wednesday announced his bid to be speaker even before it was clear his party would control the House, as G.O.P. leaders began jockeying for power following a disappointing midterm showing.

headline: After Election, Cautious Optimism That Few False Narratives Took Hold
abstract: Researchers who study disinformation said most efforts to stoke doubt about results had failed to spread widely.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Election Day, Charlie Kirk, the conservative talk show host from Arizona, shared a video on Twitter about broken voting machines in Maricopa County, followed by a series of posts suggesting that the problems were intentional.

headline: Ukraine Peace Talks Remain Distant Even as Moscow Signals a Retreat
abstract: President Biden and European leaders say they cannot push Ukraine and Russia into negotiations, though some U.S. lawmakers are questioning aid for an open-ended war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American and European officials say serious peace talks between Ukraine and Russia are unlikely in the near future, even as the Biden administration tries to fend off growing questions from some members of Congress about the U.S. government’s open-ended investment in the war.

headline: A rare win for MSNBC over CNN in the election night ratings battle.
abstract: Tuesday’s overall viewership, down sharply from 2018, was the smallest total prime-time audience for a midterm election night since 2014.
lead_paragraph: A relatively subdued election night on Tuesday yielded relatively subdued ratings: The overall television audience was 25.4 million viewers, the smallest total for a midterm year since 2014, according to Nielsen.

headline: What Many Pennsylvanians Saw in Fetterman
abstract: By reinventing his Senate campaign after a stroke, Lt. Gov. John Fetterman ended up connecting with voters who responded to his saga of loss and comeback.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — The morning after Lt. Gov. John Fetterman won Pennsylvania’s Senate race, Alberta Wilkes was in a radiant mood as she waited for a bus to the post office to buy money orders for bills.

headline: Unwilling to Hold Their Nose and Vote, Ticket-Splitters Make Their Mark
abstract: Some midterm voters seemed more inclined to support candidates of different parties this year, emphasizing contender quality over partisan identity.
lead_paragraph: For years they seemed to be an ever-more-endangered species, increasingly subsumed by the bitter tribalism that has come to define the nation’s politics.

headline: Texas Democrats Look to a Future Beyond Beto
abstract: Beto O’Rourke drew crowds but not enough votes, raising questions about when or how Democrats can win statewide office in Texas.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — On the first day of early voting in Texas in late October, the line to see Beto O’Rourke near a polling place in East Dallas snaked over wet grass in an occasionally torrential rain.

headline: The Libertarian Who Helped Push the Georgia Senate Race Into a Runoff
abstract: Chase Oliver won a little more than 2 percent of the vote. His politics are unusual: He describes himself as “armed and gay.”
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Chase Oliver’s political positioning can come across as both intriguing and a little hard to categorize: He’s a Libertarian, who proudly describes himself as “armed and gay.” In his bid to become the next U.S. senator from Georgia, he raised a mere $7,790 through the end of June. And as of Wednesday afternoon, he had earned just over 2 percent of the total vote.

headline: C.D.C. Links Deadly Listeria Outbreak to Deli Meats and Cheeses
abstract: Sixteen people in six states have been infected with the listeria strain, resulting in one death and 13 hospitalizations, the agency said.
lead_paragraph: One person has died and 13 have been hospitalized in a listeria outbreak across six states that most likely was caused by contaminated deli meat and cheese, federal health officials said on Wednesday.

headline: In New Jersey, Redistricting Helped Most Incumbents Win Big
abstract: Often a swing state, New Jersey is now divided into congressional districts that are even more purely red or blue than before.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey has often prided itself on being a swing state, a place where voters were willing to hopscotch between parties, swapping Democrats for Republicans, and vice versa, from one election to the next.

headline: What Republicans Are Saying About Tuesday Night
abstract: The midterms’ results showed the limits of “Team Crazy,” in the words of Representative Peter Meijer — one of many harsh judgments coursing through a demoralized Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: It’s a storied American ritual: Two years in, a president whose party just got shellacked hauls himself before the White House press corps to confront his accusers.

headline: Warren Beatty Is Accused of Sexually Assaulting a Minor in 1973
abstract: In a lawsuit filed this week, the plaintiff says Mr. Beatty groomed and coerced her into sex when she was 14 and 15. The actor, who had starred in “Bonnie and Clyde,” was about 35 at the time.
lead_paragraph: Warren Beatty, the famed “Bonnie and Clyde” actor and Oscar-winning director, was accused in a lawsuit this week of sexually assaulting a girl in 1973 when she was 14 and 15.

headline: If Democrats Lose the House, They May Have New York to Blame
abstract: Republicans flipped four congressional seats in New York, the most of any state in the country. How did this happen in one of the nation’s most liberal states?
lead_paragraph: As Democrats sought to maintain their narrow House majority in this year’s midterms, they counted on New York to be a crucial bulwark. Instead, as the party mostly outperformed dire predictions across the country Tuesday night, one of the nation’s most liberal states morphed into perhaps the most powerful drag on its chances.

headline: Concessions are making a modest but notable comeback in 2022.
abstract: Two years after former President Donald J. Trump rejected the results of the election, many of his supporters embraced the rituals of losing amicably.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Several bitterly contested races remain undecided, but by Wednesday it was becoming clear that the 2022 midterm campaign had spawned a modest and somewhat unexpected national political comeback — by civility.

headline: Florida Braces for Hurricane Nicole
abstract: Some communities still recovering from Hurricane Ian are preparing for Florida’s next storm.
lead_paragraph: BRINY BREEZES, Fla. — A vast stretch of Florida braced on Wednesday for shredding winds and a storm surge as forecasters warned that Hurricane Nicole, which became a Category 1 storm on Wednesday night, was racing toward Florida’s east coast.

headline: America Dodged an Arrow
abstract: Democracy survived the midterms, but we’re far from safe.
lead_paragraph: You can hold off moving to Canada. You can forgo the call to the New Zealand Embassy on how to become a citizen there. Tuesday’s election really was the most important test since the Civil War of whether the engine of our constitutional system — our ability to peacefully and legitimately transfer power — remains intact. And it looks to have come through — a little dinged up, but OK.

headline: ‘It Could Have Been Worse’ Never Felt This Good
abstract: Georgia, here we come. Again.
lead_paragraph: Doesn’t it feel as if we’ve been watching the Senate race in Georgia since the War of 1812?

headline: Democrats Hold Onto Contested State Legislative Chambers
abstract: Going into the election, Republicans held control in a majority of statehouses. By Wednesday, Democrats had flipped at least one Midwestern chamber.
lead_paragraph: Democrats made gains in state legislatures, including at least one Midwestern battleground state, while thwarting Republican efforts to flip chambers in the Mountain West and elsewhere. As results of statehouse races were still being counted in several states late Wednesday, experts said that Republicans’ efforts to expand their control of state legislative chambers appeared to have fallen short.

headline: With Runaway Win, DeSantis’s Political Career Becomes Supercharged
abstract: The Florida governor’s victory was a result of his commanding campaign, relentless voter registration and turnout efforts, and Democrats’ utter collapse in the state.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Gov. Ron DeSantis steadfastly focused his re-election campaign on President Biden rather than on his Democratic opponent in Florida. But Mr. DeSantis’s runaway victory on Tuesday, while crushing to Democrats, felt more like a win over a different rival: former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: In New Book, Pence Reflects on Trump and Jan. 6
abstract: “You’re too honest,” President Donald J. Trump said as he pressured his vice president to intervene to block Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump told Mike Pence that he was “too honest” when he balked at the idea he could unilaterally sway the outcome of the 2020 election as Mr. Trump mounted an intense pressure campaign to bend Mr. Pence to his will, the former vice president writes in his upcoming memoir.

headline: L.A. Drops Criminal Charges Against Election Software Executive
abstract: Eugene Yu was accused of illegally sending data about poll workers to China, in a case that became fodder for election deniers.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles County dropped criminal charges against the top executive of an elections technology company on Wednesday, bringing to an abrupt end an unusual case that became the focus of Americans who distrust the country’s electoral system.

headline: What We Know Now About the Midterms
abstract: Some of the dust has settled, and a clearer picture is emerging of Tuesday’s surprising, sometimes nuanced results.
lead_paragraph: As partisans and pundits digested the shock of the 2022 midterm elections on Wednesday, some new themes emerged. Finger-pointing among Republicans. Mixed results for election deniers. The return of choosy voters. And a more nuanced picture on the impact of abortion.

headline: Gal Costa Dies at 77; Singer Embodied Tropicália’s Innovative Spirit
abstract: Her graceful, flexible voice and ear for memorable songs sustained a five-decade career defining the sound of Brazilian pop.
lead_paragraph: Gal Costa, one of Brazil’s greatest singers and a model for generations of Brazilian performers, died on Wednesday at her home in São Paulo. She was 77.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 10, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 10, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article last Thursday about the photographer Steven Klein contained a number of errors. It incorrectly included the photographer Peter Lindbergh among those whose careers were sidelined by allegations of sexual misconduct. Mr. Lindbergh was not accused of sexual misconduct. The article misstated Mr. Klein’s age, using information from the artist; according to public records, he is 67, not 57. The article misstated when Mr. Klein began studying at the Rhode Island School of Design; it was in the early 1970s, not 1981. It also misstated the year that Dennis Freedman left W magazine as creative director; it was 2010, not 2009. The article misstated the year of Mr. Klein’s Vogue shoot in a meat locker; it was 2004, not 2005.

headline: With House Majority in Play, a New Class Takes Shape
abstract: The Republican ranks grew more extreme and slightly more diverse, while Democrats added several young liberals to their caucus.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Whoever holds the House majority in January, the new lawmakers will include a fresh crop of Republican election deniers, including a veteran who attended the “Stop the Steal” rally at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021; a handful of G.O.P. members of color; and a diverse group of young Democratic progressives.

headline: Why I’m Cheering Tuesday’s Results
abstract: We were led to believe that the momentum had shifted decidedly toward Republicans. It hadn’t.
lead_paragraph: I am overjoyed by the results of the midterm election so far, not just because there was no overwhelming Republican wave, but also because America rejected, generally speaking, the path to its own demise.

headline: Paul G. Allen’s Art at Christie’s Tops $1.5 Billion, Cracking Records
abstract: A museum’s worth of masterworks from the Microsoft co-founder’s collection are offered in a two-part charity sale. Five topped $100 million.
lead_paragraph: Just when it seemed the high-flying art market couldn’t soar any higher, paintings and sculptures from the collection of the Microsoft co-founder Paul G. Allen hit the $1.5 billion mark at Christie’s New York on Wednesday night, making it the biggest sale in auction history.

headline: Trump Under Fire From Within G.O.P. After Midterms
abstract: “Republicans have followed Donald Trump off the side of a cliff,” a longtime adviser said.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump faced unusual public attacks from across the Republican Party on Wednesday after a string of midterm losses by candidates he had handpicked and supported, a display of weakness as he prepared to announce a third presidential campaign as soon as next week.

headline: In Arizona’s race for governor, Hobbs defies expectations and takes a narrow lead.
abstract: The Democratic candidate’s mild manner has been a counterweight to her rival Kari Lake’s charismatic and antagonistic style.
lead_paragraph: PEORIA, Ariz. — In a cramped campaign office tucked in a strip mall, Katie Hobbs, the Democratic nominee for governor, was hours away from Election Day and trying to rally volunteers while also tempering expectations.

headline: Bighearted Sort
abstract: Dan Caprera’s Thursday puzzle is a wild one.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — As soon as I looked at it, I knew I was not in for a typical Thursday puzzle. I’ll save my full thoughts on the theme for below, but know that I really enjoyed it. Dan Caprera’s first puzzle ran on Wednesday, July 31, 2019, and today’s is his second appearance in the New York Times Crossword. I enjoyed today’s puzzle so much that I went back and solved his first one, which I missed when it first ran. In today’s puzzle, some highlights for me were 16-Across (a great debut!), 35-Across, 6-Down, 32-Down (another great debut) and 43-Down.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Early Peace Talks Appear Unlikely as Russians Retreat and Retaliate
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 10, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “We should not fool ourselves into thinking that the Russians have ever negotiated in good faith about Ukraine.”

headline: N.F.L. Week 10 Predictions: Our Picks for Each Game
abstract: Josh Allen’s status puts the Bills’ matchup against the Vikings into disarray, the Seahawks look to extend their winning steak, and the 49ers are hoping for health out of their bye week.
lead_paragraph: In last week’s loss to the Jets, Bills quarterback Josh Allen appeared to injure his right elbow on Buffalo’s final drive. A few plays later, he threw a 70-yard bomb intended for Gabe Davis, the longest pass attempt in the N.F.L. in six seasons, inspiring some hope that his arm was fine.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Takeaways from the U.S. midterms.
lead_paragraph: A day after polls closed across the U.S., President Biden struck an optimistic tone at the White House, even as control of the Senate remained up in the air. (Georgia’s Senate race will head to a runoff, while races in Arizona and Nevada have yet to be called.) “It was a good day for democracy and I think a good day for America,” Biden said.

headline: N.Y. Democrats Play the Blame Game Despite Hochul Victory
abstract: Congressional losses in New York could be the deciding factor on whether Democrats keep the House.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at why congressional races provide takeaways for Republicans and Democrats. We’ll also look at a Norway spruce that’s coming to a very prominent place in Manhattan.

headline: Word of the Day: acumen
abstract: This word has appeared in 74 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word acumen has appeared in 74 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 29 in “‘I Thought the Game Was Over’: A Big Catch Saved the Phillies” by David Waldstein:

headline: Late Night Thinks Trump Is the Biggest Loser in the Midterms
abstract: The former president was said to be livid that candidates he endorsed lost on Tuesday, including Dr. Oz.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Twitter
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this illustration is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Writing About Life, on a Deadline
abstract: The Obituaries desk plans ahead. But occasionally, an unexpected death means a reporter only has hours to learn about a person.
lead_paragraph: On an afternoon in July, Clay Risen, an Obituaries reporter at The New York Times, got a call from William McDonald, the desk’s editor. Mr. McDonald told Mr. Risen to stop what he was doing: The Times had gotten word that Ivana Trump, the glamorous businesswoman and ex-wife of former President Donald J. Trump, had died unexpectedly at 73. Mr. McDonald needed Mr. Risen to start writing her obituary immediately.

headline: The Curious Life and Strange Death of a Fashion Insider
abstract: The flamboyant Long Nguyen left a powerful creative imprint on an industry slow to accept iconoclasts like him.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Inventing a New Language for Talking About Style
abstract: Blackbird Spyplane, a popular but niche “dude-leaning” newsletter, introduces Concorde, a new endeavor aimed at women.
lead_paragraph: Blackbird Spyplane is a newsletter written for enthusiasts: rabbit-hole shoppers who stockpile extremely specific saved searches on eBay as if it’s a competitive sport. There is nothing chill or low-key about it, other than a core appreciation for the kind of crunchy outdoor apparel once associated with chill and low-key people.

headline: Kamila Valieva’s Doctor Has Long Worked in the Shadows of Sport
abstract: Dr. Filipp Shvetsky was listed as Valieva’s supervising physician at the Beijing Games, where it was revealed she had tested positive for a banned drug before the event. He says he didn’t administer it.
lead_paragraph: More than eight months after the Russian figure skater Kamila Valieva became one of the biggest stories of the Beijing Games for all the wrong reasons, the mystery behind her failed doping test that shrouded the Olympics remains unresolved.

headline: How Democrats Used the Abortion Debate to Hold Off a Red Wave
abstract: In the first major election post-Roe, Democrats tied abortion rights to everyday economics and tapped into fears about the rise of right-wing Republicans.
lead_paragraph: For months, the midterm elections appeared to be a clash over rising prices, public safety worries and fears of a looming recession.

headline: A Japanese American Family, a Native American Tribe and a Bountiful Friendship
abstract: In the face of discrimination and hate, the Inabas and the Yakama Nation forged a bond through a farm in eastern Washington that has lasted for more than 100 years.
lead_paragraph: WAPATO, Wash. — The traditional Japanese lantern in the driveway of Inaba Produce Farms offers just a hint of the richly layered history behind this once-humble agricultural operation in eastern Washington.

headline: France Cheers for a Musical It Loves but Hasn’t Watched
abstract: Songs from “Starmania” are frequently heard and covered in France, but until a new production opened in Paris, few had a chance to see the 1979 rock opera onstage.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Imagine a musical so beloved that on opening night, its lyricist receives a standing ovation before the show even starts. That’s what happened here Tuesday night. As the songwriter walked to his seat, the audience at La Seine Musicale couldn’t contain their excitement — starting with Brigitte Macron, the wife of President Emmanuel Macron of France.

headline: Lesson Plan: ‘How Many Languages Could a Child Speak?’
abstract: Make a guess and then find out the answer in this lesson.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “How Many Languages Could a Child Speak?” by Randall Munroe. (This article is also available in Spanish.)

headline: The Last Hurricane to Hit Florida’s East Coast Was Katrina in 2005
abstract: Seventeen years ago, Katrina strengthened in the Gulf of Mexico after that first landfall.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Nicole came ashore just south of Vero Beach, Fla., on Thursday, becoming the first hurricane to make landfall along Florida’s east coast since Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

headline: Amid continued military setbacks, Putin will not attend the G20 summit.
abstract: The Russian delegation will be headed by Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov, the RIA Novosti state news agency reported.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin will skip next week’s summit of leaders of the Group of 20 largest economies in Indonesia, Russian news agencies reported on Thursday, amid continued setbacks for his army in Ukraine that have weakened the Kremlin’s ability to project power.

headline: Remaking the River That Remade L.A.
abstract: Over the past century it has been channeled, subdued, blighted. Is it time for the Los Angeles River to serve the city in a new way?
lead_paragraph: Over the past century it has been channeled, subdued, blighted. Is it time for the Los Angeles River to serve the city in a new way?

headline: Is This Vegetable Healthier Raw or Cooked?
abstract: Take our quiz to find out.
lead_paragraph: Take our quiz to find out.

headline: They Caught the Seattle Market on the Way Down, but Could They Afford a House There?
abstract: After watching houses around them sell for ‘insane amounts over ask’ during the height of the pandemic, two North Carolina transplants tested their savings in the leafy neighborhoods of North Seattle. Here’s what they found.
lead_paragraph: After watching houses around them sell for ‘insane amounts over ask’ during the height of the pandemic, two North Carolina transplants tested their savings in the leafy neighborhoods of North Seattle. Here’s what they found.

headline: How Should Adults Talk to Kids About Drugs?
abstract: An Opinion writer argues that in the age of fentanyl, adults need to start having honest conversations with young people about drugs. Do you agree?
lead_paragraph: Have parents, teachers or other adults in your life ever talked to you about drugs? What did they say to you? What questions did they ask? What questions did you ask?

headline: Why the Red Wave Didn’t Materialize
abstract: When it came down to it, the Republican Party offered ordinary American workers little that might have bolstered their power or leveled the playing field.
lead_paragraph: A week before the midterms, a video circulated online of a Starbucks barista crying while explaining the need for a union: “I’m a full-time student. I get scheduled for 25 hours a week, and on weekends they schedule me the entire day — open to close.” The manager is bad, the staffing is inadequate and the stress is overwhelming.

headline: How ‘Dead Souls’ Taught Mel Brooks What Comedy Writing Could Be
abstract: “I’d never read anything like it,” says the actor and director, whose memoir “All About Me!” is newly out in paperback. “It was hysterically funny and incredibly moving at the same time. It’s like Gogol stuck a pen in his heart, and it didn’t even go through his mind on its way to the page.”
lead_paragraph: You may be surprised to learn that on my nightstand is a book called “The Art of Cooking Omelettes,” by Madame Romaine de Lyon. It’s an incredible cookbook with hundreds of French omelette recipes. I’m a bit of an omelette connoisseur, and every night before I go to sleep I love dreaming about which omelette I’ll have for breakfast the next day.

headline: A Newly Elected Black Republican Has a Message for His Party’s Leaders
abstract: Representative-elect Wesley Hunt on the G.O.P.’s push to diversify.
lead_paragraph: Wesley Hunt is a Republican representative-elect from Texas. Young and socially conservative, he is an Army veteran, a West Point graduate and a native Texan. He is also Black, in a party that has tacitly embraced racist rhetoric from some of its loudest voices. But Hunt says that rhetoric doesn’t define the G.O.P. or the future of his party.

headline: The Unbearable Envy of the Published Author
abstract: I’ve published books before but this time it’s easier because of Kevin Wilson, a writer I’ve never spoken to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a novelist with a book out this week. I’ve been lucky with this new book, but the lead-up is still terrible: nerves, anxiety, impossible hopes, a lot of fear. I joke with friends that I’m positivity Teflon: I don’t trust the good reviews; the bad reviews feel affirming in some strange, sick way. I’ve been through this twice before but this one’s different, easier somehow, and not just because I’m older and more well adjusted. It’s because of Kevin Wilson, a writer I’ve never spoken to.

headline: Biden Is No Sure Thing for 2024. What About Buttigieg? Harris? Even Whitmer?
abstract: Many Democrats have craved the chance to pick somebody else to run for president in 2024. But which somebody?
lead_paragraph: The midterms were very good to President Biden.

headline: What to Know as the Trump Organization’s Trial Resumes
abstract: After pausing because of a Covid outbreak, the prosecution of the former president’s company was to start again Thursday. Reacquaint yourself with events so far and what’s to come.
lead_paragraph: The tax-fraud trial of Donald J. Trump’s family business is scheduled to resume in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Thursday after not having met since Nov. 1 because of an outbreak of Covid-19.

headline: In ‘Tulsa King,’ Sylvester Stallone Tries Something New: Being Himself
abstract: His best-known characters often speak in grunts. But in a new series from Taylor Sheridan, he plays a smooth talker written with his real personality in mind.
lead_paragraph: Sylvester Stallone needs an introduction about as much as Rambo needs a bigger knife, or Rocky another punch to the head. But he did want to clarify one thing about himself over tea at the St. Regis hotel in Manhattan last month, ahead of the debut of his new Paramount+ series “Tulsa King.”

headline: Biden Must Ensure Ethiopia Does Not Return to War
abstract: The truce between the Ethiopian government and Tigray leaders is a significant first step toward peace
lead_paragraph: Two years into the pitiless war ravaging northern Ethiopia, on Nov. 2, the Ethiopian government and the leaders of the northern Tigray region agreed to stop fighting after talks convened by the African Union in Pretoria, South Africa.

headline: The Ceramics Obsession Has Moved to Our Walls
abstract: Sick of that ubiquitous subway tile? Try something handmade for a little more character.
lead_paragraph: “The thing with ceramics,” said Charlotte Smith, a ceramist in Atlanta, “is that the possibilities are endless.”

headline: On the Steep Slope of College Affordability, a Toehold
abstract: The enduring expense of higher education has reached Olympian heights. Nonprofit agencies are trying to offer some modest forms of relief.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series recounting the stories of people who received help from nonprofit organizations supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

headline: As Daniel Ricciardo Departs, He Looks to 2024
abstract: He lost his Formula 1 seat with McLaren after a poor season and may spend next year as a reserve driver.
lead_paragraph: The last two years have been extremely painful for Daniel Ricciardo.

headline: Tech’s Talent Wars Have Come Back to Bite It
abstract: Hiring the best, the brightest and the highest number of employees was a badge of honor at tech companies. Not anymore as layoffs surge.
lead_paragraph: When Stripe, a payments start-up valued at $74 billion, laid off more than 1,000 employees this month, its co-founders blamed themselves. “We overhired for the world we’re in,” they wrote. “We were much too optimistic.”

headline: When Tech Stocks Sputter, the Entire Stock Market Sinks
abstract: Stocks like Meta, Microsoft, Amazon and Apple have suffered staggering losses this year. But is this a good time to buy? Maybe, if you’re in it for the long term, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: The stock market adores high-growth tech companies — until it suddenly doesn’t. And when the mood changes, as it has this year, the brutality of the stock market goes on spectacular display.

headline: Tom Felton Auditioned for ‘Harry Potter’ Without Reading the Books
abstract: In his memoir, “Beyond the Wand,” the actor who played Draco Malfoy opens up about family, fame and how he landed the role of a lifetime.
lead_paragraph: Midway through a video interview with Tom Felton about his best-selling memoir, “Beyond the Wand,” the actor who played Draco Malfoy in the “Harry Potter” movies removes the blue-gray baseball cap he’d been wearing backward and begins to tousle his hair. He parts it with his fingertips, pats it with a palm, then spikes it up with a swift flick of his wrist. Felton’s locks are darker than they were in his Slytherin days — more sand than platinum — but watching him fidget with his trademark coiffure is a bit like watching Daniel Radcliffe clean his glasses. You feel as if you’re getting a peek behind the scenes at Hogwarts.

headline: What Does an F1 Race in Brazil Lack? A Brazilian Driver.
abstract: The country that produced the astonishing Ayrton Senna has not had a permanent driver in the series in five years. What happened?
lead_paragraph: Brazil used to be a force in Formula 1. The country has produced three world champions, its drivers have won 101 races — third on the nations list — and only five countries have had more drivers than Brazil’s 32.

headline: I Don’t Quite Buy the DeSantis Narrative, and Other Midterm Thoughts
abstract: Ezra Klein and Aaron Retica discuss how Democrats dodged a midterm wipeout.
lead_paragraph: The results of Tuesday’s midterm elections are still trickling in, but the broader story is clear: The red wave that many anticipated never materialized. Republicans gained 54 House seats against Bill Clinton in 1994 and 63 seats against Barack Obama in 2010. It doesn’t look as though the G.O.P. will secure anything close to that in 2022, and Democrats could retain their narrow control of the Senate — all against the backdrop of raging inflation and low approval ratings for President Biden.

headline: Masks Cut Covid Spread in Schools, Study Finds
abstract: In a so-called natural experiment, two school districts in Boston maintained masking after mandates had been lifted in others, enabling a unique comparison.
lead_paragraph: Masks have been a cultural flash point since the start of the pandemic, and mask mandates in schools have been especially incendiary. Critics have argued that there is no strong evidence to prove that masks slow the spread of Covid, and that in any case children weren’t wearing the right kinds of masks or weren’t wearing them properly.

headline: Which Is More Terrifying: Nature or Other People?
abstract: From a wilderness reality show to an octopus society in Vietnam, three debut novels explore the complexities and comforts of human connection.
lead_paragraph: Blair Braverman’s SMALL GAME (279 pp., Ecco, $27.99) uses a “Survivor”-type reality show called “Civilization” to pose questions about authenticity, competition and resilience. Unfortunately, the novel often encounters the same problems as the shows it’s criticizing: It’s repetitive, its shallowness resists any close scrutiny, its surface is too cold and shiny for any depth of feeling.

headline: In an Age of Constant Disaster, What Does It Mean to Rebuild?
abstract: Each catastrophe is a test of what kind of society we’ve built. And each recovery offers a chance, however fleeting, to build another.
lead_paragraph: The era we are now in the midst of might be defined, most notably, by the omnipresence of disaster. Plagues, droughts, floods, toxic air and water, wars, massacres, famines, earthquakes, heat waves, wildfires, recessions, dust storms, despotism — slow-motion nightmares are crashing into fast-moving catastrophes, each one amplifying the next.

headline: The ‘It’ Ring for Engagements: Toi et Moi Styles
abstract: The two-stone bauble has been the ring of choice for celebrities like Ariana Grande, Megan Fox and Kylie Jenner.
lead_paragraph: Can’t decide on a pear-shaped or an emerald-cut diamond for your engagement ring? Or, perhaps a colored gemstone?

headline: Price of Diesel, Which Powers the Economy, Is Still Climbing
abstract: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is one reason that the fuel is scarce. Another is a series of yearslong, intertwined events that cover the globe.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Gasoline prices have dropped as much as a dollar a gallon since early summer, easing a financial strain on many people. But the price of diesel, the fuel that moves trucks, trains, barges, tractors and construction equipment, has remained stubbornly high, helping to prop up the prices of many goods and services.

headline: As the Fed Raises Rates, Worries Grow About Corporate Bonds
abstract: Executives, analysts and bond traders are all wondering if corporate finance is about to unravel as interest rates rise.
lead_paragraph: As the Federal Reserve raises interest rates in an effort to tame inflation, the corporate bond market, which lends money to many companies, has been hammered particularly hard.

headline: The Cities Rats Love
abstract: One city — not New York — has been declared the “rattiest” for eight years running in an annual study by Orkin.
lead_paragraph: Humans have been battling rats for eons, but during the pandemic the rats seemed to be winning. In 2021, reports of the rodents to New York City’s 311 help line were way above prepandemic levels. This year, complaints are piling up at a similar pace.

headline: They Make Bespoke Cider. In a Garage. With Apples They Find.
abstract: The founders of Floral Terranes take foraging fruit to a whole new level.
lead_paragraph: Erik Longabardi was driving along a congested, monotonous strip of the Cross Island Parkway in Queens when he spotted a row of apple trees growing on the side of the road.

headline: When Your Layoff Has a Hashtag
abstract: Tech companies that created more workplace transparency see their own tools used to critique them.
lead_paragraph: There were few scenes of workers packing up their cubicles, shoving plaques in boxes and commiserating over beers. Instead, there were tweets.

headline: Female College Athletes Say Pressure to Cut Body Fat Is Toxic
abstract: Several women in track and field said their mental health spiraled as they skipped meals to be leaner at the urging of coaches and peers.
lead_paragraph: Audra Koopman wanted to be leaner and more powerful.

headline: 6 Y.A. Fairy Tale Retellings to Add to Your Reading List
abstract: Elizabeth Lim, the author of “Six Crimson Cranes,” recommends some of her favorite retellings of classic fairy tales.
lead_paragraph: Fairy tales made me fall in love with reading. When I was a kid, my parents would tell me bedtime stories about clever princesses who broke evil curses, fell in love and lived happily ever after. But as I grew older, “happily ever after” wasn’t enough anymore, and the kind and beautiful princesses so often featured in fairy tales started to feel bland and boring. And that was when I discovered retellings.

headline: Can New Technology Make Home Dialysis a More Realistic Option?
abstract: The Tablo System promises to make dialysis easier and more convenient for patients. But there are significant barriers to the technology.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Upstart, a series about companies harnessing new science and technology to solve challenges in their industries.

headline: An Artist’s Gateway to Freedom and Possibility
abstract: Torkwase Dyson distills stories of oppression and Black liberation into monumental artworks for her new show at Pace in New York.
lead_paragraph: Lurking deep within Torkwase Dyson’s huge architectural sculptures — two of which form her new exhibition at Pace Gallery in Chelsea — is a secret language of liberation.

headline: Mary Kelly’s Revolution Is Ongoing
abstract: The pioneering artist’s feminist work was groundbreaking in the ’70s. She never dreamed it would look just as radical half a century later.
lead_paragraph: THE FIRST PHOTO shows five young women, lights attached to their breasts and crotches, posed defiantly in the dark. In the second image, the women, now dancing, morph into whorls of light reminiscent of Christmas trees. In the third, their bodies seem to mesh, dissolving into a radiant cloud. The time-exposed photographs were taken by the artist Mary Kelly in 2005, capturing a re-enactment she staged of a long-ago feminist protest. In 1970, Kelly and a group of fellow activists had disrupted the Miss World Contest in London — which they decried for its objectification of women — by setting off flour bombs, shooting water pistols and dancing, some of them adorned with bright, flashing bulbs. It’s a moment Kelly has returned to repeatedly in her work, including for “Documenta 12” in 2007, when a hundred women, their torsos illuminated, charged through a German park en masse after dark.

headline: The 2022 New York Times/New York Public Library Best Illustrated Children’s Books
abstract: Take a peek at all 10 of this year’s winners.
lead_paragraph: The 10 winners of The New York Times/New York Public Library Best Illustrated Children’s Books Award are chosen each year by a rotating panel of three expert judges.

headline: The 2022 New York Times/New York Public Library Best Illustrated Children’s Books Winners at Work
abstract: The artists behind this year’s winning books, in their studios.
lead_paragraph: Each year, we work with the New York Public Library to administer the honor now called The New York Times/New York Public Library Best Illustrated Children’s Books Award. This year, we talked to the artists about their winning books and their lives as illustrators. The following interviews are condensed and edited.

headline: Weed Is Now Legal in Thailand. How Long Will the High Times Last?
abstract: Cannabis shops have multiplied since the drug was decriminalized, with caveats, in June. But some lawmakers are pushing for tighter regulation.
lead_paragraph: Thailand’s military government is carrying out an experiment: What happens when a country in Asia, a region where drug laws tend to be harsh, essentially legalizes marijuana overnight?

headline: This Land Is His Land
abstract: It’s simplistic to label “Yellowstone” a “red-state drama.” But the cowboy soap speaks the language of culture war with a perfect accent.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Markets Soar on Signs of Slower Inflation
abstract: Stocks rallied and bond yields tumbled as investors reset their expectations for the pace of interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: Stocks jolted higher on Thursday, after fresh data showed a moderation in inflation, bolstering investors’ expectations that the Federal Reserve will soon slow the pace of interest rate increases that have weighed on the market.

headline: After Months of Stubborn Inflation, Glimmers of Hope Emerge
abstract: The Consumer Price Index showed that prices climbed 7.7 percent in the year through October, a quick pace but a notable moderation.
lead_paragraph: Fresh economic data released Thursday showed that inflation cooled more than expected in October, a hopeful development for American consumers and welcome news for the Federal Reserve and White House after months of stubbornly persistent price increases.

headline: How Democrats Defied the Odds
abstract: In the midterms, the party bucked decades of conventional political wisdom, while the Republican playbook largely failed.
lead_paragraph: This week’s elections have been startlingly close. Control of both chambers of Congress remain up in the air.

headline: A Vatican Auditor Says He Dug Up Too Much Dirt, and Was Buried
abstract: Libero Milone is suing the Vatican for wrongful dismissal after he said he found cardinals siphoning off funds. The Vatican has hit him with a criminal investigation of its own.
lead_paragraph: ROME — On June 19, 2017, the Vatican gendarmes entered the offices of the church’s chief auditor. They confiscated his phone and iPad, threw his papers on the floor and ordered the fire brigade to smash open a locked metal filing cabinet, from which they extracted a document that they said proved he was abusing resources to spy on top Vatican cardinals.

headline: Egypt Starts ‘Medical Intervention’ on Prominent Political Prisoner, Family Says
abstract: The hunger-striking dissident Alaa Abd El Fattah escalated his protest this week when he stopped drinking water as a U.N. climate conference opened in Egypt. His family fears that he is being force fed.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — The Egyptian authorities have begun a “medical intervention” for the country’s best known political prisoner, Alaa Abd El Fattah, whose long hunger strike has cast a shadow on this week’s United Nations climate summit in Egypt, one of his sisters said on Thursday.

headline: Nicole Will Move Up the East Coast, Bringing Heavy Rain
abstract: The storm’s remnants will be in New England by Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Nicole, which hit the east coast of Florida as a Category 1 hurricane early Thursday, was expected to bring heavy rain from the Carolinas to New England through the weekend, meteorologists said.

headline: Abortion on the Ballot
abstract: Democrats won crucial races in states where abortion rights were at stake.
lead_paragraph: By the time the midterm election campaign reached its final days, some Democrats had spent weeks fretting that their nominees had consumed far too much time talking about abortion rights at the expense of economic issues — and, potentially, their seats.

headline: ‘Nothing Lasts Forever’ Review: Mining the Diamond Myth
abstract: This documentary positions an intriguing investigation into the rise of synthetic diamonds within a broader excavation of the myths these stones carry.
lead_paragraph: The drama-infused documentary “Nothing Lasts Forever,” directed by Jason Kohn, aspires to mine the mystique surrounding diamonds. Intermixing historical analysis with new discoveries, the film unveils that while diamonds come from the earth, they are really human inventions, for they are only as covetable as the illusions they carry.

headline: ‘Retrograde’ Review: The U.S. Withdrawal From Afghanistan
abstract: This documentary follows one Afghan general, Sami Sadat, to tell an emotional story.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Heineman’s latest documentary, “Retrograde,” wisely does not attempt to provide a comprehensive account of the American withdrawal from Afghanistan. Shot over the nine months following the confirmation of the U.S. withdrawal in early 2021, the shrewdly observant film sticks with one Afghan general, Sami Sadat, to tell an emotional story that feels as significant as any analysis of troop numbers.

headline: ‘Paradise City’ Review: John Travolta and Bruce Willis Reunite
abstract: Almost 30 years after “Pulp Fiction,” these kings of cool team up for a Hawaii-set action feature that isn’t as much fun as it sounds.
lead_paragraph: An action movie starring John Travolta and Bruce Willis that shares a title with a 1987 Guns N’ Roses song sounds like one of those fake movies joked about on “Seinfeld” or “30 Rock.” And yet “Paradise City” is a reality of sorts, albeit an uncomfortable reality.

headline: ‘The First Noelle’ Review: All I Want for Christmas Is My Ex
abstract: A young Black editor is set on winning back her ex-boyfriend this Christmas — even if it means breaking up his relationship.
lead_paragraph: One of the mainstays of Mariah season, as devotees of Mariah Carey’s Christmas music have christened the holidays, is Christmas movies, from classic comedies to the contrived romances created by the Hallmark Channel. As many of these films teach us, part of leaning into the holiday spirit is suspending cynicism and embracing cheerfulness and cheesiness. By this measure, “The First Noelle,” directed by Patricia Cuffie-Jones for BET+, certainly fits the bill.

headline: ‘Sam & Kate’ Review: It’s a Family Affair
abstract: Darren Le Gallo’s drama stars two real-life parent-child duos — Dustin and Jake Hoffman, and Sissy Spacek and Schuyler Fisk — as lonely small-towners looking for love.
lead_paragraph: “Sam & Kate” is the kind of film in which a car breakdown kindles a romance, fireworks provide the backdrop for a first kiss and a misplaced box (almost) ends a relationship.

headline: ‘Falling for Christmas’ Review: Tripped Down Memory Lane
abstract: Lindsay Lohan stars as an amnesiac who falls off a mountain and in love in this Netflix holiday romance that is all too familiar.
lead_paragraph: “Falling for Christmas” isn’t a Hallmark Channel original, but it certainly resembles one. Stop me if you’ve heard this one before: A gallant blue-collar widower strikes up an improbable romance with a wealthy, stuck-up heiress betrothed to a cocky himbo who is written expressly to be disliked. The rich young woman and the blue-collar guy don’t have much in common at first, but she soon shows a predilection for domestic labor, making it clear that she can be reformed. But her fiancé is irredeemable, because he’s on his phone a lot and uses terms of endearment like “angelcakes.”

headline: ‘My Father’s Dragon’ Review: Apocalypse Howl
abstract: A boy befriends a colorful creature in this animated film that struggles to maintain a consistent tone.
lead_paragraph: With its expressionistic, skillfully lit pastels, “My Father’s Dragon” appears, at first, to be a high-tier cartoon for young sophisticates, as one might expect from the Oscar nominee Nora Twomey, who previously directed “The Breadwinner.” Enter the dragon, Boris (Gaten Matarazzo), who promptly shoves a blocky paw into his armpit and squeezes out an air fart.

headline: The Mets Want to Keep Their Ace, but He Won’t Come Cheap
abstract: Despite his injury issues, Jacob deGrom is expected to garner a contract in excess of $100 million. He is one of several Mets players who are about to test free agency.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — On Wednesday, the Mets formally announced their first major move of the off-season: the re-signing of closer Edwin Díaz to a five-year, $102 million contract, the largest for a relief pitcher in baseball history. The Mets, who won 101 games during the 2022 regular season, expect to compete for a playoff spot again next year, and a reliable late-innings reliever is essential for a top team.

headline: Biden’s Message on Climate Might Not Be the One the World Wants
abstract: The president is expected to hail the new U.S. climate law on Friday at the COP27 summit in Egypt. Other countries want to talk money.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the COP27 Climate Summit in Egypt.

headline: An Outburst Threatens the French Far Right’s Effort to Go Mainstream
abstract: For the first time, the National Rally is the main opposition party in Parliament. But can it use its new perch to convince voters it has changed?
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French lawmakers erupted in turmoil last week when a member of Parliament from the far right interrupted a Black colleague’s speech about shipwrecked migrants in the Mediterranean by shouting, “Back to Africa!”

headline: A Reckoning Awaits FTX
abstract: After a rescue deal collapsed, the cryptocurrency exchange is scrambling for a lifeline, as investors and customers prepare to fight for their money.
lead_paragraph: The crypto industry faces growing turmoil after Binance, the world’s biggest crypto exchange, walked away on Wednesday from its deal to rescue its struggling rival, FTX. The prices of major tokens like Bitcoin and Ether have fallen sharply in the past 24 hours. And FTX now faces ruin as it grapples with a funding shortfall of perhaps $8 billion.

headline: ‘Dancin’’ Revival to Boogie Onto Broadway in March
abstract: The show, originally created by Bob Fosse in the late 1970s, has been reimagined with the blessing of his daughter.
lead_paragraph: In 1978, Bob Fosse staged a tribute to his favorite art form with a largely plotless show called “Dancin’” that wound up running for more than four years.

headline: WeWork Will Close About 40 Locations as Losses Narrow
abstract: The co-working company said revenue rose more than 20 percent in the most recent quarter, but it tempered its forecast for the full year.
lead_paragraph: WeWork said Thursday that it was going to close roughly 40 “underperforming” locations in the United States and tempered its revenue forecast for the year, highlighting the challenges the co-working company still faces after its near collapse and subsequent bailout in 2019.

headline: Lauren Boebert is in an unexpectedly tight House race in Colorado.
abstract: Representative Lauren Boebert, a Republican, is being challenged by Adam Frisch, a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: The race remains too close to call in Colorado’s Third Congressional District, where Representative Lauren Boebert, a far-right Republican who heckled President Biden during his State of the Union speech, was locked in a surprisingly tight contest with Adam Frisch, a Democrat.

headline: ‘My Main, Core Issue’: Abortion Was the Driving Force for Many Voters
abstract: The fall of Roe v. Wade put abortion front and center in campaigns, and motivated voters to support abortion rights or reject more restrictions in several states.
lead_paragraph: It was a driving force for a retired banker in San Antonio, an artist in Racine, Wis., an event planner in Miami Beach. It motivated college students and retirees, men and especially women. Even those who might usually skip a midterm election had been compelled to make time to cast a ballot.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s homes are a six-bedroom in Northport, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Deep River, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A six-bedroom, five-and-a-half-bath, 6,800-square-foot house built in 1996, with a wraparound porch, a two-story entry foyer, walls of palladian windows, a two-and-a-half-story great room with a wood-burning fireplace and built-in bar, a large kitchen and sunken dining area, a media room, a finished basement and an attached two-car garage, on 1.17 acres. Noreen Sweeney, Daniel Gale Sotheby’s International Realty, 631-327-2844; danielgale.com

headline: More Women Are Expected to Win Seats in the California Legislature Than Ever Before
abstract: Women competed in 65 state legislative races, and had already won or were leading in 44 of them as of Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: The first women in the California State Legislature were elected in 1918, before most American women had gained the ability to vote. Here in the Golden State, women got the right to vote in 1911, making California one of the earliest states to adopt that change.

headline: Never-Before-Seen William Eggleston Photographs, on View in New York
abstract: Plus: sculptural pepper mills, a fireplace-scented candle and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are in Bedford Stuyvesant, Murray Hill and Union Square.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom, two-bath, 1,186-square-foot apartment with a combined living and dining room that has a home-office alcove, an open kitchen with a breakfast bar and quartz counters, a primary suite with a balcony, and a washer and dryer, on the fourth floor of a five-story, non-doorman elevator building from 2008. Bruce Henderson, Corcoran Group, 646-287-1765; corcoran.com

headline: HarperCollins Workers Strike for Better Pay and Benefits
abstract: Employees say they’ll not return to work until they have a new contract. The company says it will “continue to negotiate in good faith.”
lead_paragraph: Unionized employees at HarperCollins went on strike Thursday, saying they planned to stop working until they reached an agreement on a new contract.

headline: Rising Democratic Star Survives Close Call in Houston
abstract: Lina Hidalgo, a progressive, won re-election as Harris County judge by a slim margin against a first-time candidate who focused on crime.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Lina Hidalgo, the progressive Democrat who leads Texas’s largest county, which includes Houston, narrowly won re-election despite a well-funded effort by a Republican first-time candidate who made crime a centerpiece of her campaign, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Takeaways From a Hopeful Inflation Report
abstract: The Consumer Price Index in October showed that inflation remained rapid, but there were some hopeful signs under the surface.
lead_paragraph: Consumer Price Index data released Thursday showed that inflation was finally showing signs of a meaningful slowdown, more than a year and a half after it started to pick up amid the pandemic.

headline: 84 Years Later, a Rare Look at the Nazi Attacks of Kristallnacht
abstract: The photographs of the assaults on Jews during the 1938 pogrom, which is widely commemorated as the start of the Holocaust, had been kept by a former American serviceman.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In one picture, a uniformed Nazi is seen destroying a display window while a crowd looks on, seemingly in approval. In another, uniformed Nazis pour gas on a rug in a synagogue. In a third, a terrorized woman in a housecoat is seen on a bed.

headline: ‘The Fabelmans’ Review: Steven Spielberg Phones Home
abstract: The director’s latest movie focuses on a budding filmmaker a lot like himself. But Michelle Williams, as his mother, is the soul of this fractious family drama.
lead_paragraph: For the entirety of his filmmaking life, Steven Spielberg, the great entertainer and box-office pulverizer, has been pouring himself into his movies. Whether epic-sized or relatively downsized, a Spielberg picture reveals something about him — or at least the Hollywood version — so it’s no surprise that there’s something familiar about his tender, autobiographical reverie, “The Fabelmans,” with its wide-eyed children, remote father, complex mother and insistently happy ending. You’ve seen this story before, or just glints in prequels like “The Sugarland Express,” “E.T.” and “Catch Me If You Can.”

headline: The Super-Skinny Ideal Isn’t ‘Back’ — It Never Left
abstract: Body dissatisfaction among girls has been a constant for years.
lead_paragraph: For over a year I’ve been seeing headlines lamenting the return of Y2K-era fashion, along with its focus on extreme thinness and jean rises so low, to paraphrase “Absolutely Fabulous,” the world’s your gynecologist.

headline: ‘Spirited’ Review: A Whole Lot of Humbug
abstract: Ryan Reynolds and Will Ferrell star in this musical spin on “A Christmas Carol” from Apple TV+.
lead_paragraph: Weeks before rabid hordes of consumers descend upon department stores like the avian menace in a Hitchcock film, before neighborhood dogs daintily lift their legs to the stripped-down sidewalk pines left for dead in the cheerless days of January, I’ve had an early Christmas revelation: Scrooge was onto something. All his grinching doesn’t seem so far-fetched; ol’ Ebenezer probably lost out on a Black Friday sale or watched too many bad Christmas movies, because after viewing the Sean Anders film “Spirited,” I’m feeling plenty humbuggy myself.

headline: Watch NASA’s Test of a Flying Saucer-Like Device
abstract: On Thursday morning, NASA tested a giant inflatable device, which launched to orbit and then splashed down in the ocean near Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday morning, NASA tested a giant inflatable device, which launched to orbit and then splashed down in the ocean near Hawaii.

headline: NASA Launched an Inflatable Flying Saucer, Then Landed It in the Ocean
abstract: The LOFTID mission tested a novel approach to guiding spacecraft through the extreme heat of returning from orbit, which could be used to put people on Mars.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday morning, NASA sent a giant inflatable device to space and then brought it back down from orbit, splashing in the ocean near Hawaii.

headline: Russia and Ukraine each have suffered over 100,000 casualties, the top U.S. general says.
abstract: Gen. Mark Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, called the coming winter months an opportune time for the two sides to hold peace talks, though that prospect appears dim.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia’s war in Ukraine has left more than 100,000 of Moscow’s troops dead or wounded, and Ukraine has probably suffered a similar number of casualties, the United States’ most senior general said this week.

headline: Biden, Pointing to Cooling Inflation, Extols His Economic Policies
abstract: The president took credit for signs that rapid price rises were moderating, after spending months on the defensive about his handling of the economy.
lead_paragraph: A slowdown in price gains delivered a second dose of welcome news for President Biden, who has spent months on the defensive about rapid inflation and his handling of the economy.

headline: ‘Good Enemy’ Review: Finding Second Chances
abstract: Yilong Liu’s new play toggles between China in 1984 and the United States in 2021.
lead_paragraph: There are people who can walk confidently into a party at an underground club and instantly seem to belong. Hao is not one of them.

headline: FTX Crypto Exchange Boss Says He Is Trying to Raise More Money
abstract: Sam Bankman-Fried told employees that he wanted to reinforce his company’s finances after a collapse that is drawing scrutiny from regulators.
lead_paragraph: The embattled cryptocurrency executive Sam Bankman-Fried struggled on Thursday to find a lifeline for his collapsed exchange, FTX, with crypto markets still rattled and his company facing mounting legal and regulatory threats.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Paying College Athletes
abstract: Should colleges pay their athletes?
lead_paragraph: These graphs show how adults feel about college athletes being paid (beyond just qualifying for scholarships). Some respondents felt that athletes should be paid salaries by their colleges or compensated for the use of their names, images and likenesses. Others thought that paying athletes might affect gambling and encourage athletes to cheat.

headline: Biden and Xi to Meet as Tensions Grow Over Taiwan
abstract: Setting a meeting gives the two leaders an opportunity for face-to-face time, but President Biden said he would deliver no “fundamental concessions” over Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China will meet on Monday before the Group of 20 summit in Indonesia, an encounter that Mr. Biden and his advisers said would be focused on setting expectations with the Chinese as tensions continue to rise over matters such as Taiwan and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Brazil Counted All Its Votes in Hours. It Still Faces Fraud Claims.
abstract: A report from the military found no voter fraud — but left room for Bolsonaro’s supporters to argue maybe he’d actually won.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Nearly two weeks after Brazil’s presidential election, government officials and independent security experts have reviewed the results and made a clear determination: There is no credible evidence of voter fraud.

headline: The Anatomy of a Panic Attack
abstract: Up to a third of adults will experience at least one panic attack in their lifetime. Here's why they happen, and some coping strategies that work.
lead_paragraph: Up to a third of adults will experience at least one panic attack in their lifetime. Here's why they happen, and some coping strategies that work.

headline: ‘A Couple’ Review: Tolstoy Story
abstract: In a rare turn to dramatic work, Frederick Wiseman directs a one-woman film about the long-suffering wife of a famous author.
lead_paragraph: Frederick Wiseman has often said that his documentaries strive to be fair to the events he experienced during shooting. They are, in a sense, films about hearing others out. The people in them are given time to present themselves with real complexity, in ways that aren’t necessarily exciting at every moment. Wiseman often allows scenes to play out at great length.

headline: Tell Us About a Moment of Regrettable Rage
abstract: In the last few years, have you or a loved one erupted in a surprising outburst of anger? We want to hear about it.
lead_paragraph: For an upcoming New York Times Style project that examines rage at this particular moment, we would like to hear about a time in the last few years when you or someone close to you erupted in a surprising outburst of anger — and then regretted it.

headline: An Inflation-Driven Midterm Will Not Change Biden’s Economic Focus
abstract: The president said he would not change his economic approach, adding that his policies were working.
lead_paragraph: Inflation and the economy dominated voters’ concerns on Election Day, yet they did not culminate in the kind of political drubbing of President Biden and his party that many had expected. That outcome has made Mr. Biden less inclined to pivot on economic issues to appease Republicans, who have spent months pummeling the president over his handling of the economy.

headline: ‘Economic Picture Ahead Is Dire,’ Elon Musk Tells Twitter Employees
abstract: In his first communications with Twitter’s staff, the company’s new owner painted a bleak picture as more executives resigned.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Two weeks after buying Twitter, Elon Musk painted an increasingly bleak financial picture for the company and outlined changes in a meeting with staff on Thursday and in his first companywide emails, amid an exodus of executives including the officials who oversaw content moderation and security.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein and Aaron Retica Discuss the 2022 Midterm Elections
abstract: The Nov. 10, 2022 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Aaron Retica. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Path to 218: Tracking the Remaining House Races
abstract: We’re tracking the remaining uncalled House races — and showing when they are called — as states continue to count the outstanding votes from the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: We’re tracking the remaining uncalled House races — and showing when they are called — as states continue to count the outstanding votes from the midterm elections.

headline: 3 Thanksgiving Potato Dishes That Are Better Than Mashed
abstract: With a bigger, fluffier take on hash browns, a lighter gratin and a twist on twice-baked, Claire Saffitz makes the holiday staple shine in new ways.
lead_paragraph: Because mashed potatoes are a nonnegotiable part of my family’s Thanksgiving meal, I argue year after year that we do not need stuffing on the table. Potatoes, I believe, render stuffing superfluous. Inevitably, I end up making stuffing anyway, but my reasoning stands. On a holiday when real estate — stomach, oven and table — is at a premium, hard choices about carbohydrates must be made.

headline: ‘How Did This Man Think He Had the Right to Adopt This Baby?’
abstract: Army Rangers killed her parents. A Marine is raising her in America. But her Afghan family says she was taken under false pretenses.
lead_paragraph: Around 10 p.m. on the night of Sept. 5, 2019, a counterterrorism team of United States Army Rangers and partner forces descended onto a small village in the mountains of central Afghanistan, on a mission to capture or kill foreign fighters associated with Al Qaeda. The soldiers approached a row of three mud houses near a line of trees, beyond which lay farmland. Gunfire erupted. Shouting, booms, more shots. A man and a woman emerged from one of the houses; the woman was carrying a baby. The man was wearing a suicide vest, and he set it off. Bits of him flew into the air. Through their night vision goggles, the Rangers saw the woman, wounded but moving. She tugged at something — a bomb? — and a Ranger shot her dead.

headline: New Jersey Man Arrested in Connection With Threat to Synagogues
abstract: An 18-year-old man was charged with sending a threat over social media. He is expected to appear in court on Thursday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: An 18-year-old man from Middlesex County, N.J., was arrested and charged on Thursday with threatening to attack a synagogue and Jews earlier this month, an episode that led to warnings from the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New Jersey of a broad security risk to synagogues in the state.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Somehow, Thanksgiving is suddenly around the corner — our fridge is already stocked with cranberries and brussels sprouts — so this is a good time for our recommended books to remind you: Family is complicated. That’s equally true whether you’re talking about abolitionist sisters who turn out to have come from a slaveholding family that included Black members, as Kerri K. Greenidge delves into with her history “The Grimkes,” or exploring a dynasty of merchants who shaped modern capitalism and sat among the ruling class for generations, as Joseph Sassoon writes about in his family history, “The Sassoons.” It’s true in Andrew Miller’s novel “The Slowworm’s Song,” about a (complicated) father trying to make amends with his daughter, and in Jenny Xie’s poetry collection “The Rupture Tense,” which grapples with her family’s experiences in the Cultural Revolution and her own (complicated) feelings about the Asian diaspora. It’s also true of found family, as Kit Heyam demonstrates in a wide-ranging history of transgender identities around the world and throughout time, proving that the concept of gender is itself — yes — complicated.

headline: A Powerful N.Y. Democrat Was a Shoo-In for Re-election. What Happened?
abstract: Democrats won tough races across the country. How did a party leader and a five-term congressman lose?
lead_paragraph: This summer during the run-up to the Democratic primaries, when Sean Patrick Maloney was campaigning to keep the congressional seat he has held in the Hudson Valley for a decade, New York City’s Police Benevolent Association had his back. The largest municipal police union in the country spent hundreds of thousands of dollars targeting his opponent, Alessandra Biaggi, a progressive state senator whom it described as “a radical anti-police extremist.”

headline: The Polls Were Wrong. ‘People Chose Democracy.’
abstract: Readers offer their views on what the midterms signified. Also: Issues raised by the climate summit; the asylum system; coarsened political discourse.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What if You Suddenly Won $2 Billion?
abstract: As excitement peaked over a record-breaking Powerball, TikTok creators cashed in by offering financial advice.
lead_paragraph: Unless you are the person (or people) who bought Tuesday’s winning Powerball ticket in Los Angeles County, stop reading. This article is not for you. If you don’t have in your possession a Powerball ticket with the numbers 10, 33, 41, 47 and 56, with another 10 as the Powerball, you probably don’t need advice on what do with a sudden $2 billion windfall.

headline: ‘The English’: Emily Blunt and Chaske Spencer Saddle Up
abstract: A new Amazon series puts an unlikely alliance at the heart of an unconventional tribute to the classic American western.
lead_paragraph: The new Amazon series “The English” bears all the external signs of the classic westerns of yore, with scenes that could have been pulled straight from a 1950s Technicolor epic. There are horseback riders silhouetted against retina-singeing vistas, desolate outposts appearing like sunbaked hallucinations, and low-angle shots that magnify people into mythic figures.

headline: Two Cheers for the Biden Economy
abstract: Predictions of a huge inflation backlash didn’t come true.
lead_paragraph: Why didn’t a bad economy lead to the widely predicted midterm “blood bath” for Democrats?

headline: How Georgia’s Senate Runoff Will Work
abstract: The race between Senator Raphael Warnock and his Republican challenger, Herschel Walker, will be decided in a Dec. 6 runoff.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in less than two years, a U.S. Senate race in Georgia will come down to a runoff.
