headline: Review: With Owls, Classical Is Alive and Well and Living in a Crypt
abstract: The Owls string quartet’s program in a church crypt showed off the ensemble’s unusual make up, with two cellists instead of two violinists.
lead_paragraph: When an organization calls itself Death of Classical, some people might roll their eyes. Isn’t any rebellion against the genre’s supposedly defunct status itself old hat?

headline: Tough Lines on Ukraine and China: Seeing Policy Fallout From U.S. Election
abstract: With the MAGA star dimmed, analysts expect continued support in Washington for Ukraine and NATO, and perhaps greater pressure on China.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — As the contours of the new U.S. Congress become clearer, diplomats and policy analysts are trying to discern what it will mean for American support for Ukraine’s fight against Russia, for NATO, and for what may be an even tougher line on China.

headline: Your Most Colorful Thanksgiving Yet
abstract: With an ombré gratin, crispy, saucy roasted mushrooms, and more, this vegetarian menu makes vegetables look livelier and taste more delicious than ever.
lead_paragraph: Hi there! I’m Lex, an editor and recipe developer with New York Times Cooking. As an adoring Veggie reader, I was delighted when Tejal and Tanya asked me to step in this week and tell you about the vegetarian Thanksgiving menu I’ve been working on for three months.

headline: After a Decade of Explosive Scoring, N.F.L. Defenses Are Back on Top
abstract: Scoring reached a five-year low through the first half of the 2022 season as defenses focused on stopping “Mahomesian” plays.
lead_paragraph: After a decade of offensive renaissance and innovation, scoring output in the N.F.L. through the first half of the 2022 season has reached a five-year low, thanks largely to defenses adapting to their opponents’ tendencies.

headline: ‘Is That Black Enough for You?!?’ Review: A Miracle Decade
abstract: This documentary from Elvis Mitchell looks back at a golden age of daring Black cinema.
lead_paragraph: There are moments in the early stretches of Elvis Mitchell’s documentary “Is That Black Enough For You?!?,” a film about a golden but overlooked age of bracing Black cinema, that land as, of all things, paradoxically banal. In these snippets, Mitchell, the director and a former New York Times film critic who narrates the documentary, along with talking heads including stars like Laurence Fishburne and Zendaya, expounds on the basic importance of representation, of seeing one’s lived realities on the big screen. Does a film need to trot out the virtues of on-screen diversity and the negative effect of racist tropes that so many have constantly parroted in recent years?

headline: Murdoch’s news outlets extend their criticism of Trump.
abstract: For a second consecutive day, the recriminations about Republicans’ unexpectedly weak Election Day performance played a prominent role on the pages and over the airwaves of Rupert Murdoch’s media properties.
lead_paragraph: For a second consecutive day, the recriminations about Republicans’ unexpectedly weak Election Day performance played a prominent role on the pages and over the airwaves of Rupert Murdoch’s media properties. And the consensus wasn’t kind to former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Salon Art+Design Brings Home and Art Closer Together
abstract: With tapestries and jewelry on display at the Park Avenue Armory in Manhattan, the fair makes you question the boundaries of art-versus-design.
lead_paragraph: Salon Art + Design is more international this year, gaining back exhibitors from abroad who were reluctant or unable to travel during the pandemic. But home is still the focus of this annual fair at the Park Avenue Armory in Manhattan: not just art and design objects displayed in isolation, but imagining how they live together, how they inhabit a room and how you — or a daydreaming you — could cozy up with your furniture, tapestries, jewelry and curios.

headline: House Asks Supreme Court Not to Further Delay Request for Trump’s Tax Returns
abstract: A House panel has been seeking Donald J. Trump’s hidden tax documents since 2019. Democrats may not stay in control next year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House urged the Supreme Court on Thursday not to further delay the long-running lawsuit by a committee that is seeking former President Donald J. Trump’s tax returns, saying that continuing to block access to the files would undermine Congress’s constitutional authority.

headline: D.C. Attorney General Alleges N.F.L. Covered Up Commanders’ Wrongdoing
abstract: The civil complaint, filed against the N.F.L., Commissioner Roger Goodell, the Washington Commanders and the team’s owner, Daniel Snyder, takes aim at the league’s investigation into workplace harassment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Attorney General for the District of Columbia filed a civil complaint against the N.F.L., Commissioner Roger Goodell, the Washington Commanders and the team’s owner, Daniel Snyder, on Thursday, alleging that they concealed sexual harassment and abuse of former team employees over two decades.

headline: ‘Being Thunder’ Review: Dancing Alongside a Two-Spirit Teenager
abstract: A gentle documentary about a young person whose gender identity is woven through their life in a Rhode Island Indigenous community.
lead_paragraph: The subject of ‌Stephanie Lamorré’s understated documentary “Being Thunder” is Sherenté Harris, a teenager living in Rhode Island who is a citizen of the Narragansett Tribal Nation. Sherenté is two-spirit, a term used ‌‌in ‌Indigenous ‌communities to describe those who identify as both masculine and feminine, or as between genders.

headline: Ocasio-Cortez: ‘Calcified’ Machine Politics Cost Democrats in New York
abstract: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez said Democrats should not have adopted “Republican narratives on crime and safety,” and need to abandon “pure moderate” approaches.
lead_paragraph: Democrats beat the odds across the country in the midterms, but one unforeseen sore spot stood out: New York, where Republicans flipped four seats as they aimed to win majority control of the House of Representatives.

headline: ‘Mammals’ Review: James Corden Gets Back to What He Does Best
abstract: In “Mammals,” Corden’s first scripted TV comedy in eight years, he plays an angry (and very funny) man.
lead_paragraph: Before he was likable — before “The Late Late Show” and “Carpool Karaoke” and hosting the Tony Awards — James Corden was a bit too much. In a good way. In British television shows like “Gavin and Stacey” and “The Wrong Mans,” he perfected characters who achieved high comedy through constant pressure.

headline: ‘Catch as Catch Can’ Review: Caught in a Tangle
abstract: An overcomplicated one-act play addresses anti-Asian racism and mental illness at a Christmastime family reunion.
lead_paragraph: The introductory notes in Mia Chung’s script for “Catch as Catch Can,” which requires three actors to play six roles of varying ages and genders, suggest keeping a character breakdown handy, as “the layers of meaning from this parent-child doubling that would be clear when performed may be elusive on the page.”

headline: Poetry, Power and Loss in Theaster Gates’s Survey
abstract: Known for his social practice, performance, sculpture and work with archives, the Chicago artist memorializes those who shaped his worldview in his first major American museum survey.
lead_paragraph: At the heart of Theaster Gates’s survey at the New Museum, “Young Lords and Their Traces,” sits a curious, mummy-like object in a vitrine: a boli sculpture — a power figure created by Bamana artists in Mali to harness spiritual energy. It was crumbling when the artist acquired it, so he wrapped it in strips of white cloth.

headline: R.J. Reynolds Sues California Over Flavored Tobacco Ban
abstract: On Tuesday, the state’s voters overwhelmingly supported letting a two-year-old law take effect. The company’s lawsuit is viewed by anti-smoking advocates as a tactic that could keep menthol cigarettes on the market longer.
lead_paragraph: R.J. Reynolds, the maker of Newport menthol cigarettes and top-selling vaping products, filed a federal lawsuit on Wednesday challenging California’s landmark ban on flavored tobacco, a day after voters overwhelmingly approved it.

headline: Has the Time Come for a Long-Ignored Korngold Symphony?
abstract: The Symphony in F sharp has rarely been championed by major orchestras. But now, Kirill Petrenko’s Berlin Philharmonic is taking it on tour.
lead_paragraph: “No — I have not become atonal,” the composer Erich Wolfgang Korngold wrote in a 1952 letter. “I also think that my new Symphony will prove to the World that monotony and ‘modernism’ at the cost of abandoning invention, form, expression, beauty, melody — in short, all things connected with the despised ‘romanticism’ — which after all has produced some not so negligible masterpieces! — will ultimately result in disaster for the art of music.”

headline: Dr. Lewis Kuller, a Father of Preventive Cardiology, Dies at 88
abstract: His clinical studies focused largely on how to reduce the risk factors of cardiovascular disease. He also established a link between menopause and heart disease.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Lewis Kuller, a top epidemiologist and a leading figure in preventive cardiology, could trace his interest in the field to when he was a medical resident in Brooklyn in the early 1960s, responding by ambulance to emergency calls when people had died suddenly of heart attacks at home or in the street.

headline: Two Big County Tallies in Nevada Show Democratic Route to Senate
abstract: The path became clearer on Wednesday night as the first post-election vote tallies in Nevada and Arizona showed Democrats faring well among mail voters.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party’s path to holding the U.S. Senate — even without winning the runoff election that is coming in Georgia — became clearer on Wednesday night as the first post-election vote tallies in Nevada and Arizona showed Democrats faring well among mail voters.

headline: ‘I’ve Been a Girl Friday for Years, Ya Moron’
abstract: The plucky, trash-talking detective in “Viviana Valentine Gets Her Man,” by Emily Edwards, is a throwback to fictional characters from decades past.
lead_paragraph: VIVIANA VALENTINE GETS HER MAN (Crooked Lane, 277 pp., $28.99), the sprightly debut by Emily J. Edwards, is an ode to a certain type of girl-detective novel (such as the works of Mabel Seeley and Mignon G. Eberhart, as well as an underrated early Dorothy B. Hughes effort, “The Cross-Eyed Bear”) that was published plentifully in the years before and after World War II.

headline: Lit Trivia: Do You Know These Classic Screen Adaptations of Popular Books?
abstract: Quiz yourself on seven classic screen adaptations — and what some novelists had to say about them.
lead_paragraph: Quiz yourself on seven classic screen adaptations — and what some novelists had to say about them.

headline: Norwegian Princess Engaged to a Shaman Gives Up Her Royal Duties
abstract: Princess Martha Louise’s belief in the supernatural has long been the subject of media fascination in Norway, but a focus on her healer fiancé proved too much.
lead_paragraph: In recent decades, royals around the world have relinquished their official roles because of scandals and family feuds, or to marry commoners or divorcées. This week, a Norwegian princess quit her royal duties over her love for a modern-day shaman.

headline: What Students Are Saying About the Value of Math
abstract: We asked teenagers: Do you see the point in learning math? The answer from many was “yes.”
lead_paragraph: “Mathematics, I now see, is important because it expands the world,” Alec Wilkinson writes in a recent guest essay. “It is a point of entry into larger concerns. It teaches reverence. It insists one be receptive to wonder. It requires that a person pay close attention.”

headline: For a Chef Beloved by the Art and Fashion Worlds, Flowers Make a Main Course
abstract: At the artist Danh Vo's farm north of Berlin, the restaurateur Rose Chalalai Singh created a lively lunch centered on the blossoms that grow there.
lead_paragraph: During her childhood in Bangkok, the chef Rose Chalalai Singh recently recalled, the city seemed to be teeming with exotic blooms: there was the bounty of the flower market near the Chao Phraya River, the garlands of saffron-colored marigolds at the city’s Buddhist temples. Later, as a teenager, she spent three years living on her great-uncle’s orchid farm in the canal-lined Thonburi neighborhood. “Flowers have always been a part of my life,” she said. “After all, my name is Rose.”

headline: With New Ruling, Sandy Hook Families Win Over $1.4 Billion From Alex Jones
abstract: A judge added $473 million in fees to the award Mr. Jones must pay in a Connecticut case and ordered him not to move his personal assets outside the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Infowars conspiracy broadcaster Alex Jones must pay the families of eight Sandy Hook shooting victims an additional $473 million in punitive damages for defaming them, a judge in Connecticut ruled on Thursday, bringing the total damages to nearly $1.5 billion.

headline: Lois Curtis, Whose Lawsuit Secured Disability Rights, Dies at 55
abstract: The Supreme Court decided in Olmstead v. L.C. that warehousing people with disabilities in mental institutions was discriminatory.
lead_paragraph: Since she was a child, Lois Curtis was involuntarily moved from one mental institution to another. She had grown up with cognitive and developmental disabilities that had made it difficult for her family to care for her at home and for teachers to cope with her at school.

headline: Putin Can’t Escape History
abstract: Putin has responded to setbacks by demanding ever more sacrifice from Russians for an ever crueler war.
lead_paragraph: There is a pattern to Russia’s history, and it may be catching up with Vladimir Putin.

headline: A Mexican American Artist Finds Heroes in Farmworkers
abstract: Narsiso Martinez’s portraits honor the immigrants behind big American agribusiness.
lead_paragraph: LONG BEACH, Calif. — For his most ambitious artwork to date, Narsiso Martinez has made a painting that looks like an enormous dollar bill issued by an imaginary country that actually values its working class. Filling most of a wall of his current show at the Museum of Latin American Art, it has roughly the same proportions as U.S. paper currency and some of the same symbols, with decorative medallions in the corners and a framed portrait in the center.

headline: ‘The Box’ Review: A Dark Coming-of-Age Tale
abstract: This unsettlingly cryptic thriller directed by Lorenzo Vigas follows a teenager after he retrieves the remains of his father who was found in a mass grave.
lead_paragraph: The Venezuelan director Lorenzo Vigas’s “The Box” weaves some of the greatest horrors of modern Mexican life into an unsettlingly cryptic thriller.

headline: ‘A Friend of the Family’: Jan Broberg and Mckenna Grace Discuss the Finale
abstract: The real-life subject of the Peacock true-crime series talked with a young actress who plays her about that emotional final episode. Spoilers ahead.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for the finale of “A Friend of the Family.”

headline: ‘Where We Belong’ Review: A Performer Wonders, What’s in a Name?
abstract: In an autobiographical solo show at the Public Theater, Madeline Sayet grapples with her Indigenous ancestry and the responsibility that comes with her name.
lead_paragraph: If language is how we tell people who we are, what happens when a language is lost to history? Or, more accurately, when it’s violently erased?

headline: As Nicole cleanup starts, health officials advise Floridians on what to wear.
abstract: Officials recommend donning a long-sleeved shirt and heavy-work gloves to avoid cuts while gathering debris and household waste.
lead_paragraph: As residents began to clean up and make repairs after Nicole barreled through Florida on Thursday, health officials in the state had a few savvy tips on what Floridians should wear to help protect against injuries.

headline: An Artist’s High-Tech Dream of a World With No Nations
abstract: In a retrospective at the Institute of Contemporary Arts, in London, Christopher Kulendran Thomas wonders if network technology can create a real utopia.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Can art change the world? For all the possible answers to this question, the fact of war seems to sweep it away: Has “Guernica” ever stopped a bomb? As humanity shambles on, the artist Christopher Kulendran Thomas takes up the question again, but from a perverse angle: a tech start-up spun off a defeated revolution.

headline: How to Clean Your Microwave
abstract: Expert-backed tips to get your appliance clean both inside and out.
lead_paragraph: Expert-backed tips to get your appliance clean both inside and out.

headline: Biden to Nominate Former Obama and Bush Official to Lead I.R.S. Overhaul
abstract: If confirmed by the Senate, Daniel Werfel will oversee an $80 billion revamp of the tax agency.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said he intended to nominate Daniel Werfel to become the next commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, tapping an official who served under both President Barack Obama and President George W. Bush to lead the agency as it embarks on an $80 billion overhaul.

headline: Newly Published, From Alibaba to Legos
abstract: A selection of books published this week.
lead_paragraph: IDOL, BURNING, by Rin Usami. Translated by Asa Yoneda. (HarperVia, $24.99.) Akari, a Japanese high schooler and popular blogger, finds her devotion to a member of a J-Pop group tested when rumors surface that he assaulted a female fan, leading her down a perilous path of obsession and disillusion in this novel about fame, social media and stan culture.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: This week’s roundup is heavy on science, mythology and identity-exploring novels, from the biology of climate change to a recently recovered novel by Richard Wright.
lead_paragraph: This week’s roundup is heavy on science, mythology and identity-exploring novels, from the biology of climate change to a recently recovered novel by Richard Wright.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: Xi and Biden to Meet
abstract: Plus cryptocurrency chaos and Ukraine’s wary advance toward Kherson.
lead_paragraph: President Joe Biden and Xi Jinping, China’s leader, will meet on Monday, before the G20 summit in Indonesia. The conversation will be their first in-person encounter since Biden took office.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: “Mythic Quest” is back. Our TV critic also recommends a documentary series featuring David Beckham and a game show for young viewers.
lead_paragraph: ‘Mythic Quest’When to watch: Season 3 begins on Friday, on AppleTV+.

headline: Jury Says Paul Haggis Raped Woman After Film Premiere
abstract: Mr. Haggis, a writer of the Oscar-winning films “Crash” and “Million Dollar Baby,” was sued by a film publicist after a 2013 encounter in his New York apartment.
lead_paragraph: A jury on Thursday found the Oscar-winning filmmaker Paul Haggis liable for raping a former film industry publicist in his Manhattan apartment in 2013, ordering him to pay her at least $7.5 million.

headline: Qatar Will Allow Israelis to Fly Directly to Doha for World Cup
abstract: The move fell short of creating formal diplomatic ties between the countries, but it was the latest sign of warming relations between Israel and some Arab governments.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of Mexico vs. Argentina and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: Why Did FTX Collapse? Here’s What to Know.
abstract: Things went downhill for FTX after Binance, the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange, reversed on a deal to save the company.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the cryptocurrency exchange FTX filed for bankruptcy and its chief executive, Sam Bankman-Fried, resigned, a downfall that has stunned crypto insiders and sent shock waves through the industry.

headline: Paulina Porizkova Doesn’t Call Her Book a Memoir
abstract: The model and author spoke about writing “No Filter: The Good, the Bad and the Beautiful.”
lead_paragraph: Paulina Porizkova, 57, wants to talk about beauty. Its contradictions. And how her life has been shaped by an accident of genetics.

headline: Ukraine Moves Forward in South, With Little Resistance From Russia
abstract: A day after Russia said it was withdrawing from Kherson City in the south, Ukraine’s forces moved into villages without a fight, indicating the Russians were, indeed, retreating.
lead_paragraph: SNIHURIVKA, Ukraine — The Ukrainian soldiers inched forward in their pickup truck, weaving between burned Russian military vehicles, keeping a lookout for mines and pushing deeper into territory vacated by the Russian Army just a few hours earlier.

headline: 14 Seconds-Worthy Thanksgiving Stuffing Recipes Our Readers Love
abstract: From classic cornbread dressing to a stuffing inspired by pizza, these are the dishes our readers always put on the Thanksgiving table.
lead_paragraph: There may be regional disagreements over the name for the scrumptious, carb-forward dish that may or may not go inside the turkey, but there’s one thing everyone can agree on: When done right, stuffing (or dressing!) is the absolute best part of the Thanksgiving table. New York Times Cooking has pulled together a wonderful collection of recipes, shared below, that readers come back to time and again, whether it’s a classic cornbread stuffing or a more modern cheesy pizza version that all ages will enjoy.

headline: Key Question in Oath Keepers Sedition Trial: Was There a Plan on Jan. 6?
abstract: The defendants from the far-right militia group are arguing that their participation in the storming of the Capitol was spontaneous rather than the product of a conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: In the past week or so, lawyers for Stewart Rhodes and four other members of the Oath Keepers militia have defended their clients against charges of sedition by hammering the same point to a jury: Many in the far-right group joined in the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, but nothing they did that day was part of a premeditated plan.

headline: Elon Musk Has No Idea What He’s Doing at Twitter
abstract: The chaos and confusion of Musk’s short reign is far worse than anything I’d imagined.
lead_paragraph: If you thought Elon Musk’s will-he-or-won’t-he approach to buying Twitter was chaotic, the two weeks since Musk took the helm of the social media company have been downright anarchic, with his plans for Twitter flipping and flopping as furiously as a fish on a hook.

headline: Nicole Damages Coastal Florida Highway, Stranding Residents
abstract: Storm surge triggered by Nicole caused portions of a major oceanside road to collapse.
lead_paragraph: Storm surge triggered by Nicole caused portions of a major oceanside road to collapse.

headline: Where to Eat: The Jewish Deli
abstract: An exhibit on the Jewish deli, one of the city’s finest institutions, opens at the New-York Historical Society on Friday. Here are a few spots worth your time.
lead_paragraph: An exhibit on the Jewish deli, one of the city’s finest institutions, opens at the New-York Historical Society on Friday. Here are a few spots worth your time.

headline: California Regulators Propose Cutting Compensation for Rooftop Solar
abstract: It’s the second attempt by the state Public Utilities Commission to change how people are paid for the excess energy their solar panels send to the grid.
lead_paragraph: For a second time in less than a year, regulators in California moved on Thursday to roll back the compensation that homeowners receive from utilities for the excess electricity their rooftop solar panels send to the electric grid — payments that power companies and some consumer groups have argued hurt poor and low-income households.

headline: Fishing Regulator Rejects Lifting Ban on Female Crab Harvest
abstract: A commission acknowledged concerns about the threatened shorebirds that rely on crab eggs as a critical food source around the Delaware Bay.
lead_paragraph: A fisheries regulator on Thursday unexpectedly extended a ban on harvesting female horseshoe crabs from the Delaware Bay to help protect a vital food source for the red knot, a threatened shorebird that migrates via the bay’s beaches.

headline: Watch Live: Maricopa County Board of Elections Provides Update
abstract: Election officials from Maricopa County address ballot processing and tabulation in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: Election officials from Maricopa County address ballot processing and tabulation in Arizona.

headline: A major coastal Florida road has partially collapsed, leaving residents stranded.
abstract: A six- to seven-mile stretch of the narrow A1A was “impassable” and “compromised,” St. Johns County officials said.
lead_paragraph: State Road A1A, a highway that runs north to south along the Florida coast and is the main thoroughfare in many beach towns in St. Johns County, has collapsed or flooded in several areas, leaving many residents stranded.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Harvard Museum Will Return Hundreds of Native American Hair Samples
abstract: The Peabody Museum apologized for its “complicity in the objectification of Native peoples” by holding hair samples taken from Indigenous children at government boarding schools in the 1930s.
lead_paragraph: The Peabody Museum at Harvard University said on Thursday that it would return a collection of hair samples that were taken in the early 1930s from hundreds of Native American children who were forced to attend government-run boarding schools.

headline: Swing Voters Rejected Far-Right Candidates. But Not So Much in New York.
abstract: In suburban and exurban areas that had favored President Biden, voters showed support for some Trump-aligned candidates.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, voters in swing states this week appeared to reject candidates in marquee races who were backed by former President Donald J. Trump or who were closely aligned with his policies.

headline: Migrant Shelter on Randalls Island Will Close After Opening Last Month
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams announced on Thursday that the city would take down the 84,400-square-foot facility and reopen a new migrant center in Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: New York City will shut down a tent facility for migrants on Randalls Island, in yet another shift in Mayor Eric Adams’s efforts to cope with the unexpected arrival of more than 23,000 migrants in recent months, many of whom were bused into New York from Texas.

headline: Democratic Hopes Rise on Senate Control as Two States Count Votes
abstract: In Arizona and Nevada, Republicans’ path to victory appeared to narrow, though both races remain close. The G.O.P.’s odds of success are greater in the House.
lead_paragraph: Democrats grew increasingly optimistic on Thursday that they would hold on to their control of the Senate as votes were counted in Arizona and Nevada, after chalking up vital victories in New Hampshire and Pennsylvania and watching the race in Georgia head to a runoff election in December.

headline: Trump’s Role in Georgia Becomes More Pressing, and Complicated, With the Senate Runoff
abstract: If recent history repeats itself, Mr. Trump’s role will become a key factor for deep-pocketed Republican donors.
lead_paragraph: In five of the six states where former President Donald J. Trump spent more than $16 million supporting Republican candidates during the midterm cycle, he also hosted at least one of his signature mega-rallies in the final two months of campaigning.

headline: The Right-Wing Grass Roots Scored Big in 2010. But 2022 Was Far Different.
abstract: Unlike the Tea Party movement in 2010, the pro-Trump grass roots proved to be more liability than asset when it came to winning elections in 2022.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Doug Mastriano’s campaign for governor began with denunciations of “establishment Republicans,” a guest appearance by Michael Flynn and a blast from a shofar. It ended with disco-ball-style lights illuminating a fast-emptying hotel ballroom in Camp Hill, Pa., as the sound system played Rick Astley’s “Never Gonna Give You Up.”

headline: Eager to Grab National Spotlight, Abrams Falls Again on Georgia Stage
abstract: In her second bid for governor, Stacey Abrams was dogged by complaints that she was distracted by her national ambitions and disconnected from voters at home.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Four days before Election Day, with her campaign for governor on the ropes, Stacey Abrams called into a morning radio show with a message — not for voters, but for the show’s host.

headline: The Fever Is Breaking
abstract: This has been a good year for liberalism.
lead_paragraph: A convulsion has shaken America and many other Western democracies over the past few years. People became disgusted with established power, trust in many institutions neared rock bottom, populist fury rose from right and left.

headline: Looking Back at Who Was Right About This Weird Election
abstract: There were always two competing major theories about the 2022 midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: There were always two competing major theories about the 2022 midterm elections.

headline: Carbon Dioxide Emissions Increased in 2022 as Crises Roiled Energy Markets
abstract: Global emissions from fossil fuels are likely to reach record highs this year, new data shows, putting nations further off track from stopping global warming.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Global fossil fuel emissions will most likely reach record highs in 2022 and do not yet show signs of declining, researchers said Thursday, a trend that puts countries further away from their goal of stopping global warming.

headline: Patrick Haggerty, ‘Lost Pioneer’ of Gay Country Music, Dies at 78
abstract: In 1973, he put out a little-noticed album of songs about same-sex love and social protest. Forty-one years later, he became an unlikely star.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Haggerty, who in 1973 released an album of country songs about same-sex romance that sold only 1,000 copies and seemed destined for eternal obscurity until, four decades later, its rediscovery brought him renown as the first openly gay country singer, died on Oct. 31 at his home in Bremerton, Wash. He was 78.

headline: Three Correction Officers Accused of Faking Sick Leave
abstract: As New York City’s jails faced a staffing crisis, federal prosecutors said the officers used falsified sick notes and lied about trips to the doctor to avoid going to work.
lead_paragraph: Three New York City correction officers were charged with lying about being sick and taking leave for more than a year, in the midst of a severe staffing emergency that helped plunge the city’s jails into a crisis of violence.

headline: Sean Patrick Maloney on His Loss, the Media and A.O.C.
abstract: Mr. Maloney said that he and other New York Democrats were unable to overcome suburban fears of crime. He also had some harsh words for Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.
lead_paragraph: For Representative Sean Patrick Maloney, the results of this week’s midterm elections were probably more bitter than sweet.

headline: At the Capitol, the Question of Who Won the Midterms Lingers Days Afterward
abstract: Members of both parties were poring over the ongoing counts in search of clues to the final outcome.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An air of suspense hung over the Capitol on Thursday. It was combined with an air of uncertainty. Also, an air of “What the heck is going on?”

headline: Hurricane Nicole Causes Four Deaths, Forces Evacuation of Unsteady Buildings
abstract: The storm was especially hard on Volusia County, northeast of Orlando, where officials said that inspectors had deemed 24 hotels and condominiums unsafe.
lead_paragraph: WILBUR-BY-THE-SEA, Fla. — Hurricane Nicole whipped through Florida on Thursday, a rare November storm that crashed huge waves along the coast, collapsed houses into the Atlantic Ocean, required the evacuation of unstable waterfront condo buildings and washed away roads and beaches.

headline: Jane Gross, Sportswriter Who Opened Locker Room Doors, Dies at 75
abstract: She made news by entering a pro basketball inner sanctum to do her job. Years later, her mother’s physical decline led her to write about aging for The Times and in a book.
lead_paragraph: Jane Gross, who in 1975 became the first female sportswriter known to have entered a professional basketball locker room, and who later distinguished herself at The New York Times with her compassionate reporting on aging and a well-received book about her mother’s decline in a nursing home, died on Wednesday in the Bronx. She was 75.

headline: FTX Spent Big on Sports Sponsorships. What Happens Now?
abstract: The cryptocurrency exchange’s sudden collapse puts deals with teams, leagues and counties worth hundreds of millions of dollars in doubt.
lead_paragraph: For sports fans, FTX was suddenly everywhere. The National Basketball Association’s Miami Heat played in FTX Arena. Major League Baseball umpires wore an FTX patch on their uniforms. Mercedes-Benz’s Formula 1 racecars sported the FTX logo.

headline: Kyrie Irving Is Not Antisemitic, N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver Says
abstract: Irving, the Nets guard, met with Silver this week after promoting an antisemitic film on social media last month. Silver said Irving’s actions were damaging.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver said Thursday that he didn’t believe Nets guard Kyrie Irving was antisemitic after meeting with him in person this week at the league’s headquarters in Manhattan. Irving has been facing backlash for promoting an antisemitic film on Twitter last month.

headline: As U.S. Moves On From Elections, Georgia Gears Up for Another One
abstract: The political world is diving into a runoff between Senator Raphael Warnock and Herschel Walker that will reveal the extent of Democrats’ unexpected traction in the midterm races.
lead_paragraph: CANTON, Ga. — With the last campaigns only two days in the rearview mirror, the political world dived into a Georgia Senate race that will reveal the extent of Democrats’ unexpected traction in the midterm races and whether Republicans can move past the long shadow of former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Why does it take so long to count votes in Nevada?
abstract: Nevada’s rules around mail-in voting, and the voters’ embrace of the method contribute to a delay in race calls.
lead_paragraph: It has already been days since the midterm elections, but there is still plenty of vote counting to go in Nevada, as Americans wait anxiously to see which party will control the Senate.

headline: Top U.S. General Urges Diplomacy in Ukraine While Biden Advisers Resist
abstract: Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has made the case that the Ukrainians should try to cement their gains at the bargaining table.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A disagreement has emerged at the highest levels of the United States government over whether to press Ukraine to seek a diplomatic end to its war with Russia, with America’s top general urging negotiations while other advisers to President Biden argue that it is too soon.

headline: The Coldhearted Carbon Math
abstract: Our carbon budget is running out quickly.
lead_paragraph: Last November in Glasgow, the annual United Nations climate conference ended with its president, Alok Sharma, declaring that the global goal of keeping warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius had been just barely kept alive. “Its pulse is weak,” he said.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 11, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 11, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about Wes Moore, the newly elected Governor of Maryland, referred imprecisely to Mr. Moore’s claim that he was a Baltimore native. The claim was published on his book’s dust jacket, not in the text, and it was later removed.

headline: Judge Fines Trump Lawyers in Clinton Conspiracy Suit Tossed in September
abstract: The sanctions ruling comes as a range of lawyers working for former President Donald J. Trump are under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge in Florida imposed sanctions on Thursday against a group of lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump who handled a sprawling lawsuit that accused Hillary Clinton and a range of Mr. Trump’s perceived enemies of a vast conspiracy against him.

headline: Puppies on Prozac: How to Handle Your Pet’s Anxiety
abstract: Veterinarians say they have seen an increasing number of pets experiencing mental distress. Here’s how to spot the signs.
lead_paragraph: When my dog Ozzy feels stressed, he emits loud, rambly groans that are ridiculously cute but also make me wonder if he’s having a stroke. After noticing that his anxiety swells quite frequently, our trainer recommended that we give him CBD treats to soothe his nerves. Shortly thereafter, our veterinarian prescribed him the antidepressant trazodone for when he’s especially stressed, including before vet appointments. Ozzy appears to be in good company: In the process of reporting this piece, I learned that two of my editors have cats on Prozac.

headline: The Australian Teacher Fighting to Be the World’s Strongest Woman
abstract: Elly Smith competes in a sport called strongman, where participants attempt to lift, hold, pull or carry everything from dumbbells to airplanes.
lead_paragraph: To the casual observer, Elly Smith appears to have a normal life. She’s an assistant principal at Baulkham Hills North Public School in northwestern Sydney, where she also teaches history and geography. She’s fond of her two dogs, a toy poodle called Ted and a Maltese Shih Tzu called Lucy. She’s passionate about health and fitness and highly active on Instagram, interacting frequently with her 1,300 followers.

headline: Climate Activists, Including Scientists, Are Arrested in Protests at Private Airports
abstract: The protesters temporarily shut down the main entrance to Teterboro Airport in New Jersey and also picketed at airports in North Carolina, California and Washington State.
lead_paragraph: More than a dozen protesters, including scientists, were arrested on Thursday at private airports in the United States, coinciding with similar actions around the world to highlight the toll of private jets on the environment, activists said.

headline: Tina Kotek, a Progressive, Will Be Oregon’s Next Governor
abstract: She will also be one of two of the nation’s first openly lesbian governors.
lead_paragraph: Tina Kotek, a progressive Democrat who faced a pair of well-funded challengers, was elected to lead Oregon, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Kim Schrier Holds On to House Seat in Washington State
abstract: Republicans had eyed the district as a prime potential pickup in their drive to win back the House majority, after Dr. Schrier became the first Democrat to win it in 2018.
lead_paragraph: Representative Kim Schrier, Democrat of Washington,  won election to a third term on Thursday, according to The Associated Press, beating back a steep challenge from Matt Larkin, a Republican and former Bush administration official.

headline: Divers Discover Piece of Space Shuttle Challenger Off Florida Coast
abstract: The discovery came 36 years after the shuttle exploded over the Atlantic Ocean, killing all seven crew members on board, in one of the worst accidents of the American space program.
lead_paragraph: The divers for a TV documentary plunged deep into the Atlantic Ocean on Feb. 26, hoping to find a search-and-rescue aircraft that had been lost since 1945. Mike Barnette dived farther and farther into murky waters that obscured his vision, as if he were swirling inside a glass of Guinness, until his fingers touched a flat metal object.

headline: Texas Judge Strikes Down Biden’s Student Debt Cancellation
abstract: The ruling adds to the legal obstacles the president faces in his plan to cancel up to $20,000 per borrower in federal student loan debt.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Texas on Thursday rejected President Biden’s executive action to cancel hundreds of billions of dollars in student debt, further clouding the situation for millions of borrowers who have applied to a program already on hold because of legal obstacles.

headline: Arizona Election Officials Call on G.O.P. Candidates to Tone Down the Rhetoric
abstract: In a news conference, they said they wouldn’t finish counting all the ballots until next week.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Election officials in Arizona’s most populous and politically important county announced Thursday that they would not complete counting ballots until early next week, adding to tensions in a state at the center of the false narrative that the 2020 election was stolen.

headline: Wael Shawky Enters the Realm of Myth
abstract: The multidisciplinary artist’s work dives into history and legend to explore the fantasies and manipulations underpinning our modern world.
lead_paragraph: Freshly arrived in Philadelphia from his native Alexandria, Egypt, the multimedia artist Wael Shawky’s mind was on yet another place and time: ancient Greece and the era of classical mythology. Sitting in his large studio in a converted industrial garage, he excitedly related several stories about Zeus. Shawky, 51, had been conducting a large amount of research on the topic for a film he’s making in Italy and Egypt on Greco-Roman beliefs. This immersion has, in turn, inspired new projects, including his latest show, “Isles of the Blessed,” which opens today at the Lisson Gallery in New York City. When we met last month, he had just returned to the United States, where he spends parts of the year, to finalize works for the exhibition. It will consist of 11 paintings and a short video, all titled “Isles of the Blessed,” after the Greek paradise where immortal mythical heroes live out eternity, their lives secure in legend.

headline: The End of ‘Atlanta’ Changes Everything
abstract: Donald Glover’s masterpiece was a different kind of prestige TV. It never explained itself, and was all the better for it.
lead_paragraph: “Atlanta,” the surrealist comedy-drama whose fourth and final season just reached its end, specialized in leaving indelible, discordant images in the minds of its audience, like a television stuck between channels. Its finale was no different: Following shows like “St. Elsewhere,” “Seinfeld,” “The Sopranos” and “Twin Peaks: The Return,” classics whose endings sparked critical pandemonium, it concludes with an episode that has the potential to change the way viewers consider everything that came before. But that finale’s hypnotic grit — its mix of the dreamlike and the realistic, the hypnagogic potency of films like “The Matrix” and “Inception” and the acerbic urgency of an Amiri Baraka poem — also has its roots in an earlier episode from this season, one that captures much of what the show did so well.

headline: Present Perfect Indicative
abstract: Can you spot the mini-theme in this puzzle by Brooke Husic and Erik Agard?
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Happy Friday, solvers! As you most likely know, Friday and Saturday puzzles are typically themeless, showcasing constructor voice and exciting long entries instead of the wordplay themes we often encounter on other days.

headline: Review: ‘Kimberly Akimbo,’ Both Great and Small, Seizes the Day
abstract: The season’s most moving new musical earns its place among the behemoths of Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Broadway reliably churns out several tourist-bait extravaganzas a year, the kind that feature sequins, singalongs and profits. Smallish, thoughtful, more narrowcast new musicals — let’s call them nerdicals — are rarer: one per season, if we’re lucky. Some, like “Fun Home,” “Dear Evan Hansen” and “The Band’s Visit,” win top Tony Awards; “A Strange Loop” even won the Pulitzer Prize. If they rarely last as long as, say, “Six” or “Moulin Rouge” seem likely to, these shows prove their immense value in the time they’ve got.

headline: Variety: Cascades
abstract: Joe DiPietro rafts us into the rapids, heads spinning.
lead_paragraph: CASCADES — This is only the second time we’ve seen this puzzle, after its debut in 2020; it also marks a return to variety puzzles by Joe DiPietro, a prolific daily crossword constructor. He has also contributed a couple of Puns and Anagrams puzzles and a diagramless grid some years ago.  Cascades is a different kind of challenge, but it does come with a diagramless look about it: no black squares. No empty squares, either! Those can be quite daunting.

headline: You Be the Ump: World Series Edition
abstract: Umpires were highly accurate in the World Series, getting the calls right 96 percent of the time. In this edition of “You Be the Ump,” can you do even better than they did?
lead_paragraph: Umpires were highly accurate in the World Series, getting the calls right 96 percent of the time. In this edition of “You Be the Ump,” can you do even better than they did?

headline: Playing Hard to Get Online? No, He Was Just Too Busy.
abstract: Eugene Daniels and Nate Stephens matched on three dating sites, but it took a while before they finally connected.
lead_paragraph: It took matches on three dating apps in June 2017 for Eugene Anthony Daniels II and Nathan Thomas Stephens to finally connect.

headline: Failing in Marriage Does Not Mean Failing at Marriage
abstract: My wife has kicked me out five times. Another time I left on my own. Why are we still together?
lead_paragraph: Alone one evening in early spring, seated on a green park bench beside the Charles River in Cambridge, Mass., I waited for Deb. The sun was setting and the temperature falling, and I was wearing my softball jersey and knickers and wishing I had remembered to bring my thick flannel shirt.

headline: After a Rocky Start, Smooth Sailing
abstract: Ricky Wheeler always knew Kaitlyn Johnson was a catch. It was just a matter of timing.
lead_paragraph: After dating Kaitlyn Nancy Johnson from June to October of 2017, Richard Daniel Wheeler decided they had to break up. He worked as a captain on a charter fishing boat and would be leaving Northfield, N.J., where he lived, for Grenada. He didn’t know where he would go from there or when he would be back in the United States.

headline: A ‘Magical Connection’ That Began on the First Date
abstract: Adam Drawas said he “knew in the first 10 seconds” of meeting Alan Pablos-Perez more than two years ago that he was the one.
lead_paragraph: When Adam Matthew Drawas chose the pricey Los Angeles restaurant Gwen for his first date with Alan Joseph Pablos-Perez on Feb. 1, 2020, he fully expected to foot the bill. It was only fair, he had thought, since he picked the place.

headline: Always the Wedding Singer, Finally the Bride
abstract: Maggie Doherty attended a lot of weddings as an entertainer. So when she married Josh Zager, there was no doubt what the focus would be.
lead_paragraph: When Margaret Allison Doherty and Joshua Michael Zager were married on Oct. 9 in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., there was a reason Ms. Doherty’s mother, Molly Dwyer, compared the wedding to “a music festival.”

headline: Can There Be a Rights Reckoning for Nations That Don’t Want to Do It?
abstract: In nations reckoning with atrocities, reconciliation panels and similar bodies often obscure or delay the truth. But that doesn’t mean that international justice has no effect.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Kate Cronin-Furman, then a Ph.D. student in political science at Columbia University, noticed something odd.

headline: U.C.L.A.’s Football Wins Can’t Mask Its Financial Woes
abstract: The Bruins are having their best recent season on the field, yet attendance is falling rapidly. Free tickets haven’t helped, and the athletic department’s balance sheet has suffered.
lead_paragraph: David Brownfield, who grew up a few bends in Sunset Boulevard from Westwood Village, could sing the U.C.L.A. fight song before he could shave. He graduated from U.C.L.A. in 1985 and has had football season tickets with friends ever since — even grudgingly paying what he calls the annual “extortion fee,” the $800 donation that was required for the privilege of buying his season tickets this year.

headline: When It Comes to Bearing Bad Tidings, Putin Is Nowhere to Be Found
abstract: Big decisions about Ukraine are President Vladimir V. Putin’s to make, but the Kremlin and state media are distancing him from the setback in Kherson and downplaying its seriousness.
lead_paragraph: When Gen. Sergey Surovikin was appointed the overall commander of Russian forces in Ukraine a month ago, the Kremlin’s cheerleaders in the media lauded him as exactly the kind of severe warrior needed to bring order to the stumbling invasion. “General Armageddon,” some called him.

headline: On Veterans Day, Memories of Driving a Sherman Tank
abstract: A Long Island man, now 99, was part of a tank crew that drove across France after D-Day. “War is hell,” he told his family.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday, and it’s Veterans Day. We’ll look at how a search for World War II veterans led to a 99-year-old man who drove a Sherman tank through France after D-Day. We’ll also meet someone who did a double take the first time she saw her name on the doors leading to her office — New York City’s new fire commissioner.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Ukrainian forces in Kherson.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian Army is moving cautiously into areas abandoned by Russian troops along a front line in the Kherson region of southern Ukraine, a day after Russia’s defense minister announced a retreat from the western bank of the Dnipro River. The move marked a significant setback for Russia’s military; in September it declared parts of the region Russian land.

headline: Zelensky says dozens of towns and villages in the Kherson region have been retaken.
abstract: Russia’s announcement this week that it was retreating from parts of the Kherson region has been cast in doubt, as events have been obfuscated by the fog of war and concern rose in Kyiv that the Kremlin might be bluffing in an effort to draw Ukrainian troops into a trap.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s announcement this week that it was retreating from parts of the Kherson region has been cast in doubt, as events have been obfuscated by the fog of war and concern rose in Kyiv that the Kremlin might be bluffing in an effort to draw Ukrainian troops into a trap.

headline: Seth Meyers Is Thrilled by G.O.P.’s New Treatment of Trump
abstract: “Republicans are running away from Trump faster than Josh Hawley on Jan. 6,” Meyers joked on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Europe Braces for Recession as Economies Falter
abstract: Britain’s economic output fell in the third quarter and European Union officials forecast weakening growth for countries across the continent.
lead_paragraph: The ride down may be shallow or steep, but either way, the European Union and Britain could be starting to slide into recession.

headline: What I Saw in Nepal’s Forests
abstract: A Times reporter spent a week in southern Nepal to understand its successful reforestation program.
lead_paragraph: A Times reporter spent a week in southern Nepal to understand its successful reforestation program.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Why Some States Went in Different Directions in Midterms
abstract: Abortion rights and antidemocratic stances were more relevant or pressing in some places than others.
lead_paragraph: The results of this year’s midterm elections won’t be final for weeks, but there’s more than enough data to say this: They were very different from usual.

headline: How Nepal Grew Back Its Forests
abstract: An effort decades in the making is showing results in Nepal, a rare success story in a world of cascading climate disasters and despair.
lead_paragraph: KANKALI COMMUNITY FOREST, Nepal — The old man moved gingerly, hill after hill, cutting dry shrubs until he was surrounded by trees that had grown from seedlings he had planted two decades ago. He pointed to a row of low peaks above the Kathmandu valley that were covered with dense foliage.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Strategy for Reforestation, Starting From the Ground Up
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, November 11, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “You see that? They were barren mounds of red mud 15 years ago. These trees are more than my children.”

headline: KFC Apologizes for Linking Chicken Promotion to Kristallnacht
abstract: An automated push notification sent in error by KFC Germany conflated the notorious 1938 pogrom and “tender cheese with crispy chicken.”
lead_paragraph: KFC’s German branch has apologized for seeming to encourage its customers to mark the anniversary of Kristallnacht — the notorious Nazi pogrom against Jews — by eating chicken, saying that a promotional message was sent in error as a result of an automated push notification.

headline: On Alibaba’s Singles Day, Chinese Brands Fill Shopping Baskets
abstract: As geopolitical and economic pressures mount, homegrown businesses are increasingly the preferred choice over Western competitors in a more insular China.
lead_paragraph: For years, China’s annual shopping extravaganza known as Singles Day looked like a profitable exchange between East and West. Thousands of premium Western brands like Apple and L’Oreal were bought by hundreds of millions of Chinese consumers on the e-commerce giant Alibaba.

headline: China Eases Some Pandemic Policies, While Sticking to ‘Zero Covid’
abstract: Investors cheered the changes, although officials emphasized that measures “must not be relaxed.”
lead_paragraph: As China’s economy continues to be squeezed by the cost of the country’s zero-tolerance approach to Covid, the government softened some of its restrictions on Friday, even as it remained committed to its strict pandemic policy.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever."
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever."

headline: Trump Is the Chief Obstacle to a Republican Revival
abstract: The party’s midterms setback could bring renewal.
lead_paragraph: The final votes have yet to be counted, but so far the 2022 midterm campaign bears a striking resemblance to the midterm elections of 1998. A quarter century ago, Republicans were convinced that historical precedent and the manifest flaws of the incumbent Democratic president would bring them a landslide victory.

headline: Trump, Musk and Kanye Are Twitter Poisoned
abstract: The garish celebrity playboy, the obsessive engineer and the young artist, as different from one another as they could be, have all veered not in the direction of becoming bratty little boys on a schoolyard.
lead_paragraph: I encountered Donald Trump a few times in the pre-social media era, and he struck me as someone who was in on his own joke. He no longer does. Elon Musk used to be a serious person more concerned with engineering and building businesses than with petty name-calling. He didn’t seem like the kind of person to amplify a preposterous, sordid story about Paul Pelosi. Kanye West was once a thoughtful artist. Now known as Ye, he radiates antisemitism on top of his earlier slavery denialism.

headline: Want to Hold Onto Elite Status With Your Airline? It’s Going to Cost You.
abstract: There was a moment at the height of the pandemic when rewards programs were lowering the velvet rope for more than the privileged few. But it’s time to prepare for the “great reset” in elite status.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing quite like getting special treatment while traveling. Think complimentary upgrades to the front of the airplane cabin from the back, or being moved from a room with a view of an alley to one overlooking the park. These are perks that travelers with hotel, airline and rental-car elite status have enjoyed for years, and ones that became more in reach for average people during the pandemic.

headline: A Verified Mess: Turmoil From Twitter to FTX
abstract: Plus: Is the latest round of tech layoffs a sign of impending doom, or a much-needed structural correction?
lead_paragraph: This week, we go inside Elon Musk’s “dire” warnings, FTX’s spectacular collapse and Meta’s big layoffs. Has the tech industry lost its mind?

headline: A Shock to the System Is Coming. Which Party Will Be Ready for It?
abstract: That neither the Republican nor the Democratic coalition can achieve anything like hegemony over the political system is unusual in the history of American politics.
lead_paragraph: There was no red wave. There wasn’t even a red splash. Against most expectations — and in the face of daunting fundamentals — the Democratic Party held its own against a hungry and aggressive Republican Party. It flipped seats and chambers in Michigan; it stood its ground in Virginia and Wisconsin; and it fought Republicans to a standstill in Arizona and a runoff in Georgia.

headline: Our Worst Fears Have Come True in Myanmar
abstract: But the country’s people have come too far to give up their freedom.
lead_paragraph: We apologized to our baby daughter before she was born.

headline: Old Topics, New (Audio) Revelations
abstract: When it comes to Abraham Lincoln, classical music, Andy Warhol and Truman Capote, there is always something new to learn.
lead_paragraph: For many, the word “studying” conjures unpleasant memories: of impending exams, caffeine-fueled all-nighters, the frustration of just not getting it. But what if we reimagined the word in the context of the lifelong learner, not as a chore but as the channel to a joy that can be had from staying with a single subject for hours, from revisiting it again and again, even when you think there’s nothing else to learn? Treading mostly on well-trodden ground, three new audiobooks prove that no matter how much you think you know about a subject, there’s always more to study — in a way that isn’t a drag.

headline: ‘It Was Important to Get That Right’: How ‘The Crown’ Tackled the Revenge Dress
abstract: The series’s costume designer discussed what was sure to be the most closely scrutinized re-creation of the new season, Diana’s shoulder-baring little black dress.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the acclaimed Netflix drama “The Crown” reintroduced the world to a young Lady Diana Spencer. Using pastels, puffy sleeves and floral patterns, the series painted a picture of a young woman struggling to find her place in a family that had only begrudgingly accepted her.

headline: Sizing Up This Year’s Batch of Black Friday Travel Deals
abstract: The sales are out there, but they may not be quite so enticing. From hotels to cruises to organized tours, here’s what to expect.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to Black Friday sales, travel companies usually rise to the occasion, knowing consumers are in buying mode. But now that travel is back with a vengeance — Airbnb, for example, just reported its most profitable quarter in company history — sales may not be as impressive this year.

headline: How a Sex Attack Suspect Slipped Past the N.Y.P.D. and Struck Again
abstract: The first attack in Hudson River Park set off searches, but investigators made no arrest until two more women had been victimized.
lead_paragraph: Before dawn one morning in March, a man on a bicycle rode up behind a woman running on a well-manicured path alongside the Hudson River in Lower Manhattan, tackled her and forced her to perform oral sex.

headline: There’s a Lot Congress Can Do Now, and It Starts With Changing a Law That Trump Exploited
abstract: Congress can also do more to protect the integrity of a presidential election and make progress on other issues before the current session ends.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: Today’s U.F.C. Star Doesn’t Care if You Think His Fights Are Boring
abstract: Israel Adesanya has cleared out most of his challengers and has faced criticism for some fights lacking flashy knockouts. “It’s a high-level game we play, but not everyone who watches is high-level,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Adesanya and Pereira’s fight for the middleweight crown.

headline: Paying for Climate Damage Isn’t Charity
abstract: It’s a down payment on a more stable future.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — The climate crisis has reached new levels of devastation this year for millions of people in vulnerable countries that didn’t cause the problem. Floods in Pakistan, drought in the Horn of Africa and hurricanes in the Dominican Republic — all intensified by climate change — have ruined people’s livelihoods, causing losses so immense that it is hard for many in richer countries to even fathom.

headline: Bouncing Your Way to Better Health
abstract: Trampolines aren’t just for kids. This exercise tool can be a low-impact boon for your cardiovascular fitness, pelvic floor strength and sense of balance
lead_paragraph: John P. Porcari is a bit of a reality TV show junkie. When he wants to work out, Dr. Porcari, a retired professor of sports and exercise science from the University of Wisconsin-LaCrosse, goes downstairs and watches “Alaska: The Last Frontier” or “Naked and Afraid” while bouncing on a mini trampoline. Just before speaking with The Times, he had completed four sets of 50 bounces while watching Discovery Channel’s “Gold Rush.”

headline: The Crypto Ponzi Scheme Avenger
abstract: From his home in New Zealand, the YouTuber Danny de Hek assails what he calls a dangerous and deceptive scheme, one rant at a time.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Danny de Hek was a social media guru badly in need of a social media guru. A buoyant New Zealander with geeky glasses, he dispensed advice about how to vastly expand your online audience, to a group of just 350 subscribers.

headline: After 4 Sons Vanish, Their Mother Devotes Her Life to Mexico’s Missing
abstract: Over 100,000 people are missing in Mexico, but even amid this national agony, one mother’s story stands out both for the scope of her suffering and for her work trying to end the nation’s nightmare.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Although a woman of modest means, she has traversed Mexico, filed a lawsuit against its government, met with United Nations officials and even hugged the pope, all in the service of one quest: reuniting with her four sons who have disappeared.

headline: ‘The Crown’: The History Behind Season 5 on Netflix
abstract: The Netflix show’s blending of fact and fiction has received more criticism than ever around its most recent season. Here’s how The Times reported on its plotlines.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Before Season 5 of “The Crown” even arrived on Netflix, the show’s blending of fact and fiction was drawing criticism in Britain.

headline: Election Officials Say Efforts to Bolster the Voting System Worked
abstract: Officials were braced for partisan poll monitors convinced of fraud to disrupt voting in the midterm elections. While there were scattered episodes, the vote went smoothly.
lead_paragraph: For months, election officials have worried that activists convinced that the election system is corrupt and broken would cause significant problems in the midterms. But the scattered episodes during the vote did not disrupt the system.

headline: Two Weeks of Chaos: Inside Elon Musk’s Takeover of Twitter
abstract: Mr. Musk ordered immediate layoffs, fired executives by email and laid down product deadlines, transforming the company.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Elon Musk had a demand.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, November 11, 2022
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Here’s the latest on the election results.
abstract: Democrats took a step toward retaining control of the Senate after Mark Kelly held on to his seat in Arizona, defeating Blake Masters, a venture capitalist backed by former President Donald J. Trump, according to The Associated Press.
lead_paragraph: Democrats took a step toward retaining control of the Senate after Mark Kelly held on to his seat in Arizona, defeating Blake Masters, a venture capitalist backed by former President Donald J. Trump, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Judge Blocks Licenses for Some Cannabis Dispensaries in New York
abstract: The move affects 63 of the 150 licenses that the state planned to issue.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has temporarily barred the state of New York from issuing the first batch of retail licenses for recreational cannabis in five regions pending resolution of a lawsuit filed by a Michigan-based company challenging the program’s selection requirements.

headline: The Teachers Trying to Fill the Gap in Climate Education: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Unconventional Results
abstract: In states where abortion rights or democracy was on the ballot, Democrats upended the typical midterm result.
lead_paragraph: The results of this year’s midterm elections won’t be final for weeks, but there’s more than enough data to say this: They were different.

headline: Remnants of Nicole Expected to Take Final Soggy Steps Through Northeast
abstract: Forecasters see only a small chance of flash flooding as the weather system, which made landfall in Florida as a hurricane, winds toward New England over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: The remnants of Hurricane Nicole will continue a soggy getaway through the Northeast over the weekend after soaking parts of the Southeast and the Mid-Atlantic states with several inches of rain on Friday, forecasters said.

headline: Why the Showy, Short-Lived Hibiscus Is the Flower of Our Time
abstract: The plant’s grandiose blossoms are as dazzling as they are ephemeral — and, in an age of shortened attention spans, they’re having a resurgence.
lead_paragraph: “COLLECTING CAN BE a sort of lovesickness,” Susan Orlean writes in 1998’s “The Orchid Thief”: “If you collect living things, you are pursuing something imperfectible, because even if you manage to find and possess the living things you want, there is no guarantee they won’t die or change.” Orlean is, of course, writing about orchids and the people obsessed with them, but she could also have been talking about the growers, hybridizers, collectors and floral designers who are ardent about tropical hibiscus — the large, showy pinwheel-shaped flower that comes in a spectacular array of colors. “It’s almost like tulip fever, though in a much more low-key way,” says the floral artist Brittany Asch, 35, about the resurgent interest in tropical hibiscus, the persnickety plant that’s traumatized by frost and frazzled by too much heat, and whose blooms are known to last, poetically, for a single day. Asch, who moved her New York-based studio, Brrch, to Los Angeles in late 2020 and has used the flower in her dreamy, lyrical arrangements, says that because florists in, say, Miami or Hawaii have better access to tropical hibiscuses than their counterparts in New York, this creates an “element of exclusivity” — compounded, perhaps, by the brief life of the blossoms — that renders them even more desirable.

headline: Large Earthquake Strikes Near Tonga
abstract: Officials advised people to get to the third floor of buildings if they were unable to flee to higher ground. Videos showed drivers trying to escape the danger.
lead_paragraph: A shallow, strong earthquake with a magnitude of 7.3 struck in the sea about 130 miles off the coast of Tonga on Friday, setting off tsunami warnings across the Pacific Island region.

headline: As U.S. moves on from the elections, Georgia gears up for another one.
abstract: CANTON, Ga. — With the last campaigns only days in the rearview mirror, the political world is diving into a Georgia Senate race that will reveal the extent of Democrats’ unexpected traction in the midterm races and whether Republicans can move past the long shadow of former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: CANTON, Ga. — With the last campaigns only days in the rearview mirror, the political world is diving into a Georgia Senate race that will reveal the extent of Democrats’ unexpected traction in the midterm races and whether Republicans can move past the long shadow of former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: A Blazing, Bejeweled Comet Re-Enters Chanel’s Orbit
abstract: Coco Chanel’s first — and only — high jewelry collection informs the house’s latest bijouterie.
lead_paragraph: In November 1932, Gabrielle “Coco” Chanel presented her first and only high jewelry collection, Bijoux de Diamants, in her 18th-century townhouse at 29 Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honoré in Paris. Among the roughly 50 pieces, which were inspired by the celestial floor mosaics at Aubazine Abbey (she’d lived at the Cistercian monastery’s orphanage as a child), were bracelets that coiled around the wrist like comet tails, a brooch shaped like a shimmering crescent and necklaces with diamonds arrayed to evoke the Big Dipper. “I wanted to cover women with constellations. With stars! Stars of all sizes,” said Chanel, whose bijouterie, like her pioneering clothing designs, was defined by an elegant yet restrained simplicity: Diamonds were cut and faceted using traditional techniques, and each stone’s setting was rendered to appear completely invisible.

headline: ‘It’s Never Our Time’: First-Time Home Buyers Face a Brutal Market
abstract: Unable to compete against older buyers with cash offers, younger potential buyers feel like they are never going to own a house.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2020, Alexandra Elmer and her husband, Matthew, began searching for their first home. They thought their wish list was realistic: four bedrooms, two bathrooms, a yard and central air-conditioning.

headline: Regulators Begin Cracking Down on FTX
abstract: Authorities worldwide are intensifying their scrutiny of the embattled cryptocurrency exchange, amid concern about improper use of customer money.
lead_paragraph: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the embattled crypto exchange FTX, may be racing to raise as much as $8 billion to save his imploding empire. But regulators are already moving to freeze parts of FTX’s business, while other divisions file for insolvency or prepare to halt operations.

headline: U.S. Seeks Closer Ties With India as Tension With China and Russia Builds
abstract: Treasury Secretary Yellen wants India to be part of the Biden administration’s “friend-shoring” agenda, but trade tensions linger.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The United States is placing India at the center of its ambition to detach global supply chains from the clutches of American adversaries, seeking to cement ties with one of the world’s fastest-growing economies as tensions with China remain high and as Russia’s war in Ukraine upends international commerce.

headline: Quentin Tarantino’s Greatest Hits of the ’70s
abstract: In “Cinema Speculation,” the filmmaker recalls his glory days of moviegoing.
lead_paragraph: Most film directors would no more comment on one another’s movies than they would score each other’s performance in bed. Filmmaking is a collaborative art but directors rarely get to collaborate with one another, and so frequently combine rabid curiosity about each other’s working methods with the slight fear they might be doing it wrong, while maintaining a facade of polite praise for the result. Then there is the Quentin Tarantino approach.

headline: ‘Black Panther: Wakanda Forever’ Is in Theaters. Let’s Talk About It.
abstract: Here is what people are writing about the movie.
lead_paragraph: The sequel to the thunderous Marvel hit “Black Panther,” which garnered $1.3 billion at the box office in 2018, finally reached theaters Friday, leaving many fans teary-eyed and slack-jawed. If you’re among the many, like myself, who trudged out of the theater ready to talk about every gut-wrenching, seat-shaking scene in the nearly three-hour film, these articles are for you. They spotlight some of the memorable moments and provide background on the movie’s origins.

headline: ‘The Good Fight’: Michelle and Robert King Give Closing Arguments
abstract: The legal series thrived on real-world disruption, drawing story lines from events both actual and anticipated. In an interview, the creators took stock.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for the series finale of “The Good Fight.”

headline: In Paris, a New Incense Room to Awaken the Senses
abstract: The Japanese store and restaurant Ogata Paris offers custom aromatic blends.
lead_paragraph: It was the Chinese who first coined the term wenxiang to describe the relaxing experience of breathing in aromatic smoke from small pieces of burning wood. During the Muromachi period (1338-1573), the Japanese adopted the expression, which translates as mon-koh — or “listening to incense” — as incense developed into a codified art form with its own ceremony, known as koh-do. “Sometimes koh-do is spiritual and sometimes it’s entertainment, a way to play with your senses,” says Shinichiro Ogata, the Tokyo-based architect, designer, restaurateur and chef, speaking through a translator. This past April, convinced that a meditative state of mind is more necessary than ever in our double-time world, he brought koh-do to Ogata Paris, the three-floor Japanese restaurant, gallery and boutique he opened in the city’s Marais neighborhood in 2020.

headline: How to Save on High Heating Bills This Winter
abstract: As a start, you can turn down the thermostat and insulate doors and windows. Plus, financial help is available to pay bills and to update heating systems.
lead_paragraph: The cost of heating a home is expected to spike this winter, as higher prices for natural gas and heating oil combine with a forecast for slightly colder weather than last winter.

headline: Can Germans Save Their Beloved Rhine?
abstract: Germany has embarked on an ambitious and expensive effort to preserve the river’s historical role as a vital transportation link. But will it work?
lead_paragraph: KARLSRUHE, Germany — It is one of the tightest and fastest bends in the Rhine River, a nearly 90-degree curve where a small rocky island dotted by trees further narrows the shipping channel.

headline: Embattled Crypto Exchange FTX Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: The announcement capped a stunning week that has shocked the crypto industry.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Sam Bankman-Fried, the chief executive of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX, took to Twitter to reassure his customers: “FTX is fine,” he wrote. “Assets are fine.”

headline: An explosion on a crucial bridge severed Kherson City’s last major crossing.
abstract: Videos and photographs posted to social media showed the Antonivsky Bridge to be heavily damaged.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — The Antonivsky Bridge, the main crossing over the Dnipro River in the city of Kherson, was blown up before dawn on Friday after most Russian forces retreated and just before Ukraine’s forces entered the city.

headline: With Several Key Races Still Undecided, Here’s Where Results Stand
abstract: More than two days after polls closed across the United States, control of both houses of Congress is still up for grabs, with many election outcomes not yet determined.
lead_paragraph: More than two days after polls closed across the United States, control of both houses of Congress is still up for grabs, with many races not yet called.

headline: Videos Show Kherson Civilians Welcoming First Ukrainian Troops
abstract: Footage verified by The New York Times shows civilians in Kherson’s main square greeting and cheering on some of the first Ukrainian troops to enter the city.
lead_paragraph: Footage verified by The New York Times shows civilians in Kherson’s main square greeting and cheering on some of the first Ukrainian troops to enter the city.

headline: When the Finely Tuned Spotlight Falls on the Lighting Designer
abstract: Jennifer Tipton, whose job usually entails serving the vision of choreographers and directors, has made her own show, the installation “Our Days and Night.”
lead_paragraph: Lighting designers live in the dark, shining light on others. Jennifer Tipton, who works in dance and theater, has received more attention than most in her profession. At the top of it for the last 50 years or so, she has earned Tony Awards, Bessie awards, an Obie for lifetime achievement and a MacArthur fellowship, among other accolades and prizes. Still, she’s spent her career being mostly invisible, intentionally without an identifiable style, always in service to the vision of choreographers, playwrights and directors — often famous ones, like Jerome Robbins, Twyla Tharp, Paul Taylor and Robert Wilson.

headline: Max Martin, Pop’s Low-Key Mastermind, Takes Center Stage (Sort Of)
abstract: The Swedish songwriter and producer behind smashes for Britney Spears, Katy Perry and the Weeknd is reluctantly emerging for “& Juliet,” a new Broadway show built on his music.
lead_paragraph: Once, not long ago, the Swedish songwriter and producer Max Martin met someone who had never heard one of his hits.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: How the jaguar made a comeback. Also in this edition: the new season of “The Crown,” and a review of Bob Dylan’s book.
lead_paragraph: How the jaguar made a comeback. Also in this edition: the new season of “The Crown,” and a review of Bob Dylan’s book.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The midterm elections were the talk of late night this week, including how poorly the evening went for former President Donald Trump. Here's what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: The midterm elections were the talk of late night this week, including how poorly the evening went for former President Donald Trump. Here's what they had to say.

headline: Taking Stock at the World Cup Break
abstract: As leagues prepare to pause for the tournament in Qatar, it’s a chance to reflect on the first half’s surprise stories and surprise leaders, and their potential staying power.
