abstract: Readers respond to a column by Pamela Paul. Also: Pandemic preparedness; regulating media; the need for unions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Are We More Addicted to Shopping Than We Think?
abstract: The first step to recovery is admitting we have a problem.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps I should begin with a confession of sin: I’m more materialistic than I thought. I don’t like to think of myself this way. My heroes all lived simply, if not in outright poverty. St. Francis, St. Clare, Dorothy Day and, well, Jesus himself. My family doesn’t go on fancy vacations. I don’t wear nice jewelry or drive an impressive car. So I sometimes self -righteously assume that I’m immune to greed, materialism and consumerism. But then we moved into a new house.

headline: Zelensky calls the fighting in Donetsk ‘hell,’ a sobering view after the recapture of Kherson.
abstract: Some military analysts said that the recapture of Kherson might enable Ukraine to shift forces as well as artillery east to Donetsk.
lead_paragraph: Russian attacks have turned the eastern Ukrainian region of Donetsk into a “hell,” President Volodymyr Zelensky has said, drawing attention to one of the war’s most entrenched battlegrounds even as the country celebrated the recapture of the southern city of Kherson.

headline: Here’s what we know about the attack.
abstract: The blast tore through a busy pedestrian thoroughfare popular with tourists. It was unclear who carried it out.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — An explosion shook a bustling pedestrian thoroughfare in central Istanbul on Sunday, killing at least six people and wounding dozens, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said.

headline: Deadly Blast Hits Pedestrian Thoroughfare in Istanbul
abstract: Video showing people fleeing after an explosion that killed several people and wounded dozens of others near Taksim Square, one of the city’s busiest areas.
lead_paragraph: Video showing people fleeing after an explosion that killed several people and wounded dozens of others near Taksim Square, one of the city’s busiest areas.

headline: Paul G. Allen and the Art He Didn’t Sell
abstract: “People should be able to see these pictures, and enjoy them, and appreciate them,” the Microsoft co-founder said. Will Allen’s cache of science fiction objects have a different future from the masterpieces auctioned last week?
lead_paragraph: A van Gogh landscape to die for. A sacred scene by Botticelli that puts a lump in your throat. One of Jasper Johns’s stunningly subtle map paintings.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Butternut squash congee, pasta alla Brontese and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Even the best home cooks have Thanksgiving questions. Even the most confident among them, even those who’ve cooked the feast for years. That’s why I commend to all our World of Thanksgiving and, to those new to the game, our updated roundup of Thanksgiving recipes for beginners.

headline: Samuel Folsom, 102, Who Fought the Japanese Above Guadalcanal, Dies
abstract: He went to war at 22 with limited flying experience but dodged Zeros, knocked out bombers and won the Distinguished Flying Cross and a Purple Heart.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Folsom, one of the last surviving Marine fighter pilots of World War II, who engaged in aerial dogfights and shot down two Japanese bombers in the horrific struggle for the strategic island of Guadalcanal at a crucial juncture in the Pacific war, died on Saturday in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 102.

headline: A Tenor’s Met Opera Debut, Long Delayed, Is Worth the Wait
abstract: Benjamin Bernheim’s arrival at the house was put off by the pandemic. Now singing in Verdi’s “Rigoletto,” he’s a natural fit there.
lead_paragraph: It took a few tries for Benjamin Bernheim to make his Metropolitan Opera debut.

headline: Iran and China Use Private Detectives to Spy on Dissidents in America
abstract: The U.S. investigators are hired under false pretenses by authoritarian governments to do their “dirty work,” the F.B.I. says.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Democrats See a Blueprint in Fetterman’s Victory in Pennsylvania
abstract: John Fetterman flipped a key Senate seat in part by attracting white working-class votes, including in the reddest parts of his state.
lead_paragraph: KITTANNING, Pa. — Did John Fetterman just show Democrats how to solve their white-working-class problem?

headline: David Davis, a Force Behind Game-Changing ’70s Sitcoms, Dies at 86
abstract: A writer and producer, he worked with James Brooks and others on “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” and was a creator of “The Bob Newhart Show” and “Taxi.”
lead_paragraph: David Davis, who helped usher in a golden age of television in the 1970s as a writer and producer on the groundbreaking and slyly feminist “Mary Tyler Moore Show,” and as a creator of “The Bob Newhart Show” and “Taxi,” died on Nov. 4 in Los Angeles. He was 86.

headline: Review: The Berlin Philharmonic Gives a Master Class at Carnegie
abstract: Playing on a level rare even at the top of the field, the group came to New York for the first time under its chief conductor, Kirill Petrenko.
lead_paragraph: Listening to the Berlin Philharmonic over three evenings at Carnegie Hall this week, I kept thinking of what the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter once told me. I’d asked her how she rated this orchestra next to the world’s other great ensembles. It was, she answered, like comparing apples and oranges.

headline: Review: A Dance for Our Times Travels to a Dark Place
abstract: The choreographer Serge Aimé Coulibaly explores the fear that permeates society in the North American premiere of “Wakatt” at NYU Skirball.
lead_paragraph: The opening of “Wakatt” casts the stage in a radiant glow as a half sun fills its horizon. Is it setting or rising? Does it matter? The arresting sight offers a glimpse of warmth, a sense of hope.

headline: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez describes fears of violence.
abstract: Lawmakers in Congress have experienced a surge of threats and confrontations in recent years, coinciding with a rise in violent political speech.
lead_paragraph: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez said she has feared for her life since becoming an elected official.

headline: Paul Schrade, 97, Who Was Wounded When Robert Kennedy Was Slain, Dies
abstract: A leader of the United Auto Workers and a Kennedy confidant, he remained convinced that a second gunman had been involved in the assassination.
lead_paragraph: Paul Schrade, a prominent union official who was wounded in the fusillade of bullets that killed Senator Robert F. Kennedy in 1968, and who believed that a second gunman, in addition to the convicted assassin, Sirhan B. Sirhan, fired shots that day at the Ambassador Hotel, died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 97.

headline: Russia’s War Hawks Step Up Criticism of the Military Over Kherson Withdrawal
abstract: Even Vladimir Putin and the Russian government were targets, but there was no evidence that the volume of blame would be a real liability.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s pro-war activists delivered over the weekend their most cutting criticism of the military’s performance in Ukraine to date, following the humiliating withdrawal of Russian troops from the southern Ukrainian city of Kherson. By Sunday, the drumbeat of denunciations broke the taboo against singling out President Vladimir V. Putin himself and Russia’s very system of government.

headline: An Ode to Stacey Abrams
abstract: What she gave to Georgia and the country was so much larger than any one contest, hers included.
lead_paragraph: As the Bible tells the story, Moses delivers his people from bondage and to the “promised land,” but even with all his efforts he is not allowed to enter. He must gaze upon it from a distance.

headline: Deadly Bombing in Istanbul Is Being Investigated as a Terrorist Attack
abstract: The blast killed at least six people, injured 81 others and shattered a yearslong sense of calm in Turkey as its tourism industry tries to recover from the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A bomb attack struck a bustling pedestrian thoroughfare in central Istanbul on Sunday, killing at least six people, in what officials said could be a terrorist attack, and shattering a sense of calm as Turkey’s tourist industry works to recover from the pandemic.

headline: ‘Black Panther: Wakanda Forever’ Ends Box Office Drought
abstract: Turnout was especially strong at large-format IMAX theaters, where domestic ticket sales of $14.2 million set a record for a November opening.
lead_paragraph: “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” took in a superb $180 million at North American cinemas over the weekend, ending one of the worst box office droughts on record and reaffirming Disney-owned Marvel Studios as Hollywood’s reigning blockbuster factory.

headline: Republicans Seek Distance From Trump, and Other News From the Sunday Shows
abstract: “I’ve been saying since 2020 that we have to get back to a party that appeals to more people,” said Larry Hogan, the Republican governor of Maryland and a possible 2024 candidate.
lead_paragraph: Is former President Donald J. Trump the leader of the Republican Party?

headline: Democrats’ Senate Victory Hands Biden a Critical Guardrail Against the G.O.P.
abstract: Even a bare-minimum majority preserves Democrats’ ability to confirm President Biden’s nominees and would allow them to stop Republican legislation in its tracks should the G.O.P. win the House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A day after clinching a narrow hold on the Senate, Democrats began laying plans on Sunday to use their majority as a bulwark for President Biden in Congress should Republicans wrest control of the House, including by confirming his nominees, killing G.O.P. legislation on arrival and promoting their own policies to voters.

headline: T.S.A. Says Screening Missteps Allowed Box Cutters on Flight
abstract: Two box cutters that were brought on a plane by a passenger who later threatened to stab people were not identified during a scan, a Transportation Security Administration spokeswoman said.
lead_paragraph: Mistakes in screening procedures by Transportation Security Administration employees allowed a passenger to bring two box cutters aboard a Frontier Airlines flight from Cincinnati to Tampa, Fla., the agency said on Sunday.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Biden’s Asian Diplomacy
abstract: Xi Jinping and President Biden will meet today, ahead of the G20 summit, and after Biden’s appearance at ASEAN.
lead_paragraph: World leaders are gathering in Indonesia for the G20 summit, which begins tomorrow.

headline: With Outcome Still in Doubt, Congress Opens an Uncertain Post-Election Session
abstract: A stronger-than-expected performance by Democrats that preserved their control of the Senate and left the House up for grabs has reshuffled the congressional agenda for the rest of the year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Midterm election results that defied expectations, leaving Democrats in control of the Senate and the House still up for grabs, have scrambled the agenda in Congress for the remainder of the year, leaving lawmakers toiling to determine how much can be accomplished in a brief year-end session that opens on Monday.

headline: What We Learned From Week 10 in the N.F.L.
abstract: The Vikings proved their mettle once again, Aaron Rodgers struck a partnership with the rookie Christian Watson, and the Colts tinkered their way to an unlikely win.
lead_paragraph: The Vikings and the Bills played to what might have been the N.F.L.’s best finish so far this season, with Minnesota claiming yet another late comeback victory thanks in part to an unreal catch by Justin Jefferson to keep a fourth-quarter drive alive.

headline: Lori Chavez-DeRemer, a Republican, flips an Oregon House seat.
abstract: The seat became a target for Republicans after Jamie McLeod-Skinner defeated a seven-term centrist incumbent in a Democratic primary.
lead_paragraph: Lori Chavez-DeRemer, a Republican, won a U.S. House seat in central Oregon on Sunday, according to The Associated Press, defeating her Democratic opponent, Jamie McLeod-Skinner, and handing her party a crucial victory in its push to win a  majority in the House.

headline: Russia Tried to Absorb a Ukrainian City. It Didn’t Work.
abstract: In Kherson, national songs were banned, speaking Ukrainian could lead to arrest, and students were told they were Russian. Cue the resistance.
lead_paragraph: KHERSON, Ukraine — Iryna Dyagileva’s daughter attended a school where the curriculum included memorizing the Russian national anthem. But teachers ignored it, instead quietly greeting students in the morning with a salute: “Glory to Ukraine!”

headline: You’d Better Believe It!
abstract: Taylor Johnson makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle is by Taylor Johnson, who is making his debut as a constructor for the New York Times Crossword. But Mr. Johnson is no stranger to crossword constructing. In fact, many of the constructors who appear in The Times have constructed puzzles in other places for some time before they show up in the Gray Lady.

headline: An Emboldened Biden Now Faces a Tough Choice About His Own Future
abstract: The president feels buoyant after the better-than-expected midterms. But as he nears his 80th birthday, he confronts a decision on whether to run in 2024 that has some Democrats uncomfortable.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — These are heady days for President Biden. The midterm elections offered long-sought validation. Democrats held onto the Senate, and even if they lose the House it will be by a narrow margin. The Republicans are in retreat and, by the way, so are the Russians and, just a bit at least, so is inflation.

headline: In an ‘Unreal’ Ending, Vikings Come Back Against the Bills
abstract: With help from a one-handed, acrobatic catch from Justin Jefferson and Josh Allen’s late-game miscues, the Vikings came back to beat the Bills in overtime.
lead_paragraph: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — The odds were stacked against the Minnesota Vikings. Down by 4 points to the Buffalo Bills, with two minutes remaining in regulation and pinned deep in their own end of the field, they had no choice but to run a play on fourth-and-18.

headline: FTX’s Collapse Casts a Pall on a Philanthropy Movement
abstract: Sam Bankman-Fried, the chief executive of the embattled cryptocurrency exchange, was a proponent and donor of the “effective altruism” movement.
lead_paragraph: In short order, the extraordinary collapse of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX has vaporized billions of dollars of customer deposits, prompted investigations by law enforcement and destroyed the fortune and reputation of the company’s founder and chief executive, Sam Bankman-Fried.

headline: Trump Wanted I.R.S. Investigations of Foes, Top Aide Says
abstract: John F. Kelly, who was White House chief of staff, said that as president, Donald J. Trump wanted investigations into perceived enemies like James Comey, the former F.B.I. director.
lead_paragraph: While in office, President Donald J. Trump repeatedly told John F. Kelly, his second White House chief of staff, that he wanted a number of his perceived political enemies to be investigated by the Internal Revenue Service, Mr. Kelly said.

headline: Ina Garten’s Store-Bought Thanksgiving
abstract: To make the holiday easier for home cooks, we asked the culinary contessa to create a menu that lets premade ingredients do much of the work.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, “Barefoot Contessa” introduced TV viewers to Ina Garten, framed by stacks of white plates on white open shelves in her kitchen in East Hampton, N.Y. As its title suggested, the show conveyed a down-to-earth ease that felt attainable (even if the Viking stove she sautéed on was not necessarily). Fans could dream about living in that shingle-style home, and then, if they followed her recipes, they could cook just like her.

headline: ‘The Old Man & the Pool’ Review: Wading Into Mike Birbiglia’s Comfort Zone
abstract: The comedian once again proves his virtuosity as a narrator, weaving a new harrowing tale in his latest Broadway show.
lead_paragraph: Mike Birbiglia knows what he’s doing: At this point, his act is baked to golden perfection. Exploring new territories or branching out into unexpected formal terrain is not in the cards for this comedian. His new solo show, “Mike Birbiglia: The Old Man & the Pool,” directed by his regular collaborator Seth Barrish, is built along the same lines as his previous outings.

headline: Mehran Karimi Nasseri, Who Inspired ‘The Terminal,’ Dies in Paris Airport
abstract: He slept on a bench in Charles de Gaulle Airport for 18 years, stuck in limbo as a refugee. His story inspired a Steven Spielberg film with Tom Hanks.
lead_paragraph: Mehran Karimi Nasseri, an Iranian refugee who lived for 18 years in Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris and whose intriguing tale inspired the 2004 Steven Spielberg film “The Terminal,” died on Saturday in that same airport.

headline: Behind Our Reporting on Puberty Blockers
abstract: We scoured the scientific evidence, interviewed doctors around the world and spoke to patients and families. Here's a closer look at what we found.
lead_paragraph: We scoured the scientific evidence, interviewed doctors around the world and spoke to patients and families. Here's a closer look at what we found.

headline: Replacing Legends on the College Basketball Court
abstract: Coaches for the Rutgers women and the Duke and Villanova men are following up on long runs from their Hall of Fame predecessors.
lead_paragraph: Caleb Daniels was out to dinner with his family on a Wednesday night last spring when he received a text message from Joey Flannery, the director of basketball operations for the Villanova men’s program.

headline: The Secret Is Out on How Good the Grizzlies Can Be
abstract: The young Memphis Grizzlies aren’t underdogs anymore, and that’s causing some growing pains. But they are confident — and having fun.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Ja Morant rejected the premise of the question.

headline: Why a Barber’s Chair Will Sit in the Museum of Broadway
abstract: The chair was a spare for the use of Al Hirschfeld, a celebrated theatrical caricaturist.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at an understudy that’s getting a moment in the spotlight — a barber’s chair that was ready if a famous caricaturist needed it. We’ll also look at how foreign governments are using private investigators in this country for what one terrorism expert called “low-cost, low-risk state-sponsored terrorism.”

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Six killed in a deadly bombing in Istanbul.
lead_paragraph: At least six people died in a bomb attack on a bustling pedestrian thoroughfare in central Istanbul yesterday. By Sunday evening, Turkish officials had put the number of people wounded at 81, with two in critical condition.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Walking Dead’ and the Latin Grammy Awards
abstract: The long-running post-apocalyptic series comes to an end. And the Latin Grammy Awards airs on Univision.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 14-20. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Surrounded by Threats, Japan Rethinks Decades of Military Dependency
abstract: As it pushes to significantly increase defense spending and develop more of its own hardware, the country may nudge the balance of power in Asia.
lead_paragraph: Over nearly seven decades, Japan has relied on commitments from the United States, its most important ally, for protection in the event of an enemy attack. Japan hosts the largest contingent of overseas American troops and regularly conducts drills with them. It has purchased more American-made F-35 stealth fighter jets than any other country outside the United States.

headline: Word of the Day: intimation
abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word intimation has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 2 in the book review “When It Comes to Mothers, Fact and Fiction Blur” by Janice Y.K. Lee:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Extreme Candidates and Positions Came Back to Bite in Midterms
abstract: In an election that came down to which party turned off voters the least, it was another bad national showing for the G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: A surprisingly nuanced verdict in the midterm elections has delivered at least one important conclusion about the state of the national mood: In battleground states and swing districts across the country, voters voiced their support for moderation.

headline: TikTok Builds Itself Into an Ads Juggernaut
abstract: The Chinese-owned video app’s ad business is thriving, even as a digital advertising slump hurts Meta, Snap and other rivals.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Tiffany & Company shared a sleek black-and-white video featuring the pop superstar Beyoncé dripping in gems and surrounded by nightclub revelers. The minute-long jewelry ad was posted on Instagram, where it drew 1.6 million views.

headline: They Paused Puberty, but Is There a Cost?
abstract: Puberty blockers can ease transgender youths’ anguish and buy time to weigh options. But concerns are growing about long-term physical effects and other consequences.
lead_paragraph: The medical guidance was direct.

headline: Quotation of the Day: TikTok Ads Rake It In From Rivals
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 14, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “TikTok is eating the world. The only thing that matters in the world of entertainment is time spent. If you have less time spent because TikTok is taking share, that’s negative for your advertising business.”

headline: Yellen Encourages Vaccinations in China as Covid Restrictions Slow Growth
abstract: With China’s strict pandemic policies stalling the economy at home and globally, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said American mRNA vaccines are at the ready.
lead_paragraph: BALI, Indonesia — Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said on Monday that she hopes China is able to roll out a more effective vaccination campaign to combat the coronavirus. Thus far, Beijing has largely contained its spread with strict lockdowns and travel restrictions that have slowed its economy and weighed on global economic growth.

headline: Iran Attacks Opposition Bases in Iraq’s Kurdistan Region
abstract: Two people were killed as security forces launched cross-border strikes at groups they accuse of fueling protests in Iran, which warned of more attacks.
lead_paragraph: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq — Iran launched ballistic missile and drone attacks across the border at Kurdish Iranian opposition bases in Iraq on Monday, killing at least two people and wounding eight others after what an Iranian official said were repeated warnings to Iraq to expel the groups.

headline: Hong Kong Demands Inquiry After Protest Song Is Played Before Rugby Match
abstract: “Glory to Hong Kong,” popular among pro-democracy protesters in 2019, was broadcast instead of the Chinese national anthem.
lead_paragraph: The Hong Kong government on Monday demanded “a full and in-depth investigation” after a song associated with the pro-democracy protests of 2019 was played instead of the Chinese national anthem before a match by the city’s rugby sevens team at a tournament in Incheon, South Korea.

headline: The Benevolents
abstract: Volunteers at a Montreal call center train to be an ear for a lonely society.
lead_paragraph: Volunteers at a Montreal call center train to be an ear for a lonely society.

headline: Brian Eno Reveals the Hidden Purpose of All Art
abstract: “I’m absolutely fascinated by this question, because I think I have an answer, and I don’t think it has ever been well answered.”
lead_paragraph: “I’m absolutely fascinated by this question, because I think I have an answer, and I don’t think it has ever been well answered.”

headline: Even Melania Must Know Trump Blew It
abstract: Of all the places Donald Trump proved toxic, Pennsylvania may be where he did the most impressive damage.
lead_paragraph: Marriage is hard. Even the happiest couples will occasionally bicker, nitpick or wear on each other’s nerves. So consider just how bumpy things could get if someone’s thin-skinned, emotionally erratic, accountability-averse husband started criticizing her for his high-profile screw-ups.

headline: New York Democrats urge Hochul to push out the state party chair.
abstract: A call for new leadership comes after New York Democrats lost four congressional seats that could cost the party control of the House.
lead_paragraph: Less than a week after New York Democrats suffered the loss of four congressional seats that could cost them control of the House, a call for new leadership in the state party is growing.

headline: How Have You Gotten Over Disappointment?
abstract: Tell us about a time when something important didn’t go as planned. How did you respond?
lead_paragraph: Think about a time when you had to do something difficult, stressful or time-consuming, like audition for a play, try out for a team or take an important test. Now, suppose you were told you had to do it all over again because of an accident or a mistake that had nothing to do with you.

headline: Don’t Be Fooled, Trump’s Hold on the G.O.P. Is Stronger Than Ever
abstract: He may have taken a hit in the midterms, but his party has internalized his resentment and shamelessness — and will do anything to preserve its power.
lead_paragraph: Did Donald Trump lose in the midterms? Plenty of people declared that he did, from liberal pundits to the Murdoch newspapers — the latter delivering a double whammy from the front page of The New York Post (“TRUMPTY DUMPTY”) and the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal (“Trump Is the Republican Party’s Biggest Loser”).

headline: If You Want to Understand How Dangerous Elon Musk Is, Look Outside America
abstract: Will his commitment to “free speech’” extend beyond conservatives in the U.S. and to the billions of people in the Global South?
lead_paragraph: With the benefit of ample hindsight, it has come to feel inevitable that Twitter would turn into a cesspool of abuse and misinformation and that the powerful — governments, politicians, corporations, celebrities — would find ways to control and manipulate it to their own benefit.

headline: NASA Is Returning to the Moon This Week. Why Do We Feel Conflicted?
abstract: A retired NASA astronaut, former NASA leader and an astrobiologist discuss.
lead_paragraph: NASA plans this week to return to the moon for the first time since Apollo 17 in 1972. The effort is part of a series of spaceflights under the agency’s Artemis program. After multiple delays, the first Artemis launch — a test flight without crew members — is slated for early Wednesday. (No doubt NASA’s fingers are crossed.)

headline: New York City, Once a Minimum Wage Leader, Now Lags Behind
abstract: As inflation has surged, other cities have vaulted past New York’s $15 minimum wage, considered a trailblazer only a few years ago.
lead_paragraph: When New York City’s minimum wage first reached $15 nearly four years ago, New York was at the forefront of the movement to raise living standards for workers in the fast-food industry and other low-paying sectors. But in recent months, as the costs of rent, groceries and utilities have surged, the minimum wage in a growing list of cities, including Washington, Los Angeles and Denver, has vaulted past.

headline: Do I Really Have to Obey Party Dress Codes?
abstract: A reader does not want to follow the pastel dress code for an upcoming event.
lead_paragraph: The party may actually be the last stronghold of the dress code, a sartorial diktat that is increasingly falling out of favor everywhere, from the workplace, to the school to Congress. As the balance of power shifts away from the institution and toward the individual, the idea of any establishment decreeing what is and is not appropriate dress, when dress is so deeply intertwined with personal identity, seems increasingly old-fashioned.

headline: In a Lonely World, They’re Here to Listen
abstract: Volunteers at a Montreal call center train to be an ear for a lonely society.
lead_paragraph: I remember feeling very alone when I moved to Montreal in 2013. Moving about the city, I also felt the loneliness in the strangers around me. The harm isolation does to our mental well-being is well documented, but in a world full of people, finding someone to emotionally connect with seems like an impossible task.

headline: University Presses Are Keeping American Literature Alive
abstract: As corporate houses get bigger and more commercial, these publishers are doing work that is vital in the marketplace of ideas.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, I went around the house pulling out beloved books published by university presses because I was planning to write an essay about University Press Week, which falls during November every year. My stack of books grew high and calved into two stacks, and then again into three, all heaped in front of the bookcase next to my worktable. I had to nudge them aside every time I reached for another book. It got to where I hardly noticed them, even though they were in plain view all day long.

headline: There Are Republicans Who Feel Low After Election Day. And Then There’s Ron DeSantis.
abstract: The backlash against Trump is only part of the joy.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Gail, remember the old Rolaids ad that asked, “How do you spell ‘relief’?” I think the answer is “m-i-d-t-e-r-m-s.”

headline: Turkey in a T-Shirt, and Other Thanksgiving Gimmicks We’ve Tried
abstract: From brining to bagging to clothing the bird in cotton, every year brings a fresh cooking trick that promises perfection. Here are the oddest and most memorable.
lead_paragraph: America’s relentless drive to innovate has led to the Constitution and the iPhone. But has it produced a better Thanksgiving turkey?

headline: What One Importer’s Legal Fight Says About the Power of Cargo Giants
abstract: The Biden administration has vowed to crack down on abuses by ocean carriers. But cases at the Federal Maritime Commission reveal the challenges of the campaign.
lead_paragraph: Like the rest of the e-commerce world, Jacob Weiss was contending with excruciating difficulties in getting his goods — mostly furniture — across the Pacific from factories in China.

headline: What You Get for $3 Million in California
abstract: A 1940 cottage in Newport Beach, a four-bedroom house in Larkspur and a French country-style estate in Sacramento.
lead_paragraph: A 1940 cottage in Newport Beach, a four-bedroom house in Larkspur and a French country-style estate in Sacramento.

headline: Time Has Run Out for the Leap Second
abstract: To the world’s timekeepers, the leap second is a kludge, a bane, a pain in the little hand. Now they’re ditching it. Will our days ever be the same?
lead_paragraph: Roughly every four years, an extra day gets tacked onto the end of February, a time-keeping convention known as the leap year. The practice of adjusting the calendar with an extra day was established by Julius Caesar more than 2,000 years ago and modified in the 16th century by Pope Gregory XIII, bequeathing us the Julian and Gregorian calendars.

headline: A Pizza Pilgrimage to Campania
abstract: For an Italian tour that messes nicely with tradition, head to Naples, the birthplace of pizza, where some masterful pizzaioli have elevated this humble treasure to tasting-menu status.
lead_paragraph: It began with truffles. White ones, from Alba, shaved over a butter-daubed wedge of dough, then ditto with a heady black variety from Irpinia. Seated in the courtyard of the famed Naples pizzeria Concettina ai Tre Santi, I watched my waiter with wide eyes as my evening pizza marathon commenced with an intoxicating bang.

headline: $3 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1940 cottage in Newport Beach, a four-bedroom house in Larkspur and a French country-style estate in Sacramento.
lead_paragraph: Balboa Island is a community with a small-town feel within the city of Newport Beach. This recently renovated house, which has been in the same family for decades, is a few blocks from Marine Avenue, a thoroughfare with numerous businesses, including an Italian restaurant, beachwear shops and a retro-style candy store. It is less than 10 minutes from the Fashion Island shopping mall and Corona del Mar, a popular shopping and nightlife hub.

headline: Kari Lake’s path to victory narrows in the Arizona governor’s race.
abstract: Katie Hobbs, a Democrat, maintained a slight lead on Ms. Lake after new results were released from Maricopa County on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Latest news: Katie Hobbs wins governor’s race against Kari Lake

headline: The Nation’s ‘Report Card’ on Remote Learning
abstract: America’s national test scores have dropped sharply. What do students need now?
lead_paragraph: On the first nationwide test of American students since the pandemic, scores plummeted to levels not seen in 20 years. The results show how challenging it was to keep students on track during the pandemic.

headline: Here’s a Look at the Midterm Races That Remain Undetermined
abstract: Democrats sealed control of the Senate, but the House is still up for grabs.
lead_paragraph: While control of the Senate has been settled, the House is still up for grabs.

headline: Ukraine’s Advances
abstract: Russia has suffered serious losses recently.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s retreat last week from Kherson, a southern port city that it had seized shortly after invading Ukraine, was one of the biggest setbacks yet to President Vladimir Putin’s war effort. A renewed Ukrainian military offensive has clearly put Russian troops on the run.

headline: Russia’s Foreign Ministry denies a report that Lavrov was hospitalized in Bali.
abstract: Sergei Lavrov is representing Russia at the G20 meeting in place of President Vladimir V. Putin, who decided not to attend.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergei V. Lavrov, on Monday denied that he had been hospitalized following reports that he had experienced a health problem ahead of the high-profile Group of 20 summit of global leaders in Indonesia.

headline: Liberté, Égalité, Millinery?
abstract: Paris 2024 unveils its mascots. And they are hats.
lead_paragraph: The Olympics mascot is typically a creature of some kind. But for the Paris 2024 Summer Games, it will be a hat.

headline: Remaking Rosters for a Changing Game
abstract: A pitch clock, a ban on infield shifts and the enlargement of bases could alter the value of some players, giving executives something new to exploit.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Beginning next season, the way the game is played and looks in Major League Baseball will be noticeably different. In the hopes of injecting more action, shaving time off games and reducing injuries, M.L.B. will, for the time ever, introduce a pitch clock, ban defensive infield shifts and enlarge the bases.

headline: Xaviera Simmons Is Embarrassed for America
abstract: For the interdisciplinary artist, watching the cycle of responses to white supremacist violence — outrage turning into apathy — is an anguish as familiar as heartbreak.
lead_paragraph: Xaviera Simmons is ready to move on. When we met at the Queens Museum two weeks before the opening of her new show, “Crisis Makes a Book Club,” the New York-based interdisciplinary artist, who is known for her landscape photography and staged self-portraits, ruminated on the vexing cycle of social eruption and passivity that defines American attitudes toward white supremacist violence. Surrounded by the buzz of assistants installing her exhibition, Simmons recalled how the social upheaval of 2020 fell into a familiar pattern: The antiracism uprisings and the suffering laid bare by the pandemic led to frenzied institutional acknowledgments of racial inequity followed by total stasis. She compared the feelings these events and their aftermath inspired in her to the overwhelming agony of heartbreak, and she has experienced enough of that to understand that one can’t write new chapters without breaking away from old patterns.

headline: Moderna Says New Covid Booster Strengthens Immune Response Against Subvariants
abstract: A study suggested that the updated booster shot produced higher levels of neutralizing antibodies against the Omicron subvariants BA.4 and BA.5 than the first booster, the company said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new study by Moderna suggests that its updated coronavirus booster strengthens a key component of the immune system’s defense against the Omicron subvariant that accounted for most infections in the United States in recent months.

headline: Biden and Xi Meet Amid Heightened U.S.-China Relations
abstract: This was the first face-to-face meeting between President Biden and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, as top leaders.
lead_paragraph: This was the first face-to-face meeting between President Biden and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, as top leaders.

headline: Who Bears Blame for FTX’s Failure?
abstract: With the collapse of the giant cryptocurrency exchange, investors are asking whether regulators or the venture capitalists who funded FTX, are at fault.
lead_paragraph: Andrew here. Over dinners and text messages this weekend, financiers on Wall Street and Silicon Valley, and policymakers in Washington, debated whether the multibillion-dollar collapse of FTX, the crypto exchange founded by the wunderkind Sam Bankman-Fried, should be compared to the fall of Enron, Lehman Brothers, Bernie Madoff or MF Global.

headline: Watch Live: Biden Speaks After Meeting With Xi
abstract: President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China met before the Group of 20 summit in Indonesia. It was their first face-to-face meeting as top leaders.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China met before the Group of 20 summit in Indonesia. It was their first face-to-face meeting as top leaders.

headline: ‘People are stuck in the libraries’: Students describe a campus that is sheltering in place.
abstract: Students on the University of Virginia campus had been urged to stay inside all night.
lead_paragraph: Eva Surovell, a senior and the editor in chief of The Cavalier Daily, the University of Virginia’s student newspaper, said by phone early Monday that students were sheltering in place across the campus: “People are stuck in the libraries, they’re stuck in academic buildings, they’re stuck in you name it,” she said.

headline: U.K. and France Sign New Deal to Stem Small-Boat Migrant Crossings
abstract: Britain has promised France tens of millions of euros to step up coastal patrols, a sign of thawing relations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain and France signed a new agreement on Monday to stem the growing number of small boats carrying migrants over the busy waterway between them, a sign of thawing relations on an issue that has become a sore point for the embattled British government.

headline: Turkey Accuses U.S. of Complicity in Istanbul Attack That Killed 6
abstract: Turkish police arrested a female suspect and accused her of entering from Syria to carry out the bombing on Kurdish orders. The U.S. is allied with a Kurdish-led militia in Syria.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish authorities arrested a woman on Monday they suspect was behind the deadly bombing in central Istanbul a day earlier, saying she had been sent to Turkey from Syria by Kurdish militants to carry out the attack.

headline: Qatar World Cup Faces New Edict: Hide the Beer
abstract: Before the opening game, tournament organizers are scrambling to balance late changes ordered by powerful Qatari officials with the interests of a major FIFA sponsor, Budweiser.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of Argentina vs. Mexico and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: Jeff Bezos Says He Will Give Away Most of His Fortune
abstract: The Amazon founder, estimated to be worth $124 billion, suggested in an interview on CNN that he would donate most of his money to charity in his lifetime, the first time he had made such a pledge.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, said he would give away most of his money to charity, making him the latest billionaire to pledge to donate his vast fortune during his lifetime.

headline: The C.I.A. director meets with his Russian counterpart to warn against the use of nuclear weapons in Ukraine.
abstract: The National Security Council said William J. Burns’s meeting was not in any way to negotiate or to discuss any settlement of the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: William J. Burns, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, met with his Russian counterpart in Turkey on Monday to warn Russia against the use of nuclear weapons in Ukraine, a White House spokesman said.

headline: Family of Prominent Egyptian Political Prisoner Says It Has Proof He Is Alive
abstract: A note in the handwriting of Alaa Abd El Fattah, who has been on hunger strike for about seven months, read: “I began drinking water, my vitals are good.”
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — After more than a week of silence, uncertainty and escalating controversy, the family of Egypt’s best-known political prisoner said it had received word from him on Monday that he was alive after about seven months on hunger strike and several days of refusing water.

headline: Wordle Wrap-Up: Nov. 7 to 13
abstract: A recap of the Wordle answers for the past week.
lead_paragraph: Hi Wordlers! Welcome to Wordle Wrap-Up, a reminder of which words were answers this week. For stories, stats and brain teasers, sign up for the Gameplay newsletter. For a daily reminder to play Wordle, sign up for reminders.

headline: La Brea Tar Pits Begin an Unusual Rebrand
abstract: The Los Angeles institution is hoping to connect today’s climate disasters with the ice age fossils discovered on its grounds.
lead_paragraph: The La Brea Tar Pits are among Los Angeles’s best-known attractions — and among the least understood. The sprawling, grassy grounds on the Miracle Mile are probably better known for the fake mammoth family than for the institution’s scientific contributions. That’s why the museum’s curators are hoping a long-awaited revamp could breathe life into the landmark.

headline: U.S. and China Restart Climate Talks
abstract: Discussions about combating climate change between the world’s two largest economies, and two biggest emitters of greenhouse gases, had been frozen since August.
lead_paragraph: BALI, Indonesia — President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China agreed on Monday to restart talks between their countries as part of international climate negotiations, a breakthrough in the effort to avert catastrophic global warming.

headline: At the summit, Biden’s advisers provide clues about U.S. strategy on China.
abstract: At any bilateral summit, attention is focused on the two leaders facing off across the negotiating table. But the advisers sitting next to President Biden as he met with Xi Jinping, the Chinese leader, on Monday sent a clear signal about who he listens to.
lead_paragraph: At any bilateral summit, attention is focused on the two leaders facing off across the negotiating table. But the advisers sitting next to President Biden as he met with Xi Jinping, the Chinese leader, on Monday sent a clear signal about who he listens to.

headline: Art Tells New Jersey Stories at Newark’s New Terminal A
abstract: Permanent public artworks by Layqa Nuna Yawar and Karyn Olivier offer airport travelers different views of the Garden State.
lead_paragraph: Move over, La Guardia. Newark Liberty International Airport’s just-completed Terminal A makeover comes with two monumental new works of art.

headline: Lithium-Ion Batteries in E-Bikes and Other Devices Pose Fire Risks
abstract: The batteries, also found in phones, laptops, toothbrushes and other items, have caused about 200 fires and six deaths in New York City this year, fire officials say. Here’s what to know about safety.
lead_paragraph: A lithium-ion battery in an apartment with at least five e-bikes caused a fire in Manhattan this month that injured almost 40 people. The fire, which was one of 188 caused by lithium-ion batteries in New York City this year, led to warnings about risks associated with the batteries and ways to minimize them.

headline: Republicans Appear on Track to Take the House
abstract: Democrats are falling short of their targets in key races in California and Arizona.
lead_paragraph: After a long week counting mail votes out west, a Republican House majority now seems in sight.

headline: Biden Says Meeting With Xi Was ‘Open and Candid’
abstract: President Biden and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, met face to face for a nearly three-hour meeting amid rising tensions between the U.S. and China.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, met face to face for a nearly three-hour meeting amid rising tensions between the U.S. and China.

headline: ‘Shucked’ Is Corny. It’s Country. And It’s Coming to Broadway.
abstract: The musical, with songs by Brandy Clark and Shane McAnally, just finished a pre-Broadway run in Utah, and will begin New York performances in March.
lead_paragraph: “Shucked,” a corn-pone musical with roots in country music and rural humor, will arrive on Broadway early next year after more than a decade of starts and stops.

headline: Marine Drill Instructor Charged in Recruit’s Death
abstract: Pfc. Dalton Beals, 19, died of hyperthermia, or abnormally high body temperature, during the intensive training exercise at Parris Island, S.C., according to an investigative report by the Marines.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Marine Corps has charged a former drill instructor with negligent homicide and other offenses in the death of a recruit during a grueling training exercise last year, a Marines spokesman said.

headline: Amazon Is Said to Plan to Lay Off Thousands of Employees
abstract: The job cuts of approximately 10,000, which would start as soon as this week, would focus on the company’s devices organization, retail division and human resources.
lead_paragraph: Amazon plans to lay off approximately 10,000 people in corporate and technology jobs starting as soon as this week, people with knowledge of the matter said, in what would be the largest job cuts in the company’s history.

headline: Republicans appear on track to take a majority in the House.
abstract: After a long week counting mail votes out west, a Republican House majority now seems in sight.
lead_paragraph: After a long week counting mail votes out west, a Republican House majority now seems in sight.

headline: How to Make Thanksgiving Vegetarian
abstract: As Thanksgiving Day draws ever closer, cooks all over the United States are dusting off old recipe cards for family favorites, like Grandma Judy’s pumpkin bread and Aunt Rhoda’s deviled eggs. Cooking heirloom dishes brings the past, and lost loved ones, right back to the table. My dad may not be with us, feeding me scraps of skin as he carves the turkey, but his anadama bread is a molasses-tinged memento that is as tasty as it is sentimental.
lead_paragraph: As Thanksgiving Day draws ever closer, cooks all over the United States are dusting off old recipe cards for family favorites, like Grandma Judy’s pumpkin bread and Aunt Rhoda’s deviled eggs. Cooking heirloom dishes brings the past, and lost loved ones, right back to the table. My dad may not be with us, feeding me scraps of skin as he carves the turkey, but his anadama bread is a molasses-tinged memento that is as tasty as it is sentimental.

headline: Winning Signs From the New York City Marathon
abstract: An artist takes in the sights and signs at the city’s annual race.

headline: While Other Insects Played, This Species Evolved the Blade
abstract: Scientists are studying a fruit fly’s sharp organ that helps it lay eggs and eat, hoping to unlock the secrets of herbivorous insects.
lead_paragraph: They are fruit flies, but they eat leaves. And to feed themselves, the females scrape and scoop vegetation with — this is what researchers actually sometimes call them — vaginal teeth. Then they turn their mouths to the plant juices they’ve liberated, and lap them up.

headline: ‘Dogfooding’
abstract: /dôgfo͝odĭng/
lead_paragraph: Software engineers are hungry for excellence. Dogs are hungry for dog food. And software engineers at many companies are hungry to “dogfood.”

headline: University of California Academic Employees Strike for Higher Pay
abstract: In one of the nation’s biggest strikes in recent years, teaching assistants, researchers and other workers walked off the job Monday, forcing some classes to be canceled.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Tens of thousands of academic workers across the University of California system walked out on Monday in one of the nation’s largest strikes in recent years, as teaching assistants, researchers and other university employees called for significant pay increases in the face of rising housing costs.

headline: Google Agrees to $392 Million Privacy Settlement With 40 States
abstract: Under the agreement, which state attorneys general said was the largest U.S. internet privacy settlement, Google must also make its location-tracking practices clearer to users.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Google agreed to a record $391.5 million privacy settlement with a 40-state coalition of attorneys general on Monday for charges that it misled users into thinking they had turned off location tracking in their account settings even as the company continued collecting that information.

headline: Dan McCafferty, Nazareth Frontman Who Sang ‘Love Hurts,’ Dies at 76
abstract: His Scottish band became known for hard-driving stadium rock, but its biggest hit was a cover of a country ballad about heartbreak.
lead_paragraph: Dan McCafferty, who as the frontman of the Scottish rock band Nazareth scored an international hit in the mid-1970s with the ballad “Love Hurts,” died on Tuesday. He was 76.

headline: A Hard Cider That Takes Its Cues From Sake
abstract: Try Oishii Cider, made in collaboration with Brooklyn Kura; check out a new market from Pilar Cuban Eatery in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn; and more.
lead_paragraph: Wölffer Estate Vineyard has a deep portfolio of ciders, but its latest one, Oishii Cider, stands apart. It’s crystal clear, and the first whiff and taste reveal a subtle slice of apple. Made in collaboration with the local sake maker Brooklyn Kura, Oishii Cider is slowly cold-fermented with sake yeast, giving it a sake-style profile at 13 percent alcohol without surrendering the apples. (Oishii means delicious in Japanese, but the apple variety Delicious is not used for the cider.) Chilled, it’s a fine aperitif with a whisper of sweetness and pairs beautifully with Brie-style cheeses.

headline: As the Pandemic Drags On, Americans Struggle for New Balance
abstract: As offices, restaurants and schools fill up, people are adjusting expectations and habits in another moment of deep uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: Jordi Salomon put the pandemic in the rearview mirror long ago. Her two little boys are back at school, where there has been no mask requirement since the spring. They attend birthday parties and theme parks, visit the library and play with friends.

headline: Documents Detail Foreign Government Spending at Trump Hotel
abstract: Six nations spent lavishly at the hotel during periods when they were seeking to influence the Trump administration, according to a breakdown released by the House Oversight Committee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Officials from six nations spent more than $750,000 at former President Donald J. Trump’s hotel in Washington when they were seeking to influence his administration, renting rooms for more than $10,000 per night, according to documents that his former accounting firm turned over to Congress.

headline: Lawyers for Rikers Detainees Will Ask Judge to Impose Federal Control
abstract: As conditions deteriorate, lawyers say it’s time for last-resort oversight of Rikers Island. This year, 18 people have died after having been held in New York City jails.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for people detained on Rikers Island intend to ask a federal judge to take control of the jail complex away from New York City, according to a letter filed with the court on Monday, setting the stage for a potentially pivotal hearing this week.

headline: Who Will Win the Race to Generate Electricity From Ocean Tides?
abstract: The Bay of Fundy, between Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, has one of the world’s most powerful tides. Now, engineers and scientists hope to finally turn it into a clean energy source.
lead_paragraph: ABOARD THE PLAT-I 6.40 GENERATING PLATFORM, Nova Scotia — The Bay of Fundy, off the Canadian provinces of Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, has long tantalized and frustrated engineers hoping to harness its record-setting 50-foot high tide to generate electricity.

headline: Justice Department and Trump Lawyers Clash Over Status of Seized Documents
abstract: A pair of unsealed briefs argue over the ex-president’s power to claim White House materials as his property and invoke executive privilege.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has urged a special master to broadly reject assertions by former President Donald J. Trump that he owns a range of documents the F.B.I. seized from his Florida residence and that he can invoke executive privilege to bar criminal investigators from looking at some of them.

headline: Supreme Court Allows Subpoena for Arizona Republican’s Phone Records
abstract: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol sought the records of Kelli Ward, the chairwoman of the Arizona Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court paved the way on Monday for the House committee investigating the Capitol attack to obtain phone records of Kelli Ward, the chairwoman of the Arizona Republican Party.

headline: We Want to Hear About Your Most Important Friendships
abstract: Platonic relationships are unsung — and essential. The Times wants to hear about the meaningful friendships in your life and how you’ve maintained them.
lead_paragraph: We’re living through a somewhat perilous moment for friendship in America. Social circles were shrinking even before the Covid pandemic hit — a trend that only accelerated as it dragged on. In 2021, 13 percent of women and 8 percent of men ages 30 to 49 said they’d lost touch with most of their friends. And friendship experts argue that we have a collective tendency to view platonic love as somehow less important or valuable than romantic love.

headline: Loyal to God and Trump, Mike Pence Defends His Record
abstract: In “So Help Me God,” the former vice president looks back on his career with one eye on where it might be headed.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Pence Says Trump Was ‘Reckless’ in Assailing Him on Jan. 6
abstract: In an interview with ABC, the former vice president said he was angered that President Donald J. Trump’s tweet during the Capitol attack had endangered him and his family.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence told ABC News that he was “angered” by former President Donald J. Trump’s “reckless” tweet assailing him during the Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, in his first interview about the violent efforts by Mr. Trump’s supporters to keep him in power.

headline: Drake and 21 Savage Bump Taylor Swift From the Top
abstract: The rappers’ collaborative album, “Her Loss,” opens at No. 1 with the equivalent of 404,000 sales in the United States. Swift’s “Midnights” moves to No. 2 after two huge weeks.
lead_paragraph: When Drake released his last album, “Honestly, Nevermind,” in June, it opened at No. 1 but had disappointing numbers for one of streaming’s megastars. One bright spot: Its standout track, “Jimmy Cooks,” featuring the Atlanta-based rapper 21 Savage, went to No. 1 on Billboard’s Hot 100 singles chart.

headline: Stymied by Protests, Iran Unleashes Its Wrath on Its Youth
abstract: Hundreds of minors have been detained for joining the demonstrations, and many others have died in the crackdown, according to Iranian lawyers and rights activists.
lead_paragraph: One girl, a 14-year-old, was incarcerated in an adult prison alongside drug offenders. A 16-year-old boy had his nose broken in detention after a beating by security officers. A 13-year-old girl was physically attacked by plainclothes militia who raided her school.

headline: Brazil, Indonesia and Congo Sign Rainforest Protection Pact
abstract: The three countries, home to more than half of the world’s tropical rainforests, have agreed to negotiate a “funding mechanism” for conservation.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — The three countries that are home to more than half of the world’s tropical rainforests — Brazil, Indonesia and the Democratic Republic of Congo — are pledging to work together to establish a “funding mechanism” that could help preserve the forests, which  help regulate the Earth’s climate and sustain a variety of animals, plants, birds and insects.

headline: Philadelphia’s Joel Embiid Makes N.B.A. History
abstract: Who has scored 59 points with 11 rebounds, 8 assists and 7 blocks in a game? Before Sunday night, no one.
lead_paragraph: As the Philadelphia 76ers stuttered to a hit-and-miss start, there was a sense that their star center, Joel Embiid, needed to break through.

headline: After Nevada: The New Political Landscape
abstract: Readers discuss reducing Joe Manchin’s leverage and the Georgia runoff. Also: Abuses in Iran; leaving the Catholic Church; a tale of New York City.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Blinken to Visit China in Early 2023 After Biden and Xi’s Meeting
abstract: The trip is aimed at keeping the lines of communication open and having frank exchanges about important issues at senior levels in order to avoid conflict.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, plans to visit China early next year to follow up on the meeting between President Biden and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, in Bali, Indonesia, a State Department official in Washington said on Monday.

headline: What We Know About Naomi Biden’s White House Wedding
abstract: Invitations are in hand, but the administration is taking a state-secret approach to most of the details, citing the privacy of the president’s granddaughter and her fiancé, Peter Neal.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: Dick Gregory, a Humorist With Many Passions and a Singular Gift
abstract: A new anthology collects some of the writings, interviews and speeches of the comic and civil rights activist.
lead_paragraph: By the time I was old enough to know who Dick Gregory was, in the early 1980s, he was on the downslope of his career. He’d left stand-up comedy, where he’d been a pioneer. His work during the civil rights era — he marched in Selma, and had been close to Medgar Evers and Martin Luther King Jr. — was behind him too.

headline: Historic Deauville Hotel Demolished in Miami Beach
abstract: The 17-story hotel, built in 1957, was imploded after the property fell into disrepair over the years. The Miami Beach hotel once hosted the Beatles and President John F. Kennedy.
lead_paragraph: The 17-story hotel, built in 1957, was imploded after the property fell into disrepair over the years. The Miami Beach hotel once hosted the Beatles and President John F. Kennedy.

headline: German Government Nationalizes Gas Unit Seized From Gazprom
abstract: The former Gazprom Germania, a subsidiary of the Russian state-owned gas monopoly, is deemed essential to Germany’s energy security.
lead_paragraph: The German government said on Monday that it would nationalize a former subsidiary of Gazprom, Russia’s state-owned natural gas monopoly, to maintain the country’s energy security.

headline: F.B.I. Had Informants in Proud Boys, Court Papers Suggest
abstract: In filings in the seditious conspiracy case against members of the far-right group, defense lawyers claimed that information favorable to their clients was improperly withheld by the government until recently.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. had as many as eight informants inside the far-right Proud Boys in the months surrounding the storming of the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, recent court papers indicate, raising questions about how much federal investigators were able to learn from them about the violent mob attack both before and after it took place.

headline: Students and Teachers: How Is the School Year Going for You?
abstract: Tell us about it.
lead_paragraph: This school year, students and teachers returned to campus in a more normal setting. While Covid remains a concern, it may no longer be the main issue that educators and parents are worried about.

headline: Rauw Alejandro’s Cosmic Reggaeton Takes Flight
abstract: On his third album, “Saturno,” the Puerto Rican musician further reimagines the genre, drawing on the worlds of Miami bass, late ’90s underground and freestyle music.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Puerto Rico, Rauw Alejandro often hid the mix CDs his uncle gave him, which usually included explicit lyrics, from his father. They featured puckish pop-punk bands like Blink-182, but also the precocious stars of underground, a synthesis of hip-hop and dancehall that predated reggaeton.

headline: Elon Musk Faces His Waterloo
abstract: His hard-charging style may not be so great for Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Autocratic chief executives are dazzling. Unconstrained by the bonds that hold back ordinary executives, they soar to higher highs and crash to lower lows. Today’s case study in dazzlement: Elon Musk, the world’s wealthiest person, who soared with Tesla and is crashing with Twitter.

headline: The Big Lie Is Going Global. We Saw It in Brazil.
abstract: Steve Bannon and others in the Stop the Steal campaign encouraged Jair Bolsonaro to disrespect the electoral process in Brazil after he lost the presidency.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — What happens in Washington doesn’t always stay in Washington. Donald Trump’s playbook of poisoning the polity with misinformation for years and seeking to discredit electoral results and peaceful transitions of power is being exported and deployed beyond the United States and becoming a transnational threat to democracy.

headline: Three Virginia football players were killed in the shooting.
abstract: The three students who were killed — Devin Chandler, Lavel Davis Jr. and D’Sean Perry — were current players on the team.
lead_paragraph: The suspect and at least three of the victims in the shooting at the University of Virginia on Sunday night had links to the university’s football team.

headline: Twitter Users, Sensing the End of an Era, Confess Their Secrets
abstract: Users disclosed long-ago indiscretions, made pleas for money and revealed silly quirks as they feared the social platform’s days might be numbered.
lead_paragraph: In the chaos that followed Elon Musk’s takeover of Twitter, one user, thinking the platform might not be around much longer, revealed a secret from her college days. Another made a last-minute plea to crowdfund her medical bills. Another admitted she bit into whole Kit Kat bars without breaking them apart first.

headline: Republicans Pushing to Move Past Trump Face One Big Obstacle: His Voters
abstract: A solid and devoted core of supporters appears ready to follow Donald Trump wherever he leads again — even if into defeat.
lead_paragraph: Trump rallies aren’t where you expect to hear hard-nosed analysis of Donald J. Trump’s chances of winning back the White House. But Chuck Smith, an ardent supporter who recently drove two hours to stand under the scorching Arizona sun to cheer Mr. Trump, was blunt.

headline: With Tensions Mounting, Biden and Xi Try a Warmer Tone
abstract: The American and Chinese leaders invoked years of personal contact as they met before the G20, seeking to pull back from outright conflict on a host of issues.
lead_paragraph: BALI, Indonesia — After months of deepening contention between the United States and China, President Biden and President Xi Jinping met in person for the first time as national leaders on Monday with a tone of mutual engagement that acknowledged that both their countries faced challenges from global conflict and economic headwinds.

headline: How Cortez Masto Beat the Odds and Sealed the Senate Majority
abstract: The most endangered Senate Democrat portrayed her Republican opponent as an election-denying extremist, defying national headwinds in a race that stayed tight until the end.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, it appeared that historical precedent and stiff political headwinds could doom Senator Catherine Cortez Masto’s re-election bid in Nevada, with voters in her state facing some of the highest gas prices in the country and a national landscape seemingly stacked against the Democratic Party.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Biden and Xi Discuss Taiwan
abstract: Plus Japan seeks to boost its own military and TikTok surges forward with ad revenue.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Xi Jinping, China’s leader, met for nearly three hours yesterday.

headline: Appeals Court Blocks Biden’s Student Debt Cancellation Plan
abstract: The decision comes days after the government temporarily stopped accepting applications for the debt relief because of legal challenges.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Monday issued an injunction halting President Biden’s student debt cancellation plan, further clouding the future of the president’s promise to eliminate hundreds of billions of dollars in debt for tens of millions of people.

headline: McCarthy Scrounges for Support to Become Speaker as Republicans Feud
abstract: After a historically bad midterm election for the G.O.P., the top House Republican tried to navigate infighting in his demoralized party.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Kevin McCarthy of California, the minority leader, scrounged on Monday for the support he would need to become speaker if Republicans gain control of the House, facing resistance from a newly emboldened right flank as his party grappled with its historically weak performance in the midterm elections.

headline: Giuliani Will Not Face Federal Charges Over Lobbying, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Prosecutors had seized Rudolph Giuliani’s electronic devices but did not uncover sufficient evidence to charge him with a crime.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan said on Monday that they would not bring charges against Rudolph W. Giuliani in a long-running investigation into whether he violated lobbying laws.

headline: 4 University of Idaho Students Killed in ‘Crime of Passion’
abstract: The authorities were still piecing together what had transpired at a home near the University of Idaho campus.
lead_paragraph: [Follow the latest news in the deaths of four University of Idaho students.]

headline: How Sam Bankman-Fried’s Crypto Empire Collapsed
abstract: Mr. Bankman-Fried said in an interview that he had expanded too fast and failed to see warning signs. But he shared few details about his handling of FTX customers’ funds.
lead_paragraph: In less than a week, the cryptocurrency billionaire Sam Bankman-Fried went from industry leader to industry villain, lost most of his fortune, saw his $32 billion company plunge into bankruptcy and became the target of investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department.

headline: When Does Science Go Too Far?
abstract: Matthew Cobb’s “As Gods” questions the ethical — and financial — implications of genetic engineering.
lead_paragraph: It was late in 1972 — a year in which the science of genetic engineering really began to sizzle — that two California researchers announced the unusually tidy transfer of genetic information from one bacterium to another with help from a specialized enzyme. It was a scientifically heralded result, but behind the hoopla was just one small catch. The information transferred enabled a common human disease bacterium, E. coli, to resist not just one antibiotic, but two.

headline: Jay Leno Sustains ‘Serious Burns’ in Gasoline Fire
abstract: The comedian and former “Tonight Show” host said in a statement that he was “ok” and needed “a week or two to get back on my feet.”
lead_paragraph: The comedian and television host Jay Leno, known for his expansive collection of cars, sustained burns in a gasoline fire but was expecting to recover, he said on Monday.

headline: Georgia’s Senate Runoff Is Complicated by 2021 Voting Law
abstract: A holiday that once commemorated Robert E. Lee’s birthday is cited as a reason for barring early voting two Saturdays before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A state holiday that once honored the Confederate general Robert E. Lee could take away a day of early voting in some Georgia counties in the Senate runoff between Senator Raphael Warnock and Herschel Walker.

headline: U.S.-Russia Talks
abstract: The C.I.A. director met with his Russian counterpart at a pivotal moment in the war.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: C.I.A. Director Warns Russian Counterpart Against Using Nuclear Weapons
abstract: William Burns’s talks with Russia’s foreign intelligence chief are the most senior in-person meetings since the start of the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The head of the Central Intelligence Agency warned his Russian counterpart against using nuclear weapons in a face-to-face meeting on Monday in Turkey, White House officials announced, part of the Biden administration’s effort to reduce the threat of escalation in the war in Ukraine.

headline: U.S. Investigating Killing of Al Jazeera Journalist in West Bank, Israel Says
abstract: The Justice Department inquiry is a shift by the Biden administration, which had said that Shireen Abu Akleh was probably killed accidentally, by gunfire from the position of Israeli soldiers.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The U.S. Department of Justice has opened an investigation into the killing of Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian American journalist, in the occupied West Bank, the Israeli Defense Ministry announced on Monday night.

headline: Boston Globe Names NPR’s Nancy Barnes Its Next Editor
abstract: Ms. Barnes, senior vice president for news and editorial director at NPR, has also held leadership roles at the Houston Chronicle and Minneapolis Star Tribune.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Barnes, a top news executive at NPR, will lead The Boston Globe, the newspaper announced on Monday.

headline: U.S. Fines Airlines More Than $7 Million for Not Providing Refunds
abstract: The Transportation Department penalties come after many travelers have expressed frustration about flight delays, cancellations and other problems.
lead_paragraph: The Transportation Department said on Monday that it had fined a half-dozen airlines a total of more than $7 million for failing to provide timely refunds to customers. The department’s intervention contributed to the airlines’ issuing more than $600 million in refunds, it said.

headline: An American Paralympian Says He Was Sexually Abused by a Teammate
abstract: Parker Egbert, 19, said in a lawsuit that he was repeatedly assaulted by a fellow swimmer at the Tokyo Paralympics and a training center in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: An American Paralympic swimmer accused a teammate of sexually abusing him while training and competing for the national team, according to a lawsuit filed in federal court in Colorado, bringing new scrutiny to both the U.S. Olympic & Paralympic Committee and the U.S. Center for SafeSport, a nonprofit organization created to address allegations of sexual abuse of athletes in Olympic sports.

headline: Claims of Voter Fraud Build, but Not to Same Degree as in 2020
abstract: False narratives failed to take root on Election Day. But several Republican candidates pointed to election fraud as their prospects worsened.
lead_paragraph: It took a few days for people who have spent the past two years questioning the integrity of elections to find their voice.

headline: How Democrats Quietly Meddled in G.O.P. Senate Recruitment
abstract: As they worked to hold the chamber, Democratic strategists used subtle maneuvers to try to discourage strong potential Republican candidates from running.
lead_paragraph: They called it the “Summer of Chaos.”

headline: Trump Is Weak, but the G.O.P. Is Weaker
abstract: Republicans are paying the price for years of cowardice.
lead_paragraph: After their party’s disappointing performance in the midterms, Republican elites seem to have decided that Donald Trump is their big problem. The Murdoch media empire has been trashing the former president. Many donors and operatives are reportedly rallying around Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida. But Trump, who is widely expected to announce his 2024 presidential campaign on Tuesday, won’t go quietly.

headline: Some of the House Races That Remain Undecided and by How Much
abstract: The contests have little in common, other than the fact that they are either very close or in districts that have been slow to count ballots.
lead_paragraph: Control of the House of Representatives will be decided in the coming days or maybe weeks — sorry — by the outcomes of around 15 races. More than half of them are in California, and the rest are in a smattering of other states.

headline: Accounts of Torture Emerge From Kherson, Ukraine’s ‘City of Fear’
abstract: Just days after the southern city of Kherson was liberated after eight months of Russian occupation, accounts of beatings, torture and disappearances are emerging.
lead_paragraph: KHERSON, Ukraine — Olena Naumova’s descent into two weeks of terror began in late August, when three Russian soldiers with automatic rifles banged on her door in the occupied city of Kherson. She said they ordered her to turn over her gun. She had no gun.

headline: Miami Beach Hotel That Hosted the Beatles Is Demolished
abstract: Mayor Dan Gelber said that the city had waged a “long and tortured court battle” with the owners of the Deauville Beach Resort, which shut down after a fire in 2017.
lead_paragraph: In its heyday, the Deauville Beach Resort, a Miami Beach hotel, was a sleek emblem of South Florida cool, hosting the Beatles, Frank Sinatra and John F. Kennedy, not to mention innumerable weddings, proms and poolside parties.

headline: Jan. 6 Committee Weighs Further Actions as Trump Refuses to Testify
abstract: The panel has at times acted aggressively to enforce its subpoenas, but it has not decided whether to hold Donald Trump in contempt. The committee is set to dissolve at the end of this Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol said on Monday that a contempt of Congress referral against former President Donald J. Trump “could be an option” after Mr. Trump failed to appear for a scheduled deposition.

headline: Jennifer Siebel Newsom Testifies in Weinstein Sex Crimes Trial
abstract: Ms. Siebel Newsom, a documentary filmmaker and the wife of the California governor, told jurors that Harvey Weinstein had sexually assaulted her in 2005.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jennifer Siebel Newsom, a documentary filmmaker and the wife of the California governor, Gavin Newsom, began testifying on Monday that Harvey Weinstein had sexually assaulted her when she was an actor starting out in the industry.

headline: Gunman Charged With Killing Three Fellow Students at the University of Virginia
abstract: The victims, all members of the football team, were remembered by classmates, coaches and teachers as affable students and dedicated activists.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — A 22-year-old student at the University of Virginia was charged with fatally shooting three members of the university’s football team and wounding two others as they returned from a class field trip on Sunday night, an attack that led to an overnight campuswide lockdown while the authorities searched for the gunman for roughly 12 hours.

headline: Julio Rodríguez and Michael Harris II Are M.L.B.’s Top Rookies
abstract: Seattle’s Rodríguez and Atlanta’s Harris, who emerged as star center fielders, won M.L.B.’s Rookie of the Year Awards.
lead_paragraph: One made his team’s opening day roster. The other was not in the major leagues until late May. But once October came around, Julio Rodríguez of the Seattle Mariners and Michael Harris II of the Atlanta Braves were not only the starting center fielders for their playoff teams, but both also had signed contract extensions that promised to keep them in place into the 2030s.

headline: Four Stark Lessons From a Democratic Upset
abstract: What we can learn from Marie Gluesenkamp Perez’s victory.
lead_paragraph: When I reached Marie Gluesenkamp Perez on Monday morning, the Democratic representative-elect from Washington State was sitting on the steps of the U.S. Capitol.

headline: Japan’s Economy Shrinks Unexpectedly, Hit by a Weak Yen and Rising Inflation
abstract: The economy contracted 1.2 percent as consumers and businesses were hit with rising import prices.
lead_paragraph: Japan’s economy, the world’s third largest, unexpectedly shrank in the three-month period from July to September, as a weak yen and high inflation eroded Japanese consumers’ buying power and sapped businesses’ strength.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 15, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 15, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about assertions by John F. Kelly, President Donald J. Trump’s second White House chief of staff, that Mr. Trump repeatedly sought investigations of his perceived political enemies by the Internal Revenue Service, misspelled the surname of the former head of the Special Operations Command. He is William H. McRaven, not McCraven.

headline: Katie Hobbs, Who Defied Trump in Arizona, Tops Kari Lake for Governor
abstract: Ms. Hobbs, Arizona’s secretary of state, narrowly defeated Ms. Lake, a former newscaster whose campaign was built on lies about the 2020 election.
