lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Katie Hobbs, who as Arizona’s secretary of state stood up to efforts by allies of former President Donald J. Trump to overturn the 2020 election, has clinched a victory in the state’s race for governor, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Trump Family Signs Deal With Saudi Real Estate Developer
abstract: The Trump Organization will license its name for a planned golf course in Oman, renewing questions about the former president’s mixing of politics and business as he appears poised for another run.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump family has struck a deal with a Saudi-based real estate company to license its name to a housing and golf complex that will be built in Oman, renewing a swirl of questions about former President Donald J. Trump’s mixing of politics and business just as he appears poised to announce a third presidential candidacy.

headline: Ex-Detective in Kansas Helped Men Run Sex Trafficking Operation, U.S. Says
abstract: Women and girls, who were as young as 13, experienced violence, abuse, rape and death threats from 1996 to 1998, according to a federal indictment.
lead_paragraph: A former police detective in Kansas who was charged in September with sexually assaulting two women while on duty more than two decades ago now faces new federal charges that he helped three other men run a violent sex trafficking operation that preyed on underage girls in the 1990s, the Justice Department said on Monday.

headline: Turn to Others for Assistance
abstract: If you get stuck on Sandy Ganzell’s puzzle, consider asking a nearby preschooler for help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Happy Tuesday, solvers! Today we have a puzzle from the constructor Sandy Ganzell that features a densely packed theme that’s sure to please solvers of all (and I mean ALL) ages. I’ll say more about that theme in a bit, but first, let’s take a look at some of the tougher clues in today’s puzzle.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Residents of Kherson Describe Torture and Abuse
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 15, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “I lived under the Soviet Union, and I never want to go back to the Soviet Union.”

headline: Hun Sen of Cambodia Cuts G20 Trip Short After Testing Positive for Coronavirus
abstract: The prime minister has met with more than a dozen world leaders in recent days, including President Biden, who tested negative on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: BALI, Indonesia — Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia said on Tuesday that he had tested positive for the coronavirus and that his delegation would cut short its trip to Bali for the Group of 20 summit.

headline: What Riding in a Self-Driving Tesla Tells Us About the Future of Autonomy
abstract: We took a ride with Tesla’s experimental self-driving system. It was by turns intriguing, impressive and scary.
lead_paragraph: We took a ride with Tesla’s experimental self-driving system. It was by turns intriguing, impressive and scary.

headline: Michelle Steel holds her G.O.P. House seat in California.
abstract: Representative Michelle Steel won election to a second term, defeating Jay Chen, a Democrat, after she decided to run in a new district in Orange County.
lead_paragraph: Representative Michelle Steel, Republican of California, has won election to a second term in Orange County, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Leaders at the G20 summit urge an end to the Russia-Ukraine war.
abstract: World leaders gathering in Indonesia said their nations faced challenges from conflict and economic headwinds.
lead_paragraph: BALI, Indonesia — The annual Group of 20 summit began on Tuesday under the shadow of the war in Ukraine and concerns about a possible global recession, as leaders of some of the world’s wealthiest nations and biggest emerging markets pushed for a coordinated response to the threats.

headline: Roberta Flack Has A.L.S. and Can No Longer Sing, Her Publicist Says
abstract: The highly decorated vocalist, known for hits like “Killing Me Softly With His Song,” was diagnosed with the disease in August.
lead_paragraph: Roberta Flack, the highly decorated vocalist whose smash hits like “Killing Me Softly With His Song” made her among the most recognizable voices of the 1970s, has been diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and can no longer sing, according to a statement released by her publicist on Monday.

headline: For Western Weapons, the Ukraine War Is a Beta Test
abstract: Though the battle for Ukraine remains largely a grinding artillery war, new advances in technology and training there are being closely monitored for the ways they are starting to shape combat.
lead_paragraph: Three months ago, as Ukrainian troops were struggling to advance against Russian forces in the south, the military’s headquarters in Kyiv quietly deployed a valuable new weapon to the battlefield.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Dozens of young people have died in a lethal crackdown by the authorities in Iran.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of minors in Iran have been beaten and detained for joining the protests calling for social freedom and political change that have convulsed the country for the past two months, and at least 50 have died in the crackdown, according to Iranian lawyers and rights activists. Iranian officials have said the average age of protesters is 15.

headline: The City Charter Has a New Preamble to Promote Equity
abstract: A ballot measure that New Yorkers approved on Election Day allowed for the preamble, which is 11 times longer than the one to the U.S. Constitution.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Today we’ll look at ballot measures that passed last week that call for the city to “reconstruct, revise and reimagine” institutions and laws to promote justice and equity. We’ll also look at why some Democrats say the state party chairman should resign.

headline: What is the G20?
abstract: The Group of 20 nations aims to unite world leaders around shared challenges. Here is a look at what it is and what it does.
lead_paragraph: Established in 1999 after a series of major international debt crises, the Group of 20 aims to unite world leaders around shared economic, political and health challenges. Here is a look at what the group is and does.

headline: These 17 Swing Voters Have a Very Clear Message for Donald Trump
abstract: Seventeen swing voters discuss how they voted in this year’s midterm elections and Donald Trump’s plans for 2024.
lead_paragraph: Seventeen swing voters discuss how they voted in this year’s midterm elections and Donald Trump’s plans for 2024.

headline: After the Biden-Xi meeting, Beijing signals optimism over relations with Washington.
abstract: An upbeat photo in China’s main newspaper and comments by the foreign minister suggested that Beijing believes its relationship with Washington could improve.
lead_paragraph: The prominent position of the photo on the front page of China’s main official newspaper spoke volumes: In it, the nation’s leader, Xi Jinping, smiled and shook hands with President Biden against a backdrop of Chinese and American flags.

headline: Late Night Celebrates Tiffany Trump’s Wedding
abstract: Donald Trump “gave away a daughter and the Senate on the same night,” Jimmy Kimmel joked.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: formidable
abstract: This word has appeared in 503 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word formidable has appeared in 503 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 8 in the album review “‘Her Loss’ Is Playtime for Drake and 21 Savage” by Jon Caramanica:

headline: John Aniston, Veteran Television Actor, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Aniston, the father of the actor Jennifer Aniston, played a suave villain on the soap opera “Days of Our Lives” for more than three decades.
lead_paragraph: John Aniston, a veteran television actor who was born in Greece and played a memorable Greek villain for more than three decades on “Days of Our Lives,” died on Friday. He was 89.

headline: NASA Will Try to Launch Moon Rocket After 2 Scrubs and 2 Hurricanes
abstract: Sending the Artemis I mission to space has so far eluded the agency, but it’s set to try again in the early hours of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER — Last Thursday, NASA’s giant new multibillion-dollar rocket was standing on the launchpad in the middle of Hurricane Nicole.

headline: Underwater Dining
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: When Breaking News Is a Tweet Away
abstract: Ryan Mac, a New York Times technology reporter, discussed the flurry of recent news surrounding Twitter’s new owner, Elon Musk, and the “gold mine” of sources the platform offers.
lead_paragraph: In the days since Elon Musk took control of Twitter, roughly half of its employees have been laid off. The company also introduced a revamped subscription model, amid repeated changes in direction. But the social media platform “has been a saga for years, even before Elon got involved,” said Ryan Mac, a Times reporter who covers technology.

headline: Bringing Sexy Back — To Fight H.I.V.
abstract: Most safer sex campaigns focus on danger and disease. Acknowledging the importance of pleasure — and how to make safe sex good sex — could make them more effective.
lead_paragraph: Efforts to make sex safer almost always focus on the bad stuff: what to do to avoid a terrible infection or potentially deadly virus. They rarely acknowledge the good stuff: usually the reason people have sex in the first place.

headline: Frustrations Grow Over Company’s Response to CPAP Recalls
abstract: Lawsuits claim the company, Philips Respironics, knew of problems with its breathing machines long before notifying customers of potential health risks.
lead_paragraph: By 2015, Philips Respironics knew its breathing devices had a problem: Foam inside the CPAP machines,  which help people with sleep apnea breathe at night, was breaking off into black flecks and blowing into the mouths and noses of users.

headline: As U.K. Braces for Painful Budget Cuts, the Mood Is Gloomy
abstract: Swindon, west of London, has reinvented itself several times, always a rung lower on the economic ladder. Now it awaits another step down.
lead_paragraph: SWINDON, England — Britain’s energy crisis hit Chris Watts quicker and harder than most businesspeople: His company installs and fixes gas boilers. As soon as news of skyrocketing fuel bills surfaced in August, he said, customers began putting off repairs and replacements. Desperate to cut expenses, many have yet to switch on the heat in their houses.

headline: A Teacher-Created Unit on Race and Racism Using The New York Times
abstract: A middle school teacher shares the videos, articles, writing prompts and other resources that helped her students gain a better understanding of racial injustice and inequality.
lead_paragraph: This idea was submitted by Barbara Sarbin, who teaches civics to grades 6-8 at the Volcano School of Arts and Sciences, a public charter school in Volcano, Hawaii.

headline: Wealthy Nations Offer Indonesia $20 Billion to Curb Coal
abstract: The deal is the most ambitious effort yet by the United States and European countries to persuade a developing nation to abandon the dirtiest of the fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — Indonesia, one of the world’s largest consumers of coal, pledged to sharply reduce its reliance on the fossil fuel and speed up its transition to renewable power as part of a $20 billion climate finance deal announced on Tuesday with the United States, Japan and other developed countries.

headline: Novak Djokovic Is Cleared to Play in Australian Open
abstract: Australia has lifted the tennis star’s three-year ban on entering the country, imposed when he was deported in January over his failure to be vaccinated against Covid.
lead_paragraph: Australia has cleared the way for the tennis star Novak Djokovic to seek his 22nd Grand Slam title at the upcoming Australian Open, lifting a three-year ban from the country that was imposed in January when he was deported over his failure to be vaccinated against Covid.

headline: As Europe Quits Russian Gas, Half of France’s Nuclear Plants Are Off-Line
abstract: France’s state-backed nuclear operator is scrambling to overcome a monthslong crisis to get as many reactors as possible restarted before winter sets in.
lead_paragraph: An army of engineers has fanned out through nuclear power plants across France in recent months, inspecting reactors for signs of wear and tear. Hundreds of expert welders have been recruited to repair problems found in cooling circuits. Stress tests are being conducted to check for safety problems.

headline: Should We Still Be Sending Astronauts to Space?
abstract: NASA’s Artemis program plans to send astronauts back to the moon for the first time since 1972. Is this kind of human space exploration still necessary?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever dreamed of becoming an astronaut or working for NASA?

headline: Why Did We Put So Much Faith in the Crypto Whiz Kid?
abstract: Even the collapse of FTX probably won’t kill the archetype.
lead_paragraph: Disheveled, young and exceedingly brainy, Sam Bankman-Fried perfectly fit the role of a Silicon Valley mogul in the making. Mr. Bankman-Fried, the 30-year-old founder of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX, leaned into the Silicon Valley stereotype and then some, playing video games while pitching investors and wearing a T-shirt and shorts onstage with Bill Clinton and Tony Blair. Blue-chip investors fell for his persona, and Mr. Bankman-Fried profited greatly, with his estimated net worth reaching over $26 billion at one point.

headline: Is It OK That My Wife Posts Photos of Her Breastfeeding Our Son?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on weighing the risks of sharing an intimate family moment online.
lead_paragraph: I’m proud of my wife and her breastfeeding of my son — I am so glad that they have been able to experience the bonding and health benefits that come with breastfeeding. My concern arises from the fact that my wife has posted photos online of her breastfeeding. These are not photos where everything happens to be conveniently covered up. You can see it all. I understand that my wife’s Instagram accounts are “private,” in that only connections/followers can see posts. These people range from family members, close friends of hers, close friends of mine, acquaintances and business contacts. I have asked her about the photos, and in particular what the thought process was behind posting them. She said that breastfeeding is something she is proud of and wants to share with her contacts.

headline: A Survival Guide for the End of the World
abstract: In Ewan Morrison’s new novel, “How to Survive Everything,” a teenager is abducted to a pandemic survivalist colony that’s trying to prepare for an impending apocalypse.
lead_paragraph: The opening passages of “How to Survive Everything,” the new novel from the Scottish writer Ewan Morrison, gave me serious “it’s happening again” vibes. Here we are in late 2022, still navigating life with Covid-19, and Morrison makes the bold move of setting his book — which was first published internationally in 2021 before coming to the United States now — in the not-too-distant future, at the onset of the next viral catastrophe.

headline: How Democrats Can Build a John Fetterman 2.0
abstract: No candidate can be replicated, but Democrats can still take lessons from his winning campaign.
lead_paragraph: When John Fetterman announced his candidacy for the U.S. Senate early in 2021, he vowed to compete everywhere, including areas of Pennsylvania that “feel left behind” and not “part of the conversation.” His campaign mantra was, “Every county, every vote.”

headline: A Life of Shirley Hazzard, Sublime Chronicler of Affairs of the Heart
abstract: A new biography by Brigitta Olubas is the first to examine the life of the Australian novelist celebrated for her refined poetic fiction and acute moral vision.
lead_paragraph: In 2003, at the 92nd Street Y, the writer Shirley Hazzard spoke of her new novel, “The Great Fire,” which would go on to win a National Book Award a few weeks later. She said: “The world likes to trace the author’s life in the novel but the obvious isn’t always true. Something that was very close to you and resembles your experience isn’t necessarily the deepest version of the story. … One feels for another person. One observes. One imagines.”

headline: The Desert Changed My Life. It Can Change Yours, Too.
abstract: In the Mojave, humans are reminded of our smallness, our naïveté, our transience.
lead_paragraph: On a frigid March morning in 2022, a friend and I were visiting the Mojave National Preserve in California’s San Bernardino County. Joshua trees, normally crooked and whimsical with spiky green leaves, were instead blanched white and charred, limbs swinging in 25-mile-per-hour winds. Creosote bushes, blackbrush and yucca — all of which were once shelter or food for jackrabbits, night lizards and ground squirrels — had also been scorched. In August 2020, the Dome Fire burned more than a million Joshua trees alone, leaving skeletal remains of what had been a dense woodland.

headline: A Reunion as Grueling, and Gorgeous, as a Ballet en Pointe
abstract: In Meg Howrey’s “They’re Going to Love You,” a choreographer looks back on her estranged family’s past.
lead_paragraph: Carlisle Martin, the 43-year-old choreographer protagonist at the center of Meg Howrey’s fourth novel, struggles to make dances that will disrupt classical ballet’s often formulaic roles and plotlines. “There are no mothers-in-law in ballet,” she paraphrases the renowned choreographer George Balanchine. In other words, this is “not an art form suited for portraying complicated family relationships, or psychological subtleties.”

headline: When Flying a Plane Was Thrilling — and Often Fatal
abstract: “The Great Air Race,” by John Lancaster, recounts the early days of American aviation, when the budding industry struggled to get off the ground (literally) and keep aviators alive.
lead_paragraph: Aviation has become just another boring part of modern infrastructure. Some people are afraid of it. Most people endure it. Few people bother to look out the window for a view of Earth that was unimaginable to most of our ancestors, or to reflect on the miracle of technology, engineering and organization that daily airline operations represent. Before the pandemic, roughly three million passengers took flights to or from U.S. airports each day, which averages out to more than one billion passenger journeys per year. (Traffic has nearly returned to that level.) Over the past 13 years, through more than 10 billion passenger journeys, a total of two people have died in U.S. airline accidents.

headline: Do Thank-You Notes Still Matter?
abstract: In this digital age, a handwritten note may seem like a relic. But etiquette experts say they can be more powerful than ever.
lead_paragraph: These days, checking your mailbox can be a disheartening experience. You shuffle past catalogs and bills, riffling through political fliers and advertising postcards addressed to “Resident.” But sometimes, if you’re lucky, you come across an envelope with handwriting that you recognize, thanking you for something you did, or gave.

headline: Michelle Obama Has Some Advice
abstract: In her new book, “The Light We Carry,” the former first lady shares coping strategies for surviving stress and uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy being Michelle Obama. Fabulous, yes. Easy, no. She is a world-class worrier, a change-avoider and, by her own admission, a bit of a nervous Nellie. (As a child, she almost missed her chance to be in a Christmas play, wearing a beloved red velvet dress and patent leather shoes, because she was terrified of sharing the stage with a stuffed turtle.) And let’s just say that spontaneity is not her strong suit: “I’m not a leaper or a flier, but a deliberate, rung by rung ladder climber,” writes the former first lady in her new book, “The Light We Carry.” I’m pretty sure she makes lists, then makes lists of those lists, then color-codes them all.

headline: Schumer Urges Republicans to Jettison Trump and Work With Democrats
abstract: The top Senate Democrat said the G.O.P. should join with his party on bipartisan initiatives, but Republicans were in no mood to cooperate after their electoral loss.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Chuck Schumer has a postelection proposition for Republicans: Dump Donald J. Trump and join with Democrats to enact popular legislation.

headline: Why Trump Could Win Again
abstract: He could win the Republican nomination and the presidency — and both would be bad for the country.
lead_paragraph: Because American politics has been so dominated by an entertainer, the most inevitable thing in the world is a sequel.

headline: Sugar Alcohols Are in Many Sugar-Free Foods. What Are They?
abstract: And are they better for you than regular sugar?
lead_paragraph: Q: I’ve noticed that more and more diet and sugar-free food products contain ingredients called sugar alcohols. What are they? And are they any better for you than table sugar?

headline: As Migrants Leave Tent Shelter, Mayor Defends His Strategy
abstract: The city is dismantling an emergency shelter on Randalls Island, so dozens of homeless men moved on Monday, headed for a Manhattan hotel.
lead_paragraph: Jose Manaure said he felt relieved that he would be leaving the tent shelter on Randalls Island for a hotel in downtown Manhattan, where it will be easier for him to look for jobs.

headline: Republicans’ 2022 Lesson: Voters Who Trust Elections Are More Likely to Vote
abstract: Election deniers’ doubts about voting made for compelling conspiracy theories, but proved to be a bad get-out-the-vote strategy.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — It was early on Election Day when polling places in Maricopa County started experiencing a glitch. Tabulation machines were rejecting thousands of ballots, a result of a printer error, and the confusion was causing lines and frustration at the polls.

headline: World Leaders Meet as Global Economy Faces Multiple Threats
abstract: High inflation, food insecurity and a possible global recession loom large as the Group of 20 summit discussions begin.
lead_paragraph: BALI, Indonesia — World leaders gathered on Tuesday at a moment of severe geopolitical turmoil, as the global economy slinks toward recession, weighed down by high inflation, a growing scarcity of food and the side-by-side threats of oil shock and financial crisis.

headline: What Does Your Favorite Restaurant Reservation App Say About You?
abstract: For a decade, the online reservations industry was dominated by one player. Now the myriad choices have given way to strong opinions from diners.
lead_paragraph: OpenTable is economy. Resy is premium economy. Tock is business class.

headline: Bill McKibben on the Power That Could Save the Planet
abstract: The climate activist discusses the “new era” the climate movement is entering — and the urgent need to take action.
lead_paragraph: The fight against climate change is at a crossroads.

headline: Is Rock Climbing the Future of Tourism in Malawi?
abstract: The small country in southeastern Africa is leveraging its little-known rock cliffs and boulders to develop local interest in climbing — and to draw adventure tourists.
lead_paragraph: Fifty feet above, a pack of yellow baboons rollicked and screeched across a cliff of sheer black granite. An iridescent blue lizard darted into a crack to my left. I was 750 feet up the 5,600-foot dome of Chambe, a peak within the Mulanje Massif, in southern Malawi. On one of only a handful of rock climbs in the country, I felt like I was on another planet, my senses in overdrive. Behind me, low-slung clouds like clinging cobwebs blanketed green plains.

headline: In Poland, a Warm Welcome for Ukrainian Refugees Wobbles
abstract: Poland took in millions of people fleeing the war in Ukraine. But a vocal minority is trying to stoke tensions as Russian attacks threaten to prompt a new surge.
lead_paragraph: LODZ, Poland — Andrzej Kompa, a Polish historian appalled by his government’s past denunciations of migrants as a disease-carrying menace, was pleasantly surprised when Poland opened its arms this year to millions of people fleeing war in neighboring Ukraine.

headline: Ukraine’s 15,000-Mile Lifeline
abstract: How the country’s vast rail system has helped it withstand an invasion.
lead_paragraph: On the night of Feb. 23, when Kyiv was still rife with rumors and denials about the Russian troops and weaponry amassing along the border, Oleksandr Kamyshin, the 38-year-old chief executive of Ukrzaliznytsia — Ukraine’s national rail system — sent a photograph to the management’s Telegram group chat in an attempt to settle everyone’s nerves. The photo showed him tucking his two sons, 8 and 12, into bed in their apartment in central Kyiv. The head of passenger services, Oleksandr Pertsovskyi, replied with a photo of his toddler taking a bath. The implication of both photos was clear: The leaders, and their families, were staying put.

headline: After a Perilous Journey, Migrants Try to Make It in New York City
abstract: Faced with lengthy bureaucratic delays, tens of thousands of Venezuelan migrants are slipping into the city’s underground economy and joining its army of undocumented workers.
lead_paragraph: Alberto Azuna stood on the corner of 125th Street and Third Avenue in Manhattan on a recent morning and adjusted his baseball cap. He squirmed inside a tight winter jacket, then straightened himself. “OK, let’s go down this way,” he said.

headline: Trump has filed the official paperwork to run for president in 2024.
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump is expected to announce a 2024 presidential bid on Tuesday, his third campaign for the office, shortly after he filed the official paperwork to do so. A growing number of Republicans, however, see him as a political liability given the party’s showing in the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump is expected to announce a 2024 presidential bid on Tuesday, his third campaign for the office, shortly after he filed the official paperwork to do so. A growing number of Republicans, however, see him as a political liability given the party’s showing in the midterm elections.

headline: Film Club: ‘Long Line of Ladies’
abstract: How does your family and community mark and celebrate the transition to adulthood?
lead_paragraph: “Long Line of Ladies” is a 22-minute Op-Doc film that touches on themes of adulthood, community, family and tradition. It brings audiences into the world of Ahtyirahm “Ahty” Allen, a 13-year-old member of Northern California’s Karuk tribe, as she anticipates her “Ihuk” or Flower Dance — a once-dormant coming-of-age ceremony that takes place after young women in her community have their first period. This beautifully captured film takes us on a journey of tradition and self-discovery, allowing us to peek behind the curtain of a ceremony in the Karuk tribe that was nearly lost until its revival in the 1990s.

headline: Another Trump Campaign
abstract: Why is Donald J. Trump in such a hurry to announce a new bid for the White House?
lead_paragraph: Days after voters rejected his vision for the country in the midterms, former President Donald J. Trump is expected to announce a third run for president.

headline: In Their First Loss, the Eagles Score Early and Then Slumber
abstract: Philadelphia had scored 133 points in the second quarter of its first eight games, and won them all. It scored none in the second quarter against Washington on Monday, and lost.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Last week, when a certain Jimmy Johnson said he was not yet sold on the Philadelphia Eagles, despite their 8-0 start, guard Landon Dickerson was baffled.

headline: Trump’s Precarious Moment
abstract: He’s expected to announce his third White House run at a time when he is politically vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: There will be no golden escalator this time, but neither will there be mocking guffaws or can-you-believe-this eye-rolling. As Donald Trump is expected to kick off another presidential campaign tonight, the world has changed rather drastically since his first. Whatever else is thought of his attempted comeback, it will not be dismissed as an implausible joke.

headline: Leaving Brooklyn for the ’Burbs
abstract: Making the move was easier than they expected. A gut renovation that took just six weeks helped.
lead_paragraph: Making the move was easier than they expected. A gut renovation that took just six weeks helped.

headline: Leaving Brooklyn for Connecticut Was Easier Than They Thought
abstract: A gut renovation that took just six weeks helped. So did the poolside bar they built from a kit.
lead_paragraph: Like many New Yorkers who left the city in the early days of the pandemic, Elana Tenenbaum Cline and Daniel Cline assumed it was a temporary measure. When they decamped from their Brooklyn apartment to Ms. Tenenbaum Cline’s parents’ house in Connecticut with their newborn son, Noah, they expected to return to the city within a couple of months.

headline: Xi holds talks with Australia’s prime minister, ending a yearslong freeze in top-level talks.
abstract: The meeting between the leaders of China and Australia during the Group of 20 summit was another sign that Beijing is looking more broadly to ease diplomatic rifts with Western countries.
lead_paragraph: Building on his summit on Monday with President Biden, President Xi Jinping of China held talks on Tuesday with Australia’s prime minister, Anthony Albanese, ending Beijing’s yearslong freeze on top-level talks between the two trade partners.

headline: Marie Kondo Takes On a New Role: Life Coach
abstract: There’s a big difference between the way most of us wish we lived and how we actually do. The tidying guru is back with a new book to help fix that.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: A reopened rail route to Mykolaiv restores some order amid war.
abstract: On Monday night, the first train from Kyiv departed for the Black Sea city, which had been pummeled for months by Russian attacks.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — The big board at Kyiv’s central train station has for months been a long list of destinations that were unreachable because of the war.

headline: Palestinian Assailant Kills 3 Israelis in West Bank
abstract: The attack began in a settlement industrial zone and continued along a highway, and took place on the day that Israel is to swear in a new Parliament.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian assailant stabbed several civilians in an Israeli-controlled industrial zone in the occupied West Bank on Tuesday, then fled by car and continued his deadly rampage along a highway, where he hit another person with the vehicle. Three Israelis were killed and several more were severely wounded at various points along the assailant’s path, according to the Israeli ambulance service.

headline: Walmart Defies Gloom Over Inflation With Sales and Profit Upgrade
abstract: Ahead of the critical holiday shopping season, the nation’s largest retailer reported stronger-than-expected earnings and signaled confidence with a $20 billion share buyback.
lead_paragraph: Walmart on Tuesday reported a rise in sales in its latest quarter, signaling that consumers continued to spend despite high inflation and that the retail behemoth had moved past the missteps that plagued it earlier this year. It also increased its full-year forecast for revenue and profit, and projected confidence by announcing a $20 billion share buyback.

headline: Why the G20 Summit Matters to Investors
abstract: Stocks rallied in Asia on Tuesday following a historic meeting between President Biden and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: The Group of 20 summit in Bali was always going to be dominated by Russia’s war in Ukraine and the fear of a global recession caused by the food and energy crisis it has triggered. But positive noises after talks on the eve of the meeting between President Biden and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, have offered a glimmer of hope, even though deep divisions remain.

headline: U.C. Workers Strike on All 10 Campuses
abstract: The walkout involves nearly 48,000 unionized academic workers at the prestigious public university system.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In what organizers are calling the largest strike in the history of U.S. higher education, tens of thousands of academic workers across the University of California system walked off the job on Monday to call for higher wages and better benefits.

headline: For the Want of an Insulation Screw
abstract: Hammered by supply chain woes and fluctuations in demand, builders have learned to become more adept managing challenges.
lead_paragraph: Like many development projects in the pandemic, construction of the Applied Research Center at Florida Polytechnic University was burdened by delays. Skanska, the general contractor responsible for the building, struggled to find materials.

headline: In Brazil, Lula Beat Bolsonaro. Now Comes the Hard Part.
abstract: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva had one of Latin America’s best presidencies ever in the century’s first decade. His second try looks far more difficult.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — The baseball caps, red with white block letters, were meant to deliver an unmistakable message: “Make Brazil 2002 Again.”

headline: Charlie Hunnam Is a Cat Person
abstract: The actor, now starring in the Apple TV+ series “Shantaram,” talks about the brilliance of the iPod and what he learned from reading Sebastian Junger.
lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, the British actor Charlie Hunnam took a book with him on an overseas vacation and was so engrossed that he didn’t get around to sightseeing.

headline: Collapsed Crypto Exchange FTX Could Owe More Than 1 Million Creditors
abstract: In a court filing on Monday, the cryptocurrency exchange said it was in touch with “dozens” of regulators across the world.
lead_paragraph: The collapsed crypto exchange FTX and its related businesses could owe money to more than one million people and organizations, according to documents filed in bankruptcy court on Monday, illustrating the scope of a corporate meltdown that has drained traders’ accounts and plunged the cryptocurrency industry into crisis.

headline: Prominent Egyptian Political Prisoner Ends Hunger Strike, Family Says
abstract: During the U.N. climate conference in Egypt, world leaders pressed the Egyptian president to release Alaa Abd El Fattah, who has been on a hunger strike for more than seven months.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Alaa Abd El Fattah, the imprisoned British-Egyptian dissident who has been on hunger strike for more than seven months in a bid to win his freedom, has broken his strike even though he remains behind bars, his family said on Tuesday.

headline: Old Latin Mass Finds New American Audience, Despite Pope’s Disapproval
abstract: An ancient form of Catholic worship is drawing in young traditionalists and conservatives. But it signals a divide within the church.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Eric Agustin’s eight children used to call the first day of the week “Party Sunday.” The family would wake up, attend a short morning Mass at a Catholic parish near their house, then head home for lunch and an afternoon of relaxing and watching football.

headline: Biden and Xi Break the Ice
abstract: Climate cooperation could get a boost from breakthroughs at a meeting of the world’s 20 biggest economies.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of the world’s 20 biggest economies are meeting this week in Indonesia.

headline: World Population Reaches 8 Billion, U.N. Says
abstract: The rapid population growth has been driven by the world’s poorest countries. More global challenges are ahead.
lead_paragraph: Until 1804, fewer than one billion people roamed our planet. More than a century later, in 1927, we crossed two billion.

headline: In Colombia, Drilling Pays the Bills. The Country’s Leaders Want to Quit Oil.
abstract: The president says oil is his economy’s worst addiction. Phasing it out would be a global first for a major oil producer.
lead_paragraph: ARAUCA, Colombia — Over the past four decades, Colombia has pumped billions of barrels of oil from under a vast savanna it shares with neighboring Venezuela. Through pipelines, the thick crude travels over the Andes and to the Caribbean coast, and then onto tankers, mostly to the United States.

headline: Grammy Awards 2023: The Full List of Nominees
abstract: Artists, albums and songs competing for trophies at the 65th annual ceremony were announced on Tuesday. The show will take place on Feb. 5 at Crypto.com Arena in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé is the top nominee for the 65th annual Grammy Awards, with nine nods, all but one for her dance-heavy album “Renaissance.” (The other is for “Be Alive,” from the film “King Richard.”)

headline: Did Five Paintings Lose Their ‘Oomph’? It’s a $410 Million Question.
abstract: Holding companies connected to Ronald O. Perelman are suing his insurers, saying that five of his pieces worth that amount were damaged in a 2018 fire. His insurers say the fire never reached the paintings.
lead_paragraph: When Steve Wynn, the casino magnate, put his elbow through a Picasso he owned, there was little doubt about the damage he had done to a painting he hoped to sell, in 2006, for more than $100 million.

headline: Markets Rise on Signs of Lower Inflation
abstract: Lower-than-expected data on wholesale prices and resilient earnings from retailers were welcomed by investors.
lead_paragraph: Stocks rose on Tuesday, edging higher after a measure of wholesale inflation rose more slowly than expected, bolstering recent signs that inflation may be cooling.

headline: ‘The Crown’ and the Appeal of a Royal TV Interview
abstract: As Prince Charles and Diana showed in the 1990s, a royal taking to television can be risky. That hasn’t stopped other members of the family from following suit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Part way through the latest season of “The Crown,” a young Prince William (Senan West) helps his grandmother, Queen Elizabeth II (Imelda Staunton), set up a new television at Windsor Castle, because she doesn’t understand the channel-changing mechanism. William’s great-grandmother, the Queen Mother (Marcia Warren), turns to him and says, “It’s so sad to see her struggle to understand a medium with which she is inextricably linked.”

headline: I Cooked 20 Thanksgiving Stuffings to Create the Ultimate Recipe
abstract: In search of the highest form of the holiday favorite, Eric Kim traveled back in time — and ate a lot of bread.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Walmart Agrees to Pay $3.1 Billion to Settle Opioid Lawsuits
abstract: The money would help pay for addiction treatment and drug education programs in communities across the United States.
lead_paragraph: Walmart, the largest retailer in the United States, has agreed to pay $3.1 billion to resolve thousands of lawsuits over its pharmacies’ roles in the opioid crisis, the company and lawyers for states, local governments and tribes announced Tuesday.

headline: U.K. Pledges $1.2 Billion to Fight Diseases in Poor Countries
abstract: The contribution to the Global Fund is less than aid organizations had hoped for. Britain has been cutting foreign aid since 2020.
lead_paragraph: Britain announced on Monday that it would contribute $1.19 billion over three years to combat H.I.V., tuberculosis and malaria across the world, about half the amount aid organizations had hoped for and more than a month after other Group of 7 nations had pledged their support.

headline: A Show About Colonial Power, Born From the Freedom to Make Mistakes
abstract: “Houseboy” took shape at the South Africa-based Center for the Less Good Idea, where artists are allowed to follow their own impulses.
lead_paragraph: William Kentridge is a protean creator of visual artworks, animation, installations, theater, opera and film. (He also occasionally performs himself.) A major exhibition of his work is currently on show at the Royal Academy in London, and another has just opened at The Broad in Los Angeles.

headline: How a Mondrian Painting Sold for $51 Million at Sotheby’s
abstract: The sale, a benchmark in the artist’s market, was the result of a prearranged deal between the auction house and a buyer.
lead_paragraph: A classic grid painting by Piet Mondrian sold during a Sotheby’s auction on Monday for $51 million, including fees, which topped the previous $50.6 million benchmark for the Dutch artist that was set in 2015.

headline: How Doctors View Patients With Disabilities
abstract: When patients with disabilities receive substandard care. Also: Kari Lake’s defeat; Mike Pence; Ukraine; South African coal; Apple’s betrayal; when to brush.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Master of Light’ Review: Rebuilding Through Rembrandt
abstract: The painter George Anthony Morton, who spent his 20s in prison on a drug conviction, is the subject of this documentary coming to HBO Max.
lead_paragraph: In the documentary “Master of Light,” George Anthony Morton recalls a difficult upbringing in Kansas City, Mo. “If there was a neighborhood drug house, that was where we lived,” he says. His struggling mother, Tela, had him at 15. But Morton says that he “always escaped through art” and that teachers recognized his potential and encouraged his talent.

headline: A Composer’s ‘Travel Guide’ to His Family’s Unspoken Past
abstract: Michael Gordon’s new work reflects on his father’s flight from Poland in 1939 and the migratory life — and buried traumas — that followed.
lead_paragraph: “I recognize my father in this picture,” the composer Michael Gordon said during a recent interview, turning through a shoe box of photographs that were taken in Poland before World War II.

headline: Park Avenue Armory Season Spotlights Homelessness and Medical Ethics
abstract: Highlights include Robert Icke’s moral thriller “The Doctor” and the tenor Jonas Kaufmann in a staging of Franz Schubert’s final songs.
lead_paragraph: An immersive drama about homelessness, a moral thriller about the intersection of faith and medical ethics, and the world premiere of a theatrically staged solo performance of the composer Franz Schubert’s final songs are among the 2023 season offerings the Park Avenue Armory announced on Tuesday.

headline: Russian Missiles Hit Residential Buildings in Kyiv
abstract: Kyiv’s mayor said that at least one person was killed after Russia struck the capital as part of a broad aerial attack targeting several cities across Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Kyiv’s mayor said that at least one person was killed after Russia struck the capital as part of a broad aerial attack targeting several cities across Ukraine.

headline: At G20 Summit, Xi and Biden Offer Rival Visions for Solving Global Issues
abstract: China and the United States showed how global summits are an arena for great powers to compete, with implications for the war in Ukraine and Asia’s future.
lead_paragraph: BALI, Indonesia — While President Biden and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, have eased tensions between their countries, they are vying for influence in Asia and beyond, offering competing stances on how to address poverty and the war in Ukraine.

headline: A single fiery missile fragment brings terror and death to a Kyiv apartment building.
abstract: Residents told of a frantic escape: “We were just running around, no idea what to do,” one said.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — An explosion in the sky above the home of Svitlana and Petro Romanchuk in central Kyiv shook their apartment, and then a fiery hunk of metal fell from the sky. It ripped through their kitchen and engulfed the building in flames, killing their downstairs neighbor and forcing at least 70 families living in the five-story residential building from their homes.

headline: ‘Targeted’ Killings and No Arrest Bring Fear to University of Idaho
abstract: The police said they did not have a suspect in custody, and were working to document the events that led to the deaths of four friends at a house off campus.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Idaho — Some students were packing their bags to leave town. Others who stayed behind feared the uncertainty around them. Two days after four University of Idaho students were found dead at a home just outside of campus, residents had little comfort that they were safe.

headline: Gov. Murphy Reinstates Bear Hunting in New Jersey, a Year After Ending It
abstract: The governor cited an increase in reported bear sightings and aggressive encounters. Opponents have said they intend to try to block the Dec. 5 hunt in court.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON, N.J. — Starting next month, New Jersey will again allow hunters to use guns and bows to shoot bears on private and state-owned land in a major policy reversal for Gov. Philip D. Murphy, a Democrat who campaigned for a first term on a pledge to end the hunts.

headline: Beyoncé, Kendrick Lamar and Adele Lead 2023 Grammy Nominations
abstract: Brandi Carlile, Lizzo and Harry Styles, also near the top of the pack, will compete for the biggest awards at the 65th annual ceremony in February.
lead_paragraph: At the 2021 Grammys, Beyoncé picked up four awards, bringing her total to 28 and making her the winningest woman in Grammy history. At the 2023 ceremony, she will have nine chances to add to her total: The 41-year-old star is the top nominee for the 65th annual Grammy Awards, with all but one of her nods coming for her dance-heavy album “Renaissance.”

headline: Marcus Samuelsson’s First New York Restaurant in Seven Years Is Open
abstract: Aperitivos in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, Tocqueville reopens, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Rose Noël, the former executive chef of Maialino Mare in Washington, D.C., is opening a seafood restaurant with Marcus Samuelsson, his first spot in the city in about seven years. Hav means ocean in Swedish, and Mar translates as honey in Amharic. (Both languages played a role in Mr. Samuelsson’s life.) Input from the chef de cuisine, Fariyal Abdullahi, and the head baker, Farheen Jafarey, also shaped the menu, which features Black mermaid rice with mushrooms, crab, lobster and peas; dawadawa bass with clams and herbs; and seaside waffle with rock shrimp and uni butter. In addition to wines and cocktails, the drinks include Ethiopian beer and several nonalcoholic choices. The 125-seat restaurant, done in shades of green, will be a showcase for Black art. Thelma Golden, the director of the Studio Museum in Harlem, and Derrick Adams, an artist and a creative partner who contributed impressive wall-mounted sculptures, will curate the selection, which will also feature a series depicting Black mermaids commissioned by Mr. Samuelsson. Midcentury style is evident in the Noguchi-style chandelier and bentwood lamps.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Bill McKibben
abstract: The Nov. 15, 2022 episode of ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Bill McKibben. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Trump’s 2024 announcement injects new uncertainty into Justice Dept. inquiries.
abstract: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, who shuns politics, finds himself at the center of the storm.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia testified on Tuesday about efforts by allies of former President Donald J. Trump to overturn the 2020 election. Allen H. Weisselberg, a former business associate of Mr. Trump, appeared in a tax fraud case targeting the family company. And the Justice Department is fully resuming its two Trump investigations after a brief pause for the midterm elections.

headline: Your Scalp Would Like Some Attention, Please
abstract: A new wave of serums and exfoliators highlight the importance of creating a good foundation for healthy hair.
lead_paragraph: Hair is a powerful marker of identity, and its loss is almost always charged with intense emotion. It’s perhaps unsurprising, then, that scalp-focused remedies — of both the moderately effective and snake oil varieties — have been around for millenniums. Ancient Egyptian women would rub a mixture of castor and almond oil into their scalps in the hopes of promoting hair growth. Likewise, Ayurvedic practitioners in India have long prescribed massaging the head with oil, a practice that British colonists eventually brought back to England. Harking back to these treatments, a new crop of products — featuring some technological advancements and updated ingredients — has emerged, with an eye toward if not restoring lost locks, then at least supporting growth by affording the scalp the same care and attention we give to the rest of our skin.

headline: Will Pelosi Stay or Will She Go? Perhaps a Little Bit of Both.
abstract: With Democrats on the cusp of losing the House, all eyes are on Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s next move, and the party is frozen in place until she decides what to do.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Democrats celebrate a stronger-than-expected performance in the midterm elections, a consequential question is hanging over the party: What will become of Speaker Nancy Pelosi, the party’s long-serving House leader and the first woman to hold the post?

headline: Watching ‘The Crown’ With Britain’s Anti-Monarchists: ‘I Feel Queasy’
abstract: Since the show debuted in 2016, there has been an increase in republican sentiment. How has the show contributed to that?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Monday evening, Finna Ayres and Matt Turnbull met in Ayres’s London home to do something their friends would have found shocking: watch the latest season of “The Crown,” Netflix’s show about the ins and outs of Britain’s royal family.

headline: Top Trump Organization Executive Testifies Against Firm He Helped Build
abstract: Allen H. Weisselberg, the Trump Organization’s former chief financial officer, admitted that he had received lucrative off-the-books perks from the company.
lead_paragraph: After decades of loyal service to Donald J. Trump, Allen H. Weisselberg on Tuesday testified in the criminal tax-fraud trial of the former president’s family business, kicking the proceedings into high gear as he assumed an uncomfortable role: star witness for the prosecution.

headline: DeSantis, without naming Trump, slams ‘hugely underwhelming’ midterms for the G.O.P.
abstract: “Independent voters aren’t voting for our candidates,” Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida said at an event hours before Donald Trump was expected to announce a third presidential bid. “That’s a problem.”
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s announcement at Mar-a-Lago tonight.

headline: McCarthy overwhelmingly won G.O.P. backing for speaker, but the vote signals he still faces a tough fight.
abstract: The challenge indicates a potentially rough fight ahead of him to secure the job at the start of the new Congress.
lead_paragraph: Representative Kevin McCarthy of California on Tuesday resoundingly won the Republican nomination for speaker, but a challenge from his right flank that drew more than two dozen defectors showed weakness in his hold on his party, indicating a potentially rough fight ahead of him to secure the job at the start of the new Congress.

headline: ‘Stutz’ Review: An Actor’s Tribute to a Therapist
abstract: In his documentary, Jonah Hill gently turns the tables on the psychiatrist and author Phil Stutz.
lead_paragraph: In 1956, the poet H.D. published “Tribute to Freud,” an appreciation of her psychoanalyst, Sigmund Freud. Now, the actor and director Jonah Hill celebrates his therapist in “Stutz,” his involving documentary about Phil Stutz, who co-wrote the book “The Tools” with Barry Michels.

headline: Pop Stars Are Mugging for TikTok. Fans Are Loving It.
abstract: Performers like Dua Lipa and Rosalía are peppering their tours with dance moves and gestures that can seem specifically engineered to go viral. In some cases, they are.
lead_paragraph: By the time Dua Lipa announced that there would be a Latin American leg of her “Future Nostalgia” tour, Will Laura Schmidt, who lives in Peru, had already bought plane tickets to Europe so he could attend the singer’s concert in Munich in May.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Why Aren’t You Married?’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: My first friends were my cousins and siblings. After eating early family dinners, we spent many Sunday evenings sprawled across our grandparents’ bed. We lay sated, entranced by the television, our limbs crossing limbs, our heads lying on each other’s thighs and stomachs, like we were playing a great game of Twister. We were not prepared to be separated by life, loss and time. Despite our journeys away from each other, our bond could only be stretched, never truly broken. During the pandemic, we connected online. Now, in middle age, we came back together for a joyful Sunday brunch. — Tonya Coats

headline: Nobody Cares About Biden’s Energy Policy. Great!
abstract: The president’s plan shows that a carrots-not-sticks climate strategy is a winner.
lead_paragraph: Democrats had far better midterms this year than they did in 2010. Still, with Republicans on the cusp of winning narrow control of the House, there’s unlikely to be major legislation passed over the next two years. So as was the case for President Barack Obama, President Biden’s legislative high-water mark will probably be a bill he got passed in his first two years. In that sense, the Inflation Reduction Act — which, despite its name, is mainly a climate and health care bill — is this administration’s equivalent of Obamacare.

headline: Restaurant Review: Four Stars for Yoshino, Where the Omakase Stands Alone
abstract: At his 10-seat counter, Tadashi Yoshida renders sushi meals costing more than $600 with artistry and precision.
lead_paragraph: If you show up a few minutes early for your 5:30 p.m. reservation, Tadashi Yoshida’s door on the Bowery will be locked. It is also unmarked. To the right of the entrance is a discreet panel with a buzzer just below the name, Yoshino; after you press the button, someone will appear in the door to undo the bolt and let you in.

headline: The Four-Star Restaurants of New York
abstract: These are the places that received the top rating in their last starred reviews from The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Pete Wells, the restaurant critic of The New York Times, gives four stars this week to Yoshino, a small sushi counter on the Bowery. Three other New York City restaurants received four stars in their last starred reviews by Times critics. Here are the others:

headline: Ellen Levine, 79, Dies; Editor With Keen Sense of Women Readers
abstract: She was Good Housekeeping’s first female top editor, earlier edited Woman’s Day and Redbook, and helped Oprah Winfrey create a newsstand sensation.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Levine, Good Housekeeping’s first female top editor, whose keen sense of what American women wanted from a magazine also led her to success as Hearst Magazines’ editorial director and Oprah Winfrey’s partner in creating an instant newsstand hit, died on Nov. 6 at her home in Manhattan. She was 79.

headline: When ‘Racism’ Is Not Really Racism
abstract: The problem with the terms ‘systemic,’ ‘structural’ and ‘institutional.’
lead_paragraph: “Systemic bigotry.”

headline: Georgia Judge Suspends State’s Abortion Ban
abstract: A county judge blocked Georgia’s ban on abortion early in pregnancy, meaning that abortions after six weeks are once again legal in the state.
lead_paragraph: A Georgia county judge on Tuesday blocked the state’s ban on abortions after six weeks of pregnancy, saying the law was unconstitutional when the state legislature approved it in 2019 — more than three years before the U.S. Supreme Court revoked the constitutional right to abortion.

headline: Serial Productions
abstract: Serial Productions makes narrative podcasts whose quality and innovation transformed the medium.
lead_paragraph: Serial Productions makes narrative podcasts whose quality and innovation transformed the medium.

headline: Ramen for Lunch and More Reader Questions
abstract: Looking for quality ramen at lunch without a wait? We’ve got you.
lead_paragraph: Happy week before Thanksgiving, all! Before I hop into this month’s reader questions, I wanted to highlight some of the incredible work my colleagues have put together for those who won’t be dining out on Thanksgiving Day. Genevieve Ko created nine stunning pie recipes, though if you don’t like pie, Melissa Clark has three alternatives. Yewande Komolafe has you covered on salads, while Alexa Weibel put together a showstopping collection of vegetarian dishes. The contributors J. Kenji López-Alt, Claire Saffitz and Ina Garten came through on the turkey, potatoes and a store-bought version of the meal. And if your yearly contribution is wine, here are 10 you might consider pouring, from Eric Asimov and The Times’s wine panel.

headline: New Foundation
abstract: Being back in the workplace only really matters “if the amount of care and caring that became the No. 1 conversation in March of 2020 carries through,” J Wortham, a co-host of “Still Processing,” says.
lead_paragraph: Wesley and J discuss the push to “return to office” — and what it means for their lives, as well as American culture as a whole. What have 50 years of workplace sitcoms, from “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” to “Abbott Elementary,” taught us about our romance with the office? And what do TikTok parodies and the TV show “Severance” get right about the history of labor in America? In this period of returning to so-called normalcy, Wesley and J reflect on how we can ensure that the lessons of the early pandemic aren’t forgotten.

headline: Grammys Snubs and Surprises: Bad Bunny, Rosalía, Zach Bryan and Abba
abstract: Beyoncé has the most nominations for the 2023 awards, and many recent perennials are back again. But some of music’s most inventive younger stars didn’t break through.
lead_paragraph: Another year, another head-scratching combination of nominees for the Grammy Awards, which will be held on Feb. 5, 2023, in Los Angeles.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: Trump 2024?
abstract: Plus a deadly explosion in Poland and a record-breaking global population estimate.
lead_paragraph: Just a few hours after we send this newsletter, Donald Trump will make a “special announcement” at Mar-a-Lago, his home in Florida. He is expected to announce a 2024 presidential run.

headline: The Big Liar and His Losing Little Liars
abstract: Most election deniers who lost last week have conceded and did not claim fraud. That doesn’t absolve them from embracing Trump’s Big Lie in the first place.
lead_paragraph: I got a little emotional voting this year.

headline: 32 Charged in Brooklyn Gang Shootings That Injured 14 and Killed 2
abstract: Two warring gangs began a feud on social media before taking their fight to the streets. The indictment came on the heels of several gang-related cases this year.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Brooklyn on Tuesday charged 32 people who they said were associated with two rival gangs in the borough’s Brownsville neighborhood. The two groups had been locked in a cycle of retaliatory shootings over several years that had left two gang members dead and 14 people injured.

headline: Trump Wins Legal Battle Against His Niece
abstract: Mary Trump had claimed that the former president and other relatives had cheated her out of tens of millions of dollars. A judge dismissed her lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump won a legal battle against his niece Mary L. Trump this week, when a New York judge dismissed Ms. Trump’s lawsuit claiming he and other relatives had cheated her out of tens of millions of dollars in inheritance.

headline: The White House requests nearly $48 billion from Congress for Ukraine and pandemic aid.
abstract: The request comes as lawmakers are beginning to work out the details of a sprawling spending package that must become law before Dec. 16 to avoid a government shutdown.
lead_paragraph: The White House asked Congress on Tuesday to approve nearly $48 billion to prepare for a possible winter surge in coronavirus infections and to direct additional support to Ukraine as it continues to battle a Russian invasion, according to administration officials.

headline: Rafael Nadal’s Battle Against Time
abstract: Nadal, the 22-time Grand Slam singles champion, has played all year like he is running out of time. There is a reason for that, and it’s not hard to miss at the ATP Finals.
lead_paragraph: TURIN, Italy — There was a moment Sunday night when Rafael Nadal was suddenly Rafael Nadal again.

headline: Foreign Trade Competition Has Hurt Black and Disadvantaged Workers Most, Report Says
abstract: A government trade agency report suggested that the impact of trade policy differed for workers depending on their race and socioeconomic status.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — People of color have been disproportionately hurt by the economic disruptions caused by global trade, as a trend toward offshoring and globalization in recent decades prompted U.S. factories to relocate abroad, according to a newly released report from a government trade agency.

headline: Estée Lauder Agrees to Buy Tom Ford Brand in $2.8 Billion Deal
abstract: Tom Ford’s high-end fragrances routinely make best-seller lists, and the deal, the luxury industry’s biggest this year, also brings apparel to Estée Lauder, which had been strictly focused on beauty.
lead_paragraph: Tom Ford — designer, film director, art collector and fashion world provocateur — can now add one more accolade to his list: billionaire. On Tuesday, Estée Lauder announced it had agreed to buy his company in a deal that totaled $2.8 billion.

headline: FTX’s In-House Performance Coach Is Just as Surprised as You Are
abstract: George K. Lerner, a psychiatrist who has worked at the collapsed crypto exchange FTX since last year, said he had no knowledge of wrongdoing at the firm.
lead_paragraph: In the week since the onetime billionaire Sam Bankman-Fried became the business world’s biggest villain, many of his friends, associates and investors have gone quiet, either out of embarrassment or on the advice of their lawyers.

headline: Elon Musk Fires Twitter Employees Who Criticized Him
abstract: Mr. Musk, who is rapidly transforming the social media company, also has cut its contractor work force.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Elon Musk continued cutting Twitter’s work force in his third week of owning the social media company, firing employees who had criticized him and eliminating contractors.

headline: Takeaways from the fifth day of the Trump Organization trial.
abstract: Top executives of the company took the stand, including Allen H. Weisselberg, the former chief financial officer. He spoke of luxury perks provided tax free.
lead_paragraph: The tax-fraud trial of Donald J. Trump’s family business continued in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Tuesday with testimony from the prosecution’s star witness: Allen H. Weisselberg, the former chief financial officer of the Trump Organization.

headline: Polish Official Responds to Blast Near Ukraine Border
abstract: A deadly explosion took place at a grain processing facility near the border with Ukraine, according to Polish media outlets. The cause of the explosion was not immediately clear.
lead_paragraph: A deadly explosion took place at a grain processing facility near the border with Ukraine, according to Polish media outlets. The cause of the explosion was not immediately clear.

headline: Warnock Joins Lawsuit to Overturn Restriction on Early Voting in Georgia
abstract: The lone Saturday that falls into the early-voting period for the runoff election between Senator Raphael Warnock and Herschel Walker is subject to a limit related to holidays.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Senator Raphael Warnock joined a lawsuit on Tuesday that seeks to overturn a rule that limits Saturday early voting in Georgia’s runoff election.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: New York City Reaches Deal to Build Soccer Stadium in Queens
abstract: The New York City Football Club will pay roughly $780 million to build the stadium in Willets Point in Queens as part of a project that will include housing and a hotel.
lead_paragraph: New York City officials have reached an agreement to build the city’s first professional soccer stadium, the centerpiece of a giant mixed-use development that would transform a long-underutilized waterfront section of Queens.

headline: Pence on Trump’s 2024 Run: ‘I Think We’ll Have Better Choices’
abstract: In an interview, the former vice president expressed anger over Donald Trump’s conduct on Jan. 6, 2021, but deflected questions about his character.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence said on Tuesday that he was angered by President Donald J. Trump’s conduct on and before Jan. 6, 2021, but he took pains to avoid attacking him as Mr. Trump geared up for a presidential campaign and Mr. Pence considers one of his own.

headline: California First Partner Becomes Key Witness in Weinstein’s Los Angeles Trial
abstract: Jennifer Siebel Newsom, a documentary filmmaker and the wife of Gavin Newsom, the California governor, endured tough questioning as she testified that she was sexually assaulted by the former producer Harvey Weinstein.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jennifer Siebel Newsom already had her own career as an actor and a documentary maker when Gavin Newsom was elected governor of California in 2018. She was well known enough to help her husband draw attention and crowds, and was at his side setting strategy as the future first couple campaigned, often with their children, on a bus across the state.

headline: Judge Invalidates Rule Allowing Migrant Expulsions on Border
abstract: The pandemic-era health order, known as Title 42, has allowed the government to expel hundreds of thousands of migrants who otherwise might be allowed to pursue asylum claims.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday blocked the government from continuing to use a Trump-era public health emergency measure to swiftly expel migrants who cross the southern border unlawfully, an order that could enable thousands of potential asylum seekers to enter the country.

headline: The L.A. Sheriff Concedes After a Combative First Term
abstract: Sheriff Alex Villanueva defended his tenure before conceding to Robert Luna, a former Long Beach police chief.
lead_paragraph: Alex Villanueva, the combative leader of the Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department, conceded defeat on Tuesday following a bitterly fought contest with Robert Luna, a former Long Beach police chief, for one of the nation’s most powerful law enforcement jobs.

headline: House Republicans Grill Homeland Security Chief About Border Crisis
abstract: The hearing further solidified the expectation that the secretary, Alejandro N. Mayorkas, will continue to hear threats of impeachment if the G.O.P. wins the majority in the House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Homeland Security secretary, Alejandro N. Mayorkas, faced hostile questions about the southwest border from House Republicans on Tuesday, foreshadowing the kind of grilling he can expect more of from the G.O.P., which has threatened to impeach him should it take control of the House, as it is expected to do.

headline: Donald Trump Is Finally Finished
abstract: The only coherent explanation for Republicans’ underperformance is the ex-president.
lead_paragraph: Whether or not Donald Trump’s hat is in the ring, he’s finished as a serious contender for high office.

headline: After a Midterm Letdown, Republican Rebels Try to Make Their Leaders Sweat
abstract: To make sense of the brewing clashes in Congress, we spoke with Carl Hulse, the chief Washington correspondent for The Times.
lead_paragraph: It’s the ultimate inside game. But the postelection jockeying for leadership posts in the House and Senate is one of the most telling indicators of how America’s two main political parties are processing their wins and losses. The races are largely conducted behind closed doors, with much of the positioning and vote-whipping having taken place over the course of months.

headline: Top Republicans Face Dissent as McCarthy Wins G.O.P. Nod for Speaker
abstract: Even as Representative Kevin McCarthy, the minority leader, survived his first test, he lacked the votes to cement the speakership. His Senate counterpart also faced a challenge to his position.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican leaders in Congress are confronting fresh threats to their power and divisions in their ranks from an emboldened and embittered right flank, after a weaker than expected midterm election performance that has demoralized their party.

headline: U.C.L.A. Faces Judgment Day with U.C. Regents, and Perhaps Lawmakers
abstract: Leaders of the University of California system are considering whether to block U.C.L.A.’s move to the Big Ten. The lawmaker who touched off national changes in endorsement deals is watching, too.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — By the time the U.C.L.A. football team kicks off Saturday against its crosstown rival, Southern California, with a berth in the Pac-12 Conference championship game at stake, the Bruins may know a more consequential result — whether or not they will be able to join the Trojans in bolting for the Big Ten Conference in less than two years.

headline: Poland Suggests Russian-Made Missile Killed 2 Inside Its Borders
abstract: The explosion in a Polish village across the border from Ukraine occurred as Russia bombarded Ukrainian cities with about 100 missiles.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Poland said early Wednesday that an explosion that killed two people at a grain-processing plant near the Ukrainian border had “most likely” been caused by a Russian-made missile, raising the prospect that the NATO alliance would be drawn more directly into the war in Ukraine.

headline: Iran Cracks Down as Protests Show No Sign of Easing
abstract: Security forces fired on a crowd at a metro station on Tuesday, setting off a panicked rush of commuters, video showed.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian authorities moved aggressively to disperse demonstrations in dozens of cities across the country on Tuesday, as an uprising demanding an end to clerical rule entered its third month, and neither protesters nor the government showed any signs of backing down.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 16, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Nov. 16, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the United States and China resuming discussions about combating climate change misstated the current average global temperature increase in Fahrenheit. The current average global temperature increase, compared with the preindustrial era, is 1.1 degrees Celsius. That is the equivalent of roughly 2 degrees Fahrenheit of increase, not 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit.

headline: U.S. Catholic Bishops Elect Leaders for Anti-Abortion Fight
abstract: The bishops said they would redouble efforts to end abortion; a new president and vice president are expected to continue the conservative leanings of the hierarchy.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — A week after bruising losses for anti-abortion forces in the midterm elections, America’s Roman Catholic bishops rededicated themselves to ending abortion and elected a slate of new leaders to support that goal during their annual meeting on Tuesday.

headline: Watch Live: Former President Trump Speaks at Mar-a-Lago
abstract: Former President Trump makes an announcement from his home in Palm Beach, Fla., where he is expected to say he will run for president in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Former President Trump makes an announcement from his home in Palm Beach, Fla., where he is expected to say he will run for president in 2024.

headline: Buck Showalter and Terry Francona Are M.L.B.’s Top Managers
abstract: Showalter led the Mets to the second most wins in franchise history, while Francona won a division title in Cleveland despite having the league’s youngest roster.
lead_paragraph: Buck Showalter felt humbled but incomplete the first time he won a Manager of the Year Award for a New York team.

headline: In Arizona, Kari Lake’s Next Move Splits Factions of G.O.P.
abstract: The defeated candidate for governor is weighing whether to concede or mount a legal challenge. The choice is pitting old-guard Republicans against election deniers pushing for a fight.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Kari Lake’s defeat in the governor’s race in Arizona has set off a high-stakes tug of war within the Republican Party, as Ms. Lake’s right-wing allies pushed her to mount a Trump-style challenge to the results, while some establishment leaders — including a former Republican governor — urged her to concede her loss and move on.

headline: After the Killings at the University of Virginia, a Coach Remembers His Players
abstract: “It feels like a nightmare, honestly,” Tony Elliott said, “and I’m ready for somebody to pinch me and wake me up.”
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — Tony Elliott, the University of Virginia football coach, and Carla Williams, the athletic director, entered the Tuesday news conference 15 minutes late. Both looked exhausted, their eyes red and filled with tears as they sat in front of two microphones.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Nadal Is Battling Time, but Time Seems to Have the Upper Hand
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, November 16, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “But what I don’t have is any doubt that I’m going to die for it.”

headline: ‘Downstate’ Review: A Foulness in the Very Air They Breathe
abstract: The deep, dark tragicomedy by Bruce Norris is set in a group home for sex offenders.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Norris’s “Downstate” is the kind of play that takes over your body gradually. Its tension seeps into your limbs, settles tautly in your solar plexus and does not leave. Out on the street after the performance, your every synapse remains on high alert.

headline: The Chaos Inside Donald Trump’s Mind
abstract: Far from a model C.E.O, the former president is an inattentive, lazy, incompetent manager, saddling his presidential campaign with a heavy disadvantage.
lead_paragraph: In August 2020, the Trump campaign found itself with a staggering $200 million budget shortfall. In September 2020, Brad Parscale, a senior adviser who had until recently served as campaign manager, had a public breakdown on the street in front of his house in Florida, and the police were called to restrain him. In the crucial last months of the race, campaign staff members kept Donald Trump away from their data guru, Matt Oczkowski, whom Mr. Trump found weird and boring. And by the final weeks of the campaign, the incumbent president was being outspent by as much as three to one — an unprecedented mismatch in the history of modern presidential races.

headline: America Deserves Better Than Donald Trump
abstract: Mr. Trump’s return to the campaign trail poses new dangers to American democracy.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump, twice impeached for seeking to undermine the integrity of the 2020 presidential election, says he is running for president again in 2024.

headline: Biden says the missile that killed 2 in Poland probably was not fired from Russia.
abstract: It was unclear from the president’s remarks whether he meant the missile was not likely to have been fired from inside Russia, or by Russian forces in Ukraine or elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: BALI, Indonesia — President Biden pledged support for a full investigation of the explosion that killed two people in Poland on Wednesday, but suggested to reporters that the missile that detonated probably had not been fired from Russia.

headline: Ooh, That Could Work!
abstract: John Hawksley’s puzzle corrects some common misconceptions.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Happy Wednesday, Wordplay readers! Today we have a puzzle from John Hawksley, who is making his third appearance in the New York Times Crossword.

headline: Review: At ‘Camp Siegfried,’ a Nazi Summer of Love on Long Island
abstract: The lure of fascism comes disguised as adolescent romance in Bess Wohl’s disturbing new play.
lead_paragraph: She’s a brainy brunette wallflower, a fraying nerve barely held together by tightly plaited milkmaid braids.

headline: Trump’s Announcement Is a Sign of Weakness
abstract: An admission of weakness poorly disguised in a show of strength.
lead_paragraph: The defiant timing of Donald Trump’s announcement of his candidacy for president in 2024, dropping amid Republican recriminations over their midterm disappointments, is an admission of weakness poorly disguised as a show of strength.

headline: We Fact-Checked Trump’s Speech
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump made a number of claims about his policies and President Biden’s record. We checked them for accuracy.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump announced his re-election bid on Tuesday night in an address at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida. During the speech, he spoke about U.S. energy policies, the border wall and tax cuts. We checked the speech for accuracy, and this is what we found.Trump exaggerated his record on oil and gas.“Gas prices have reached the highest levels in history. And expect them to go much higher now that the strategic national reserves, which I filled up, have been virtually drained in order to keep gasoline prices lower just prior to the election. Joe Biden has intentionally surrendered our energy independence,” Mr. Trump said.

headline: Don’t Buy Into the Trump-DeSantis Smack-Down
abstract: Trump may be running for president again, but that doesn’t mean we have to give him a do-over.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is a petulant narcissist, so his feuds with Govs. Ron DeSantis and Glenn Youngkin are surely sincere, but they also show that Trump hasn’t lost his feral instinct for media attention.
