headline: 8 Charged in Scheme to Smuggle Endangered Monkeys From Asia, U.S. Says
abstract: Cambodian wildlife officials, black-market dealers and top executives at a monkey breeding company conspired to illegally export long-tailed macaques to the U.S., prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have charged eight people with running an international monkey-smuggling operation in which hundreds of the endangered primates were poached from the wild in Southeast Asia and shipped to the U.S. for research purposes, the Justice Department said on Wednesday.

headline: Imani Perry Wins National Book Award for ‘South to America’
abstract: Tess Gunty received the fiction prize for her debut, “The Rabbit Hutch.” Art Spiegelman, the author of “Maus,” received a lifetime achievement award.
lead_paragraph: Imani Perry won the National Book Award for nonfiction on Wednesday for “South to America: A Journey Below the Mason-Dixon to Understand the Soul of a Nation,” in which Perry, a professor of African American studies at Princeton, travels to the American South, where she is from, to examine race, culture, politics and identity.

headline: A New Source of Economic Anxiety in Britain: Soaring Mortgage Rates

lead_paragraph: In June 2021, Monique Foulger reached a major milestone: At 30 years old, she bought her first home, a modest one-bedroom flat in Croydon in South London.

headline: N.F.L. Week 11 Predictions: Our Picks for Each Game
abstract: Winter weather enters the picture as the Bills try to halt their slide against the Browns and the Packers host the Titans. But conditions should be electric for Kansas City’s rematch against the Chargers.
lead_paragraph: Chaos reared its head in Week 10 and its handiwork was everywhere. Josh Allen fumbled with 41 seconds left in the fourth quarter, leading to a Vikings win. Officials missed a face mask call during the Eagles fourth-quarter comeback try against the Commanders. The Cowboys’ unsuccessful decision to go for it on fourth down opened the door for the Packers.

headline: For Ukraine, Keeping the Lights On Is One of the Biggest Battles
abstract: This week’s missile assault by Russian forces has hit at least 15 energy facilities — some for the fifth or sixth time — forcing controlled blackouts in every part of the country.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Russia is turning winter into a weapon, even as its soldiers flail on the battlefield.

We’ll also look at a law that takes effect next week and will allow women to sue New York State over allegations of sexual abuse in prisons going back decades.

headline: A Dutch court is delivering a verdict in the MH17 crash, which killed 298 people.
abstract: AMSTERDAM — A Dutch court is delivering its verdict in the trial of four men with ties to the Russian security services over the shooting down of a passenger jet above eastern Ukraine in 2014, during a Moscow-backed separatist uprising that foreshadowed Russia’s full-scale invasion of the country this year.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — A Dutch court is delivering its verdict in the trial of four men with ties to the Russian security services over the shooting down of a passenger jet above eastern Ukraine in 2014, during a Moscow-backed separatist uprising that foreshadowed Russia’s full-scale invasion of the country this year.

headline: The MH17 case: A timeline of tragedy and conflict.
abstract: The disaster claimed 298 civilian lives, and came in the midst of a conflict that foreshadowed Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine.

lead_paragraph: DIAMNIADIO, Senegal — Ask those who have watched Aliou Cissé take Senegal to two World Cups in a row and direct his team to a victory in the Africa Cup of Nations in February, and they will tell you that his country’s wealth of soccer talent is only one part of the reason.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Klingon Cat Names
abstract: A couple disagrees on what to call their new pet.
lead_paragraph: Tyler writes: My partner, who is also named Tyler, wants a second cat. I’m not a fan of cats, so he takes full responsibility for ours. I told him if he adopts another cat, I would get to name it. He agreed. But he doesn’t like the name I’ve chosen — Gowron, after the Chancellor of the Klingon High Council — and insists I choose another.

lead_paragraph: The attack severed a crucial Russian supply line and triggered a month of Russian airstrikes. Experts reconstructed how Ukraine pulled it off.

headline: What Could 20 Years’ Worth of Savings Buy on the West Side? Two Longtime Renters Found Out.

lead_paragraph: When a couple realized they could afford a down payment on a two-bedroom apartment for themselves and their young son, they focused their search on H.D.F.C. co-ops, an appealing yet vexing option for many middle-income home buyers. Here’s what they found.

headline: Europe’s Energy Risks Go Beyond Gas
abstract: Disruption of Russian gas supplies kicked off the crisis, but other energy sources also faltered, raising serious questions about Europe’s energy future.
lead_paragraph: Disruption of Russian gas supplies kicked off the crisis, but other energy sources also faltered, raising serious questions about Europe’s energy future.

headline: Poem: Self-Portrait as Collected Bones [Rejoice, Rejoice]
abstract: Michael Wasson’s poem uses the self-portrait to investigate identity within the legacy of colonialism and erasure of the Indigenous body.
lead_paragraph: Michael Wasson’s poem uses the self-portrait to investigate identity within the legacy of colonialism and erasure of the Indigenous body. This poem relies on repeated elements, attempting to make a self out of violence — the anaphora of “For,” the colons throughout, and the repetition of “rejoice rejoice.” The speaker grapples with the challenges of passive acceptance within past and current violence. “Rejoice” is religious language that means “to be glad” or “to take delight.” This language is juxtaposed next to the theft and auction of Indigenous bones and objects: “Mother, tell me/what you remember of another man’s hand/reaching into your throat,” the speaker asks. The bones keep singing “rejoice rejoice” as a way to both lament and reclaim the speaker’s and his ancestor’s bodies. Selected by Victoria Chang

headline: A Small-Town Librarian Spoke Against Censorship. Then the Dark Money Came for Her.
abstract: Now she’s fighting back.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Jones is a librarian. This summer, worried that her town might try to ban books, she spoke up at a public library board meeting about the importance of a diverse collection and preserving young people’s access to books with sexual health content and L.G.B.T.Q. themes.

headline: What Books Does Haruki Murakami Find Disappointing? His Own.
abstract: “The books I try not to pick up, and don’t want to read, are ones I wrote myself and published in the past,” says the Japanese writer, whose new book is “Novelist as a Vocation.” “Though it does make me want to do better with my next work.”
lead_paragraph: Michael Connelly’s “The Brass Verdict.” It’s a hard-bound copy I bought for a dollar in a used bookstore in Honolulu. It’s hard to put down once I start reading. Price isn’t everything, of course, but is there any other form of entertainment that provides so much enjoyment for a dollar?

headline: Should We All Go Cashless?
abstract: Do you still pay for things in cash? Or have you moved on to credit cards and digital payment apps? Will cash be someday obsolete?
lead_paragraph: Do you still like to pay for things in cash? Or do you prefer swiping a credit card, scanning your phone and making purchases with apps like Apple Pay, Venmo and Zelle?

headline: Taking Action When Needs Are Most Acute
abstract: Relief organizations and their clients have learned to adapt in order to achieve meaningful results during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series recounting the stories of people who received help from nonprofit organizations supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

headline: The Post-Mortem
abstract: In the aftermath of the midterm elections, Democrats and Republicans face key questions about the future of their parties.
lead_paragraph: The midterm elections have left both parties in a moment of reflection. For Republicans, it’s time to make a choice about Trumpism, but one that may no longer be theirs to make. For Democrats, it’s about how much of their future is inherently tied to the G.O.P.

headline: The Real Case for Donald Trump Is About Justice
abstract: To his supporters, he is an emperor in exile.
lead_paragraph: In “The Golden Bough,” his masterwork of comparative religion, James Frazer surveyed the customs according to which divinely sanctioned monarchs were relieved — sometimes violently — of their sacred office. As soon as such a ruler showed signs of weakness, suggesting that his godly powers were on the wane, he “must be killed,” Frazer observed, “and his soul must be transferred to a vigorous successor before it has been seriously impaired by the threatened decay.”

headline: America Should Open Its Arms to Chinese Students
abstract: The U.S. should view them not as a threat but as a critical source of the future thinkers who will help broker relations.
lead_paragraph: After more than four decades of cautious but steady engagement with the West, China is shutting the door.

headline: Help! I Was Banned From Lyft and No One Will Tell Me Why.
abstract: An app user was barred after just two uneventful trips, and the company wouldn’t explain or reinstate him. Our columnist gets him riding again, but transparency remains elusive.
lead_paragraph: My most recent work trip was from my home office in the suburbs to my office in downtown San Francisco and back — two uneventful Lyft rides, my first time using the platform, for some late-night video conferences scheduled in an Asian time zone. When I tried to repeat my booking the next day, I received a message that my account had been disabled. Despite a lengthy email exchange, Lyft would not tell me why I had been banned, citing legal restrictions. It’s not a huge inconvenience — I live in the Bay Area, with accessible transit, taxis and, of course, Uber — but it leaves me wondering why it happened, and about the power of large tech companies to exclude individuals from what to some is an essential service. Still, what if I want to rent a bike from BayWheels, a public bike-sharing program in my area run by Lyft? Or what if Lyft buys Uber — would I be banned from there as well? Can you help — even if to encourage some transparency in big tech? Matt, Marin County, Calif.

headline: New York City Approves Taxi Fare Hike, Raising Average Fare 23%
abstract: Passengers will also pay more for Uber and Lyft rides.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s taxi regulators will raise fares for the first time in 10 years, a change that city officials hope will boost the struggling industry.

headline: Ukraine Is Advancing, and Russia Is Retreating, but President Zelensky Has a Big Problem
abstract: The economy is in tatters.
lead_paragraph: Despite the Ukrainian Army’s battlefield advances and Russia’s retreats, most recently from parts of Kherson Province, Ukraine’s economy has been left in tatters. A prolonged war of attrition — which seems likely — will subject it to additional strain. For the Kyiv government, the cost of prosecuting the war while also meeting the material needs of its citizens will mount even if the Ukrainian Army keeps gaining ground. Worse, winter looms and Russia, frustrated by the serial military failures it has experienced since September, seems bent on crippling Ukraine’s economy by taking the wrecking ball to its critical infrastructure. On Tuesday alone, an estimated 90 Russian missiles rained down across Ukraine.

headline: The Family That Cooks Together Publishes a Best Seller
abstract: The Leung family teamed up to write “The Woks of Life,” a compendium of recipes for Chinese dishes.
lead_paragraph: As the season of holiday meal preparation approaches, here’s an interesting thought experiment: Could you write a cookbook with your family? For most of us, the answer is a resounding no, for reasons involving logistics, talent and temperament.

headline: SpaceX Employees Say They Were Fired for Speaking Up About Elon Musk
abstract: Charges filed with federal regulators accuse the company of retaliating against eight workers over an open letter critical of the chief executive.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Democrats Lost the Midterms, Too
abstract: Just because a catastrophe was averted does not mean all is well.
lead_paragraph: The surprising results of the midterm elections were understandably received by Democrats with an elated mix of relief and vindication. A president’s party normally does much worse in his first midterms, and polls suggested this time would be no different.

headline: Last Call for the Monkeypox Vaccine Van
abstract: As the monkeypox emergency subsides, the city has stopped placing vaccine vans outside nightclubs and sex parties. Vaccinations will still be available at sexual health clinics.
lead_paragraph: Michael Doshier was on his way to a party at the House of Yes, a graffiti-splashed dance club in Bushwick, last Thursday night when he got a text. “We actually didn’t go in yet,” his friend wrote. “They’re giving out monkeypox vaccines so we’re getting them!”

headline: Why Office Buildings Are Still in Trouble
abstract: Hybrid work, layoffs and higher interest rates are leaving lots of office space vacant and hurting the commercial real estate business.
lead_paragraph: With the pandemic receding, children back in school and businesses telling employees to return to the office, the companies that own big office buildings were hoping to move on this fall from a nightmarish two years.

headline: Meet Your New Corporate Office Mate: A ‘Brainless’ Robot
abstract: Naver, a South Korean internet firm, is trying to introduce robots into the world of cubicles and conference rooms without making employees uncomfortable.
lead_paragraph: The new workers zipped around the office completing mundane tasks like fetching coffee, delivering meals and handing off packages. They did not get in anyone’s way or violate personal space. They waited unobtrusively for elevators with unfailing politeness. And, perhaps most enticingly, they did not complain.

headline: How Drake’s $100 Million Bet Saved the Long-Lost Art Carnival Luna Luna
abstract: In 1987, the Austrian artist André Heller debuted an avant-garde amusement park with works by Basquiat, Dalí and Haring. Its disappearance was a winding tale. Its return is even more bizarre.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Earlier this year, in a 50,000-square-foot warehouse lined with weathered shipping containers and crates, the Viennese artist André Heller was reunited with one of the great loves of his life and career.

headline: Covid Almost Broke This Hospital. It Also Might Be What Saves It.
abstract: For decades, smaller “safety net” hospitals like Wyckoff Heights Medical Center, in Brooklyn, have been losing money and are under pressure to close. But the pandemic has shown just how needed they are.
lead_paragraph: The bearded young man suffering a psychotic episode craned his neck to get a better view of his body before looking away in horror. “Something’s coming out of me,” he bellowed from the gurney where he lay in the emergency room at Wyckoff Heights Medical Center, an independent hospital in Brooklyn.

headline: ‘Life Brought Me Here.’ An Island Nation Adapts to a Changing Climate
abstract: Droughts, cyclones and floods have forced the people of Madagascar, a poor country in the southern Indian Ocean, to find new homes, new livelihoods and even new diets.
lead_paragraph: AMBOVOMBE-ANDROY, Madagascar — From the time she was a young bride, all Taliasoa Vaolina knew was planting beans and corn to feed her family in their village in Madagascar. But three years ago, the worst drought in a generation set in.

headline: Enemies of Democracy Should Fear the American Voter
abstract: Most candidates who refused to concede that Trump was defeated in 2020 lost their own elections.
lead_paragraph: Early on the morning after the 2022 midterm elections, Governor Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan received a phone call from Tudor Dixon, her Donald Trump-endorsed opponent, whom Ms. Whitmer was projected to defeat by double digits. Ms. Dixon is no halfhearted MAGA loyalist. As the price of the former president’s endorsement (or perhaps because she’d succumbed to the big lie) she had refused to acknowledge he had been legitimately defeated in 2020. She likewise refused to say she’d accept the results of her own election if she lost.

headline: The 25 Travel Experiences You Must Have
abstract: A pair of internationally minded writers, a chef, an architect and a landscape photographer made a list of the most extraordinary adventures a person should seek out. Here are the results.
lead_paragraph: One July morning, a five-person jury — including the writers Pico Iyer and Aatish Taseer, the architect Toshiko Mori, the chef and food scientist David Zilber and the landscape photographer Victoria Sambunaris — gathered over Zoom to debate what, exactly, constitutes a “travel experience” and how some might rise above the rest. To get the conversation started, each panelist had nominated at least 10 selections in advance of the call; their job now was to slash that list from 55 to 25.

headline: Vocabulary in Context: Teen Mariachis
abstract: Test your vocabulary and reading comprehension with this quiz based on the Times article “A Championship Season in Mariachi Country.”
lead_paragraph: Test your vocabulary and reading comprehension with this quiz based on the Times article “A Championship Season in Mariachi Country.”

headline: Russian attacks on Ukraine’s power grid are endangering nuclear plants, a U.N. agency warns.
abstract: The director of the International Atomic Energy Agency called the effect of the strikes on the energy grid “very concerning.”
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Russia’s assault on Ukraine’s energy grid is endangering the safe operation of the country’s nuclear power plants, the United Nations nuclear watchdog agency has warned.

headline: Renters Are on the Move. Where Are They Going?
abstract: New migration patterns emerge as renters search for something they can afford.
lead_paragraph: As climbing interest rates, low inventory and sky-high prices push more frustrated home buyers into the rental market, rents are naturally rising too, forcing many to flee areas that have become too expensive.

headline: The Far Right Rises in Israel
abstract: A look at the improbable return of former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the arrival of the nation’s most right-wing government.
lead_paragraph: This week, Israel swore in a new Parliament, paving the way back to power for former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, even as he is on trial for corruption. Now, the country is on the cusp of its most right-wing government in history.

headline: Riddled With Metal Pellets, an Iranian Protester Heals in Hiding Abroad
abstract: Most who took part in antigovernment rallies try to stay below the radar in their own country, but some, particularly those injured in the crackdown, have been forced to flee.
lead_paragraph: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq — When Masoud, a 27-year-old computer programmer, returned to his family home in Tehran, bleeding after being shot by security forces with dozens of metal pellets, his father urged him to go to the hospital.

headline: France Urges U.S. to Change ‘Made in America’ Electric Car Policy
abstract: The French finance minister, Bruno Le Maire, said U.S. subsidies would inflict damage to Europe’s economy.
lead_paragraph: France has warned the United States that its recently passed climate and energy law threatens the economies of Europe and urged the Biden administration to enact the law so that subsidies for American electric vehicles do not put European carmakers at a competitive disadvantage.

headline: On German Stages, Women Take Control
abstract: Female-led productions in Hamburg and Munich — including an Annie Ernaux adaptation and a reworking of Ibsen’s “A Doll’s House” — pack both a theatrical and a moral punch.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — Shortly after the announcement last month that the French writer Annie Ernaux had won the Nobel Prize in Literature, there was a run on the box office at the Deutsches Schauspielhaus here: All the tickets for the theater’s adaptation of Ernaux’s 2000 memoir, “Happening,” sold out.

headline: Why the Crypto Collapse Matters
abstract: The failure of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX put the entire industry under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: How could a $32 billion company vaporize overnight? That’s what anyone watching the sudden collapse of FTX, a hot cryptocurrency start-up that plunged into bankruptcy last week, might be puzzling over.

headline: ‘Christmas With You’ Review: Pop-Rocking Around the Christmas Tree
abstract: Aimee Garcia plays a pop star scrambling to write a holiday hit in the insipid rom-dram “Christmas With You.”
lead_paragraph: When watching the dullest, most formulaic Netflix fodder, you may find it necessary to fixate on an odd element simply to stay invested. By far the sturdiest component of “Christmas With You” is Freddie Prinze Jr.’s hair. Who sculpted it to such a disconcerting spike? Did it time-travel from the late 1990s? Does gravity apply to it?

headline: ‘Blue’s Big City Adventure’ Review: It’s Gotta Be the Clues
abstract: The beloved children’s series “Blue’s Clues” gets a splashy, exuberant musical.
lead_paragraph: “Blue’s Clues & You!” is an educational program for preschool-aged children about a friendly cartoon dog. It’s a modern revival of a show from the 1990s, “Blue’s Clues,” which was about the same dog, but which had a different live-action host. The dog, Blue, helps the host solve mysteries, and the audience is encouraged to participate in the fun by shouting answers at the screen. It’s designed to subtly and enjoyably help kids practice and deepen their reasoning abilities — the series co-creator Angela Santomero has said that she intended to make “a show that would help preschoolers feel good about themselves.”

headline: ‘Bones and All’ Review: You Eat What You Are
abstract: Luca Guadagnino’s latest stars Timothée Chalamet and Taylor Russell as young cannibals on the run.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who travels the roads of America must sooner or later confront the question of what to eat. Do you prefer the convenience of interstate fast food or the authenticity of a local greasy spoon? For the footloose young lovers in “Bones and All,” Luca Guadagnino’s gory, ridiculous and curiously touching new film, the decision is more a matter of “who” than “what.” Maren (Taylor Russell) and Lee (Timothée Chalamet) are foodies gripped by a specific and exotic appetite. They will order pancakes in a pinch, but what they really crave is human flesh.

headline: ‘Bantú Mama’ Review: Lessons Learned and Taught
abstract: Stuck in Santo Domingo after evading arrest, a French-Cameroonian woman is taken in by a family of three children raising themselves.
lead_paragraph: In an early scene of “Bantú Mama,” while the protagonist, Emma (Clarisse Albrecht), is getting her hair braided by a Haitian woman at a resort in the Dominican Republic, Emma shares that she is of Cameroonian and French descent. “I’ve always wanted to go to Africa,” the Haitian braider says, to which Emma responds, in French, “Me, too.”

headline: ‘The Menu’ Review: Eat, Pray, Run!
abstract: Ralph Fiennes and Anya Taylor-Joy face off in this pitch-black satire of class and high-end dining.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing subtle about “The Menu,” but that’s a large part of its charm. Like Hawthorn, the exclusive upscale restaurant where most of the action takes place, this brutal satire of class division — viewed through the lens of high-end gorging — is ruthlessly focused and gleamingly efficient. And by unabashedly flaunting its crowd-pleasing ambitions, the script (by Seth Reiss and Will Tracy) cheekily skirts the very pretentiousness it aims to skewer.

headline: ‘There There’ Review: Only Connect
abstract: The one-acts that make up Andrew Bujalski’s film percolate with sly humor, decency, curiosity and sheer nerve.
lead_paragraph: “There There” unspools a linked series of one-acts that feels as unpredictable and alive as its characters. The writer-director, Andrew Bujalski, zeros in on the delicate dances and negotiations between the people in these two-handers, which percolate with sly humor, decency, curiosity and sheer nerve.

headline: ‘The Inspection’ Review: Boot Camp, a Love Story
abstract: Elegance Bratton’s autobiographical first feature is a lyrical, wrenching look at a young Marine’s journey through basic training.
lead_paragraph: At 25, after nearly a decade of living in homeless shelters and on the streets, Ellis French (Jeremy Pope) decides to make a change. He visits his mother (Gabrielle Union), a New Jersey corrections officer who had kicked him out of the house for being gay when he was 16, to collect his birth certificate, and enlists in the Marine Corps. It’s 2005, a few years into the post-9/11 forever wars and deep into the “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell” era.

headline: ‘Flaming Ears’ Review: A Madcap Paradise Restored
abstract: An Austrian experimental feature from the 1990s presents a post-apocalyptic world as an artist’s utopia.
lead_paragraph: The Austrian experimental film “Flaming Ears” was made in 1991, and the opening cards of the film’s new restoration note that it has been reconstructed from prints after the original negatives and sound recordings were lost.

headline: ‘Actual People’ Review: A Post-Grad Malaise
abstract: The feature debut from the writer, director and star Kit Zauhar tracks Riley, a college senior, fumbling aimlessly through the melancholy of her final days in school.
lead_paragraph: About halfway through “Actual People,” Riley, the disillusioned 22-year old on her way out of college, is told suddenly and unceremoniously by her therapist that this is the end of their final session. Good luck out there, the therapist concludes, more or less, with a smile. “Wait, what?” Riley (Kit Zauhar) says, jolting up.

headline: ‘A Christmas Story Christmas’ Review: Nostalgia Is Fragile
abstract: The cast of the perennial holiday classic “A Christmas Story” returns for this half-baked legacy sequel.
lead_paragraph: “A Christmas Story,” Bob Clark’s bittersweet coming-of-age comedy based on the semi-autobiographical writings of the humorist Jean Shepherd, is that rarest of things: a holiday movie that’s actually good. “A Christmas Story Christmas,” the new legacy sequel, is something much more common: a holiday movie that’s very bad.

headline: Facing Recession, U.K. Outlines Billions in Tax Increases and Spending Cuts
abstract: The government is betting that the plan will put public finances back on sound footing but acknowledges that the measures are likely to deepen the economic misery for Britons.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Seeking to restore Britain’s fiscal credibility after a calamitous foray into trickle-down economics, the British government on Thursday announced tens of billions of pounds of tax increases and spending cuts that officials promised would plug a gaping hole in the nation’s public finances.

headline: Cancer, My Husband’s Doctor, and Catherine Deneuve
abstract: Watching his oncologist onscreen, I finally saw our lives more fully.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: As N.Y.C. Swipes Out MetroCards, One Artist Honors the Yellow and Blue
abstract: For more than 20 years, Thomas McKean has turned the New York City fare card into art. His supplies may run out as the city upgrades its payment system.
lead_paragraph: Thomas McKean has noticed a number of things New Yorkers don’t do anymore: leaving business cards on windshields, using plastic “Thank You” bags and hailing yellow cabs. Soon, Mr. McKean, an artist, will add another ubiquitous piece of New York history to that list: swiping MetroCards to ride the subway or bus.

headline: Investor Losses From FTX’s Implosion Are Growing
abstract: The crypto exchange’s collapse is stoking fears of contagion across the industry. Meanwhile, FTX’s founder, Sam Bankman-Fried, is still speaking out.
lead_paragraph: The breadth of the global fallout from FTX’s collapse has continued to emerge. Temasek, Singapore’s state-backed fund, said on Thursday that it had fully written down its $275 million investment in the crypto exchange, joining the Silicon Valley firm Sequoia Capital and SoftBank, the Japanese tech conglomerate, in declaring their stakes worthless.

headline: New Chief Calls FTX’s Corporate Control a ‘Complete Failure’
abstract: “This situation is unprecedented,” said John J. Ray III, who helped manage Enron after its collapse in an accounting fraud scandal in 2001.
lead_paragraph: John Jay Ray III helped manage the aftermath of some of the largest corporate failures in history, including the implosion of the energy trading firm Enron after an accounting fraud scandal in 2001.

headline: Myanmar Frees Former British Ambassador and Others in Amnesty
abstract: Among those released were Victoria Bowman, the former diplomat, and Sean Turnell, an Australian economic adviser to Myanmar’s imprisoned civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
lead_paragraph: Myanmar’s military junta said Thursday it was releasing and expelling four foreign prisoners as part of a broad amnesty that also includes dozens of political prisoners.

headline: Republicans Lay Out Biden Investigations, but Democrat-Aligned Groups Promise Counteroffensive
abstract: The Biden administration has been bracing for congressional investigations, cognizant of the serious political threat posed by even a narrow Republican majority in the House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hours after winning control of the House, Republicans began laying out plans on Thursday for investigations of President Biden, his administration and his family, and were met with promises of a multimillion-dollar counteroffensive from a network of groups allied with Democrats.

headline: What the Unusual Midterm Elections Mean for Climate Action
abstract: A split Congress makes it unlikely that Republicans will undo Biden’s climate legislation, but they’re likely to try to slow it. There may also be room for agreement on infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Democrats’ strong showing in the midterm elections — both their defense of their Senate majority and their gains in important state races — essentially ensures that President Biden’s signature climate change law, passed in August, will be fully implemented despite threats from some Republicans to block or undo it.

headline: Fed Up With Political Texts? You’re Not Alone.
abstract: Californians received an estimated 163.9 million political texts in October, some of them beyond the reach of a state transparency law.
lead_paragraph: Like voters around the country, people in California were inundated with political text messages during the midterm election campaign. In October alone, Californians received a whopping 163.9 million of the messages, according to estimates from RoboKiller, an app that blocks robocalls and spam texts.

headline: A New Book Shows Sies Marjan’s Colors Haven’t Faded
abstract: Plus: bright cashmere sweaters, a chance to peek into John Waters’s art collection and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: “There’s been significant development over the past five years,” Bjorn Boyer, the co-owner and co-founder of Eastwind Hotels, says of New York’s Catskills region. The group will open its newest property, Eastwind Oliverea Valley, in the area this January. It joins the ranks of hotels like Wildflower Farms and Inness in the rejuvenation of the mountainous stretch of upstate New York that’s just a short drive away from the city. Oliverea Valley’s 30 accommodations — a mix of free-standing A-frame cabins and stylish guest rooms in a central building — mark the first time the brand, which also operates hotels in Windham and Lake Placid, has “started from scratch,” says Boyer. The interiors are inspired by the Scandinavian sentiment of hygge, with wood furnishings, gently worn rugs and sheepskin throws. Just 25 miles away is another newcomer: Hotel Lilien, an 18-room boutique hotel and cocktail bar designed by the San Francisco-based firm Field Theory in collaboration with the Lost Boys Hospitality Group, which opened for weekend stays in August but will be fully bookable starting Dec. 1. The hotel features a mix of furnishings that pay homage to the original 1890s architecture of the property. Think “a blue-green Wes Anderson-esque reception nook, Huey sconces, Mulberry duck motif wallpaper, a black-and-white checkered tumbled marble entry floor and antique Persian rugs,” all of which took “over a year” to hunt down, said Leah Harmatz, founder and principal designer at Field Theory. “We layered in pieces from different eras, just as someone who lived in a home over many decades would slowly amass an inspired and meaningful collection of furniture and art.”

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom in Bedford, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Jersey City, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A five-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath, 4,600-square-foot house built in 1986 and renovated in 1992, with a two-story entrance, an open living room and a family room with fireplaces, an eat-in kitchen, an office, a finished lower level and basement storage space, central vacuum and air-conditioning, a backyard deck, an attached two-car garage and a koi pond, on 5.04 acres. Cecilia Heller, Houlihan Lawrence, 914-318-4992; houlihanlawrence.com

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are in Bay Ridge, Sutton Place and the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, one-bath, 800-square-foot prewar apartment with a combined living and dining room that has a nonworking fireplace, a windowed galley kitchen with white appliances, a windowed bathroom, and parquet floors, on the second floor of a six-story nondoorman, Tudor-style elevator building that’s part of a two-building complex with laundry rooms and a gym. Dianne Henning, Corcoran Group, 917-974-0005; corcoran.com

headline: Children’s Groups Want F.T.C. to Ban ‘Unfair’ Online Manipulation of Kids
abstract: Children’s privacy and health experts pressed regulators to prohibit video games and social networks from using attention-hacking techniques on youngsters.
lead_paragraph: My Talking Tom, an animated video game featuring a pet cat, is one of the most popular apps for young children. To advance through the game, youngsters must care for a wide-eyed virtual cat, earning points for each task they complete.

headline: Trump Organization Finance Chief Details the Birth of Tax-Fraud Scheme
abstract: Allen H. Weisselberg came close to tears as he told how money for cars, apartments and tuition was camouflaged in the ledgers of the company he served.
lead_paragraph: The criminal trial of Donald J. Trump’s family business took an emotional turn Thursday as one of the former president’s most loyal executives laid bare the machinery of a sprawling tax fraud, scoring points for both prosecution and defense during hours of illuminating testimony.

headline: The significance of the jet’s downing has increased with the war.
abstract: The verdict offers a bare measure of justice for the 298 people killed in the downing of the jet, but it may set an example for possible prosecutions of Russian crimes during the current war.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — A Dutch court on Thursday convicted three men with ties to the Russian security services of murder and sentenced them to life in prison for their role in shooting down of a passenger jet above separatist eastern Ukraine in 2014. A fourth man was acquitted.

headline: World of Warcraft and Other Blizzard Games Will Be Pulled From China
abstract: Blizzard Entertainment is suspending most of its gaming services in China after failing to renew a licensing deal with NetEase, a Chinese gaming partner.
lead_paragraph: For years, Western video games served as cultural touchstones for many young people in China, leaving a generation with fond memories of late nights packed in smoke-filled internet cafes. Now, the next generation may have to make do with a more homegrown selection.

headline: Pelosi Steps Aside, Signaling End to Historic Run as Top House Democrat
abstract: “For me, the hour has come for a new generation to lead the Democratic caucus that I so deeply respect,” Speaker Nancy Pelosi said. She has led her party in the House for two decades.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Nancy Pelosi stepping down from leadership.

headline: A Genre-Spanning Choreographer Who Says Yes to the Unknown
abstract: Jennifer Weber has two shows opening on Broadway, “&Juliet” and “KPOP,” and her “Hip-Hop Nutcracker” is coming to Disney+.
lead_paragraph: Among the movement challenges that the choreographer Jennifer Weber has been facing lately: dodging tourists on the sidewalks around Times Square as she runs between theaters. Her first Broadway show opens on Thursday. Her second opens Sunday.

headline: Police Expected the Halloween Crowd. Why Couldn’t They Stop the Disaster?
abstract: An analysis, based on official documents and parliamentary testimony, reveals that authorities in South Korea missed crucial chances to prevent a crowd crush that would kill 158 people.
lead_paragraph: For years, officials had known that Halloween weekends in Itaewon, a popular nightlife district in Seoul, attracted large crowds, warning internally that people could be “crushed to death.”

headline: Elizabeth Holmes’s Fraud Sentence Will Send a Message One Way or Another
abstract: Ms. Holmes, founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, is scheduled to learn her fate on Friday. She faces a maximum of 20 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: [Elizabeth Holmes was sentenced to more than 11 years in prison. Follow for the latest news.]

headline: ‘Mickey: The Story of a Mouse’ Review: Disney’s Clown Prince
abstract: Jeff Malmberg’s film traces the back story of the animated animal that made cinema history and became a global symbol of wholesome, helium-pitched happiness.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Malmberg’s “Mickey: The Story of a Mouse” traces the back story of the animated animal that became a cinema landmark and a global(ized) symbol of wholesome, helium-pitched happiness. It’s boosterish and jam-packed, like many pop-culture documentaries (not just ones produced by Disney about Disney).

headline: Bringing World-Class Art, and Wonder, to Mental Health Patients
abstract: The nonprofit Hospital Rooms has commissioned leading artists to make work for British psychiatric hospitals, turning them into spaces that could rival some museums.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The artist Sutapa Biswas has works in the Tate collection and was the subject of two major retrospectives last year. But, she said recently, one of the highlights of her career was a piece that few people will ever see: an abstract mural of a night sky in a London psychiatric hospital.

headline: Read All About It: A History of Breaking News at The Times
abstract: Whether natural disasters, cultural moments or developments on the war in Ukraine, The Times has always sought fresh ways to be first to deliver the news.
lead_paragraph: Readers might be accustomed to seeing New York Times breaking news alerts flash across their phone screens or be in the habit of checking one or more of The Times’s Live blogs as they’re updated throughout the day. But delivering breaking news is hardly new territory.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Nov. 30, 2022
abstract: How does life expectancy differ among ethnic and racial groups? How has Covid changed this relationship?
lead_paragraph: Note: We are featuring this graph for two weeks at the top of the “What’s Going On in This Graph” column. On Wednesday, Nov. 30, there will be a live-moderated discussion of this graph.

headline: Steven Ginsberg Named Editor of The Athletic
abstract: Mr. Ginsberg, a longtime editor at The Washington Post, will start in the newly created role in January.
lead_paragraph: The Athletic, the sports website owned by The New York Times Company, announced on Thursday that Steven Ginsberg, a top editor at The Washington Post, would become its executive editor.

headline: Can a Piece of Tape Help You Sleep?
abstract: Here’s what experts say about the trend of taping your lips closed at bedtime.
lead_paragraph: In a video on TikTok, one person claims it gives her more energy. Others, a sharper jawline; improved skin, mood and digestion; reduced brain fog, cavities, gum disease and bad breath; and a strengthened immune system.

headline: To Level Up Your Strength-Training Workout, Embrace the Battle Rope
abstract: These bulky ropes in the corner of the gym can look intimidating. But it turns out they are an excellent full body workout for beginners that’s gentle on the body.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you’ve seen them at the gym — heavy coils of rope anchored at the middle to a post or the floor. They may look like they were brought up from a dungeon or off the deck of a boat, but they’re called “battle ropes” — and they’re an effective and safe tool for strength training.

headline: 188 Convictions Tied to Discredited N.Y.P.D. Officers Are Tossed Out
abstract: The convictions were connected to eight officers who “abused their positions of power,” the Manhattan district attorney said, and came amid hundreds of other dismissals sought by city prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan district attorney’s office on Thursday sought the dismissal of 188 misdemeanor convictions, going as far back as 2001, that were tied to the work of eight former New York Police Department officers, sergeants and detectives who have since been discredited.

headline: Meret Oppenheim: Enough With That Tempest in a Teacup
abstract: In the artist’s overdue retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, there is much to see besides her notorious pocket-size sculpture.
lead_paragraph: One of the great things about “Meret Oppenheim: My Exhibition” at the Museum of Modern Art is that “Object,” the little 1936 sculpture whose notoriety tended to overshadow the rest of her long, prolific career, gets lost in the shuffle.

headline: How Jellied Cranberry Sauce Is Made
abstract: Americans buy 75 million cans a year, with 85 percent sold during the Thanksgiving to Christmas season. Here’s how it’s made, from the farm to the factory.
lead_paragraph: Jellied cranberry sauce is one of the easiest things to prepare on Thanksgiving. It slides onto the serving plate, retaining its cylindrical shape — and even some of the can grooves. Slice it along the rings and you have perfect circles of tart jelly to serve alongside traditional American fixings.

headline: ‘The Wonder’ Review: The Hungry Woman
abstract: In this period drama, Florence Pugh plays a British nurse hired to observe an Irish girl who’s said not to have eaten in four months.
lead_paragraph: From the moment that Florence Pugh appears in the period drama “The Wonder” — seated at a table on a dimly lit ship and methodically eating from a plate while she gazes into some private horizon — you are with her. Her character, Lib Wright, looks so self-contained and so manifestly uninterested in the other passengers that you can’t help but be intrigued by her. She’ll keep you watching and interested as you follow her through this perverse, provocative story about women, their appetites and a world that barbarically tries to control them both.

headline: Navalny says he is now in permanent solitary confinement.
abstract: The Russian opposition leader has been jailed since March 2021 after surviving an assassination attempt that American intelligence agencies blamed on Russian security agents.
lead_paragraph: Aleksei Navalny, the Russian opposition leader jailed after surviving an assassination attempt, said on Thursday that he has been transferred permanently to a solitary confinement cell that would limit his contact with other prisoners and the outside world.

headline: ‘The People We Hate at the Wedding’ Review: Drunk People With Secrets
abstract: A star-studded cast led by Allison Janney adds luster to this breezy family comedy.
lead_paragraph: When two American siblings head to London to attend the luxurious wedding of their estranged British half sister, secrets tumble out in the worst ways, at the worst possible times. Allison Janney leads a first-rate ensemble in “The People We Hate at the Wedding,” a lighthearted adaptation of the Grant Ginder novel of the same name from the director Claire Scanlon (“Set It Up”).

headline: Leonid Meteor Shower: How and When to Watch It Peak
abstract: Thursday night into Friday morning will be one of the dates scattered throughout each year when skywatchers can catch a meteor shower.
lead_paragraph: Thursday night into Friday morning will be one of the special dates scattered throughout each year when skywatchers can catch a meteor shower as a multitude of flares potentially burst in the darkness.

headline: Why Does Fashion Love This Radical Anticapitalist Concept?
abstract: “Degrowth” has been the buzzword of sustainable fashion conversations in 2022. But is it a realistic goal when the fashion industry only seems to be getting bigger?
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series examining Responsible Fashion, and innovative efforts to address issues facing the fashion industry.

headline: New York City Dining Questions, Answered
abstract: Nikita Richardson, who writes the Where to Eat: New York City newsletter, tackles questions about game hen, late-night diners and ramen, no reservation needed.
lead_paragraph: Nikita Richardson, who writes the Where to Eat: New York City newsletter, tackles questions about game hen, late-night diners and ramen, no reservation needed.

headline: Meet the ‘Closer’ Who Finds the Right Words When Climate Talks Hit a Wall
abstract: Sue Biniaz is considered one of the most innovative American legal minds when it comes to climate negotiations. She once rescued a collapsing deal by using quotation marks.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — Sometime in the next few days, the moment will come. Negotiators from among 200 countries with varied interests and motives will be sweating over terms and definitions as they strain to forge a global climate agreement. That’s when the woman known as “The Closer” goes to work.

headline: Have Republicans Learned Anything From Their Dance With the Donald?
abstract: He’s running again. They’re running away. For the wrong reasons.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is done. I keep hearing and reading that, and I have no reason to disbelieve it: Announcing his 2024 candidacy at Mar-a-Loco on Tuesday night, he was less a phoenix rising than a balloon deflating. I could almost hear the helium seeping out of him.

headline: Starbucks Workers Strike at Dozens of Stores Nationally
abstract: Workers said they were protesting the company’s refusal to bargain in good faith and other anti-union activity.
lead_paragraph: Starbucks employees went on strike on Thursday at dozens of unionized locations nationwide, citing what they say is the company’s refusal to bargain in good faith and anti-union tactics like firings and store closings.

headline: A Rising Conductor Who’s ‘Not Just a Pair of Hands’
abstract: Raphaël Pichon has quickly become one of the most interesting conductors not just in his specialty of period instruments, but in classical music.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A sobering thought: The founders of the period-instrument movement, who from the 1960s or so wielded their new performance practices and their forgotten scores to shake up the staid traditions of the classical music world, are starting to pass from the scene.

headline: ‘Bad Axe’ Review: A Pandemic Family Portrait
abstract: The filmmaker David Siev chronicles his family’s struggle to keep their Michigan restaurant afloat through the pandemic in this hermetic documentary.
lead_paragraph: A ways into the documentary “Bad Axe,” David Siev’s pandemic family portrait, the director’s mother, Rachel, lashes out at him. “David, you don’t live here,” she says. “You don’t have a clue.”

headline: 21 Budget-Friendly Dinners the Whole Family Will Eat
abstract: Here’s hoping.
lead_paragraph: Feeding a family is no joke. That one doesn’t eat raw tomatoes, this one hates chicken (unless it’s in nugget form) and that one over there won’t touch anything green. It’s improbable, if not impossible, to please everyone all at once, so instead of trying to address every little preference with one finished dish, opt for recipes that are easily adapted or deconstructed at the stove or the table. The 21 below are just those sorts — with a few guaranteed crowd-pleasers like pancakes and nachos thrown in — and they are cost-conscious to boot.

headline: Weyes Blood Gives Beautiful Voice to Global Pain
abstract: Natalie Mering’s new album, “And in the Darkness, Hearts Aglow,” redirects the sounds of late ’60s and early ’70s West Coast folk-rock to a 2023 concern: pandemic isolation.
lead_paragraph: Do flower children still inhabit a dying planet? If temperatures keep rising, will there be anything left of the garden? On an increasingly ambitious series of records released over the past decade, Natalie Mering, who makes music under the name Weyes Blood, has sought answers to these riddles.

headline: ‘Slumberland’ Review: A Land of No Enchantment
abstract: This ostensible family entertainment stars Marlow Barkley and Jason Momoa, and is directed with the delicacy of a flying mallet.
lead_paragraph: There are few movie experiences more taxing than the picture that signals its eagerness to ingratiate, then spends minute after tedious minute tugging on the viewer’s sleeve to no effect. This is the salient feature of “Slumberland,” which is directed with the delicacy of a flying mallet by Francis Lawrence, whose filmography boasts more adult-oriented exercises in irritation such as “Water for Elephants.”

headline: What to Know About the U.K. Budget Proposal
abstract: The government’s budget proposal, known as the Autumn Statement, will lead to £55 billion in tax rises and spending cuts to fill a massive funding gap. Here are five takeaways.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government on Thursday unveiled its much-anticipated budget proposal as the country sinks into recession after months of political upheaval.

headline: A Candidate’s Age: Should It Matter?
abstract: Readers discuss whether a candidate’s age should affect fitness for office. Also: A caution for Democrats; going cashless; the Latin Mass; seduced by learning.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Thanksgiving Cook’s Timeline
abstract: Vegetarian salads, stuffing, pies, potatoes and more to plan a great meal next week.
lead_paragraph: My brother is hosting us for Thanksgiving in Los Angeles, right at the edge of the San Gabriel mountains, and it’ll be a team effort, but I’m in charge of the cooking. This means I can’t put it off any longer: It’s time to think things through and really get organized!

headline: Nancy Pelosi, Badass
abstract: She elbowed her way to the top of the congressional boys’ club, then distinguished herself as the most effective House leader since the middle of the last century.
lead_paragraph: When Nancy Pelosi first took up the speaker’s gavel in January 2007, it was amid soaring talk of making history and breaking barriers. “For our daughters and granddaughters, today we have broken the marble ceiling,” she proclaimed at her swearing-in. “Now the sky is the limit. Anything is possible.”

headline: Customs and Border Protection Agent Is Fatally Shot Off Puerto Rico
abstract: Two other agents were wounded in an exchange of gunfire with two people on a suspected smuggling vessel, an agency spokesman said. One of the people aboard the vessel was killed.
lead_paragraph: A Customs and Border Protection agent was fatally shot and two other agents were wounded on Thursday in a gun battle with two people aboard a suspected smuggling vessel off the coast of Puerto Rico, an agency spokesman said.

headline: How to Play the Royal Game of Ur
abstract: Learn how to play the oldest board game in existence!
lead_paragraph: Learn how to play the oldest board game in existence!

headline: The Royal Game of Ur: How to Play the Oldest Board Game on Record
abstract: For 4,600 years, a mysterious game slept in the dust of southern Iraq, largely forgotten. The passion of a museum curator and the hunger of young Iraqis for their cultural history may bring it back.
lead_paragraph: It is the end of a long, hot day of selling your wares in a market in ancient Mesopotamia, around 2,400 B.C., and you are looking for a way to unwind.

headline: ‘The Crown’: The Story of Mohamed Al-Fayed and His Valet
abstract: In the latest season, we meet the Egyptian businessman, his son, Dodi, and Sydney Johnson, his personal servant — all with connections to the royal family.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It’s 1946 in a dusty square in Alexandria, Egypt. Teenagers play a boisterous football match, and one of the players looks on curiously as the former King Edward VIII and Wallis Simpson, now the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, arrive at the nearby British consulate, their car door opened by an immaculately dressed young Black man.

headline: Lauren Boebert’s House race is nearing a recount.
abstract: The race, in Colorado’s Third Congressional District, is one of the few that remain undecided. Adam Frisch, the Democratic challenger, trails Ms. Boebert, the Republican incumbent, by 551 votes.
lead_paragraph: The closest House race in the nation appears to be headed toward a recount.

headline: What has happened in the Trump Organization trial so far?
abstract: The company’s tax-fraud trial began fitfully, stalled by an outbreak of Covid-19. Allen H. Weisselberg is the third witness, and a key one.
lead_paragraph: Allen H. Weisselberg, a loyal lieutenant to Donald J. Trump for decades, will take the stand again on Thursday to testify against Mr. Trump’s family business, the Trump Organization.

headline: Jacob’s Pillow Theater, Destroyed in Fire, to Be Rebuilt
abstract: The cultural center plans to use a $10 million gift to build a new space focused on dance and technology.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, a devastating fire destroyed the Doris Duke Theater, a hub of creativity and experimentation on the campus of Jacob’s Pillow, a celebrated dance center in Becket, Mass.

headline: Look through images of Nancy Pelosi’s tenure as speaker of the House.
abstract: Here are some enduring images of Ms. Pelosi during her speakership.
lead_paragraph: In her two decades leading House Democrats, Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California has been one of the most visible women in Washington. She was sworn in as the first woman to become speaker of the House in 2007, surrounded by the children of members of Congress. And over the years, Ms. Pelosi was often photographed as the lone woman in rooms full of men, until the ranks of Congress became more diverse.

headline: Kari Lake says she is ‘exploring every avenue’ to fight her loss, despite no sign of election-tilting problems.
abstract: While Maricopa County, which includes Phoenix, had long lines and glitches with election tabulators, there has been no evidence that the problems influenced Arizona’s race for governor.
lead_paragraph: Kari Lake, the Republican who lost her bid for governor of Arizona after running a campaign heavily focused on election denialism, suggested in a video on Thursday that she planned to contest her defeat, arguing without evidence that voters had been disenfranchised.

headline: Lab-Grown Meat Receives Clearance From F.D.A.
abstract: In a first step toward cultivated meat reaching dinner tables and restaurant menus, regulators said that a start-up company’s chicken was safe to eat.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has cleared a California company’s “slaughter-free” chicken, putting lab-grown meat one step closer to restaurant menus and grocery store shelves in the United States.

headline: Full Transcript of Nancy Pelosi’s Speech
abstract: The first and only female speaker of the House, Nancy Pelosi announced that she would step down from leadership in January but would remain in Congress.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced on the House floor on Thursday that she would not seek a leadership role in the next Congress. The following is a transcript of her remarks, as recorded by The New York Times.

headline: A Price on History? Aaron Judge’s 62nd Home Run Ball to Be Auctioned.
abstract: In a sports memorabilia market flush with cash, the ball could set a record for game-used baseballs by selling for more than $3 million.
lead_paragraph: Late in the summer, while Aaron Judge was swatting balls over fences and closing in on his historic 62nd home run of the season, a parallel fascination centered on the potential value of the record-setting ball.

headline: ‘EO’ Review: Imagining the Lives of Other Creatures
abstract: The titular character of this fantastic adventure is no Disneyfied, cutesy creature. The director Jerzy Skolimowski emphasizes his animality and un-knowableness.
lead_paragraph: The title character of “EO” — a shocking and tender tour de force about life, love, death and the wretched disregard human beings hold toward other living creatures — stands roughly four feet tall. He has large ears, knobby knees, a softly rounded belly and dark, soft eyes that see the world in blunt terms. He is gentle, observant, generally quiet, and can run with surprising speed, which he does when his uneventful life takes a turn for the disastrous. His needs are basic, his life humble. He’s a faithful friend and a dutiful worker. He’s also a donkey.

headline: What Students Are Saying About the Foods That Remind Them of the People They Love
abstract: Teenagers share the dishes and culinary traditions that have been passed down in their families.
lead_paragraph: This week we asked students “What foods are closely linked to someone you love?” The question was inspired by the essay “My Greek Father’s Simple, Comforting Bowl of Chickpeas and Spinach” by Alex Moshakis.

headline: Family of Egyptian Political Prisoner Says He Had Near-Death Experience
abstract: Alaa Abd El Fattah, who is being given nutrients intravenously, told his relatives he collapsed in prison but planned to resume his hunger strike again.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Alaa Abd El Fattah, Egypt’s best-known political prisoner, is thin, frail and psychologically unstable after spending months with little food and days without water. But he plans to resume his hunger strike again after a short break, his family said on Thursday, after visiting him in prison.

headline: Brittney Griner is transferred to a penal colony outside Moscow, her lawyers say.
abstract: The W.N.B.A. star, who has been detained in Russia since February, is facing nine years in a Russian prison on a drug charge.
lead_paragraph: The American basketball star Brittney Griner was transferred to a penal colony outside Moscow on Thursday, her lawyers said, where she will begin to serve a nine-year prison term after a Russian court convicted her on a drug charge.

headline: Keith Haring Mural Auctioned for $945,000
abstract: A portion of the proceeds from the sale of the mural, rediscovered after 30 years, will return to Mount Sinai Kravis Children’s Hospital, where the mural was originally housed.
lead_paragraph: Diane Rode, a senior director at Mount Sinai Kravis Children’s Hospital, said she remembers Keith Haring’s energy as he painted a mural before a crowd of patients in 1986.

headline: Hakeem Jeffries, poised to succeed Nancy Pelosi, would make history.
abstract: Mr. Jeffries, a Democrat, would be the first Black politician to head a House or Senate caucus for either major party.
lead_paragraph: Representative Hakeem Jeffries, the New Yorker poised to succeed Speaker Nancy Pelosi as the leader of House Democrats, is a political liberal, a former corporate lawyer and an exceedingly careful tactician who rose to the pinnacle of power representing some of the nation’s most iconic Black neighborhoods.

headline: Thierry Mugler: Nothing Is Ever Too Extreme
abstract: At the Brooklyn Museum, a tribute to fashion’s showman who built temples out of curves and proved clothing had metamorphic properties.
lead_paragraph: Manfred Thierry Mugler, the boundary-pushing French couturier whose glamazons and fembots helped define fashion in the 1980s and ’90s and who died earlier this year, famously hated retrospectives. “In the museum world, everyone knew he was against the idea,” said Thierry-Maxime Loriot, the curator at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts, the institution that finally convinced Mugler to reconsider.

headline: Ready or Not, a Young U.S. Team’s Moment Arrives
abstract: The United States arrived at the World Cup with one of the youngest rosters in the tournament. But is this new generation of stars getting its shot four years too soon?
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of Argentina vs. Mexico and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: Resignations Roil Twitter as Elon Musk Tries Persuading Some Workers to Stay
abstract: Mr. Musk, Twitter’s new owner, had given employees a Thursday deadline to decide whether to leave or stay “to build a breakthrough Twitter 2.0.”
lead_paragraph: The World Cup usually brings a surge of traffic to Twitter, and that is expected again as the tournament starts this weekend.

headline: Buffalo Shooting Suspect Expected to Plead Guilty in Massacre
abstract: The accused gunman in a racist massacre at a Buffalo supermarket earlier this year has agreed to plead guilty in the deaths of 10 people.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO, N.Y. — The gunman who was accused of killing 10 people in a racist massacre at a Buffalo supermarket earlier this year has agreed to plead guilty to all state charges against him, according to two victims’ relatives.

headline: Dutch Court Convicts 3 of Murder for 2014 Downing of Airliner in Ukraine
abstract: The victim’s families drew some solace from the verdict, which placed responsibility for the tragedy squarely with Moscow, but the men found guilty may never be arrested.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — A Dutch court on Thursday convicted three men with ties to the Russian security services and sentenced them to life in prison over the downing of a passenger jet above eastern Ukraine in July 2014, during a Moscow-backed separatist uprising that foreshadowed Russia’s full-scale invasion of the country.

headline: The Surprising Afterlife of Unwanted Atom Bombs
abstract: The Biden administration has called for the retirement of the B83 superweapon, but nuclear experts say its most destructive parts will live on indefinitely in one form or another.
lead_paragraph: What happens when old atomic bombs are retired? Last month, the Biden administration announced its intention to withdraw the nation’s most powerful weapon from the U.S. nuclear arsenal.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends checking out a chill woodworking show, a fizzy comedy and a great new Irish sadcom.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Craftsman’When to watch: Now, on HBO Max and Discovery+.

headline: ‘The Menu’ Serves Fine Dining on a Skewer
abstract: A look at how the creators of the new satirical film took the already high-pressure world of elite restaurants to a thrilling and terrifying level.
lead_paragraph: Is the new thriller “The Menu” a parody of the state of fine dining? You’d think so: A small group of people pay astronomical sums to be isolated on an island, fed ingredients that wash up on the beach by employees who are trapped there, and subjected to the hospitality of a creative visionary who is secretly filled with rage.

headline: Ticketmaster Cancels Sale of Taylor Swift Tickets After Snags
abstract: After a presale for the pop star’s Eras Tour ended in chaos earlier this week, the ticket broker canceled its plans to sell tickets to the general public on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Ticketmaster has canceled its planned public sale of tickets to Taylor Swift’s latest tour after a whirlwind few days that demonstrated not only Swift’s extraordinary fan following but the limitations of music’s dominant ticketing system.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: MH17 Convictions
abstract: Plus, Nancy Pelosi leaves leadership and the week in culture.
lead_paragraph: A Dutch court sentenced three men to life in prison yesterday in the 2014 case of a passenger jet that was shot down over a separatist region of eastern Ukraine. The men, who have ties to the Russian security services, were tried in absentia. A fourth man was acquitted.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: I attended the National Book Awards last night — in formal wear and in meatspace for the first time since 2019 — and while everyone mingled before the official ceremony got underway, I kept hearing snippets of conversation along the lines of “It’s such a great book.” That’s not surprising, really. This was a book event filled with bookish people celebrating books; there were bound to be good recommendations bandied about. Still, it was heartening. Those overheard snippets are the same ones that stop me in the course of a normal day and entice me to linger, waiting to catch the title in question, equally prepared for the thrill of discovery or the thrill of recognition. You can see the list of last night’s winners here. Meanwhile, we have our own list of titles to recommend — each of them, for its own reason, such a great book. Happy reading.

headline: Kitchen Basics for Hosting Thanksgiving
abstract: All the things you'll need to host Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: All the things you'll need to host Thanksgiving.

headline: D.C. Attorney General Files Second Complaint Against N.F.L. Team
abstract: In a civil complaint filed Thursday, the Washington Commanders franchise was accused of misusing ticket revenue and failing to refund customers’ deposits.
lead_paragraph: The attorney general for the District of Columbia filed a civil complaint against the Washington Commanders on Thursday, accusing the team of failing to refund hundreds of thousands of dollars in season ticket deposits to fans.

headline: Writer Who Accused Trump of Rape to File New Defamation Lawsuit
abstract: E. Jean Carroll, whose first defamation lawsuit faced challenges because Donald J. Trump was then the president, will sue him again over similar statements he made after leaving office.
lead_paragraph: When the writer E. Jean Carroll three years ago accused President Donald J. Trump of raping her in the mid-1990s in a department store dressing room, he denied having assaulted her and branded her a liar.

headline: ‘The Bandaged Place’ Review: A Dance With His Devils
abstract: Evocative choreography and warm performances hold together Harrison David Rivers’s play about the slippages between desire and trauma.
lead_paragraph: Movement can be more eloquent than words, as it often is in “The Bandaged Place,” which opened at the Black Box Theater on Tuesday. That’s a testament both to the expressive power of dance and to its potential, by proximity, to make language seem all the more inadequate.

headline: Takeaways from the sixth day of the trial.
abstract: Allen H. Weisselberg, the Trump Organization’s former finance chief, spent the day on the stand. He is the key witness in the case.
lead_paragraph: The tax-fraud trial of Donald J. Trump’s family business continued in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Thursday with more testimony from Allen H. Weisselberg, the former chief financial officer of the Trump Organization.

headline: An Unlikely Group Scrambles for World Cup Rooms: FIFA’s Elite
abstract: The luxury hotel set to host soccer’s most senior leaders wasn’t quite ready when they began arriving, the latest in a series of last-second tweaks to Qatar’s well-laid plans.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Luxury hotels featured prominently in Qatar’s master plan to host the 2022 World Cup, and in the more than a decade since the tiny Gulf country was awarded the hosting rights to men’s soccer’s biggest championship, five-star accommodations have risen alongside the city’s high-rise towers at an astonishing rate.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What Temperature Is a Turkey Done? And More Thanksgiving Questions, Answered
abstract: We have all your Thanksgiving turkey questions covered.
lead_paragraph: Making a Thanksgiving turkey is much easier than you think. Really! But whether it’s your first time making the bird, or your 50th, questions are bound to come up. New York Times Cooking has anticipated some of your most frequently asked questions, many of which we get year after year. Below, you’ll find the answers, and hopefully some peace of mind. Just remember: Whatever happens, it’ll all be great. Promise. (Still planning the feast? New York Times Cooking has many recipes to fill your table.)

headline: A Night Out With Old Jewish Men
abstract: The popular Instagram account threw an intergenerational party. In a temple, of course.
lead_paragraph: David Roffe, 70, swirled pink wisps of sugar floss onto sticks, thrusting pink clouds of cotton candy into the hands of young, stylish partygoers.

headline: Michael J. Gerson, Presidential Speechwriter and Columnist, Dies at 58
abstract: He composed many of George W. Bush’s signature addresses, and later, as a writer for The Washington Post, took a stand against Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Michael J. Gerson, who as George W. Bush’s chief speechwriter and one of his closest advisers composed many of the president’s signature addresses and wielded outsize influence on his domestic and foreign policies, and who later, as a regular columnist at The Washington Post, became a sharp critic of the Trump administration, died on Thursday in Washington. He was 58.

headline: Officer in Charge of Uvalde Police on Day of School Shooting Steps Down
abstract: Mariano Pargas Jr. was the acting chief of the Uvalde Police Department during the massacre. A state investigation found his decisions were faulty.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — A lieutenant who was the acting chief of the police in Uvalde, Texas, during the shooting at Robb Elementary School stepped down on Thursday, a city spokeswoman said, amid questions about his actions and after the release of video footage showing that he did not order officers to quickly breach the classrooms.

headline: Alabama Again Cancels an Execution Over Delays Inserting IV Lines
abstract: After last-minute appeals and issues with inserting an IV line, prison officials determined there was not enough time left to execute an inmate before his death warrant expired.
lead_paragraph: Alabama called off its plans to execute a man on Thursday after a whirlwind few hours in which the Supreme Court allowed the execution to proceed, but prison officials determined they did not have enough time to kill the man before his death warrant expired at midnight.

headline: Portrait of a Speaker: Nancy Pelosi’s Most Enduring Moments
abstract: From becoming the first woman speaker to leading the impeachments of Donald J. Trump, Nancy Pelosi has been one of the most visible women in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In her two decades leading House Democrats, Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California has been one of the most powerful and iconic women in Washington. When she was sworn in as speaker in 2007, surrounded by the children of members of Congress, she became the first woman to serve in that post. And over the years, Ms. Pelosi was often photographed as the lone woman in rooms full of men, even after the ranks of Congress became more diverse.

headline: 21 Killed in Fast-Moving Gaza House Fire
abstract: A family celebration turned deadly, and officials said that gasoline stored in an apartment fueled the fire and contributed to the high death toll.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A festive family gathering in the Gaza Strip celebrating a birthday and a graduation turned deadly on Thursday night, when a fire broke out and engulfed a multistory building, killing all 21 people at the party, an official said.

headline: He Was Wrongly Imprisoned at 16. Eight Years Later, He Walks Free.
abstract: Shamel Capers was convicted at the age of 16 of a murder he insisted he did not commit. On Thursday, the conviction was thrown out after the discovery of exonerating evidence.
lead_paragraph: When Shamel Capers, 24, shuffled into a crowded Queens courtroom on Thursday, he was still a convicted murderer, his hands shackled to a thick leather belt as three court officers stood close by.

headline: The Visions of Octavia Butler
abstract: As a science fiction writer, Butler forged a new path and envisioned bold possibilities. On the eve of a major revival of her work, this is the story of how she came to see a future that is now our present.
lead_paragraph: As a science fiction writer, Butler forged a new path and envisioned bold possibilities. On the eve of a major revival of her work, this is the story of how she came to see a future that is now our present.

headline: California Regents Set December Showdown for U.C.L.A.’s Big Ten Move
abstract: The leaders of the University of California system said they needed more time to consider whether to allow U.C.L.A. to move from the Pac-12, to the detriment of Cal-Berkeley.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The University of California Board of Regents on Thursday put off until next month a decision whether to bless or block U.C.L.A.’s move to the Big Ten Conference, saying it needed more time — and information — before making such a consequential call that would also affect the state’s other flagship university, Cal-Berkeley.

headline: After Years of Coming Close, Paul Goldschmidt Is the N.L. M.V.P.
abstract: Goldschmidt, a first baseman for St. Louis, flirted with the triple crown and beat out San Diego’s Manny Machado and his fellow Cardinal Nolan Arenado for the award.
lead_paragraph: As a high school senior and Astros fan growing up near Houston, Paul Goldschmidt was watching from his center-field seat in Minute Maid Park when Albert Pujols smashed one of the signature home runs of his career. It came against Astros closer Brad Lidge in Game 5 of the 2005 National League Championship Series.

headline: Why Republicans’ Wafer-Thin House Majority Is a Gift for Democrats
abstract: Democrats would have loved to keep the chamber. But politically, being in the minority will have its benefits.
lead_paragraph: Republicans handed President Biden two political gifts this week.

headline: Is This the End Game for Crypto?
abstract: What’s the point of reinventing banks, only worse?
lead_paragraph: Recent events have made clear the need to regulate crypto, an industry that grew from nothing to a $3 trillion market capitalization a year ago, although most of that has now evaporated. But it also seems likely that the industry couldn’t survive regulation.

headline: State Attorney General to Review Deadly U. of Virginia Shooting
abstract: The state’s top law enforcement official will look at how the university assessed the potential threat posed by a suspect before three students were killed.
lead_paragraph: The Virginia attorney general will review what led to a shooting on Sunday at the University of Virginia that left three students dead, his office announced on Thursday amid questions about whether the university may have missed warning signs about the suspect.

headline: Former Team Psychologist Settles Lawsuit Against the Spurs and Joshua Primo
abstract: Dr. Hillary Cauthen had said in her civil complaint that Primo, a former San Antonio guard, exposed himself to her and that the team did not take appropriate steps to protect her or others.
lead_paragraph: A sports psychologist who filed a lawsuit this month against the San Antonio Spurs and Joshua Primo, a former player for the team, accusing him of repeatedly exposing himself to her during treatment sessions while she worked for the team, has dropped her case, according to her lawyer.

headline: Capping a Record-Setting Year, Aaron Judge Wins A.L. M.V.P.
abstract: Judge, a slugging outfielder for the Yankees, swatted 62 home runs and beat out Shohei Ohtani, the Angels’ two-way superstar, for the American League’s top honor.
lead_paragraph: The notion of value shadowed Aaron Judge all season. In April, the Yankees placed a value on his long-term future with the team: $213.5 million over seven years. In October, Judge placed a value on the American League home run record: He was going for it, every day, even after the Yankees clinched the A.L. East and a first-round bye in the postseason.

headline: Biden Administration Offers New Path to Discharging Student Debt in Bankruptcy
abstract: The Justice and Education Departments said the process would be more fair and consistent for people in bankruptcy seeking relief on their federal student loans.
lead_paragraph: As President Biden’s broad plan to cancel student debt for millions of borrowers faces mounting legal challenges, his administration took a separate step that could make it easier for the most vulnerable student borrowers to clear their debts: through bankruptcy.

headline: The Power of Quitting
abstract: Society often tells us that it’s admirable to persist at all costs. But a new book by a professional poker player says sometimes you need to walk away.
lead_paragraph: Quitting is hot right now. There was the Great Resignation, in which 40 million Americans reportedly left their jobs for better ones. Then there was the recent hullabaloo over quiet quitting, in which people were choosing to do less at work. Now, there’s a new book out about the many benefits of quitting all kinds of things.

headline: Pelosi’s Decision to Step Aside Paves Path for a New Generation of Democrats
abstract: Representatives Hakeem Jeffries of New York, Katherine Clark of Massachusetts and Pete Aguilar of California were widely expected to seek the top three slots.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Nancy Pelosi stepping down from leadership.

headline: Review: On Broadway, ‘& Juliet’ (& Britney & Katy & Pink)
abstract: Shakespeare’s tragedy becomes a girl-power romp in a cotton candy jukebox musical, featuring songs by the Swedish hitmaker Max Martin.
lead_paragraph: They don’t even bother to hide the jukebox. It’s right there, out in the open, before the show starts: a chrome Cyclops glowering at you from the stage of the Stephen Sondheim Theater, of all places.

headline: Robert Clary, Who Took a Tragic Journey to ‘Hogan’s Heroes,’ Dies at 96
abstract: After surviving concentration camps as a youth, he went on to star on the hit 1960s sitcom set in a German prisoner-of-war camp.
