lead_paragraph: Robert Clary, a Parisian Jew who survived concentration camps as a youth and went on to star on “Hogan’s Heroes,” the hit 1960s sitcom set in a German prisoner-of-war camp during World War II, died on Wednesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif., He was 96.

headline: North Korea Launches Another ICBM, One of Its Most Powerful Yet
abstract: It was the latest in a series of increasingly provocative weapons tests in recent weeks, and drew condemnation from Japan and the United States.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — North Korea ​​on Friday launched its second intercontinental ballistic missile​ this month and one of its most powerful yet, South Korean and Japanese officials said, pressing ahead with its recent barrage of weapons tests in defiance of admonitions from the United States and its allies.

headline: What You Always Get on Your Birthday
abstract: Have yourself a very Robyn Weintraub Friday.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — In my time at Wordplay, I’ve mostly avoided naming a puzzle of the year or a favorite constructor. Other crossword sites bestow this honor — Diary of a Crossword Fiend’s annual Orca Awards come to mind — but after a few years of trying it myself, it left me feeling uncomfortable. Each puzzle deserves to be enjoyed on its own.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon’s puzzle is full of gastronomy.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — I am so glad that we can rely on Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon’s acrostics to mark important dates, because Thanksgiving really sneaked up on me this year. This schmaltzless, noncommercial selection is fascinating and makes for a neutral conversation piece, so appreciate it like a vegan side dish that’s still a buttery-tasting crowd-pleaser.

headline: Lesser Prairie Chickens Gain Protection Under U.S. Endangered Species Act
abstract: The new listing aims to prevent further loss of habitat for the flamboyant, stocky birds, which have drastically dwindled in population.
lead_paragraph: After more than two decades of pleas from conservation groups, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service on Thursday announced protections for the lesser prairie chicken, a flamboyant, stocky bird that once covered America’s grasslands in the hundreds of thousands but whose population has since dwindled to roughly 30,000.

headline: Kyrie Irving Could Return to the Nets Soon. A Top Jewish Leader Still Hopes to Meet Him.
abstract: Jonathan Greenblatt, the head of the Anti-Defamation League, was contacted by the Nets after Irving was suspended after highlighting an antisemitic film. On Thursday, Greenblatt said he had yet to speak with Irving directly.
lead_paragraph: When Jonathan Greenblatt, chief executive of the Anti-Defamation League, learned that Nets guard Kyrie Irving had posted a link on Twitter to an antisemitic film, he was touring a college with his son.

headline: The Parking Lot Conversation That Solidified Their Connection
abstract: When Samantha Moray drove Lanny Grossman to his car after their first date in April 2021, he knew he had to see her again. Three months later he said “she was the one.”
lead_paragraph: For Samantha Loren Moray and Lanny Seth Grossman, love has always been in the unexpected details, from an after-date parking garage conversation to a “dine around” second date to a “walk down memory lane” proposal.

headline: For the Love of Community and Artisanal Pasta
abstract: Kristina Gambarian and Ayinde Sankofa became close while working at the same restaurant. Now they are partners in life, love and business.
lead_paragraph: Kristina Gambarian had just moved into her new apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn, only days before inviting her co-worker, Ayinde Adelaja Sankofa, over. It was early November 2019, and he had missed his train to Morristown, N.J., following one of their after-work walks to the station, and an Uber would have cost him more than $100.

headline: Who’s Afraid of a Lovely Fern?
abstract: It’s just a plant — but one that takes me back to the traumatic adolescence I tried so hard to escape.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t want the staghorn fern, but the thought of owning one made my husband, Tom, so happy. On the way to our friend’s house to pick it up, he bounced in the passenger seat like a child bound for the circus as I — heart pounding, hands sweating — gripped the steering wheel.

headline: A Union That Defied Tradition Gets a Blessing From Chaka Khan
abstract: Amanda Bupp and Kim Anh Jiménez connected through Instagram in April 2019. A month later, they met in person, shared their first kiss and began a long-distance relationship.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Renee Bupp is known among friends for being notoriously punctual. But when it came time to meet Kim Anh Jiménez for the first time in May 2019, she was late, rattled, and out of sorts. Ms. Bupp was nervous to meet the woman she had been getting to know, and falling in love with, online and over the phone over the last month.

headline: He Sold an Xbox and a Printer to Afford Their First Date. It Paid Off.
abstract: Caroline Vazzana and David Lopes met as college students. Nine years later, they had a fashion-filled wedding befitting of a style influencer.
lead_paragraph: When Caroline Vazzana and David Lopes met on a double date, which they only agreed to as favors to friends, they couldn’t have imagined they would one day get married.

headline: Will Taxing the Windfall Profits of Oil Giants Fix Countries’ Economies?
abstract: Britain is raising a tax on gas and oil producers, and adding a levy on companies that supply electricity — a similar approach to that of other governments chasing revenue.
lead_paragraph: Major oil and gas companies have raked in multibillion-dollar profits at unheard-of levels. Households around the world are reeling from soaring energy prices, while governments are struggling with outsize spending and slowing economic growth.

headline: Quotation of the Day: One of Ukraine’s Biggest Battles Is Keeping the Lights On Until Spring
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Nov. 18, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “If we survive this winter, and we will definitely survive it, we will definitely win this war.”

headline: Corrections: Nov. 18, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 18, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about Harvard and Yale withdrawing from the influential U.S. News & World Report rankings of the nation’s best law schools misstated law school requirements around standardized testing for admission. Dozens of law schools are allowing applicants to take the GRE instead of the LSAT. They have not replaced the LSAT.

headline: Extreme Heat Will Change Us
abstract: Half the world could soon face dangerous heat. We measured the daily toll it is already taking.
lead_paragraph: Half the world could soon face dangerous heat. We measured the daily toll it is already taking.

headline: Out of This World: Fiction and Nonfiction About Space, Aliens and U.F.O.s
abstract: Julie Buxbaum, Candace Fleming and Jasmine Warga offer kids opportunities to learn while being entertained.
lead_paragraph: You’ve probably heard the one about my father, Stephen Hawking, believing in aliens, and maybe even the mercifully niche conspiracy theory that he was an alien himself. Well, he didn’t and he wasn’t. Although he held the view that aliens might exist somewhere in the magnificent vastness of the universe, without clear proof he remained agnostic on the subject.

headline: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Three men have been found guilty of the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 and the murder of the 298 people onboard.
lead_paragraph: A Dutch court yesterday sentenced three men with ties to the Russian security services to life in prison over the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, commonly known as MH17, which killed all 298 people aboard. The plane was shot down over eastern Ukraine in July 2014 during a Moscow-backed separatist uprising that foreshadowed Russia’s full-scale invasion this year.

headline: Why the World Cup Belongs in the Middle East
abstract: This year’s tournament is a triumph for football’s millions of fans in the Arab world.
lead_paragraph: When FIFA announced in 2010 that Qatar would host this year’s World Cup, football fans and sports pundits were left scratching their heads. Qatar, it was said again and again, had no real business hosting the tournament: The weather is too hot; there aren’t enough stadiums; the country doesn’t even have a halfway decent football team. And of course, there was the question of who would be building the sites for the games and under what conditions. As the regretful former FIFA president who had announced Qatar’s winning bid 12 years ago said recently of the country, “Football and the World Cup are too big for it.”

headline: Word of the Day: inculcation
abstract: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word inculcation has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 7 in the Opinion essay “How to Go From Homelessness to Venture Capital” by Peter Coy:

headline: Late Night Reacts to Nancy Pelosi’s Big Announcement
abstract: Stephen Colbert said that he assumed Pelosi was stepping down as party leader because she would instead “be the next host of ‘The Daily Show.’”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Banksy in Ukraine
abstract: Are you familiar with this artist? What do you think he is saying with this mural?
lead_paragraph: The anonymous British street artist Bansky unveiled his latest creation on Nov. 11: a female gymnast depicted on a war-torn building in Borodyanka, Ukraine.

headline: The Instagram Version of Missed Connections Is Here
abstract: New Yorkers are reinventing the popular Craigslist service that, in its heyday, was known for reuniting people from chance encounters.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A Hollywood Investigation on the Big Screen
abstract: It’s surreal to watch “She Said,” a film about the article that detailed accusations of sexual assault by Harvey Weinstein. Just ask the journalists behind the story.
lead_paragraph: There’s something strangely meta about watching a movie that uncovers a system of abuse in Hollywood, the world’s movie capital. But “She Said,” a new film by the director Maria Schrader, does just that, by chronicling the investigation behind the seismic 2017 New York Times article that revealed decades of allegations of sexual abuse by the Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein.

headline: N.Y. Democrats Blame Eric Adams for Election Losses. He Doesn’t Care.
abstract: The New York City mayor focuses relentlessly on crime, and critics say he lent legitimacy to Republicans who played up the issue in their midterms campaigns.
lead_paragraph: As New York Democrats sought to spread blame for their dismal performance in the midterm elections, a fair share was directed toward someone who wasn’t even running: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City.

headline: ‘Disenchanted’ Review: Middlingly Ever After
abstract: Amy Adams reprises her role as Giselle in this cluttered sequel.
lead_paragraph: It was 15 years ago with “Enchanted” that the part of Giselle, a fairy tale maiden from Andalasia flung into Manhattan to charm the rats, cockroaches and bachelors, launched Amy Adams into Hollywood stardom. (Her happily-ever-after includes six Oscar nominations.) Adams doesn’t gain much by returning for “Disenchanted,” a cluttered and noisy sequel directed by Adam Shankman from a screenplay by Brigitte Hales. Neither does the original film’s fan base.

headline: Why It Was Easier to Curb Monkeypox Than Covid
abstract: The city has pulled back its monkeypox vaccination vans as the number of cases dropped sharply.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at why the monkeypox outbreak is subsiding in New York City. And, an election follow-up: Did Mayor Eric Adams’s focus on crime hurt Democratic candidates last week?

headline: How Europe Decides Who Wins the World Cup
abstract: The global appetites of Europe’s major leagues shape talent pipelines from South America to Africa. That picks winners and losers long before the games are played.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of Argentina vs. Mexico and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: Ban on Beer Is Latest Flash Point in World Cup Culture Clash
abstract: Qatar’s about-face on alcohol signaled that FIFA, soccer’s governing body, may no longer be in full control of its showcase championship.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of Argentina vs. Mexico and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: U.S. Backs Immunity for Saudi Leader in Lawsuit Over Khashoggi Murder
abstract: The State Department said Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the kingdom’s de facto ruler, should have legal immunity as the head of the Saudi government.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Biden administration has declared that Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia should be granted immunity in a U.S. legal case over his role in the murder of the Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi, effectively blocking yet another effort to hold the kingdom’s leader accountable for the grisly crime.

headline: Empty Classrooms, Abandoned Kids: Inside America’s Great Teacher Resignation
abstract: It’s never been harder to be a teacher in America, and it’s driving them out en masse.
lead_paragraph: It’s never been harder to be a teacher in America, and it’s driving them out en masse.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "The Menu," starring Ralph Fiennes, Anya Taylor-Joy and Nicholas Hoult.
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "The Menu," starring Ralph Fiennes, Anya Taylor-Joy and Nicholas Hoult.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Including titles by Ann Patchett, Mario Vargas Llosa and more.
lead_paragraph: Including titles by Ann Patchett, Mario Vargas Llosa and more.

headline: A Hard Fork in the Road: FTX’s Unraveling and Elon’s Loyalty Oath
abstract: Sam Bankman-Fried’s DMs go public, and Congress announces an investigation. Tech’s nightmare November continues.
lead_paragraph: The balance sheet contains an apology, the in-house coach is concerned that company executives are “undersexed” and billions in customer funds remain in jeopardy. The wreckage at FTX goes from bad to worse.

headline: Secret Weed Dinners and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Who Runs the World? Ants.
abstract: Earth is overflowing with ants, but they’re no menace. Humans could learn a lot from them.
lead_paragraph: In September, scientists at the University of Hong Kong published the most complete census of ants ever assembled. The numbers are so big as to seem made up. The study estimated that there are at least 20 quadrillion — that is, 20,000,000,000,000,000 — ants on Earth. That’s about 2.5 million ants for every human being. And because the study relied on a conservative estimate for ants that live in trees and did not include subterranean ants, the census is almost certainly an undercount. “I wouldn’t be surprised if it actually turns out to be an order of magnitude higher,” Sabine Nooten, an author of the study, told The Times.

headline: What to Read During the World Cup
abstract: The competition is not without controversy, but every four years, it enthralls billions. Here are 10 books that explain its history, its appeal and its future.
lead_paragraph: The men’s World Cup is back, and with it comes a monthlong celebration of soccer and an informal temperature check of the sport. This edition, which runs from Nov. 20 to Dec. 18, offers spectacle at a cost. It will be the first World Cup played in the winter instead of the summer, to accommodate for the oppressive heat of the host country, Qatar, which stands accused of bribery and dire labor and human rights abuses.

headline: How Do You Handle Boredom?
abstract: Do you find yourself easily bored? What do you do to cope with the monotony?
lead_paragraph: Do you find yourself easily bored? Do you often find yourself exclaiming “I’m soooo bored!”?

headline: Empty Classrooms, Abandoned Kids: Inside America’s Great Teacher Resignation
abstract: It’s never been harder to oversee America’s classrooms, and it’s driving educators out en masse.
lead_paragraph: A survey of National Education Association members at the beginning of the year revealed an unsettling truth: More than half of the respondents said they were looking for a way out. That’s an astounding number of unhappy teachers. If they all quit, it would leave millions of students in the lurch.

headline: An ‘Abbott Elementary’ Writer Who Draws From Her Experience
abstract: Brittani Nichols was recruited by Yale to play basketball and fell in love with acting.
lead_paragraph: Name: Brittani Nichols

headline: What Is ‘Friendshoring’?
lead_paragraph: At the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, Bonnie Glick, then the deputy administrator of the United States Agency for International Development, was struggling to navigate the complex sourcing for essentials like H.I.V. medications and malaria vaccines.

headline: A Longtime Artist Reimagines City Landmarks
abstract: Cynthia Karalla almost fell into the Central Park Lake and was pierced by brambles to create works for a luxury condominium building — the biggest payday she has ever seen.
lead_paragraph: Cynthia Karalla has never been represented by a New York City gallery but has managed to survive as an artist here for four decades, scraping by on individual sales. So when a high-end Manhattan developer inquired about buying a large number of her pieces this summer, she was both shocked and thrilled.

headline: The Mysterious Comets That Hide in the Asteroid Belt
abstract: Comets normally fly in from the far reaches of space. Yet astronomers have found them seemingly misplaced in the asteroid belt. Why are they there?
lead_paragraph: What do you expect to find in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter? Unsurprisingly, asteroids — millions of bits of rocky debris — would be the correct answer. But recently, astronomers have found some oddball objects that appear to be misplaced hiding in the rubble: comets.

headline: Adams’s Efforts to Address Mental Health Crisis Fall Short, Report Says
abstract: The New York City public advocate, Jumaane Williams, found that the number of mental health crisis centers and mobile response teams has fallen since 2019.
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Eric Adams took office in January on a platform of reducing crime, some left-leaning Democrats feared that he would prioritize policing efforts over some of the root issues in crime, like mental illness or joblessness.

headline: Sent From David Hockney’s iPad
abstract: A new book of the artist’s digital drawings charts the seasonal rhythms of East Yorkshire.
lead_paragraph: A continent away from his perennially sunny Los Angeles poolscapes of the 1960s and ’70s, the British artist David Hockney, now 85, has turned his attention to the ever-changing diurnal rhythm of the world outside his bedroom window, in Bridlington, East Yorkshire.

headline: There Is a Way to Break Out of Our Constitutional Stagnation
abstract: States are turning back into “laboratories of democracy.”
lead_paragraph: There are two constitutional traditions in the United States. The first is the one we all know, tied to Philadelphia and the framers, the Civil War and Reconstruction. It’s the one that structures our political system and fuels some of our most heated conflicts. The second is a little more obscure, despite the fact that it shapes as much of our political life as the first.

headline: Unpacking the Psychology of Gift-Giving
abstract: What makes for a great present? Attention, empathy and a little bit of espionage.
lead_paragraph: What do diamond earrings, an old window frame, a purple bicycle, a china teapot, a jigsaw puzzle, a flat iron, instant ramen and an espresso machine have in common? They were all gifts that respondents to a not-so-scientific field survey said were among the best, or worst, they had ever received.

headline: ‘Do You Really Want to Rebuild at 80?’ Rethinking Where to Retire.
abstract: It’s a small yet noticeable shift, experts say — but climate change is causing retirees to start reconsidering moves to disaster-prone dream locales.
lead_paragraph: For a decade, Melissa and Guy Hoagland, both retired physicians in their 60s, had split their time between their homes on a barrier island in Florida and in Half Moon Bay, a small coastal city in the San Francisco Bay Area.

headline: How FTX’s Sister Firm Brought the Crypto Exchange Down
abstract: Alameda Research was Sam Bankman-Fried’s first company. He built FTX partly to help Alameda’s trading business. Then things got out of control.
lead_paragraph: In late 2017, Sam Bankman-Fried, then 25 years old, co-founded Alameda Research, a small trading firm that marked the beginning of his cryptocurrency empire.

headline: The End of Vaccines at ‘Warp Speed’
abstract: Financial and bureaucratic barriers in the United States mean that the next generation of Covid vaccines may well be designed here, but used elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Operation Warp Speed, the Trump-era program that poured billions of dollars into developing Covid shots, seemed to signal a new dawn of American vaccine making, demonstrating how decades of scientific grunt work could be turned into lifesaving medicine in a matter of months.

headline: The Mystic of Mar-a-Lago
abstract: Donald Trump gave people something to coalesce around as a communion of disdain, but it signified nothing at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: The first time I saw the hat was out West four years ago. On a reporting trip to a small fruit-growing agricultural town divided between white Republicans and Mexican and Central American migrant workers, I was invited to attend a raffle luncheon. Within minutes of my arrival, a jovial, big-bellied white man walked into the lobby of the community center that was hosting the event, wearing the hat. I was a Black woman alone. I had felt entirely comfortable there, however, until I saw the hat.

headline: In France, Victims’ Fund Struggles to Heal Terrorism’s Traumas
abstract: At the trial over the 2016 terrorist attack in Nice, bereaved family members and survivors vent frustration at a cumbersome process to obtain compensation.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For most of her testimony, Célia Viale kept her composure. She recounted the agonizing two-day wait to learn that her mother was among 86 people killed in a terrorist attack. She described a “whirlwind” of visits to the morgue, the police station and a psychologist.

headline: Will Covid Boosters Prevent Another Wave? Scientists Aren’t So Sure.
abstract: The shots may help vulnerable Americans dodge serious illness or death. But some experts believe boosters must be improved and are calling for a new strategy.
lead_paragraph: As winter looms and Americans increasingly gather indoors without masks or social distancing, a medley of new coronavirus variants is seeding a rise in cases and hospitalizations in counties across the nation.

headline: Words Were Once His Harshest Weapon. Now He Carries an AK-47.
abstract: Anton Filatov, a Ukrainian film critic, was pulled into a theater he never expected to enter: the front lines of war, where he now writes of the scene in the trenches instead of what’s onscreen.
lead_paragraph: ROZDOLIVKA, Ukraine — Before the war arrived at his doorstep, Anton Filatov, a Ukrainian film critic, said the most dangerous thing he ever carried was a fork.

headline: Anselm Kiefer Raises History’s Ghosts
abstract: On his vast estate in southern France and in two new U.S. exhibitions, the German-born artist conjures a world that hovers in the penumbra between life and death.
lead_paragraph: BARJAC, France — For Anselm Kiefer, there is no innocent landscape. The German artist, born beneath the bombs of the last months of World War II, sees in everything a cycle of ruin and rebirth. From dust and debris something stirs. Here at La Ribaute, the sprawling property in southern France where he lived and worked for 15 years, Kiefer has created a labyrinth of his obsessions in the form of more than 70 often disconcerting works installed on-site.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, November 18, 2022
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Georgia State Agency Investigating Jail Beating Caught on Camera
abstract: The videos, which began circulating on Monday, show officers entering the cell where Jarrett Hobbs was held at the Camden County jail in Woodbine, Ga., and punching him repeatedly.
lead_paragraph: The Georgia Bureau of Investigations said this week it would review the beating of a detainee caught on camera at a jail in Camden County, after videos of the incident, showing multiple correction officers repeatedly punching the man, circulated on social media.

headline: The Man Who Was Supposed to Save Crypto
abstract: The spectacular rise and fall of Sam Bankman-Fried and FTX.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, much of the crypto industry imploded, taking with it billions of dollars. From that crash, one company and its charismatic founder emerged as the industry’s savior.

headline: How to Download Your Twitter Archive
abstract: Those worried about the service’s longevity can preserve their tweets, media and direct messages.
lead_paragraph: After a mass exodus of “critical” workers at Twitter, raising fears that the site might not continue to operate reliably, some users might be thinking it’s a good time to preserve years of tweets and other data.

headline: Taking on the Climate
abstract: International climate summits are imperfect, but they have led to real progress.
lead_paragraph: At the biggest international climate summit of the year, world leaders meeting over the past two weeks have been dogged by reports that countries are falling short of their commitments to combat climate change.

headline: A Beloved Show Gets Another Life
abstract: The unexpected revival of “Neighbours,” the long-running drama that offered a sweet, uncontroversial vision of Australia, comes via Amazon. Will streaming change its nature?
lead_paragraph: In July, the ending of “Neighbours” felt definitive, recalled Sarah Mayberry, a writer for the show who has penned hundreds of episodes over 24 years.

headline: An iPhone Factory Needs Workers. The Chinese Government Wants to Help.
abstract: The government has sought out military veterans and Communist Party members to try to help an Apple supplier address a labor shortage at a major factory.
lead_paragraph: Apple’s largest iPhone factory, in the city of Zhengzhou, has been beset with production problems caused first by a Covid lockdown and then by a shortage of workers. Now, that plant is getting help from an unlikely source: the Chinese government.

headline: Twitter’s Nest Gets a Little Emptier
abstract: Hundreds of workers decided to leave the troubled social network, after Elon Musk demanded employees commit to a new “hard core” work environment.
lead_paragraph: No, Twitter is not dead this morning, despite #RIPTwitter trending on the social network last night. But its future looks more turbulent than at any point since Elon Musk took over three weeks ago, as a huge number of workers decided to quit rather than agree to the billionaire’s loyalty pledge, which involved committing to a “hard core” work routine to grow the platform.

headline: What Californians Are Grateful For in the Golden State
abstract: As one reader put it: “If we ever left California, we would just leave the country.”
lead_paragraph: The end of the year tends to make us all a little reflective. The long, dark evenings allow time to contemplate what we’ve accomplished, where we’re headed and, especially with Thanksgiving approaching, what we’re most grateful for.

headline: Kumail Nanjiani Didn’t Know He Was Playing the Bad Guy
abstract: In the new Hulu true-crime series “Welcome to Chippendales,” he plays the founder of the famous all-male revue. He swears he didn’t go full Method.
lead_paragraph: Kumail Nanjiani had read the scripts. He had shot the scenes. But when he saw the rough cuts of the final episodes of “Welcome to Chippendales,” the true-crime limited series that premieres on Hulu on Nov. 22, he had a revelation.

headline: Their Budgets Flush, Many States Are Sending Checks to Residents
abstract: Up to 20 are using some of their budget surpluses to help taxpayers deal with high inflation. But some economists worry that the payments could fuel inflation.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans received stimulus checks from the federal government during the depths of the pandemic. This year, many states have a budget surplus and are using some of it to help taxpayers deal with high inflation.

headline: How Was Russia Able to Launch Its Biggest Aerial Attack on Ukraine?
abstract: Western and Ukrainian officials have said Moscow’s stockpile of missiles was dwindling. But the assaults this week raise questions about that.
lead_paragraph: The 96-missile barrage fired across Ukraine on Tuesday was Russia’s biggest aerial attack of the war so far. But it followed months of assertions by Western and Ukrainian officials that Moscow’s stockpile of missiles and other weapons was rapidly dwindling.

headline: Markets Dip After a Week of Fed Warnings
abstract: Several Fed officials sought to temper investors’ enthusiasm over signs that inflation could be slowing.
lead_paragraph: Stocks fluctuated on Friday, ending a week in which a parade of Federal Reserve officials sought to curb investors’ exuberance over early signs that inflation might finally be slowing.

headline: Alice Davis, Costume Designer for Disney Rides, Dies at 93
abstract: She created the costumes for more than 150 singing, dancing robotic children in It’s a Small World, and for the buccaneers of Pirates of the Caribbean.
lead_paragraph: Alice Davis, a Disney Company costume designer who created the outfits worn by the animatronic figures in two of the company’s most enduring and popular rides, It’s a Small World and Pirates of the Caribbean, died on Nov. 3 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 93.

headline: The Charming Star With Soulful Eyes Happens to Be a Donkey
abstract: The “EO” filmmakers wanted to tell their story via a silent animal but felt dogs or cats were clichéd. Their choice turned out to be anything but stubborn.
lead_paragraph: Hola is the beautiful diva whose stunning features make her ready for her close-up. Tako is the brave old pro, able to take on potentially daunting tasks like crossing a stream. Marietta is the stunt performer with a particular set of skills. They are all the stars of the Polish filmmaker Jerzy Skolimowski’s “EO.” They are also all donkeys, three of six who share the titular role.

headline: As Russia raises possibility of a deal to free Griner, U.S. officials dismiss it as mere talk.
abstract: Russia reiterated its openness to a prisoner exchange with the United States involving the notorious convicted arms dealer Viktor Bout. The State Department says Russia refuses to negotiate in good faith.
lead_paragraph: A day after it emerged that the American basketball star Brittney Griner had been sent to a Russian penal colony, a top Russian diplomat said on Friday that the prospect of a prisoner exchange was increasing, and acknowledged that it could involve a Russian arms dealer imprisoned in the United States.

headline: The population question
abstract: Earth has reached 8 billion inhabitants. But more people doesn’t have to mean more greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: There are now 8 billion of us.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Now is the time for Thanksgiving prep and a few non-Thanksgiving meals.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Thanksgiving is in six days, and it’s my job to be blunt about it. Now is the time to clean out your fridge and freezer to make room for all that you’ll be cooking in the coming days, to buy your turkey, to thaw your turkey, to count your cutlery and plates. It’s time to figure out if you have enough serving platters and time to buy wine, cider, root vegetables and more butter than you think you’ll need.

headline: ‘She Said’ Filmmakers and Weinstein Victims: An Emotional Collaboration
abstract: Though the drama avoids showing assaults or even much of the producer, a survivor likened reliving the experience to “watching your own car crash.”
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Having IBS and Other Digestive Issues Can Make Holiday Dinners a Minefield
abstract: Indulging during the “most wonderful time of the year” can worsen symptoms, but experts have tips for navigating the season.
lead_paragraph: Harrison Kefford is finally looking forward to the holidays again. After having his colon removed in February, he can’t wait to eat his grandmother’s fudge and pile his plate high with something other than plain turkey. Maybe he’ll even enjoy some gravy with his meal.

headline: Ned Rorem, Composer Known for Both His Music and His Diaries, Dies at 99
abstract: A Pulitzer Prize winner, he wrote many orchestral works but was most celebrated for his vocal pieces. He was also well known for writing candidly about his life.
lead_paragraph: Ned Rorem, who was honored as a composer of beguiling music and famous for publishing revealing diaries about his life and loves, died on Friday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 99.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: A pilgrimage to the birthplace of pizza. Also in this edition: Marie Kondo takes on a new role, and 25 years of “The Lion King” on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: A pilgrimage to the birthplace of pizza. Also in this edition: Marie Kondo takes on a new role, and 25 years of “The Lion King” on Broadway.

headline: Michael Butler, Who Brought ‘Hair’ to Broadway, Dies at 95
abstract: He came from a wealthy family, but he championed the ideas of the counterculture. Journalists called him “the hippie millionaire.”
lead_paragraph: Michael Butler, a flamboyant financier and producer who brought the groundbreaking rock musical “Hair” to Broadway in 1968 and then to the world via a dozen road companies, died on Nov. 7 at a nursing home in Reseda, Calif. He was 95.

headline: Hakeem Jeffries, widely seen as Nancy Pelosi’s successor, formally asks colleagues for support.
abstract: Mr. Jeffries is slated to set in motion a long-sought generational change at the top of the House Democratic caucus.
lead_paragraph: Representative Hakeem Jeffries of New York formally announced on Friday that he sought the role of Democratic leader, a bid that would make him the first Black man to hold the top party leadership role in either chamber of Congress.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a Bollywood murder mystery, an elliptical Portuguese documentary, a Chinese drama about gay hustlers and more.
lead_paragraph: This poetic first feature from the Portuguese director Catarina Vasconcelos dwells in that boundary-blurring realm where dreams may become memories, humans can seem like animals, and fiction dissolves into fact. Over a series of spectacular tableaux shot on 16-millimeter film, Vasconcelos relates the story of three generations of her family, narrated in parts by different characters in the saga. She begins with the letters (fictionalized, we eventually learn) that Catarina’s grandmother, Beatriz, exchanged with her grandfather, Henrique, a naval officer who spent most of his time at sea while his wife raised six kids.

headline: Gucci Mane’s Tribute to Takeoff, and 6 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by PinkPantheress, Jenny Hval and Rod Wave.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: More Than 5 Feet of Snow in Buffalo Area, and More Is Expected
abstract: A storm lasting through the weekend is underway on the eastern coasts of Lakes Erie and Ontario, with snowfall rates reaching over three inches per hour.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — With Thanksgiving still days away, an unpredictable, late-fall snowstorm blew through Western New York on Friday, unleashing whipping wind and bands of snow as hundreds of thousands of residents hunkered down.

headline: A Lingering Gettysburg Battle: Where Did Lincoln Stand?
abstract: A former Disney animator has combined analysis of 19th-century photos with 3-D modeling software to determine exactly where Lincoln delivered the Gettysburg Address.
lead_paragraph: GETTYSBURG, Pa. — Four score and 79 years ago this Saturday, Abraham Lincoln stood up in the newly dedicated cemetery for Union soldiers who fell at Gettysburg and delivered one of the most famous speeches in American history.

headline: Nancy Pelosi’s Grace and Spirit as She Prepares to Step Down
abstract: Readers react to Nancy Pelosi’s announced departure as speaker. Also: The Republican House; Ron DeSantis; crypto trading; Canada’s forests.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Deadly Blaze in Gaza Strip Kills 21 People Gathered for a Family Party
abstract: The fast-moving blaze and the high number of deaths led to accusations that emergency units were too slow in responding.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Palestinian mourners gathered in Gaza on Friday, a day after a fast-spreading fire killed 21 people at what had started as a family celebration.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: This week, the late-night hosts riffed on the midterm election results and two major announcements from Washington. Here's what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: This week, the late-night hosts riffed on the midterm election results and two major announcements from Washington. Here's what they had to say.

headline: U.S. Rugby Team Fails to Qualify for World Cup
abstract: A tie against Portugal was not enough to send the Americans to a tournament they had played in six straight times.
lead_paragraph: In a stinging setback for American rugby, the U.S. men failed to qualify for the 2023 World Cup in France, after a hard-fought 16-16 tie with Portugal in Dubai on Friday.

headline: John Kerry Tests Positive for Covid at U.N. Climate Talks, Complicating Final Hours
abstract: Debate intensified over a contentious issue: the creation of a fund to help poor and vulnerable countries pay for loss and damage caused by climate change.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — John Kerry, the United States special envoy for climate change, has tested positive for Covid-19, a State Department spokeswoman said, a development that will sideline him at a crucial moment in the waning hours of negotiations at United Nations climate talks.

headline: Taylor Swift Calls Ticketmaster Woes ‘Excruciating’ in Statement to Fans
abstract: Following widespread issues with the sale of tickets to her upcoming Eras Tour, the singer wrote that she hopes “to provide more opportunities for us to all get together and sing these songs.”
lead_paragraph: Following days of ticketing drama that left millions of Taylor Swift fans unhappy, without recourse and unsure where to place blame, the singer called the situation “excruciating” in a sternly worded but ultimately vague statement on Instagram on Friday that put the responsibility on corporate partners.

headline: The Pasta You Need
abstract: Genevieve Ko swirls chile crisp into fettuccine Alfredo for a comforting, simple pasta you’ll make again and again.
lead_paragraph: This isn’t a newsletter about Thanksgiving. But it is a newsletter about the days leading up to Thanksgiving, three weeknights for fast, easy dinners. My personal guidelines for those days: Make everything as simple as possible. Don’t cook or eat anything that echoes the sweet and mushy dishes (I say this with love) of the Thanksgiving menu. And don’t make roast chicken, which is too turkeylike in a week when I’ll be wrangling a gigantic bird and its interminable leftovers.

headline: Are the Federal Reserve’s Rate Increases Working?
abstract: The Fed’s campaign to slow the economy is gradually taking hold, but officials have been particularly surprised by the job market's resilience.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve this year has raised interest rates at the fastest pace since the 1980s, making it increasingly expensive to borrow money as it seeks to slow consumer and business demand and drive inflation lower.

headline: Justice Dept. Is Said to Investigate Ticketmaster’s Parent Company
abstract: The inquiry predates the botched presale of Taylor Swift tickets this week and is said to focus on whether Live Nation has abused its power in the live music industry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has opened an antitrust investigation into the owner of Ticketmaster, whose sale of Taylor Swift concert tickets descended into chaos this week, said two people with knowledge of the matter. The investigation is focused on whether Live Nation Entertainment has abused its power over the multibillion-dollar live music industry.

headline: At the Latin Grammys, Youth and Age Were Both Welcome
abstract: Jorge Drexler, Bad Bunny, Rosalía, Christina Aguilera, Christian Nodal and the 95-year-old Angela Álvarez reaped wins at the 23rd annual awards.
lead_paragraph: The 23rd annual Latin Grammy Awards split their bounty on Thursday night — a sensible choice given the geographic, generational and sonic diversity of Latin music. In a show broadcast from Las Vegas on Univision, multiple awards went to three very disparate songwriters: the literary-minded Jorge Drexler from Uruguay, with six; the genre-crossing hitmaker Bad Bunny from Puerto Rico, who won five; and the chameleonic, style-mashing Rosalía from Spain, who earned four.

headline: Rishi Sunak, With Elite Pedigree, Must Now Sell Britain on Austerity
abstract: The country’s new prime minister must now persuade ordinary Britons that they should support his government through a painful ordeal of tax increases, spending cuts and a recession.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jeremy Hunt, Britain’s finance chief, presented a doom-and-gloom budget this week, but it is ultimately the job of his boss, Rishi Sunak, to sell it. And it is hard to imagine a more improbable evangelist than this 42-year-old Conservative prime minister and former Goldman Sachs banker.

headline: In ‘There There,’ the Actors in the Room Are Far Far From Each Other
abstract: Andrew Bujalski set the rules for the ultimate pandemic film: No one could be in the same location. That wound up including the cinematographer and director.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Bujalski felt that viewers would have only one shot to see his new movie, “There There,” completely cold. That chance came and went in June, when his eccentric, experimental and possibly unprecedented feature had its premiere at the Tribeca Festival.

headline: Taffy Brodesser-Akner Discusses ‘Fleishman Is in Trouble’
abstract: The journalist talks about her debut novel, and Neil Gaiman discusses “Norse Mythology.”
lead_paragraph: For the next few months, we’re sharing some of our favorite conversations from the podcast’s archives. This week’s segments first appeared in 2019 and 2017, respectively.

headline: New York Post Takes Aim at Trump, and Hits a Nerve
abstract: The paper’s increasingly harsh coverage has gotten the news media and political worlds talking about whether the Murdoch media empire has broken permanently from the former president.
lead_paragraph: Since Election Day last week, The New York Post’s front pages have been merciless to former President Donald J. Trump. First, the paper heralded his political rival, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, as “DeFUTURE.” A day later, it illustrated Mr. Trump as Humpty Dumpty about to have a great fall.

headline: Love Letter: Knowing Your Trigger
abstract: Why did a fern, of all things, fill her with fear?
lead_paragraph: For two decades, Julie Buckner Armstrong would walk into the street to avoid the staghorn ferns that thrived in her Florida neighborhood.

headline: Lauren Boebert’s Rival, Adam Frisch, Concedes Their Colorado House Race
abstract: Ms. Boebert and Mr. Frisch have been locked in one of the country’s closest contests as she seeks a second term in the House.
lead_paragraph: In one of the country’s closest House races, Adam Frisch, a Democrat challenging Representative Lauren Boebert of Colorado, a far-right gunslinger known for her provocations on Capitol Hill, said on Friday that he had called her to concede, as Ms. Boebert appeared increasingly likely to win a second term. The Associated Press has not called the contest.

headline: Garland Names Special Counsel for Trump Inquiries
abstract: Even before Mr. Garland’s announcement, there were signs that prosecutorial activity in both cases was accelerating after a brief slowdown in the run-up to the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Merrick B. Garland appointed a special counsel on Friday to take over two major criminal investigations involving former President Donald J. Trump, examining his role in events leading up to the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol and his decision to retain sensitive government documents at his home in Florida.

headline: The State of the N.F.L.’s Playoff Push
abstract: Who's a virtual lock for the postseason, according to The Upshot's playoff simulator, and who has work to do?
lead_paragraph: Who's a virtual lock for the postseason, according to The Upshot's playoff simulator, and who has work to do?

headline: Raising Millions at Hollywood’s ‘Mom Prom’
abstract: Female stars ruled the night at the Baby2Baby gala, which brought in donations of more than $10 million in service of families in poverty.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Glamour, altruism and cognitive dissonance hung in the air.

headline: Trump Organization’s Lawyers Try to Pin Blame on Former Finance Chief
abstract: Allen H. Weisselberg, a longtime employee and the trial’s key witness, finished testifying Friday in an appearance that bared the company’s inner workings.
lead_paragraph: Allen H. Weisselberg, the longtime chief financial officer of Donald J. Trump’s family business, finished testifying against the employer he has served for a half century on Friday, capping the most eventful week of the Trump Organization’s tax fraud trial thus far.

headline: I Was the Head of Trust and Safety at Twitter. This Is What Could Become of It.
abstract: Elon Musk’s brand of radical transformation has unavoidable limits.
lead_paragraph: This month, I chose to leave my position leading trust and safety at Elon Musk’s Twitter.

headline: A Cinematic Los Angeles Apartment With Nods to David Bowie
abstract: The designer Tiffany Howell transformed a well-loved home once shared by her clients with their many college roommates into a sophisticated ’70s-inspired sanctuary.
lead_paragraph: Every home keeps the stories of its past inhabitants, but in the case of a 2,200-square-foot apartment in a stately 1923 building in Los Angeles’s Koreatown, the current occupants — he a cinematographer and she a TV writer — are also its resident historians. In 2007, as undergraduates, they hit it off at a party there shortly after the cinematographer had moved into the place with other students from the University of Southern California. In his subsequent years as a tenant, roommates came and went, and the five-bedroom living quarters housed such items as a bar stolen from a film set and a taxidermy deer and wildebeest that faced off across the living room.

headline: Elon Musk’s Twitter Teeters on the Edge After Another 1,200 Leave
abstract: Mr. Musk sent emails on Friday asking to learn about Twitter’s underlying technology as key infrastructure teams have been decimated.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk sent a flurry of emails to Twitter employees on Friday morning with a plea.

headline: Oil Prices Slide as Investors Worry Energy Demand Is Slowing
abstract: The U.S. benchmark oil price fell to about $80 a barrel on Friday, and gasoline prices in some states are now close to $3 a gallon.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Saudi Arabia is slashing oil exports. U.S. crude oil in storage is dropping. Members of the European Union will soon sharply reduce how much fuel they buy from Russia.

headline: F.D.A. Approves a Drug That Can Delay Type 1 Diabetes
abstract: The therapy will cost nearly $200,000. But it’s the first treatment in 100 years to alter the course of the disease, which usually begins in adolescence.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first treatment that can delay — possibly for years — the onset of Type 1 diabetes, a disease that often emerges in teenagers.

headline: Who Is Jack Smith, the New Special Counsel?
abstract: Mr. Smith will take on the role of special counsel after leaving his current position as a specialist prosecutor based in The Hague investigating war crimes.
lead_paragraph: Jack Smith, the Justice Department’s newly appointed special counsel, will come to the task of investigating former President Donald J. Trump with a wealth of experience: He has been prosecuting criminal cases for nearly three decades.

headline: Review: Two Debuts Make for a Week of Philharmonic Firsts
abstract: The Philharmonic began to simulcast concerts on the 50-foot media wall in its lobby. Led by Hannu Lintu, they were some of the best this season.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic is still rolling out the features of its new home, the freshly gut-renovated David Geffen Hall.

headline: A New Effort to Help Places Mired in Poverty
abstract: Should people move to jobs or should jobs move to people? Lately the Biden administration has been tilting toward the latter.
lead_paragraph: Should people move to jobs or should jobs move to people? It’s a long-running debate. Lately the Biden administration has been tilting toward the latter. It’s directing $1 billion in Build Back Better money to strengthening clusters of employers in parts of the country where high-paying jobs are scarce.

headline: Three Couples Go All In on a Portuguese Dream Home
abstract: Plus: a forager’s haven in the Bavarian Alps, a lakefront retreat in southern Sri Lanka and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to T Wanderlust, a new travel newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Twice a month, we’ll recommend global destinations and hotels worth visiting. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every other Friday, along with our T List newsletter each Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Are You a Member of Gen Z Spending Too Much on Your Housing?
abstract: With today’s inflation and skyrocketing housing costs, 30 percent of monthly income designated for rent might not cut it. We want to hear from members of Gen Z on their experiences.

headline: The Case for a Less-Effective Altruism
abstract: How we think about philanthropy.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, I took my family to Harkness Memorial State Park, a spread of green lawns and gardens that occupies a point on the Connecticut shore just southwest of New London. We visited a great many state parks during the worst Covid months, wandering and climbing and killing time outdoors, but this was our first visit to Harkness, and we timed it well: It was one of those November late afternoons where the landscape still has just enough of fall for the setting sun to sharpen all the colors, and the varied monuments of the park — a carriage house, an Italianate garden, a Renaissance Revival mansion, a former windmill — assumed a kind of hyperreality against the stark backdrop of the grass and sky and sea.

headline: Review: A Composer Reconstructs Painful Family Stories
abstract: For the New York premiere of “Travel Guide to Nicaragua,” Michael Gordon sifted through a few mementos and fragments of scant narratives.
lead_paragraph: Shaping memories into a complete narrative can often be like creating a mosaic. It may call for picking up certain shards — one’s own tactile recollection here, a story inherited from an elder there — and piecing those bits together to form a new whole. One such reinvention is the composer Michael Gordon’s dreamlike “Travel Guide to Nicaragua,” which had its New York premiere on Thursday night at Zankel Hall after its debut on Wednesday at the Congregation Rodeph Shalom synagogue in Philadelphia.

headline: Wonking Out: Why Interest Rates (Probably) Won’t Stay High
abstract: To predict where rates will land, look beyond the pandemic fallout.
lead_paragraph: Bubbles seem to be bursting everywhere. Cryptocurrency is the most obvious example, but as I noted in my latest column, the decline in crypto prices has been more or less matched by the decline in high-flying tech stocks: You would have lost roughly the same amount of money buying Meta stock last year as you would have lost buying Bitcoin.

headline: Prosecution and Defense Sum Up in Oath Keepers Sedition Trial
abstract: Both sides presented closing arguments in the trial of Stewart Rhodes and four other members of the far-right militia. They have been charged with seditious conspiracy for their roles in the Jan. 6 Capitol attack.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors at the sedition trial of five members of the Oath Keepers militia made their final remarks to the jury on Friday, saying that the far-right organization, under the direction of its leader, Stewart Rhodes, strove after the 2020 election to stop Joseph R. Biden Jr. from entering the White House in a sweeping plot that culminated in the violent assault on the Capitol.

headline: Justice Department Asks Supreme Court to Let Student Debt Cancellation Proceed
abstract: The Biden administration is asking the court to overturn a nationwide injunction imposed by an appeals court.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration asked the Supreme Court on Friday to allow its student loan relief plan to go forward, arguing that delaying enactment of a proposal to cancel billions of dollars in debt would leave borrowers in limbo.

headline: Novak Djokovic Finds Harmony and a Lot of Wins
abstract: Djokovic missed long stretches of the tennis season because he has refused to get vaccinated against Covid-19. That has only made him more determined.
lead_paragraph: TURIN, Italy — He has been detained and then deported from one country and barred from entering two others that are major stops on the tennis circuit.

headline: Ukrainian Teenager Who Fled War Will Play at Carnegie Hall
abstract: Dmytro Tishyn, who left his hometown with only a backpack and his father’s bassoon, will be playing with the New York Youth Symphony on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Dmytro Tishyn, a 16-year-old Ukrainian bassoonist who fled the Russian invasion this year, is preparing for a New York Youth Symphony concert at Carnegie Hall on Sunday.

headline: Judge Blocks Student Housing Firm From Collecting $14 Million
abstract: The ruling is the latest twist in an ongoing battle that Nelson Partners Student Housing has waged with investors and students.
lead_paragraph: A Texas judge temporarily blocked an embattled student housing operator from using the $14 million in commissions it received from the sale last month of a student housing complex in Arizona.

headline: Digging In for Winter
abstract: A slow grind on the battlefield appears likely in the coming months.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Keith Levene, Public Image Ltd.’s Buzz-Saw Guitarist, Dies at 65
abstract: Considered a post-punk pioneer, he was also a founding member of the Clash but left before it became one of the biggest bands of its era.
lead_paragraph: Keith Levene, a founding member of the seminal British bands the Clash and Public Image Ltd. whose slashing yet melodic fretwork helped define the sound of post-punk guitar, died on Nov. 11 at his home in Norfolk, England. He was 65.

headline: Suspect in University of Virginia Shooting Had Guns in His Dorm Room, Report Says
abstract: Authorities found a semiautomatic rifle, a pistol and ammunition, according to a local newspaper.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — The suspect in the shooting deaths this week of three fellow University of Virginia students had a semiautomatic rifle, a pistol, ammunition and a device designed to increase a weapon’s rate of fire in his dorm room on campus, according to a police search warrant inventory obtained by The Daily Progress, a local newspaper.

headline: Manhattan D.A. Slams Brakes on Prosecution of Woman in Husband’s Death
abstract: Tracy McCarter was charged with killing her estranged husband. District Attorney Alvin L. Bragg said he was not convinced of her guilt.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan district attorney’s office will halt the prosecution of Tracy McCarter, a woman charged with murder in 2020 after her estranged husband died of a stab wound after a confrontation with her, according to a letter sent to the judge presiding over the case.

headline: At Danksgiving, There’s No Need to Go Outside for a Smoke
abstract: For a certain kind of Thanksgiving celebration, cannabis — in all its forms — is a key component of the year’s biggest meal.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was a Thanksgiving tablescape like any other: Pumpkin pie, mashed potatoes and stewed greens jockeyed for space with elaborate flower arrangements, plenty of elbows and reaching hands.

headline: Elizabeth Holmes Is Sentenced to More Than 11 Years for Fraud
abstract: Ms. Holmes was convicted in January of four counts of fraud for deceiving investors with claims about her blood testing start-up Theranos.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the failed blood-testing start-up Theranos, was sentenced to more than 11 years in prison on Friday for defrauding investors about her company’s technology and business dealings.

headline: Hakeem Jeffries, Pressing to Lead Democrats, Marks a Generational Shift
abstract: The congressman, who has served in the House for a decade, would be a far different leader from Speaker Nancy Pelosi, whom he is running to succeed.
lead_paragraph: Standing on the Senate floor during President Donald J. Trump’s 2020 impeachment trial, Representative Hakeem Jeffries, Democrat of New York, laid out the case for convicting and removing Mr. Trump, whose lawyer had just asked: “Why are we here?”

headline: Ohio Authorities Link Man to 1978 Murder and Say He May Have Killed 3 Others
abstract: Prosecutors said that Ralph Howell, who died in 1985, raped and murdered a Cincinnati college student, and are convinced he was a serial killer.
lead_paragraph: From October 1976 to April 1978, at least four young women, three of them teenagers, were found raped and murdered in the Cincinnati area. One of them was Cheryl Thompson, a freshman at the University of Cincinnati, who left home to meet her boyfriend at a disco one night and was found strangled to death on a riverbank two weeks later.

headline: A Family's Quest for the Perfect Tequila
abstract: The Jose Cuervo family has been crafting tequila for generations. When they celebrated their 200th anniversary, they decided to share their premium Reserva de La Familia tequila with the world.
lead_paragraph: The Jose Cuervo family has been crafting tequila for generations. When they celebrated their 200th anniversary, they decided to share their premium Reserva de La Familia tequila with the world.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What Employees Does Twitter Need, Anyway?
abstract: The many departures have set off a wave of hand-wringing about whether the site can continue to operate well.
lead_paragraph: The resignations of more than 1,000 Twitter employees this week included many people who kept the site running smoothly and protected it from hackers. Their departures set off a wave of hand-wringing about whether the site will continue to operate well.

headline: As More Top Law Schools Boycott Rankings, Others Say They Can’t Afford to Leave
abstract: Four schools joined Yale and Harvard’s rebellion against U.S. News. And the bar association will no longer require schools to mandate the LSAT or GRE. But rankings still matter.
lead_paragraph: For more than 30 years, roughly the same 14 law schools have been the most highly rated by U.S. News, fluctuating only slightly. The list has been so set in amber that people refer to it as the T14. Graduating from schools on this list can make a material difference in careers, from salary to Supreme Court clerkships.

headline: What Is a Special Counsel? Here’s What You Need to Know.
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump’s continuing presence on the political scene has prompted the appointment of a third special counsel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Merrick B. Garland’s appointment on Friday of Jack Smith, a longtime prosecutor, as a special counsel to oversee two criminal inquiries involving former President Donald J. Trump renewed attention on a position that has played a significant role in politically charged investigations in recent years. Here’s a closer look.

headline: 3 Women Are Fatally Stabbed in Queens Home
abstract: A grandmother, her daughter and stepdaughter were found dead by a home health aide.
lead_paragraph: Three women — a mother, her daughter and her stepdaughter — were found stabbed to death in a Queens home on Friday morning, the police said.

headline: Sheriff’s Report on ‘Rust’ Shooting Doesn’t Find Source of Live Rounds
abstract: A central question in the death of the film’s cinematographer was unanswered in the report delivered to prosecutors, who previously indicated that up to four people could be charged.
lead_paragraph: A 551-page report detailing the investigation by the Santa Fe County Sheriff’s Office into the fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the film “Rust” last year painted a picture of a chaotic movie shoot but did not answer one of the fundamental questions of the case: How did live ammunition make its way onto the set, against the rules, and into the gun Alec Baldwin was practicing with that day?

headline: A Georgia judge allows another Saturday of early voting in the Senate runoff, a victory for Democrats.
abstract: Democrats had argued that a 2016 state law restricting early voting on a Saturday near a federal holiday, in this case Thanksgiving, would unfairly disenfranchise voters in the state’s runoff election for Senate.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A Fulton County judge ruled on Friday that early voting in Georgia’s runoff election for Senate could be held on the Saturday after Thanksgiving, rejecting arguments that such a move was barred under state law.

headline: Maryland Finds That for Hundreds of Clergy Abuse Victims, ‘No Parish Was Safe’
abstract: The state attorney general investigated more than 80 years of sexual and physical abuse in the Archdiocese of Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: The attorney general of Maryland has identified more than 600 young victims of clergy sexual abuse over the course of 80 years in the Archdiocese of Baltimore, according to a court document filed Thursday.

headline: Democratic Centrists Lament Missed Opportunities to Keep the House
abstract: After an election this close, Democrats are debating whether losing the majority was so inevitable after all.
lead_paragraph: All of the Democratic cheers about the party’s surprisingly strong midterm showing have drowned out a running argument on the left that never ends: Whose political philosophy had it right, centrists or progressives?

headline: Russia Raises Hopes for Griner’s Release, but U.S. Says It’s Just Talk
abstract: The State Department says Russia refuses to negotiate seriously to free the basketball star Brittney Griner, who was sent to a penal colony with a nine-year sentence on a cannabis charge.
lead_paragraph: A day after the American basketball star Brittney Griner was sent to a Russian penal colony, a top Russian diplomat said on Friday that the prospect of a prisoner exchange was increasing, and acknowledged that it could involve a Russian arms dealer imprisoned in the United States.

headline: Carol Leigh, Who Sought a New View of Prostitution, Dies at 71
abstract: She was serious about issues related to sex for money. But she also spoke through an amusing persona she called Scarlot Harlot.
lead_paragraph: Carol Leigh, who sought to change the image and treatment of sex workers — a term she is generally credited with coining — through both mainstream advocacy work and her colorful performances and writings under the name Scarlot Harlot, died on Wednesday at her home in San Francisco. She was 71.

headline: Wall St. Brokers Look to Buy Rights to Assets Trapped on FTX
abstract: Customers could be offered pennies on the dollar for what they lost when the crypto exchange filed for bankruptcy last week.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street brokers are circling the ruins of FTX, offering to pay the crypto exchange’s customers pennies on the dollar for the bankruptcy rights to their trapped cash and cryptocurrency on the platform, before looking to sell those rights to specialist hedge funds.

headline: Iranian Protesters Attack Khomeini’s Childhood Home as Unrest Spreads
abstract: The house where the Islamic revolution’s founder grew up was set on fire during a fresh surge of anger over the government’s killing of children, including three in the city of Izeh.
lead_paragraph: Three months into a nationwide uprising, Iranian protesters have turned their fury against the founder of the Islamic revolution and of the country’s theocracy, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

headline: Staughton Lynd, Historian and Activist Turned Labor Lawyer, Dies at 92
abstract: After being blacklisted from academia for his antiwar activity, he became an organizer among steel workers in the industrial Midwest.
lead_paragraph: Staughton Lynd, a historian and lawyer who over a long and varied career organized schools for Black children in Mississippi, led antiwar protests in Washington and fought for labor rights in the industrial Midwest, died on Thursday in the town of Warren, in northeast Ohio. He was 92.

headline: Like a Charm
abstract: Benji Goldsmith’s debut puzzle might make you go into overtime.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Themeless debut puzzles are rare birds. Benji Goldsmith is the 75th new Times constructor this year — but only the second to make a debut on a Saturday. (There are a few more Friday debuts, but they still make up a small percentage of the 75 firsts.)

headline: Ohio Man Who Blamed Trump for Storming of Capitol Gets 3 Years in Prison
abstract: Dustin Byron Thompson, 38, an unemployed exterminator from Columbus, based his defense on the argument that he had been following orders from the president on Jan. 6, 2021.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio man who said that Donald J. Trump was responsible for his decision to storm the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and steal a bottle of bourbon and a coat rack was sentenced on Friday to three years in prison, the authorities said.

headline: Quotation of the Day: French Fund for Victims Does Little to Heal Terrorism’s Traumas
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Nov. 19, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “It seems that having your mother crushed by a 19-ton truck in an attack is not a reason for a traumatic grief.”

headline: Corrections: Nov. 19, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 19, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about an Iranian protester who fled to Iraq after being shot and wounded during an antigovernment protest in Tehran described incorrectly the injuries suffered by the protester. He was shot and wounded by metal pellets, but not blinded by a rubber bullet.

headline: Kim Jong-un Takes His Daughter to Missile Test Launch
abstract: Little is known about North Korea’s ruling family. Yesterday was the first public appearance of the child, who is thought to be named Ju-ae.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — As North Korea fired its largest ballistic missile on Friday, the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, appeared at the launch along with his wife, Ri Sol-ju, and a young girl who had never been publicly seen before.

headline: Train service between Kyiv and Kherson is restored after nine months.
abstract: A train, carrying 200 passengers, made the 11-hour journey for the first time since Ukraine retook the city, a senior official said.
lead_paragraph: The first train from Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, to Kherson since before Russia’s invasion arrived on Saturday after an 11-hour journey, a step in reconnecting the vital southern city a week after Ukrainian troops wrested control back from Russian occupation.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Brooklyn’s in the House. And the Senate.
abstract: With Hakeem Jeffries and Chuck Schumer poised to lead the Democrats in Washington, the New York borough that they live in enters the political spotlight.
lead_paragraph: In the Jonathan Lethem novel “Motherless Brooklyn,” readers learn the phrase “Tell your story walking.” It’s a quintessentially Brooklyn sentiment: I will listen to you, sure, but keep it moving.

headline: How Fairfield University Ended Up With Few Low-Income Students
abstract: Fairfield has the lowest percentage of Pell Grant recipients of any college in the United States. But was it a choice?
lead_paragraph: FAIRFIELD, Conn. — Last night, the first official basketball game at Fairfield University’s brand-new, 85,000-square-foot Leo D. Mahoney Arena took place. The building, which cost $51 million, takes pride of place in the center of campus.

headline: Former Anti-Abortion Leader Alleges Another Supreme Court Breach
abstract: Years before the leaked draft opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, a landmark contraception ruling was disclosed, according to a minister who led a secretive effort to influence justices.
lead_paragraph: As the Supreme Court investigates the extraordinary leak this spring of a draft opinion of the decision overturning Roe v. Wade, a former anti-abortion leader has come forward claiming that another breach occurred in a 2014 landmark case involving contraception and religious rights.

headline: With nearly half of Ukraine’s energy grid knocked out, Zelensky says 17 regions face a ‘difficult situation.’
abstract: As temperatures drop into the 30s Fahrenheit and winter closes in, Ukraine is grappling with energy supply problems caused by Moscow’s relentless bombardment of the country’s infrastructure, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine says.
lead_paragraph: As temperatures drop into the 30s Fahrenheit and winter closes in, Ukraine is grappling with energy supply problems caused by Moscow’s relentless bombardment of the country’s infrastructure, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine says.

headline: Meet the Designer Behind Naomi Biden’s Pre-Wedding Look
abstract: Naomi Biden, President Biden’s granddaughter, wore a transitional outfit designed by Danielle Frankel to her rehearsal and dinner last weekend.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, after working for the designer Vera Wang for three years, Danielle Frankel debuted her own atelier line of wedding apparel, with a focus on hand-sewn garments and a discerning eye for draping and intricate details. She quickly became a sought-after label, dressing celebrities like Zoë Kravitz, Julia Garner and Alexandra Daddario for their weddings.

headline: When Siblings Argue Over the Costs of a Parent’s Estate, Who Wins?
abstract: When one sibling becomes the trustee, they take on the responsibility of settling the estate, including whatever debts remain.
lead_paragraph: Q: My sister is the trustee for my mother’s estate, which was held in trust. She also inherited the house my mother lived in. My brother also lived there for seven years as my mother’s caregiver. In February my sister transferred the house into her name, and in June she started eviction proceedings against my brother. He vacated in September. My brother and I just received notice that my sister is billing beneficiaries for household expenses: utilities, taxes, gardener, phone and an eviction attorney. Shouldn’t any house expenses after the home was recorded in her name be her responsibility?

headline: How to Tell the Difference Between Regular Distraction and A.D.H.D.
abstract: Everyone has bouts of distraction and forgetfulness. Here’s when psychiatrists diagnose it as something clinical.
lead_paragraph: Do you: Cut the tags out of your clothes? Relive (and regret) past conversations? Have episodes of burnout and fatigue? Zone out while someone is talking? Become hyper-focused while working on a project? Take on dozens of hobbies? Daydream? Forget things?

headline: A Gen Z Fashion Heir Puts His Stamp on the Family Business
abstract: Jean Arnault, the 24-year-old son of the luxury goods titan Bernard Arnault, is introducing a new watchmaking prize from Louis Vuitton.
lead_paragraph: An omnipotent billionaire. A clutch of heirs primed to take over the family business. Speculation over which successors are in favor.

headline: Georgia Senate Rivals, With Little Time to Spare, Sprint Toward Runoff
abstract: Herschel Walker and Senator Raphael Warnock have only a few weeks to campaign, and Senate control is no longer at stake — which has both scrambled the race and left it largely unchanged.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — As Republicans steamed this week over an underwhelming midterm performance, Herschel Walker wanted to talk about another subject altogether: vampires and werewolves.

headline: A Broadway Star Celebrates a Different Kind of Opening Night
abstract: Robbie Fairchild, a Tony-nominated former principal dancer for the New York City Ballet, opens the doors to his floral-arrangement business.
lead_paragraph: The storefront was lit up like a stage. People passed by, bundled up, peering into the action. Inside, a small group of friends sipped bubbly, greeted one another with hugs and air kisses and cheered along to a performance by the Broadway performer Jay Armstrong Johnson.

headline: Naomi Biden, President’s Granddaughter, Is Wed at the White House
abstract: The wedding took place on the South Lawn on Saturday morning. A reception with dessert and dancing was to follow in the evening.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Naomi Biden, the eldest grandchild of President Biden, and Peter Neal were married in a private ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House on Saturday morning. It was the quintessential Biden affair: planned by the close-knit family and a handful of trusted aides.

headline: Gauging Our Return to Office and the Subways, One Tip at a Time
abstract: It has been over a year since buskers, and their music, returned underground, and their slightly fuller tip jars and instrument cases suggest things may be looking up.
lead_paragraph: As Azusa Dance belted out the chorus of Aretha Franklin’s “Chain of Fools” just past the turnstiles at the 34th Street-Herald Square subway station, a man dropped a dollar bill into her pink bin. “Thank you, darling,” she said with a bow.

headline: What if You Could Go to the Hospital … at Home?
abstract: Hospital-at-home care is an increasingly common option, and it is often a safer one for older adults. But the future of the approach depends on federal action.
lead_paragraph: Late last month, Raymond Johnson, 83, began feeling short of breath. “It was difficult just getting around,” he recently recalled by phone from his apartment in the Jamaica Plain neighborhood in Boston. “I could barely walk up and down the stairs without tiring.”

headline: Hundreds of Protesters in Iran Blinded by Metal Pellets and Rubber Bullets
abstract: Security forces have been firing ammunition that has ruptured the eyes of antigovernment demonstrators in the past two months. “Everything went dark,” one said.
lead_paragraph: The protester was speeding toward a demonstration in Tehran on his motorbike when an Iranian security officer standing 10 feet away raised his gun and fired a rubber bullet.

headline: President Biden Is Turning 80. Experts Say Age Is More Than a Number.
abstract: The New York Times spoke to 10 experts in aging to paint a picture of what the next six years might look like for a person of the president’s age.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden has said it is a “legitimate question to ask anybody over 70 years old whether or not they’re fit” to serve in the White House. To those who question his fitness, he has a stock answer: “Watch me.”

headline: How a Cheesemonger Spends His Sundays
abstract: Matthew Cortellesi roams the city, photographing its reflection in water and glass. When the evening comes, he’ll sing a few show tunes, too.
lead_paragraph: “Cheese is a celebration,” said Matthew Cortellesi, the manager of “formaggi e salumi” (cheese and cured meats) at Harry’s Table by Cipriani, an elegantly casual food court and restaurant, in the West 60s of Manhattan. “It’s an opportunity for discovery, and it’s accessible to everyone,” he said of cheese, which can range in format and flavor from a gooey, pungent Camembert to a hard smoked Gouda. “There’s storytelling in each type.”

headline: The World Cup That Changed Everything
abstract: The decision to take the World Cup to Qatar has upturned a small nation, battered the reputation of global soccer’s governing body and altered the fabric of the sport.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of France vs. Tunisia and the latest World Cup standings.
