headline: Was This $100 Billion Deal the Worst Merger Ever?
abstract: At Time Warner, executives saw AT&T as just a “big phone company from Texas.” At AT&T, they thought Hollywood would play by their rules. That combination led to strategic miscalculation unrivaled in recent corporate history.
lead_paragraph: Soon after a sweeping courtroom victory in 2018 cleared the way for AT&T’s $100 billion takeover of Time Warner, John Stankey, AT&T’s chief operating officer and the newly anointed chief executive of Warner Media, summoned his top Warner Media executives to a meeting at the Time Warner Center off Columbus Circle.

headline: Gang Warfare Cripples Haiti’s Fight Against Cholera
abstract: The disease is spreading in the Caribbean nation in part because armed groups control poor neighborhoods with ruthless violence and prevent doctors from providing basic care.
lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — To reach the hospital, the mothers traveled the front lines of a gang war, bringing sick babies during lulls in gun battles and passing corpses along the way.

headline: Soccer’s Most Stylish Man
abstract: Héctor Bellerín is a fullback for F.C. Barcelona. Off the field he’s a men’s wear influencer and fashion designer.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Even in dark Gucci sunglasses, Héctor Bellerín couldn’t walk the few blocks from his apartment to the parking garage where he kept his battery-powered Cupra Born without causing a scene. Most of the swarming fans held their composure; one young woman trembled as she asked the professional soccer player for a picture. The World Cup was a month away — the first game is on Sunday in Qatar — and although he won’t be competing this year, it didn’t matter. Being a soccer player in Barcelona is like being a Kardashian in Calabasas, Calif., or anywhere else.

headline: As tennis honors Sergiy Stakhovsky of Ukraine, he reflects on shifting his focus from sports to the war.
abstract: His career came to an abrupt end in February, when Russian forces invaded his country and he became a soldier.
lead_paragraph: TURIN, Italy — When professional tennis took a few minutes on Friday night at the ATP Tour Finals to honor a handful of players who had announced their retirement from the sport this year, one of them walked onto the court at the Pala Alpitour stadium wearing military fatigues.

headline: On Eve of World Cup, FIFA Chief Says, ‘Don’t Criticize Qatar; Criticize Me.’
abstract: Gianni Infantino defended the host country’s decision to ban the sale of beer at stadiums and fired back at the “hypocrisy” of Western criticisms.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — The president of world soccer’s governing body on Saturday sought to blunt mounting concerns about the World Cup in Qatar with a strident defense of both the host country’s reputation and FIFA’s authority over its showpiece championship.

headline: Did Billions in Spending Make a Dent in Homelessness? Canada Doesn’t Know.
abstract: An auditor general’s report found that multibillion-dollar federal housing programs were not being tracked to see whether they actually reduced homelessness.
lead_paragraph: While other Canadian cities are firmly in the throes of winter, Toronto, after months of balmy weather, finally surrendered to its first snowfall on Tuesday, with more on the way. Winters are a habitual stress test on Toronto’s infrastructure, especially public transit, but also on its constellation of social services for the homeless.

headline: Pie, Made Easy
abstract: Stressed about a homemade Thanksgiving pie? Don’t be. My tips will help.
lead_paragraph: In David Mamet’s comedy “Boston Marriage,” the character Claire says: “Yes, this shall be our party. And we must have a pie. Stress cannot exist in the presence of a pie.”

headline: Armchair Travel, Hypothermia and Zapping
abstract: Our critic recommends old and new books.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: What Is Next for the FTX Fallout?
abstract: The dramatic collapse of the crypto exchange continues to reverberate throughout the industry.
lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offer a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: Title Search: Can You Find 15 Spy Novels Hiding in Plain Sight?
abstract: Espionage-themed novels have been thrilling readers for decades and here’s a chance to test your knowledge of the genre.
lead_paragraph: Espionage-themed novels have been thrilling readers for decades and here’s a chance to test your knowledge of the genre.

headline: Battered School Holds Memories of Collective Trauma in a Ukrainian Village
abstract: In Yahidne, a village in northern Ukraine, a basement became a virtual prison for hundreds of residents for four weeks. Months later, that horror lingers.
lead_paragraph: YAHIDNE, Ukraine — The elementary school’s former custodian carefully turned the key to the green door leading to the basement and walked down the stairs, shining a flashlight. Eventually, he paused the beam on a calendar scrawled on the cement wall and on the list of names alongside it.

headline: Democrats Need to Realize How Much Dobbs Mattered
abstract: The overturning of Roe v. Wade got people to the polls. Democrats must learn from that.
lead_paragraph: Support for abortion rights appears to have been a major factor in the midterm elections, helping Democrats fare much better than expected in many places. Though Republicans seized control of the House, dashing hopes of federal legislation to codify Roe v. Wade in the next two years, the midterm results suggest that running on abortion can be a winning strategy for Democrats. The outcome offers lessons to Democrats looking ahead to a 2024 presidential election that could determine if a federal abortion ban is on the table.

headline: Facebook Is a Freak Show Ghost Town, and I’m Loving It
abstract: Facebook has become my modern-day version of a bazaar, with its rows of tiny stalls offering untold treasures.
lead_paragraph: Now that Elon Musk’s takeover has hastened the demise of Twitter, many are grasping for alternatives to their beloved town square. Mastodon, Cohost and Koo have all been floated as options. But I won’t bother joining any of those. Instead, you can find me on Facebook.

headline: Twitter Was Influential in the Pandemic. Are We Better for It?
abstract: Reflecting on what worked and what didn’t.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s user base is modest compared with those of Facebook, YouTube and Instagram, yet its impact on society has been tremendous, in large part because of who uses it and the way that it serves as a conduit between social and traditional media. We saw this through Donald Trump’s use of the platform‌‌. And we have seen it again ‌during the Covid-19 pandemic‌‌: Twitter became a ‌locus for ‌‌conversations among scientists, journalists‌ and policymakers that ultimately shaped our pandemic response.

headline: Leg Booty? Panoramic? Seggs? How TikTok Is Changing Language
abstract: A new vocabulary — a little fun, a little dystopian — has emerged on the social video platform, as creators try to get around algorithms and strict content moderation. They call it algospeak.
lead_paragraph: To hear some people on TikTok tell it, we’ve spent years in a “panoramic.” Or perhaps it was a “panini press.” Some are in the “leg booty” community and stand firmly against “cornucopia.”

headline: The Anti-Abortion Movement, After Dobbs and the Midterms
abstract: Readers react to a column by Ross Douthat and two guest essays about abortion after the Supreme Court decision.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Trump, Macho Macho Victim
abstract: His campaign is off to a special start (as in special counsel).
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Among many remarkable moments in the past few days, this was my favorite: Donald Trump finally acknowledged that Joe Biden is the president.

headline: There Are No Lone Wolves
abstract: Right-wing extremist violence in the U.S. is part of a global phenomenon. It should be treated that way.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in May 2020, Payton Gendron, a 16-year-old in upstate New York, was browsing the website 4chan when he came across a GIF.

headline: The First H.B.C.U. Gymnastics Team Is Aiming Even Higher
abstract: Fisk University put a gymnastics team together after sensing an opportunity to encourage Black women to compete in the college sport.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — In early August, a video of a group of female gymnasts stretching, tumbling into a foam pit, and smiling for a group selfie went viral. En route to amassing nearly one million views on TikTok, the video was picked up by several news outlets.

headline: This Week, Billionaires Made a Strong Case for Abolishing Themselves
abstract: Musk, Bezos, Bankman-Fried, Trump — some of our most prominent billionaires laid waste to their carefully cultivated image as benevolent saviors.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, a swelling chorus of Americans has grown critical of the nation’s bajillionaires. But in the extraordinary week gone by, that chorus was drowned out by a far louder and more urgent case against them. It was made by the bajillionaires themselves.

headline: Republicans, Fear the Young
abstract: Gen Z and millennial voters held back the red wave.
lead_paragraph: Stressed and sickened by thoughts of their rights and democracy slipping away, young Americans across gender, racial, geographic and education lines banded together last week to help save the Democrats from what many foresaw as a sizable midterm defeat. If the elections had been decided by voters 45 and older, Republicans would have won the House by an even greater margin and likely taken the Senate. But thanks to young voters (especially the 18-to-29 age group, which had the second-highest turnout in midterm elections in almost 30 years, according to early estimates from Tufts University), Democrats retained the Senate, showing that an alliance of Gen Z and millennial voters answered history’s call to defend democracy. The majority of them rejected the big lie. They possess the turbulent, kinetic energy that withstands red waves. They will propel Democrats’ progressive agenda forward if the party seizes the moment.

headline: Why Are We Still Obsessed With Robert Moses?
abstract: David Hare’s sold-out play about the brutal planning czar coaxes us toward a reappraisal — maybe.
lead_paragraph: It is a wonder of some kind and a sign of the city’s renewed vibrancy that night after night, hundreds of people travel six flights by escalator to the main theater at the Shed on Manhattan’s far West Side to see Ralph Fiennes work himself into a state of near rapture over the promise of the Southern State Parkway. The actor is a few weeks into his performance as Robert Moses in “Straight Line Crazy,” David Hare’s confused effort at re-examining the influence of modern urbanism’s titanic autocrat. The play sold out quickly; ticket prices in the secondary market have since reached $900 a seat in some instances. Clearly, something is going on here.

headline: Through Imprisonment and Exile, Sevgi Soysal Kept Writing
abstract: Her final completed novel, “Dawn,” highlights voices of protest in Turkey amid political turmoil.
lead_paragraph: The poet and political exile Nazim Hikmet had this advice for those behind bars: “You won’t say, ‘Better I had swung from the end of a rope like a flag’ — you’ll put your foot down and live. It may not be a pleasure exactly, but it’s your solemn duty to live one more day.” The rebellious Turkish novelist Sevgi Soysal (1936-76) did just that, her life stranger than fiction. After the military coup in Turkey on March 12, 1971, amid a period of labor unrest and street battles between leftists and ultranationalists, Soysal spent a portion of her final years in detention, writing at a furious pace.

headline: Trump Inquiries Remain Politically Charged, Despite Special Counsel
abstract: The appointment of an independent investigator is meant to address the perception of conflict of interest. But the system no longer seems adequate in this polarized political moment.
lead_paragraph: In appointing a special counsel to investigate former President Donald J. Trump, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland was, in theory at least, trying to insulate the matter from politics as much as possible.

headline: World Cup in Qatar Caps Big Gulf Push Into International Sports
abstract: In hosting major international sporting events, buying up soccer teams and even creating a golf league, the resource-rich Gulf States are seeking attention, prestige, economic diversification and political credibility.
lead_paragraph: For most of Mariam al-Anezi’s life, it felt as if no one knew where Qatar was. She would tell people she came from a place next to Dubai, the better-known Gulf Arab emirate a seven-hour drive away.

headline: Do Not Underestimate Trump’s Grip on Republican Voters
abstract: Republican elites will not have the final say over whether he stays in control.
lead_paragraph: It has never been that Donald Trump defies political gravity as much as it has been that Republican elites refused to let him fall. This was how he survived the scandals of the 2016 presidential election, consolidating support from conservative and Republican elites in the wake of the emergence of the “Access Hollywood” tape.

headline: In a First, Rich Countries Agree to Pay for Climate Damages in Poor Nations
abstract: After 30 years of deadlock, a new U.N. climate agreement aims to pay developing countries for loss and damage caused by global warming. But huge questions remain about how it would work.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — Negotiators from nearly 200 countries concluded two weeks of talks early Sunday in which their main achievement was agreeing to establish a fund that would help poor, vulnerable countries cope with climate disasters made worse by the pollution spewed by wealthy nations that is dangerously heating the planet.

headline: In New Special Counsel, a Prosecutor Schooled in Corruption Cases
abstract: A veteran public corruption and war-crimes prosecutor, Jack Smith will take over two Trump-related criminal investigations.
lead_paragraph: When Jack Smith was appointed to lead the Justice Department’s public integrity unit in 2010, he recommended closing a series of high-profile investigations into members of Congress without charges — attracting criticism that the division had lost its nerve. He rejected that idea.

headline: As the War Rages, Ukraine Wages a Daunting Battle to Rebuild
abstract: Fully 61,000 square miles could be littered with land mines and other explosives left by retreating Russian forces, while half the electric grid has been destroyed.
lead_paragraph: KYIV — Ukrainian efforts to stabilize some of the country’s battered electricity supply and make a dent in the seemingly endless task of demining swaths of the country offered a glimpse into the Herculean task that lies ahead off the battlefield.

headline: The Red Sea’s Coral Reefs Defy the Climate-Change Odds
abstract: As warming waters devastate coral around the world, the sea’s stunningly colorful reefs have been remarkably resilient. But pollution, mass tourism and overfishing put them at risk.
lead_paragraph: SHARM El SHEIKH, Egypt — The vast majority of the world’s coral reefs are likely to be severely damaged in the coming decades if the planet keeps warming at its current rate.

headline: Ed Rudy, Chronicler of the Beatles’ First Trip to America, Dies at 93
abstract: He sent reports about the Fab Four’s travels to radio stations in February 1964. Then he turned the material into an album that rose to No. 20 on the Billboard chart.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 7, 1964, when the Beatles were greeted by thousands of screaming fans at John F. Kennedy International Airport, a radio reporter named Ed Rudy was there.

headline: It’s Official: The Leap Second Will Be Retired (a Decade from Now)
abstract: On Friday, an international vote was taken to ditch the leap second, a technical fudge that has caused headaches since its inception 50 years ago.
lead_paragraph: The time has come — or will come, in 2035 — to abandon the leap second.

headline: The Monster Buffalo Snowstorm May Have Set a Record. More Is on the Way.
abstract: Officials said the storm appeared to drop a record amount of snow for Erie County in a 24-hour period, and that two people had died as a result.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — The city of Buffalo, where heavy snow is commonly met with a shrug and a shovel, spent Saturday navigating chest-high drifts left by a lake-effect storm that ran roughshod over the region. Forecasters promised a continued pummeling overnight.

headline: Dr. Mitchell Rosenthal, Phoenix House Founder, Dies at 87
abstract: A psychiatrist, he was an early apostle for treating drug and alcohol addiction with group therapy in a residential setting.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Mitchell Rosenthal, the founder of Phoenix House, which branded itself the largest private, nonprofit therapeutic drug-treatment program in the United States, died on Nov. 14 in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Kari Lake Claims Her Voters Were Disenfranchised. Her Voters Tell a Different Story.
abstract: Ms. Lake’s supporters say in testimonials that they had problems at Phoenix-area polling sites. But a review by The New York Times shows that most of them successfully cast their ballots.
lead_paragraph: When he stepped inside a Phoenix polling place on the morning of Election Day on the way to work, Kevin Bembry was told that the tabulation machines were not functioning properly and he might want to vote somewhere else.

headline: In ‘G-Man,’ a J. Edgar Hoover as Complex as the Country He Served
abstract: The first major biography of the F.B.I. director in nearly 30 years, the book by Beverly Gage revises our conception of a man often remembered as little more than a cartoon villain.
lead_paragraph: J. Edgar Hoover, who served as director of the F.B.I. for an astonishing 48 years, has long been remembered as the stuff of liberal nightmares: a redbaiter, a wiretapper, a sower of discord through covert manipulations.

headline: George Lois, Visionary Art Director, Is Dead at 91
abstract: He brought the counterculture to advertising and designed memorable covers for Esquire magazine, many of them wordless critiques of American society.
lead_paragraph: George Lois, Madison Avenue’s best-known 20th-century art director, who put the counterculture of the 1960s and ’70s into postwar advertising and created stunning covers for Esquire magazine that rebuked American racism and involvement in the Vietnam War, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.

headline: World Cup Schedule: How to Watch Every Match
abstract: From the group stage all the way to the final on Dec. 18.
lead_paragraph: The World Cup is in the final round of its group stage, which runs through Friday. The results of the group stage decide which teams advance to the knockout stage, which is a traditional bracket-style tournament.

headline: Latest on the University of Idaho Killings: What We Know
abstract: The gruesome stabbing deaths of four University of Idaho students remain unsolved. The police asked the public to continue sending tips.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Idaho — Investigators have now processed more than 1,000 tips in the aftermath of the gruesome stabbing deaths of four University of Idaho students, but the authorities said Friday that they still do not have a suspect in the killings that have mystified and shaken this college town.

headline: Adele Returns to the Stage in Las Vegas, Resolute and Reflective
abstract: The pop star’s “Weekends With Adele” residency began after nearly a year of delays, with a design that emphasized intimacy and a set heavy on her 2011 breakout album, “21.”
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Adele has become a titanically successful superstar by presenting herself as something of an oxymoron: a relatable diva.

headline: EarthCam Video Shows Meteor Flying Over Toronto
abstract: A fireball spotted zooming across Toronto’s skyline was also seen by observers in the northeastern United States.
lead_paragraph: A fireball spotted zooming across Toronto’s skyline was also seen by observers in the northeastern United States.

headline: Fireball Flashes Above Ontario and Parts of the U.S.
abstract: The bright meteor was the sixth object detected in space before striking Earth, the European Space Agency said.
lead_paragraph: A fireball that soared over Ontario, Canada, early on Saturday was the sixth object to be detected in space before it struck Earth, the European Space Agency said.

headline: Did the Midterms Save American Democracy?
abstract: Or did they just prove that it was stable all along?
lead_paragraph: For everyone furiously debating the condition of American democracy, the 2022 midterms were a beautiful thing — a gift to both sides of the argument, a Rorschach test that yields to either interpretation.

headline: ‘Love and Rockets,’ a Series that Helped Redefine Comics, Turns 40
abstract: With its Chicana punk rockers and panels of untranslated Spanish, “Rockets” was unlike anything else — and, it turns out, just what the world of comics was craving.
lead_paragraph: In 1981, Jaime and Gilbert Hernandez were living in Oxnard, Calif., working as janitors to fund the trips they took down the 101 to see punk bands like Black Flag in Los Angeles, and their work on a comic book series they called “Love and Rockets.”

headline: 2 Men Arrested in Threats to New York Jewish Community, Police Say
abstract: The two were arrested on Saturday at Pennsylvania Station. The police said they seized a large hunting knife and a firearm with a 30-round magazine.
lead_paragraph: The authorities arrested two men on Saturday at New York’s Pennsylvania Station and seized a large hunting knife and an illegal firearm with a 30-round magazine in what they described as a “developing threat to the Jewish community.”

headline: Fan Club
abstract: Joe Deeney’s Sunday puzzle is for lovers.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Joe Deeney, of Melrose, Mass., is a supply chain director for Philips, a health technology company based in Amsterdam. He’s been solving crossword puzzles for as long as he can remember; in 2015, he was working on one that he wasn’t particularly fond of and thought, “I can do better than that!” Fourteen Times puzzles later, this is his Sunday debut, and he has now “hit for the cycle” with a puzzle constructed for each day of the week.

headline: Massive Snowstorm Hits Western New York
abstract: The city of Buffalo and its neighbors experienced potentially record-breaking snowfall, as officials said that more than 70 inches fell in Erie County — with more expected.
lead_paragraph: The city of Buffalo and its neighbors experienced potentially record-breaking snowfall, as officials said that more than 70 inches fell in Erie County — with more expected.

headline: Kyrie Irving Apologizes in TV Interview: ‘I Don’t Condone Any Hate Speech’
abstract: The Nets indicated Irving could potentially be available for Sunday’s game but have yet to officially announce the end of his suspension.
lead_paragraph: Nets guard Kyrie Irving, who has been suspended since Nov. 3, said during a television interview published on Saturday that he wanted to “apologize deeply” for his posting of a link to an antisemitic film.

headline: Elon Musk Reinstates Trump’s Twitter Account
abstract: Mr. Musk, who had asked Twitter users about whether to bring back the former president to the service, said, “The people have spoken.”
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk said on Twitter on Saturday that he would reinstate former President Donald J. Trump to the platform as part of a shake-up of the social media service, with Mr. Trump’s account quickly showing up again on the site.

headline: ‘A Light to the World’: University of Virginia Pays Tribute to Shooting Victims
abstract: More than 9,000 people gathered for a memorial service for Devin Chandler, Lavel Davis Jr. and D’Sean Perry.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — As the authorities continued to seek answers in the killing of three University of Virginia students, the college and its community paused on Saturday to reflect on the “vibrant, beautiful young men” who were praised for touching countless lives before theirs were cut short.

headline: World Cup 2022: How Belgium Can Advance to the Round of 16
abstract: How Belgium can qualify for the next round of the 2022 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: How Belgium can qualify for the next round of the 2022 World Cup.

abstract: How Australia can qualify for the next round of the 2022 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: How Australia can qualify for the next round of the 2022 World Cup.

lead_paragraph: How Ghana can qualify for the next round of the 2022 World Cup.

abstract: How Denmark can qualify for the next round of the 2022 World Cup.
lead_paragraph: How Denmark can qualify for the next round of the 2022 World Cup.

abstract: How Spain can qualify for the next round of the 2022 World Cup.

headline: World Cup 2022: How Iran Can Advance to the Round of 16

headline: Corrections: Nov. 20, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 20, 2022.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article last Sunday about a new guard of gallerists misspelled the given name of a partner in Objective Gallery. He is Marc Jebara, not Mark.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Gang Violence Hinders Haiti’s Battle Against Cholera
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 20, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “We were already in a system on its knees. Now, cholera unfortunately will spread quicker than the health system will be able to answer to it.”

headline: France’s Karim Benzema Is Out of World Cup
abstract: The forward was seen as critical to the title hopes of a France team already hit hard by injuries.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of Argentina vs. Mexico and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: Malaysians Were Pitched Political Stability. Elections Created More Chaos.
abstract: The country has been hit by a series of political shocks in recent years and now confronts the first hung Parliament in its history.
lead_paragraph: A prime minister accused of stealing hundreds of millions of dollars. The national patriarch coming out of retirement to oust him in a historic election. Infighting within the new government, forcing the patriarch’s resignation. Two new prime ministers in less than two years.

headline: Gareth Southgate Cannot Make England Whole Again
abstract: Being the England manager was never an easy job. And that was before the country started falling apart.
lead_paragraph: BURTON-ON-TRENT, England — Gareth Southgate mentions the letter almost as an aside. It had arrived at his home, out in the Yorkshire countryside. He does not go into detail about its contents beyond the fact that it was not exactly constructive feedback. It was best described, he said, as a “very strange letter about race.”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘I Stood on the Sidewalk Outside the Hall and Held Up the Extra Ticket’
abstract: A successful transaction, a cabdriver’s curious habit and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Key Findings From The Times’ Investigation of Sports Betting
abstract: The New York Times examined thousands of pages of documents and interviewed lobbyists, executives, lawmakers, regulators and others to understand how the sports-betting industry grew so big so fast.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, it was illegal to gamble on sports in most of the United States. Today, anyone who turns on the television or visits a sports website or shows up at a stadium is likely to be inundated with ads to bet, bet, bet.

headline: Inside the Making of Inside The Times
abstract: From sticky notes to printed pages: How our reimagined section was designed with readers in mind.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, sections of The New York Times have developed devoted readerships, both niche and international. The National desk commands attention with headlines that reflect history; Opinion columns demand debate; Styles pages are instantly recognizable, splayed across coffee tables all over the country.

headline: How Colleges and Sports-Betting Companies ‘Caesarized’ Campus Life
abstract: In order to reap millions of dollars in fees, universities are partnering with betting companies to introduce their students and sports fans to online gambling.
lead_paragraph: In September 2021, an official in Michigan State University’s athletic department sent an email to his boss with exciting news: An online betting company was willing to pay handsomely for the right to promote gambling at the university.

headline: How a Draft of the Constitution Ended Up in a Drawer in Trenton, N.J.
abstract: New Jersey was no less involved in the Revolutionary War than Pennsylvania or Massachusetts. So why does it hide away its priceless artifacts?
lead_paragraph: The 13th royal governor of colonial New Jersey was a Philadelphia-born, London-schooled lawyer whose appointment was solemnized by an elaborate document that bore the seal of King George III. The governor’s name was both familiar and surprising: “Our Trusty and Welbeloved William Franklin,” is how the king’s 1763 commission described him, Benjamin’s son.

headline: Desperate for Growth, Aging Casino Company Embraced ‘Degenerate Gambler’
abstract: David Portnoy, who has a history of misogynistic and racist behavior, is now a public spokesman for the sports-betting industry.
lead_paragraph: Years before he became a controversy-courting media icon, gambling promoter, liquor pitchman and pizza reviewer, David S. Portnoy was drowning in debts.

headline: As Climate Protests Get Bolder, British Police Strike Back With New Powers
abstract: New rules curtailing protests have alarmed some who fear an erosion of civil rights. They come as environmental protesters have intensified their tactics to draw attention to climate change.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When environmental protesters recently stopped traffic on the M25 freeway that circles London, one journalist, Charlotte Lynch, was standing on a bridge above reporting on the latest of the group’s disruptive demonstrations for her radio station, LBC.

headline: Netanyahu’s Comeback Widens Divide Over Israel Among American Jews
abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu has mounted a political comeback with the backing of a far-right coalition that has stirred concerns among some over the direction Israel will take.
lead_paragraph: Rabbi Rachel Timoner of Brooklyn had always cherished Israel as a haven where Jews could aspire to their highest ideals. But after Benjamin Netanyahu won a sixth term as prime minister with the help of two far-right parties this month, she was shaken.

headline: Why States Were Unprepared for the Sports-Betting Onslaught
abstract: Government oversight of sports betting offers scant consumer protections and looks to the industry to police itself, The Times found.
lead_paragraph: David Hummel placed his first sports bet in January 2021, wagering $250 on the underdog in a mixed-martial-arts fight. He won $662.50, he said, “and it was probably the worst thing that could have happened to me.”

headline: Cigars, Booze, Money: How a Lobbying Blitz Made Sports Betting Ubiquitous
abstract: The gambling industry and its allies got their way with lawmakers after showering them with donations, gifts and dubious arguments.
lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — Representative John Barker, a cattle breeder, retired judge and chairman of one of the most powerful committees in the Kansas legislature, had a glass of 30-year Redbreast Irish whiskey in his hand and a Don Tomas cigar from Honduras in his mouth.

headline: What Julia Fox and Hillary Clinton Wore to Parties Last Week
abstract: Top outfits from the parties for Thierry Mugler, Air Mail, Pioneer Works and the National Portrait Gallery
lead_paragraph: The sartorial spirit of Thierry Mugler, the enfant terrible of 1980s French fashion, came to life at the Brooklyn Museum on Tuesday for the opening of the designer’s retrospective. Habitués of the city’s nightlife and fashion underground channeled his over-the-top style. Many wore vintage Mugler or fanciful outfits of their own creation.

headline: In Utah, Restoring Spruce Forests One Cone at a Time
abstract: Seasonal workers climb tree after tree to collect seeds that will eventually help regrow forests, an effort that could get the country closer to its climate goals
lead_paragraph: MOAB, Utah — Blake Votilla stared up at the 120-foot spruce tree. He strapped braces with four-inch spurs to his shins and clipped two large red plastic sacks on his climbing harness. Reggaeton blasted from a portable speaker on his hip.

headline: U.N. Climate Talks End With a Deal to Pay Poor Nations for Damage
abstract: Nations reached a landmark deal to compensate developing nations for climate harm. But some leaders said the summit didn’t go far enough in addressing the root causes of global warming.
lead_paragraph: SHARM EL SHEIKH, Egypt — Diplomats from nearly 200 countries concluded two weeks of climate talks on Sunday by agreeing to establish a fund that would help poor, vulnerable countries cope with climate disasters made worse by the greenhouse gases from wealthy nations.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Keep Baking That Sourdough, and Change the World
abstract: Lockdown has reminded David Sax that “The Future Is Analog.” At least for people a lot like him.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic has produced so many depressing artifacts: the mountain of masks, the gallons of hand sanitizer, the baton-length nasal swabs. But one of the worst might be the Work From Home Office Playset by Fisher-Price. At first the thing was a much-needed parody. Then suddenly it was actually on the market, including a wooden laptop and headset, fabric apps and a simulacrum of a disposable coffee cup.

headline: How the Pelosi Attack Suspect Plunged Into Online Hatred
abstract: David DePape’s life was unstable when he embraced Gamergate and far-right conspiracy theories. He is now accused of breaking into Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s home and assaulting her husband.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Bitter over the end of a long relationship, estranged from his children and working carpentry jobs to keep a roof over his head after a time living on the streets, David DePape retreated into isolation, spending hours each day in the online worlds of gaming and chat rooms.

headline: President Biden Turns 80, Making Him the First Octogenarian in the Oval Office
abstract: The president’s milestone birthday has brought new attention to the gerontocracy that has led both parties for years and raised questions about when a new generation will come forth.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If he was watching from the White House, President Biden might have winced last week when Speaker Nancy Pelosi declared in her speech on the House floor that “the hour has come for a new generation to lead.” Fortunately for him, she made sure to then add “the Democratic Caucus,” a caveat he no doubt appreciated.

headline: Democratic Senate Loss in Ohio Raises Bar for Sherrod Brown in 2024
abstract: Tim Ryan’s loss to J. D. Vance is another reminder that Ohio is no longer a swing state. Can Mr. Brown, the Democratic incumbent, hold the seat in what’s shaping up as a crucial Senate election in 2024?
lead_paragraph: Both John Fetterman of Pennsylvania and Tim Ryan of Ohio sought Senate seats this year as Democrats appealing to the working class.

headline: In Iraq’s Mountains, Iranian Opposition Fighters Feel the Squeeze
abstract: The armed groups, which have trained in the Kurdistan region for decades, face attacks from Iran and pressure from the Iraqi government to give up their weapons.
lead_paragraph: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq — Sitting under an oak tree on a mountainside in the Kurdish region of Iraq, Mohammad Kurd said he recently fled neighboring Iran after two friends were killed by security forces and the powerful Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps started going door to door to arrest antigovernment protesters.

headline: At Least 5 Dead and 25 Injured in Gunman’s Rampage at an L.G.B.T.Q. Club in Colorado
abstract: The police said a suspect in the shooting, who was also injured, was arrested.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — A man shrouded in body armor and wielding an AR-15 style rifle attacked an L.G.B.T.Q. nightclub in Colorado Springs on Saturday night, in a rampage that killed at least five people and injured at least 25 others.

headline: Welcome to the Joy-Free World Cup
abstract: Soccer’s biggest championship is supposed to be a celebration. So why is everyone so unhappy?
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of Argentina vs. Mexico and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: Blacks and Jews, Again
abstract: Blacks and Jews have competed, quarreled and jostled with each other to gain attention and empathy for our struggles and the injustices we confront.
lead_paragraph: “What effective measures will the collective Negro community take against the vicious antisemitism?” Rabbi Everett Gendler shared this question with Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. at a meeting of the Rabbinical Assembly in 1968, 10 days before King was murdered.

headline: Is There a Problem With Thanksgiving?
abstract: All the ways we make ourselves cranky about a holiday about giving thanks.
lead_paragraph: Have we decided what the problem with Thanksgiving is going to be this year?

headline: What New Hampshire Can Tell Us About Restoring Faith in Elections
abstract: The state is trying to work with people who doubt the voting process rather than demonize them.
lead_paragraph: WINDHAM, N.H. — Brad Winslow is a genial 67-year-old who hugs people he just met. But when it comes to elections, his trust evaporates. A self-described computer geek who has spent much of his career programming machines, Mr. Winslow has long suspected that vote-counting tabulators could be rigged to advantage one politician over another.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘What Does Sustainable Living Look Like? Maybe Like Uruguay’
abstract: No greater challenge faces humanity than reducing emissions without backsliding into preindustrial poverty. One tiny country is leading the way.
lead_paragraph: Across the world, developed nations have locked themselves into unsustainable, energy-intensive lifestyles. As environmental collapse threatens, the journalist Noah Gallagher Shannon explores the lessons in sustainability that can be learned from looking “at smaller, perhaps even less prosperous nations” such as Uruguay.

headline: A number of mass shootings have occurred in Colorado, including several in Colorado Springs.
abstract: Attacks had occurred for years before the deadly shooting at an L.G.B.T.Q. nightclub on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Colorado has been the scene of several of the United States’ most notorious mass shootings, including those at Columbine High School in 1999 and a movie theater in Aurora in 2012.

headline: The Week in Business: FTX’s Collapse
abstract: The turmoil at Twitter continues. The holiday shopping season officially begins, although retailers have already been running sales. And the Fed releases the minutes from its last meeting.
lead_paragraph: In the course of days, the collapse of one of the largest cryptocurrency exchanges, FTX, has led to a series of revelations — about the corporate dysfunction inside FTX, the entangled personal lives of the people who ran it and what the exchange’s new leader said appeared to be efforts to “conceal the misuse of customer funds.” The company has filed for bankruptcy, and federal prosecutors are now investigating what happened to the lost funds of possibly more than one million creditors. The downfall of Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder and former chief executive of FTX, has called into question the future of the crypto industry as well as that of a closely affiliated movement in which he heavily invested. That movement was centered on a moral philosophy known as effective altruism, and it financed itself in large part with donations from FTX’s philanthropic arm.

headline: A Contentious World Cup
abstract: Concerns about corruption and human rights loom over a typically joyous sporting event.
lead_paragraph: The World Cup begins today in Qatar. The games, which normally start in late spring or summer, were pushed to accommodate the desert country’s climate — one of many reasons this is a weird World Cup.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 21, 2022
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Several European captains plan to wear rainbow armbands despite a threat of discipline.
abstract: The armbands were designed to show support for minority groups amid ongoing concerns about Qatar’s treatment of the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
lead_paragraph: Update: Germany’s players protested a FIFA decision that blocked their captain from wearing a rainbow armband.

headline: At least 437 children have been killed in the war since February, Ukraine says.
abstract: Andriy Kostin, Ukraine’s prosecutor general, said that the true numbers were likely to be far higher.
lead_paragraph: At least 437 children are among more than 8,300 civilians who have been killed in Ukraine since Russia launched its full-scale invasion in February, the country’s prosecutor general said on Saturday in a grim new accounting of the war’s toll.

headline: What Holds a Marriage Together, or Doesn’t
abstract: Marriage: Tom and Gisele’s, and others’. Also: Unpaid internships; children and drugs; undocumented farmworkers; Covid tests in New York.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Russia and Ukraine again trade blame for shelling at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant.
abstract: The United Nations’ nuclear watchdog agency called the strikes “extremely disturbing.”
lead_paragraph: At least a dozen shells exploded at a large nuclear plant in southern Ukraine on Sunday, Ukrainian and Russian authorities said, damaging equipment in attacks that the United Nations’ nuclear watchdog agency called “extremely disturbing.”

headline: Even Your Political Enemies Deserve a Slice of Pie
abstract: Gratitude means noticing our interdependence.
lead_paragraph: Just as some friends have inside jokes, my best friend, Woody, and I have an imaginary holiday. We call it Interdependence Day, an intentional play on Independence Day. The point is to recognize how we are all in this together. We mention it from time to time — things we hope to celebrate on Interdependence Day, people we want to honor on Interdependence Day, how we should get together for Interdependence Day.

headline: U.S.C., Backed by Its Big Name, Makes Case for National Title Run
abstract: Southern California earned a trip to the Pac-12 Conference championship game with a rivalry win over U.C.L.A., giving it a chance to state its case for the College Football Playoff.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — It was Larry Smith’s parting lament, delivered as he was on his way out as the Southern California coach with a loss to Fresno State in the Freedom Bowl, which came three years after a run of three consecutive Rose Bowl trips.

headline: Migrants hired to work at the opening match waited all day without food and water.
abstract: Instead of a day of work, the workers endured no water, no food and no toilets under the hot desert sun.
lead_paragraph: A group of more than 200 migrant laborers hired to work concession stalls at the Qatar World Cup’s opening game said they had been left without food, water and toilet facilities for seven hours while they waited for their assignments.

headline: Michael J. Fox, Diane Warren and Cher at the Raucous Governors Awards
abstract: The actor and songwriter, along with Euzhan Palcy and Peter Weir, received honorary Oscars as current contenders like Jennifer Lawrence worked the crowd.
lead_paragraph: It’s an honor to be nominated for an Oscar, and Diane Warren would know: The veteran songwriter has been recognized by the academy 13 times, setting a record as the woman who has received the most nominations without a win.

headline: A Crowd of Possible Trump Rivals Renews G.O.P. Fears of a Divided Field
abstract: Ron DeSantis, Ted Cruz, Mike Pompeo, Nikki Haley and other Republicans with a potential eye on 2024 gathered in Las Vegas at a moment of deep vulnerability for Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Senator Ted Cruz aggressively worked one ballroom, taking selfies and staying for handshakes with donors and activists for so long the linens had already been cleared.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Cheesy baked pasta, roasted salmon with miso rice, and more.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. There is no worse feeling than wanting to make a perfect pizza pie on a Sunday night and knowing that you can’t because you forgot to make pizza dough beforehand. That kind of feeling — missed opportunity! — can stick in your mind for days.

headline: Danny Kalb, Guitarist Who Gave Blues-Rock an Edge, Dies at 80
abstract: His 1960s band, the Blues Project, won a following with a driving, experimental approach to traditional material that was anything but purist.
lead_paragraph: Danny Kalb, a guitarist whose 1960s band the Blues Project brought New York City drive and experimentation to blues-rock, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Brooklyn, where he lived. He was 80.

headline: Attacked Club Had Planned Transgender Day of Remembrance Event for Sunday
abstract: Club Q, the scene of a deadly shooting in Colorado Springs on Saturday night, was to hold a brunch event on Sunday for those lost their lives to anti-transgender violence.
lead_paragraph: Hours before it was hit by a deadly mass shooting Saturday night, Club Q in Colorado Springs posted on Facebook about a planned “all ages drag brunch” on Sunday morning. The event was described by the club as a celebration of the Transgender Day of Remembrance, which honors the memory of transgender people who lost their lives to anti-transgender violence.

headline: In Life and Music, Ned Rorem Was Unwaveringly Himself
abstract: This composer, diarist and reluctant pioneer of gay liberation has died. A critic remembers visiting him in his twilight.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, during one in a series of visits I made to Ned Rorem’s apartment, he said with his trademark lightness that it would be “kind of cute” to make it to 100 years old.

headline: In Asian Town, Some of the Workers Who Built the World Cup Gather to Watch It
abstract: Qatar’s big show would not have been possible without migrant workers. On Sunday, thousands gathered to gaze at some of their work.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — On the outskirts of Qatar’s capital and miles away from the stadiums and the sheen of the World Cup, thousands of true nation builders gathered in a fenced-off parking lot at Asian Town, between a mall and a cricket stadium.

headline: Turkey Bombs Kurdish Foes in Iraq and Syria, Likely Killing Dozens
abstract: Turkish officials said the airstrikes were a counterterrorism operation against militants it accused of bombing Istanbul last week.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkish fighter jets carried out dozens of airstrikes in northern Syria and Iraq on Sunday, in what Turkish officials called an antiterrorism campaign to root out militants they accused of orchestrating a deadly bomb attack last week in Istanbul.

headline: I Studied Trump’s Twitter Use for Six Years. Prepare for the Worst.
abstract: Elon Musk’s decision to activate Donald Trump’s account is a dangerous one.
lead_paragraph: The situation at Twitter has been chaotic. Over the past few weeks, new owner Elon Musk introduced a major product — and then paused it. He’s dismissed hundreds of employees — and then asked some of them to return.

headline: Kyrie Irving Returns From Suspension
abstract: In his first news conference since his suspension began, before a game against the Memphis Grizzlies, Irving said he doesn’t stand for “anything close to hate speech or antisemitism.”
lead_paragraph: In his first game since being suspended for posting a link on social media to an antisemitic film, Nets guard Kyrie Irving shook off early rust to score 14 points  to help the Nets to a win, 127-115, against the Memphis Grizzlies in Brooklyn.

headline: Christie’s Pulls T. Rex From Auction, Citing Need for ‘Further Study’
abstract: The sale of a specimen named Shen fell apart after a fossil company questioned how much of it was a replica of Stan, a T. rex auctioned off two years ago for a record price.
lead_paragraph: Christie’s said Sunday that it was withdrawing a Tyrannosaurus rex skeleton that it had been planning to auction this month in Hong Kong, where it was initially expected to fetch between $15 million and $25 million, after questions were raised about the number of replica bones used in the specimen and the way it was described in marketing materials.

headline: Qatar Stepped Onto the World Cup Stage. And Immediately Stumbled.
abstract: At last it was here, the last word in Qatar’s attempt to announce itself to the world, to showcase all that it could do, all that it could build. Then the soccer started.
lead_paragraph: AL KHOR, Qatar — The highway stretches out into nowhere, its surface pristine, the soaring glass spires of Doha slowly receding in the distance. It passes the ghost city of Lusail, its cranes standing motionless in the desert air. For miles, there is nothing but asphalt and sand and sky, the horizon broken only by the colossal outline of the Al Bayt Stadium.

headline: Inmates Who Killed a Writer and a Publisher Escape in Bangladesh
abstract: Men convicted of fatally stabbing the Bangladeshi-American author Avijit Roy and his publisher fled custody in an unsettling reminder of extremist violence against intellectuals.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Two men on death row in Bangladesh for the high-profile killings of a secular author and his publisher escaped Sunday while en route to a hearing in the capital, the authorities said.

headline: Videos Suggest Captive Russian Soldiers Were Killed at Close Range
abstract: Videos circulating online and reported on by Russian state media have raised questions about whether Ukrainian soldiers committed a war crime.
lead_paragraph: A series of videos that surfaced on social media last week has ignited a debate over whether Ukrainian forces committed war crimes or acted in self-defense as they tried to capture a group of Russian soldiers who were then killed.The videos show the grisly before-and-after scenes of the encounter earlier this month, in which at least 11 Russians, most of whom are seen lying on the ground, appear to have been shot dead at close range after one of their fellow fighters suddenly opened fire on Ukrainian soldiers standing nearby.

headline: Turkey Launches Airstrikes Over Northern Syria and Iraq
abstract: The airstrikes, which Turkish officials called an antiterrorism campaign against Kurdish militants, came a week after a deadly bomb attack in Istanbul. The airstrikes killed more than two dozen people.
lead_paragraph: The airstrikes, which Turkish officials called an antiterrorism campaign against Kurdish militants, came a week after a deadly bomb attack in Istanbul. The airstrikes killed more than two dozen people.

headline: Brandeis University Student Killed and 26 Injured in Shuttle Bus Crash
abstract: The authorities did not immediately release the conditions of those hurt but said their injuries were of “varying degrees.”
lead_paragraph: One Brandeis University student was killed late on Saturday and 26 other students were injured after the shuttle bus they were in crashed into a tree in Waltham, Mass., just west of Boston, the authorities said.

headline: Seven Months on a Strict Twitter Diet
abstract: You don’t need Twitter — or any social media platform — nearly as much as you think you do.
lead_paragraph: Seven months ago, with the first rumblings that Elon Musk might buy Twitter, I made the decision to pull back from the site, and use it only to alert people to things like the publication of my column or my television appearances.

headline: How to Watch the U.S. at the World Cup: Schedule, Roster and Expectations
abstract: The Americans will play England on Friday. Here’s how to watch, and what to watch for.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of U.S. vs. England and the latest World Cup news.

headline: Ben Affleck and Matt Damon to Start Film Production Company
abstract: Unlike streaming services and most studios, they plan to share profits with their actors and off-camera artisans.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood’s most powerful stars, directors and writers have been increasingly vocal about their dissatisfaction with streaming-era paychecks, namely the refusal of entertainment companies to share the money generated from breakout hits, as was more common in decades past.

headline: Gareth Bale and Wales Embrace the Games of a Lifetime
abstract: Bale and his teammates have never seen Wales play in a World Cup. His nation has waited even longer.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates of U.S. vs. Wales and more World Cup news.

headline: Two Men Arrested in Threat to New York’s Jewish Community Are Charged
abstract: Manhattan’s district attorney said the men had intended to attack a synagogue.
lead_paragraph: Two men arrested just before midnight on Friday at New York’s Penn Station, in what authorities said was a “developing threat to the Jewish community,” have been charged with multiple felony counts, including criminal possession of a weapon and making a terroristic threat.

headline: Club Q Suspect Appears to Have Been Accused of Threatening Mother With Bomb
abstract: A man with the same name and age as the club shooting suspect was arrested in June 2021 after police negotiators persuaded him to surrender.
lead_paragraph: The man identified by authorities as the suspect in the nightclub shooting in Colorado Springs Saturday night appears to have been arrested last year, accused of engaging in a lengthy standoff with the police after threatening to hurt his mother with a homemade bomb.

headline: Canada Imposes Sanctions on Haiti’s Former Leader and Other Officials
abstract: Among the six targeted over possible ties to criminal gangs were former President Michel Martelly and two former prime ministers.
lead_paragraph: Canada announced sanctions on a slew of powerful politicians in Haiti over the weekend, part of a broad push to punish officials believed to have ties to the increasingly dominant gangs terrorizing the Caribbean nation.

headline: Dagny Corcoran, Bookselling Fixture of L.A. Art Scene, Dies at 77
abstract: Her store, Art Catalogues, specialized in books for and about museum and gallery exhibitions and became a gathering place for artists and bibliophiles.
lead_paragraph: Dagny Corcoran, a revered California art-book seller whose shop and jam-packed dinner parties became way stations for a generation of artists, bibliophiles and Hollywood literati, died on Nov. 9 in Los Angeles. She was 77.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: The World Cup Kicks Off
abstract: Plus COP27 ends with a landmark deal and Twitter reinstates Donald Trump’s account.
lead_paragraph: The World Cup began yesterday. In the first match, Ecuador defeated Qatar, the host nation.

headline: Jay Pasachoff, Who Pursued Eclipses Across the Globe, Dies at 79
abstract: An astronomer at Williams College, he probably saw more solar eclipses than any other human in history.
lead_paragraph: Jay M. Pasachoff, an astronomer at Williams College who spent more than 50 years traveling the world to observe solar eclipses and, with 74 sightings under his belt, probably witnessed more of them than any other human in history, died on Sunday at his home in Williamstown, Mass. He was 79.

headline: Review: In ‘Difficult Grace,’ a Cellist Moves Beyond Classical Confines
abstract: In his wide-ranging multimedia program at the 92nd Street Y, Seth Parker Woods used different artistic avenues as channels for personal and communal exploration.
lead_paragraph: The cellist Seth Parker Woods presented an evening-long, multimedia program titled “Difficult Grace” Saturday evening at the 92nd Street Y’s Kaufmann Concert Hall. It was the full staging’s world premiere, but, as Woods remarked, he had premiered a “nucleus version” in February 2020 in Seattle; the coronavirus lockdown gave him the opportunity to rework his concept into its current form.

headline: What We Learned From Week 11 in the N.F.L.
abstract: The Eagles squeaked out a win on the ground, Ezekiel Elliott and Tony Pollard had a field day for the Cowboys, and Zach Wilson ran into Bill Belichick again.
lead_paragraph: In Week 11, N.F.L. teams continued to settle into their identities, even as they begin to feel urgency with the postseason approaching. While the Bills got back on track, winning a surprise neutral-site game against the Browns, the Saints, the Falcons, and the Ravens continued to make their cases for playoff berths.

headline: Down and Out When 2022 Began, Novak Djokovic Is On Top Again. Kind Of.
abstract: Djokovic, the Serbian star, missed long stretches of the season because he refused to get vaccinated against Covid-19. After winning the ATP Finals, is he the king of tennis again? Maybe.
lead_paragraph: TURIN, Italy — The 2022 men’s tennis season finally ended Sunday night with Novak Djokovic, the 21-time Grand Slam singles champion, seemingly on top once more. This being tennis though, the story is not that simple. It rarely is, especially when Djokovic is involved. Actually, it’s pretty complicated.

headline: ‘Nothing Like a Buffalo Winter’: Residents Undaunted by 6 Feet of Snow
abstract: Life began returning to normal in western New York after a storm that at times dumped five inches of snow an hour on the region.
lead_paragraph: Buffalo seemed largely unfazed Sunday even as bad weather lingered after one of the biggest winter storms in recent state history dumped more than six feet of snow on the city, with intense winds triggering whiteout conditions that shut the region down.

headline: These Are New York’s First Recreational Marijuana Retailers
abstract: Cannabis regulators in New York State have said they hope to have the first retail locations for recreational marijuana in operation by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: New York took a significant step on Monday toward launching a legal market for recreational cannabis by approving 36 businesses and nonprofits for licenses to operate the first retail dispensaries in the state.

headline: Requiring Rare Knowledge
abstract: Brandon Koppy’s puzzle celebrates the beautiful game.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Review: In ‘Sandra,’ a Search for a Friend Leads to Self-Discovery
abstract: In the playwright David Cale’s thriller, a woman looking for a vanished friend discovers a new sense of self.
lead_paragraph: David Cale’s new play, “Sandra,” is packed with classic thriller tropes, as if he had challenged himself to cram as many of the genre’s staples as possible into a 90-minute show — I kept waiting for someone to transfer information from a computer to a USB key as seconds ticked by.

headline: Ukraine Plans Evacuations in 2 Stricken Cities as Temperatures Plunge
abstract: The government is making plans to evacuate residents who want to leave from Kherson and Mykolaiv, where fighting has badly damaged the infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian government is preparing to help evacuate residents from two cities where shattered electricity and heating infrastructure has raised fears of a humanitarian crisis when winter sets in, officials said over the weekend.

headline: Trump Family’s Newest Partners: Middle Eastern Governments
abstract: The government of Oman is a partner in a real estate deal signed last week by the former president, intensifying questions about a potential conflict as he seeks the White House again.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When former President Donald J. Trump returned briefly last week to his office at Trump Tower in New York, he was joined by his son Eric Trump and the top executive of a Saudi Arabian real estate company to sign a deal that creates new conflict-of-interest questions for his just-launched presidential campaign.

headline: News Corp Investors Raise Concerns About Proposed Merger With Fox
abstract: Concerned that a merger would undervalue News Corp, investors are asking a special committee of independent board members to look more skeptically at the proposal.
lead_paragraph: An activist investor escalated its pressure on News Corp on Sunday, asking it to reconsider a proposal by Rupert Murdoch to combine the two parts of his media business, News Corp and Fox.

headline: How Gregg Berhalter Made the U.S. Team His Own
abstract: After an embarrassing failure to qualify for the 2018 World Cup, the U.S. has returned to the event with a new identity instilled by its coach.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates of U.S. vs. England and more World Cup news.

headline: Club Q Patron Who Tackled Gunman ‘Saved Dozens and Dozens of Lives’
abstract: The carnage at a Colorado Springs nightclub where at least five people were killed in a shooting on Saturday night could have been far worse, the club’s owners said.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — The patron who tackled a gunman inside a gay nightclub in Colorado Springs on Saturday night prevented a deadly shooting from being far worse, the club’s owners said on Sunday.

headline: Jason David Frank, Who Starred in ‘Power Rangers’ Franchise, Dies at 49
abstract: Mr. Frank played the Green and White Rangers in the campy television show, which featured six teenage high school students who transformed into superheroes to defend Earth against evil aliens.
lead_paragraph: Jason David Frank, who played the Green Ranger and later the White Ranger on the popular 1990s children’s television show “The Mighty Morphin Power Rangers,” died on Saturday. He was 49.

headline: Allegation of Supreme Court Breach Prompts Calls for Inquiry and Ethics Code
abstract: A minister’s claim that a major contraception decision was prematurely disclosed through a secretive influence campaign underscores the court’s lack of transparency and accountability.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers are demanding further investigation at the Supreme Court and renewing their calls for binding ethics rules for the justices, after allegations that a landmark 2014 contraception decision was prematurely disclosed through a secretive influence campaign by anti-abortion activists.

headline: Deal to Merge Two Publishing Giants Is on the Verge of Collapse
abstract: Penguin Random House’s agreement to buy Simon & Schuster is set to fall through. Simon & Schuster’s parent company decided not to extend it after a judge blocked the purchase.
lead_paragraph: Penguin Random House’s deal to buy Simon & Schuster, a rival publisher, is close to collapsing after Simon & Schuster’s parent company decided to allow the purchase agreement to expire, according to a person familiar with the decision who spoke anonymously to discuss confidential deliberations.

headline: Disney Brings Back Bob Iger After Ousting Chapek as C.E.O.
abstract: Mr. Iger is returning to the company he ran for 15 years after being succeeded by Bob Chapek in 2020.
lead_paragraph: In a move that dropped jaws in Hollywood and prompted comparisons to an implausible screenplay, the board of the Walt Disney Company fired Bob Chapek as chief executive on Sunday and announced that Robert A. Iger would return to run the company, effective immediately.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Ends With a Promise of More Life
abstract: The 11th and final season of “The Walking Dead” concluded Sunday night by teeing up several impending spinoffs. Here are five takeaways from the long-awaited ending.
lead_paragraph: This article includes spoilers for the series finale of “The Walking Dead.”

headline: How Do You Pronounce Qatar? Probably Incorrectly.
abstract: Is it Kuh-TAR, like guitar? Or KUH-ter, like cutter? A vital World Cup investigation.
lead_paragraph: Is it Kuh-TAR, like guitar? Or KUH-ter, like cutter? A vital World Cup investigation.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: A nightclub shooting in Colorado kills five.
lead_paragraph: At least five people were killed when a man stormed into an L.G.B.T.Q. nightclub in Colorado Springs just before midnight on Saturday and opened fire with a long rifle, the authorities said. Officials praised patrons inside the establishment, Club Q, for quickly subduing the gunman, though at least 25 people were injured in the chaos.

headline: What Will Russia Without Putin Look Like? Maybe This.
abstract: The country isn’t doomed to repeat the past.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s current condition — militarized, isolated, corrupt, dominated by the security services and hemorrhaging talent as hundreds of thousands flee abroad to escape service in a horrific war — is bleak.

headline: No Corrections: Nov. 21, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 21, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Word of the Day: obsequious
abstract: This word has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word obsequious has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 14 in “‘Official Competition’ Review: Madness in Their Methods” by A.O. Scott:

headline: What to Know About the Georgia Runoff
abstract: As Senator Raphael Warnock and Herschel Walker enter the final weeks of their runoff election, both sides are pouring money into ads and courting national allies for visits.
lead_paragraph: As Senator Raphael Warnock and Herschel Walker enter the final weeks of their runoff election, both sides are pouring money into ads and courting national allies for visits.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Inside a Crypto Nemesis’ Campaign to Rein In the Industry
abstract: Gary Gensler, the chair of the S.E.C., is at the center of a reckoning over the future of cryptocurrency after the implosion of FTX.
lead_paragraph: In March, eight months before his cryptocurrency empire imploded, Sam Bankman-Fried joined a video call with Gary Gensler, a longtime financial regulator who now leads the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: A Conversation With the Women Who Curate New York’s Museums
abstract: Ann Temkin of MoMA and Naomi Beckwith of the Guggenheim discuss how they’re rethinking business as usual — and why they have reason to be hopeful.
lead_paragraph: At a time when museums are facing numerous challenges — including the pandemic fallout and demands for greater diversity — leaders at those institutions find themselves grappling with how to chart a new future without completely jettisoning the past.

headline: Inside the Saudi Strategy to Keep the World Hooked on Oil
abstract: The kingdom is working to keep fossil fuels at the center of the world economy for decades to come by lobbying, funding research and using its diplomatic muscle to obstruct climate action.
lead_paragraph: Shimmering in the desert is a futuristic research center with an urgent mission: Make Saudi Arabia’s oil-based economy greener, and quickly. The goal is to rapidly build more solar panels and expand electric-car use so the kingdom eventually burns far less oil.

headline: Why the World Cup in Qatar Brings Fans Joy and Anxiety
abstract: Two things can be true at the same time: The World Cup will dazzle fans and also make them dizzy over the human rights issues where the event is staged.
lead_paragraph: Kieran Jones, an avid soccer fan who lives in Cardiff, Wales, can tell you all the details about the last time his beloved Welsh national team made it to the World Cup. It was 1958, nearly a decade before he was born. A young and then little-known Brazilian named Pelé scored the goal that knocked Wales from the tournament.

headline: Can Big Tech Get Bigger? Microsoft Presses Governments to Say Yes.
abstract: Microsoft’s $69 billion deal for Activision Blizzard, which is undergoing reviews in 16 countries, has become a test for whether tech giants can buy companies amid a backlash.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, Microsoft has accused Sony, its chief video game rival, of misleading regulators. Its lawyers have showed off game consoles, including an Xbox, to British officials. And the president of a major union that Microsoft wooed has spoken up on the company’s behalf to the Federal Trade Commission.

headline: Would You Pay $1,000 to See the World’s Biggest Lizards?
abstract: Indonesia wants to make it vastly more expensive to see the country’s famous Komodo dragons. The local tourism industry is up in arms.
lead_paragraph: PADAR ISLAND, Indonesia — The tourists arrived by the boatload, ready to climb 900 steps to the summit of remote Padar Island for their sunrise reward: a sweeping vista of turquoise bays set off by white-sand beaches. In the distance, they could see Komodo Island, where the world’s largest lizard, the fearsome Komodo dragon, roams freely, evoking the age of the dinosaurs.

headline: Party Poster
abstract: In Mumbai, India, science, religion and politics collide when a group of laundry workers sets out to design a poster in time for a major festival.
lead_paragraph: In Mumbai, India, science, religion and politics collide when a group of laundry workers sets out to design a poster in time for a major festival.

headline: What Should I Wear to Testify in Court?
abstract: A reader grapples with the appropriate attire to take the stand as a witness for the prosecution in an upcoming trial.
lead_paragraph: We spend a lot of time thinking about and reacting to what the plaintiffs and defendants of trials wear. Just consider the reaction to Amber Heard’s pinstriped suiting and 1930s updos during the Depp-Heard defamation trial, as well as Johnny Depp’s three-piece suits and tightly controlled ponytails. Or the scrutiny given to Elizabeth Holmes when she traded her black tech-wizard turtlenecks for bland blazers and skirts during her fraud trial.

headline: Who Is Someone You Would Like to Thank?
abstract: What would you write in a thank-you note to that person?
lead_paragraph: When was the last time someone did something nice for you?

headline: Turning the Gestures of Everyday Life Into Art
abstract: The choreographer Katja Heitmann collects people’s habits and mannerisms — how they walk, stand, kiss, sleep and fidget — for her ongoing dance project.
lead_paragraph: TILBURG, the Netherlands — A few times each day, Mahat Arab, a 26-year-old Dutch spoken-word artist, cracks the knuckles of his left hand during tasks that make him feel anxious, like driving a car or talking on the phone. Karolien Wauters, a 23-year-old dancer, often tucks her hand into the waistband of her leggings. And Chandra Merx, a 41-year-old City Council official in Maastricht, raises her eyebrows, not only as an expression of surprise, but also as a reflex when she’s rushing or lost in thought.

headline: The Pro-Life Movement Made a Bargain With Trump, and It Has Paid Dearly
abstract: The movement’s greatest legal triumph could lead to enduring cultural defeat.
lead_paragraph: The midterms were hard for pro-life Americans. In every state where abortion referendums were on the ballot, the abortion-rights side prevailed, even in red states such as Kentucky and Montana and a swing state, Michigan. The overturning of Roe v. Wade helped keep the Senate blue. It almost stopped the Republican Party from taking the House. Exit polls indicate that abortion was just behind inflation as the most important issue for voters — and 76 percent of those who made abortion their top issue chose Democrats.

headline: Kathy Acker, Drawn to the Margins, Pushed Literature’s Boundaries
abstract: “Eat Your Mind,” a new biography by Jason McBride, surveys her life and art.
lead_paragraph: Kathy Acker — proto-punk, tough-stemmed flower, ransacker of texts, literary heir to William S. Burroughs and Gertrude Stein, sex worker, loather of establishments, striver for maximum impudence — was born into a soft life on Manhattan’s East Side in 1947.

headline: Laughing at Kanye Doesn’t Help
abstract: My people have always turned our haters into humor. It still breaks my heart when antisemitism starts trending.
lead_paragraph: Just a couple of weeks after vowing, on Twitter, to go “death con 3 On JEWISH PEOPLE,” the musician and designer Kanye West, who now goes by “Ye,” found himself on camera outside what looked like a strip of businesses in Los Angeles — one of those parking-lot nonplaces so typical to TMZ-style videos. A scrum of reporters asked him about the multiplatformed antisemitic hatred he had, lately, been trading in, and the ensuing fallout, which saw him dropped by corporate partners including Adidas and Balenciaga. In response, he produced his phone and read, with increasing vigor, from a website listing which media and entertainment companies have Jewish executives, finally holding up his phone as if to offer visual proof of who, supposedly, controlled everything.

headline: How to Give Thanks in a Screwed-Up World
abstract: This time of year, despite all sorrows, I try to see the world the way my father did.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — My father always had a ready answer to the question that greases the gears of human discourse. Whenever anyone he didn’t know particularly well — a neighbor or a sales clerk or someone at church — would ask, “How are you, Mr. Renkl?” my father didn’t say, “Just fine, thank you.” His answer was always “Fantastic!” Later, when he was dying, it was the answer he gave even to family members checking in. Right up to his death, he was always faaaantastic.

headline: The Subtle Art of Political Messaging as Practiced by the Laundrymen of Mumbai
abstract: The medium is the message: a poster with your face on it.
lead_paragraph: In India during religious festivals, political elections and even banal events like politicians’ birthdays, large banners go up in public places. These posters share nearly identical elements: portraits of devotees, politicians or aspiring politicians and messages devoted to elders or the gods.

headline: How One of the Country’s Most Storied C.E.O.s Destroyed His Legacy
abstract: Jack Welch spent his last few years regretting the most important decision of his career.
lead_paragraph: Jack Welch, one of the most celebrated corporate chieftains of his time, spent the last few years of his life profoundly regretting what he believed was the most important decision of his career: his choice of successor.

headline: As New York City Schools Face a Crisis, Charter Schools Gain Students
abstract: Enrollment at charters is up and the governor has signaled a measure of support, but the privately run schools still face an enormous battle as they seek to expand.
lead_paragraph: As traditional public schools in the nation’s largest system endure a perilous period of student loss and funding shortfalls, New York City’s charter schools are on an upward trajectory.

headline: The Apartment Found Her? Yes, and Three of Her Fellow Doctors
abstract: Puja Patel wanted her own apartment and wanted to be within walking distance of her new job as an emergency room doctor at Mount Sinai Queens.
lead_paragraph: In May, Dr. Puja Patel took a vacation to Italy. But like many people looking to escape, she struggled to do so — work and real life always hover, buzzing with cellphone notifications and reminders. For Dr. Patel and her three friends on the trip, all of whom spent the pandemic working in hospital emergency rooms, it was about processing what they had just experienced.

headline: That Feeling When the Magic Stops Working
abstract: For Trump, Pelosi, Biden and Musk, not everything is going according to plan.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, before we get to politics, let’s talk about the terrible shooting at the gay club in Colorado Springs on Saturday night. To me, it speaks to both gay rights and gun violence. We’ve been making certain progress on the first, not really on the second. And if you want to tie in the mass shooting at the University of Virginia and the terrible stabbings in Idaho — Lord, what do you say?

headline: Scientists Don’t Agree on What Causes Obesity, but They Know What Doesn’t
abstract: Rates of obesity won’t budge as long as society views it as a personal issue.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A select group of the world’s top researchers studying obesity‌ recently gathered in the gilded rooms of the Royal Society, the science academy of Isaac Newton and Charles Darwin, where ideas like gravity and evolution were once debated.

headline: John Roberts’s Early Supreme Court Agenda: A Study in Disappointment
abstract: Soon after he joined the court, the chief justice said he would seek to protect its credibility by encouraging narrow, unanimous rulings. That project has failed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After finishing his first term on the Supreme Court in 2006, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. was feeling pretty good. The court had issued its longest run of unanimous decisions in modern history, and he was ready to sketch out an ambitious and optimistic plan for the balance of his tenure.

headline: Dumpster Diving to Shame Stores and Fight Waste
abstract: Activists are posting their hauls on TikTok to raise public awareness.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Manhattan Prosecutors Move to Jump-Start Criminal Inquiry Into Trump
abstract: The district attorney’s office is investigating Donald J. Trump’s role in a hush-money payment to a porn star, an approach that previously failed to bear fruit.
