lead_paragraph: The Manhattan district attorney’s office has moved to jump-start its criminal investigation into Donald J. Trump, according to people with knowledge of the matter, seeking to breathe new life into an inquiry that once seemed to have reached a dead end.

headline: The Judge and the Case That Came Back to Haunt Him
abstract: In 1981, Anthony Kline helped send a juvenile offender to prison for four decades. This year, in a twist of fate, he had a chance to decide her case again.
lead_paragraph: None of Anthony Kline’s colleagues had ever seen it happen. The most senior justice on California’s First District Court of Appeal, Kline was asking to be transferred to the juvenile bench, at the advanced age of 83. Juvenile was the scrappy place you started a career, not the triumphant place you ended one. But after four decades in appeals, Kline was feeling estranged from real life. He wanted to spend a year in juvie before retiring.

headline: Beyond Meat Is Struggling, and the Plant-Based Meat Industry Worries
abstract: A few years ago, business was booming. That growth has slowed, with some wondering if the number of consumers has reached its limit.
lead_paragraph: For a while, it seemed Beyond Meat was taking over the world.

headline: He Helps the RealReal Keep It Real
abstract: Dominik Halás, 29, is entrusted by the company to authenticate vintage clothes — many of which are older than he.
lead_paragraph: The trash bags seemingly contained a treasure trove. Comme des Garçons, Maison Margiela, Helmut Lang and Jean Paul Gaultier were all names on the tags of the clothes stuffed inside.

headline: A Cure for Thanksgiving Stress? For Many, It’s a Cruise.
abstract: No cooking, no cleanup, no script: A growing number of Americans are spending the holiday at sea, making new friends and traditions.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Webb planned and hosted Thanksgiving for more than 48 years. She would wake up at 4 a.m. to start setting the table, spend all day cooking for about 16 guests — including her two children and three grandchildren — and then clean the house once everyone left.

headline: How Did Mud Get Everywhere?
abstract: From stages to runways, dirt has become a go-to metaphor.
lead_paragraph: Balenciaga’s spring 2023 show, which took place this October at a darkened convention center on the outskirts of Paris, was a complete mess. To match the collection’s aggressive, almost militaristic severity — a multipocket combat jacket, graffitied hoodies, a dress made entirely from the brand’s repurposed leather City bags — the Spanish artist Santiago Sierra hauled over 9,700 cubic feet of dank earth into the venue to create troughs through which models plodded, their clothes gathering sludge with each step. A custom scent, redolent of decomposition and developed by the Norwegian smell researcher and artist Sissel Tolaas, lingered in the post-apocalyptic bog. According to Balenciaga’s artistic director, Demna, the set was “a metaphor for digging for truth.”

headline: How Wild Turkeys Find Love
abstract: A photographer in Wisconsin set out to learn how wild turkeys attract their mates — and found that the answer involves wingmen and sexy snoods.
lead_paragraph: As spring bursts forth, wild turkeys begin the mating game. Groups congregate in lawns and fields — and sometimes in the middle of the street. Males puff out their iridescent feathers, fan their tails and drag their wings on the ground in a vie for the right to breed. Their faces and necks turn dazzling shades of blue and red.

headline: Greenwich Village, Storied Home of Bohemia and Gay History
abstract: The architectural historian Andrew Dolkart leads a walk past landmarks like the Stonewall Inn, Julius’ bar and the home of Lorraine Hansberry.
lead_paragraph: The fountainhead of American bohemia, Greenwich Village has always departed from the straight and narrow. Its entanglements of winding streets, defying the city grid, include remnants of cow paths and property lines from when the area was a sprawl of Dutch, then English, farms.

headline: With Anxiety on the Rise, Some Children Try ‘Exposure Therapy’
abstract: A gold-standard treatment for phobias and anxieties encourages young people to follow an old and simple dictum: Face your fears.
lead_paragraph: CRANSTON, R.I. — Audrey Pirri, 16, had been terrified of vomiting since she was a toddler. She worried every time she shared a meal with family or friends, restricting herself to “safe” foods like pretzels and salad that wouldn’t upset her stomach, if she ate at all. She was afraid to ride in the car with her brother, who often got carsick. She fretted for hours about an upcoming visit to a carnival or stadium — anywhere with lots of people and their germs.

headline: What You Get for $4.7 Million in California
abstract: A 1929 Spanish Revival retreat in Pebble Beach, a midcentury home in Beverly Hills and a four-bedroom house in a gated community in Laguna Niguel.
lead_paragraph: A 1929 Spanish Revival retreat in Pebble Beach, a midcentury home in Beverly Hills and a four-bedroom house in a gated community in Laguna Niguel.

headline: Trapped Between Extremists and Extreme Weather, Somalis Brace for Famine
abstract: The worst drought in 40 years is pushing Somalia to the brink. If it triggers a rare famine declaration, the militant group Al Shabab will also be to blame.
lead_paragraph: The sea of rag-and-stick tents that spreads in every direction from the hungry, embattled city of Baidoa, in southern Somalia, gives way to sprawling plains controlled by the militants of Al Shabab.

headline: On the River at Night, Ambushing Russians
abstract: Ukrainian units plying the Dnipro River venture behind enemy lines under the cover of darkness, carrying out reconnaissance and sabotage.
lead_paragraph: ON THE BANKS OF THE DNIPRO RIVER, Ukraine — Under cover of darkness, a group of soldiers heaved their dinghy off the sand into the water. Another group loaded equipment with a heavy clanking into their boat, while a third pushed off silently with oars. Engines humming quietly, the boats turned to the open water and disappeared into the blackness.

headline: $4.7 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1929 Spanish Revival retreat in Pebble Beach, a midcentury home in Beverly Hills and a four-bedroom house in a gated community in Laguna Niguel.
lead_paragraph: The architect of this house, Hugh W. Comstock, worked extensively in the area in the 1920s and 1930s, designing a number of storybook cottages in nearby Carmel-by-the-Sea. This home has been updated several times since it was built, although many original details — including the roof’s adobe-style tiles — remain intact.

headline: The 2022 Well Gift Guide
abstract: Looking for the perfect present? We’ve got 28 ways to keep your loved ones healthy and happy.
lead_paragraph: One minute, you have all the time in the world to find perfect presents for your partner, the colleague you picked for Secret Santa and your mother-in-law; the next, it is Dec. 23 and you’re browsing gift cards at the drugstore. The Well desk is here to help you find great affordable gifts (and a few luxurious splurges). Our editors and reporters have picked their favorite items for living well — from skin care and self care to fitness and better rest — so you can stay calm now, and your loved ones can feel happy and healthy all year long.

headline: Up for Auction: Nike Air Force Ones Signed by Ice-T
abstract: A sale of gifts to New York City mayors also features a Louis Vuitton soccer ball that was given to Rudolph Giuliani.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Today we’ll look at the city’s auction of 50 gifts to past mayors. We’ll also look at how prosecutors are once again scrutinizing Donald Trump’s role in hush-money payments to a porn star.

headline: U.N. inspectors report new shelling damage at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear complex.
abstract: While there were no immediate safety concerns, the head of the U.N. nuclear watchdog said the scope of the damage “demonstrates the sheer intensity of the attacks on one of the world’s largest nuclear power plants.”
lead_paragraph: International nuclear inspectors reported significant damage from weekend shelling at Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant but found key equipment intact and “no immediate nuclear safety or security concerns,” the U.N.’s nuclear watchdog said on Monday.

headline: Who Should Run in 2024? We Asked Our Readers.
abstract: More than 10,000 told us about their ideal candidates.
lead_paragraph: The midterm elections left neither Democrats nor Republicans with a clear advantage heading into the next presidential campaign season. Donald Trump just announced his candidacy, but that’s not stopping other Republicans from considering jumping in. President Biden says he will make a decision about a re-election bid early next year; some Democrats say they don’t want him to run again, but it’s hardly obvious who else would be a formidable Democratic Party nominee in 2024.

headline: ‘He Saved a Lot of Lives’: Combat Veteran Tackled Colorado Gunman
abstract: The quick actions of a retired army major and others took down the gunman before he reached a crowded patio.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Richard M. Fierro was at a table in Club Q with his wife, daughter and friends on Saturday, watching a drag show, when the sudden flash of gunfire ripped across the nightclub. His instincts from four combat deployments as an Army officer in Iraq and Afghanistan kicked in.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Fans Torn in Two: Loving the Games but Not the Host
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 21, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “There isn’t one thing that really stands out that’s terrible. It’s everything. It’s all bad.”

headline: Trump Faces a New Special Counsel
abstract: In a moment of political déjà vu, the Justice Department’s criminal investigations into Donald J. Trump have taken a familiar turn.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is running for president again. Donald J. Trump is back on Twitter again. And now a special prosecutor has been appointed to investigate Donald J. Trump again.

headline: Gambling’s Spread
abstract: The popularity of sports betting has exploded in recent years in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, betting on live sports was illegal in most of the United States. Now, fans watching games or attending them at stadiums are barraged with advertisements encouraging them to bet on matchups, not just watch as spectators.

headline: In Morocco, a Hotel That Offers the Luxury of Peace and Quiet
abstract: The newly opened Olinto is a serene escape in the foothills of the Atlas Mountains.
lead_paragraph: In the early ’90s, Fabrizio Ruspoli di Poggio Suasa, a French Italian aristocrat from Paris and a former dealer in 18th-century French furniture, moved to Marrakesh. Ruspoli, who grew up visiting his grandmother in Morocco, quickly felt at home among the city’s well-known expats — among them at the time the interior designer Bill Willis, the fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent and his partner, Pierre Bergé — and soon purchased the popular French restaurant La Maison Arabe, transforming it into the medina’s first riad hotel. But in the three decades since his arrival, says Ruspoli, Marrakesh has, for better and worse, grown “along with the noise of scooters.” So three years ago, he decided to sell the hotel to seek a quieter life about an hour’s drive outside of town in the Atlas Mountains. But not too quiet: This fall, Ruspoli and his longtime partner, José Abete, opened a new property, Olinto, in the lush Ouirgane Valley. Set on 10 acres planted with olive groves and fragrant gardens, the hotel has dramatic views of the red earth mountains, with nine vine-covered guesthouses with rooftop sitting areas, private gardens and, in some cases, pools. A spa will open sometime next year, but for now, guests can lounge on the many wisteria-lined terraces and enjoy massages in the traditional hammam. Ruspoli, who says he was “born playing a piano,” named his new project in honor of his like-minded ancestor Marquis Francesco Maria Ruspoli, a patron of Handel, who adopted the moniker Olinto, after a village in ancient Greece, as part of his membership in a musical and literary society called the Academy of Arcadia. “My hope is to host something similar here: a retreat and, eventually, a small music festival surrounded by my gardens,” he says. Rates start at $700 per night, olinto.net.

headline: It was never easy being Club Q in Colorado Springs.
abstract: For years, the city was a center of anti-gay activism.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — In its early days, 20 years ago, the site for Club Q was selected in part because of its setting, well back from the nearest roads, which offered its clientele the protection of not being seen entering and leaving.

headline: Powerful Earthquake Kills at Least 162 in Indonesia; Toll Expected to Mount
abstract: The quake on the nation’s main island, Java, destroyed hundreds of buildings, and officials feared that many people were still trapped beneath the rubble.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A powerful earthquake struck Indonesia’s main island of Java on Monday, killing at least 162 people, injuring hundreds more and shaking tall buildings in the capital, Jakarta, 60 miles away. Many people were believed to be still trapped beneath the rubble, leading to fears that the death toll would sharply increase.

headline: Iranian fans with pre-revolutionary flags are denied entry to the England game.
abstract: On the field, Iran’s players staged their own silent protest by declining to sing their country’s national anthem.
lead_paragraph: Iranian fans carrying the country’s pre-revolutionary flag were barred from entering their country’s World Cup game against England on Monday unless they surrendered the flags, which are viewed as a symbol of protest of Iran’s theocratic government.

headline: Goals come in bunches for England in a romp over Iran.
abstract: Five England players scored against Iran, who lost their goalkeeper early on to injury.
lead_paragraph: England ran rings around an overmatched Iran in a 6-2 shellacking in Qatar on Monday.

headline: Netanyahu Awarded Damages After a Predecessor Called Him ‘Mentally Ill’
abstract: The Israeli prime minister-designate, Benjamin Netanyahu, and his family won a libel suit against a former prime minister, Ehud Olmert, but got far less compensation than they had demanded.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Even by the often toxic standards of Israeli political discourse there are limits, a judge ruled on Monday, awarding damages to the newly designated prime minister of Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu, and members of his family in a libel suit they brought against another former prime minister, Ehud Olmert, who had described them as being “mentally ill.”

headline: Ex-President Unlawfully Released From Jail, South African Court Rules
abstract: The Supreme Court decision raises the possibility that former President Jacob Zuma, who was granted medical parole from a contempt-of-court sentence, may have to return to prison.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — A South African court ruled on Monday that a decision to allow former President Jacob Zuma to serve out a 15-month sentence at home on medical grounds after he failed to cooperate with a corruption inquiry was unlawful, raising the possibility that he may have to return to prison.

headline: Would You Risk Your Life to Return to Your Former Self?
abstract: In “Aesthetica,” Allie Rowbottom imagines a 35-year-old ex-influencer who’s about to undergo an extreme surgery to undo every cosmetic procedure she’s endured to date.
lead_paragraph: It is 2032, and a 35-year-old woman sits beside a hotel pool in Los Angeles, recalling her first bikini wax. This is where Anna Wrey’s story begins, on one long night before she is to undergo an extreme and elective surgery known as “Aesthetica,” which promises to reverse every procedure she’s had on her face and body since that wax, 15 years earlier. The doctor warns her of the risks of autoimmune complications and sepsis, but “I entwined myself, willingly, in a fast dance with death,” Anna says, booking immediately.

headline: Investors Cheer Leadership Shakeup at Disney
abstract: Shares in the entertainment giant climbed more than 9 percent in premarket trading on Monday following the ouster of chief executive officer Bob Chapek.
lead_paragraph: Last December, Robert Iger told a Variety reporter he wasn’t second-guessing his departure from Disney after leading the entertainment giant on a 15-year run of growth and profits. Besides, he’d later acknowledge, Hollywood is going through an “age of great anxiety” with uncertainty at the box office and in the streaming wars.

headline: 1947: Rail Walkout in Marseilles Halts Traffic
abstract: The number of strikers in the French port city reached 100,000, with thousands of passengers stranded and communication disrupted.
lead_paragraph: MARSEILLES, Nov. 20 — A general walkout of the Marseilles railroad men this afternoon brought the number of strikers in this port city up to 100,000 and halted all rail communication with other cities.

headline: 5.6-Magnitude Quake Kills More Than 250 People in Indonesia
abstract: A powerful earthquake struck Indonesia’s main island, Java, on Monday, killing more than 250 people and injuring hundreds of others, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A powerful earthquake struck Indonesia’s main island, Java, on Monday, killing more than 250 people and injuring hundreds of others, officials said.

headline: Story Collections That Ask: ‘How Did I Get Here?’
abstract: From farmworkers in California’s Central Valley to vacationers in Jamaica and Connecticut, these protagonists find themselves in lives they don’t quite recognize.
lead_paragraph: Dionne Irving’s electric collection, THE ISLANDS: Stories (259 pp., Catapult, paperback, $16.95), investigates the alienations that come with displacement, tracing the movements of Jamaican immigrants and their descendants across the United States, Panama and Europe. What does it mean to be a part of the Black diaspora — born of a shared history of colonialism, racism and slavery — while also feeling dislocated from the Jamaican culture you still carry with you? In an ars poetica for the entire collection, the Queens-born Jamaican protagonist of “Some People” thinks after a P.T.A. dinner party: “She will recreate herself until she figures out who she is, asking herself again and again, How did I get here?” The answers for each protagonist sweep generations, migrations and continents.

headline: Wordle Wrap-Up: Nov. 14 to 20
abstract: A recap of the Wordle answers for the past week.
lead_paragraph: Hi Wordlers! Welcome to Wordle Wrap-Up, a reminder of which words were answers this week. For stories, stats and brain teasers, sign up for the Gameplay newsletter. For a daily reminder to play Wordle, sign up for reminders.

headline: Exploring a Plan to Remake the L.A. River
abstract: The concrete-encased river is seen as a blight, but figuring out how to redesign it is a tall task.
lead_paragraph: Today we’ll start with a short history lesson about one of Los Angeles’s most vital (and most forgotten) landmarks: the Los Angeles River.

headline: Key Freight Rail Union Rejects Deal, Increasing Strike Risk
abstract: The tentative agreement, brokered in September with help from the Biden administration, had averted a strike before the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: Members of a union that primarily represents freight rail conductors have narrowly voted down a tentative labor contract, their union said Monday.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Bachelor in Paradise’ and Thanksgiving Day Parade
abstract: The reality dating show wraps up this season, and the 96th annual Macy’s parade takes place in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 21 — 27. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Liza Colón-Zayas Swears by Brené Brown, ‘Hacks’ and Hugs
abstract: The actress, who won fans for her turn as a wary prep cook on “The Bear,” makes her Broadway debut in “Between Riverside and Crazy.”
lead_paragraph: “I’m sorry!” Liza Colón-Zayas said from the bedroom of her Bronx home on a Friday afternoon as car horns blared over the phone. “This is the only time of the day it’s loud!”

headline: A Tale of Two Weddings: Trump and Biden
abstract: In Washington, D.C., and Mar-a-Lago, political and personal mythmaking collide.
lead_paragraph: Two weekends. Two weddings. Two seats of power. Two first families: one former, one current, both hoping, it seems likely, to be future as well. And so two nonpolitical events that, nevertheless, came framed in the mythmaking of politics.

headline: On the Ground at the U.N. Climate Summit
abstract: Here’s a look at the conference's effect on the local economy.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a look at the conference's effect on the local economy.

headline: In Silence or Aloud, High-Profile Iranians Signal Support for Protests
abstract: World Cup soccer players, movie personalities and other prominent Iranians have shown support for the protests that have engulfed the country.
lead_paragraph: At the World Cup in Qatar, Iran’s soccer players on Monday declined to sing their country’s national anthem. In Tehran, two well-known actresses were arrested over the weekend for defiantly removing their head scarves. And at least nine prominent Iranians were summoned for questioning for daring to criticize the authorities.

headline: Buffalo Museum to Reopen in May
abstract: New York State has committed $20 million for the campus expansion, in the governor’s hometown, designed by the OMA partner Shohei Shigematsu.
lead_paragraph: The former Albright-Knox Art Gallery, now named the Buffalo AKG Art Museum, will reopen to the public on May 25, 2023, with a vastly renovated and expanded campus designed by the OMA partner Shohei Shigematsu.

headline: Who Needs Turkey?
abstract: We have alternatives for your Thanksgiving centerpiece, as well as sides to fill out the meal.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a Thanksgiving confession. During the first year of the pandemic, when our little family of three celebrated the holiday with no flock of relatives to feed, we replaced the usual 12-pound turkey with a diminutive roast duck. I posted this on my Instagram and got a blizzard of positive responses.

headline: The Trisha Brown Company Hires a Choreographer Not Named Trisha Brown
abstract: Judith Sánchez Ruíz, a former dancer in the company, has been commissioned to make its first work not by Brown.
lead_paragraph: For all of its 52-year history, the Trisha Brown Dance Company has exclusively presented work by its founding artistic director, the choreographer Trisha Brown, who died in 2017. But the company announced on Monday that it has commissioned its first dance by a choreographer other than Brown: Judith Sánchez Ruíz, whose “Let’s Talk About Bleeding” will have its premiere during the company’s 2023 season at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan.

headline: Climate Change Is Threatening Hawaii’s Coral Reefs. So They Called the Insurance Guy.
abstract: If worsening coastal storms damage the reefs, the Nature Conservancy will get a payout and use the money to repair the coral — work that state officials can’t afford to do.
lead_paragraph: As climate change makes coastal storms more destructive, an environmental group is trying a new approach to protecting Hawaii’s coral reefs. It could become a model for defending natural structures around the country — if it works.

headline: Drag events across the country have often faced threats in recent years.
abstract: Club Q, where five people were killed in a shooting over the weekend, had been scheduled to host a drag brunch on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: The deadly shooting at Club Q, one of the few refuges for L.G.B.T.Q. people in Colorado Springs, came at a time when drag events, and the venues that host them, have been subject to frequent threats across the United States.

headline: With time running out against Senegal, the Dutch strike, twice.
abstract: In his World Cup debut, Cody Gakpo scored in the 84th minute to put the Netherlands ahead of Senegal.
lead_paragraph: The goal that distinguished the Dutch on Monday came late, against the run of play and after several missed chances. But it granted them victory nonetheless against a stubborn Senegalese side that demonstrated, even without the forward Sadio Mane, the quality to emerge from a rugged Group A.

headline: Colorado Springs’s gay community mourns friends, and a sense of safety.
abstract: Workers at one restaurant decided they would serve dinner in a kind of defiant love for their community, which has not always felt welcome in a conservative area that was once a center of anti-gay activism.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — The grief swirling through Colorado Springs’s tight-knit L.G.B.T.Q. community was still raw when Kevin Dexter gathered his staff members at Shuga’s, an eclectic downtown restaurant, to decide whether to open on Sunday.

headline: Jeremy Pope Is Telling Himself ‘Yes’
abstract: As the Tony-nominated actor segues to the big screen in the gay military drama “The Inspection,” he reflects on years of shame and learning to accept himself.
lead_paragraph: I’ve interviewed my fair share of leading men, and I know how often that conversation turns into a war of attrition. Can I convince these famous, fortified actors to drop their walls before our time is up? Some of them are so skittish about introspection that it’s a challenge to even earn their eye contact.

headline: Colorado Springs Mourns the Loss of Five Lives and a Haven
abstract: The victims included caring bartenders who wanted to make people feel at home, and patrons of a club that offered more than a fun night out.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Whether it was bingo night on Wednesdays, karaoke night on Thursdays or drag shows on weekends, Ed Sanders looked forward to seeing Derrick Rump and Daniel Aston as they tended bar at Club Q.

headline: They Aren’t Headed to Cooperstown, but They Made Their Mark
abstract: This year’s Baseball Hall of Fame ballot has 14 new finalists, headlined by the polarizing Carlos Beltrán. The other 13 don’t require much debate, but they offer plenty of memories.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Beltrán could do it all: At various points in his 20-year career, he hit 40 homers, stole 40 bases, batted .300 and won Gold Gloves. He helped five different franchises reach the postseason, and even won the Roberto Clemente Award for community service.

headline: Amid Disruptions, England’s Win Over Iran Was the Easy Part
abstract: Ticket confusion and the squelching of various forms of protest overshadowed a fairly routine victory.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of Mexico vs. Argentina and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: Was Naming a Special Counsel in the Trump Cases the Right Move?
abstract: Readers discuss Attorney General Merrick Garland’s decision to appoint one. Also: Donald Trump and Elon Musk; heroism in Colorado; Qatar’s dark side.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: NASA Spacecraft Finishes Its Close Encounter With the Moon
abstract: The uncrewed Orion capsule, part of the Artemis I mission, flew within 81 miles of the lunar surface as it headed into the next stage of its journey.
lead_paragraph: NASA’s Orion spacecraft zipped past the moon’s far side on Monday, passing within 81 miles of the surface.

headline: What Is Offside in Soccer?
abstract: Understanding the rule can be tricky. This is your guide.
lead_paragraph: Understanding the rule can be tricky. This is your guide.

headline: This Mars Documentary Required Many Sols
abstract: “Good Night Oppy” chronicles the work and passion of the scientists who shepherded the Mars rover program.
lead_paragraph: Early in the documentary “Good Night Oppy,” footage from late 2002 shows Steve Squyres, clad in scrubs, staring down in quiet awe, his eyes welling up as he shakes his head in disbelief. Squyres, the principal investigator for NASA’s first Mars rover mission, is watching his babies take their first steps.

headline: Buffy Sainte-Marie Broke Boundaries in Folk. A Documentary Tells Her Story.
abstract: She brought attention to Indigenous issues in her music, and was the first Indigenous person to win an Oscar. “Buffy Sainte-Marie: Carry It On” makes the case for her continued importance.
lead_paragraph: One evening in 1962, a recent college graduate fresh to New York City took the stage for an open mic night at Gerdes Folk City in Greenwich Village. Her name was Buffy Sainte-Marie.

headline: From Yale Law to Oath Keepers: Stewart Rhodes’s Unlikely Journey
abstract: Jurors are expected to begin deliberating on Tuesday in the Jan. 6 seditious conspiracy trial of Mr. Rhodes, who went from an outsider at Yale Law to founder of a far-right militia group.
lead_paragraph: As a married father with young children, gun enthusiast and former Army paratrooper on a campus dominated by liberals, Stewart Rhodes stood out among the roughly 200 students who enrolled at Yale Law School in 2001.

headline: U.S. Approves Aid to Extend Life of California Nuclear Plant
abstract: The Energy Department’s grant of $1.1 billion is the latest step that could keep the reactor in operation beyond its scheduled shutdown in 2025.
lead_paragraph: California’s last nuclear power plant received a $1.1 billion federal grant on Monday as the state seeks to extend the plant’s operations — currently set to end in 2025 — to meet electricity demand at a time of intensifying climate events.

headline: Taylor Swift’s ‘Midnights’ Returns to No. 1 for a Third Week
abstract: Drake and 21 Savage’s collaborative album “Her Loss,” which topped the chart last week, falls to No. 2.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift’s “Midnights” returns to No. 1 on the latest Billboard album chart, notching its third time at the top after the slot was held for one week by Drake and 21 Savage.

headline: Planning for a Dark Christmas in Kyiv
abstract: Russian attacks have left millions across Ukraine without electricity. Our reporter went out in Kyiv to see how the city is preparing for a dark holiay.
lead_paragraph: Russian attacks have left millions across Ukraine without electricity. Our reporter went out in Kyiv to see how the city is preparing for a dark holiay.

headline: ‘The Hours’ Becomes an Opera. Don’t Expect the Book or Film.
abstract: A new adaptation is having its stage premiere at the Metropolitan Opera, featuring three star singers, Renée Fleming, Joyce DiDonato and Kelli O’Hara.
lead_paragraph: “I think it needs to be more surreal,” the conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin said from the orchestra pit of the Metropolitan Opera on a recent afternoon.

headline: Capitol Police Officer’s Suicide After Jan. 6 Qualifies for Line-of-Duty Death Benefit
abstract: Howard Liebengood was the first officer who died by suicide to qualify for death benefits after Congress expanded a program to compensate the families of officers killed in the line of duty.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has classified the suicide of Howard Liebengood, a Capitol Police officer who defended the Capitol during the Jan. 6, 2021, attack and took his own life days later, as a line-of-duty death, approving benefits for his wife, Serena.

headline: The history behind the Welsh national team’s anthem.
abstract: The 1983 tune by Dafydd Iwan, a Welsh folk singer, seems to follow the team everywhere.
lead_paragraph: The chorus of the song comes crashing down in an irresistible wave. You may not have any clue what the words mean, but that’s OK. Neither do many of the people singing it.

headline: What Elon Musk Is Doing to Twitter Is What He Did at Tesla and SpaceX
abstract: Firing people. Talking of bankruptcy. Telling workers to be “hard core.” Mr. Musk has repeatedly used those tactics at many of his companies.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk was sleeping at the office. He dismissed employees and executives at will. And he lamented his company was on the verge of bankruptcy.

headline: Prosecution Rests as Trump Company Trial Moves Faster Than Expected
abstract: In a sign of confidence, Manhattan prosecutors skipped a witness they had said they would call. The case could end as soon as next week.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan prosecutors rested their case in the tax fraud trial of Donald J. Trump’s family business on Monday without calling a witness they had previously planned to question, an indication of confidence after the company’s longtime chief financial officer testified last week.

headline: What Stage of Capitalism Is Sam Bankman-Fried?
abstract: FTX’s $32 billion valuation was a fantasy, but nobody bothered to look at it closely.
lead_paragraph: How do you make a multibillion-dollar company disappear in a week? For Sam Bankman-Fried and his crypto exchange FTX, the simple answer is that a leaked balance sheet leads your biggest rival, himself under federal scrutiny, to instigate a sort of “bank run” you cannot possibly cover, exposing billions of dollars in shortfalls you apparently created by riskily investing money that wasn’t yours. And revealing yourself, in the process, to be a very new kind of financial villain — one who pitches not just the prospect of profit but also deliverance from the corrupt speculative system in which you “made” your “billions.”

headline: Man Is Charged in Fatal Crash Into Apple Store Outside Boston
abstract: A 53-year-old man was charged with reckless homicide after the authorities said he drove his S.U.V. into the store in Hingham, Mass., killing one person and injuring more than a dozen others.
lead_paragraph: A 53-year-old man has been charged with reckless homicide after the authorities said he plowed his S.U.V. through the front window of an Apple store in a suburb of Boston on Monday, killing one person and injuring more than a dozen others.

headline: Western New York Digs Out After Heavy Snowfall
abstract: Crews cleared roads in the Buffalo area after a storm dropped six feet of snow in recent days.
lead_paragraph: Crews cleared roads in the Buffalo area after a storm dropped six feet of snow in recent days.

headline: Army Veteran Went Into ‘Combat Mode’ to Disarm the Club Q Gunman
abstract: Richard M. Fierro, who served for 15 years in the military, was at the nightclub in Colorado Springs with his family when the gunman opened fire. “I just knew I had to take him down,” he said.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Richard M. Fierro was at a table in Club Q with his wife, daughter and friends on Saturday, watching a drag show, when the sudden flash of gunfire ripped across the nightclub and instincts forged during four combat deployments in Iraq and Afghanistan instantly kicked in. Fight back, he told himself, protect your people.

headline: 5 Solutions for a Turkey S.O.S.
abstract: Each year, The Times’s Food editors field crucial (and common) questions about cooking the bird. Here are the answers.
lead_paragraph: Each year, The Times’s Food editors field crucial (and common) questions about cooking the bird. Here are the answers.

headline: A Strong Start Slips Through Americans’ Fingers in World Cup Opener
abstract: A late penalty gave Wales the opening it needed to pull to a draw with the United States.
lead_paragraph: AL RAYYAN, Qatar — Walker Zimmerman wagged his left pointer finger in the air from where he lay sprawled out on the ground. He shook his head and yelled, “No, no, no, no, no!” But it was to no avail. The referee was already pointing to the penalty spot.

headline: A Sustainability-Minded Cookbook Supporting the United Nations
abstract: Read the broadly international book, watch a documentary on a renowned Memphis, Tenn., barbecue restaurant, and more.
lead_paragraph: Not too many cooks, but just enough: There are 75 of them — chefs, farmers and Indigenous home cooks — that have contributed recipes to this collaboration between the United Nations and Kitchen Connection Alliance, a nonprofit that seeks to improve systems for growing and distributing food worldwide. Sustainability and healthy eating are front and center. There are five recipe sections covering food systems, biodiversity, sustainable consumption, food and climate change, and food waste. Among the stellar recipes in the generally vegetable-forward collection are Moroccan chorba with eggplant and sweet potato; a simple squash soup from the American Black Créole Community; Austrian potato goulash; and venison carpaccio with watercress salad, suitable for a party buffet. The carbon footprints are given only for the recipes in the climate change chapter; though they have them for the other recipes. And as comprehensive as this book might be, there is no recipe index and almost no reference to buying organic, though “sustainably sourced” is advised for seafood and eggs. Proceeds from sales benefit the development of a children’s version of the book and support the U.N. Bookstore and projects with Indigenous communities.

headline: Grim Videos and a Troubling Question
abstract: Footage suggests that a group of Russian soldiers captured by Ukrainian troops was killed at close range.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Alabama Suspends Executions After Lethal Injection Problems
abstract: Gov. Kay Ivey ordered a temporary stop to all executions after prison officials could not access the veins of two prisoners.
lead_paragraph: Alabama’s governor issued a sweeping order on Monday suspending all executions in the state and calling for a review of Alabama’s execution process following a series of problems delivering lethal injection drugs this year.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Indonesia’s Deadly Earthquake
abstract: Plus Iranian players protest at the World Cup and “Neighbours” will start filming again.
lead_paragraph: At least 162 people were dead after a powerful earthquake struck Java, Indonesia’s main island, yesterday. Hundreds more were injured. Officials expect the death toll to rise sharply — many people are trapped under damaged buildings or in landslides.

headline: The Best 50-Year-Old Investing Advice Money Can Buy
abstract: The latest thoughts on index investing from its first advocate.
lead_paragraph: Investing in broad-based index funds seems unambitious — a fallback for people who lack the confidence to pick stocks that will outperform the market.

headline: A Huge Merger’s Collapse Breaks a Pattern of Consolidation in Publishing
abstract: The deal to acquire Simon & Schuster would have made the buyer, Penguin Random House, even larger, and reduced the number of big publishers in the U.S. to four.
lead_paragraph: After two years of regulatory scrutiny and heated speculation in the publishing world, after a hard-fought court battle and hundreds of millions of dollars in expenses, Penguin Random House’s deal to buy Simon & Schuster officially collapsed on Monday.

headline: ‘No Fowl Play’: Biden Pardons a Pair of Thanksgiving Turkeys
abstract: The only “red wave” this holiday season, President Biden said, would be if his German shepherd “knocks over the cranberry sauce.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two lucky turkeys, named Chocolate and Chip, were spared their lives on Monday, but not from hearing about President Biden’s favorite subject of late: the Democrats’ stronger-than-expected showing in the midterm elections.

headline: New York’s L.G.B.T.Q. community is on edge after the attack.
abstract: Hours before the Colorado mass shooting, a gay bar in Manhattan was targeted for the fourth time this month when someone threw a brick at its window.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, revelry at a gay bar in Manhattan was interrupted for the fourth time this month by someone throwing a brick at its plate-glass window.

headline: ‘Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery’ Review: Another Clue for You All
abstract: Daniel Craig returns as the world’s greatest detective, facing down a blue-chip cast of possible murderers in Rian Johnson’s new whodunit.
lead_paragraph: It starts as a game for the amusement of a tech billionaire. Miles Bron, a would-be master of the universe played with knowing exuberance by Edward Norton, invites a small group of friends to a party on his private island. The weekend’s entertainment will be a make-believe murder mystery, with Miles himself as the victim and center of attention. By the end, real homicides have been committed and the fun has become democratic, as rank-and-file ticket buyers and Netflix subscribers enjoy themselves at the expense of imaginary members of the economic, political and cultural elite.

headline: A Jewelry Designer Finds a Scent as Unique as Her Latest Avant-Garde Ring
abstract: At Kaori, the new incense room within the Japanese store and restaurant Ogata Paris, Gaia Repossi embarks on a one-of-a-kind sensory journey.
lead_paragraph: On a mild fall morning in Paris, Gaia Repossi, the 36-year-old artistic director of the Italian fine jewelry house Repossi, was sitting at a long tatami-topped table in front of a woman in a lab coat who was diligently taking notes. The setting was Kaori, a small sanctuary-like space dedicated to the making and enjoyment of incense that opened in April within Ogata Paris, the three-floor Japanese store, tearoom and restaurant in the city’s Marais neighborhood. Lining the old stone walls of the room, which is situated in the basement of Ogata’s imposing 17th-century building, were apothecary cabinets filled with glass jars. The air smelled earthy and fresh, like a forest.

headline: Holiday Stress
abstract: What, if anything, is hard about the holidays for you?
lead_paragraph: “Family drama around the holidays is such a cliché that I can probably name a dozen movies off the top of my head that start with the premise of a moderately dysfunctional clan getting together for Thanksgiving or Christmas,” begins a recent Parenting newsletter.

headline: Bao Tong, 90, Dies; Top Chinese Official Imprisoned After Tiananmen
abstract: He helped design China’s political reforms in the 1980s and tried to avert the bloodshed that ended the democracy protests. After prison, he became a critic of the party.
lead_paragraph: Bao Tong, who was the highest-ranking Chinese official imprisoned over the pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square that ended in mass carnage in 1989, and who later became an acerbic outsider-critic of the Communist Party, died on Nov. 9 in Beijing. He was 90.

headline: The Monkeypox Cases That Might Have Been Missed
abstract: Despite monkeypox fading from public attention, scientists are still learning how it spreads — including without sexual contact or any symptoms.
lead_paragraph: In the monkeypox outbreak that unspooled this summer in the United States and dozens of other countries, men who have sex with men were the most at risk. But thousands of women were also infected, and many more cases were probably missed, according to the first ever study of women and nonbinary people who had contracted the disease.

headline: Disaster Upon Disaster: Photos Show Toll of Indonesia Earthquake
abstract: The quake that toppled hundreds of buildings on the island of Java also blocked roads needed to get medical help to victims.
lead_paragraph: Not long after a powerful quake hit West Java, Indonesia, on Monday, disaster began to pile upon disaster.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: 10 Prompts for Talking and Writing About Thanksgiving
abstract: What are your Turkey Day traditions? What are you grateful for this year? What is your favorite Thanksgiving memory? And more.
lead_paragraph: Every school day, we post a writing prompt based on a New York Times article for teenagers to respond to. And every November, we ask about Thanksgiving.

headline: Man Arrested in Fatal Stabbing of 3 Women in Queens Home
abstract: A 22-year-old man was arrested in Virginia in connection with a killing on Friday of three relatives inside their home in the Springfield Gardens neighborhood in Queens.
lead_paragraph: A 22-year-old man was arrested in Virginia in connection with the killings of three women — a mother, her daughter and her stepdaughter — who were found stabbed to death in a Queens home on Friday morning, the police in New York said on Monday.

headline: What Not to Buy on Black Friday
abstract: Not every deal is worth it.
lead_paragraph: Not every deal is worth it.

headline: How to Spend $1 Trillion? Mitch Landrieu Wants a Say.
abstract: The former New Orleans mayor, who helped the city rebound after Hurricane Katrina, has been tasked with making sure the money from President Biden’s infrastructure bill reaches those who need it most.
lead_paragraph: ELM CITY, N.C. — Inside this brick-walled town hall just feet away from a freight train line, a crowd of Black, white and Indigenous small-town leaders sat eager to hear how President Biden’s $1 trillion infrastructure plan would help their communities.

headline: Chaos on Twitter Leads a Group of Journalists to Start an Alternative
abstract: Journa.host promises to be a new “reliable home for journalists.” What happens when they move in?
lead_paragraph: It’s one thing to hope for a better community online, and another, very different one, to build it. Just ask the users and administrators of journa.host, which was started by journalists concerned over the direction of Twitter.

headline: Iger’s Sudden Return to Disney Shocks a Discontented Kingdom
abstract: After Bob Chapek, the departing chief executive, tried to put a sunny spin on a disastrous earnings report this month, senior Disney leaders began talking about resigning.
lead_paragraph: After a transition marked by numerous setbacks, some self-inflicted, Bob Chapek seemed by early fall to have finally found his footing after two years as Disney’s chief executive.

headline: The suspected gunman faces hate-crime charges. Here’s what that means in Colorado.
abstract: A possible motive behind the mass shooting at an L.G.B.T.Q. nightclub in Colorado Springs has started to come into focus, with the suspect, Anderson Lee Aldrich, 22, being held on five counts of murder and five counts of hate crimes.
lead_paragraph: A possible motive behind the mass shooting at an L.G.B.T.Q. nightclub in Colorado Springs has started to come into focus, with the suspect, Anderson Lee Aldrich, 22, being held on five counts of murder and five counts of hate crimes.

headline: How Carolyn Maloney’s Ticket to the Met Gala Led to an Ethics Inquiry
abstract: When the Manhattan congresswoman found out she had been dropped from the guest list in 2016, she was “unhappy to say the least,” according to a congressional ethics report.
lead_paragraph: The Met Gala is one of the must-be-seen events on Manhattan’s social calendar, a chance to pose among the biggest names in fashion, film and music on the red-carpeted steps of the Metropolitan Museum.

headline: How Democrats Can Fight This G.O.P.
abstract: They can forestall sabotage and make saboteurs pay a price.
lead_paragraph: Normally, one would expect a political party that suffered severe electoral disappointment — falling far short of typical midterm gains despite high inflation and consumer discontent — to moderate its positions, to seek compromise in order to achieve at least some of its policy goals.

headline: Does Fusion Voting Offer Americans a Way Out of the Partisan Morass?
abstract: A new push by nonprofit groups hopes to revive the practice in New Jersey and possibly elsewhere across the country.
lead_paragraph: One of the great paradoxes of America’s polarized political system is that people seem to hate it, yet few can conceive of a way out.

headline: Ukraine Remembers a Milestone on the Long Path to Putin’s War
abstract: In hindsight, protests that began nine years ago and toppled a Ukrainian president were a pivot point in efforts by Vladimir V. Putin to exert Russian control over Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukrainians took to the streets nine years ago in protests that within weeks became street battles and in demonstrations that turned to revolution. They barricaded Kyiv’s Independence Square and set it ablaze. The police gunned people down. Soon, the president was forced out.

headline: Everyone Is on a Long and Forlorn Search for Goals
abstract: A team hoping to reach the knockout rounds can’t score only perfect goals. It must score the cheap and scrappy ones, too. And this U.S. team does not, at least not as often as it should.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of Argentina vs. Mexico and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: Club Q and the Demonization of Drag Queens
abstract: The massacre in Colorado Springs was at once shocking and entirely predictable.
lead_paragraph: The massacre this past weekend at Club Q, an L.G.B.T.Q. club in Colorado Springs, was at once shocking and entirely predictable, like terrorist attacks on synagogues and abortion clinics.

headline: Progressive Activists Ready Campaign to Counter New House G.O.P. Majority
abstract: A new group is planning a war room to focus on what it sees as the harms of Republican policies on Americans and to counter expected investigations of the Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With Republicans on track to assume control of the House next year, progressive groups that have been bracing for that prospect for months are rolling out a coordinated campaign to counter the new majority as soon it takes charge in January.

headline: A Report on Violence at Rikers Is to Be Kept Secret
abstract: A monitor appointed to oversee the jails said the information should be held in confidence so that it is not taken out of “context.”
lead_paragraph: A report tracking violence at the Rikers Island jail complex in New York City will be hidden from the public, preventing people from viewing documents with statistics about assaults on staff, and incidents involving force against detainees, a federal judge has ordered.

headline: Review: In This Solo ‘Christmas Carol,’ the Night Is Never Silent
abstract: Jefferson Mays stars in a Broadway adaptation of the Dickens classic, a one-man production that was originally live-captured for streaming.
lead_paragraph: Has Jefferson Mays ever met a role — or a root vegetable — that he hesitated to take on? In the noisy, excitable one-man version of “A Christmas Carol” on Broadway, in a production that opened Monday at the Nederlander Theater, Mays stars as Ebenezer Scrooge, spirits of Christmas, assorted Cratchits, street folk, partygoers. He even plays a boiling potato, straining against a pot lid. At the festive board, Mays is side dish, main course, everything.

headline: Atlanta to Pay $1 Million to Rayshard Brooks’s Family
abstract: Mr. Brooks was fatally shot in 2020 as two Atlanta officers tried to arrest him.
lead_paragraph: The city of Atlanta agreed on Monday to pay $1 million to settle a lawsuit brought by the widow and the estate of Rayshard Brooks, a Black man who was fatally shot by a white police officer in 2020, and whose death touched off nationwide protests.

headline: David Valadao, a Republican Who Voted to Impeach Trump, Wins Re-election
abstract: His victory, which came after nearly two weeks of vote-counting, made the congressman one of just two House Republicans who supported impeaching the former president to remain in Congress.
lead_paragraph: Representative David Valadao, Republican of California, won re-election on Monday, according to The Associated Press, managing to survive politically after his vote to impeach former President Donald J. Trump, a move that cost some of his Republican colleagues their seats.

headline: It’s Like Cheatin’
abstract: Prepare to deal with Wendy Brandes’s Tuesday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: How Pulisic Crafted the U.S. Goal in Its World Cup Opener
abstract: See the key play where the Americans scored the opening goal in their 1-1 draw with Wales.
lead_paragraph: See the key play where the Americans scored the opening goal in their 1-1 draw with Wales.

headline: Todd and Julie Chrisley, Reality TV Stars, Are Sentenced to Prison for Fraud and Tax Evasion
abstract: The stars of “Chrisley Knows Best” were convicted in June of conspiring to defraud banks out of more than $30 million and evading taxes for several years.
lead_paragraph: Todd and Julie Chrisley, the stars of the reality TV show “Chrisley Knows Best,” were sentenced on Monday to federal prison after being convicted of defrauding banks to obtain more than $30 million in personal loans and evading taxes to fund a lavish lifestyle.

headline: For Ukraine, So Much Unexpected Success, and Yet So Far to Go
abstract: Ukraine is on the offensive along most of the 600-mile front line, and the Russians are in a defensive crouch. But about one-fifth of Ukrainian territory is still occupied by Russia.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — In forests, in fields and in fierce urban combat, the Ukrainian military has defied the odds, and all expectations, and forced Russia into multiple retreats over nine brutal, bloody months of war.

headline: Quotation of the Day: At Home and Abroad, High-Profile Iranians Signal Support for Protests
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 22, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “We are here, but it does not mean that we should not be their voice, or we must not respect them.”

headline: Corrections: Nov. 22, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 22, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the uncrewed flight of the giant Space Launch System and a new era of spaceflight, using information from NASA, misstated a spacecraft’s distance from the moon during a flyby. It is about 80 miles, not 60 miles.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: A devastating earthquake has killed more than 150 people in Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: A powerful earthquake struck near the city of Cianjur on Indonesia’s main island, Java, yesterday, killing at least 162 people and injuring hundreds more. Many people were believed to be still trapped beneath the rubble, leading to fears that the death toll would rise. As far as 60 miles away, in the capital, Jakarta, the quake shook furniture and tall buildings. See photos from the disaster.

headline: Eastern Europe Was the Crucible of Modern Football. Now It’s a Wasteland.
abstract: The region has a story to tell about sporting destiny.
lead_paragraph: There is a theory that, other than Uruguay at the inaugural tournament in 1930, every World Cup winner has been in some way influenced by the wave of great Hungarian coaches scattered across the globe in the aftermath of World War I.

headline: Late Night Reacts to Trump’s Reinstatement to Twitter
abstract: Jimmy Kimmel joked that the former president would stick to his vow to stay off the platform only “until the next time he’s on the toilet for more than 20 minutes.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: luminary
abstract: This word has appeared in 62 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word luminary has appeared in 62 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 9 in “Why Correspondence Chess Is Still Popular Among Elite Players” by Greg Keener:

headline: Outbreaks Test China’s Efforts to Limit the Cost of ‘Zero Covid’
abstract: China wants to fine-tune its stringent pandemic restrictions to reduce the disruption to daily life caused by lockdowns. But officials are still taking few chances.
lead_paragraph: Barely a week after no longer requiring residents to show a negative Covid test to use mass transit, the authorities in the northern Chinese city of Shijiazhuang have locked down much of the city for five days as infections surge.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Dutch Fans Stand by Their Team, if Not the World Cup
abstract: Human rights issues in Qatar have turned many in the Netherlands off the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — In a normal World Cup year, bars, pubs and cafes in the Netherlands are decorated in orange well before the tournament and filled to maximum capacity with soccer fans. The Dutch call it “Orange fever.”

headline: Is N.Y.’s Child Welfare System Racist? Some of Its Own Workers Say Yes.
abstract: New York City’s Administration for Children’s Services must protect children without overpolicing families. A report the agency commissioned says it often fails.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: In a ‘Sea Change,’ Women of the Philharmonic Now Outnumber the Men
abstract: The New York Philharmonic, which was an all-male bastion for most of its 180 years of existence, currently has 45 women and 44 men.
lead_paragraph: When the New York Philharmonic moved to Lincoln Center in 1962, its new hall had no women’s dressing rooms. That’s because there were no women in the orchestra.

headline: Beijing Is Tackling Its Air Pollution Problem. Why Can’t New Delhi?
abstract: The return of smog season in India’s capital has again left residents asking why nothing has changed. The answer may be largely political.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, the capitals of Asia’s two largest countries both had some of the dirtiest skies in the world. On the worst days, millions were enveloped in thick gray canopies of smog that darkened the sun and besieged the lungs.

headline: Why Did the Chicken Cross the Barn? To Sign Up for the Scientific Study.
abstract: A farm sanctuary in New York is investigating the inner lives of cows, pigs and chickens — but only if they volunteer.
lead_paragraph: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y. — It was a crisp October day at Farm Sanctuary, and inside the small, red barn, the chicken people were restless.

headline: China Factory Fire Kills 38
abstract: Officials say an investigation is underway into what caused the tragedy at the two-story facility operated by a wholesaler of industrial equipment, clothing and chemical products.
lead_paragraph: A fire swept through a two-story factory in central China on Monday, killing 38 people in one of the most deadly fires in the country in recent years.

headline: In Indonesia, an Earthquake, Landslides and Homes ‘Flat to the Earth’
abstract: As workers try to find survivors, rescue efforts have been hampered by power outages and blocked roads in a disaster that has killed at least 268 people and injured more than a thousand.
lead_paragraph: Schoolhouses were reduced to skeletal, warped frames, thousands of homes were uprooted from their foundations and an entire village was engulfed by a landslide in the wake of a devastating earthquake in a mountainous region of Indonesia.

headline: Europe’s Wind Industry Is Stumbling When It’s Needed Most
abstract: Makers of wind turbines are reporting mounting losses, and fret about losing out to rivals from China, as countries chase ambitious clean energy targets.
lead_paragraph: These should be great times to be in the wind energy business, especially in Europe. Governments here have long promoted offshore wind projects, and those efforts have accelerated since Russia started cutting natural gas shipments in its war against Ukraine.

headline: Will You Be Watching the 2022 World Cup?
abstract: The decision to host the World Cup in Qatar has led to concerns about corruption and human rights. Should we still watch?
lead_paragraph: Please note: Our Student Opinion questions specifically invite the voices of young people. We ask that adults respect the intent of this forum and refrain from posting here.

headline: What We Know About the Colorado Springs Shooting
abstract: A suspect is accused of opening fire at an L.G.B.T.Q. nightclub, killing at least five people and injuring another 18 people.
lead_paragraph: Colorado Springs communities were grieving this week in the wake of a mass shooting on Saturday night that left five people dead and 18 people injured. A suspect was being held and faced hate-crime and murder charges.

headline: I’m Going to Ukraine. Do I Have to Tell My Parents?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the conversations we must have with our loved ones, even when they’re difficult.
lead_paragraph: I work for an international medical-aid nongovernmental organization. I usually have a perfectly safe desk job at headquarters. Recently I was offered a three-week detachment to Ukraine and decided to take it. My job there won’t be near the front lines; I’ll be in Kyiv, which admittedly has been experiencing some targeted airstrikes, and moving a little toward the southeast. I am not blind to the risks of being in a country at war. My partner is supportive, and I’ve told my brother.

headline: Are the U.S. News College Rankings Finally Going to Die?
abstract: With top law schools quitting the rankings, will other colleges and universities follow?
lead_paragraph: Yale’s law school made the stunning announcement last week that it would no longer participate in the influential rankings published annually by U.S. News & World Report. Given the outsize importance attributed to the rankings by prospective applicants and alumni, Yale’s decision sent shock waves through the legal profession, and indeed all of higher education. Yet the law schools at Harvard, Berkeley, Georgetown, Columbia, Stanford and Michigan quickly followed suit. Will the universities of which they are a part join the boycott? Will other colleges and professional schools do the same? Could this be the beginning of the end for college rankings?

headline: What if You Can’t Find the Silver Lining in Your Illness?
abstract: Five years after my cancer diagnosis, I’m struggling to feel grateful for the experience.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of November, I celebrated the five-year anniversary of my breast cancer diagnosis. Theoretically, this should have been a joyous occasion. The last five years have brought me a host of gifts: mercifully clear scans, the salve of distance, more precious time to watch my children grow. None of these things I take for granted.

headline: This Is Your Brain on ‘Deep Reading.’ It’s Pretty Magnificent.
abstract: The literacy scholar Maryanne Wolf maps out the ways “deep reading” nourishes our capacity for attention, empathy and insight.
lead_paragraph: Every day, we consume a mind-boggling amount of information. We scan online news articles, sift through text messages and emails, scroll through our social-media feeds — and that’s usually before we even get out of bed in the morning. In 2009, a team of researchers found that the average American consumed about 34 gigabytes of information a day. Undoubtedly, that number would be even higher today.

headline: The Case for Supreme Court Term Limits Just Got a Lot Better
abstract: That’s one way to keep “an inconvenient aristocracy of entrenched officials” from forming.
lead_paragraph: The most striking detail in the recent investigation by The New York Times into another potential Supreme Court breach is not the evidence that Justice Samuel Alito or his wife may have leaked information to conservative friends in 2014 about the outcome of Burwell v. Hobby Lobby Stores, which extended “religious liberty” to the actions of family-owned corporations.

headline: How I Got Through My Miscarriages
abstract: Reading Diane Noomin’s feminist comics allowed me to feel the full range of my own grief.
lead_paragraph: I got pregnant for the first time early in the pandemic. It felt like perfect timing. There was nothing to do but binge watch TV, go on walks and feel nauseated in the privacy of my own home. The outside world was perilous and unrecognizable, but my life was full of meaning and possibility.

headline: End-Times Tourism in the Land of Glaciers
abstract: I gazed from the cruise ship’s railing with a contemporary Alaskan’s gloom.
lead_paragraph: Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve is one of those Alaska showpieces more often seen by visitors than by the state’s residents. When I finally got there this summer, after more than 40 years living in Alaska, I arrived the way most people do, on board a cruise ship, in the company of a few thousand tourists from around the world.

headline: On This Night, She Was the (Other) Story
abstract: As Brooke Gladstone, the host and managing editor of “On the Media,” was honored at WNYC’s annual gala the day after the midterms, the developing news was rich with material for her radio show.
lead_paragraph: “So do you spend a lot of nights out with C-list characters?” Brooke Gladstone asked cheerfully while firing up her cappuccino maker.

headline: Some Advice for Jack Smith, the New Special Counsel in the Trump Investigations
abstract: We can learn a lot from previous presidential investigations.
lead_paragraph: Jack Smith, the special counsel appointed by Attorney General Merrick Garland to take over the investigations of Donald Trump, has joined a select club: He is one of a small number of special prosecutors in modern history to investigate a sitting or former U.S. president. Now is a good time to look back to these examples and take stock of what we can learn from them.

headline: Coney Island Has a Bit of Everything. Does It Need a Casino?
abstract: A developer is seeking one of three new casino licenses for Coney Island, hoping to sell the project as a way to revitalize the Brooklyn neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: The Cyclone roller coaster. The boardwalk. The famous hot dogs. Not to mention the aquarium, baseball stadium and wide expanse of ocean beach. What more could Coney Island need?

headline: What Makes Trump Different From DeSantis and Other Republicans
abstract: To his supporters, he will still be the only outsider candidate capable of taking on a corrupt system.
lead_paragraph: Despite near-unison attempts from conservative media to declare his moment in the Republican sun over, Donald Trump refuses to go away. He is officially back on the hunt for the Republican nomination, and this resistance from many parts of the Republican universe obscures the fact that he may very well still win the nomination — if not in spite of the elite power brokers of the political right trying to stop him, then perhaps because of them.

headline: How Can I Soothe My Stomach After Thanksgiving Dinner?
abstract: A gastroenterologist explains how to manage symptoms like bloating, gas and heartburn during the biggest food holiday of the year.
lead_paragraph: Q: Thanksgiving is my favorite holiday, but it always leaves me feeling bloated, gassy and uncomfortable afterward. Are there any ways to avoid those symptoms while still enjoying the best meal of the year?

headline: What Is Ozempic and Why Is It Getting So Much Attention?
abstract: More people are turning to a diabetes medication to induce weight loss — but experts say it’s not a miracle drug.
lead_paragraph: Ozempic, a drug used to treat diabetes, has gained attention recently as celebrities, a tech mogul and TikTok influencers have described taking it to lose weight in short time frames.

headline: The Horrors of Rich-People Food, Fleshed Out on Film
abstract: With a pinch of dark humor, “The Menu” and “Fresh” explore the potential terrors of feeding the 1 percent.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Cool, Wild and Very Remote Andaman Islands
abstract: This archipelago in the Indian Ocean offers pristine nature, Indian culture, a glimpse of fascinating communities and some of the most spectacular beaches in the world.
lead_paragraph: We were stepping carefully through a dripping wet forest at the edge of the beach, at night. Above us, 150-foot-tall trees towered, their canopy blotting out the stars. I could hear bats chittering and waves crashing. The smell of wet leaves cut through the salty air.

headline: Jail Is a Death Sentence for a Growing Number of Americans
abstract: In Houston’s jail, where the population is at its highest in a decade, 24 people have died this year. More than half had a history of mental problems.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Shelton was contending with diabetes and periodic substance abuse when he moved in with his sister outside Houston in order to get his life together.

headline: Hail to the Queen: Angela Bassett on ‘Black Panther: Wakanda Forever’
abstract: The veteran star of “What’s Love Got to Do With It” and “Waiting to Exhale” tried to talk the director, Ryan Coogler, out of a plot twist in the Marvel sequel.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever.”

headline: Two Lives Long Harnessed Together, Until One Could Not Go On
abstract: Rush may have been the longest-lived thoroughbred in American history when he died at 39. For three decades, his owner said, “He would fight for me, and I would fight for him.”
lead_paragraph: WINDSOR, Conn. — Bridget Eukers paused in the barn, her thoughts seemingly far away, and touched her horse’s halter like an amulet. On the floor just outside his empty stall lay a scattering of yellow chrysanthemums left by a sympathetic friend.

headline: At Home With Brooke Shields
abstract: When the actor and former child model found her Greek Revival house in the West Village, the renovation goal was simple: Put it back the way it was.
lead_paragraph: When the actor and former child model found her Greek Revival house in the West Village, the renovation goal was simple: Put it back the way it was.

headline: China’s Grandparents Are Done Babysitting and Ready to Go Viral
abstract: Rapping grannies, crooning 70-year-olds and gamers in their 80s are challenging traditional Chinese views about aging and what it means to have a long and happy life.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The 65-year-old woman crouches in a field and holds up a head of cabbage. Behind her, two friends sway back and forth, cucumber and radish in their hands. “This rotten cabbage, let’s pull it out, eat it, achieve some foodie freedom,” Guo Yifen, the woman with the cabbage, raps in a low and creaky voice in the song “Spicy Hot Pot Real Rap.”

headline: How Brooke Shields Created a London-Style Home in the West Village
abstract: When the actor and former child model found a Greek Revival house in need of saving, her renovation goal was simple: Put it back the way it was.
lead_paragraph: Around the time Brooke Shields celebrated her 16th birthday, she and her mother/manager, Teri, bought a townhouse on the Upper East Side.

headline: Legal Retail Marijuana Is Just Around the Corner
abstract: With 28 licenses having been awarded, shops are expected to open by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at the first cannabis licenses issued in New York State. We’ll also look at how gridlock alert days are chosen, because today is one.

headline: In Philippines, Harris Promises Support and Denounces China
abstract: The vice president accused China of “intimidation and coercion” in disputed waters, as the Biden administration seeks partners to counter Beijing.
lead_paragraph: PUERTO PRINCESA, Philippines — Vice President Kamala Harris on Tuesday denounced China for what she called “intimidation and coercion” in the disputed waters of the South China Sea and promised that the United States would stand by the Philippines, at a time when the Biden administration is looking for ways to counter Beijing’s influence in the region.

headline: The ‘Tripledemic,’ Explained
abstract: In the United States, three big respiratory viruses are competing for attention.
lead_paragraph: This winter, three major respiratory viruses — respiratory syncytial virus or R.S.V., the flu and the coronavirus — are poised to collide in the United States in what some health officials are calling a “tripledemic.”

headline: Ukraine War Continues to Slow Global Growth, Report Says
abstract: “Risks remain tilted to the downside,” the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said, predicting economies will grow only 2.2 percent next year.
lead_paragraph: Higher inflation and slower growth are the heavy price that the global economy is paying for Russia’s war in Ukraine, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said on Tuesday.

headline: South Africa’s Leader Wins a Crucial A.N.C. Political Battle
abstract: President Cyril Ramaphosa emerged well-placed to win a second term as the head of the country’s governing party, although there is much haggling and horse-trading to come.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa, whose presidency has been upended by claims that he tried to cover up the theft of a huge sum of cash at his farm, emerged well-placed to win a second term as leader of the governing African National Congress, and president of the country, after nominations by his party’s rank and file were released on Tuesday.

headline: To the Moon
abstract: NASA is on a return mission.
lead_paragraph: Humankind took one small step toward the moon yesterday: NASA’s uncrewed Orion spacecraft arrived at the dusty orb and dipped as close as 81 miles above the surface, part of a multiyear project to return to our closest celestial neighbor half a century after the last visit.

headline: ‘Leonor Will Never Die’ Review: Rewriting Life, One Scene at a Time
abstract: A comatose genre director in the Philippines becomes trapped in one of her own screenplays in this messily inventive debut feature.
lead_paragraph: The agony of irrelevance might be commonly addressed in movies, but rarely with the lightheartedness of Martika Ramirez Escobar’s airy fantasy, “Leonor Will Never Die.”

headline: The Colombian Architect Who Reimagined Modernism for a New Era
abstract: Rogelio Salmona transformed the look of Bogotá, while also considering how to build homes for an increasingly liberal society.
lead_paragraph: IN THE YEARS before his death in 2007 at the age of 80, the Colombian architect Rogelio Salmona would guide students through the house that he and his second wife, the architect María Elvira Madriñán, had built for themselves in the rural hill country north of Bogotá. From the top of the gently sloped 6.3-acre lot, they would follow a wide brick path under a canopy of native chicalá and guayacán trees to its end at a solitary brick lintel hung with dangling ferns. Through the threshold, they would enter the first of the house’s three courtyards, square enclosures staggered along a diagonal and sutured together by a brick canal, a furrow in the ground’s otherwise flat pavers, and ending in a fountain. In the second patio, they would climb a staircase that spread to a roofscape of catwalks and barrel vaults, eventually descending to the final terrace and out again into the garden that Salmona and Madriñán, now 67, had spent more than a decade planting before they laid the house’s first brick. Only after circumambulating the 1,625-square-foot house, named Casa Río Frío for the stream that bounds the property to the east, and only if his visitors insisted, would Salmona take them inside for a perfunctory tour of its monastic interiors: its two baths and three bedrooms, its kitchen and living room and studio, built in concrete, granadillo wood and, most of all, brick.

headline: Saudi Arabia Leaves Another Scar on Argentina’s Soul
abstract: Argentina started as a favorite in the tournament as its star, Lionel Messi, looked for a final chance at the trophy. Now the team will struggle to advance.
lead_paragraph: LUSAIL, Qatar — This time was supposed to be different. For Lionel Messi, this time was not supposed to end like all of the others, with those slumping shoulders, that distant stare, that hollow grimace.

headline: German retailer ends sponsorship to protest FIFA’s decision on #OneLove armbands.
abstract: Rewe ended its long sponsorship of Germany’s soccer federation on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Update: Germany’s players protested a FIFA decision that blocked their captain from wearing a rainbow armband.

headline: Denmark vs. Tunisia: Christian Eriksen returns to a global stage in a 0-0 draw.
abstract: Denmark had more of the ball, but Tunisia’s swarming defense, and a few ill-timed bad passes, frustrated its efforts.
lead_paragraph: Denmark and Tunisia played to a scoreless draw in their opening World Cup game.

headline: A New Range of Honey From the Gardens of LeBron James and Ai Weiwei
abstract: Plus: Norman Teague’s culturally minded furniture and more from T’s cultural compendium.
lead_paragraph: Since the spring of 2020, Richard Christiansen’s Flamingo Estate has grown from selling produce boxes to offering a wide array of made-in-California products, including garden-scented candles, wine and regeneratively farmed olive oil. But before all of that, there was honey. The first thing Christiansen — the founder of the ad agency Chandelier Creative — did upon moving to his densely vegetated seven-acre property in Los Angeles’s Highland Park in 2016 was establish some beehives. As a child in rural Australia, he had been surrounded by his parents’ hives: “It’s just this timeless, beautiful thing that everyone can do,” he says. Earlier this year, Christiansen installed hives in the gardens of a few famous friends and fans of Flamingo Estate, with all proceeds from the resulting honey sold this holiday season going to a number of charities, including Cancer for College and Refugees International. In southern Portugal, the artist Ai Weiwei’s bees are feasting on olive trees. Will Ferrell, Tiffany Haddish and LeBron and Savannah James have hives in different parts of Los Angeles, and Julianne Moore has been hosting hers in Montauk, on Long Island. “These bees are like my children, so I only wanted them to go to the best places,” Christiansen says. (His own swarm was used for the Los Angeles sites; elsewhere, he relied on trusted local apiarists.) Going forward, he plans to introduce his bees to other fabulous gardens. As he sees it, it’s a kind of vacation for these industrious insects. “These bees wake up,” he says, “and they fly out to the most amazing view.” From $250, flamingoestate.com. — Ella Riley-Adams

headline: What Will Iger Do With ESPN and Hulu?
abstract: With Robert Iger back in charge at Disney, his to-do list takes shape: turn around the streaming businesses, and groom a successor.
lead_paragraph: On Robert Iger’s first day back as C.E.O. of Disney, the stock popped, adding billions to the entertainment giant’s shrinking market valuation. Now comes the hard part: finding a path to growth, and resolving a Space Mountain-sized heap of concerns from the future of flashy properties like Hulu and ESPN to finding a successor.
