headline: The Week in Business: Shoppers Open Their Wallets
abstract: A shake-up at Disney. Scrutiny of Ticketmaster in the wake of chaos in Taylor Swift concert ticket sales. And coming up: Is hiring slowing?
lead_paragraph: Bank account looking a little leaner than usual after Thanksgiving? That’s not altogether surprising. Those who had the classic dishes on the table on Thursday — turkey, gravy, stuffing, potatoes and, of course, lots of butter in nearly everything — paid as much as 41 percent more for their dinner this year than last. But many dug deeper into their wallets on Friday, kicking off a holiday shopping season that has billions of dollars riding on it. As inflation has climbed, showing signs of moderation only recently, interest rates have increased and pandemic fears have largely receded, retailers have struggled to keep up with consumers’ shifting habits. Some have found success with introducing holiday goods in the late summer and early fall and rolling out more early discounts.

headline: Cholera and Crime
abstract: Haiti is in the midst of a humanitarian disaster.
lead_paragraph: Haiti is in the middle of a humanitarian disaster. Gang warfare has deepened since the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse in the summer of 2021. Hunger has intensified. Cholera is spreading, as it has before, partly because armed groups are preventing doctors from providing care.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 28, 2022
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: After Deadly Blaze, Surge of Defiance Against China’s Covid Policies
abstract: Protests became rare once the government cut off most routes to collective action. But ubiquitous Covid rules, bringing shared suffering, have created a focus for anger.
lead_paragraph: The fire began with a faulty power strip in a bedroom on the 15th floor of an apartment building in China’s far west. Firefighters spent three hours putting it out — too slow to prevent at least 10 deaths — and what might have remained an isolated accident turned into a tragedy and a political headache for local leaders.

headline: Idle Crypto Is the Devil’s Workshop
abstract: Sam Bankman-Fried’s downfall is spectacular and interesting, but it’s really nothing new.
lead_paragraph: The newest monetary system in the world may be undone by the oldest problem there is.

headline: Cheer, Chant, Clean: Japan Takes Out the Trash, and Others Get the Hint
abstract: Japanese fans went viral for cleaning up after a World Cup victory. Fans from other countries are following their example.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of Mexico vs. Argentina and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: Is Bilal Baig Ready for Fame? Sort Of.
abstract: “Sort Of,” the melancholy comedy loosely based on the performer’s life and experiences, returns for its second season on HBO Max on Dec. 1.
lead_paragraph: Only a few minutes after the writer and performer Bilal Baig arrived at an upstairs gallery of the Whitney Museum of American Art, a fan approached.

headline: Mexico’s View From Last Place: ‘We Still Have Some Hope’
abstract: Its streak of advancing to the knockout stage in seven straight World Cups is dangerously close to ending.
lead_paragraph: Entering the World Cup, there were many questions about the Mexican national team. How good was the squad, really? Was its coach making the right calls? Was this all going to end in bitter disappointment again? Two games into the tournament and the answer feels clear.

headline: Marijuana Pardons Affect Just a Sliver of Those Swept Up in the War on Drugs
abstract: President Biden’s pardons for thousands of Americans convicted of possessing marijuana don’t apply to state charges or many immigrants at risk of deportation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Valerie Schultz’s conviction for possession of a small amount of marijuana in 2010 was anything but simple.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Good morning. I’m Emily Weinstein, the Food and Cooking editor here at The New York Times, and I’ll be your host today. Are you having an excellent long weekend? Have you had pancakes yet? Are you already diving headlong into cookie-making with Gantt charts and custom holiday baking playlists?
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’m Emily Weinstein, the Food and Cooking editor here at The New York Times, and I’ll be your host today. Are you having an excellent long weekend? Have you had pancakes yet? Are you already diving headlong into cookie-making with Gantt charts and custom holiday baking playlists?

headline: In Ukraine, Bakhmut Becomes a Bloody Vortex for 2 Militaries
abstract: Even as they have celebrated successes elsewhere, Ukrainian forces in one small eastern city have endured relentless Russian attacks. And the struggle to hold it is only intensifying.
lead_paragraph: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — For almost an hour, the stream of Ukrainian casualties in the eastern city of Bakhmut seemed unending: Ambulances, an armored personnel carrier and private vehicles all screamed to a halt, one after another, and disgorged the wounded in front of the city’s only military hospital.

headline: Protests Flare Across China Over Covid Restrictions
abstract: Demonstrators called for China’s leader, Xi Jinping, to step down, amid anger at the deaths of at least 10 people in an apartment fire in Xinjiang, presumably while under Covid lockdown.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators called for China’s leader, Xi Jinping, to step down, amid anger at the deaths of at least 10 people in an apartment fire in Xinjiang, presumably while under Covid lockdown.

headline: 9 Months, 100 People: Inside the Making of a Holiday Window
abstract: Only a handful of department stores in New York City still create them — but the ones that do go all out.
lead_paragraph: It was go time.

headline: Roman Coins Thought for Centuries to Be Fakes Get a Fresh Appraisal
abstract: New research suggests that the gold coins, which were found in 1713 and long dismissed as forgeries, may be authentic.
lead_paragraph: In 1713, a medals inspector documented the acquisition of eight gold Roman coins that had been buried in Transylvania. For centuries, experts believed them to be forgeries — and poorly made ones, at that.

headline: Borje Salming, N.H.L.’s First Star From Sweden, Dies at 71
abstract: A Hall of Fame defenseman for the Toronto Maple Leafs, he led the way for other European hockey players in the league.
lead_paragraph: Borje Salming, the Toronto Maple Leafs’ Hall of Fame defenseman who became the N.H.L.’s first Swedish star and a pioneer for the numerous European players who have changed the face of the league, died on Thursday in Nacka, Sweden. He was 71.

headline: As Winter Looms, Snowfall and Mud Present New Hardships for Ukraine
abstract: Officials urged Ukrainians to continue conserving energy, as analysts said that deteriorating weather was one factor slowing Ukraine’s battlefield progress.
lead_paragraph: Increasingly frigid winter weather presented new challenges for Ukraine on Sunday as mud churned up the battlefield and snowfall made the government’s task of restoring power supplies devastated by weeks of Russian bombing all the more urgent.

headline: Riots break out in Brussels after Belgium’s surprising loss to Morocco.
abstract: The violence erupted after Morocco upset Belgium, 2-0, at the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: Riots erupted in the heart of Brussels and several other Belgian cities on Sunday after Belgium was upset by Morocco, 2-0, at the World Cup.

headline: Iran Calls for U.S. to Be Expelled From World Cup
abstract: U.S. Soccer angered Iran by posting a doctored Iran flag on social media. The Americans said the decision was intentional but later deleted the posts.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of U.S.A vs. Iran and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: 10,500 Toddler Bottles and Cups Recalled Over Lead Poisoning Risk
abstract: Green Sprouts recalled the cups and bottles because the base can break off and expose a piece that contains lead.
lead_paragraph: A company has recalled about 10,500 bottles and cups for toddlers over lead poisoning concerns to children if a part of the product breaks off, the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission said.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Covid Protests Intensify in China
abstract: Plus World Cup updates, Kiribati’s judicial shake-up and “Gangnam Style,” 10 years later.
lead_paragraph: Protests erupted in cities and college campuses across China this weekend, as public anger at the country’s draconian Covid controls spilled onto the streets.

headline: Germany meets the moment and keeps its World Cup hopes alive.
abstract: A sin
lead_paragraph: AL KHOR, Qatar — This is how fine the margins can be: As the first bout between heavyweights of this World Cup ticked into injury time on Sunday, Álvaro Morata of Spain found himself cantering into the penalty area, the ball at his feet, goalkeeper Manuel Neuer’s net looming ever larger in his vision. Behind him, Nico Schlotterbeck of Germany was straining to close ground.

headline: Landslide Kills at Least 14 at Funeral in Cameroon
abstract: Rescuers were still searching for people who might have been swept up in the disaster.
lead_paragraph: YAOUNDÉ, Cameroon — A landslide in Cameroon’s capital, Yaoundé, killed at least 14 people attending a funeral on Sunday, the region’s governor said.

headline: Why Retailers Are Trying Extra Hard to Woo Holiday Shoppers
abstract: With an economic slowdown a distinct possibility, stores hope customers’ willingness to open their wallets will last through the season.
lead_paragraph: Amazon held what amounted to an extra Prime Day in October, blanketing its site with deals. Best Buy rolled out Black Friday-level sales last month. And on Friday, Kohl’s entered the first 200 people to walk into each of its stores into a sweepstakes, with prizes including gift cards to Sephora and a family trip to a Legoland resort.

headline: Footage Shows Protests Across China Over Covid Restrictions
abstract: Rare nationwide protests have broken out in multiple cities in China. Many expressed frustration over stringent Covid lockdowns; others demanded freedom of speech and even the removal of China’s top leader.
lead_paragraph: Rare nationwide protests have broken out in multiple cities in China. Many expressed frustration over stringent Covid lockdowns; others demanded freedom of speech and even the removal of China’s top leader.

headline: What We Learned From Week 12 in the N.F.L.
abstract: The Jets kept pace by beating the Bears after making a quarterback change. The Titans and Bengals are developing one of the A.F.C.’s most underrated rivalries and the Ravens’ fourth-quarter drama continued.
lead_paragraph: The A.F.C. playoff race only gets more and more contentious with each passing week, and teams are adjusting to make sure they can keep pace. To that end, the Jets reset their offense by sitting quarterback Zach Wilson and running back James Robinson. The Bengals and the Titans put their contrasting styles on display in another hard-fought matchup that is becoming one of the conference’s most underrated rivalries.

headline: Nine Civilians Killed in Militant Siege at a Mogadishu Hotel
abstract: An extremist group, Al Shabab, claimed responsibility for the 22-hour gun-and-bomb assault in the Somali capital, which ended with the death of all six attackers.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A protracted assault by Al Shabab militants on a Mogadishu hotel frequented by government ministers ended with at least nine civilians, including one police officer dead, the Somali police said Monday — the latest bloody attack by the militants in the center of the capital.

headline: Really Miffed
abstract: Chloe Revery makes her New York Times Crossword debut, and she’s … well, you’ll find out.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Review: In ‘KPOP,’ Korean Pop and Broadway Meet (Too) Cute
abstract: The worldwide sensation and American-style musical theater form an awkward alliance onstage.
lead_paragraph: “A lot of people come to these things and they don’t even understand the language,” says Harry, a filmmaker who passes for the villain in the noisy yet skimpy new musical “KPOP.” “So what are they watching for?”

headline: Louise Tobin, 104, Dies; Jazz Vocalist Made Comeback After a Hiatus
abstract: She was a rising swing era star when she quit to raise children, at the request of her first husband, the bandleader Harry James. But her singing days weren’t over.
lead_paragraph: With the big band era in full swing in 1939, Louise Tobin, a vocalist with Benny Goodman’s orchestra, was on the cusp of nationwide fame. But she soon put her career on hold at the request of her husband, the trumpeter and bandleader Harry James.

headline: Mexico’s President Leads Supporters in March Through Capital
abstract: Tens of thousands of Mexicans walked through the streets Sunday to show their support for President Andrés Manuel López Obrador amid some pushback to his political agenda in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Two weeks after tens of thousands of Mexicans protested against proposed electoral changes they say would undermine democracy, Mexico’s president on Sunday marched through the capital accompanied by massive crowds in a display of popular support for his mandate.

headline: Germany’s Late Equalizer Revives Its World Cup Hopes
abstract: See how Niclas Füllkrug scored a late goal, in a 1-1 draw with Spain, to preserve Germany’s chance of advancing to the knockout rounds.
lead_paragraph: See how Niclas Füllkrug scored a late goal, in a 1-1 draw with Spain, to preserve Germany’s chance of advancing to the knockout rounds.

headline: Another Patron Who Subdued Assailant at Club Q Acted to Save ‘the Family I Found’
abstract: Thomas James, a Navy petty officer, knocked down the attacker along with an Army veteran.
lead_paragraph: Thomas James was trained in the military on how to act in a crisis. And he responded immediately when an assailant entered Club Q in Colorado Springs on Nov. 19 shrouded in body armor and began shooting with an AR-15-style rifle, the police said.

headline: Small Plane Crashes Into Transmission Tower in Maryland
abstract: Rescuers on Sunday night worked carefully to extricate the two people on board. Photos showed the plane entangled in power lines.
lead_paragraph: A small plane crashed into a transmission tower in Maryland on Sunday, knocking out electricity to tens of thousands of customers as rescuers raced to extricate the two people on board who were trapped about 100 feet above the ground, the authorities said.

headline: Vanished in the Pacific
abstract: Driven by Covid chaos, online disinformation and a YouTube guru, two Americans went looking for solace on a sailboat in the middle of the ocean. They found a different fate.
lead_paragraph: Driven by Covid chaos, online disinformation and a YouTube guru, two Americans went looking for solace on a sailboat in the middle of the ocean. They found a different fate.

headline: Once a Star of College Basketball, Kevin Ollie Is Now Disrupting It
abstract: Since winning his lawsuit against the university he coached to a national championship, Ollie has found purpose running an upstart pro league.
lead_paragraph: “I’m in a great place,” said Kevin Ollie, his voice clear and firm as we spoke recently in a telephone interview. “Exactly where I need to be.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: Fatal Fire Spurs Unrest in China Over ‘Zero Covid’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 28, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “I felt like finally I could say what I’ve wanted to say.”

headline: No Corrections: Nov. 28, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 28, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Some Child Welfare Workers Say the System Is Racist
abstract: A draft report found that caseworkers overpolice parents during investigations of possible child abuse and neglect.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at a report that asked whether the city’s child welfare system is racist — and found that some of its own workers said it is. We’ll also look at a 358-page volume that may be the most important book that pedestrians and drivers in the city will never read.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Love Actually’ 20-Year Reunion and ‘Barmageddon’
abstract: The stars of the beloved holiday movie reflect with Diane Sawyer, and USA airs a preview of Blake Shelton’s new celebrity game show.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 28-Dec. 4. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Something Remarkable Is Happening in African Football
abstract: The continent’s teams are coming to understand the power of the diaspora.
lead_paragraph: Something exciting is happening in the World Cup: The five teams representing Africa in the tournament have African coaches.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Anger over Covid restrictions in China has created a crisis for its leader, Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: After at least 10 people died in an apartment building fire in the western Chinese city of Urumqi, many suspected that a Covid lockdown had hampered rescue efforts or trapped victims inside their homes. Speculation spilled into fury online: The event has now unleashed the most defiant eruption of public anger against the ruling Communist Party in years.

headline: Word of the Day: obsolete
abstract: This word has appeared in 184 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word obsolete has appeared in 184 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 23 in “Why New Yorkers Still ❤️ Film” by Ted Alcorn:

headline: A Stadium Mural Celebrated Migrant Workers. When the World Cup Began, It Was Gone.
abstract: A mosaic of photographs once decorated Qatar’s showpiece stadium in Lusail. Now a V.I.P. entrance sits beside the spot.
lead_paragraph: LUSAIL, Qatar — The giant mural with thousands of faces was certainly an arresting feature for visitors of Qatar’s showpiece stadium in the months leading to the World Cup.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Brooklyn D.A. Assigns 1 in 5 Workers to Fight Violence Against Women
abstract: A new division will be created in a major restructuring meant to streamline complex cases against abusers. It’s part of a national trend.
lead_paragraph: One October morning in a New York City courtroom, a woman from Pakistan tearfully recounted how an arranged marriage with a man she barely knew had devolved into violence in a tiny apartment in Flatlands, Brooklyn.

headline: Have the Anticapitalists Reached Harvard Business School?
abstract: Social justice joins discounted cash flows on the syllabus as essential knowledge for aspiring corporate leaders.
lead_paragraph: At Harvard Business School, inside a seminar room with a smattering of button-down shirts and puffy fall jackets, a group of future corporate managers were talking about capitalism. What makes capitalism truly and purely capitalism? What are its essential components? Property rights. Financial markets.

headline: Biden Helped Democrats Avert a ’22 Disaster. What About ’24?
abstract: A stronger-than-expected midterm showing has quieted the party’s public hand-wringing about a re-election campaign for President Biden. But it hasn’t put those worries to rest.
lead_paragraph: Expecting a cataclysmic midterm election, many Democrats had been bracing for an end-of-year reckoning with whether President Biden, who once declared himself a “bridge” to a new generation, should give way to a new 2024 standard-bearer.

headline: Two Innovators on ‘Telling Stories Through Ice Cream’
abstract: Jeni Britton Bauer and Pooja Bavishi are both redefining the market by making their own rules.
lead_paragraph: Pooja Bavishi was making ice cream in a shared kitchen space in Brooklyn in 2016 the first time she met Jeni Britton Bauer, who had arrived to mentor up-and-coming food entrepreneurs.

headline: When Visiting Michelangelo’s David, She Brings a Duster
abstract: The revered statue in Italy is not going to dust itself. That’s where Eleonora Pucci comes in.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — Imagine a job that lets you get up close and personal — really, really up close and personal — with one of the world’s most famous statues.

headline: Amid Scandals and Politics, Poland’s Youths Lose Faith in Catholic Church
abstract: The Polish church is in a deep crisis, as its authority is sapped by cascading sexual abuse scandals and as more people grow wary of its perceived alliance with the country’s right-wing government.
lead_paragraph: BYDGOSZCZ, Poland — A committed Catholic who served from childhood as an altar boy, Karol dreamed as a teenager of entering the seminary in his hometown in northern Poland and becoming a priest.

headline: Millions in Houston Are Told to Boil Water, Prompting School Closures
abstract: A power outage at a water purification plant caused water pressure to drop and triggered the notice. Officials expect the order to be in effect for at least a day.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Houston residents were told Sunday night to boil their water before using it after a power outage at a purification plant caused water pressure to dip and triggered a mandatory boil-water notice, officials said. The order prompted officials in Texas’s largest city to close public schools for at least one day.

headline: Lesson Plan: ‘26.2 Miles Is Easy. Getting Around New York City Is Not.’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn why it’s easier for one athlete to win a marathon in New York than to navigate the city in a wheelchair. Then, students will evaluate the accessibility of public spaces where they live.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “26.2 Miles Is Easy. Getting Around New York City Is Not.” by Talya Minsberg with photographs by Clark Hodgin

headline: Canada has one more game before turning its focus to 2026.
abstract: Guaranteed a spot in the next World Cup, Canada aims for one positive result.
lead_paragraph: AL RAYYAN, Qatar — After the final whistle, after Canada had been eliminated from the 2022 World Cup with a 4-1 loss to Croatia on Sunday, its goalkeeper Milan Borjan stood in the middle of a huddle of his teammates and waved his arms as he spoke.

headline: Happiness is £4 Million
abstract: An idealistic journalist and a prosperous real estate guru question each other’s worldviews.
lead_paragraph: An idealistic journalist and a prosperous real estate guru question each other’s worldviews.

headline: Tom Stoppard Fears the Virus of Antisemitism Has Been Reactivated
abstract: “It stays silent and mostly invisible,” says the playwright. “Until you poke it with a stick.”
lead_paragraph: “It stays silent and mostly invisible,” says the playwright. “Until you poke it with a stick.”

headline: Would You Like to Work Among Robots Someday?
abstract: A company is trying to introduce robots into the corporate workplace. Does this sound like an exciting future or a dystopian nightmare to you?
lead_paragraph: When you picture yourself working in the future, what do you see? Do you think of working in an office, in a factory, in a restaurant, on a farm or at home? What do you think your workplace will be like?

headline: A Very Young Gymnast
abstract: In “Winterland,” Rae Meadows’s fifth novel, an 8-year-old from Siberia gets the nod to train with elite athletes in the U.S.S.R.
lead_paragraph: “Above all else,” the famous Romanian Olympian Nadia Comaneci writes in her memoir “Letters to a Young Gymnast,” “you have to be hungry to do something unbelievable.”

headline: Why Is It So Hard for Men to Make Close Friends?
abstract: American men are stuck in a “friendship recession.” Here’s how to climb out.
lead_paragraph: The Tuesday before every Thanksgiving, Aaron Karo and Matt Ritter, both 43, go out to dinner with a group of seven men whom they befriended as second graders in Plainview, N.Y.

headline: If We Ignore Donald Trump, We Might See Who He Really Is
abstract: My father’s advice on how to deal with bullies would work great on Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: When I was about 8 or 9, I was bullied ruthlessly in school by a boy in my class. I faked being sick so I wouldn’t have to go to school, but my parents figured out that something was going on and my father came in to talk to me. I confessed to him that I was scared of my tormentor, and what followed was a lesson in the beauty of ignoring another person. He explained that bullies crave attention and that if they are ignored, they sort of deflate. He then showed me how frustrating it is to feel like you’re invisible, by ignoring me when I tried to speak to him. It worked. I returned to school, I ignored the bully and he gave up his attacks on me.

headline: How Would You Feel About a 100-Year-Old Doctor?
abstract: We should mandate periodic competency assessments for physicians after a certain age.
lead_paragraph: I read an article recently about a 100-year-old doctor named Howard Tucker who is still practicing medicine in Cleveland. Dr. Tucker began working as a neurologist in 1947, when Harry Truman was president.

headline: If Money Buys Happiness, What Happens Next?
abstract: An idealistic journalist and a prosperous real estate guru question each other’s worldviews.
lead_paragraph: While working to become a full-time reporter at an online publication in Beijing in 2021, Cici Fenfeng Wu was tasked with covering the country’s real estate market. The property market contributed tremendously to China’s economic growth, as well as to its economic imbalance, and she was assigned to do a profile of one of the investors behind the market.

headline: There Are Some Things We Are Grateful for and Some We Are … Not
abstract: You can guess which category Trump, Ye and Nick Fuentes go into.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Gail, I hope you had a lovely and restful Thanksgiving weekend. At the risk of turning the meaning of the holiday on its head, I wanted to ask you what you don’t feel grateful for, at least politically speaking.

headline: Why Are Lots of Kids Likely to Be Sick This Holiday Season?
abstract: We can lower the toll of respiratory viruses for good.
lead_paragraph: Before the Covid-19 pandemic, little was done beyond flu shots to counter the seasonal respiratory virus infections that circulate among the general public in a typical year — such as influenza viruses, coronaviruses, rhinoviruses and more.

headline: How a Cyberattack Plunged a Long Island County Into the 1990s
abstract: Suffolk County officials had to return to the days of paper checks and faxes after an episode that exposed government weaknesses.
lead_paragraph: Emergency dispatchers taking down 911 calls by hand, unable to use their geolocation technology for callers. Police officers radioing in crime scene details, rather than emailing reports to headquarters. Office workers resorting to fax machines.

headline: Turning Point for Garland as Justice Dept. Grapples With Trump Inquiries
abstract: After months of an already hyperpartisan political environment, the attorney general appears to be acknowledging that his approach has to be recalibrated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, a stoic former federal judge intent on restoring rule-of-law order at the Justice Department, gradually came to accept that he would need to appoint a special counsel to investigate Donald J. Trump if the former president ran for the White House again.

headline: Anderson Cooper Explores Grief and Loss in Deeply Personal Podcast
abstract: Over the eight episodes of “All There Is,” the CNN anchor digs into his own family traumas as well as those of others.
lead_paragraph: Anderson Cooper has never been a big crier.

headline: Soledad O’Brien’s Painted Hardwood Floors Spark Debate on a New Trend
abstract: The broadcast journalist recently painted the floors of her Florida bungalow. Some people loved the idea; others hated it.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Soledad O’Brien bought a home in Flamingo Park, a neighborhood of 1920s bungalows in West Palm Beach, Fla. Like many older homes — Ms. O’Brien’s was built in 1945 — hers needed work. And like other homeowners, Ms. O’Brien, the broadcast journalist, had no desire to do the work all at once.

headline: What You Get for $1.8 Million in California
abstract: A renovated showplace in Los Angeles, a ranch house in Sonoma and a midcentury home in Orinda.
lead_paragraph: A renovated showplace in Los Angeles, a ranch house in Sonoma and a midcentury home in Orinda.

headline: $1.8 Million Homes in California
abstract: A renovated showplace in Los Angeles, a ranch house in Sonoma and a midcentury home in Orinda.
lead_paragraph: During the past year, the sellers did a gut renovation of the home that involved a complete interior makeover and the installation of a new roof, a new HVAC system, new copper plumbing and a tankless water heater.

headline: China Protests Break Out as Covid Cases Surge and Lockdowns Persist
abstract: After a weekend of confrontations between officials and demonstrators, video from two sites in Shanghai and Beijing showed a heavy security presence. Here’s the latest on the situation.
lead_paragraph: “Lift the lockdown,” the protesters screamed in a city in China’s far west. On the other side of the country, in Shanghai, demonstrators held up sheets of blank white paper, turning them into an implicit but powerful sign of defiance. One protester, who was later detained by the police, was carrying only flowers.

headline: 3 Weeks After Hack, This Country’s Government Is Still Off-line
abstract: The Pacific Island nation of Vanuatu has said little about a Nov. 6 cyberattack that has significantly inconvenienced many of its 320,000 people.
lead_paragraph: The government of the Pacific Island nation of Vanuatu has essentially been off-line for three weeks because of a cyberattack, leaving people struggling to get access to services and forcing some civil servants to use pen and paper to conduct business.

headline: Memes, Puns and Blank Sheets of Paper: China’s Creative Acts of Protest
abstract: In a country where the authorities have little tolerance for open dissent, demonstrators against Covid restrictions have turned to more subtle methods.
lead_paragraph: In Shanghai, a vigil grew into a street protest where many held blank sheets of white paper in a symbol of tacit defiance.

headline: Yahoo Takes Minority Stake in Ad Network Taboola
abstract: Yahoo’s chief executive sees the deal as a long-term bet on digital advertising. The companies estimate that their ad partnership will generate $1 billion annually.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo is deepening its push into digital advertising, even as its competitors warn that the market is faltering.

headline: Qatar’s Big Bet on the World Cup
abstract: How a tiny nation ended up hosting the single largest sporting event on the planet — and at what cost.
lead_paragraph: The World Cup, the biggest single sporting event on the planet, began earlier this month. By the time the tournament finishes, half the global population is expected to have watched.

headline: Pandemic Learning Loss
abstract: The role remote education played.
lead_paragraph: Months into the current school year, most American students are still trying to make up for what they lost during the pandemic. This fall, we saw some of the clearest evidence yet of the extent to which the pandemic — and the school closures that came with it — hurt children’s education.

headline: Mo Brings Plenty Was About to Quit Acting. Then Came ‘Yellowstone.’
abstract: The actor wasn’t satisfied with the Native representation he saw onscreen. Now he’s helping TV’s biggest drama get it right.
lead_paragraph: In a scene from Season 3 of the hit neo-Western series “Yellowstone,” Mo, the steady right hand and loyal fixer of the Native American power broker Thomas Rainwater, lights some sage and lets the smoke waft through Rainwater’s office. They’re about to meet with Angela Blue Thunder (Q’orianka Kilcher), a hard-charging Native lawyer with a take-no-prisoners attitude toward going after the Montana ranch land owned by John Dutton (Kevin Costner).

headline: A Modernist London Refuge Drawn From Europe’s Aesthetic Past
abstract: Inside a nondescript building, Child Studio has created a hybrid work space influenced by Art Deco details and Yves Saint Laurent’s Paris salon.
lead_paragraph: IN THE SHADOW of Claridge’s hotel, a black iron gate marks the entrance to an otherwise hidden address. Cut into a red-and-yellow brick wall in Brook’s Mews, a cobblestone artery in London’s Mayfair neighborhood, it gives way to a private passage. This narrow alley, the proportions of which summon a darker, Dickensian past, leads to a compact courtyard, marked only by a pair of olive trees that shield the entrance to a contemporary office building.

headline: Major News Outlets Urge U.S. to Drop Its Charges Against Assange
abstract: In a joint letter, news organizations warned that the indictment of Julian Assange “sets a dangerous precedent” that could chill reporting about matters of national security.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The New York Times and four European news organizations called on the United States government on Monday to drop its charges against Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, for obtaining and publishing classified diplomatic and military secrets.

headline: China’s Covid Contagion
abstract: Stock markets in Asia and Europe fell on Monday, as did U.S. futures and crude prices, as investors worried about the fallout of social unrest in China.
lead_paragraph: Protests across China over the country’s strict zero-Covid policies shook up global markets over worries that the authorities will take longer to reopen the world’s second-largest economy. The visuals were jarring: Thousands took to the streets over the weekend in the biggest challenge to the authority of the Chinese Communist Party in years.

headline: A Tall Vase Inspired by Bodega Flower Stands
abstract: Most of the ceramist Reinaldo Sanguino’s creations are meant not just to be admired, but to be used.
lead_paragraph: The ceramist Reinaldo Sanguino became obsessed with clay as a boy in Caracas, Venezuela, where he would go down to the river and shape the mud with his hands. Now 49, he came to the United States in his 20s to study at the Haystack Mountain School of Crafts in Maine for a summer and, after laboring for years on the trade show and art fair circuit, was discovered around 2012 by David Alhadeff, the founder of the New York City-based Future Perfect design gallery. Sanguino, who often starts with a simple hand-built or wheel-thrown clay form, makes stools, hanging wall pieces and tables, as well as monumental vessels, in his Long Island City, Queens, studio, then transforms the material with a glazing process to produce one-of-a-kind creations characterized by saturated shocks of colors, metallic glimmers and hints of oatmeal, with knotted or stitched-together pieces of fabric, yarn or burlap for texture. This two-foot-tall vase, which suggests an amphora, has craggy holes on the sides for branches or blossoms; unlike some art potters, he intends for most of his work, however precious, to be used. “I’m inspired by the rough beauty of bodega flower stands, which are staffed by immigrants,” he says. “The point is always to be real.” The Other Series vase, $10,000, thefutureperfect.com.

headline: Meta Fined $275 Million for Breaking E.U. Data Privacy Law
abstract: The penalty, imposed by Irish data regulators, brings European fines against Facebook’s parent company to more than $900 million since last year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the latest penalty against Meta for violating European privacy rules, the tech giant was fined roughly $275 million on Monday for a data leak, discovered last year, that led to the personal information of more than 500 million Facebook users being published online.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of Nov. 21, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.

headline: California Will Soon Have the Nation’s Most Expansive Record-Clearing Law
abstract: State lawmakers approved one of the most far-reaching criminal justice reform measures in the nation this year, but it attracted little attention.
lead_paragraph: It’s Monday. California will soon enact the nation’s broadest law sealing criminal records. Plus, Gov. Gavin Newsom says he won’t challenge President Biden for the Democratic nomination.

headline: For Putin’s Opponents, Exile From Russia Proves a Boon
abstract: The political network of Aleksei A. Navalny, the imprisoned opposition leader, had seemingly been crushed. But working from abroad, the Navalny team is using YouTube to spearhead antiwar efforts.
lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — Sitting before a large video monitor in his suburban Moscow office last week, President Vladimir V. Putin addressed local officials opening a turkey breeding center in distant Siberia.

headline: Buffalo Gunman Pleads Guilty in Racist Attack That Left 10 Dead
abstract: The man, who shot 13 people at a supermarket in May, faced multiple murder, domestic terrorism and hate crime charges.
lead_paragraph: The gunman who killed 10 Black people in a racist massacre at a Buffalo supermarket in May pleaded guilty to state charges against him in Erie County Court on Monday morning.

headline: With No Major Releases to Challenge Her, Taylor Swift Sticks at No. 1
abstract: “Midnights” logs a fourth week leading the Billboard 200, while Drake and 21 Savage, Bad Bunny and Lil Baby also hold their spots in the Top 5.
lead_paragraph: Squint and you might mistake the latest Billboard album chart for last week’s: Almost all of the top slots are unchanged, led by Taylor Swift at No. 1 for a fourth time with “Midnights.”

headline: Crypto Lender BlockFi Files for Bankruptcy as FTX Fallout Spreads
abstract: BlockFi was entangled with FTX, and its stability was thrust into uncertainty after FTX collapsed.
lead_paragraph: BlockFi, a cryptocurrency lender that targeted ordinary investors eager for a piece of the crypto mania, filed for bankruptcy on Monday, felled by its financial ties to FTX, the embattled exchange whose recent downfall has shaken the crypto industry to its core.

headline: Belarus’s architect of Western outreach dies suddenly, state media reports.
abstract: Vladimir Makei served 10 years as the foreign minister of Belarus, a key geopolitical battleground between Russia and the West.
lead_paragraph: A top Belarusian official who led a failed attempt to thaw diplomatic relations between the nation’s Kremlin-allied government and the West died suddenly over the weekend, state media and government agencies in Belarus said, amid growing speculation over his country’s involvement in the war in neighboring Ukraine.

headline: World’s Largest Active Volcano Erupts for First Time in Decades
abstract: Mauna Loa, on the island of Hawaii, erupted for the first time in 38 years. There were no immediate evacuation orders for the local community.
lead_paragraph: Mauna Loa, on the island of Hawaii, erupted for the first time in 38 years. There were no immediate evacuation orders for the local community.

headline: Mauna Loa Volcano in Hawaii Erupts for the First Time in Nearly 40 Years
abstract: No evacuation orders were issued, but officials advised residents to review their preparedness plans. The volcano last erupted in 1984.
lead_paragraph: Mauna Loa, located on the Big Island of Hawaii, erupted for the first time in 38 years late Sunday night, following a series of striking eruptions in recent years of the smaller and nearby Kilauea volcano.

headline: Adeem the Artist, Crafting a Country Music of Their Own
abstract: Adeem Bingham has wrestled for decades with their identity as a Southern, Christian, queer songwriter. Can modern country music make space for them and their experiences?
lead_paragraph: Hannah Bingham understood that the blouse she had bought for her spouse of six years, Adeem Bingham, who was turning 32 in 2020, would be more than a mere garment or birthday present. Deep green silk and speckled with slinking tigers and glaring giraffes, it was Hannah’s tacit blessing for Adeem to explore beyond the bounds of masculinity.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: Thoughts on the film “The Menu,” and what you actually want to cook in the weeks between the holidays.
lead_paragraph: Before I fall into the December holiday rabbit hole, it’s time to go to the movies. I kicked off my holiday blockbuster season with “The Menu” and a giant tub of popcorn, in case anything from the fancy, multicourse menu in the satirical thriller made me peckish.

headline: Russia Fortifies Defenses in Southern Ukraine, Analysts Say
abstract: The Institute for the Study of War said Russia appears to view the prospect of a Ukrainian counteroffensive as a serious threat after Moscow pulled back from Kherson.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces are digging trenches and erecting barriers to strengthen their defenses against the possibility of a new Ukrainian offensive in the south following Moscow’s loss of a key city there, a research group said in a report published on Sunday.

headline: A Protest? A Vigil? In Beijing, Anxious Crowds Are Unsure How Far to Go.
abstract: In a country where protests are swiftly quashed, many who gathered to voice their discontent — under the watchful eye of the police — were uncertain about how far to go.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The crowd was hard to make out at first, a dark mass huddled along the Beijing riverbank after sunset. The people stood quietly, almost nervously, dozens bundled in thick coats beside yellowed willow trees. At their center was a small altar, strewn with candles and flowers, for the 10 people who died in a fire in western China last week.

headline: China Appears to Limit Crowd Shots to Avoid ‘Zero-Covid’ Comparisons
abstract: With matches on a 30-second delay, China’s television network is able to replace crowd shots with close-ups of coaches.
lead_paragraph: In Qatar, the maskless fans at the World Cup are joyfully screaming, packed elbow-to-elbow in crowded stadiums, seemingly having a wonderful time.

headline: Organ Donations Rise Around Motorcycle Rallies
abstract: A new study suggests a link between the large gatherings and a slightly higher number of transplants after traffic crashes.
lead_paragraph: This summer, when half a million bikers clogged the streets of tiny Sturgis, S.D., for one of the country’s largest motorcycle rallies, there might have been a small unexpected benefit for nearby patients desperately awaiting organ transplants.

headline: Puberty Blockers for Transgender Youths
abstract: Readers discuss the benefits and risks of puberty blockers. Also: Donald Trump’s dinner with antisemites; robots in the workplace.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sympathy, and Job Offers, for Twitter’s Misinformation Experts
abstract: Seeing false and toxic information as a potentially expensive liability, companies in and outside the tech industry are angling to hire people who can keep it in check.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks since Elon Musk took over Twitter, dozens of people responsible for keeping dangerous or inaccurate material in check on the service have posted on LinkedIn that they resigned or lost their jobs. Their statements have drawn a flood of condolences — and attempts to recruit them.

headline: Where Does All the Cardboard Come From? I Had to Know.
abstract: Entire forests and enormous factories running 24/7 can barely keep up with demand. This is how the cardboard economy works.
lead_paragraph: Before it was the cardboard on your doorstep, it was coarse brown paper, and before it was paper, it was a river of hot pulp, and before it was a river, it was a tree. Probably a Pinus taeda, or loblolly pine, a slender conifer native to the Southeastern United States. “The wonderful thing about the loblolly,” a forester named Alex Singleton told me this spring, peering out over the fringes of a tree farm in West Georgia, “is that it grows fast and grows pretty much anywhere, including swamps” — hence the non-Latin name for the tree, which comes from an antiquated term for mud pit. “See those oaks over there?” Singleton went on. “Oaks are hardwood, with short fibers. Fine for paper. Book pages. But not fine for packaging, because for packaging, you need the long fibers. A pine will give you that. An oak won’t.”

headline: 2 Dead as Tornadoes Belt the South
abstract: A mother and child were killed by a falling tree in Montgomery County, Ala. The storm system was expected to weaken as it moved into the Northeast on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Punishing storms and tornadoes swept across the American South overnight, leaving two people dead in Alabama, an emergency official said, and dropping hail as large as two inches in parts of the region.

headline: A Sikh Temple Combats Loneliness With Chai and Laughter
abstract: A village in northern India has found a way to address a growing global issue: a deep sense of isolation among older people.
lead_paragraph: KAKKAR, India — Sitting cross-legged with his long white beard flowing in the afternoon wind, the 95-year-old man took a deep breath and began leading a dozen or so other Sikhs in chanting a sacred verse in praise of their god.

headline: Monkeypox Has a New Name: Mpox
abstract: Health experts said the old nomenclature was imprecise, played into racist stereotypes and fueled stigmatization, making it harder to contain the most recent outbreaks.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization, responding to complaints that the word monkeypox conjures up racist tropes and stigmatizes patients, is recommending that the name of the disease be changed to mpox. Both names are to be used for a year until monkeypox is phased out.

headline: The Fans Screamed for Qatar. Their Passion Hid a Secret.
abstract: A heaving mass of flesh and energy has brought life to the host nation’s matches at the World Cup. They are Qatar’s loudest fans, but they’re not from Qatar.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Midway through the second half of Qatar’s match against Senegal at the World Cup, the drumming stopped as a man in a bucket hat and sunglasses rose and asked for quiet.

headline: The Chef Tanya Holland Chronicles the Journey of ‘California Soul’
abstract: In her new cookbook, the acclaimed owner of Brown Sugar Kitchen traces the Great Migration’s influence on West Coast cuisine.
lead_paragraph: At 6 a.m. on a recent Tuesday, the chef Tanya Holland sat alert in the green room of “Good Morning America” just off Times Square, asking her small team if they needed anything. With dozens of television appearances under her belt, Ms. Holland did not seem nervous, but instead used this quiet moment to rehearse her brief cooking segment.

headline: Ahead of U.S.-Iran, Tough Questions and Two Teams Feeling the Heat
abstract: U.S. Soccer angered Iran by posting a doctored Iranian flag on social media. The American players and their coach said they had nothing to do with it.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of U.S.A vs. Iran and the latest World Cup standings.

headline: Fruitcake Is Delicious, and This Recipe Proves It
abstract: Claire Saffitz’s version skips the long aging process, baking up in a day, and doubles down on deliciousness.
lead_paragraph: What would the holidays be without jokes about fruitcake — that it’s leaden, dry and hard, better used as a doorstop or dumbbell than served as dessert?

headline: A U.S.-Iran Soccer Showdown Intensifies With Protests as a Backdrop
abstract: The unrest that has gripped Iran for the past two months has heightened what would already have been a tense encounter at the World Cup in Qatar on Tuesday between the two geopolitical foes.
lead_paragraph: When players representing Iran and the United States take the field at the World Cup in Qatar on Tuesday, millions of fans will be dissecting every move — not just passes, fouls and headers, but also whether the Iranian players sing the national anthem, celebrate any goals or speak about the protests shaking their country.

headline: A Paris Museum Has 18,000 Skulls. It’s Reluctant to Say Whose.
abstract: Critics say the Museum of Mankind withholds information about its vast collection of human remains that could help former colonies and descendants of conquered peoples get them back.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — With its monumental Art Deco facade overlooking the Eiffel Tower, the Musée de l’Homme, or Museum of Mankind, is a Paris landmark. Every year, hundreds of thousands of visitors flock to this anthropology museum to experience its prehistoric skeletons and ancient statuettes.

headline: U.S. Crypto Exchange Kraken Settles With Treasury Dept.
abstract: The crypto exchange, which had been under investigation for violating U.S. sanctions, agreed to pay $360,000 to settle the allegations.
lead_paragraph: Kraken, a U.S. cryptocurrency exchange, agreed on Monday to pay more than $360,000 to the Treasury Department to settle accusations of sanctions violations involving virtual currency transactions by users in Iran.

headline: Eleanor Jackson Piel, Lawyer Who Fought Capital Convictions, Dies at 102
abstract: A renowned defender of the marginalized, she had many celebrated victories, including a Florida appeal known as the case of the Death Row Brothers.
lead_paragraph: Eleanor Jackson Piel, a civil rights lawyer renowned for handling wrongful convictions and death row appeals — once securing a reprieve for a man 16 hours before he was to be executed — died on Saturday at her home in Austin, Texas. She was 102.

headline: You Can’t Resist This Easy Squash-Chickpea Recipe
abstract: Just try not to nibble all the caramelized and spiced bits straight off the pan before dinnertime — we dare you.
lead_paragraph: I have a little problem when it comes to roasted winter squash. When I take a pan out of the oven, those soft orange cubes caramelized and glistening, I can’t stop myself from gobbling piece after piece until the batch is decimated and my dinner derailed.

headline: For Novice Cooks, Gavin Kaysen’s ‘At Home’ Is a Good Place to Start
abstract: Pick up the chef’s debut cookbook, attend a talk about the seasonality and nutritional value of Japanese ingredients, and more.
lead_paragraph: As user-friendly cookbooks go, for novices and more experienced kitchen hands, put the chef Gavin Kaysen’s first book, “At Home,” at the top of your shopping list. Mr. Kaysen, who came up through the ranks of Daniel Boulud’s empire, then went home to Minneapolis to establish his own restaurants, keeps things focused on home cooking in this book. There are photos of his (enviable) home kitchen, and accompanying most of the recipes are step-by-step instructional shots. Organized by seasons, it starts about now, digging into winter with coq au vin, less common Parisian gnocchi (no potatoes), and cassoulet. Spring brings crab cakes, summer is for swordfish kebabs with corn, and for fall he offers braised lamb shanks. Throughout there are tips, like why his braised dishes cook uncovered, how to keep food warm and buy sugar snaps, and how to organize your freezer. The tone throughout is welcoming and warm.

headline: Cormac McCarthy’s Unsettling Dream of a Novel
abstract: “Stella Maris” is the second of McCarthy’s two new books about grief, math and the nature of knowledge.
lead_paragraph: Artists tend to simplify their form with age, and the big novel has traditionally been, to paraphrase writers dead and living, no country for very old men. But this fall, Cormac McCarthy, who is pushing 90, has arrived with a pair of audacious linked novels, one a total banger and the other no embarrassment. If this is what it sounds like to be on your last legs, young writers should ask their server for whatever he’s having. If McCarthy’s voice is any indication, he’s still limber enough to outrun an aggrieved cheetah in his drawers and stocking feet.

headline: Preacher Accused of Being ISIS Marriage Broker Faces Trial in New York
abstract: Prosecutors say that Abdullah el-Faisal, who served time in Britain for inciting racial hatred, tried to find recruits for the Middle East extremist group.
lead_paragraph: In late 2016, Abdullah el-Faisal, a Jamaican preacher who was an outspoken supporter of the Islamic State, began communicating on WhatsApp with a woman in New York who claimed to be an aspiring jihadist with medical training.

headline: Russia postpones a meeting on a nuclear arms control treaty.
abstract: The treaty, New START, calls for reciprocal inspections, but they have not been occurring, first because of the coronavirus pandemic, and now amid tensions over U.S. sanctions on Russia.
lead_paragraph: Russia has postponed a scheduled meeting with U.S. officials to discuss the last remaining nuclear arms treaty between the two countries, in the latest sign of the diplomatic breakdown between Washington and Moscow since the invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Trump Plans Limited Role in Georgia Senate Runoff
abstract: The former president, who held two big rallies before the state’s two runoff elections two years ago — both of which Democrats won — will steer clear of Georgia before next week’s Senate election.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump will not cross the Florida state line to campaign with Herschel Walker during the final week of the Georgia Senate runoff election, after both camps decided the former president’s appearance carried more political risks than rewards, campaign officials for the two Republicans said on Monday.

headline: Here’s the Latest on the FTX Collapse
abstract: The collapse of FTX, one of the world’s largest cryptocurrency companies, is still sending shock waves through the crypto world.
lead_paragraph: FTX, one of the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchanges, collapsed with stunning speed this month.

headline: Elon Musk Takes On Apple’s Power, Setting Up a Clash
abstract: In a series of tweets on Monday, Mr. Musk accused Apple of threatening to pull Twitter from its App Store and of trying to censor.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — “What’s going on here @tim_cook?” Elon Musk tweeted on Monday to Tim Cook, the chief executive of Apple, igniting a spat between the world’s richest man and the world’s most valuable public company.

headline: Antiwar Activists Who Flee Russia Find Detention, Not Freedom, in the U.S.
abstract: Thousands of Russians are crossing the U.S. southern border to claim asylum. Many are ending up in immigration prison. “I left Russia for a place just like Russia,” said one.
lead_paragraph: PINE PRAIRIE, La. — They had fallen in love their first year in medical school in Russia, joined by their commitment to building democracy in a country where any remaining hope of it was disappearing.

headline: Will the Era of Butts Ever End?
abstract: A new book takes a look back at the posterior’s cultural role throughout history.
lead_paragraph: From the title of Heather Radke’s new book “Butts: A Backstory,” and its cover image of a ripe, callipygian peach, one might expect a book of provocative photos, or perhaps a chronicle of a personal fetish. But “Butts” is in fact a carefully researched and reported work of cultural history.

headline: 5 New Haven Officers Charged in Paralysis of Black Man They Transported
abstract: The man was being taken to a Connecticut police station when the driver of a police van hit the brakes hard, shattering the man’s spine.
lead_paragraph: Five Connecticut police officers were charged on Monday with misdemeanors in a case in which a Black man who was being transported in the back of a police van became paralyzed when the driver hit the brakes hard, shattering the man’s spine.

headline: ‘The Gett’ Review: Jewish History and a Woman’s Future
abstract: The ancient and contemporary swirl together in Liba Vaynberg’s ambitious, off-kilter play about life after a divorce.
lead_paragraph: It is something of a shock to encounter Jennifer Westfeldt, as gorgeous and screwball-comedy perfect as ever, playing the mother of an actual grown-up — a daughter deep enough into adulthood that not only has she gotten married, but now she’s getting a divorce.

headline: U.N. Mission Joins Growing Calls to Label Great Barrier Reef ‘In Danger’
abstract: The report’s authors said current conservation efforts were not enough to address the “ongoing and increasingly serious challenge” presented by climate change.
lead_paragraph: The Great Barrier Reef in Australia, the world’s largest coral reef ecosystem and one of its most biodiverse, is under significant threat from climate change and should be placed on a list of world heritage sites in danger, a United Nations-backed mission has recommended.

headline: Stocks Drop as Economic Worries Weigh on Sentiment
abstract: After turmoil in China set a negative tone, a Fed governor suggested the market was underestimating the chance that the central bank would have to keep raising rates.
lead_paragraph: Stocks fell on Monday, a drop that shows investors continue to grapple with economic concerns as spreading protests in China added to the list of risks facing the global economy.

headline: Chinese Unrest Over Lockdown Upends Global Economic Outlook
abstract: Growing protests in the world’s biggest manufacturing nation add a new element of uncertainty atop the Ukraine war, an energy crisis and inflation.
lead_paragraph: The swelling protests against severe pandemic restrictions in China — the world’s second-largest economy — are injecting a new element of uncertainty and instability into the global economy when nations are already struggling to manage the fallout from a war in Ukraine, an energy crisis and painful inflation.

headline: Russia’s Battle for Bakhmut
abstract: The city in the Donbas has become a destructive vortex for Ukrainian and Russian forces.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Limit Public Corruption Cases
abstract: The fraud convictions of Joseph Percoco, a former aide to Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York, and Louis Ciminelli, a contractor in Buffalo, appeared likely to be overturned.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, which has become increasingly skeptical of federal prosecutions of public corruption in state government, seemed poised on Monday to hand prosecutors two more defeats.

headline: Bob Iger, Acknowledging ‘Challenging Times,’ Meets With Disney Employees
abstract: At a town-hall meeting on Monday, Disney employees seemed overjoyed at the return of Mr. Iger, who replaced Bob Chapek as chief executive.
lead_paragraph: It was part pep rally and part therapy session: For 45 minutes on Monday, Robert A. Iger stood inside a film soundstage in Burbank, Calif., and fielded questions from Disney employees about the company’s dramatic turn from Hollywood juggernaut to streaming-era cautionary tale.

headline: Defense Rests as Trump Company Trial Draws to Close
abstract: Closing arguments in the tax-fraud case are expected to begin Thursday after lawyers argue over the instructions jurors will receive from the judge.
lead_paragraph: Defense lawyers representing Donald J. Trump’s family business rested their case Monday, marking the end of witness testimony in the company’s tax fraud trial and clearing the way for closing arguments this week.

headline: Banks Plan to Start Reimbursing Some Victims of Zelle Scams
abstract: A rule change planned for early next year would shift liability for some losses onto the banks, not their customers.
lead_paragraph: The seven banks that own the payments network Zelle are preparing a major rule change early next year that will require the network’s member banks to compensate customers who fall victim to certain kinds of scams, according to two people familiar with the plans.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Anxiety in China
abstract: Plus Ukraine updates, a U.S.-Iran World Cup preview and a “She Said” interview.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, protesters gathered in the cold in Beijing, calling for an end to coronavirus restrictions. “We don’t want lockdowns, we want freedom!” they shouted.

headline: Susan Kikuchi, 74, Dies; Staged Martha Graham Dances and ‘King and I’
abstract: Like her mother, she became a Graham dancer, and then oversaw acclaimed productions of the choreographer’s works as well as Jerome Robbins’ musical.
lead_paragraph: Susan Kikuchi, a former dancer in Martha Graham’s company who was acclaimed in the United States and abroad for her outstanding stagings of Graham’s dances and for her revivals of the Jerome Robbins musical “The King and I,” died on Nov. 14 in Manhattan. She was 74.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: 1. Protests against China’s strict Covid-19 restrictions ricocheted across the country.

headline: White House Weighs How Forcefully to Support Protesters in China
abstract: The demonstrations over Covid lockdowns present a challenge for President Biden, who has insisted he will call out abuses by authoritarian governments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The surprise eruption of protests in China over Covid lockdowns presents President Biden with his latest challenge in balancing an embrace of democracy with the need to prevent a fast-decaying relationship with an autocratic nation from rupturing.

headline: When High Fashion and QAnon Collide
abstract: Two new Balenciaga campaigns ignited a firestorm that traveled from the internet to Fox News, fueled by allegations that the brand condoned child exploitation.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Congress Looks to Intervene in Rail Dispute as Strike Deadline Looms
abstract: After urging from President Biden, Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the House would consider an agreement that could avert a shutdown of the nation’s freight trains.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi said on Monday that lawmakers plan to intervene this week in the deepening labor dispute between rail companies and their unionized workers, voting on whether to impose an agreement that could avert a shutdown of the nation’s freight trains just before Christmas.

headline: Prince and Princess of Wales to Visit Boston as the Royal Family Recasts Itself
abstract: William and Catherine will announce the winners of awards for work on the environment. But their visit is weighted with additional significance.
lead_paragraph: On its face, the visit by William and Catherine, the Prince and Princess of Wales, to Boston this week is typical of the British royal family’s philanthropic work.

headline: Was Election Denial Just a Passing Threat?
abstract: Or is it here to stay?
lead_paragraph: In the months before the midterm elections, a reporter for Time magazine asked Mark Finchem, the Republican nominee for secretary of state in Arizona, why he was so convinced that Donald Trump had won the state in 2020 despite all evidence to the contrary.

headline: How China Lost the Covid War
abstract: What the rest of us can learn from the zero-Covid disaster.
lead_paragraph: Do you remember when Covid was going to establish China as the world’s dominant power? As late as mid-2021, my inbox was full of assertions that China’s apparent success in containing the coronavirus showed the superiority of the Chinese system over Western societies that, as one commentator put it, “did not have the ability to quickly organize every citizen around a single goal.”

headline: Ukraine Warns of More Strikes on Power Plants, as Russians Dig In
abstract: Russian forces are fortifying positions in southern Ukraine after retreating from Kherson, and the Kremlin denied planning to withdraw from the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant.
lead_paragraph: Amid Ukrainian warnings that Moscow is preparing a new wave of strikes on energy plants, Russian forces are fortifying their defensive lines in southern Ukraine after retreating from the city of Kherson.

headline: Hall of Fame Committee Could Be Tough on Players With Steroid Links
abstract: Sunday’s vote on players like Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens will be secret, but past statements from committee members indicate a hard line on players accused of cheating.
lead_paragraph: For a player who starred at Wrigley Field, Ryne Sandberg finished his Hall of Fame speech, in 2005, the way you would expect: “Thank you and go Cubs!” But right before that, on a stage filled with the most hallowed names in baseball, Sandberg made a pointed choice of words to cap his address.

headline: Videos Show Heavy Police Presence in Response to Protests in China
abstract: In Chinese cities where protests were held over the weekend, the police put on a show of force on Monday to deter gatherings. Some protesters showed up despite the tight security.
lead_paragraph: In Chinese cities where protests were held over the weekend, the police put on a show of force on Monday to deter gatherings. Some protesters showed up despite the tight security.

headline: Jewish Allies Call Trump’s Dinner With Antisemites a Breaking Point
abstract: Supporters who looked past the former president’s admirers in bigoted corners of the far right, and his own use of antisemitic tropes, now are drawing a line. “He legitimizes Jew hatred and Jew haters,” says one. “And this scares me.”
lead_paragraph: For much of Donald J. Trump’s presidency, Jewish Republicans rationalized away the bigoted fringe of Mr. Trump’s coalition, arguing that the unsavory supporters in his midst and the antisemitic tropes he deployed paled in comparison with the staunchly pro-Israel policies of his administration.

headline: Whole Foods to Stop Buying Maine Lobster Amid Risk to Endangered Whales
abstract: Maine’s political leaders criticized the decision, which was based on assessments by two conservation groups that have raised concerns that North Atlantic right whales have become entangled in the ropes used to fish for lobster.
lead_paragraph: Whole Foods has said it plans to stop buying Maine lobster, citing concerns from environmental groups that say endangered North Atlantic right whales have become entangled in fishing gear.

headline: In Oxford School Shooting, Safety Policies Were Overlooked, Say Ex-Board Members
abstract: The two former members said they resigned in September so that they could speak more freely about the tragedy last year in Michigan.
lead_paragraph: A year after a shooting that killed four students at Oxford High School in Michigan, the school district and broader community are still wrestling with painful questions about how, or whether, the rampage could have been prevented.

headline: G.O.P.-Controlled County in Arizona Holds Up Election Results
abstract: Republican local officials are threatening to disrupt the final tally of midterm votes in one more sign of the politicization of elections.
lead_paragraph: Republican officials in an Arizona county voted on Monday to hold up certification of local results in this month’s midterm elections, reflecting an expansion of partisan battles into obscure elements of the election system and largely uncharted legal territory.

headline: Antisemitism’s March Into the Mainstream
abstract: Dining with a white supremacist, Trump demolishes another taboo.
lead_paragraph: Tom Stoppard’s wrenching drama “Leopoldstadt,” which I recently saw on Broadway, begins in 1899 at a Christmas party in the Vienna apartment of Hermann Merz, a prosperous and assimilated Jewish businessman, who is married to a Catholic and nominally converted. Hermann is convinced that the antisemitism that plagued his forefathers is fading into the past.

headline: Supreme Court Defends Alito After Breach Allegation
abstract: The court reiterated Justice Alito’s statement that neither he nor his wife disclosed a 2014 contraception ruling that a minister claims to have learned before it was public.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday defended Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. against allegations that a former anti-abortion leader had been tipped off in 2014 to a landmark contraception ruling written by the justice. The court also sidestepped questions from lawmakers about whether the claim would be investigated further.

headline: Wide-Eyed Wonderment
abstract: Fly through David Rockow’s New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Anthony Ornato, Key Jan. 6 Witness, Speaks With House Panel
abstract: Mr. Ornato, a former Secret Service agent and White House aide, is at the center of a dispute over competing accounts of President Donald J. Trump’s actions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Anthony M. Ornato, the former Secret Service agent and White House aide at the heart of a dispute over conflicting accounts of President Donald J. Trump’s actions during the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, was interviewed on Tuesday by the House committee investigating the attack, according to two people familiar with the matter.

headline: China Launches Astronauts to Newly Completed Space Station
abstract: After decades of military secrecy, Chinese officials opened their desert rocket launch center to a handful of visitors and called for international cooperation in space.
lead_paragraph: Tall as a 20-story building, a rocket carrying the Shenzhou 15 mission roared into the night sky of the Gobi Desert on Tuesday, carrying three astronauts toward a rendezvous with China’s just-completed space station.

headline: Russian Retreat Reveals Signs of an Atrocity in a Ukrainian Village
abstract: In the southern Kherson region, the pattern seen in eastern Ukraine is repeating: The withdrawal of Russian forces yields evidence of possible war crimes.
lead_paragraph: PRAVDYNE, Ukraine — First came small pieces of bone. Then a pair of arms tied at the wrists with rope.

headline: The Elusive Dream of Owning a Home in New York City
abstract: For many middle- and working-class New Yorkers, it’s an even more distant possibility than it used to be.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at why homeownership has been pushed even further out of reach for middle-class people in New York. We’ll also look at the trial of a Jamaica preacher who, prosecutors in Manhattan say, tried to recruit women for ISIS and marry them off to jihadists.

headline: Representative Donald McEachin, Virginia Democrat, Dies at 61
abstract: Mr. McEachin, who had just been overwhelmingly re-elected to his Richmond-area district, had been treated for colorectal cancer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative A. Donald McEachin, Democrat of Virginia, died on Monday after a battle with colorectal cancer, his office said.

headline: Quotation of the Day: With Sly Memes and Wordless Protests, Fed-Up Chinese Test the Authorities
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, November 29, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “If you hold a blank sheet, then everyone knows what you mean.”

headline: Corrections: Nov. 29, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Nov. 29, 2022.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article on Friday about a new era of direct confrontation between the Biden administration and Iran misspelled the surname of a woman who died while in police custody in Iran. She is Mahsa Amini, not Mahsa Amina.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Ukrainian military officials say Russia is planning more strikes on infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian military officials say that Moscow is preparing a new wave of strikes on energy plants. A military spokeswoman said Ukraine had received intelligence reports suggesting that more strikes might come this week, perhaps using missiles launched from a Russian naval vessel in the Black Sea.

headline: Word of the Day: florid
abstract: This word has appeared in 30 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word florid has appeared in 30 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 4 in the book review “Anne of Everywhere” by Catherine Hong:

headline: The Woman Once Considered Africa’s Richest Faces Arrest in Graft Inquiry
abstract: Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of Angola’s former president, was accused of enriching herself with state resources during her time in control of the country’s oil company.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The Angolan authorities are seeking the arrest of Isabel dos Santos, a former president’s daughter who was once considered Africa’s wealthiest woman, over accusations that she enriched herself with state resources, the nation’s attorney general has told a state-run news agency.

headline: Giving Tuesday
abstract: What can you do for others this holiday season?
lead_paragraph: Nov. 29 this year is known on social media as #GivingTuesday, a day when you are invited to take a break from buying things, and, instead, show generosity to others. The GivingTuesday website suggests thinking about it this way:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: As Haiti Unravels, U.S. Officials Push to Send in an Armed Foreign Force
abstract: Fearing a mass exodus, some Biden officials are pressing for a multinational force, but they don’t want to send U.S. troops and haven’t been able to persuade other countries to take the lead.
lead_paragraph: After days of gunfights in early November, Haitian police officers emerged triumphant: They had finally liberated the nation’s biggest port from the gangs that had taken it over for two months.

headline: Can This Man Stop Lying?
abstract: Christopher Massimine, whose compulsive lying derailed a promising career in theater, maintains that it’s a mental illness that has dogged him since childhood.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Will Smith Revisits His ‘Horrific Decision’ on Oscar Night
abstract: The actor, who appeared on “The Daily Show” to promote his new film, “Emancipation,” discussed his infamous slap of Chris Rock with Trevor Noah. “That’s not who I want to be,” Smith said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: What Should Stores Do With Unsold Goods?
abstract: Retailers sometimes throw out returned, damaged or otherwise unwanted items. What should happen instead?
lead_paragraph: Activists are exposing the wastefulness of retailers by rummaging through trash and posting their hauls on TikTok as a way to shame stores and raise public awareness. Coach, CVS, TJ Maxx, HomeGoods and Party City have all been criticized for throwing away or destroying merchandise.

headline: Fifth Graders Give Monologues About a Person Whose Life Has Been ‘Overlooked’
abstract: A teacher shares how he used a Times obituary series to show students that “history is a kind of kaleidoscope, made up of many people’s stories.”
lead_paragraph: This teaching idea was submitted by Michael Salmon, who taught fifth-grade English, social studies and math at Sidwell Friends Middle School in Washington, D.C.

headline: How the Supreme Court Is Erasing Consequential Decisions in the Lower Courts
abstract: The pace of these actions has increased in the past 22 months, neutralizing important civil rights and civil liberties decisions.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court is increasingly setting aside legally significant decisions from the lower courts as if they had never happened, invalidating them in brief procedural orders. The pace of these actions has increased in the past 22 months, neutralizing important civil rights and civil liberties decisions.

headline: Must I Mentor a White Law Student When I Requested a Black Mentee?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how racial dynamics can affect the obligations of mentorship.
lead_paragraph: I am a Black woman and I signed up as a mentor for a law-student-mentoring program at my alma mater. I made a request for a Black mentee, but I was paired with a white woman. Now I’m second-guessing participating in the program. Black attorneys make up less than 5 percent of all attorneys and continue to face horrific experiences in law school and in the legal community. This is whom I envisioned myself supporting when I registered for the program as a recent graduate. I imagined deep conversations about law professors and law-firm culture, and sharing how I’ve learned to navigate them as a Black woman. Not only will these conversations not apply to my mentee the same way, but I can’t help wondering if assisting them will ultimately contribute to my own oppression. There are so many factors in her favor that I don’t really want to help give her even more of a leg up in my free time. On the other hand, I don’t have anything against her, and law school is universally scary during the first year. Should I be thinking about this differently? Is it wrong to bow out? Name Withheld

headline: After Covid, Playing Trumpet Taught Me How to Breathe Again
abstract: The benefits of group (music) therapy.
lead_paragraph: Our director stepped onto the podium, and the auditorium stilled to an expectant silence. The black sequins on her conducting dress flared in the stage lights; the audience behind her was lost to the glare. With a glance and a whispered word, she gave us final instructions. As she raised her baton, we all breathed in time; on the downbeat, we exploded into sound. The song was “The Hounds of Spring,” by Alfred Reed, and I can still hear the opening bars. That concert, the entirety of which felt downright enchanted, propelled me into music college, where I studied music education, learning the basics of a dozen instruments so I could teach them someday. After a year, I turned in my loaner instruments, transferred to a new school and changed my major. At 18, I wanted to save the world, and I thought I could do it better some other way.
