abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin of The New York Times will do a live interview today with Mr. Bankman-Fried, the former chief executive of the failed crypto exchange FTX.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of the DealBook Summit. An R.S.V.P. is no longer necessary.

headline: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen speaks at a critical moment for the global economy.
abstract: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen is speaking at The New York Times’s DealBook Summit on Wednesday at a pivotal time for the global economy and the Biden administration. She is playing a leading role in the effort to squeeze Russia’s economy with sanctions, tame the most rapid inflation in four decades and ease trade tensions brewing between the United States and Europe.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen is speaking at The New York Times’s DealBook Summit on Wednesday at a pivotal time for the global economy and the Biden administration. She is playing a leading role in the effort to squeeze Russia’s economy with sanctions, tame the most rapid inflation in four decades and ease trade tensions brewing between the United States and Europe.

headline: Kyiv’s mayor expresses resolve as Russian attacks aim to make his city unlivable.
abstract: Vitali Klitschko says of Moscow: “They want to destroy the country from inside.”
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — When Russian troops were bearing down on Kyiv in the first months of their invasion, Vitali Klitschko, the former boxing champion who has been the mayor of the Ukrainian capital since 2014, had a clear message: “Better that we die than we give up.”

headline: Watch Live: Zelensky Addresses DealBook Summit
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky is the sixth president of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky is the sixth president of Ukraine.

headline: Our Children Won’t Stop Bickering Over Our Vacation Condo. Help!
abstract: A reader’s five adult children can’t seem to agree on an equitable arrangement for sharing her and her husband’s unused vacation home during the holidays.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I own a vacation condominium (with two bedrooms and two bathrooms) that we like to make available to our five adult children. We don’t use it over the holidays, but the kids’ use of it during this period has become contentious. Four are married, one is divorced and they all have children. It used to work out when three of the families wanted to spend a few nights there, but now all five of them want to use the condo over the 10-day Christmas break. We suggested shared usage or a rotation system, but this has resulted in sibling quarrels that are reported back to us for resolution. I know it’s early for holiday questions, but can you help?

headline: A Breakthrough in the University of California Labor Dispute
abstract: Postdoctoral scholars and academic researchers announced a tentative deal, but the strike continued Tuesday as 36,000 other academic workers lacked an agreement.
lead_paragraph: With the University of California strike in its third week — and threatening to encroach on final exams for some 300,000 students — negotiators announced a breakthrough on Tuesday: a tentative agreement that would cover about one-quarter of the unionized workers who walked off the job in the largest university-based labor action in U.S. history.

headline: A Mysterious Professor, a Financier and a Beauty Phenomenon
abstract: Who can explain the success of the skin care brand Augustinus Bader?
lead_paragraph: What can explain the level of extreme devotion, on the part of Augustinus Bader skin care users, to 50 milliliter bottles of creams that cost $280 each — and now an expanded offering of everything from body creams to hair vitamins?

headline: I Will Miss Alessandro Michele’s Freaky, Geeky Gucci
abstract: Whatever you may think of his designs, he changed how people dressed.
lead_paragraph: I was never exactly an unadulterated fan of Alessandro Michele, the recently-no-longer Gucci designer. I often found his collections overwrought and self-indulgent; unedited, like the rambling monologues he would conduct after shows in the guise of a news conference, throwing himself into a thronelike chair in exhaustion. Yet for the last week, ever since the announcement that he was leaving the brand after nearly eight years, I haven’t been able to stop thinking that we will miss him more than we have yet imagined.

headline: Michael Feingold, Forceful Drama Critic, Dies at 77
abstract: For decades he wrote about theater in The Village Voice, but he also was a dramaturge and a Tony-nominated translator.
lead_paragraph: Michael Feingold, whose learned writing about the theater was a fixture of The Village Voice for decades, and who was also a dramaturge, a translator and a Tony Award-nominated lyricist and adapter, died on Nov. 21 in Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: How Senators Voted on the Same-Sex Marriage Bill
abstract: The legislation passed by a vote of 61 to 36.
lead_paragraph: The Senate passed legislation on Tuesday to mandate federal recognition for same-sex marriages. The 61-to-36 vote marked a moment of bipartisanship before Republicans assume control of the House of Representatives in January.

headline: Stream These Three Great Documentaries
abstract: This month’s picks include an experimental film on border crossings, a tribute to a wildlife explorer and a chronicle of a civil rights leader.
lead_paragraph: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.

headline: Stocks Jump as Fed’s Powell Signals a Slowdown in Pace of Rate Increases
abstract: In his final public remarks before a crucial Federal Reserve meeting, the central bank’s chair said the time to moderate rate increases could come as soon as December.
lead_paragraph: Stocks rose in afternoon trading on Wednesday as investors weighed comments from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome H. Powell that seemed to confirm expectations that the central bank could slow its interest rate increases soon.

headline: Flashlights, Fire and Ingenuity: Life Without Power in Kyiv
abstract: After months of repeated Russian strikes, Ukraine’s capital can no longer take electricity, water, heat, cell service or internet for granted. And the hum of generators is everywhere.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Elevators across Ukraine’s capital are stocked with emergency supplies in case the power fails. Banks have sent messages to customers to assure them their money is safe in the event of prolonged blackouts. The National Philharmonic played on Tuesday night on a stage lit by battery-powered lanterns, and doctors last week performed surgeries by flashlight.

headline: An Italian Village Hit the Jackpot. Will That Save or Destroy It?
abstract: Tiny Livemmo won nearly 20 million euros to reverse its decline. Figuring out how to spend it is a big job, but someone’s got to do it.
lead_paragraph: LIVEMMO, Italy — The only full-time employee of Livemmo, a secluded mountain village of 196 residents in northern Italy, has a lot on his to-do list.

headline: Give Moms the Gift of Guaranteed Income
abstract: The Magnolia Mother’s Trust is helping Mississippi families thrive.
lead_paragraph: This newsletter is part of Times Opinion’s 2022 Giving Guide. Read more about the guide in a note from Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury.

headline: House Passes Bill to Avert a Rail Strike, Moving to Impose a Labor Agreement
abstract: The House approved a bill to force rail companies and workers to accept a pending agreement. It also passed a separate measure to add seven days of paid leave, a key demand of the employees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday resoundingly approved legislation to avert a nationwide rail strike by imposing a labor agreement between rail companies and their workers, as lawmakers rushed to shield the economy from the threat of a holiday-season work stoppage and prevent a disruption in shipping across the country.

headline: Yellen Urges More Regulation of Cryptocurrencies after FTX Collapse
abstract: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen called the collapse of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX a “Lehman Moment,” referring to the investment bank that filed for bankruptcy in 2008.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen called the collapse of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX a “Lehman Moment,” referring to the investment bank that filed for bankruptcy in 2008.

headline: Buckingham Palace Staff Member Resigns Over Remarks to Black Guest
abstract: The founder of an antiviolence support group said an aide pressed her on where she was from, dismissing Britain as an answer. The palace called the questioning “unacceptable and deeply regrettable.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Ngozi Fulani was invited to a glittering reception at Buckingham Palace on Tuesday hosted by Camilla, the queen consort and wife of King Charles III, she did not expect to find herself being repeatedly questioned by a member of the household staff about where she was from.

headline: For China’s Leader, Another Dilemma: How to Mourn Jiang Zemin
abstract: The former president’s death drew tributes from Chinese people at a fraught moment for the current leader, Xi Jinping, who faces widespread criticism of his harsh Covid policies.
lead_paragraph: The deaths of Chinese Communist leaders are always fraught moments of political theater, and especially so now with the passing of Jiang Zemin soon after a wave of public defiance on a scale unseen since Mr. Jiang came to power in 1989.

headline: President Zelensky of Ukraine rebukes Elon Musk’s peace proposal.
abstract: Speaking at the DealBook summit, the Ukrainian leader said the billionaire would do well to fully understand the situation before making pronouncements about it.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Wednesday invited Elon Musk to visit Ukraine to see the damage done to the country by Russian forces, saying that such a visit could help the billionaire understand the situation before making pronouncements about it. He also said he didn’t think there was any immediate threat that Vladimir Putin, president of Russia, would use nuclear weapons as the war enters a new phase of winter combat.

headline: Food for Partying
abstract: Dips, finger food and potluck favorites for the holiday season ahead.
lead_paragraph: I was invited to a collaging party at a friend’s house recently. Crafting of any kind is pretty new to me, but I fell hard for the process of riffling through piles of magazines, old picture books, discarded catalogs and stacks of textured, printed papers. My contribution was a bunch of pressed autumn leaves and — no surprise — some snacks and beverages to sustain us while we snipped and chatted.

headline: Ant Milk: It Does a Colony Good
abstract: Everything in the ant hill seems to need the liquid secretions from members of the colony that are in their pupal stage.
lead_paragraph: Orli Snir, a biologist at the Rockefeller University in New York, couldn’t keep her ants alive. She had plucked pupae from a colony of clonal raider ants, where the sesame seed-size offspring that looked like puffed rice cereal were being fussed over by both younger larvae and older adult ants. Then she had isolated each pupa into a tiny, dry test tube. And every time, they drowned.

headline: Physicists Create ‘the Smallest, Crummiest Wormhole You Can Imagine’
abstract: Scientists used a quantum computer to explore the ultimate escape route from a black hole.
lead_paragraph: In an experiment that ticks most of the mystery boxes in modern physics, a group of researchers announced on Wednesday that they had simulated a pair of black holes in a quantum computer and sent a message between them through a shortcut in space-time called a wormhole.

headline: Ashkenazi Jews Have Become More Genetically Similar Over Time
abstract: A new study of skeletons from a cemetery in Germany reveals a hidden history of Jews in the Middle Ages.
lead_paragraph: A study of skeletons unearthed from a medieval Jewish cemetery in Germany has revealed a surprising genetic split among Ashkenazi Jews of the Middle Ages that no longer exists.

headline: Shooting Suspect’s Video Adds to Questions About University’s Investigation
abstract: The University of Virginia senior charged with killing three classmates had appeared in a video with a gun, rapping about murder and his own mental troubles.
lead_paragraph: More than a year before he was charged with shooting and killing three fellow University of Virginia students, Christopher Darnell Jones Jr. appeared in a music video holding a gun and rapping about murder and his own mental troubles.

headline: The Communist Party Is Losing China’s People
abstract: China’s obsession with controlling Covid has exposed the government’s inherent weakness.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The scenes in China in recent days have been electrifying.

headline: Job Openings Ease, but Layoffs Are Little Changed
abstract: Government data for October shows the labor market is still strong, though cooling slightly.
lead_paragraph: Employers continued to pull back in October on the number of jobs they were looking to fill, the latest sign that the labor market is strong but gradually cooling.

headline: What It Really Takes to Breastfeed a Baby
abstract: Spend a day in the life of four mothers feeding, pumping and supplementing their milk with formula.
lead_paragraph: Spend a day in the life of four mothers feeding, pumping and supplementing their milk with formula.

headline: Now Arriving: Yayoi Kusama and Kiki Smith’s Grand Central Madison Mosaics
abstract: Beach scenes, wild turkeys and fantastic abstract forms in glass grace the M.T.A.’s new Long Island Rail Road terminal, with works by other artists.
lead_paragraph: As workers busily finished construction of the brand-new train station Grand Central Madison in November, the artist Kiki Smith was standing in front of her new mosaic “River Light,” an abstracted, blue-and-white depiction of glinting sunshine on the East River.

headline: Zelensky Derides Musk’s Peace Proposal for Ukraine and Russia
abstract: During an interview at The New York Times’ DealBook Summit, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine rebuked Elon Musk’s peace proposal that included ceding territory to Russia.
lead_paragraph: During an interview at The New York Times’ DealBook Summit, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine rebuked Elon Musk’s peace proposal that included ceding territory to Russia.

headline: 2022 World Cup Bracket: The Knockout Stage
abstract: The World Cup will soon reach its knockout stage: win or go home. The teams in the bracket will be updated as the round of 16 matchups are determined in the group stage.
lead_paragraph: The World Cup will soon reach its knockout stage: win or go home. The teams in the bracket will be updated as the round of 16 matchups are determined in the group stage.

headline: Plantar Fasciitis Is a Real Pain
abstract: Tiger Woods announced he has the common foot condition. Here’s what to know about symptoms, treatment and prevention.
lead_paragraph: The pain starts when you wake up — a stab in your heel when you get out of bed, an ache when you put weight on your foot. The condition is persistent and common; according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, at least 10 percent of people get it.

headline: N.Y.U. Putting $1 Billion Into Its Engineering School in Brooklyn
abstract: The university is seeking to improve its ranking among competitors and raise New York City’s profile in the technology sector.
lead_paragraph: New York University will announce Wednesday that it is investing $1 billion in its flagship engineering school in Downtown Brooklyn, in a bid to improve its ranking among competitors and raise New York City’s profile in the technology sector.

headline: Verdict in Trump Organization Trial Could Come Down to 3 Little Words
abstract: What jurors make of the phrase “in behalf of” could decide whether the former president’s namesake company is guilty of tax fraud.
lead_paragraph: Despite all the talk of fancy apartments, free Mercedes-Benzes and cash flowing at Christmastime, the criminal tax fraud trial of Donald J. Trump’s family business could come down to three mundane words: “in behalf of.”

headline: Some Rail Workers, Seeking Sick Days, Say Biden Betrayed Them
abstract: The request for Congress to impose contract terms that several unions had rejected rankled rank-and-file members who had rallied behind the president.
lead_paragraph: As the legislative representative for his local union, Gabe Christenson, a longtime freight railroad conductor, worked hard to help elect Joe Biden president in 2020. “I have shirts from me campaigning — blue-collar Biden shirts,” he said. “I knocked on doors for him for weeks and weeks.”

headline: Wordle Wrap-Up: Nov. 21 to 27
abstract: A recap of the Wordle answers for the past week.
lead_paragraph: Hi Wordlers! Welcome to Wordle Wrap-Up, a reminder of which words were answers this week. For stories, stats and brain teasers, sign up for the Gameplay newsletter. For a daily reminder to play Wordle, sign up for reminders.

headline: November News Quiz for Students: Climate Agreement, Taylor Swift, World Cup
abstract: Have you been paying attention to the news in November? See how many of these questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to the news in November? See how many of these questions you can get right.

headline: Moving Mentally Ill People Off the Streets of New York
abstract: Readers respond to Mayor Eric Adams’s plan. Also: Advice for President Biden; blaming Republicans; guns in public; many kinds of love.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In a Show of Unity, House Democrats Elect Hakeem Jeffries Minority Leader
abstract: A new trio, including Representatives Katherine Clark of Massachusetts as No. 2 and Pete Aguilar of California as No. 3 will take the reins in January, replacing Speaker Nancy Pelosi and her team.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats on Wednesday elected new leaders to take the mantle from the three octogenarians who have led them for two decades, ushering in a long-awaited generational change that, for the first time in the history of either party or chamber in Congress, installed a trio of top leaders that includes no white men.

headline: Layoffs Hit CNN as Cost-Cutting Pressure Mounts
abstract: Chris Licht, the network’s chairman, said that the company would be notifying affected employees later this week.
lead_paragraph: CNN on Wednesday began a long-awaited series of job cuts, as the network’s parent company looks to reduce spending amid pressure from investors.

headline: 4 Homemade Food Gifts They’ll Love (and So Will Your Wallet)
abstract: Hot cocoa mix, festive popcorn tins, saltine bark and batched manhattans: these recipes make the best holiday presents.
lead_paragraph: Of all the holiday gifts I’ve been lucky enough to receive, it’s the tasty homemade ones that stay in my memory. There were the shelf-stable bottles of batched cocktails ready for a quick stir with ice, the cookie boxes with gingerbread galore, the pleasingly sticky brittles and toffees, and all the festive chocolate bark.

headline: Does Broadway Need Another ‘Romeo and Juliet’ Musical? Pat Benatar Says Yes.
abstract: After competing ideas and a cease-and-desist order, “Invincible — The Musical” arrives onstage. Just don’t call it a jukebox musical.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Romeo, devastated and bereft, gazed over Juliet’s lifeless body, lying atop a table in a rehearsal studio at the Wallis Annenberg Center for the Performing Arts here. But rather than offer a farewell soliloquy before taking his own life, in this adaptation of the Shakespeare play, Romeo broke into song, the lyrics familiar to any rock music fan who grew up in 1980s.

headline: BlackRock C.E.O. Discusses FTX Crypto Exchange Collapse
abstract: Larry Fink, the chief executive of BlackRock, said that his company invested $24 million in FTX, and hinted that his own firm may have been given faulty information.
lead_paragraph: Larry Fink, the chief executive of BlackRock, said that his company invested $24 million in FTX, and hinted that his own firm may have been given faulty information.

headline: A Resonant Topic in Georgia’s Senate Runoff: Insulin Prices
abstract: The cost of insulin is nowhere near as contentious as just about everything else raised in the runoff, but in a state with a high diabetes rate, it has proved a powerful issue.
lead_paragraph: MACON, Ga. — The runoff election for Senate in Georgia has not lacked for drama, with a fresh round of attack ads, a fevered get-out-the-vote effort and both sides casting the outcome as pivotal for the nation’s future even though control of the chamber is no longer at stake.

headline: Hiroshi Miyamura, Given Medal of Honor in Korean War, Dies at 97
abstract: He was the first living Japanese American to receive the country’s highest military award for valor.
lead_paragraph: Hiroshi Miyamura, a former Army corporal who killed at least 50 Chinese Communist troops in a firefight near Seoul during the Korean War before being taken prisoner, and who, while captive, became the first living Japanese American to be awarded the Medal of Honor, died on Tuesday at his home in Phoenix. He was 97.

headline: Andy Jassy says Amazon will allow the antisemitic film that Kyrie Irving tweeted to remain on sale for now.
abstract: He said the company has a panel that reviews content that might be objectionable, but that cases were not always “straightforward.”
lead_paragraph: Appearing at the DealBook Summit on Wednesday, Amazon’s chief executive, Andy Jassy, said the e-commerce giant had no immediate plans to remove — or add a disclaimer — to the antisemitic film that the Brooklyn Nets guard Kyrie Irving drew attention to on the Amazon website last month.

headline: In Georgia, Walker’s Pace in the Finish Worries Republican Allies
abstract: The Senate candidate’s performance in the final days of the runoff campaign has Republicans airing frustrations. But no one is counting him out yet.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Herschel Walker was being swamped by negative television ads. His Democratic opponents were preparing to flood the polls for early voting as soon as doors opened. After being hit by fresh allegations of carpetbagging, he was left with just over a week to make his final appeals to voters in the runoff for Georgia’s Senate seat.

headline: Powell says that rates will rise more and remain high ‘for some time.’
abstract: The Federal Reserve chair said the central bank will keep lifting rates to control price increases, and played down a recent cooling in inflation.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said the central bank could slow its interest rate increases at its meeting next month — even as he emphasized that policymakers have more work to do to ensure that rapid price inflation will return to normal.

headline: Ben Affleck Says His New Movie Studio Will Be ‘Radically Different’
abstract: The Hollywood star will be Artists Equity’s chief executive while his longtime acting partner, Matt Damon, will be its chief creative officer.
lead_paragraph: The Hollywood star will be Artists Equity’s chief executive while his longtime acting partner, Matt Damon, will be its chief creative officer.

headline: Amazon Will Challenge Staten Island Union Election, C.E.O. Says
abstract: Speaking at The New York Times’ DealBook summit, Andy Jassy said that Amazon’s legal fight over a union election in Staten Island could end up in federal courts.
lead_paragraph: Speaking at The New York Times’ DealBook summit, Andy Jassy said that Amazon’s legal fight over a union election in Staten Island could end up in federal courts.

headline: Could Theatrical Movies Shut Out Streamers for the Top Oscars?
abstract: A year after Apple’s historic best-picture win, the lead categories could be filled entirely by big-screen films. But don’t call it a comeback just yet.
lead_paragraph: One of the last firewalls in film fell earlier this year, when Apple TV+ became the first streaming service to win the best picture Oscar for its heartwarmer “CODA.”

headline: 17 Public Employees Charged in Schemes to Steal Covid Relief Funds
abstract: They include New York City Police Department workers and a jail official. The phony loan applications added up to more than $1.5 million, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A New York City correction official, eight Police Department employees and eight other current and former city and state workers have been charged in schemes to defraud Covid relief programs that were intended to provide money to struggling business owners, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: Deaths From Substance Abuse Rose Sharply Among Older Americans in 2020
abstract: In the pandemic’s first year, death rates linked to alcohol and drugs climbed among seniors as lockdowns and isolation spread.
lead_paragraph: Deaths due to substance abuse, particularly of alcohol and opioids, rose sharply among older Americans in 2020, the first year of the coronavirus pandemic, as lockdowns disrupted routines and isolation and fear spread, federal health researchers reported on Wednesday.

headline: What the T Magazine Editors Are Eyeing This Holiday Season
abstract: Whimsical signet rings, sculptural menorahs, rocklike crayons — and more gifts we’re coveting this year.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. For this week and the next, we’ve turned it into a holiday gift guide, with recommendations from T staffers on what we want for ourselves this season, as well as the gifts we’re thinking of giving our friends and loved ones. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. You can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Why This World Cup Is Dogged by Corruption Allegations
abstract: FIFA’s system allegedly fostered bribery, but despite years of investigations and arrests it’s still in place.
lead_paragraph: Every World Cup has tournament-defining moments that fans will remember in the same way they remember meeting the love of their life. Or the Kennedy assassination.

headline: South Africa’s President, Cyril Ramaphosa, Faces Impeachment
abstract: An independent panel found evidence that Mr. Ramaphosa, who is accused of a cover-up involving millions of dollars in cash, may have engaged in misconduct.

headline: New York Police Name a Chief Who Has Faced Internal Discipline
abstract: Jeffrey Maddrey will be the acting chief of department. He was punished after an incident with a colleague, who later sued him for harassment.
lead_paragraph: The head of the New York City Police Department on Wednesday named a chief to the agency’s highest uniformed rank despite past disciplinary charges and drawn-out litigation dating back years.

headline: Outcome in Oath Keepers Trial Could Hold Lessons for Coming Jan. 6 Cases
abstract: The conviction of Stewart Rhodes for sedition was a signal victory for the Justice Department, but prosecutors still face challenges as they prepare for the trials of other far-right figures.
lead_paragraph: When a jury convicted the leader of the Oath Keepers militia of sedition charges on Tuesday, it was a signal victory for the Justice Department, one that served to ratify the government’s central claim in the case.

headline: Review: Complexions Returns With New Dances but Not New Moves
abstract: The contemporary ballet company, whose chief choreographer is Dwight Rhoden, presented dances at the Joyce Theater that felt like more of the same.
lead_paragraph: To return to something after many years and find it exactly as remembered can be comforting. When I attended Complexions Contemporary Ballet at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, more than a decade had passed since I had last seen the company. I found little evidence of change, which wasn’t what I had hoped.

headline: NATO Nations Grow More Receptive to U.S. Pleas to Confront China
abstract: After the pain of an energy crisis brought on by the Ukraine war, Europe is keen to reduce its strategic vulnerabilities to China, not to speak of other authoritarian governments.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — For years now, the United States has been trying to pivot its foreign policy focus to Asia, to face a potential threat from a more powerful China, and to get its NATO and European allies to take the challenge posed by the Chinese Communist Party more seriously.

headline: San Francisco Considers Allowing Use of Deadly Robots by Police
abstract: The Police Department said robots would use deadly force only “in extreme circumstances.” Opponents said the policy could lead to more police violence.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco police could use robots to deploy lethal force under a policy advanced by city supervisors on Tuesday that thrust the city into the forefront of a national debate about the use of weaponized robots in American cities.

headline: Scooter Driver Who Struck and Killed Actress Gets Up to 3 Years
abstract: Brian Boyd, who fatally hit Lisa Banes on a Manhattan crosswalk, tried to explain his actions in court, angering the judge. “I did beep my horn,” he said.
lead_paragraph: A State Supreme Court judge on Wednesday sentenced a scooter driver to as much as three years in prison for fatally hitting an actress, Lisa Banes, after the man tried to avoid blame for the accident following an earlier admission of guilt.
